SECTION: PUBLICATIONS


LENGTH: 823 words


ABDULLAHI AHMED AN-NACIM and Francis M. DENG, eds., Human Rights Africa: Cross Cultural Perspectives. Washington: The Brookings Institution (1775 Massachusetts Avenue, N.W., Washington, DC 20036), 1990. $16.95 (paper). 399 pp.

2 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 23, 1992


THE HEAT IS ON


LENGTH: 427 words


Pressures are building on Liberian rebel leader Charles Taylor tothe fighting that flared between his National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) and the multi-national West African peacekeeping force (Ecomog) in mid-October. U.S. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Leonard Robinson says that the United States holds Taylor "personally responsible" for the latest outbreak of fighting in the West African nation, founded by freed American slaves in 1847.

International observers say Taylor's forces attacked the country's capital, Monrovia, and the Ecomog troops that guard it. But, Taylor insists that his fighters are simply defending themselves and the people of Liberia from unwarranted foreign aggression. He maintains that the actions of the NPFL have been justified and has asked for UN intervention to "halt the killing of Liberians" by Ecomog soldiers. 

International attention to the fighting in Liberia soared after reports of the killing of five American nuns in NPFL-controlled territories. Robinson says he holds Taylor responsible for the nuns' deaths, describing rebel fighters as "undisciplined' and "drug-crazed." Members of a Roman Catholic order have issued pleas for the return of the nuns' bodies for burial. Sister Margaret Mary Kopish testified before the House subcommittee on Africa, describing eyewitness reports of the nun's killings by Taylor's soldiers.

The rebel leader denies any involvement in the murders and invited U.S. officials to conduct an impartial investigation into the matter. Taylor promised that if his troops were found responsible for any wrongdoing, they would be held accountable, and the international community would be made aware of their punishment.

The UN Security Council has imposed an arms embargo, in an effort tohalt Taylor's advance and return control of the country to Ecomog forces and interim President Amos Sawyer. Neighboring Cote d'Ivoire and Burkina Faso have been accused of illegally supplying Taylor with weapons, although both nations say they are observing the boycott. The United Nations also has agreed to send a special representative to investigate the possibility of future peace talks in this war-ravaged country.


LOAD-DATE: December 1, 1992


LANGUAGE: English

3 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 23, 1992


WHEN IT RAINS IT POURS


LENGTH: 307 words


For over two weeks, rain has fallen in drought stricken Zimbabwe,bringing hopes for an end to the worst drought in 100 years across southern Africa. Over 18 million people in the region's ten nations are in danger of starvation due to the destruction of food crops by drought and the general lack of water. 

In some areas of the country, including the capital, Harare, up to three inches of rain have fallen.

Although southern Africans have being waiting anxiously for the rains,there have been some unfortunate and unanticipated side effects of the sudden showers. Many farmers have reported that the deluge of rain has washed out crops that had just been planted. At least a dozen people have been killed by lightning or trapped under mud squatter shacks that have collapsed. The rains have even interrupted Zimbabwe's popular sporting events, postponing international cricket matches.

Food aid shipments also were interrupted, when rains swept away bridges and made roads impassable. About ten million Zimbabweans currently receive food aid from international donors. Leaders from southern African nations have appealed to the United Nations for increased attention to the region's increasingly perilous situation. Southern Africa has been competing for food aid with the famine struck nations of the Horn of Africa; in the Horn, some 23 million people are threatened by famine. At least 40 million people are suffering from hunger in Eastern and Southern Africa.


LOAD-DATE: December 1, 1992


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November 23, 1992


TAKE THAT!


LENGTH: 227 words


In mid-November, Zaire's pro-democracy national conference approvdraft constitution which, if ratified, will change the nation's name and shift power from President Mobutu Sese Seko to an elected Prime Minister. The name of the Central African country would become the Federal Republic of Congo much like its neighbor, the Republic of Congo. Under the draft, the president would serve as a largely ceremonial figure, and the country would be governed by a Prime Minister and an elected multi-party parliament.

Mobutu threatened to halt the democracy conference last August when a similar proposal was made. His supporters boycotted the gathering, and the president has suggested that his loyalists might issue an alternative proposal for the new constitution.

It was Mobutu who changed the country's name from Congo to Zaire afterhe seized power in a 1965 coup. Although the president yielded to protestors demanding a multi-party system two years ago, critics claim that he has engineered numerous delays in the transition to democracy. No date for a national referendum on the new constitution has been set.


LOAD-DATE: December 1, 1992


LANGUAGE: English

5 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 23, 1992


HOME SWEET HOME?


LENGTH: 334 words


Six weeks after President Joaquim Chissano's government and the rMozambique National Resistance Movement (Renamo) signed a peace accord ending 16 years of civil war, the people of the former Portuguese colony are hopeful that peace has finally come to stay. After nearly two years of talks, a truce has allowed Renamo forces to retain control of large areas of central Mozambique, unchallenged by government forces. For the first time since 1982, a passenger bus has traveled into Renamo's former main base at Gorongosa without a military escort.

Despite the fact that humanitarian aid now is reaching remote areas, many Mozambicans are leaving their isolated villages and migrating toward the towns. Thousands of refugees who fled to nearby countries are returning to Mozambique.

Food relief workers are concerned that current food supplies are not sufficient to deal with the sharp increase in demand. Meetings are being held throughout the country to improve communication between government district managers and Renamo regional commanders and to discuss ways of increasing humanitarian assistance.

International observers are concerned that the eruption of violence inAngola, another former Portuguese colony, following a 16-month cease-fire, could undermine peace efforts in Mozambique. The United Nations special envoy to Mozambique, Aldo Ajello, has requested a UN peacekeeping force to join the more than 82,000 government and Renamo troops already under UN supervision. Currently, the world body has assigned 25 monitors and 20 soldiers to aid in the southern African country's transition process.


LOAD-DATE: December 1, 1992


LANGUAGE: English

6 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 23, 1992


MANDELA'S LITTLE BROWN BOOK


LENGTH: 387 words


The American publishing company, Little Brown, is having major problems capitalizing on what it had hoped would be the publishing coup of the decade: the autobiography of South Africa's Nelson Mandela.

Little Brown outbid the rest of the publishing world in the scramble for Mandela's story in May 1990, three months after his release from prison. Although the company refused to confirm the figure, it is believed to have paid the ANC president about $3 million. 

The book had been due for publication this year, but the company has now signed a ghost-writing deal with an American journalist in an embarrassed attempt to get the project completed by the end of 1993.

Initially there were moves to get Nobel laureate Nadine Gordimer to write the book, but this idea was shot down -- reportedly by some in the ANC who are said to have objected to a white South African doing the job, no matter what her international standing. The project was then handed over to Professor Es'Kia "Seke" Mphahlele, the 72-year-old South African writer, who has since abandoned the attempt.

Now Richard Stengel, a contributing editor at Time magazine and the author of a previous work of non-fiction on South Africa, has signed a contract to complete the book. Again details of the deal are secret, but he is believed to have been paid in the region of $300,000 -- a sum which reflects the growing anxiety of Little Brown to recover their original investment.

Stengel has put on hold a definitive social history of the American sneaker, or casual shoe, while he completes the Mandela project. He had to be "cleared" by the ANC as a suitable author before Little Brown could sign him up.

Part of the problem with the project is that Mandela's prison diaries,which were to have been the basis of the book, apparently end in the 1960s, leaving the last quarter century of his life uncovered.

-- David Beresford


LOAD-DATE: December 1, 1992


LANGUAGE: English

7 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 23, 1992


BUDGET CUTTERS STALK
 
HUNGER COMMITTEE


LENGTH: 307 words


Eighty-five members of Congress have proposed "budget-saving measthat include the elimination of the House Select Committee on Hunger. The eight-year-old committee was formed to address domestic and international humanitarian issues. 

Led by the late Mickey Leland from 1984 until his death in 1989, the bipartisan committee was labeled the "conscience of Congress" by the New York Times. This year, chaired by Congressman Tony Hall (D-OH), the committee has worked to focus U.S. attention on the plight of starving Somalis and organized the first humanitarian summit among the nations of the Horn of Africa.

The proposal that would eliminate the hunger committee has prompted several advocacy groups to actively lobby Congress for the committee's survival.

InterAction, a broadly based coalition of 143 private and voluntary organizations working in international development, urged its members to write letters supporting the committee to their state representatives before the reform proposal comes to a vote during the 103rd session of Congress. InterAction argues that the committee does important work on a budget less than that of one congressional office.

For the last four years, the Coalition for a Select Committee on Hunger has worked to keep the hunger committee alive. The coalition, which unites over 400 organizations, such as the Salvation Army, the Children's Defense Fund and Unicef, says that the initiatives undertaken by the hunger committee have been effective in saving millions of lives.


LOAD-DATE: December 1, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


8 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 23, 1992


THE PARTY'S OVER


SECTION: DATELINE: AFRICA


LENGTH: 347 words


The African National Congress has called on the United Nations toto ensure that free elections for an interim government take place in South Africa by the end of 1993.

Addressing a mid-November General Assembly session on apartheid, ThaboMbeki, the ANC international affairs director, directed the world body's attention to a recent comment by President F.W. de Klerk implying that his National Party government would still be in place after 1995. Mbeki urged the UN to send Pretoria an "unequivocal message" that the world community will not tolerate government attempts to hold onto power.

The ANC official cited new revelations pointing to government complicity in fomenting violence in black townships. He asked for UN help in curbing covert police and army activity, and in "disarming and confining to barracks all special forces."

Mbeki said the election of an interim government and an assembly charged with writing a new South African constitution would mark a historic turning point. For the first time in 44 years, he said, the United Nations could take the issue of apartheid off its agenda and replace it with an item on the "democratic transformation of South Africa."

Mbeki and a score of other top ANC leaders were in New York for a conference sponsored by anti-apartheid organizations to discuss how to support South Africa's transition to majority rule. Nearly 1,000 people attended a series of plenaries and workshop sessions at Riverside Church on topics such as education, health, housing, legal rights and foreign investment in the post-apartheid era.


LOAD-DATE: December 1, 1992


LANGUAGE: English

9 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 23, 1992


GHANA ELECTION OBSERVERS ARE PART OF A TREND


BYLINE: David Zaring for Africa News Service


LENGTH: 1067 words


DATELINE: Accra, Ghana


"We went to one voting station where everything seemed to be goinsmoothly, except that the polling booth had been placed upside down," says Ed Brown, election observer for the Carter Center of Emory University, and former executive director of Atlanta's Voter Education Project. When Brown's team pointed out the inversion, an official for Ghana's presidential election told them in no uncertain terms that the booth was fine the way it was, and that officials didn't want to appear to invalidate the ballots of those who had voted earlier by making changes.

Voting observation can be a series of vignettes like Brown's -- gleanings from small samples of balloting stations from which broad generalizations about the nature of an election must be made. But observer missions are becoming an increasingly important medium for Western involvement in Africa. 

For Ghana's November 3 presidential vote -- the country's first in 13 years -- Canada, the European Community, the Commonwealth of Nations and Atlanta's Carter Center sent delegations who worked with Ghanaian monitors and volunteers from local diplomatic missions to observe the balloting.

"It's becoming routine to send international observers to elections, and yet for many African countries, the election process itself is new enough to make the assistance we provide valuable," says Paul McDermott, director of the Carter Center's Liberia Office.

Richard Joseph, head of the center's African Governance Program, argues that such observer missions can be a particularly useful allocation of development aid. "Elections really are a way of getting governments that are unable to make progress in, say, economic and social areas, to tackle the things that are holding them back within their political systems," he says.

Observer missions can range in size from Canada's four-person team, which included three provincial election officials and a Montreal lawyer, to the larger delegations fielded by the Carter Center and the Commonwealth. The Center flew in an 18-member delegation from the United States, assembled a further six-person secretariat, and helped to train a group of 150 local observers. The U.S. Agency for International Development largely funded the Carter Center mission, which included professors, social workers and elected officials. The Ghana mission is the largest yet from an organization that is making election observation one of its major interests. "We've started a trajectory of increasing involvement in the continent," says Joseph.

The Commonwealth (formerly known as the British Commonwealth) sent a team of 15 politicians and bureaucrats, who were assisted by a nine-member group from the Commonwealth Secretariat. "We are not supervising the elections and are not in a position to ensure that things go well in every polling station," says Sir Ellis Clarks, former president of Trinidad and Tobago and leader of the delegation.

Given the large number of polling places and the short amount of time to visit them, election monitoring has become as much a matter of presence as of observation. "We are here to let everyone know -- the parties, the government, the electoral officials and the international community -- that there is an impartial body observing the scene, one that will state whether it felt that the elections were free and fair," Joseph told Ghanaians.

Some of the observers describe that task, which posted one foreign observer for every 200,000 or so Ghanaians, as a particularly challenging one. "Election observation is a tough job. While it's easy to see if there's a long line at the polling station, it's not so easy to see if people are being subtly intimidated or wrongly turned away," says Carter Center observer Bob Wilson, a former district attorney in Georgia.

The Commonwealth statement on the elections expressed concern with the"shortcomings apparent to us as we observed proceedings in all the regions. In the main, these centered on the admitted imperfections of the voters roll and the organization and conduct of some polling stations." Nonetheless, Sir Ellis ultimately pronounced the elections to be "free and fair, and free from fear," while the Carter Center observers decided that the process was not so much rigged as beset by logistical difficulties.

"Americans, for example, have the facilities to identify anyone from abirth certificate, a driver's license or even social security, credit card, banking and insurance information. For us, identification for elections is easy, but Ghanaians just don't have all of those records," says Wilson.

Many observers marveled at the long waits and the hardships Ghanaians were willing to endure in order to cast their vote. Sir Ellis commented on the long lines at the polling booths, lines that McDermott compared with those he saw at a Grateful Dead concert. Carter Center observer Donald Rothschild, a visiting Africanist at the Brookings Institution, says that he was struck "by those people waiting in the hot sun. They really wanted to participate in the democratic process."

Some veteran observers were particularly affected by the elections in Ghana, with its old slaving forts and legacy of Kwame Nkrumah's Pan-Africanism. "This place has tremendous significance and symbolism attached to it," Ed Brown says. "It is one of the historical touchstones for black people all over the world. I am especially happy to be in this place to help it reclaim the great potential it has and the great expectation we have for it." *


LOAD-DATE: December 1, 1992


LANGUAGE: English

10 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 23, 1992


AFRICA VOTES


BYLINE: Cindy Shiner * Africa News Service


SECTION: AN AFRICA NEWS SPECIAL REPORT


LENGTH: 1107 words


DATELINE: Abidjan, Cote d'Ivoire


Africans are voting in record numbers, in a pro-democracy push thhas already forced more than two dozen authoritarian leaders to share power or leave office. When Pascal Lissouba was elected in Congo last August, he became the sixth African opposition leader in two years to win a presidential vote.

Presidential, legislative and local balloting is taking place in country after country across the continent in what has been described as Africa's second independence, three decades after the rupture from European colonial rule.

Like Africa's first break with the past, these latest transitions havenot been easy. Sometimes they have fallen short of popular dreams; other times they have become bloody. But the first fragile democracy campaigns have spread, inspiring the entire continent and giving Africans the hope of futures where choice and tolerance are routine elements of political life. 

Africans are finding that pressing for elections -- or even holding them -- is only one battle in a long campaign for democracy.Current developments in West Africa highlight the challenges.

In Nigeria, President Ibrahim Babangida is imploring his citizenry to retain confidence in the democratic process, despite his announcement of a delay in presidential elections from December until next June. The rescheduling had been expected, since the ruling military council decided in October to set aside the results of September primaries. Those countrywide presidential votes have been criticized widely as fraudulent, although legislators elected in July balloting will take their seats in January.

Many Nigerians blame Babangida's regime for the problems in the transition process. The military leaders have micro-managed electoral arrangements -- establishing two political parties and banning all others, placing restrictions on candidates, and redrawing state borders.

The decision to delay the handover to a civilian president has been criticized by a prominent former military leader, General Olusegun Obasanjo, who supervised the country's last transfer from a military to an elected civilian government in 1979. "Principle has been abandoned for expediency," Obasanjo said in a nine-page letter to Baban-gida, his former aide. "The result is the crisis we now face," the former head of state said.

Babangida has disqualified the 73 candidates who ran in September primaries, and he has dismissed the leaders of both political parties. A new process for selecting candidates has been devised focusing on the country's 31 states. Inauguration of an elected civilian president is now set for August 29, 1993.

Meanwhile, in Ghana the first presidential election in 13 years has precipitated a major political crisis. Albert Adu Boahen, a history professor who offered himself as an alternate to the country's socialist and military-led past, hoping to do well enough in the first round of voting to force a runoff with Flt. Lt. Jerry Rawlings, Ghana's military ruler for the past 11 years. But Rawlings shocked many Ghanaian intellectuals by soundly beating his four opposition contenders with 58% of the vote, compared to Adu Boahen's 30%.

Rawlings introduced economic reforms that have made his country popular with Western lending institutions. While the economic austerity program has sometimes pinched pocketbooks, especially in urban areas, the government also pursued policies to deliver services to destitute, long-neglected rural areas.

Under his leadership, Ghana has enjoyed five percent growth and inflation has dropped from 100% to 15%.

"The cocoa farmer in the village sees that he has roads where he didn't have roads ten years ago, that he has electricity where he didn't have electricity ten years ago," says K. Afari-Gyan, an official with the Interim National Electoral Commission. "Talk of human rights (by opposition candidates) holds no meaning" for ordinary Ghanaians, he says

Opposition leaders claim the vote was rigged -- although internationalobservers judged it fair despite some disorganization -- and have announced a boycott of December parliamentary polls. A transition to civilian rule is scheduled for January.

The planned boycott has led to heightened tensions and outbreaks of politically connected violence. The worst incident was a clash between contending groups in the northern provincial city of Tamale in mid-November, when some 40 people were wounded by gunshots and arrows.

The opposition could reconsider its boycott stance if Rawlings indicates a willingness to adopt some of the measures the parties are advocating, including a new voters registry.

The outcome of national voting in Cameroon is even more controversial than in Ghana. Opposition leaders claim that the government of President Paul Biya rigged the October 11 vote, and international observers have agreed that the elections were fraught with irregularities.

Biya has imposed a state of emergency on the Northwest province, the opposition's stronghold, following post-election violence that left at least ten people dead. Opposition leader John Fru Ndi, Biya's leading challenger, was placed under house arrest.

Fru Ndi's party has petitioned the Cameroon Supreme Court to annul theelection results, although the court ruled earlier that it could take no action or reports of irregularities. South African Archbishop Desmond Tutu, a Nobel Peace Prize laureate, recently visited Cameroon for talks with the president and Fru Ndi, in an effort to mediate the crisis. *

-- with files from Kwame Karikari in Accra


LOAD-DATE: December 1, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


11 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 23, 1992


AFRICA'S NEW GOVERNMENTS BEAR THEIR PEOPLES' HOPES


LENGTH: 1227 words


Address by Zambian President Frederick J.T. Chiluba, accepting thHoughton Star Crystal Annual Achievement Award of the African-American Institute in New York on November 12. Chiluba, a trade union leader, was elected a year ago.

The 1960s probably represent Africa's "Golden Decade." All over Africathe people danced as one colonial power after another lost its hold on African colonies. After so many years of very sluggish economic growth in the colonial era, the people of Africa now had an opportunity to shape their own destiny. 

In that Golden Decade, few African countries needed food aid from outside. Much of Africa was able to feed itself, and in some instances, even surplus food for export could be realized. Our countries' balance of payment profiles were consistently positive. Our foreign currency reserves were reasonable and our foreign debt negligible.

It was during the decade of the 1970s that the sad story of Africa began to unfold. Something went wrong along the way. The promise of the 1960s was slowly turning into a nightmare.

Governments presiding over multiparty democracies soon enough convinced themselves of the need to become one-party collectives. Other political parties were proscribed; dissenting views became treasonable. Private ownership of property was proscribed, and large sections of the economy were placed under government control.

For the next two decades, Africa was to fall under the spell of one-party dictatorships. In their (own) honor, most of our African politicians built sky-high political monuments, and the citizens were reduced to cheering crowds bent on bare knees and feet, singing praises to their leaders.

Civil wars, military insurrections and coups d'etat traversed almost the entire face of the continent. It became fashionable to plant land mines but not grain with which to feed the people. African governments raised their prison walls and behind them hid the brains and hands needed to take Africa out of its misery.

This is the Africa of the 1970s. If the seventies and eighties represent the decades of the African dictatorships, the nineties will in my view be the decade of democracy and freedom in Africa. Africa is now realizing that one-party dictatorships, with their propensity for economic mismanagement, command economic policies and institutionalized inefficiency resulted in economic stagnation.

The future is certainly promising. The people of Africa now demand governments that will demonstrate a commitment to their people. They demand governments that will have faith in the wisdom of the citizens. They want governments that will implement policies with achievable goals. They want governments that will treat their citizens as the official arbiters of the success or failure of policy.

My government is part of the new African dream. We are endeavoring to create conditions that will encourage efficiency in the political and economic life of our people. We are implementing economic policies that will turn the economy from a perpetual state of stagnation to one of growth. We have removed subsidies and price controls in order to allow market forces to take control of the economy. We believe, of the many things a government can legitimately do, the running of business is not one of them.

We have worked out attractive investment terms for both local and foreign investors that will guarantee private individuals a real stake in the economy of the country.

Our efforts are bearing fruits. Within the one year we have been in office, we have seen a gradual turnaround in the performance of the economy. When we assumed office in October 1991, the rate of inflation was 400% on an annualized basis. One year later, with the policies we have implemented, inflation has come down to 80% per annum.

We have gone a long way toward our objective to balance the budget within two years of assuming office. This is the goal we intend to achieve. Our efforts, as you know, have been considerably slowed down by the worst drought in living memory that has swept the southern Africa subcontinent.

This year alone, Zambia requires $320 million worth of grain to cover the shortfall created by the drought. We faced a major catastrophe. We are grateful to many of our friends in the international community who responded with uncharacteristic speed to our plea for assistance.

Many nations, notably the United States of America, acted swiftly in mobilizing drought relief for my country. We are grateful to the American people. We are grateful to the American government.

Zambia is not yet out of the woods. Zambia almost entirely relies on hydropower. Lower levels in our power-generating rivers have forced us to introduce power rationing that has affected industrial production and growth. Our traditional water sources have dried up. Humans and livestock have to travel long distances to sources of drinking water. For us, drought has been devastating.

While we know that the responsibility to develop Zambia and improve the conditions of living of our people lies squarely on the Zambian people themselves, we are aware that there are factors crucial to the success of this process over which we have no control.

Indeed, no economy in the world can boast of total independence. We need the active and meaningful support of the international community while we slowly marshal internal resources for productive investment to enable sustainable growth and greater self-sufficiency.

Africa should be assisted to develop, not as an act of international benevolence, but because any growth in the African economy will impact positively on the global economy. The more African economies grow, the less external aid they will require and the bigger the market they will provide to the international economy.

Africa's fragile democracy will have to deliver economically. Our people correctly link the efficacy of any government system to its ability to provide food, shelter and clothing. If democracy is to grow in Africa, African economies must be supported to achieve sustainable economic growth. *


LOAD-DATE: December 1, 1992


LANGUAGE: English

12 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 23, 1992


OUR LEGACY MUST BE STABILITY


SECTION: DOSSIER:


LENGTH: 1067 words


Address to the nation by Nigerian President Ibrahim Babangida on November 17, announcing that the Armed Forces Ruling Council (AFRC) had decided to postpone the handover to a civilian governement.

The commitment of this administration to January 2, 1993 as the date of handing over to an elected president is one which this administration has pursued diligently. Specifically, it is a date which members of the armed forces and I are committed to for the handing over of power to an elected president. 

Fellow Nigerians, it is now no longer news that the events which preceded the decision to postpone elections constitute a setback to the transition program and pose a serious dilemma to me, not only as a person, but also as a general and officer of the Nigerian Army and president, commander-in-chief of the armed forces of Nigeria. Other bodies involved in the transition are not spared this dilemma -- the military as the mid-wife of the transition program; the entire government whose one arm -- the legislature -- is already constituted and awaiting to be inaugurated by the second elective arm to serve as a complement to it; and other agencies of government charged with the major responsibilities of the transition program. No less in dilemma are our countrymen and women who look forward to that date, January 2, 1993, when our country was to commence the full stage of the transition program and join other democratic nations around the world! This dilemma and problems have raised the single most critical issue of governance, namely: credibility.

Fellow citizens, let us reflect a little while on the crisis we have had to face since 1985. The administration has had to cope with two attempted coups -- one of which but for Allah's protection, could have taken many lives and caused disintegration of our dear country, all in the name of wanting to introduce a new social order. Let me also further remind you that this administration has had to face the greatest religious crisis and the greatest communal riots in our history, ostensibly engineered and orchestrated by those who have no faith in the transition program and in the democratic process.

The riots are still fresh in our memories. Seditious publications weremade against this administration and its key actors, with a view to inciting the public against us. But we are fully resolved that we can not abandon our duties. I want to assure you that this administration will not stay a day longer than necessary. We will strive to see the nation out of this circle of despair, fear and despondency. Our country deserves the best. And we will not abandon you unless we are able to install or guarantee the installation of a stable democratic orderI

When this administration came to power, the quest for justice and the need for a balanced federal system had to be faced once and for all 11 additional states and more local government areas. What do we have today? We now have a system of 30 states and 589 local government areas and four area councils of the Federal Capital Territory. You will agree that this is one of the boldest attempts in history. We have now reached the stage in our country where all ethnic groups can now boast of a "home" -- state, local government or ward -- which they can call their own, and which they can use as a launching pad in the politics of national leadership. States and local government areas, and not ethnic or religious groups, can then constitute the correct units of representation.

I want to stress that this administration wants to be remembered as one which had the rarest opportunity to serve our country, and handed over the reins of government in an orderly fashion to an elected visionary president. More importantly, we want to be remembered as those who left behind a stable democratic order where no one is oppressed, and where everyone and every group is guaranteed the freedom to aspire to any political post in the land.

Having considered the necessary political activities that must take place before the presidential elections with the shortest possible time frame assigned to each of these activities, the AFRC has slated the presidential elections for June 12, 1993.

In order to facilitate a speedy and smooth changeover from the military to fully democratized civilian rule the present council of ministers (the cabinet) will be dissolved on January 2, 1993, and in its place a transitional council which shall consist of a chairman and some prominent Nigerians, shall be established. The functions of the transitional council shall include the completion of projects already commended by this administration and ensuring the smooth handing-over process from the present administration to the incoming one. The chairman and members of the transitional council shall not be involved in political activities throughout the transition period , and shall not hold any political appointment of the incoming civilian administration for a period of 12 months from the end of transition. The chairman of the transitional council shall be a civilian who shall preside over the meetings of the transitional council.

Having come this far, we must not now bequeath chaos to our people andleave the nation in disarray. As for credibility, sincerity and good conscience, let it be known that neither I nor my colleagues cherish or harbor any "hidden agenda." Rather, we seek an enduring credibility that will be borne out of a stable and durable republic. That shall forever remain our goal. And we need your support.

Thank you and God bless the Federal Republic of Nigeria. *

13 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 23, 1992


SUDAN'S ATTACK ON WOMEN'S RIGHTS EXPLOITS ISLAM


BYLINE: Fatima Ahmed Ibrahim


LENGTH: 894 words


The Islamic Front, a close ally of the current military governmenSudan, began its attack on women as early as 1954. It was then that the Sudanese Women's Union (SWU) was campaigning for women to be allowed to vote and sit in parliament. The Front responded by launching a fierce attack on this campaign in the Mosques. The women's demands, it declared, violated Islamic principles and were contrary to Sudanese traditions and values.

But when the SWU finally won these rights for women in 1965, the Frontswallowed its opposition. It came begging for the votes of women. 

This contradiction in the Front's stand -- first opposing women's rights and then exploiting these rights after they had been won -- revealed its dishonest use of Islam. It sacrificed what it had described as Islamic principles in order to achieve its political aims.

In 1983, Islamic frontists became formal partners in the dictatorial government of Gen. Gaafar Muhammad Nimeri. Their leader, Hassan El Turabi became Nimeri's deputy. Together they introduced Sharia, or Islamic law, to Sudan.

Women were the first to suffer from these laws. Under the new code, itwas possible for a woman seen in public with a man not from her immediate family to be convicted of adultery, even if she were wearing all her clothes. The maximum penalty for adultery is 80 flogs, a fine of up to 100 Sudanese pounds (about $10) and one year's imprisonment.

The law was abandoned but was followed by another which said all womenhad to wear veils as in Iran, on the grounds that the Sudanese women's traditional dress, the tobe, was not an Islamic dress. According to this new law, women who did not wear veils in public could be flogged. The SWU and other women's organizations campaigned against these new laws with some success. But in November the government issued new decrees restricting women's rights.

Gen. Omar Hassan Ahmad El Bashir, who seized power three years ago, claims that under his Islamic Front-aligned government, women have had greater access to the job market. But women have long been present in the judiciary, the police, the armed forces and other professions.

In fact, when Bashir came to power, women were sacked by the hundreds,including the first female judge, Ihsan Fakhri. The police refused to promote women, such as officer, Asia Adam, on the grounds that women did not have the right to occupy senior positions, despite the fact that they were capable policewomen who deserved promotion.

The question one must ask is this: Is this the true reflection of Islam's attitude to women?

The answer is definitely no. Careful analysis and study of Islam from its original sources -- the Koran and the sayings of the Prophet Muhammad -- demonstrates that Islam does not discriminate against women, nor does it stop them from going out to work or from dealing in politics. It does not favor one sex over the other. Moreover, Islam clearly objects to the practice of polygamy.

It is clear that all the laws that have been enacted in Sudan in the name of Islam are far from being related to Islam. In fact, Islam is being used as a means to achieve certain political aims. Ultra-right-wing parties and organizations are using religion as a means to seize the reins of power in Sudan.

People within such groups are exploiting the high levels of illiteracyin Sudan which leave most people unable to study Islam from its original sources. Extremist groups cheat and exploit the masses in the name of Islam. Their actions amount to a contradiction of Islamic principles.

The taking of power by force in the name of Islam constitutes a clear violation of Islamic principles. God reminded the Prophet Muhammad in the Koran that he had no authority over people. His purpose was to inform them of God's message. God forbade his messenger from exercising any power over people in the name of Islam. Moreover, there is a verse in the Koran which clearly states that people are free to choose to become believers or atheists.

Faith constitutes the spirit and foundation of Islam. This concept of faith is by no means incompatible with democracy. What is incompatible with real democracy and indeed the true principles of Islam, is the determination of extremist groups to use Islam to impose their ideology on Sudan. *

Fatima Ahmed Ibrahim is a founding member of the Sudanese Women's Union and the president of the Women's International Democratic Front. This comment first appeared in the BBC magazine Focus on Africa.


LOAD-DATE: December 1, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


14 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 23, 1992


WOMEN ARE THE SILENT VICTIMS IN LIBERIA


BYLINE: Shana Swiss and Binaifer Nowrojee


SECTION: VIEWPOINT:


LENGTH: 1320 words


Many Americans first heard about Liberia's civil war when the recbrutal murder of five American nuns thrust the West African country into the headlines. The five were murdered in territory occupied by Charles Taylor and his rebel group, the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL), whose attacks on the capital, Monrovia, have ended a tenuous 1990 cease-fire.

That these latest victims were women, all of them either nurses or teachers, reflects the larger but unreported tragedy that Liberian women and children have suffered during the course of the war. Since fighting began in December 1989, thousands of Liberian women and girls have been raped and killed or forced to witness the torture and murder of others. Those who survived now bear physical and psychological injuries that will take years to heal. 

During our visits to Liberia in the past two years, we have heard agonizing stories from Liberian women about the war's effect on their lives. One young woman described how her sister had been tied up, raped and beaten for two days. Today, as a result of nerve damage, both of her hands are paralyzed.

Outside of Monrovia, personnel from a residential school told us that soldiers abducted and raped 25 school girls. A 14-year-old girl was captured and sexually abused for months by a company of soldiers before she escaped, according to a Liberian physician we interviewed.

It is natural to want to believe that these are rare and abnormal events. Yet, rape is an all too common accompaniment to conflict for tens of thousands of women. Reports from around the world tell us that in wartime, rape is a daily part of women's lives.

Just as the reality of rape in war has been largely ignored by the world community, so has its impact. A 1990 study by two physicians in Uganda found that 100% of the women who had been raped by soldiers continued to suffer from the trauma more than four years after the rape occurred. Over half of the women revealed their rape experience for the first time during the interviews.

Because of the stigma attached to rape, shame and secrecy often silence its victims. From our preliminary work in Liberia, we believe that thousands of women and girls in that country have been victims of sexual coercion and rape. And the knowledge of the vast numbers of women who are attacked can numb public response.

It is the victim's and the world's silence, along with the physical and psychological injuries of rape, that make recovery especially difficult. Unresolved rape trauma can severely compromise a woman's ability to participate in family life, the community and society. The consequences of rape in war reverberate for years.

Yet, in Liberia, responses to the problem were being mounted. Before the latest onslaught of violence, several women's organizations were developing programs for victims of rape and other war trauma. The National Women's Commission of Liberia was reaching out to girls who are living on the streets as a consequence of their victimization. Unicef had begun to create materials on the rape trauma of girls and adolescents for use in Liberia's training program for teachers.

But just as these programs were being initiated, intense fighting erupted on the outskirts of Monrovia last month. Even those few efforts at healing have been disrupted as the capital becomes a battleground once more. We have every reason to fear that women are again being raped by soldiers on a daily basis.

A major step toward reestablishing the safety and security of women and girls is to support the regional West African effort to end the fighting. In 1990, the 16-nation Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas) sent a regional peacekeeping force to Monrovia, the first of its kind in Africa. With its force in place, Ecowas negotiated an agreement with the combatants in preparation for national elections. This effort, while flawed by lack of regional consensus about how to implement a cease-fire most effectively, poses the only viable solution to restoring peace in Liberia.

So far, Ecowas has shown commendable tenacity and resourcefulness in its commitment to a peaceful Liberia. It has proven that a regional effort is possible, even when the rest of the world appears indifferent to the tragedy of a spiraling conflict. However, if this regional effort is to succeed, the international community must reverse the chronic neglect it has shown to Liberia's plight in the following ways:

* United Nations Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali should immediately issue a statement calling for restraint on the part of the warring parties until he can appoint a neutral UN envoy to work on implementing the Ecowas peace plan.

* The UN Security Council should pass international sanctions against the warring factions that are disobeying the November 10 cease-fire called by Ecowas.

* The Organization of African Unity (OAU) needs to take similar steps. In July, the OAU resolved to "adopt a mechanism for preventing, managing and resolving conflict." If the OAU is serious about reversing its traditional inaction toward human rights violations in Africa, Liberia should be a starting point.

* The OAU and the UN should work jointly with Liberians toward apolitical solution to the conflict as Ecowas continues its peace-enforcement role.

* The United States should continue to support the Ecowas initiative and take a more active role in urging UN involvement.

Once the hostilities cease, international humanitarian assistance should be earmarked to restore the Liberian programs to assist women and girls victimized during the war. Particular attention should be given to dealing with the widespread and long-term effects of rape in Liberia.

The alternative is grim. Escalating fighting and its attendant atrocities will place the physical integrity and safety of all Liberians, particularly women and children, at great risk. The international community cannot continue to ignore the clear violations of internationally accepted conventions governing the protection of women during war. Rape is specifically prohibited in Protocol II to the Geneva Convention. Yet in this century, soldiers have raped hundreds of thousands of women with impunity. Governments, United Nations bodies, human rights organizations and the world community must begin to expose the record and protect women from this crime. *

Shana Swiss, a physician, is director of the Women's Program of Physicians for Human Rights. Binaifer Nowrojee, an attorney at Harvard Law School, is former Africa Program director of the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights.


LOAD-DATE: December 1, 1992


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November 23, 1992


UNITED NATIONS PUTS SOMALI PAIN ON DISPLAY


LENGTH: 320 words


When the United Nations decided to host an exhibition of photogradepicting the agony of war-ravaged Somalia, organizers had to balance the goal of shocking viewers into responding with the danger of inducing "compassion fatigue."

The large color photos that line the UN visitors' lobby are hard to look at. Stark, devastating images of pain, utter desperation and death, mainly in the faces of wraith-like children, assault the senses.

All parties to the exhibition -- the sponsor Time Warner, the United Nations and the 23 photojournalists whose work is on display -- are keenly aware that the effect may be overwhelming, engendering a sense of helplessness that causes viewers to turn away.

Posted near the images is an acknowledgment of the deep "sympathy and sorrow" the photographs evoke and a strong appeal to turn those sentiments into action. Readily accessible throughout the display are lists of humanitarian groups aiding Somalia, with addresses and brief descriptions of their work. "These pictures, in their own small way," says Time Warner President Gerald M. Levin, "might help move the world community to more concerted action."

The 50 photographs of "Somalia's Cry" will be on display at the UnitedNations through December 3. On December 7 the exhibition will open at New York City's North Gallery, in the Equitable Building at 787 Seventh Avenue (at 52nd Street), where it will remain through the end of the year. Discussions are underway to take "Somalia's Cry" to other U.S. cities and possibly abroad. For more information, call Sandra Drayton at Life magazine, (212) 522-4884. *


LOAD-DATE: December 1, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


16 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 23, 1992


CLINTON ON THE LINE


LENGTH: 840 words


DATELINE: (by Reed Kramer * Africa News Service


Governor Bill Clinton has given the first indication since his election victory that as president he may pay more attention to Africa than his Republican predecessors. Among world leaders with whom he has talked by telephone are three from Africa -- Nigerian President Ibrahim Babangida, African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela and South African President F.W. de Klerk.

With Babangida, Clinton talked briefly about Nigeria's democratic transition and about the West African peacekeeping operation in Liberia, in which Nigeria -- a major oil supplier -- has the leading role. To the two South Africans, the president-elect indicated his desire to see an end to violence and the rapid introduction of majority rule in the country, transition aides say. 

Former President Jimmy Carter, the last Democrat in the White House, who during his term promoted independence for what is now Zimbabwe and boosted anti-apartheid pressures on South Africa, says high-level attention can make a big difference for Africa right now.

"I'd like to see the next administration elevate the consideration given to Africa," he said in a telephone interview from the Carter Center in Atlanta. With so many African countries moving towards democracy, Carter said, the U.S. government should "expedite and promote" both free elections and the necessary follow-up to insure that democracy takes hold.

"In the case of Haiti," he said, "the international community just walked away after the voting. We don't want that to happen in Zambia and Ghana and other places in Africa."

According to Clinton advisors, there are no plans to appoint any transition team members to work specifically on Africa. The foreign policy briefing papers prepared for the Democratic candidate prior to the election include sections on key African issues. The chief authors of those materials were Michael Clough, former senior Africa analyst at the Council on Foreign Relations, and Walter Carrington, a former U.S. ambassador to Senegal who now serves on the staff of Rep. Mervin Dymally, chairman of the House Africa subcommittee.

"I think Clinton's emphasis on democracy during the campaign suggests he will be sensitive to programs of support for Africa," Carrington says. In one major address, Clinton criticized President George Bush for failing to back Africa's "fledgling democratic movements" and for refusing to "distance ourselves from corrupt and dictatorial leaders." Clinton said "the stirrings for democratic reform" in Africa should be actively encouraged.

President Carter says he thinks Clinton may be willing to move away from the Euro-centric foreign policies of the past and "escalate overall consideration" for Africa. "We spend a lot more time being concerned about matters in Croatia than we do about Sudan or Mozambique or Somalia or Liberia. I'd like to see that change."

But Randall Robinson, executive director of the African-American lobbyTransAfrica, says he fears that Clinton is not yet sensitized to African issues. When asked in one of the presidential debates about U.S. response to suffering in Yugoslavia and Somalia, Clinton responded only about Bosnia, Robinson said during an appearance on the NBC "Today" show's recent specials on Africa.

In late August, Clinton issued a statement decrying "months of neglect" of Somalia and urging "strong support" for United Nations relief efforts. "We must respond to Somalia's relief needs now with the same concern and compassion that we demonstrated during the Ethiopian famine in 1984-85 and towards the Kurds during the winter of 1991," the Clinton statement said.

During various subsequent campaign appearances after that Clinton mentioned Somalia as a place where the United States was not doing enough. In Raleigh, North Carolina on October 4, Clinton told a questioner that the administration started doing more about Somalia "after we got on them, but we need to do more."

Clinton also mentioned South Africa in most of his foreign policy pronouncements. "We Americans cannot afford to turn a blind eye to South Africa," he said in a June statement. "The stakes are too high." *


LOAD-DATE: December 1, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


17 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 23, 1992


SUDAN FAMINE ECHOES SOMALIA


BYLINE: Andrew Bilski


LENGTH: 1254 words


DATELINE: Mundri, Sudan


The 200-mile (320-kilometer) trek had taken a grim toll. On the outskirts oMundri, a rebel-held town in war-torn southern Sudan, about 1,000 emaciated Dinka refugees struggled through ten-foot-high elephant grass. Many of the men were naked except for chunky armlets of ele-phant ivory above their elbows and copper bracelets fashioned from spent mortar shells. The women urged the exhausted children on by swatting them with leafy branches. Along the way, the travelers ate grass and leaves to survive, quenching their thirst from muddy puddles. They said that they had fled their homes in Bor, a district on the eastern bank of the Nile River, because of raids by their ethnic cousins, the Nuer. The attacks, they said, had left thousands dead and crops burned to the ground. "I have never seen anything like it," said Koul Malith, one of the Dinka refugees. "If you left Bor now, you would be walking on the bones of the dead." 

Since 1983, the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) has been battling the Muslim-led military government in Khartoum, a war that pits better-developed northern Sudan, mostly Islamic and Arab, against the poor south, comprised largely of African Christians and animists. The struggle contributed to a famine in 1988 that caused an estimated 250,000 deaths. Fifteen months ago, the SPLA split along ethnic lines, turning the Nuer against the Dinka and broadening the already devastating conflict. The Dinka support SPLA founder Col. John Garang, who wants Sudan to be a unified secular state. The Nuer aligned themselves with a splinter faction that calls for the secession of southern Sudan.

Now, relief workers say that the nine-year civil war and its destruction of peasant farms is slowly creating a disaster as great as that in Somalia, where two million people are in danger of starving to death.

The war has forced at least 4.5 million people, or 76% of southern Sudan's population, to flee from their homes in search of food and security in other parts of Sudan or in Ethiopia and Uganda. Hunger and disease have killed a further 500,000, relief workers say. Meanwhile, the distribution of international relief supplies, already hindered by the war between the government and the SPLA, has been further impaired by the factional fighting within the rebel movement. In late September, the relief network suffered a devastating blow when rebels killed three United Nations aid workers and a photojournalist. In response, UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali suspended the world body's Operation Lifeline aid program in the eastern equatorial region of southern Sudan until security is restored.

Aid workers accuse both the Khartoum government and the rebels of obstructing relief efforts. In February, government leaders, citing concern that aid supplies might fall into rebel hands, banned relief flights into southern Sudan by the International Committee of the Red Cross. In May, the government extended

the ban to trucking. UN relief flights are sporadic, depending on the whims of Khartoum officials. To make matters worse, in late September the government announced that it would donate 100,000 tons of surplus sorghum to Somalia and other drought-stricken African countries, ignoring the more than one million southern Sudanese who are at risk of starvation. The message was clear: If Khartoum cannot find a military solution to the war, it will starve the seat of insurrection into submission.

Meanwhile, the SPLA hampers relief efforts by requiring foreign aid workers to acquire visas to enter rebel-held areas and by stealing food earmarked for civilians. The rebels have become progressively less cooperative since May 1991, when their principal supporter, President Mengistu Haile Mariam of neighboring Ethiopia, was overthrown. That deprived the rebels of vital shipments of arms and supplies, leading to the loss of 14 towns to government forces earlier this year. Since June, the Garang faction of the SPLA has been shelling Juba, the largest government-held city in the south. In September, rebels threatened to shoot down any relief planes flying there.

Caught in the middle of the fighting are 300,000 civilians, herded into Juba from surrounding villages by government troops for use as a human shield from SPLA attacks. In mid-August, the government expelled all expatriate missionaries from the city, which is now closed to journalists, leaving no foreigners to witness the human rights abuses there. According to the expelled clergymen, soldiers have executed hundreds of alleged SPLA sympathizers, including a Sudanese employee of the U.S. Agency for International Development.

Soldiers have also mined routes out of Juba to prevent their civilian hostages from leaving. According to London-based Amnesty International, troops have burned down heavily populated areas of the city to create free-fire zones. "As a result," a spokesman for the human rights organization says, "more than 100,000 people are reported to be squatting, many in appalling conditions and without shelter from the seasonal rains." But those rains are a mixed blessing. When the dry season begins in December, fighting is expected to intensify.

Western leaders consider the government of Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan El Bashir to be one of the most repressive in the world. After he took power in a 1989 coup, Bashir and Islamic fundamentalist leader Hassan El Turabi, head of the National Islamic Front, embarked on what they call a holy war against southern infidels. Last year, the government imposed Islamic law on the entire country, punishing thievery with amputation of limbs and the drinking of alcohol with public flogging.

This year, officials ordered southern schools to teach the Koran and Arabic, a language that many Africans in the south do not speak. Bolstered by an infusion of Iranian-supplied arms and Chinese MiG fighter jets, Bashir and Turabi see the capitulation of southern Sudan as the first step in a putsch to Islamicize the rest of Africa.

Washington officials clearly distrust Khartoum government leaders. ButU.S. options appear to be limited: the United States cut off all economic and military aid to Khartoum after the 1989 coup. At the same time, Western nations have been overburdened by relief efforts in Somalia, where worldwide attention has been focused.

Andrew Natsios, an administrator with the U.S. Agency for International Development, said that a catastrophe of epic proportions looms in Sudan. "It's not like Somalia yet," said Natsios, "but it may well be at some point." *


LOAD-DATE: December 1, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


18 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 23, 1992


AFRICA'S CHILDREN CAN BE SAVED, GROUPS SAY
 
Dakar Conference Considers Strategy


LENGTH: 720 words


DATELINE: New York


Believing that more can be done to protect children from the effeof Africa's economic crises, the Organization of African Unity and the United Nations Children's Fund (Unicef) scheduled an international conference on assistance to African children for November 25-27 in Dakar, Senegal.

A document prepared for the meeting challenges the world community to recognize Africa's successes and its promise as well as its failures and its problems.

Africa's Children, Africa's Future says that the image of Africa as acontinent in constant crisis is flawed. "Few regions in the world so quickly made gains in improving the lives of their children as Africa did in its first two decades of independence," says the report, "despite the fact that in 1960 (Africa) was the world's most economically deprived continent." African countries raised health, education and other indicators of progress to levels that industrialized nations took more than a century to achieve. During the 1960s and 1970s, life expectancies climbed while infant mortality declined. Primary school enrollment soared. 

Even amid the natural disasters and economic catastrophes of the 1980s, Africans can cite certain advances. Contrary to the popular image, overall food production in Africa has actually increased since the 1970s, at about the same rate as in other parts of the world. And the continent was able to double the immunization rate of its children, with 22 nations reaching the objective of 75% coverage that health experts regard as virtually equivalent to full protection. That achievement, the report says, which required immense dedication and creativity, illustrates what can be done.

The campaign to chart a new course for Africa's children is buoyed by the political climate of the last two years, including the burgeoning democracy movements across the continent and the economic reform programs that numerous countries are implementing. The Dakar conference document hails "Africa's determination to push ahead with tough policy reforms even though the major powers, whose support is vital for the success of these reforms, are preoccupied with other, more 'strategic' regions."

But the advances of the post-independence years have eroded in the last decade, and reversing the current downward trends will be difficult. In many countries, living standards have dropped, school enrollment rates are down, and basic services such as health care are becoming scarcer. Today, African children constitute only 10% of the world's child population, but a third of the 40,000 children who die every day around the world are African.

A major obstacle to improving that record are the wars that still range in the spots that were among the hottest battlegrounds of the Cold War: Somalia, Sudan, Mozambique, Angola and Liberia. But even countries that are at peace face major challenges.

The courses of action recommended by Africa's Children include a broadrange of action at the local and regional levels, such as promotion of breast-feeding, making sure that girls have equal access to education with boys, and expanding family planning services.

Making contraceptive measures available to all women who want them could yield dramatic results. Although African food production has been rising consistent with world averages, population has risen faster than in other regions, meaning that food production per person has gone down.

Economic growth will be the linchpin of African progress, the report concludes. But it argues strongly that higher growth rates can be built only on improved health, education and nutrition for Africa's people, particularly its women and children, who are the poorest of the poor. *


LOAD-DATE: December 1, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


19 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


DECEMBER 7, 1992


A NEW DEAL


LENGTH: 203 words


 

In the central African nation of the Congo, opposing political groups agreed early this month to the formation of a government of "national union." In August voting, Pascal Lissouba was elected president, defeating the incumbent, Denis Sassou-Nguesso. But parliamentary balloting gave no party a commanding majority, and a no-confidence vote last month resulted in the ouster of reformist prime minister Stehpane Bongho-Nourra.

After lengthy negotiations between Lissouba's supporters and the former ruling party, a power-sharing deal was agreed that will allow Lissouba to name a new prime minister "after consulting with the political parties." A new round of parliamentary elections will be held later this year, but the unity government will serve until then.


LOAD-DATE: January 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


20 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


DECEMBER 7, 1992


FACE-OFF IN KINSHASA


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Political tensions in Zaire reached the boiling point again early this month when President Mobutu Sese Seko sent troops to oust government ministers from their offices after announcing the dismissal of the Cabinet. Mobutu ordered Prime Minister Etienne Tshisekedi, who was elected prime minister by the National Democracy Conference last August to form a new "government of national unity." 

Tshisekedi and the long-ruling president have been sparring over control of the country's finances and army and over a timetable for holding the country's first democratic elections in three decades. Mobutu's move was evidently intended to force Tshisekedi to compromise. The president wants elections held quickly, while the prime minister and the National Conference delegates want an 18- to 24-month period to rebuild the country's shattered economy and prepare voter rolls throughout the huge country, Africa's third largest.

Roman Catholic Archbishop Laurent Monsengwo Pasinya, the conference chairman, has been mediating between the two men, convening the only three sessions they have held since Tshisekedi became prime minister. The cleric has proved himself a skilled diplomat and is credited by many democracy supporters with having averted a harsher crackdown up to now.


LOAD-DATE: January 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


21 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


DECEMBER 7, 1992


TRAVEL ADVISORY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

The leader of the Polisario Front Independence movement in Western Sahara says that recent mass demonstrations against Moroccan occupation of the former Spanish colony have been crushed by Moroccan authorities. Mohammed Abdelaziz says the situation in the former Spanish colony, where a United Nations peacekeeping force is charged with conducting elections, is beginning to reassemble an intifada, or generalized resistance, to Moroccan control. 

Abdelaziz says that the United Nations is failing to protect Saharans from the widespread arrests and torture that typically follow the protests. He is particularly bitter about an incident in October, when several young Saharan demonstrators who had sought asylum in the headquarters of Minurso, the UN monitoring group, were denied refuge and were arrested by Moroccan authorities.

In an interview during his first visit to Britain, the Polisario secretary -general appealed to the United Nations to fulfill its mission of allowing Saharans to exercise a free choice about their future, and he called on the world body to pressure Morocco to allow access to the territory by the international press. He said the presence of journalists and independent observers would offer some protection to Saharans who oppose Moroccan rule in the former Spanish colony.

"We are getting reports all the time of horrible tortures," Abdelaziz says. "Our people are being thrown from helicopters, blindfolded and handcuffed. They are being buried alive in mass graves. This is a regime the international community must act against."

But he says Polisario's cause is hindered by Americans who see Morocco as an exotic vacation spot rather than a police state. While he says Polisario has no objections to Western tourists visiting Morocco, he warns of "good-hearted people being deceived" by the attractive facade that masks a harsh reality.


LOAD-DATE: January 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


22 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


DECEMBER 7, 1992


ALL OR NOTHING


LENGTH: 334 words


 

The postponement of a new round of peace talks on Sudan has cast a further shadow over the fate of the threatened population in the south of the country. Representatives of the government of Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan Ahmad El Bashir, was to meet a delegation from the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) in Nigeria on December 5. 

Conditions are worsening rapidly for an estimated 9 million people in the south, where the SPLA is fighting for autonomy from the northern-based regime. United Nations officials say suffering in parts of southern Sudan is as bad as in Somalia.

Announcing the postponement of peace talks, Bashir blamed the delay on conflicts within the SPLA. Two breakaway factions have been formed since an attempt was made in August of 1991 to overthrow SPLA chief John Garang. In November, Bashir invited all SPLA factions to attend the peace talks, but Garang protested, accusing the Sudanese leader of trying to exploit the movement's divisions.

Thousands of Sudanese have fled to neighboring Uganda and Kenya to escape the famine and civil strife. International agencies report that close to 4.5 million people have been forced from their homes since the war began in 1983. The United Nations estimates that as many as 600,000 Sudanese have died as a result of the conflict.


LOAD-DATE: January 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


23 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


DECEMBER 7, 1992


HOME FOR THE HOLIDAYS


LENGTH: 280 words


 

A U.S. aid worker who was held for a month by rebels in the West African nation of Sierra Leone has been released and reunited with his Sierra Leonean wife and two children.

Michael O'Neill, who works for Africare, a Washington, DC-based development group, was captured on October 24 along with a Sierra Leonean colleague in the diamond mining town of Koidu. A rebel group called the Revolutionary United Front, led by Foday Sankoh, admitted to abducting O'Neill, who was coordinating Red Cross food relief efforts in Sierra Leone.

O'Neill says that he was treated well during his captivity and that the kidnapping apparently was a desperate attempt to attract international attention to the situation in rebel-held areas of the country. He says Sankoh wanted a witness to the condition of the people in those areas, where food and other supplies are scarce and deaths are mounting.

Meanwhile, the Sierra Leone government has stepped up actions against dissidents, arresting at least 19 people last month on suspicion of plotting to overthrow the regime of Capt. Valentine Strasser.


LOAD-DATE: January 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


24 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


DECEMBER 7, 1992


ALL-OUT WAR


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Algerian President Belaid Abdesselam has declared "total war" on the country's Muslim fundamentalists. Abdesselam says he is determined to destroy the "spider's web" of support for the movement and has vowed to dissolve the local and regional governments and charitable and union groups sympathetic to the "extremists." 

The army-backed government has been battling opponents since January, when parliamentary elections were canceled after the fundamentalist Islamic Salvation Front (FIS) appeared poised to win a majority of seats.

Abdesselam imposed a curfew beginning December 5, when a partial amnesty offered to FIS supporters expired. Only about 100 people responded to the offer.

The curfew, which applies to the capital, Algiers, and six other regions, requires everyone to stay indoors from 10:30 p.m. until 5:00 a.m., with the exception of medical and other emergency personnel.

According to human rights observers, thousands of people are being detained in Algeria without trial. Ali-Yahia Abdenour, a human rights leader, has called for a neutral commission to investigate the alleged torture of detainees.


LOAD-DATE: January 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


25 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


DECEMBER 7, 1992


ANOTHER ROUND


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Voters in Madagascar will be going back to the polls in mid-January to choose between the two top vote getters in the November 25 presidential contest. President Didier Ratsiraka garnered 29% of the vote, far less than opposition leader Albert Zafy. But Zafy's 47% was not enough to avoid the run-off.

In Ghana, legislative elections scheduled for early December are now slated to take place on December 29. Opposition parties have threatened a boycott to protest what they regard as irregularities in the presidential voting on November 3. Jerry Rawlings, after 11 years as head of the military government, won the presidential balloting with 58% of the vote.

In the Central African Republic, new elections have been scheduled for February 14 and 28. Presidential and parliamentary elections were held in October, but opposition candidates went to court to challenge the results. The country's supreme court ruled that the process was flawed. President Andre Kolingba, whose term expired late last month, has extended his tenure in office until the new voting takes place.


LOAD-DATE: January 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


26 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


DECEMBER 7, 1992


DATELINE: AFRICA - ALLIED PRESSURE


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Libya's leader Muammar Quaddafi has threatened to pull his country out of the United Nations to protest the proposed tightening of UN sanctions. Britain, France and the United States are pushing for the United Nations to strengthen the economic and political boycott, in an effort to force Libya to turn over suspects in the bombings of American and French airliners in 1988 and 1989. 

The three allies have asked Libya to hand over the six intelligence operatives indicted in the two bombings. A U.S. airliner exploded over Lockerbie, Scotland , killing everyone on board in 1988, and a year later, a French UTA flight was bombed en route to Niger. The UN Security Council earlier this year imposed punitive sanctions on the Libyan government, banning all civilian flights to and from the country, placing an embargo on all arms sales and curtailing diplomatic relations.

While there has been some talk among the allies of urging the United Nations to adopt an oil embargo against Quaddafi's government, experts believe that is unlikely because of German and Italian dependence on Libyan oil.

The sanctions already have damaged Libya's economy. According to Libyan officials, the measures have cost the country $2.4 billion. Several infrastructural projects have been delayed by a lack of sufficient funds, thousands of civil workers have not been paid for several months and the country's oil industry has fallen behind technologically. As a means of relieving economic stress on the citizenry, Quaddafi has announced a new government "share the wealth" program, which will distribute half of the country's yearly oil income directly to Libyan families in sums of $7,000 to $10,000 a year.


LOAD-DATE: January 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


27 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


DECEMBER 7, 1992


AFRICA EXPLORES: 20TH CENTURY AFRICAN ART


BYLINE: Karen Lange for Africa News Service


SECTION: CULTURE


LENGTH: 1680 words


 

The picture of Africa presented by most African art exhibits in the United States is like the picture of America presented by Colonial Williamsburg:

centuries out of date.

Rooms filled with traditional masks and other wood carvings, most a century or more old, reflect an Africa that the early Western traders and explorers saw. The art of that era was cataloged and collected by missionaries, colonial administrators and anthropologists.

But African art forms continued to develop between the 16th and 19th centuries. An exhibit currently touring the United States allows American audiences to see the next chapters in that evolution. 

"Africa Explores: 20th Century African Art," opened November 7 at the Carnegie Museum in Pittsburgh, after stops earlier this year in Dallas, St. Louis and Charlotte, NC. It is scheduled to open at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington, DC, on February 6 and at the Center for Fine Arts in Miami on May 15.

The exhibit's 130 objects from 15 countries in sub-Saharan Africa bring together, for the first time in a major exhibit, diverse types of contemporary African art. The show groups the pieces within five categories: "traditional" art, "urban" or popular art, "new functional" or innovative art, "international" or academic art, and "extinct" art or art that has lost its original function but lives on as a symbol of national or cultural identity.

The exhibit aims to depict Africa's exploration of its relationship to the West, Islam, Christianity and its own artistic heritage in the wake of the continent's contact with Europe, according to the Center for African Art in New York, which put together the show.

"This exhibition challenges two widely held misconceptions about 20th century African art: that its celebrated traditional art belongs to cultures glorious but extinct, dead upon contact with the West, and that there is no modern Africa or African art, merely second-hand Western culture," writes Susan Vogel, executive director of the Center for African Art.

Bryna Freyer, curator at the Smithsonian's National Museum of African Art, says the show "counteracts the feeling that African art has stopped; that when the colonial era came in people became instantly uncreative."

"For me and others, this has been a real watershed," says Mark Leach, curator of contemporary art at the Mint Museum in Charlotte, NC, where over 21,000 people attended "Africa Explores" during August, September and October -- several thousand more than average for an exhibit of this size. "It has really challenged people's conceptions of what African art is."

Even the traditional art in the exhibit is not what museum goers in the United States have come to expect. For example, Ere Ibeji, a cult based in the Yoruba region of Nigeria, traditionally required a family that lost a twin to commission a wooden sculpture of the deceased. But 20th century families have begun to substitute brightly colored twin plastic dolls or photographs with double images of the surviving twin.
