Such objects, on display in "Africa Explores", take advantage of modern technology, while allowing Muslims and Christians to distance themselves from traditional religion without completely abandoning its practices, according to the exhibition catalog.

Among the exhibit's displays that startle visitors are a six-foot-long wooden onion painted in green enamel and an equally large wooden chicken and a Mercedes Benz, the creations of Kane Kwei, a Ghanaian coffin maker. The caskets were produced as the final resting places of, respectively, a successful farmer , a respected woman with many children and a wealthy entrepreneur.

Kwei combined the traditional value of honoring the dead with a 20th century arrival in Africa -- the desire to be remembered as an individual -- to devise a fresh art form. The exhibit catalogs such pieces as "new functional," and the catalog points out that African art, past and present, shares at least one characteristic. It fulfills a function, beyond pure pleasure or decoration.

"They are extravagantly made and extravagantly decorated for only one purpose:

to bury the dead," Leach says of the caskets. "We have a tendency in the West to really fetishize things to the extent that we lose the relationship with the object -- we revere things rather than use them. These people are still in touch."

"A lot of people might suppose Africa is just sort of imitating Western culture," Vogel says. "It's not. Africa is inventing its own art that is a combination of African ideas and techniques and some Western ideas and techniques."

Some of the "new functional" and "urban" art in "Africa Explores" is so recent that it is still not accepted by the African elites in charge of museums and universities on the continent, says V.Y. Mudimbe of Zaire, who teaches romance languages and comparative literature at Duke University and who wrote part of the exhibit catalog. What is being shown in Charlotte and Pittsburgh might not find its way into museums in Dakar, Kinshasa or Lagos, Mudimbe says. "The exhibit forces people to think about what is art."

The paintings of Cheri Samba, a Zairean "urban" artist with several pieces in "Africa Explores", reflect the influence of advertisements and comic books rather than an academic school of art. Rather than obscure meanings, the works offer direct messages.

"Lutte Contre Les Moustiques" (Battle Against the Mosquitoes) shows a man with a slingshot and a woman with a bow and arrow back to back in a bedroom fighting against mosquitoes, which carry the parasites that cause malaria. The title is painted on the top of the picture. At the bottom are the couple's words: "Dear, you kill those on the right, while I hit those on the left," the man says. "I'm doing it my love," the woman answers. "I have already killed two, but it seems to me that they come back to life." In text painted below, Samba observes that malaria, commonly called moustiques, is a killer, especially of young children, and seems to be growing more powerful.

As his worldwide popularity grows, following a number of exhibits of his work in Europe, Samba appears poised on the verge of another category in the exhibit -- what the catalog calls "international."

Many of the paintings in this category in the show also carry social or political messages, albeit more subtle ones, expressed in styles familiar to American museum goers. "E Onde Esta A Minha Mae, Os Meus Irmaos, E Todos Os Outros?" (Where Are My Mother, My Brother, My Sisters and All the Others?) by Malangatana Valente Ngwenya of Mozambique, depicts a mass of human figures, lost and struggling, as though caught in the country's civil war. The dominant color is blood red.

There is much that "Africa Explores" leaves out. Because of their different art traditions, works from Ethiopia and Sudan are not represented. Limited space kept out works from South Africa and other countries. But the exhibit suggests a new way for future scholars as well as museum goers to look at African art in the future.

"'Africa Explores' is not the final statement about contemporary African art," the catalog cautions. "This is rather the beginning." *


LOAD-DATE: January 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


28 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


DECEMBER 7, 1992


BOLSTER UN PEACEKEEPING


SECTION: DOSSIER


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

Following is an excerpt from Memorandum to the President-Elect: Harnessing Process to Purpose, prepared for the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace and the Institute for International Economics by a bipartisan panel of former top government officials.

Regional and internal threats to peace will be a staple on the world scene in the years ahead. The crises in Somalia and what was once Yugoslavia are likely to be precursors, not exceptions, and as was the case in Desert Storm, multilateral or collective action will be preferable to unilateral American responses. Unless we rely more on collective solutions to military challenges, they are likely not to be dealt with at all. 

This commission believes that greater American support for both UN peacekeeping and peacemaking efforts is a national security objective in which policy and a reorganizational effort should move forward together. In his speech to the UN General Assembly on September 21, President Bush made several useful proposals to improve UN peacekeeping capabilities as well as increase the American support to them. But the UN secretary-general has made a series of even more ambitious proposals to which the United States needs to formulate a response.

Peacekeeping is only one role the United Nations is called upon to undertake. Peacekeepers can maintain a peaceful situation with a military presence, but cannot carry out military operations or bring peace to an area in which fighting is going on, as the world has seen in the former Yugoslavia.

For such contingencies, the United Nations must be able to mount collective efforts to enforce peace under Chapter VII of the UN Charter. Its members must be prepared to deploy combat-ready troops, to marshal the logistics and intelligence necessary to support them, and to plan for potential deployments in advance.

Without American leadership, there is little likelihood of a significant international commitment in this vital area -- and the long-term costs to the nation and the world in refugee and relief activities and political chaos will increase enormously.

This commission recommends that you start a process of enhancing U.S. support for UN peacekeeping and peacemaking, bringing Congress and American military leaders into the discussions at every stage. We propose the following measures:

*Focus and upgrade responsibility for UN and other international peacekeeping/peacemaking efforts at the under-secretary level of both the State Department and the Defense Department. Strengthen the staff capabilities of both departments in this area.

*Move the funding for the American contribution to UN peacekeeping efforts from the State budget to Defense. In technical terms, this means moving the costs from the so-called "150 account," which includes State, to the "050 account," which funds the Pentagon. While such a funding change is never easy, this commission believes that some form of compromise between the Foreign Affairs Committees and the Armed Services Committees (perhaps joint hearings, as several members of Congress suggested to this commission) would be possible, given the obvious national interests involved.

*Establish a new military command, headed by a three- or four-star officer, to support UN military operations and, if necessary, U.S. participation in them. This new command would have the responsibility for planning, establishing doctrine, and training U.S. forces that might be used in UN efforts.

*Designate one or two U.S.-based brigades for support of UN operations. The current force structure is easily capable of supporting this additional mission. Should military activity commence, these units would come under the control of the command proposed above. Actually putting such forces under a UN command raises delicate legal and political considerations that must be dealt with on a case-by-case basis with proper congressional approval.

While our informal discussions with congressional leaders lead this commission to believe that such proposals are within reach, there will be differences within both Congress and the military about the value and details of these proposals. The process can only move forward with strong leadership from you and your secretary of Defense. *


LOAD-DATE: January 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


29 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


DECEMBER 7, 1992


MAKE A 'NEW BEGINNING'


SECTION: DOSSIER


LENGTH: 2534 words


 

Below are excerpts from a 12-page memorandum to President-Elect Bill Clinton from the Joint Ministry in Africa Office of the United Church of Christ and the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ), two Protestant denominations with approximately 3 million members in the United States and Canada. "Our churches have worked in Africa for more than 150 years," the memorandum says. "We relate to a broad range of church partners in 13 countries as well as ecumenical agencies all over Africa."

We are greatly pained by the current trends of drift and neglect in U.S. policy toward Africa.

We are worried that Africa has been forgotten by the United States and that our foreign policy toward that continent seems to be rudderless and without meaning. 

It is from our faith convictions that we write to you at this time. Our sense of hope tells us that your administration potentially augurs a new beginning in U.S. foreign policy toward Africa.

The arrival of your administration coincides with a unique period in African history. In many countries, years of dictatorship have given way to broad-based democracies. However, these democracies are fragile, weakened by economic problems and the threatening presence of the military and retired dictators on the sidelines.

Unfortunately, this is also a time of great strife and suffering. In many countries people continue to be repressed and tortured, denied their humanity and economic opportunities. It is a time of truth, which challenges us to show our true colors. Where do we stand with regard to peace, justice and freedom in this world?

What makes 1992 significant is that the Cold War is over. People around Africa are taking on the challenge of building a new democratic order without the shadow of superpower interests hanging over them. Because of the magnitude of Africa's problems, the challenges that people there are taking on require international friendship and assistance.

The United States has been a superpower player on the African scene for more than 30 years. As a nation, the United States says that it speaks for human rights, democracy and freedom. Do we really believe in these ideals?

Our government is the largest contributor to and most influential member of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank and therefore bears considerable responsibility for the policies of these bodies. Our aid and weapons have contributed to the oppression and detention of thousands of South Africans; to civil conflicts in Angola, Liberia, Ethiopia and Somalia resulting in the deaths of more than one million people; and to the current chaos and social explosions in Zaire and Kenya.

The death toll inflicted on Africans in these conflicts is worse than the combined total of U.S. citizens killed in World Wars I and II, Korea, Vietnam, and the Persian Gulf.

There are some things you can do to change the legacies of war, dictators and neglect. In doing these things, you can help bring a new dawn to Africa. Simply by carrying through on your campaign goals and promises you can do a lot. The costs would not be great but the effects of your actions most certainly would be. Your administration would be investing in peace, democracy and development.

Here are some of our thoughts -- many of which are consistent with your principles -- on what you could do in specific areas.

Zaire:

*Publicly distance the United States from Mobutu, stating in no uncertain terms that his rule is unacceptable in both human rights and democratic terms.

*Work with U.S. friends in Europe and with U.S. banks to freeze Mobutu's assets. The assets were meant for the Zairean people and should only be released when Mobutu is completely out of power.

Angola:

*Urge the government to release all of the Unita leaders it is holding.

*Urge both sides to come together for the sake of Angola's people.

*Upon the release of Unita's leaders, and the beginning of negotiations,recognize the Angolan government and support international reconstruction efforts.

*Stop any existing covert funding going to Unita. Resumption of any aid should be for humanitarian reasons only.

*Investigate rumors of South African government involvement in providing logistical support for Unita military actions. If these rumors are proven true, consider moving to reimpose federal sanctions on South Africa.

* Support the United Nations presence in Angola.

South Africa:

*Signal to South Africans that until their country has a fully representative and democratic government that represents the disenfranchised majority, the United States will not support the release of IMF funds for South Africa and will continue to support state and local sanctions.

*Support the recent call by South African church leaders for the convening of a multiparty conference.

*Support the church leaders' call for an election date of some time in 1993.

*Consider using the threat of reimposing federal sanctions if the currently stalled negotiations do not move forward toward legitimate rule.

Liberia:

*Support the West African peacekeeping force (Ecomog) and all diplomatic efforts to bring the different sides together.

*Support the UN ban on weapons sales to all forces except the West African peacekeeping troops.

*Investigate the role that several European companies are playing in funding one of the rebel forces.

*Provide reconstruction funds via the United Nations. The funds would be taken from military accounts and act as compensation for past U.S. policies.

*Consider developing a food for guns strategy in consultation with Ecomog and the UN.

Western Sahara:

*Use leverage to foster a fair and sovereign solution -- via the United Nations -- to the Western Saharan situation and to make a human rights statement about Morocco, where both Sahrawis and Moroccans languish in prison and endure other hardships for their political beliefs.

Kenya:

*Work with President Bush, the United Nations and Kenyans to ensure that effective monitoring of the December elections takes place.

*Closely watch these elections and investigate other international structures that might be placed on the government in the event that the elections are not legitimate.

Mozambique:

*Support an adequate UN presence that could help move Mozambique toward a situation more akin to Namibia's peaceful and democratic transition rather than a repeat of the Angolan tragedy.

*Increase humanitarian assistance to rebuild the poorest country in the world.

*Press the South African government to stop South African citizens from providing Renamo rebels with weapons.

*Investigate reports that U.S. citizens are supplying Renamo with weapons.

*Develop an exchange program designed to provide food for guns.

Sudan:

*Call for an immediate cease-fire.

*Work with the United Nations to pressure the Sudanese government to open up relief routes in the south.

*Consider an international financial blockade on the Sudanese government in order to stop the forced relocation of people from Khartoum and the Nuba mountains.

*Work with the United Nations to develop a comprehensive humanitarian effort for Sudan. Be prepared to support this effort morally, financially and physically.

Continent-wide:

*Lead the way in checking the flow of arms and increasing relief supplies.

*Invest in people, in education, farmers, land conservation, schools, housing , and local industry to ensure that catastrophes do not repeat themselves.

*Support a debt transfer for sub-Saharan countries where these countries would stop paying interest on their debt in foreign currency and instead pay it in local currency.

* The full text of the document is available from the United Church Board for World Ministries, 475 Riverside Drive, New York, NY 10115-0109.


LOAD-DATE: January 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


30 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


DECEMBER 7, 1992


PRESSURE ANGOLA BUT DON'T PUSH UN PRESENCE IN SOUTH AFRICA


BYLINE: Thomas P. Sheehy


SECTION: VIEWPOINT


LENGTH: 1294 words


 

Angola soon may resume its 16-year-old civil war that has claimed 350,000 lives. On October 31, one month after the country's first democratic elections, heavy fighting erupted in and around Angola's capital of Luanda between the government forces of President Jose Eduardo dos Santos' Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA) and partisans of Jonas Savimbi's National Union for the Total Independence of Angola (Unita). Thousands of Angolans were killed in four days of fighting. Since then, MPLA and Unita forces have continued to skirmish in the Angolan countryside.

The MPLA reportedly distributed thousands of weapons to its cadres, leading to the massacre of thousands of unarmed civilians suspected of being Unita supporters. Moreover, the MPLA apparently sought to decapitate Unita by killing its vice president, Jeremias Chitunda, and other top Unita leaders. But the MPLA denies responsibility for the outbreak of violence and instead blames Angola's turmoil on an abortive Unita coup d'etat attempt. 

Vice President Chitunda and other top Unita leaders were in Luanda at the MPLA's request -- and under UN security guarantees -- to negotiate arrangements for the required presidential runoff between Savimbi and dos Santos. Unita was pressing to remedy election shortcomings, including inadequate Unita access to the mass media, excessive MPLA control over the administration of the election, and the intimidating tactics of the MPLA's 30,000-strong "anti-riot" police force. The government was insisting that Unita withdraw from areas it had occupied since the elections.

Last month's bloodshed shattered these talks, and Angola now is effectively partitioned. The only hope for peace is if the two parties can negotiate a political solution. Additional fighting or an extended partition would be disastrous for Angola.

The United States correctly has maintained that democratic elections and an integrated national army are the only way to find peace. The United States also has urged a general cease-fire and the release of several Unita generals who are being held captive by the MPLA.

To help prevent Angola from plunging into renewed civil war, the United States should support Unita's call for an independent investigation of the Luanda massacre. The State Department has said nothing about the Luanda massacre beyond pro forma statements decrying the loss of Angolan life. Washington's meek neutrality signals acquiescence to the killings, reducing the possibility that Savimbi and dos Santos will renew negotiations soon.

The United States should also withhold diplomatic recognition of the MPLA regime. Recognition would reduce the MPLA's incentive to negotiate seriously with Unita and further erode Washington's already diminished influence with Unita.

Recognition should be given only to a democratic Angolan government -- in this case, one resulting from a presidential runoff election or a power-sharing deal between the MPLA and Unita.

South Africa, too, may be on the brink of civil war, with the on-again off -again multiparty negotiations for a post-apartheid South Africa.

If South Africa erupts into full-scale violence, the United States could find itself under tremendous pressure to participate in, or even lead, a United Nations peacekeeping operation there. Participation in such a UN force, similar to the one now in Yugoslavia, would not be in the U.S. national interest. To avoid this predicament, Washington should resist pressuring the South African government into accepting increasing international intervention into its internal affairs.

This intervention to date consists of 65 or so UN-sanctioned peace monitors. Despite their good intentions, the peace monitors actually could encourage more violence in South Africa. Some South African activists using or contemplating violent political tactics probably view the admission of UN and other peace monitors as a "defeat" for the South African government.

Given the potential for increased violence, it is likely that there will be pressure to dispatch more peace monitors to South Africa, regardless of their effect. The mechanism for doing so is in place. UN Security Council Resolution 772, passed last August, authorizes Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali to deploy an unspecified number of peace monitors to South Africa. Some Security Council members already have sought to send 400 UN peace monitors to South Africa. All that is needed is the South African government's permission. So far, the South African government has welcomed a "reasonable" number of peace monitors, but not as many as 400.

De Klerk is in a weak position to resist demands that South Africa accept additional peace monitors, having already sanctioned an unprecedented intervention in its internal affairs. The United States, however, must not pressure South Africa into accepting more peace monitors. In fact, the United States should even avoid pressuring de Klerk into keeping the current peace monitors if they are unwanted. There are two reasons for this: 1) peace monitors cannot reverse the political dynamics fueling the violence; they may, in fact, be used politically by one side against the others; and 2) if things were to get out of hand, and the UN had to launch a major peacekeeping operation in South Africa, the United States would be pressured to take the lead to finance it and possibly provide military support.

To be sure, the United States has interests in South Africa. Washington would like to see a peaceful dismantling of apartheid and a stable transition to democracy. These interests, however, in no way warrant a major U.S. financial and military commitment to a UN peacekeeping operation. * Thomas Sheehy is a policy analyst at the Heritage Foundation in Washington, DC.


LOAD-DATE: January 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


31 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


DECEMBER 7, 1992


SEE AFRICA FOR YOURSELF


BYLINE: C. Payne Lucas and Kevin Lowther


SECTION: VIEWPOINT


LENGTH: 1040 words


 

An African safari may not be high on Bill Clinton's official travel plans, but it should be.

Not since John F. Kennedy assumed office has a newly elected American president commanded as much hope and respect among Africans as Bill Clinton. But Kennedy, whom Africans still revere for championing their independence before it was the fashion, never set foot in sub-Saharan Africa.

President Clinton can make amends for that historic oversight. In the process, he could give enormous moral impetus to Africa's emerging democracies and a new generation of leaders who are Clinton's political age-mates. 

Africa is a natural part of the next president's international constituency. Although he could easily ignore or downgrade African issues, Clinton has ample reason to take the continent seriously.

Africans understand Clinton's domestic agenda and do not expect the new administration to increase foreign assistance substantially or pursue an overtly activist role in African affairs. What they do see in Clinton, however, is an American president who can genuinely empathize with their problems and engage them as equals in discussion and resolution of global issues and mutual concerns.

Africans perceive Clinton as a "man of the people," someone who is comfortable with human contact, who listens well and seeks to build consensus -- all important aspects of social and political life in Africa. To many Africans, Clinton represents a "new dawn," a powerful symbol associated originally with the continent's emergence from colonial domination. Today, the image reflects the incipient democratization that is replacing Africa's first generation of post-independence rulers with younger, more pragmatic and better-educated leaders who are prepared to live or die politically by the popular vote. In his foreign policy campaign speeches, Clinton stressed the importance of helping new democracies, particularly in the former Soviet bloc, to weather transitional turmoil. Africa's democratic rebirth is no less vulnerable. For every Tajikhistan, there is an Angola; for every Yeltsin, a Soglo in Benin or a Chiluba in Zambia.

Africans assume that Clinton understands this reality and will act accordingly. They believe that African democracy is inherently as worthy as Russian democracy and that the Clinton administration will take the lead in giving new meaning and substance to African independence.

However, Clinton can hardly be expected to appreciate the resonance of his own priorities, governing style and philosophy within a continent that sees such promise in his presidency.

That is why he should visit Africa during his first year in office. He would meet a new generation of leaders and private citizens who are trying to promote political and human rights reforms, economic liberalization, environmental awareness and acceptance of ethnic diversity. And he would discover that it is in our national self-interest to encourage job creation and productivity in Africa and to strengthen democratic systems and institutions as a buffer against the kind of Balkanization that threatens to destabilize much of the former Soviet Bloc.

In spite of its frequent crises, natural or otherwise, Africa has the potential to be a keystone of stability in a changing world. African nations have embarked on the difficult road to democratic change. They are swallowing the bitter pill of structural economic adjustment. And they have begun to recognize that their survival -- and ours -- may be linked to how well they conserve a fragile environment.

Africans need to know that President Clinton cares whether the continent rises from its current miseries or sinks further into conflict and chronic underdevelopment. If he does nothing else for Africa, he needs to pursue his stated support for a strong, international rapid-deployment peacekeeping force.

Such intervention could have saved thousands of lives -- and millions of dollars in relief funds -- in Somalia, Sudan, Angola, Liberia and elsewhere.

To many Africans, Bill Clinton is the reincarnation of the Kennedy spirit. Just as JFK embodied Africans' heady expectations at independence in the early 1960s, Clinton represents Africans' aspirations in the 1990s. He owes them the visit Kennedy never made. * C. Payne Lucas is executive director of Africare, a Washington, DC-based development and relief organization. Kevin Lowther is the agency's director for Southern Africa.


LOAD-DATE: January 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


32 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


DECEMBER 7, 1992


GHANA'S ECONOMIC: MIRACLE CALLED A MYTH


SECTION: VIEWPOINT


LENGTH: 1360 words


 

The West African nation of Ghana has achieved economic growth rates that are among Africa's highest and exceed those of many industrial nations, including the United States and Japan.

Ghana's boom began after Jerry Rawlings, a young air force lieutenant, seized power in a 1981 coup. Despite his radical, anti-imperialist rhetoric, Rawlings turned to the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund for help in turning the country's economy around, after two decades of corruption and mismanagement by previous military and civilian governments.

Six years of growth that have averaged over five percent annually has been cited as a factor in Rawlings' decisive win over four opponents in last month's first presidential election in more than a decade. But Rawling's critics say Ghana's economic achievements are not as impressive as the government and its foreign backers have suggested. 

The following article by Kwasi Anyemadu, who teaches economics at the University of Ghana, is excerpted from a column published by the Ghanaian Chronicle newspaper.

ACCRA, GHANA - Kwasi Anyemadu The improved performance of the economy during the rule of the PNDC is the regime's proudest achievement.

There have, indeed, been improvements in the economy in many respects, but the economic situation is not as healthy as government propagandists claim. Sluggish growth in the agricultural sector is evident, so also is distress in the manufacturing sector. There also have been for some time now considerable strains on the macroeconomy, a fact concealed from the Ghanaian public and the world at large by falsification of economic data, or if you are not given to semantic caution, by plain, brazen lies.

Some reading this article will be impressed by the contradictions inherent in a situation in which a regime, whose leader self-righteously claims that he and his men are the only people of integrity in the land, can be so deficient in candor with respect to matters of such vital importance to the people.

However well placed such moral indignation might be, this is not the main reason I have written this article. The main reason is that, irrespective of whatever short-term, tactical "justifications" there might have been for embarking on this disreputable venture of falsifying data, the efficient management of the economy is now being hampered by the gulf between the published figures and the reality on the ground. As would not be surprising to anybody, the policies which are appropriate are different whether the budget is in surplus, as it is officially claimed, or is in deficit, as is the real case; whether there is an overall balance of payments surplus and addition to reserves, as it is claimed, or whether there is an overall balance of payments deficit and a loss of reserves, as is the case currently.

Let me at this stage say something about the timing of this article. Ever since I became aware of the extent of the data falsification, I have labored under a serious crisis of conscience. Should I expose the falsifications or keep quiet over them and continue to be part of the cover-up? Would the short -term damage to the credibility of the country be outweighed by the undoubted long-term benefits of truth and transparency? During the election campaign, I resisted the temptation, which was sometimes very strong indeed, to speak out because I did not want matters of such national importance to be entangled in the web of partisan contention.

The actual timing of this article has been determined, to a large extent, by considerations related to my work at the University of Ghana. I teach a course on the economy of Ghana, and I know I cannot stand in front of my class and describe to my students a fiscal situation different from what is contained in published documents -- national and international -- without seeming incompetent.

I do not know when the data falsification or "creative accounting" began. It is possible that in the eyes of the perpetrators, there was some national interest justification. There were credits from the IMF and other donors to draw down. The release of each (disbursement) was, however, subject to criteria in the area of fiscal performance, money supply, credit, balance of payments, etc. It might have seemed that some creative "management" of the data was justified to ensure the continued flow of the vital foreign exchange inflows. At any rate, since the advisability of some of the conditionalities was debatable, not abiding by them in reality probably did not do much harm to the economy.

As this data falsification was done from year to year, however, the fiction depicted in the official statistics departed more and more from reality and came to hinder prudent economic management. For instance, in 1991, there was supposed to be an overall balance of payments surplus of $130 million and an addition to the reserves. In reality, however, there was no addition to the reserves but, on the contrary, a draw-down of accumulated reserves.

Nevertheless, the 1992 budget also projected an addition of $140 million to the reserves.

If we had owned up to the true situation at the end of 1991, we could have instituted measures to restrain the demand for foreign exchange. The gap between the real situation and that depicted by the official statistics is even wider with respect to the fiscal situation. Workers and others who demand government expenditures ought to know the truth.

I am confident that if the truth is known to the general public and our collaborators in the multilateral financial institutions, it will inspire the same search for solutions that will arrest the situation and ensure that a sound macroeconomic situation is created on the basis of which accelerated growth may be generated. *


LOAD-DATE: January 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


33 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


DECEMBER 7, 1992


MINE COULD BE ENVIRONMENTAL DISASTER


SECTION: DOSSIER


LENGTH: 1360 words


 

An ambitious $300 million mining project in the West African nation of Guinea continues to draw fire from environmental groups, who believe it would destroy one of Africa's last remaining rain forests. The venture is expected to produced about nine million tons of high-grade iron ore annually, extracted from Guinea's Nimba Mountain region.

The area has been classified a "World Heritage Site" because of its extensive biological diversity, and environmentalists are concerned that the mining operation would endanger several species of rare flora and fauna.

Politically, the project is controversial as well, since its viability depends on shipping the iron through Liberian territory controlled by the National Patriotic Front, the Liberian rebel movement headed by Charles Taylor. 

Thirty environmental organizations from 11 countries recently sent the following letter protesting the project to the World Bank. In response, an official in the bank's West and Central Africa Department said the bank believes the project "should not be undertaken until an independent economic and environmental evaluation is complete," but failed to condemn the venture as the groups are asking.

We are writing to you to ask that the World Bank express firm opposition to the planned Mount Nimba iron ore project. A decree issued by the government of Guinea on August 6, 1992 which entrusts 540 hectares of Mount Nimba to the international mining consortium Nimco, lends new urgency to the need to take convincing measures for the protection of Mount Nimba.

The Mount Nimba iron ore project, a giant opencast mining operation, will directly and indirectly lead to the irreversible destruction of the Mount Nimba World Heritage Site, one of the world's richest reserves of biodiversity. The mine will also reduce the natural resource base on which the livelihoods of the overwhelming majority of the local population depend. Mining operations will cause the disappearance of parts of two rivers and aggravate water shortages. The discharges of waste water and other pollution will inevitably move downstream, creating enormous added pressure on the people and the environment.

In addition, the project's impact on the mountain peaks is likely to change both local and regional rainfall patterns with unforseeable consequences for the integrity of ecosystems and the production of both food and cash crops not only in Guinea, but also in Cote d'Ivoire and Liberia.

The project also merits rejection on economic grounds alone. Aside from 600 unskilled jobs at the mine site which will be created at a staggering environmental cost, financial benefits will be limited to the payment of a small percentage of royalties to the government, which has shown little or no commitment to a sustainable and more equitable approach to development.

Liberia, by comparison, seems to receive greater benefits just for providing its railway and port facilities. The tragic irony for Liberia, however, is that the mining project will largely benefit rebel leader Charles Taylor, who controls the railway corridor and port on which the viability of the mine depends. Payments to Charles Taylor from the Mount Nimba mine threaten to further engulf the whole region in armed conflict as Taylor attempts to overthrow the interim government in Monrovia, which is backed by troops from six West African nations.

Concerned about an ecological debacle of giant proportions, the World Bank's involvement so far seems to be limited to using a Japanese technical assistance grant to finance an ongoing environmental data collection in the area. Unfortunately, Guinean government authorities believe that this data collection represents a World Bank-supported environmental assessment. This perception needs to be rectified.

Much to its credit, the World Bank has stated in clear terms that the preliminary environmental evaluation executed by Nimco in 1990 cannot be considered an adequate environmental assessment and that neither the government of Guinea nor the investors should take a final decision on the project prior to the completion of an extensive environmental assessment.

However, the most recent developments in Guinea warrant a strong and unambiguous signal from the World Bank, requesting that the government of Guinea suspend the decree at least until a thorough environmental and social impact assessment has been carried out. Otherwise, the World Bank's planned $30 million Natural Resource Management Project for Guinea, which will cover Mount Nimba and all of Guinea's forest region, will be irrelevant and should be canceled. It would merely give the appearance of being a clean-up operation for the massive destruction that will be caused by the mine.

The same is true for a possible Global Environment Facility (GEF) project for Mount Nimba. Should the government of Guinea agree to cancel the mining project , the Guinean environmental organization ASSOANE believes that a well-prepared GEF project could make a substantial contribution to the conservation of the biodiversity of Mount Nimba. The preparation of a possible GEF project would require close consultation with local people to be able to respond directly to local needs.

Mining Mount Nimba and the conservation of the area's unique ecosystems are not compatible. In recognition of this fact, members of the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN), including the governments of over 50 states, adopted IUCN Resolution 18.51 in 1990, which opposes the mining of Mount Nimba. Mount Nimba was established as a World Heritage Site under the World Heritage Convention, which is celebrating its 20th anniversary this year.

Especially in the post-Unced context, protecting the integrity of international environmental conventions would be of prime importance. The World Bank, in its role as chairman of the GEF, which for now is the interim financing mechanism for both the biodiversity and climate change conventions, should use its influence to that effect. *


LOAD-DATE: January 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


34 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


DECEMBER 7, 1992


THE CIA AND THE DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE IN AFRICAN STUDIES


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Excerpts from a petition being circulated by the Association of Concerned Africa Scholars to students, faculty and professionals associated with African studies in the United States:

We scholars of Africa call upon our colleagues to reject the National Security Education Act of 1991. The act supports undergraduate study abroad, graduate research fellowships, and international studies programs. Students must repay their grants or work either in a related education field or in a federal agency , with emphasis on national security employment. The program is to be administered by the Defense Intelligence College of the Department of Defense and overseen by an advisory board chaired by the secretary of Defense and including, among others, the director of the CIA.

We have long argued for expanded funding for African studies. Despite Africa's importance to the U.S. and especially to the people of African descent, African studies has received minimal funding by comparison to other world areas. However, this act provides defense and intelligence agencies with influence on the direction and priorities of international studies. The disastrous effects of earlier links between scholars and national security agencies and the lengthy record of CIA and military interventions in Africa are well established.

Funding from national security agencies threatens the openness of scholarly inquiry and publication, the physical safety of scholars and students overseas, and cooperation between African and U.S. scholars. Many area studies associations, Africa scholars, programs and centers have therefore opposed such funding.

For all these reasons, we call on:

* Our colleagues to express their opposition to NSEA 1991 as formulated and to all proposals for links with and funding from military and intelligence agencies; and

* On the Congress to ensure the integrity of African studies by appropriating increased funding through civilian agencies. *


LOAD-DATE: January 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


35 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


DECEMBER 7, 1992


SCHOLARS TROUBLED BY CIA LINKS IN NEW GOVERNMENT FUNDING


BYLINE: William Acworth for Africa News Service


LENGTH: 1267 words


 

Washington, DC Congress has appropriated $150 million to fund international research at U.S.

universities, but African scholars say they may reject the support on ethical grounds.

At a time of budgetary cutbacks in higher education, the appropriation, established by the National Security Education Act (NSEA), has been welcomed by many university administrators. But the involvement of the Central Intelligence Agency and the Pentagon in the new program has alarmed regional specialists, who say that such oversight threatens the integrity and independence of their research. In response to these concerns, Congress passed several amendments to the act in late October, but the changes have failed to satisfy the board of directors of the African Studies Association (ASA), which has decided not to participate in the program unless further changes are made. 

The NSEA was originally proposed in 1991 by Senator David Boren (D-OK), chairman of the Select Committee on Intelligence. His proposal, cosponsored by Senators Sam Nunn (D-GA) and John Warner (R-VA), was enacted in October 1991, and in mid-1992, $150 million was deposited into the "educational trust fund" that is the centerpiece of the Boren legislation. Although there are still some technical issues to be ironed out, Capitol Hill and Pentagon sources say they expect a pilot program to be up and running by the fall of 1993, the beginning of the next academic year.

According to Boren, the purpose of the NSEA is to make sure that the U.S. government has a pool of talented and experienced analysts available when U.S. "national security interests" are threatened in relatively obscure areas of the world. The program will use the funds in three ways: 1) to provide scholarships to undergraduates interested in studying abroad; 2) to fund graduate study at home or abroad; and 3) to fund area studies programs at U.S. universities. Not all countries or regions will qualify for study -- only those that the program's board of directors defines as "critical" to national security. troubles some members of the academic community are the links between the program and the defense and intelligence agencies of the U.S. government. According to the latest version of the act, as amended in October, the program will be supervised by a 13-member "National Security Education Board." The board will be chaired by the secretary of Defense, and will include the secretaries of Commerce, Education and State, as well as the directors of the CIA and the United States Information Service and the chair of the National Endowment for the Humanities. The board also will include six non-governmental representatives appointed by the president.

The original plan called for day-to-day administration of the program by the Defense Intelligence College, but that was changed in October, due in part to pressure from the academic community. At the moment, the program is administered by an eight-person staff operating out of an office at the Pentagon.

Last spring, three leading representatives of area studies programs in the United States sent a letter to Senator Boren expressing concern that the NSEA might pose a threat to the exercise of academic freedom and the reputation of area studies. The letter, signed by Edmond Keller, ASA president, Barbara Aswad, president of the Middle East Studies Association, and Lars Schoultz, president of the Latin American Studies Association, praised Boren for his attention to international studies but expressed "grave concern" about the role of the CIA and the Defense Intelligence College in the administration of the program.

"For scholars of our regions, these provisions represent a significant problem , if not outright risk," the letter said. "Linking university-based research to U.S. national security agencies, even indirectly, will restrict our already narrow research opportunities; it will endanger the physical safety of scholars and our students studying abroad; and it will jeopardize the cooperation and safety of those we study and collaborate with in those regions."

In response to these and other objections, Boren shepherded several NSEA amendments through Congress in late October, reducing the influence of the Defense Department and the CIA in the program. But Africanists say the reforms have not gone far enough. At the annual meeting of the African Studies Association in Seattle last month, the association's board of directors reviewed the situation and decided to reaffirm its opposition to the NSEA as presently conceived. Although the board meeting was held behind closed doors, sources say the board agreed to reject "every penny" of NSEA funding so long as the program remains tied to the CIA and the Defense Department. The ASA board also agreed to authorize the incoming president of the ASA, David Robinson of Michigan State University, to work with other area studies associations to modify the Boren legislation, so that it meets the association's concerns about the links to Defense and the CIA.

Some ASA members believe that the NSEA, while already a legal entity, is still fluid enough to be transformed. There have been no appointments to the NSEA board, and the Clinton administration may find appointees who can allay academic concerns. In addition, Senator Boren will step down as chairman of the Intelligence Committee in January, to be replaced by Senator Dennis DeConcini, a Democrat from Arizona who has shown a personal interest in African affairs. DeConcini staffers say that the senator has not determined what his position will be on the NSEA issue.

Keller says the ASA board plans to present its concerns to DeConcini and other members of the Intelligence Committee when the next session of Congress begins in January. The ASA also will lobby new members of Congress, in the hope that they will be more open to the views of scholars from outside the government. *


LOAD-DATE: January 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


36 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


DECEMBER 7, 1992


ACTIVISTS REGROUP FOR APARTHEID'S END


BYLINE: Karen Gellen * Africa News Service


LENGTH: 1840 words


 

New York - "Mandela is free but he still can't vote," says the cover of a brochure distributed by the American Committee on Africa (ACOA), echoing the African National Congress (ANC) leader's appeal to "keep the pressure on" the South African regime. But as Pretoria and the ANC engage in negotiations on a transition to majority rule, the anti-apartheid movement in this country is redefining its role. What will be the priorities, activists are asking, when Mandela not only votes, but heads a government?

The ongoing vitality of the anti-apartheid movement was demonstrated this fall during a large and lively New York conference "in support of the ANC and other democratic forces" in South Africa. Also evident, however, was a sense of unease, as activists debated the relevance of their work in a complex new era.

In contrast to past meetings focusing on sanctions, lobbying, protests and boycotts, the New York conference was devoted to the tasks confronting an ANC "government-in-waiting." This time, some of the key issues were housing, education, a new legal system, health care and post-sanctions economic investment. 

ANC International Affairs Director Thabo Mbeki cautions that Pretoria's stonewalling on elections might ultimately require U.S. activists to "go back to the South African Embassy," a reference to the highly visible protests and mass arrests of the 1980s, organized by the Washington, DC-based group TransAfrica and the Free South Africa Movement.

But the ANC's main message to supporters is its pressing need for practical help and expertise in building a post-apartheid society. "The government has its foreign think tanks and advisers," observes ANC representative Victor Mashabela, "and we need them as well. We're asking our longtime friends to help us find people with the necessary skills."

Some veteran anti-apartheid campaigners say they feel shunted by the ANC's evolving agenda and are disquieted by the movement's consultations with establishment political figures and major U.S. corporations about future investment opportunities. They also express concern about the South African group's priorities.

There is pressure from the ANC, says one prominent activist, for the U.S. movement to "get off the backs of the corporations and stop alienating potential investors." The ANC is sending "mixed messages," he argues, about the ongoing value of sanctions, leaving U.S. advocates out on a limb. Another longtime anti-apartheid lobbyist says the ANC is disregarding advice from the "progressive development community" and opting instead for traditional World Bank economic formulas. Activists also express confusion at the prospect of supporting the ANC when it sheds its role as a hounded liberation movement and takes the reigns of an elected government.

Despite such concerns, most veteran activists appear to be committed to continuing work on South African issues. With the issues less clear-cut, "this is the most difficult, but most important time to keep the pressure on South Africa," says Jim Cason, associate director of the ACOA, the oldest of the major U.S. anti-apartheid organizations.

Cason cites the continuing political violence in South Africa, the formidable obstacles to genuine democratization and an ongoing need to monitor the role of U.S. corporations in South Africa. Although most federal economic sanctions were lifted by the Bush administration in 1991, over half the states and some 100 cities maintain restrictions or prohibitions on business dealing with firms involved in South Africa. These will likely remain in force, at the ANC's request, Cason says, until a nonracial government takes power in South Africa.

The job for the 1990s, according to many activists, is recasting the goals of the solidarity movement. "We organized for independence in Southern Africa, to free Mandela and end apartheid," says Roberta Washington, a long-time member of the Mozambique Solidarity Network. "As those things finally occur, many people think their work is done. We have to look instead at our underlying goals -- helping to build new societies that bring a better life for the people of Southern Africa. That hasn't been achieved yet."

Washington, a New York architect who has worked in Mozambique, led a session on "Housing, Community Planning and Infrastructure" at the conference. She says the most productive form of solidarity work may be to offer expertise and material aid. A good model, she adds, is a project that brings Mozambican doctors to New York's Harlem Hospital for training, while U.S. doctors work in Mozambique.

Imani Countess, executive director of the Washington Office on Africa, a church- and trade union-sponsored lobby group, also notes a degree of disorientation in the anti-apartheid ranks. She says, however, that activists need to understand the complexity of the tasks confronting the ANC as it prepares for majority rule. As a future government, she maintains, the ANC would be "irresponsible" if it did not deal with international business and political leaders.

Countess, like Washington, stresses material aid campaigns, Sister City projects, fundraising for South African causes and other grass-roots solidarity work. She also predicts that the Clinton administration will provide more fertile ground for activists to influence U.S. policy towards Southern Africa.

The San Francisco-based Global Exchange, which promotes personal and group ties between Americans and people in developing countries, also plans to stay active on the anti-apartheid front. When the ANC comes to lead a new South African government, says Kevin Danaher, the organization's public education director, many U.S. activists will emphasize ties with the Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu) and other popular organizations that constitute "civil society." It is natural, he notes, for grass-roots movements in this country to support their non-governmental counterparts in South Africa.

Danaher, who has written extensively on anti-apartheid issues, is nonetheless critical of activists who attack the ANC for "selling out" when it seeks corporate investment and consults with the World Bank and other financial institutions. He argues that any future democratic government will need vast resources to cope with the legacy of apartheid and meet popular demands for change. Those possessing the necessary "tens of billions" of dollars, he says, are "the white men in three-piece suits from London, New York and Bonn" as well as the current South African elite.

Anti-apartheid activists who expect the ANC to disdain "tainted" funds, says Danaher, have never witnessed the terrible poverty in countries like South Africa.

Some anti-apartheid groups, such as the ACOA and the Interfaith Center on Corporate Responsibility, have responded to changing conditions by preparing to shift from advocating sanctions to monitoring U.S. corporate behavior in South Africa. When the ANC believes conditions for lifting sanctions have been met, these groups say, they will focus on monitoring compliance by multinational corporations with a code of conduct drafted by the ANC and Cosatu. (See box on page 2.)

The ANC is appealing to anti-apartheid forces to remain active in the new era.

"We need you now more than ever before," Lindiwe Mabuzo, the ANC's chief U.S. representative, told delegates to the New York conference. Mabuzo acknowledges that her movement has not always maintained adequate links with U.S. activists in the period marked by the ANC's legalization and the start of negotiations. The ANC, she says, must communicate more effectively to its supporters the challenges of marshaling the huge resources and direct aid needed for new priorities like running an election campaign, writing a constitution and building a health care system.

The purpose of the anti-apartheid movement, Mabuzo reminded the activists, was never simply to oust the apartheid regime. The goal was to "ensure real democratization" -- a difficult, protracted task that she said would require a strong network of allies abroad in order to succeed. *


LOAD-DATE: January 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


37 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


DECEMBER 7, 1992


LIBERIA'S CHILDREN COMING BACK FROM WAR


BYLINE: Cindy Shiner * Africa News Service


LENGTH: 1640 words


 

Monrovia, Liberia -The last George Brown saw of his brother and sister was their backs as they fled from rebel gunfire into the countryside.

"I wanted to follow them, and my ma said, 'No, stay with me,'" says Brown, who did not know his age, but looked 15. Shortly thereafter, the teenager was forced to fight alongside the same rebels who had chased off his brother and sister and his father, a former Liberian army soldier.

"'You wanna join us or you wanna follow your ma?' they asked me, and I said I wanted to follow my ma," he says. "They asked me: 'You know where your ma go? We killed your ma and if you not join up with us we will kill you.'" Brown, who has been fighting with the National Patriotic Front, led by Charles Taylor, is one of a number of youngsters who recently surrendered to West African troops protecting the capital, Monrovia. They have been taking part in a rebel assault on Monrovia which began in mid-October and say they are fed up with being scared and hungry in the swamps that surround the seaside city. 

Thousands of children like Brown are caught up in Liberia's war -- used and abused, forced into combat, drugged, abandoned and killed. A survey of 518 street children carried out by the United Nations Children's Fund (Unicef) last year found that 17% had witnessed the deaths of their parents. Many have witnessed the slaughter of their entire families.

Taylor's group is notorious for conscripting boys and girls to fight its guerrilla war. A rival rebel group, the United Liberation Movement (Ulimo) has also brought nine- to 18-year-old children into the fighting ranks, and youths have been part of Liberia's national army as well.

Inside the macabre world of warfare, the children have been forced to take part in ceremonies involving black magic, torture and murder. One 13-year-old had to slit a woman's throat to prove he was man enough to fight, or be killed himself, one social worker who works with children recounted recently. "It's the same woman he sees in his nightmares," says the social worker, who asks not to be named for fear of becoming a rebel target.

Maj. Gen. Adetunji Olurin, field commander of the seven-nation West African force, says the involvement of the youngsters is shocking. "We have children of our own, too," he says. "It is disgusting to see children drugged, walking like robots in the battlefield, firing away into no direction at all and getting killed. That is the result of a madman."

Liberia's civil war began in December 1989 when Taylor invaded from Cote d'Ivoire with a small band of rebels. At least 60,000 people died in the first year of fighting. Until the recent offensive, West African troops had kept a two-year-long uneasy peace, while diplomats sought to work out a political resolution. Since the recent attack began, the intervention force has held off the rebels in swamps surrounding the city, but hundreds of civilians have been killed in fighting in the suburbs and in bombing raids by West African aircraft.

When the war resumed recently, five-year-old Duo decided he wanted to change his name. Still traumatized by the killing he witnessed in 1990, he was afraid soldiers would find him and cut off the one leg he was left with after an army raid on Monrovia's Lutheran church two years ago. About 600 people, including Duo's brother and father, were killed in the attack by Liberian army soldiers. His mother escaped but has left him to the care of the church workers.

The fears of Duo and 24 other children who were crippled by the war, polio or birth defects, were compounded because they could not run from the gunfire that erupted in October. At the Benito Meni Rehabilitation Center where the children lived, one terrified 17-year-old who lost both legs in the Lutheran Church massacre heaved himself out of a wheelchair and hid under a table.

"Obviously, for a number of the children, they had been there before and it was just like a nightmare coming back," says Roman Catholic Father Joe Glackin, of Scotland, who works with orphans and former child combatants. "There is complete insecurity."

In the midst of the fighting, a brave Spanish priest, Justino Izquierdo, rescued the children from the rehabilitation center which was nearby to where five American nuns were killed a few days earlier.

The suffering here is rebounding on children in other ways as well. Relief workers say there have been several cases where hungry adults have befriended street children and brought them to shelters to get an allotment of the rice that is set aside for the youngsters. Other children are abandoned at shelters because parents know they will receive food and medical care there. Some deserted children and orphans live in wrecked cars, storage containers at the port and even dilapidated lottery booths.

Amid the grim tales of abuse and abandonment, Liberian church groups and non -governmental organizations, along with international relief agencies, have implemented several programs to help orphaned children and child soldiers.

Among them is a new facility that is opening this month by taking in 17 of the youths who recently surrendered to West African troops. The War-Affected Children's home, an old house donated by a Liberian, is being rehabilitated by orphans and former child combatants of the 1990 war, says Esther Guluma, who heads Unicef's education department in Monrovia.

Only children under the age of 15 will stay at the home -- this is the age at which children are supposed to receive protection from war by the Geneva Convention -- and the former combatants will be housed as prisoners of war. The yard is surrounded by a huge wall topped with shards of glass and is guarded by West African soldiers.

At the facility, the children will undergo psychological counseling, learn basic reading and writing skills, and have a program heavy with sports and carpentry. "They will be doing the work (to prepare) for the additional ones that, I'm afraid, will come later," says Guluma. Up to 150 children are expected to be housed at the home, she says.

Father Glackin says the more the former child soldiers feel they are contributing to society -- after having committed atrocities themselves -- the better chance they have at recovery from trauma and one day leading normal lives. "But it's on such a large scale; that's the scary thing," he says. "You're talking about thousands and thousands of children."

Len Capozzi, a psychological counselor who has worked with children traumatized by violence in Chicago's housing projects, says rehabilitation of war-affected children is essential to their reintegration into society. very serious, because if a child is traumatized and cannot get over the trauma and anxiety, it could lead to pathology later in life," including conduct disorders and social phobias, he says.

Roman Catholic Father Joe Brown, who works with former combatants of the 1990 war, says there is hope for young ex-soldiers. "The change in some of them is fantastic," he says. Many have learned skills such as carpentry and masonry. The more useful they see themselves in society, the less likely they are to relapse into drug use or return to combat, he says.


LOAD-DATE: January 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


38 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


DECEMBER 7, 1992


ANC/COSATU POSITION PAPER ON GUIDING PRINCIPLES FOR FOREIGN INVESTORS


LENGTH: 734 words


 

Below are excerpts from a document presented to a conference of anti-apartheid activists meeting in November in New York.

Introduction

The apartheid legislative process that governs investment at present is major obstacle to growth and development. In this context, the process of foreign investment needs to be assessed with care. 

At present, the basic International Labor Organization Conventions do not apply across South Africa. Discriminatory practices are widespread, and the lack of transparency in government is hiding corruption and inefficiency and promoting political violence and destabilization. Measures to protect the environment are weak, weakly implemented or non-existent. Investment in such a context will, therefore, not automatically contribute to growth, development or the eradication of apartheid.

Guiding Principles

We therefore propose that any investment after the lifting of the policy of economic sanctions should be guided by the following principles:

*Workers' Rights -- Companies should uphold workers' rights including the recognition of representative unions and their rights to bargain collectively, to strike, to picket peacefully; and strike breakers will not be hired.

*Investment should enhance employment creation.

*Equality of Opportunity -- Companies will eliminate all discrimination on the basis of race, religion, sex, political opinion or physical handicap and will implement affirmative action programs.

*Environmental Protection -- Investment must incorporate environmentally sound and clean practices and technology.

*Training and Education -- Investment should enhance the productive capacities of South Africans and should, in particular, institute training and adult education programs for workers in consultation with the trade union movement.

*Security of Employment -- Investment should contribute to the security of employment of South Africans.

*Empower Black Business -- Companies should, where possible, adopt business practices which enhance the development of black business in South Africa.

*Implementation -- Mechanisms should be put in place to evaluate the implementation of the above principles, including the disclosure of relevant information by companies.

Future Policies of a Democratic Government

It is our intention to have the above principles incorporated in the future policies and laws of a democratic government, and these will apply to all investors, domestic or foreign.

In the interim phase, we will campaign for these principles and will support the further development of codes of conduct along with other democratic formations.


LOAD-DATE: January 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


39 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


DECEMBER 7, 1992


COMPANIES READY FOR RETURN TO SOUTH AFRICA


BYLINE: Karen Gellen * Africa News Service


LENGTH: 2440 words


 

Conduct will Face Scrutiny by Sanctions Lobby

New York- Major U.S. companies are testing the waters for a plunge back into South Africa, despite the ongoing political turmoil there. Although most corporations are waiting for a green light from black South African leaders before actually investing, the corporate consensus seems to be that the time has come to prepare for doing business in the post-apartheid era.

Companies that pulled out of South Africa in response to demands by anti -apartheid campaigns, and those that never went in, are rushing to confer with the African National Congress (ANC), the country's largest political group, led by Nelson Mandela.

The South African-American Business Council, formed by a group of African American entrepreneurs last year during an ANC-endorsed tour of South Africa organized by the African American lobby TransAfrica, is seeking opportunities for cooperative ventures with black South African businesses.

The dozens of U.S. corporations that remained in South Africa also are positioning themselves for business in the near future under an ANC-led government. 

In partnership with the Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu), the country's largest labor federation, the ANC has drafted a "code of conduct" to guide corporate practices in South Africa. The draft calls for companies to guarantee fair labor practices such as collective bargaining and the right to strike, mandates equality of employment opportunity and environmental protection, and says that investment should enhance training and business opportunities, particularly for disadvantaged workers.

The proposed code has sparked a fierce lobbying effort, much like the one that accompanied the battle over sanctions in the 1980s. Some corporations are voicing strong opposition to any guidelines; others are entering into a dialogue with the ANC over the evolving policy; and some of the American groups that fought for sanctions are campaigning in support of the ANC and Cosatu code.

The debate surfaced last month at a forum on "Investment Opportunities in a New South Africa" at the World Trade Center in New York City. The event, attended by several top ANC officials and representatives of dozens of U.S. corporations, was part of a three-day conference organized by anti-apartheid leaders in the United States to discuss the transition to majority rule. At the forum, the ANC's Don Mkhwanazi unveiled the draft code, titled the "Platform of Guiding Principles for Investors." He said the ANC would seek to enshrine the code in law when a new South African government comes to power. The issue of mandatory compliance -- with the prospect of monitoring mechanisms in the U.S. -- is troubling to some U.S. corporations, who say the ANC may scare off vital investment.

One leading corporate spokesman, Sal Marzullo, says that by proposing the code , the ANC is sending "mixed signals" to investors about the post-apartheid economic climate. A former Mobil executive, Marzullo heads the Industry Support Unit, which serves 52 U.S. multinationals that have continued to operate in South Africa in defiance of the pressure to withdraw.

"Why do you need a code of conduct when multinationals behave very well without one?" Marzullo said in an interview. U.S. companies have spent $450 million on housing, education, job training and other social programs in South Africa since 1977, he says, and the cost of doing business there is "already higher than anywhere else in the world."

Most of the programs Marzullo refers to were adopted by U.S. companies aan alternative to pulling out of South Africa when public pressure for sanctions mounted. That corporate strategy grew out of an initiative by Leon Sullivan, an African American pastor and a member of the General Motors board of directors, who promoted a set of "good conduct" principles for American companies involved in South Africa in the early 1980s before he became an advocate of sanctions at the end of the decade.

Marzullo warns that a new code will drive away investment and bring the economy to ruin. "South Africa took centuries to build and could be destroyed in a decade," he says.

William C. Dunning, a vice president of Caltex Petroleum, the largest U.S. company operating in South Africa, and another leading figure in the Industry Support Unit, is equally blunt. "Business doesn't like government getting into its business," he says. Caltex, a subsidiary of Chevron and Texaco, which operates a large refinery in Cape Town and about a thousand service stations throughout the country, is also the largest American employer in South Africa.

Dunning says the ANC needs to articulate a liberal investment policy that welcomes business and would, for example, enable foreign companies to repatriate 100% of their profits for the first five years. Otherwise, the Caltex executive says, South Africa will lose out to its neighbors, like Zambia, which he says has a "very liberal" investment code, and Namibia and Mozambique, which are actively courting companies.

But Marzullo and Dunning acknowledge that South Africa remains particularly attractive to investors. The country has a prime geographic location, a developed market economy, a "world class" infrastructure, abundant natural resources and a huge potential domestic market. Dunning notes that black consumers now make up more than 50% of the country's buying power, a figure certain to grow in the post-apartheid era.

Some companies, rather than resisting the idea of a code of conduct, are opting to work with the ANC and Cosatu to help shape the guidelines. Apple Computer, which withdrew from South Africa in the mid-1980s, has sent executives to South Africa twice this year and has consulted with Nelson Mandela and Archbishop Desmond Tutu, among others.

One initiative that the ANC's Mkhwanazi welcomes as "exciting and progressive" comes from the Executive Leadership Council, an organization of 100 African Americans who are vice presidents in Fortune 500 companies.

A leader of the group, Honeywell's Mannie Jackson, says U.S. business can either "put its head in the sand, or try to influence what the eventual code of conduct will be." The council has published its own proposed code, which Jackson says is being reviewed by 150 chief executives, together with each company's senior black employees. "We want to be involved on the front end," says Jackson, "in specifying future codes of conduct."

He says that as "the first generation of African Americans to invade corporate America," council members have unique insights to offer, particularly in "avoiding some of the mistakes we made in our own affirmative action days."

The council's draft code calls on U.S. companies to fund a nationwide Head Start program in South Africa, to prioritize the training of black professionals, to increase black membership on their boards to at least 30% by the year 2000, and to use mainly black suppliers.

Some anti-apartheid activists are critical of the Executive Council's approach. According to Sister Barbara Ayers, who earlier this year represented church investors at a conference on codes of conduct sponsored by the South African Council of Churches, Jackson's initiative could become a "critical diversion" from ANC and Cosatu efforts to promulgate a universally recognized code.

Unlike an earlier draft of the code of conduct prepared by Cosatu that focused exclusively on outside firms, the current ANC/Cosatu version is aimed at "all investors, domestic or foreign." The latest draft also adds provisions designed to enhance the development of black entrepreneurs, a provision that initially was resisted by the trade unions, whose focus is on labor rights and opportunities for workers.

According to Israel Skosana, who heads South Africa's largest black-owned corporation, the National Sorghum Breweries, black business accounts for less than two percent of South Africa's gross domestic product. Skosana says he founded his company -- which uses only black suppliers and has 85% black management -- by going door-to-door in black communities to sell tiny share holdings. There are now 10,000 individual stockholders in National Sorghum Breweries. He calls his company, which employs 4,l00 mainly unionized workers, a "deliberate act of black economic empowerment."

Speaking on the World Trade Center panel, Skosana appealed to U.S. businesses to see National Sorghum as a model for promoting black entrepreneurial expansion.

While many companies react negatively to the prospect of a mandatory investment code, American anti-apartheid groups see the guidelines as a vehicle for continuing to pressure for change. But the activists say they are sensitive to South Africa's need to attract outside investors.

According to Richard Knight, research director of the American Committee on Africa (ACOA) in New York, who traveled to South Africa in October for discussions on the code with Cosatu and ANC officials, the guidelines are aimed at preventing abuses, not discouraging investors. South African trade unionists "are not expecting the same wages a company would pay in New York, but they don't want to bring in sweatshop labor," he says. What they want is "quality investment" in the country, Knight says.

Donna Katzin, director of South Africa programs for the New York-based Interfaith Center on Corporate Responsibility, which has spearheaded the church -sponsored shareholder campaigns aimed at forcing companies out, says self -interest will lure many companies back. Clear, mutually understood terms for doing business will be an advantage, Katzin says, because they will contribute to limiting conflict and promoting the stability that multinationals view as essential.

Anti-apartheid groups already are exploring ways to ensure corporate compliance with the code. Last summer, the ACOA was instrumental in securing the passage of resolutions supporting "socially responsible investment" in the post-sanctions era by both the U.S. Conference of Mayors and the National Conference of State Legislatures.

Action by those groups was seen as significant, because it was city councils and state legislatures that led the moves toward wider anti-apartheid sanctions in the United States during the last decade. Even now, almost 18 months after the Bush administration lifted the restrictive measures against South Africa adopted by Congress in 1986, leaving in place only an arms embargo, 26 states and some 100 cities are heeding the ANC's call to maintain sanctions until a multiracial interim government in installed.

But anti-apartheid groups concede that identifying infringements of a new investment code will not be as easy as fingering sanctions violators. The Investor Responsibility Research Center, a Washington, DC-based corporate monitoring group, says that measuring compliance will be tricky, since the draft proposals are stated as broad, social goals rather than as specific targets for such things as training programs.

Still, activist groups hope that the precedent of the successful sanctions campaigns will persuade U.S. companies that their behavior in a new South Africa will be closely scrutinized at home. "We may have to hold their feet to the fire," says ACOA's Knight, to ensure that corporations adhere to whatever code of conduct is finally adopted.

"South Africa is not just another place where U.S. companies are doing business," he says. "Because of the whole struggle against apartheid, people in this country have a special place in their hearts for South Africa." *


LOAD-DATE: January 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


40 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 2, 1992 / June 7, 1992


Probes Tie South African Officials to Assassinations Community Leaders Go Into Hiding


LENGTH: 1187 words


Africa News Service

A South African newspaper has published new evidence to support its report, earlier this month, that top government officials ordered the 1985 murders of four political activists in the Eastern Cape region.

The New Nation, a Johannesburg weekly, says it has located and interviewed the official who signed a top secret memo published by the newspaper, and that he has confirmed the authenticity of the document. The memo records a telephone conversation about the killings between Gen. C.P. van der Westhuizen, now chief of staff of Military Intelligence, and a Gen. van Rensburg, a senior member of the State Security Council, a cabinet-level body that no longer exists but that included three people currently serving as government ministers.

The latest report is part of a series of investigations by South African journalists into the causes of continuing violence in South Africa. The revelations appear to support charges of high-level government complicity in political assassinations as well as in fomenting conflicts which have killed thousands of people in black townships.
