In a March 20 statement, the African National Congress (ANC) and other anti-apartheid groups said the newest information forces them to reconsider their participation in the National Peace Accord, a pact signed last September that was designed to end the violence and establish structures for negotiating a peaceful transition to democracy.

Meanwhile, in the townships where bloody assaults and confrontations have become routine, many activists have returned to the old habits of life underground: not spending too much time in one place, sleeping in different locations each night, and trusting only a few people to know their whereabouts.

The most dramatic information on government involvement in the killings has been published by the New Nation, aimed primarily at blacks, and the Weekly Mail, whose readers are mostly white. The two papers have been both competing and collaborating, coming up with scoops in separate probes but sharing information and checking on the credibility of each other's sources. The result is a continuing parade of exposes, with each journal confirming and then expanding upon revelations published in the other.

The accusations come at a time when President F.W. de Klerk had hoped to gain strength from the overwhelming endorsement of his policies of negotiation by an all-white referendum in March. The president, who so far has not been named in the assassination charges, appears to be trying to contain the damage by refocusing attention on the future.

That tactic, says Cape Town University political scientist William Schrire, is doomed to fail. "The obvious analogy," Schrire told the Reuters news agency, "is that of a member of the Nazi party trying to establish democracy in Germany and thinking he can escape the legacy of the past."

Part of that legacy, according to the New Nation, is the June 1985 memo which records van Rensburg and van der Westhuizen's agreement that prominent community organizer Matthew Goniwe and three colleagues must be "permanently removed from society, as a matter of urgency." The bodies of the four men were found three weeks later, on June 29.

After de Klerk questioned the authenticity of the memo, the New Nation tracked down Lt. Lourens du Plessis, who had drafted and signed the document as a record of the two officials' telephone conversation. The memo was sent to the attention of the State Security Council marked "extremely secret."

As bad as conditions were at the time of the 1985 killings, many activists say the situation today is at least as bad and getting steadily worse. A recent report by the Southern Africa Project of the Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law in Washington, DC, says that an average of 45 more people each month are dying in political violence this year, compared to last year. In 1991, sixty political activists, all belonging to the ANC, were killed compared to 21 the previous year.

A Weekly Mail report says that in the Vaal triangle, which includes Johannesburg and Pretoria, at least seven ANC members were killed in April alone. The Vaal Council of Churches has been documenting dozens of instances of kidnappings, murders, harassment and police intimidation of activists and their families.

The Mail also warns that the violence is threatening to spiral out of anyone's ability to control. It says that some former members of the ANC's armed wing have taken advantage of the chaos in the townships by acting as street gangs, collecting levies and imposing protection fees on residents.

The ANC says the government is pursuing "low intensity warfare," aimed at weakening the other parties in the negotiations on a future constitution.

Constitutional talks stalemated this month over the issue of what percentage of voters could alter a projected interim constitution, which is supposed to be a transition stage between white rule and majority rule. The government says a 75% vote will be necessary in order to protect minority rights. The ANC and its allies accused the government of trying to insure that the interim constitution -- although less than fully democratic -- "would be irremovable except by an excessively high majority."

There also remains continuing suspicion about the de Klerk government's sincerity in wanting to stop the violence, which some feel give it an excuse to maintain control.

The current issue of the New Nation reports that the government is working hard for a general amnesty agreement that would enable police and government officials to be absolved of legal guilt for ordering or carrying out violence against dissidents. The Weekly Mail has previously reported that a police constable, sentenced to 18 years for killing activists, has been released after serving 17 months. The paper revealed that four other policemen convicted of political murders have been freed after serving only small portions of their sentences. n


LOAD-DATE: May 26, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


41 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 11, 1992


GE linked to South African diamond caper


LENGTH: 134 words


The U.S. Justice Department is investigating charges that General Electric and a South African diamond cartel, DeBeers Consolidated Mines Ltd., conspired to fix the price of industrial diamonds. 

The Wall Street Journal reported that Justice Department officials began the investigation after a former GE executive filed a lawsuit outlining the alleged scheme and other improprieties. The GE executive claims he was discharged after repeatedly protesting efforts to fix prices of industrial diamonds. A company spokesperson told the Wall Street Journal that he was removed for "performance shortcomings."


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


42 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 11, 1992


EC approaches North Africa


LENGTH: 200 words


European Community (EC) foreign ministers this week will discuss forging stronger economic and political links with Algeria, Morocco and Tunisia.

Twelve ministers meeting in Brussels will consider a plan to establish free trade, foster market economies and encourage investments with the three nations. 

Libya was excluded from the overture because that country is on poor terms with the EC, especially after its refusal to turn over suspects in the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103. Mauritania already receives trade preference from the EC.

An Inter Press Service International story speculated that EC interest in strengthening ties with Algeria, Morocco and Tunisia is motivated by the EC's desire for an agreement to allow 700 EC fishing boats in Moroccan waters, and fear that high unemployment in the three countries will drive their citizens to Europe looking for work.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


43 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 11, 1992


Ties resumed


LENGTH: 134 words


 

Mauritania and Senegal in late April restored diplomatic relations broken in 1989, following a violent dispute over cattle grazing on the banks of the river that separates the two countries. Borders were shut after more than 300 were killed during the dispute, which led to attacks on black Africans in Mauritania and to the looting of Mauritian shops in Senegal.

Mauritania and Senegal announced the restoration April 23rd, after a visit to the Senegalese capital of Dakar by the Mauritian minister of foreign affairs and cooperation. They also announced the resumption of air and postal links and the planned reopening of borders.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


44 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 11, 1992


Opposition seats up


LENGTH: 254 words


 

An opposition member replaced a ruling party member as prime minister of Rwanda in April and formed a new coalition government.

Four opposition parties had planned a rally in March to protest 60 deaths that month due to fighting between the majority Hutu and minority Tutsi ethnic groups. But the opposition cancelled the rally when they were promised one of their members would be named prime minister.

Dismas Nsengiyareme, the leader of the Republican Democratic Movement, was named prime minister April 3rd, by President Juvenal Habyarimana of the National Republican Movement for Development (NRMD), which has ruled as the only legal party since 1975.

On April 16th, Nsengiyareme named nine members of the ruling party to his cabinet, giving the NRMD the defense, interior, planning and youth posts, and reserving the rest of the posts, including foreign affairs and education, for the opposition.

NRMD members held 16 of 17 cabinet posts in the former government.

The new government is expected to call multiparty elections and to try to reach a peace settlement with a predominately Tutsi rebel movement in the north.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


45 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 11, 1992


Chad OK's opposition


LENGTH: 133 words


 

The government of Chad has authorized two opposition parties, the first in 20 years, in preparation for a national conference this month and elections later this year. But violence threatens the country's transition toward democracy: a co-founder of one of the opposition parties was killed in January 1992, by security forces.

In February, the vice president of the Chadian Human Rights League was murdered, six people died during an unsuccessful coup attempt, and 78 people were killed in reprisal by President Idriss Deby's guard, according to the human rights league.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


46 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 11, 1992


Prime minister out


LENGTH: 160 words


Sao Tome and Pr ncipe's first elected prime minister lost his job in late April following protests against an economic austerity program he implemented. 

President Miguel Trovoada fired Daniel Daio April 22nd, a day after the Movement for the Liberation of Sao Tome and Pr ncipe organized a demonstration of several thousand and called for a general strike.

Trovoada was elected with Daio in March 1991, with the country's transition to democracy, but began distancing himself from Daio as economic reforms recommended by the International Monetary Fund became increasingly unpopular. However, sources say the new prime minister proposed by Daio's ruling Democratic Convergence Party is expected to continue the austerity program.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


47 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 11, 1992


Democracy moves in Tanzania


LENGTH: 187 words


 

Tanzania's ruling party, Chama Cha Mapinduzi (CCM), has voluntarily begun the process of relinquishing their three-decade-old monopoly on power. Parlimentary debate now underway is expected to result in multiparty elections in 1995. 

Since taking over from founding President Julius Nyerere, current President Ali Hassan Mwinyi has been transforming the state-controlled economy his predecessor created. Mwinyi's market-oriented economy has cut inflation, boosted growth and won him the support of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, which pledged $ 1 billion in aid for agriculture and mining.

Eager for reform in the political arena, CCM's oppostion has formed five parties in the last year and has called for multiparty elections to be held next year, rather than in 1995, as is presently proposed in the country's parliment.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


48 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 11, 1992


Togolese demonstrate


LENGTH: 254 words


Opposition parties, religious groups and market women have taken to Togo's streets since January to protest the continuing pressure the military is exerting on the country's move toward democracy.

A national conference held in August 1991, had begun the process of stripping power from President Gnassingbe Eyadema, Togo's dictator for the last 24 years. Joseph Koffigoh was named the country's new prime minister, and a series of elections were scheduled for April 1992.

In December 1991, Eyadema's soldiers arrested Koffigoh. The coalition backing Koffigoh, in an effort to appease Eyadema and his military, agreed to the appointment of three Eyadema allies to Koffigoh's cabinet, and the new prime minister was released from custody.

Since the appointment of the new cabinet ministers, the April elections have been postponed and a referendum on a new constitution has been set for May 31st. Presidential elections are scheduled for August 1992.

Meanwhile, Koffigoh has ordered an investigation into the attack last week on a political rally in the north of the country. Gilchrist Olympio, an opposition leader and son of a former Togolese president, was wounded. Three people were reported killed.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


49 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 11, 1992


Ghana lifts ban


LENGTH: 214 words


 

An 11-year ban on political parties in Ghana will be lifted later this month, according to terms of a new constitution overwhelmingly approved by voters in an April 28th referendum.

The new constitution provides for an elected president and legislature. Presidential elections are scheduled for November 3rd and parliamentary elections for December 8th. The new constitution also protects members of the ruling Provisional National Defense Council (PNDC) from prosecution by future governments.

Political parties had been banned since Flt.-Lt. Jerry Rawlings seized power in a 1981 coup.

Opponents of Rawlings have called for an interim government to run the country until elections are held. They also called for an end to laws restricting political expression and for the release of political prisoners. Some opponents boycotted the assembly that produced the constitution on the grounds that members of the ruling PNDC controlled the gathering.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


50 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 11, 1992


Algerian call to arms


LENGTH: 227 words


 

A bulletin distributed April 20th in Algiers called on Islamic fundamentalists there to "move from the word to the gun." It is the first official opposition call to violence, although about 50 police have been killed since January in the attacks the government blames on the Islamic Salvation Front (FIS). 

The FIS was set to win control of a new parliament after the first round of elections December 26th. But in January former President Chadli Bendjedid called off a second round, created a National Consultative Council to take parliament's place, then resigned, leaving the government to the newly-formed High Council of State (HCE). More than 100 people were killed early in the year in clashes between government opponents and police before the authorities declared a state of emergency February 9th, arresting about 9,000 FIS supporters and sending about 7,000 without charge to camps in the Sahara Desert. A court officially banned the FIS March 5th.

The bulletin began circulating in mosques and markets the day the council Bendjedid created began sessions.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


51 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 11, 1992


Mali chooses leader


LENGTH: 200 words


Alpha Oumar Konare, a founder of the party that forced president Moussa Traore from power last year, was elected president of Mali in late April with about 70 % of the vote. One-fifth of those eligible cast ballots April 26th, in the country's first free elections. 

The country's former finance minister, Tieoule Mamadou Konare, received about 30 % of the vote.

Konare, a 46-year-old historian and former youth minister, helped found the Alliance for Democracy in Mali (ADEMA), which organized strikes and protests against Traore's 22-year military rule. Up to 200 were killed in March 1991 when the government sent troops to put down demonstrations. Military officers, led by paratroop Lt.-Col. Amadou Toumani Toure, took power in a coup later that month. Toure formed a transitional government, with a civilian prime minister, that pledged to return the country to civilian rule and establish the first democracy in Mali since independence.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


52 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 11, 1992


Summit tackles violence


SECTION: BITS & PIECES


LENGTH: 267 words


Church officials and leaders of 18 black political groups met in Johannesburg April 22nd to seek a way to end the wave of violence gripping South Africa. A release from the South African Council of Churches says that the political leaders hold the the ruling National Party responsibile for the violence. The release quotes the leaders: "The structural injustices of apartheid as well as the agencies of the apartheid regime are the primary sources of violence."

The Council of Churches said the participants also agreed that they share responsibility for the continuance of the violence.

"We were not into the game of finger pointing," said Anglican archbishop and Nobel Laureate Desmond Tutu, who attended the summit. "We said we as a community need to be involved in an exercise of introspection to determine why it is that black people do kill black people."

Invitations to the summit were extended to organizations with large black constituencies most directly affected by the violence. Representatives of government, military and police were not invited, but church leaders are seeking a separate meeting with them.

Summit participants called for an international mechanism to monitor the violence.

54 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 11, 1992


Djibouti


SECTION: FAST FACTS


LENGTH: 120 words


Size: 8,958 square miles, about the size of New Hampshire.

Population: 483,00 (1987 official estimate)

Djibouti is officially on the way to democracy, after 15 years under a single party dominated by one of the country's two main ethnic groups. But rebels in the north remain skeptical of the government's commitment to multiparty elections and will likely break a March cease-fire that ended four months of fighting. About one in 10 people in the country is a refugee.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


55 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 11, 1992


Sudan


SECTION: FAST FACTS


LENGTH: 160 words


 

Size: 967,500 square miles, about the size of the United States east of the Mississippi River. 

Population: 20,564,364

Drought in the north and the biggest government offensive in the nine-year-old civil war against rebels in the south have left a third of the population in urgent need of aid. Hundreds in the south -- where fighting and disputes over aid distribution cut relief routes -- have already starved. Despite a string of government victories during the recent dry season, the country remains divided between the Islamic authorities in the north and two rebel factions in the Christian, animist south, with peace talks scheduled for later this month.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


56 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 11, 1992


Somalia


SECTION: FAST FACTS


LENGTH: 134 words


Size: 246,201 square miles, a little smaller than Texas.

Population: 7,339,000 (UN estimate, mid-1989)

Four and a half million people face hunger and disease in a country splintering along kinship lines after the January 1991, ouster of dictator Mohamed Siad Barre. Large-scale fighting threatens to break out in the northeast and a long-term national settlement is nowhere in sight. But a tense peace in the capital of Mogadishu has allowed the first major shipment of relief food in five months to reach the city, where 50 to 100 people were dying daily.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


57 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 11, 1992


Ethiopia


SECTION: FAST FACTS


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Size: 483,123 square miles, about the size of California, Nevada, Utah and Arizona combined; Eritrea, a former Italian colony annexed by Ethiopia in 1962, is about the size of Indiana (36,183 square miles).

Population: 49,513,000; Eritrea, 2,614,699

Multiparty elections in Ethiopia and a referendum in Eritrea on the territory's independence are scheduled for next year. Hopes for peace and democracy are widespread following the overthrow of military ruler Mengistu Haile Mariam last year. But 30 years of war have left much of the country in ruins, and banditry and clashes over land and power plague the southeast. About eight million people need immediate aid. In some parts of the southeast, people are already starving. The hunger and deprivation threaten the transition to democracy.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


58 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 11, 1992


HORN OF MISERY


LENGTH: 2547 words


In Akobo, a Sudanese town of 45,000 on the border with Ethiopia, relief worker John Jock Chol radioed a call for help to the projects director of an aid coordinating group in neighboring Kenya.

"Two thousand returnees arrived (yesterday) from Pochala," said Chol's March 23rd message. "Many are seriously wounded. They are in very bad condition. Thousands and thousands are still coming. If food is delayed, all the arrivals will die. Please try ways and means through the UN."

Three weeks earlier the Sudanese government had banned all UN flights to the refugee-swollen towns of Akobo, Nasir and Waat in southeastern Sudan. Many of the desperate people Chol saw were triply displaced by the region's shifting wars and had trekked back and forth across the Sudanese/Ethiopian border. 

"These people have lost everything," Chol radioed March 25th. "They are staying under trees naked."

Two days later: "We are dying. Seven children died last night and more will die today."

April 10th: "Twenty-three people starved yesterday. Everybody is weak and waiting to die. The pastors' wives and others went to Gagwang nine days ago looking for food; they have not returned. We don't know if we will be on radio next week. It depends on God's will. We hope that some will remain."

The desperation in those pleas is echoed across the area known as the Horn of Africa. Chol's messages could just as well be the voice of a person in a forced relocation camp in the Sudanese desert, searching for food, water and shelter as the temperature rises; or the voice of a refugee in eastern Ethiopia, stranded in a strange city that relief organizations have abandoned to bandits; or that of a resident of the Somali capital Mogadishu, starving while watching ships loaded with food turn away from port because of shelling between rival militias.

At least 23 million people in Somalia, Sudan, Ethiopia, Eritrea and Djibouti are at risk from starvation, epidemics and disease, according to the UN Special Emergency Programme for the Horn of Africa (Sepha). Thousands have already died.

War and famine have forced more than eight million people in the region from their homes during the last year. More than a million have crossed national borders and at least seven million are on the move within their own countries.

Now the flood of refugees has spread to Kenya and as far south as Uganda, countries that are themselves experiencing drought and shortages. By late April, the number of refugees in Kenya had reached 180,000; that number is expected to rise to 340,000 by the end of June.

Humanitarian organizations warn that 1992-93 may be a repeat--or worse--of the 1894-85 famine that killed a million people.

While lack of rain contributes to the problem, it is the numerous and intractable armed conflicts that have displaced families, disrupted crop production, blocked relief supplies and spawned banditry.

In many ways, the misery is a Cold War legacy. Although feuds over land and cattle have been commonplace for generations, the deadliness of the current fighting and the widespread anarchy are new, fueled by proxy wars where superpowers vie for influence in the region.

Through the 1980s, the United States and the Soviet Union poured more than $ 13 billion of military assistance into the Horn, piling up arms and debtsthat will long outlast their own rivalry.

The complexity of the region's quarrels and the magnitude of events elsewhere have averted world attention from the creeping disaster. "People are talking about it, but there is no material response," laments Fesseha Tessema, a counselor at Ethiopia's UN mission. "People have to die on the television screen before something happens. After they die, to be on television, that doesn't help them."

And there is a measure of impatience in newsrooms or policy forums when the subject of famine in the Horn of Africa arises.

"There is a certain compassion fatigue which sets in," says U.S. Assistant Secretary of State for Africa, Herman Cohen. "Now, of course, we have the southern African drought, which is competing with the Horn on the humanitarian side. There's just not enough money to take care of every tragedy. And it seems to me that the natural disaster tragedies probably have greater priority than man-made. I think people who continue to make war with impunity have to understand that the West cannot just keep on feeding everyone indefinitely."

Aid agencies agree that farmers in the Horn need peace to feed themselves. But relief workers argue that, in the short term, emergency assistance is essential.

Even when aid is available, however, successful delivery requires heroic efforts. Relief efforts must contend with shelling of airports, seaports and hospitals, looting of supplies, thefts of vehicles, hijacking of planes and direct military attacks on food convoys and offices. Alain Peters, director of the New York office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, says that at least 15 aid workers have lost their lives in the Horn.

The situation in Somalia has become so bad that the International Committee of the Red Cross, for the first time in their history, has hired armed escorts. Relief organizations temporarily withdrew staff from southern Sudan, eastern Ethiopia, northern Somalia and from the Somali capital of Mogadishu in recent months.

While the countries of the Horn share refugees, they each have unique problems that will need differing solutions.

In Somalia, a civil war ended a year and a half ago with the ousting of strongman ruler Mohamed Siad Barre. But instead of shedding their arms, the former dictator's opponents began to fight with each other. While four and a half million Somalis, 60% of the population, go hungry, struggles for power rage across the country. The bloodiest struggle is in the capital, where forces of General Mohamed Aidid Farrah and interim Somali President Ali Mahdi face off across city streets and neighborhoods. The Washington, D.C.-based Africa Watch and Physicians for Human Rights estimate 14,000 people were killed and 27,000 wounded in the capital between November and February.

Voluntary organizations blame both men for continuing a meaningless conflict. "They have unleased a monster they cannot control," says Fawzi Guleid, who represents a Somali humanitarian group. "They do not have any clearly stated political agenda or share anything save deep-rooted distrust and personal animosity. They are very capable of prolonging the misery of the people indefinitely."

In recent weeks there has been some wary optimism that international pressure might force the antagonists to settle. UN negotiators have persuaded Aidid and Mahdi, as well as the leaders of factions outside the capital, to respect "zones of peace" within which relief organizations can safely distribute aid.

On April 21st, UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali announced a 90-day plan of action to provide food, seeds, basic health services and water to the 1.5 million Somalis in the most acute danger of dying, as well as to another 3.5 million with urgent needs. Three days later, the Security Council approved sending 50 unarmed monitors to observe a cease-fire between Aidid and Mahdi. The council postponed endorsing the deployment of 500 soldiers to escort food convoys, although it backed the idea in principle.

On May 2nd a UN ship carrying 5,000 tons of wheat docked in the port of Mogadishu and began offloading its grain. A few days earlier, Red Cross ships landed cargos totaling 12,000 tons,

While the supplies are a stop-gap solution to a vast problem, it was the first time in over five months that sizable amounts of food had reached the capital.

The end of a four-month rebellion in Djibouti in March has brought at least a temporary peace in the former French colony, where French troops are monitoring the cease fire. However, government opponents have threatened to renew their fight unless the authorities free political prisoners and make good on their commitment to multiparty elections. About 100,000 in the country are refugees from Somalia and Ethiopia.

One in three people in Sudan will need food aid this year, after droughts and nearly a decade of civil war between the Arabic-speaking Islamic government in Khartoum and black African rebels seeking greater autonomy and power for the largely Christian south of the country.

The Sudan Peoples' Liberation Front (SPLF), which has led the fight against northern domination and the imposition of sharia, the Islamic code of law, has itself split into two factions.

A government offensive against the rebels, coming after floods in 1991, has left 300,000 southerners in desperate need. As many as 4 million people have fled their homes, the U.S. Agency for International Development estimates.

The government and both SPLF factions are scheduled to meet for peace talks May 27th in the Nigerian capital of Abuja, according to Siraj H. Yousis, counselor at Sudan's mission to the UN. He said the agenda includes ending the fighting and reaching a political settlement that will keep the south within Sudan.

But, in recent weeks, there has been increasing speculation in international diplomatic circles that elements of the Sudanese government might be ready to consider the eventual secession of the south. Early this month, according to reports from UPI, the Cairo newspaper Al Alam Al Youm said that Hassan Al Turabi, head of the ruling Sudanese Islamic Front, is discussing such a plan with Western governments.

Of all the Horn's countries, Ethiopia and the territory of Eritrea appear to have the greatest chance to break the cycle of famine and war. Rebel forces that overthrew Mengistu Haile Mariam a year ago adopted a national charter that set the country on a two-year path toward democracy. And an interim government is pressing for peace.

In Eritrea, which was annexed by former Ethiopian emperor Haile Selassie in 1962, a referendum on independence is scheduled for April 1993. The Eritrean Peoples' Liberation Front, which is governing during the transition period, has promised multiparty elections if Eritrea becomes a separate state. The provisional government has set former fighters to work rebuilding the territory's houses, schools, water systems and health centers destroyed by war.

Still, most of Eritrea's 3.2 million people need food aid to avert a famine larger than that of a decade ago, according to the New York-based Women's Committee for Refugee Women and Children. And Ethiopian church leaders warned at an April 1st press conference that millions of refugees, displaced people and ex-soldiers will die without aid to stem starvation and epidemics.

Leah Leatherbee, director of the Horn of Africa Program of the Fund for Peace in New York, has general praise for the transitional government's respect for human rights. But she warns that if the economy fails to recover quickly, "competition for scarce resources will likely develop along some of the ethnic, religious or social fault lines already visible."

At a humanitarian summit last month, leaders of Dijbouti, Kenya, Sudan, Ethiopia and Eritrea agreed to create "corridors of tranquility" that would ensure the safety of relief workers and the unimpeded distribution of aid. Just prior to the meeting, Congressman Tony Hall of Ohio told the House Africa subcommittee that he was encouraged by the steps being taken. "I am excited about the new role the United States can play," he said, "not as a 'superpower' but as a 'superpartner' with the nations of the Horn."

For that to happen, conflicts must be stopped and famine avoided -- a prospect that remains bleak as long as world attention is focused elsewhere.

The Rev. William Lowrey, projects director for the Nairobi, Kenya-based Association of Christian Resource Organizations Serving Sudan, said that as many as 300 people died in the town of Akobo before the Sudanese government lifted its ban on UN relief flights on April 19th. More than half the townspeople are malnourished, he says.

But relief flights are continuing and food and seeds are being delivered. The deaths of thousands in the town, feared by Chol, were prevented.

Akobo was just one fortunate place that happened to have a radio, Lowrey said. "In a strange twist of events," he mused, "the voices of Akobo were heard. But the voiceless hundreds of thousands across southern Sudan still feel helpless and unheard. The greatest good that could come from this would be if the cries of Akobo would now draw attention to those in far worse shape who cannot speak and are cut off from all help."

-- Karen Lange


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


59 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 11, 1992


LETTERS


LENGTH: 1254 words


 

We cherish letters from our readers. Address your comments and opinions to: The Editor, Africa News, Box 3851, Durham, NC 27702, USA

I subscribed when I realized that reading AfricaNews informed me about countries I didn't even know existed! I find the mass media (including NPR, though with more exceptions than the rest) focuses on preserving the status quo. I count on you to be a source of information without the propaganda agenda -- left or right.

As someone who produces organic food for a living, I particularly value articles like the one on the devastating effects of coffee and chocolate prices on Cote d'Ivoire. 

Patrick Battle

Burnsville, North Carolina

I have been a subscriber for close to 10 years, and I find AfricaNews to be a very informative publication.

I belong to several national and worldwide hunger organizations which make solicitations for contributions for countries experiencing drought and hunger. However, these organizations don't go much further than saying there is a crisis situation. And, because some of their newsletters publish quarterly, they are not a source of current information. Sometimes you never learn if the situation ever returned to normal. I guess the situation just "fades away."

I always check AfricaNews for current reports on countries that I have learned are experiencing drought, hunger, or starvation.

In the last two or three years, I have been following civil war and hunger related situations in the Horn of Africa. I believe it was 1989-90, that civil war claimed some 500,000 lives in the Sudan. In late 1990, and early 1991, various organizations were releasing estimates of some 20 million people at risk in the Horn.

The Sudan civil war continues. Ethiopian rebels have overthrown their government and Eritrea has won its freedom, but hunger continues in those countries. The political situation in Somalia has exploded, and earlier this year thousands reportedly faced starvation outside of Mogadishu.

In Equatorial Guinea, Burundi and Uganda, one-party governments and their dictators suppress all opposition. Disappearances, torture, and brutality are commonplace.

I would like to see comprehensive and continuing coverage of these situations by AfricaNews in order to keep concerned people informed and, therefore, able to take various actions to alleviate suffering.

Rick Gadus

Cleveland, Ohio

On October 21, 1988, a group of African scholars attending the annual meeting of the Financial Management Association (FMA) in New Orleans, Louisiana, launched the African Finance & Economics Association (AFEA). What occasioned the birth of the association was the virtual lack of African issues on the current research agenda of American universities.

Since its founding, the association has undertaken several projects. In 1989, we conducted a symposium on the African debt crisis under the auspices of the Financial Management Association (FMA). In 1990, we organized a special session on "Current Perspectives on African Finance and Economics" under the auspices of the Allied Social Science Association (ASSA). In January 1992, under the auspices of the ASSA, the AFEA held a symposium, "Europe 1992, and its Implications for African Economies."

The aforementioned activities are just the beginning. A major mission of the AFEA is to harness the expertise of African scholars (i.e., financial analysts and economists) in order to conduct meaningful research on economic, financial and business related issues on African economies.

We will continue to organize symposiums to discuss, in practical terms, issues that are germane to the growth and development of Africa. These symposia are slated for Washington, DC, on September 25, 1992, and Nairobi, Kenya, in August 1993. We have also embarked on the publication of The Journal of African Finance and Economic Development, designed as our association's research arm.

Robert G. Sherman, Ph. D.

Assistant Professor of Finance and

Banking and President, AFEA

Glendale, AZ

The referendum for Western Sahara, sponsored by the United Nations Security Council and General Assembly to end the 17-year-long war in the former Spanish Sahara, is fast becoming a casualty of bad faith, mismanagement, and cynical manipulation. Originally scheduled to be held last January, the "free and fair referendum" is in danger from reported Moroccan obstruction of the process; from apparent financial and organizational mismanagement within the UN; and from changeover in the leadership in the office of the secretary-general.s

In a letter to the Security Council last January, Secretary-General Boutros-Ghali suggested that if several issues concerning the referendum could be resolved, that he might propose a solution other than a vote. His report is scheduled to be given to the Security Council at the end of this month.

Several hearings by the House Subcommittee on Africa and letters from members of the House and the Senate to President Bush and to Secretary of State James Baker to give strong support to a legitimate referendum appear to have had little effect on the White House to date.

I urge your readers to write President Bush, Secretary of State James Baker, and Secretary-General Boutros-Ghali of the United Nations, urging full commitment of the U.S. and the U.N. to the free and fair referendum advocated by the UN and the Organization of African Unity. With Secretary-General Boutros-Khali's new report scheduled for the end of May, action is needed NOW.

Anne Lippert

Saharan People's Support Committee Newsletter


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


60 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 11, 1992


VIEWPOINT:SOUTHERN AFRICA DROUGHT THREATENS SPREAD OF PEACE, DEMOCRACY


LENGTH: 1240 words


 

People in southen Africa are scared, and they have a right to be. Their corn fields lie scorched and wasted by the region's worst drought in decades. Cattle are dying. Water sources are drying up just as the long dry season begins.

National emergencies have been declared throughout the region and an international relief effort has been initiated. Some diplomats and aid officials, however, are concerned that donor fatigue and a perceived tilt by the West toward eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union are blunting our sense of urgency and willingness to respond. 

When I left southern Africa in April, late rains had restored an illusory patina of green to the landscape. Compared to the Horn of Africa or the Sahel -- the more traditional range for killer droughts -- much of southern Africa seemed almost verdant to the casual observer. A closer look, however, revealed that what appeared to be healthy stands of corn -- the region's staple -- actually bore no cobs or kernels. The almost total lack of rain during the critical growing period in January and February aborted as much as half the region's harvest.

The food security unit of the 10-nation Southern African Development Coordination Conference (SADCC) estimates that the corn harvest will be 40% less than last year's below-average production. SADCC members expect to import 7 million metric tons of corn and other cereals to meet the shortfall. South Africa, which normally exports corn to its neighbors, will import another 4 million tons. The region thus will need about 12 million tons in the coming year. Ethiopia, during its 1984-85 apocalypse, imported less than 2 million tons.

Southern Africa drought victims are not expected to congregate in large camps where their misery can be observed en masse by the international media. The suffering and dying will be largely hidden, as it was in 1983 when 100,000 Mozam-bicans quietly starved to death beyond the world's notice.

While frequently subject to localized droughts, southern Africa is essentially a self-sustaining region in food production. Most people, in most years, are able to raise a crop. This drought, however, has engulfed the entire region with volcanic suddenness, catching villagers and governments alike unprepared.

Zimbabwe, for instance, in recent years has reduced its once enormous (and costly to store) corn reserve by exporting to neighboring countries and by inducing commercial farmers -- through disincentive pricing -- to shift to cash crops such as tobacco.

Now the drought has combined with a painful economic restructuring program in Zimbabwe to produce severe deprivation. Although designed to produce a healthier economy in the medium term, the price liberalizations, civil service cutbacks and other austerity measures have begun causing serious hardships. The most visible burden is the extreme shortage and rising cost of mealie meal (ground corn flour). Riot police already have been called out in Harare, the capital, to contain potential violence at shops selling limited stocks.

Meanwhile, in Zambia, the drought is an untimely challenge to the recently elected government of President Frederick Chiluba. Zambians have high expectations that Chiluba will rapidly revive their standard of living after years of steep decline under former President Kenneth Kaunda. The acid test for Chiluba will focus on his ability to ensure adequate supplies of mealie meal at affordable cost. But even under the best scenario, the drought will prevent Chiluba from delivering on his economic promises this year, and Zambians' renewed faith in multiparty democracy could be shaken.

The drought is so severe in Mozambique that Renamo rebels are allowing captive villagers to seek water and food in government-held areas. Cholera, which killed hundreds last year, has broken out in the port city of Beira. One expert fears it could spread "explosively" in the peri-urban bairros crowded with rural refugees from both war and drought.

The causes of such a sudden dry spell are unknown, though some ascribe it to global warming and worry that conditions could worsen in future years. Whatever its origins, this is a drought that (conservatively) will kill tens of thousands and shorten the lives of countless others, especially children. The drought also threatens to undermine the democratization, economic reforms and hard-won peace now sinking tentative roots in the region from South Africa to Angola.

In an American election year, these factors may not count for much. Pat Buchanan has been urging abolition of foreign assistance. Aid levels have been frozen. And we seem increasingly preoccupied with sustaining our former Soviet Bloc antagonists.

Quite by accident, Africa, eastern Europe and the Commonwealth of Independent States have arrived simultaneously at a critical juncture in their political and economic evolution. All have an equal claim upon our good will and largess. However, with the Cold War now in cold storage, we seem more inclined to help our former ideological adversaries than the pawns we once courted in the Third World.

As East Europeans burn their Communist bridges and receive generous U.S. and Western assistance in return, African nations which earlier embarked on courageous economic reforms -- at our urging -- fear that they will be left without the financial support needed to stay the course.

The level of Western response to the southern African drought (as well as that in the Horn of Africa) will suggest whether this fear is legitimate. Given the temptation in this American political season to borrow from Peter to pay Paul, or from southern Africa to benefit Kazakhstan, the answer appears all too evident.

If there be fewer wells dug than there could have been, if there are fewer seeds to plant next season, if more malnourished children are claimed by opportunistic disease in the coming year of want, southern Africans will be left to ponder the seeming fickleness of our generosity. n

Kevin G. Lowther is regional director for southern Africa at Africare, a Washington-based development organization.

By Kevin G. Lowther


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


61 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 11, 1992


TRAVELER'S JOURNAL


LENGTH: 2067 words


Marsabit, Kenya

April 25. We landed in Nairobi without incident, and I was surprised how serene Nairobi appeared on our late-night taxi ride into town. I had spent several months of anxious letter writing, telephone calls, and faxes trying to scrutinize the current situation in Kenya. Is President Daniel arap Moi holding on, or is he losing it? Is the University still open, or closed again? How goes the drought? Is it really as bad as 1984? How many refugees have come in to the north from Ethiopia and Somalia?

I've come back to Kenya to continue my research on Rendille and Ariaal, pastoralists of Marsabit district, Kenya's arid northernmost region. I was anxious about reports of extensive livestock raiding in the North by groups armed with guns brought by the flood of refugees.

Reading the Daily Nation was sobering: photos of women and children slain in the town of Molo near Nakuru in the Rift Valley; the victims of fighting between Kalenjin supporters of Moi against Luo and Kikuyu farmers, who are now treated en masse as the opposition. The Nation is bolder than in 1990 when I last visited Kenya. It is now openly calling for the government to stop the ethnic fighting and supporting the churches' call for multiparty elections. 

At a dinner party with a mixed crowd of Kenyans and Americans, we discussed Kenya's politics. Most there were supporters of Ford (Forum for the Restoration of Democracy), including several Kikuyu, who preferred the progressive and multi-national Ford to the conservative Kikuyu Democratic Party. Everyone expressed horror at the Molo killings, where even the bodies of children were burned by the attackers. Some say Kanu, the ruling party, was directly behind the Kalenjin violence. (The Kalenjin are closely related to President Moi's small ethnic group, the Tugen.) Others said there were reports of military helicopters dropping arrows to the attackers.

The violence is beginning to spill into Nairobi, where a Kalenjin was killed at the bus station by angry Kikuyus. One of the dinner guests remarked, "This killing is no longer politics; it is now a matter of vengeance. 'You killed my brother, now I must take yours.' " Everyone seemed worried. I don't have the sense that people know when this will end.

April 30. It's a relief to head up North. When we left Nairobi, several thousand university students were demonstrating, blocking a long portion of Uhuru Highway with signs that read, "Down With Moi. Down With Saitoti." We left town quickly. These demonstrations can turn ugly, and violent. Driving around Mount Kenya from Nanyuki, I am amazed how green everything looks. The spring rains have been good so far, at least in the central highlands. Even as we descend into the vast northern lowlands at Isiolo, the desert is green with flowering acacia trees and grasses. We see Samburu cattle herders, Rendille camel pastoralists, and Turkana, grazing their animals along the Vaso Nyiru near the turn-off to the Samburu gamepark. But these cattle are emaciated, and I know that the onset of rains here after a 19-month drought accelerates death and famine, as insects bring new diseases to finish off the weak in herds. The Rendille are better prepared than the Samburu for drought, because they rely on camels rather than cattle for milk and meat. But even in Rendille country, we see scores of carcasses--cattle, small stock, even camels.

We finally arrived at our destination of Korr, in the center of Rendille country, with Mount Marsabit to the northeast, Mount. Kulal and Lake Turkana to the northwest, and the Ndoto mountains to the southwest. The Rendille and Gabra live in the lowland deserts. Samburu and Boran cattle keepers prefer the highlands to the west and east.

My reunion at Korr is warm and friendly as always. I am the guest of Larian who runs a shop with his wife Annamarie and serves as my assistant, interpreter, driver and best friend during my fieldwork. I also meet my friends Patrick and Kawap. The news they bring is simple and disheartening. This year's drought has been devastating, and the raids on the area by the Gabra, Boran, and Somalis are becoming intolerable.

Kawap, an elder of about 50 years, is one of the first Rendille to be educated in the Catholic schools of Marsabit in the 1960s. We had a long conversation in his quiet house.

"I think these two years have been the worst years for Rendille, the worst I have known. There are so many animals dying of different diseases. Many camels died, cattle died, many goats and sheep. I think some people who had 100 cattle -- maybe two, three, four remain. For myself, I can tell you exactly. I had 300 goats and sheep, but now only 73 remain. Cattle were 34, and now only 11. Camels 13, now only two remain. Others have been completely wiped out. You hear of people running into the bush mad, tearing their clothes off and crying, wanting to die. We brought them back. And even some people have died from this drought; four people in Kargi, north near Mount Marsabit died just starving. If it were not for these mission foods, you would see hundreds, even thousands dying.

"This is worse than 1984. Then we had a lot of famine relief. We had so much yellow maize we were feeding it to our goats. Our houses were stocked like shops. But now we have the problem of refugees from Ethiopia and refugees from Somalia. There are 60,000 refugees in Moyale on the Ethiopian border. And we can hardly find sugar in the shops or posho (corn meal). Posho is so expensive because there is so little of it .

"And now we face many attacks from the Boran and Gabra to the north and Somalis and Boran to the east. I think 3,000 camels have been taken from the Rendille in the past two months. When we defend with our spears, we get killed by guns. Three people were killed last week near Kargi by Boran who came not to kill people but to take animals because it is so dry and there are so many people who are suffering. But these people, they get their guns from the refugees, who sell guns for nothing, for 100 shillings ($ 3) even, just to buy some small amount of posho or sugar. These are big rifles, Kalashnikov I think they call them.

"The government is trying but they aren't doing much. These government police or army, you know they aren't from here. They come from Kikuyu or the highlands;they don't knoe how to track; they can't even walk in this desert . For that we need the live stock theft unit which is many Rendille and Samburu. But they are far away from here"

May 3. We heard last night that the Gabra had raided Rendille near Kargi, 36 miles (60 km) to the north, and that five or six people were killed. Patrick, a young Rendille elder with a large herd of animals, rushed off to Kargi in the land rover of Abdi, a local shopkeeper, to hear the news directly of this latest Gabra raid. He returned that night telling us:

"They attacked yesterday in three places, about twenty men each time, about half armed with guns. They took thirty camels and 1,200 goats and sheep from Kargi, but we got the goats and sheep back. They shot an elder and four young people, two boys and two girls, whose father had taken them to the Fora refugee camp to drink milk.

Another elder, a school teacher from Kargi, is seriously wounded with a bullet through his lung. The elders are sending a message to all Rendille to come north and be prepared for war. We are telling the Gabra, 'If you can climb into the sky or into the ground you better do it, because we are coming after you now.' "

Larian is more cautious. "This thing will only escalate. It is a senseless war. It started when two Rendille boys eager to be initiated as warriors killed a Gabra boy a year ago.

"You know, Gabra and Rendille, we are not friends, but we have not fought each other since 1972. The Rendille elders wanted to pay 50 cattle to the Gabra to avoid the war, but the Gabra refused saying they wanted the lives of the boys.

"We could not agree and the two boys ran away and hid. Now Gabra have come back to revenge. But truly, I believe this is the government's fault. They could have arrested those two boys one year ago, and there would have been peace. But they didn't. And even now, they bring their police to Kargi town, but they just stay in town doing nothing. The government could have stopped this thing."

Annamarie quietly adds, "The vengeance won't stop. It will just continue and continue. We will go and kill some of theirs, and they will return and kill some of ours. It will only end when there are no more warriors left to fight."

May 4. I meet with Monte Wambili, a leading Rendille elder. Monte is about 50 years old, a quiet and serious man who had fought as a warrior in the battles against the Boran in the 1960s.

Through Larian, I asked Monte if there is any way to avoid a war. Monte replies softly but in no uncertain terms: "We must fight; things cannot stay like this. Now they are stealing from us so many animals. It is better that I am killed than let things go on this way. The first time they raided our small stock in camels, and we could have forced a revenge at that time; then we would not have this raid a second time. If they had killed some of our people they would have also lost some people. We are going to have a meeting, we cannot live as cowards, we cannot run away now. So we are going to revenge. They will lose some people. We cry, so they too will cry . How can we cry by ourselves only and they don't cry with us.

"The only way we get to end this thing is fighting. It is not good but it will happen anyhow. It is not something we wish to give, but only fighting will stop it. When they too have lost people then it will end. We are caught in the middle like a chair in this room. We have no place to move. They have been attacking us. We go to Laisamis and they attack us there, and now Gabra from the other side (north). And now these people are attacking us on both sides, armed with weapons from Somalia and Ethiopia.

This government does not protect our people, and in one month 3,000 camels were stolen. The government will try to find our animals, but they cannot bring the people back. If the government will act like a government and protect us than we can be a bit tolerant and hope for peace. But I do not think this will happen."

Elliot Fratkin is assistant professor of Anthropology at Penn State University. His book, Surviving Drought and Development: Ariaal Pastoralists of Northern Kenya is published by Westview Press.n

By Elliott Fratkin
