MAY 11, 1992


Aid to Malawi may depend on reform


SECTION: NEWS ROUNDUP


LENGTH: 347 words


Aid to Malawi will be discussed this week in Paris amid opposition calls for donors to freeze all development contributions until the government agrees to political reform.

Opposition groups in exile have asked donors to halt all aid beyond drought and refugee relief until "President for Life" Kamuzu Banda's regime respects human rights and allows a transition to multiparty democracy. 

Malawi is heavily dependent on foreign aid -- in 1989, $ 394 million from donors accounted for a quarter of the country's gross national product, according to 1991 World Bank figures.

The call to stop development contributions to Malawi follows a recent decision by donors to suspend aid to Kenya in response to government corruption and violence toward pro-democracy demonstrators. The United States cut its planned 1992 aid to Kenya by more than a third. A spokesperson for the Agency for International Development said the U.S. is now reviewing its assistance to Malawi,

Banda, in his 90s, has ruled Malawi as a one-party state since independence 27 years ago, driving opponents underground or out of the country.

The exiled opposition came home in early April, but didn't get very far.

Chakufwa Chihana, secretary-general of the Southern African Trade Union Coordinating Council, was arrested April 6 as he stepped off the plane at the Lilongwe airport with the text of a speech calling for democratic reform.

Banda had vowed at a speech during a rally in March that returning opposition members would end up as "meat for crocodiles."


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


63 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 11, 1992


Sierra Leone coup makers promise vote


SECTION: NEWS ROUNDUP


LENGTH: 494 words


Soldiers who took power in Sierra Leone late last month are promising to step down in favor of a democratically elected government after they end a rebellion in the east.

"We are only patriotic Sierra Leoneans," said Captain Valentine Strasser, in a radio broadcast April 30th, the day President Joseph Momoh fled to Guinea. "As soon as we all put our hands together and set this nation on the right track for meaningful development, we shall return to our military barracks where we rightfully belong." 

Momoh, who took office in 1985, as President Siaka Stevens' hand-picked successor, had promised multiparty elections in November. But opponents accused him of using the war along the Liberian border as an excuse to postpone the ballot.

Villages have been destroyed and thousands have been killed or driven from their homes in fighting between two Liberian factions and between the Sierra Leonean government and a rebel group calling itself the Revolutionary United Front (RUF). Led by Corporal Foday Sankoh, RUF is an offshoot of Charles Taylor's National Patriotic Front of Liberia. (See "Liberia", page 1.)

Government soldiers fighting the rebels drove to the capital of Freetown April 29th, to demand three months back pay, food and equipment. Their protest turned into a coup when Momoh dismissed the soldiers as troublemakers, and troops he sent to quell the revolt joined in the takeover.

Strasser, who has been named head of state, defense minister and chairman of the National Provisional Ruling Council, claimed Momoh was overthrown to end 23 years of rule by the oppressive and corrupt All People's Congress Party, which he said wrecked the economy and the country's infrastructure.

Strasser claimed the new government will aim to end fighting in the east and pursue the process of returning the country to multiparty democracy. He has called on rebels to lay down their arms and work toward "national reconstruction."

The new ruling council has also pledged to restructure Sierra Leone's economy. Coup leaders appointed Momoh's former finance minister and World Bank official Jim Funa to the new government. Funa had previously negotiated an agreement in which the International Monetary Fund resumed loans to the country.

No date for the promised elections has been announced.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


64 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 11, 1992


DISARMAMENT PLEDGE RAISES LIBERIA PEACE HOPES


LENGTH: 1587 words


 

WASHINGTON -- West African peace initiative is showing new signs of life in Liberia, after months of political stalemate that has kept the country on the brink of renewed civil war. Liberian rebel leader Charles Taylor, whose army holds most of the country, has agreed to the deployment of a West African peacekeeping force into areas under his control and has said his troops will lay down their weapons and move into supervised camps within the next 60 days.

Taylor sent word of his pledge to a meeting of prominent Liberians in Washington on May 2nd, and he confirmed his promise in a telephone interview from Gbarnga, his provisional headquarters 125 miles (200 km) from the Liberian capital, Monrovia. "We are committed to disarmament, we are committed to encampment and we expect to have elections that are free and fair," Taylor said in the interview.

The first contingents of the West African force -- known as Ecomog -- moved into Taylor-held territory last week to create a buffer zone along the border Liberia shares with Sierra Leone, where recent fighting between Taylor's troops and a group of former Liberian soldiers has threatened a return to the turmoil that has devastated the country over the last two and a half years. 

The Washington meeting, held at Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies and co-sponsored by the Atlanta-based Carter Center, the Brookings Institution and two Liberian groups, was convened to explore prospects for peace.

The Liberian conflict began at the end of 1989 with an invasion by a small group of Taylor's men and eventually escalated into a brutal war that resulted in tens of thousands of deaths and the displacement of over half the population. Despite repeated attempts by the 16-nation Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas) to end the fighting and hold free and fair national elections, Liberia -- a nation founded in the mid-19th century by freed American slaves -- remains deeply divided today.

Monrovia, where about a third of the total country's population of 2.6 million has taken refuge, is administered by an interim government established by a broad range of Liberian political, civic, and religious organizations. The rest of the country lies behind lines controlled by Taylor's National Patriotic Front.

Previous attempts by the West Africans to win Taylor's cooperation have faltered, principally because the rebel leader regards the Nigerian-led mediation as an illegitimate intervention designed to block him from taking power. The latest regional initiative was launched early last month at a mini-summit of West African leaders in Geneva, convened by President Felix Houphouet-Boigny of Cote d'Ivoire and attended by both Taylor and the interim government president, Amos Sawyer.

A communique signed by all participants at that meeting established a timetable for the deployment of peacekeeping troops along the Liberia and Sierra Leone border and subsequently throughout the country. Though Taylor renounced the accord on his return to Liberia, he now says he will cooperate with the plan to disarm and encamp combatants as a first step towards holding elections later this year.

Nyondweh Monkomona, who chairs the election commission established under Ecowas auspices with appointees from both Taylor and Sawyer, said preparations for the voting are well underway. At the Johns Hopkins conference, Monkomona said elections could be held in six months, as the West African peace plan envisages, if sufficient resources are found. "We are starting with nothing -- not a pencil, not a chair or a desk," he said, for a task that will require everything from stationery to four-wheel drive vehicles. Both the interim government in Monrovia and Taylor's provisional administration in Gbarnga have pledged $ 250,000 and have already donated $75,000 each, Monkomona said, but much more is needed.

The conference at Johns Hopkins, which drew over 200 leaders from both sides of the political divide, managed to find areas of consensus on what needs to be done to achieve peace. Participants agreed to call for adherence to the agreement for disarming and encamping combatants, to appeal urgently for Sawyer and Taylor to hold their first face-to-face meeting in Liberia, and to demand that transportation and communications be opened up throughout the country. "What we have done, I think, is to reinforce the reconciliatory currents in both camps," said Dr. I. William Zartman, director of the school's African Studies Program, who served as conference chairman.

However, the failed settlement attempts of the past two years indicate that further action is needed, according to the Rev. Canon Burgess Carr, a Liberian religious leader currently working for the Episcopal Church in New York, who advocates holding a national forum in Liberia to push the peace process forward. "If we could get all the parties around a table -- whatever shape the table takes -- and have the kind of discussion we had here, we could solve this thing," he said following the Johns Hopkins gathering. "Liberians are sick and tired of this conflict."

Organizers of the conference are compiling the points of consensus to be sent to both leaders and making plans to dispatch two respected older Liberians to Monrovia and Gbarnga with a request that Sawyer and Taylor name two additional persons each to join in convening a forum within the next few weeks.

Support for holding a Sawyer/Taylor meeting and for increasing contacts among Liberians has also come from a convention organized by Taylor's National Patriotic Front in Gbarnga at the end of April. One resolution adopted by the gathering, which was reportedly attended by several thousand people from all parts of Liberia under Taylor's control, calls for the leaders to meet within a month "on Liberian soil." A meeting between the two slated for Easter Sunday, just prior to the opening of the Gbarnga convention, was cancelled at the last minute when Ecomog decided security could not be assured.

In the interview, Taylor said the resolutions of the Gbarnga conference will serve as "the Bible of what I intend to." The meeting expressed "the will of the Liberian people -- my views don't matter any more," he said.

Signaling the continuing uncertainty surrounding the peace process, Taylor said the Gbarnga delegates rejected the agreement reached in Geneva, which he co-signed and which reaffirmed the peace plan drawn up by an earlier summit in the Ivorian capital of Yamoussoukro last October. The "only binding document" is from the Yamoussoukro meeting, he said.

Taylor did not make clear his objections to the Geneva communique, which states as its central premise "the validity of the Yamoussoukro Accord." In Geneva, the leaders issued a new timetable for disarmament and encampment, since the one agreed in December was scuttled by Taylor's refusal to comply. Ecomog now plans to establish control over all seaports, airports and border posts by May 14th and conclude the disarming and encamping of all factions by June 8th.

One additional uncertainty is the impact the April 30th coup in Sierra Leone may have on the peace process in Liberia. The soldiers who ousted President Joseph Momoh listed the simmering fighting along the Liberian border among their grievances and called on the insurgents, who are allied with Taylor's forces, to lay down their guns. The Ecomog buffer will likely curtail the activities of the anti-

Taylor Liberian group, Ulimo, whose attacks have recently reached deep into central Liberia, and the pro-Taylor Sierra Leone dissidents, led by Foday Sankoh.

Nigerian Major General Ishaya Bakut, the Ecomog commander said the the deployment into Taylor-held areas was smooth. "I believe and I pray that the problems and misunderstandings of the past will be removed as we roll forward with the plan," he said in a telephone interview just after the first units were dispatched. By Reed Kramer


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


65 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 11, 1992


UN MISSION AT RISK IN WESTERN SAHARA


LENGTH: 2307 words


 

EL AAIUN, WESTERN SAHARA -- For 17 years a bitter war over a piece of rocky desert along Africa's north Atlantic coast has been waged largely in obscurity. Now this dusty former outpost of the Spanish empire has become an unlikely testing ground for the United Nations' role as world peacekeeper.

Members of the 25-nation UN peacekeeping force who are posted here say that the Western Saharan operation is in danger of failing completely and has raised questions about the will of the U.S. administration to fully support peace initiatives that may threaten friendly governments. King Hassan II of Morocco, considered a moderate in the Arab world, has staked the prestige of his throne on keeping Western Sahara under Moroccan rule. Americans on the UN team say the U.S. has shown little inclination to persuade the king to observe the peace accord, even when the lives of American citizens are at risk.

On September 5th, the UN began deploying what is now a 375-person contingent to monitor a cease-fire between a Saharan independence movement called the Polisario Front and the Moroccan military, which invaded the territory when Spain withdrew in 1975. 

The UN Mission for the Referendum in Western Sahara, known as Minurso, was charged with supervising a referendum in which the Saharans would choose between independence and union with Morocco. But the peace plan is badly off track. The vote, scheduled for January 6th, has not been held, and none of the preconditions for the balloting has been met. The UN force remains far short of its intended 2,916-person strength.

Minurso officials have repeatedly complained to UN headquarters that a lack of cooperation from Morocco is jeopardizing the mission. They say the Moroccan government has moved in tens of thousands of Moroccans to pack the voters' rolls, has blocked supplies destined for forces in the field, has refused to provide information on the number of its troops and their locations, and has interfered with UN patrols. On at least one occasion, Moroccan soldiers drew their weapons and threatened to fire on a patrol that included Americans.

Last February the State Department barred Col. Albert Zapanta, the top U.S. official with the initial Minurso deployment, from testifying about the Saharan operation before the House Foreign Affairs Africa Subcommittee. Zapanta says he would have told the committee that the U.S. needs to put its weight behind the peace effort. "It was obvious to me that there were forces at work in Morocco that blocked and stalled and impeded our progress wherever they could," he says. "I think that the U.S. can use its influence on the Moroccan authorities to ensure that our soldiers and officers in the field are not threatened any longer and to nudge the process along."

In a report released by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in March, committee staffer George A. Pickart called Senate attention to the problems, which he said endanger the health and lives of the 30 Americans serving in Western Sahara. Citing what he called "Morocco's obstructionist posture toward Minurso," including refusal to allow mission supplies through customs, the report said that illness from unsanitary conditions and extremes of weather has been common. Pickart also criticized the United Nations' hierarchy for failing to provide the political and logistical support to solve the problems. Like Zapanta, Pickart urged the U.S. government to exert its substantial influence to secure Morocco's compliance with the terms of the accord.

The Senate plans to hold hearings on the Saharan situation prior to the May 25th congressional recess and Zapanta says he expects to testify.

United Nations Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali has acknowledged the lack of progress towards a referendum as well as the complaints against Morocco. In a nine-page report to the Security Council, he said Morocco has been responsible for 75 of 77 cease-fire violations, and he set a deadline for resolving the issues that are blocking implementation of the peace plan. The Secretary-General warned that unless there is agreement by the end of May, "it will be necessary to consider alternative courses of action and possibly adopt a new approach to the whole problem."

On March 24th, Boutros-Ghali appointed a new Special Representative for Western Sahara to replace Swiss diplomat Johannes Manz, who resigned last January. The new envoy, Sahabzada Yakub Khan of Pakistan, has already toured the region, visiting Saharan refugee camps in Algeria and meeting with representatives of both Polisario and Morocco.

A visit to Western Sahara suggests that the small Minurso force has been given a difficult if not impossible task. The muted UN reaction to Moroccan intransigence has contributed to frustration and cynicism among the field forces - an attitude apparently shared by Johannes Manz. In a confidential memo to the Secretary-General just before his resignation, Manz expressed "great sadness" at the lack of a forceful response to Morocco's breaches of the peace accord. He urged that the UN "firmly retake the initiative in this complex process."

The peace plan accepted by Morocco and Polisario in 1990 calls for the UN to oversee the establishment of conditions for a free and fair referendum, including the identification and registration of voters and the creation of a climate of confidence and stability.

Although the question of voter eligibility has dominated public discussion, it is the ability to foster a sense of security among Saharans that may prove most elusive. "This is the worst police state I have ever seen," says one Minurso member who has served in several parts of Latin America and Asia.

For a visitor returning to Western Sahara after a long absence, there is an almost eerie sense of disorientation. Fifteen years ago, El Aaiun was a picturesque village, dominated by the whitewashed domes of traditional Saharan architecture. Today, the capital is a city of square concrete structures sporting the ochre and sienna tones favored by Moroccan builders. Moroccan settlers, drawn by the lucrative tax and financial incentives offered by the government, have fueled a building boom and now account for an estimated half the 100,000 population.

Moroccan professionals, encountered in businesses and hotels, speak of their time in Western Sahara as an involuntary tour of duty. A teller at the Banque Commerciale du Maroc says that his four-month assignment in El Aaiun is nearly over and he is eager to return to his job in the Moroccan port city of Agadir. A clerk, whose husband was assigned to teach in a Saharan school, says she pines for her home in Casablanca. "I don't like it here," she says. "It's different and it's dirty."

But like Europe's former colonies in Africa and Asia, Western Sahara has offered enterprising settlers a way to get ahead. The manager of one of El Aaiun's largest hotels says he was a kitchen helper and a waiter in Switzerland before coming to the Sahara.

Amid the boom-town atmosphere, the graceful, billowing Saharan garments -- sari-like wraps for women and pale blue or white robes for men -- have mostly disappeared. Over the past few months, Moroccan authorities have asserted increasing pressure on local residents to abandon their distinctive dress, a policy Saharans say is intended to make them invisible to international visitors.

Morocco strictly enforces a lack of contact between Saharans and UN personnel. Armed soldiers guard the entrances to Minurso headquarters and to the two main hotels where mission members are bunkered. Saharans say anyone who tries to approach the UN locations is turned away and often arrested. Only in the outlying desert sites, where international teams monitor the cease-fire, is there a semblance of free exchange between UN observers and Saharans.

But difficulties have persisted there, too. UN forces report being denied access to places within their patrol areas by armed Moroccan soldiers. In one incident, a Moroccan jeep sideswiped a Minurso vehicle to prevent its progress into an area the Moroccans had declared off limits.

On a hill perched above UN headquarters, a make-shift tent camp has become the most visible evidence of the problems facing UN peacekeepers. The tents, decorated with symbols of the Moroccan royal family, house thousands of people that the Moroccan government says are Saharan nomads, gathered to exercise their right to vote. The area remains off limits to Minurso by order of the Moroccan government, and journalists are allowed in only with official escorts. A visitor's car attempting to pass a sentry point on the camp's perimeter was whistled to a stop.

Asked about the purpose of the tents, a guard said they were pitched to shelter "the people who have come to vote that the Sahara is Moroccan." He said the tent dwellers had been bused in from such southern Moroccan cities as Goulemime and Tiznit, and he warned that approaching the tents or photographing them is forbidden.

The tent city is a reminder that, eight months after the cease-fire, the warring parties are no closer to agreeing on a voters' role. Deciding who is Saharan, in a vast desert where nomads roam across national borders, is the unenviable task of the Minurso Identification Commission. But disputes over the criteria for determining Saharan origins have brought the identification process to a halt.

During the peace negotiations, Polisario and Morocco accepted a 1974 Spanish census that counted 74,000 Saharans as the basis for the voters' roll. Since that time, however, King Hassan has demanded the addition of 120,000 people he says have Saharan ancestry.

As one of his last acts in office, former UN Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar proposed expanded eligibility criteria, including proof of intermittent residency in the territory for 12 years prior to the 1974 census.

That attempt to accommodate the king's position, combined with the continuing heavy hand that Morocco is exercising in the territory, has eroded Saharan faith in the UN effort. "We are exactly like Kuwait, invaded by our neighbor," said one Saharan. "When the UN came, we were happy. But now we are afraid."

Saharans expected Minurso to investigate Polisario complaints that hundreds of people are bring detained by Moroccan authorities, under the noses of UN observers. But there has been no formal inquiry, and Morocco has refused to admit independent human rights groups.

UN observers believe that the peace process is now at a point of critical transition and that the appointment of a new Special Representative may revive the morale of UN troops. The decision by the Minurso commander, General Armand Roy of Canada, to begin flying the blue UN flag at headquarters -- in defiance of a Moroccan ban on symbols of UN authority -- has cheered the forces already.

Still, there is a growing conviction within Minurso that Morocco has no intention of leaving Western Sahara, whatever the outcome of a referendum. In his private memo to the Secretary-General, former Special Representative Manz said that a negotiated agreement "with neither a clear winner nor a clear loser" may offer the only prospect for a solution.

Col. Zapanta, who was deputy Minurso commander as well as the ranking American officer, believes that any solution to the Saharan impasse will require aggressive action. "Out of all the countries (in Minurso)," he says, "it's the United States that has the credibility with all the players and the power to make it happen."

Other UN observers said that more than the success or failure of one mission is at stake. Only if the world body proves tough enough to implement its own accords, they said, can it credibly claim the mantle of peacekeeper. n By Tami Hultman


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


66 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 11, 1992


Generals Said to Plan Power Grab for Mobutu


LENGTH: 467 words


When President Mobutu Sese Seko considers what his future might hold if the balance of power shifts in favor of his opponents, he has only to look across the river from his yacht to Brazzaville, the capital of neighboring Congo.

Last year, a Congolese national conference turned into an inquisition into the 12-year rule of President Denis Sassou-Nguesso, who after the three months of deliberations was left with only ceremonial powers.

Togolese President Gnassingbe Eyadema, a Mobutu protege, suffered a similar fate when spreading protests and demonstrations forced him to allow a national democracy conference in Togo's capital Lome. 

Well-placed sources in Zaire, whose inside information has proven reliable over the past several months, report that plans have been formulated to seize control of the country if Mobutu's hold on power seems threatened.

They may be following the example of the Togolese army, which last December staged an uprising, laying seige to the national conference meeting hall and -- for a brief period -- taking the conference-chosen prime minister as their captive. Although President Eyadema was outside of Lome when the troops acted and said he had no role in encouraging their intervention, the soldiers won concessions for the president that restored some of his authority.

In Zaire, the sources report, a group of army generals loyal to the president -- some on active duty, others assigned to civilian posts -- held a series of meetings over Easter weekend to devise a plan for seizing strategic locations throughout the capital, Kinshasa. The takeover might be triggered by a deadlock in the national conference discussions or might occur when the president seems to be losing ground to his opponents. The objective of the seizure would be to position Mobutu to step in as mediator between the opposition political coalition and the military, enhancing his stature internationally, and perhaps extending his hold on power.

Throughout his three-decade rule, Mobutu has averted military threats to his control, both by rewarding handsomely those closest to him and by periodic reshuffling of the top posts to keep any one officer from gaining too much authority. Another top level shift is being planned in connection with preparation for the takeover, according to the sources.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


67 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 11, 1992


ZAIRE'S WEIGHTY CRISIS PERSISTS


LENGTH: 2747 words


KINSHASA, ZAIRE -- If there is such a thing as economic anarchy, it exists here, where cash is weighed instead of counted, bankers beg clients to deposit money and the exchange rate climbs faster than a scared monkey.

There is so little confidence in the country's currency, the Zaire, that a national conference on democracy, currently meeting in this central African capital, worked out its operating budget in U.S. dollars. But it is unclear where money to pay the proposed $ 12.8 million for the conference will come from, since the government already has a spending deficit of about $ 200 million and the state still does not have a budget for this fiscal year.

Government theft and mismanagement have sent the annualized inflation rate soaring to 5,000 percent. Unemployment is estimated at 70%. Twenty years ago, it was possible to buy a car for as little as 500 Zaires. Now, the largest denomination bill in circulation, the 200,000 Zaire note, is worth just less than two dollars. 

The growing economic crisis parallels a political stand-off that pits a lively pro-democracy movement against President Mobutu Sese Seko, who came to power 27 years ago with backing from the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency. Tensions have escalated since December 5th, when Mobutu's latest presidential term expired with no indication that he would keep an earlier pledge to call national elections.

Currently, Mobutu is facing the greatest challenge of his long tenure, with an opposition coalition demanding that he cede power, particularly the power of the purse. Under international pressure to respond to democracy demands, the government grudgingly allowed a national conference to convene to discuss the country's political future. During the last two years, such conferences have become common in Africa as a means of stripping power from authoritarian governments and paving the way for democratic elections.

The Zairean president is one of the continent's last longtime rulers, and he has more to lose than most. During his three decades in office, Mobutu has become one of the world's richest people, with a personal fortune estimated at billions of dollars that many Zaireans say was siphoned from the national treasury.

Roman Catholic Archbishop Monsengwo Pasinya, who was formally chosen as president of the democracy conference last month, has called for an investigation into allegations by some delegates that Mobutu's government has been paying off conference participants to buy influence over the process.

"There is no patriotism in this country," says Kayemba Ntamba, a political science and law professor at the University of Kinshasa. "Power is founded on money."

"We of the second republic in Zaire are accustomed to cheating people," says 29-year-old Katambwa Mike Masiya, a reporter for Umoja newspaper, one of Zaire's oldest. "It is now in the heads of people to such a point that they can't control it. It is a psychological problem. It is Mobutu's policy."

Communications employees routinely rip telephone wires out of the ground so residents will slip them some extra cash to fix them. Where the Bureau des Routes does not step in to repair roads, teenagers and young children do. They fill in the yawning potholes of Kinshasa's decaying streets with dirt and rocks, hoping drivers will stop and give them a tip. Zaire has its own form of toll roads; soldiers haphazardly set up roadblocks at night to extract every possible bit of cash, cigarettes or beer from the vehicles they stop.

As the democracy movement sees it, if Mobutu has reasons to resist the shift of power, Zaire has more to gain from honest, competent government than most countries. Zaire is potentially one of Africa's richest nations; it is the world's second largest exporter of industrial diamonds (behind Australia), and its soil is packed with cobalt, copper and uranium. The power of the Zaire River, if harnessed, could provide electricity for all of Africa and most of Europe.

But years of corruption and diversions of public funds have left the country -- which is the about the size of Alaska, Texas, and California combined -- with a deteriorated infrastructure that affects every aspect of economic activity. The state-run Gecamines mining industry is expected to produce less than 200,000 tons of copper this year, half the output in 1989.

The escalating spiral of political protests and government resistance to democracy demands has further disrupted economic and civic life. To stem campus protests two years ago, the government closed universities. For most of this year, strikes have emptied public primary and secondary schools and most of the country's hospitals. As in the majority of the job actions by public servants, strikers were not only asking for monies due them -- after months without paychecks -- but were also pressing for political demands, in this case the resumption of the national conference after its suspension by the government in January.

The economic situation has worsened considerably since last September, when unpaid soldiers went on a looting spree throughout the country. Civilians joined the pillaging, which cost Zaire an estimated $ 1 billion in damage and prompted the evacuation of 15,000 foreigners, many of whom owned businesses providing jobs for Zaireans. Kinshasa's Cite district, home to Zaire's middle-class, is by Western standards a rapidly disintegrating urban slum.

Zaire's Banking Association warned recently that the 12 commercial banks operating in the country would be forced to close their doors because of insufficient cash to operate. Already, banks are shut most of the time, dealing with selected customers through the back door. Most withdrawals are limited to the equivalent of $ 5 or $10.

"My banker came to me the other day begging me to deposit some money," said one businessman, who like others interviewed for this story declined to be identified. Most businesses in the capital conduct their affairs in international currency.

Umoja newspaper recently poked fun at the national slogan written on Zaire's currency, "Peace, Justice, Work," saying it should read, "Chaos, Decadence, Debauchery." Economists and businessmen speculate that the government may be manipulating the currency, planning to release it all at once, which would force up the exchange rate, and then blame the resulting debacle on the national conference.

Overseas, the country's embassies are suffering from the crisis as well. Zaire's mission to the United Nations was threatened with eviction from its New York offices last month for back-due rent of $ 400,000. (Attorneys representing Zaire said last week that the bill has been paid and the eviction notice withdrawn.) The country's embassy in London has received a similar threat: pay up or leave.

A leading European businessman said the government sends lorries to the central bank to retrieve money to pay parliament. But it bypasses the central bank, flying money in from abroad, to pay the presidential guard, he said. Sources close to the government say when money is flown in from Germany, where it is printed, a helicopter picks up the delivery and flies it directly to Mobutu's luxury yacht on the Zaire river where the president spends much of his time.

On the banks and sandbars of the river, dozens of abandoned riverboats have become homes for desperate immigrants from the country's interior. The migrants string up pieces of ragged cloth for privacy or retreat into the bowels of the boat's machinery for protection against afternoon rains and wind.

The search for food has also become increasingly difficult, although there is no evidence of hoarding. In fact, inflation stabilized in February because so few people could afford to buy food. "We don't eat at noon, or at 2 p.m.," says 26-year-old Charlotte Bodesi, secretary of a local non-governmental organization for women and development. "We eat when we have something to eat." For many families, that means rotating the days that different children are fed, she says.

Take the cases of Kambungu Faustin, Lupangu Nzala and a woman who calls herself only Marie.

Kambungu, a blind man of 60, whose wife died last year, has four children and relies on handouts from the church and his neighbors to survive. Sitting on a wooden chair in front of his one-room scrap metal home, he says he is waiting for his daughter to return home with some money to feed him and the other three children. The daughter is 13 years old.

Lupangu is 41 years old and looks well into his 50s. He walks two hours to work each day, but he is so thin he looks as though he barely has the strength to raise himself from his bed each morning at 5:30 a.m. "There were two or three days when I didn't eat this week, but I made the effort to come here, because I have work, even if I don't have the energy," said Lupangu, who works as a handyman for the health department.

Marie, like others of her profession here, is referred to as a "free woman." She's a prostitute, but she doesn't sell her body to support a drug habit. She takes two to three clients a week at the equivalent of $ 2.50 each tofeed herself.

Mama Yemo Hospital, Zaire's premier health care institution that is named after Mobutu's late mother, is the ideal metaphor for the country's decaying social, economic and political infrastructure.

Medical workers went on strike February 21st demanding higher wages and resumption of the national conference. With virtually no one to attend to them, any patient who could walk went home, leaving less than 50 of the hospital's 2,500 beds occupied. The only signs of life were a few wards where AIDS patients lay dying. Mama Yemo was once reputed to have one of the the highest number of births of any maternity ward in the world. A visitor today will find only a handful of mothers and babies.

Since the democracy conference resumed, most doctors and nurses have returned to work, hoping a solution to their economic woes lies at the forum. Meanwhile, Mama Yemo, like many institutions in Zaire, appears to be going back to nature. White birds that look like small storks pick through garbage cans on the open grounds of the hospital. Vines grow through the windows of a once-thriving 14-room surgery ward and black cobwebs hang from its crumbling corners.

The only medical supplies available are the remains of earlier donations by Medecins Sans Frontieres, or MSF (Doctors Without Borders). Those bandages and medicines are saved for emergencies, says Dr. Tombe Diabeno, chief of surgery. Some were used after troops fired on peaceful anti-government demonstrators February 16th, when human rights groups estimate that up to 32 people died and more than 100 were injured. Much of the rest was stolen by soldiers who were sent to the hospital to replace striking medical workers, said one diplomat, who didn't want to be identified.

The only people who are likely to find medical care are those with money, says Diabeno. "If they don't have the money, they're going to die. When someone comes here, he must come with the material to give it to the surgeon because in the hospital there is no material. We have no gloves or alcohol," he said.

Belgium, Zaire's former colonial power, as well as the United States, France and the European Community, have severed all but humanitarian aid to Zaire to pressure the government towards democratic reforms. However, the international community's lack of confidence in Zaire's move towards democracy and the absence of a tangible crisis, such as last Septem-ber's looting, has made it difficult for non-governmental groups to find funding.

"Now the situation is worse -- you can't identify even a calamity which you need to present for funding," said Dr. Marc Arbyn, of MSF. "The situation has become chronic. For us, we go away, but for Zaire, the imports of equipment and basic medicines will stop."

He said the group's most recent funding ran out at the end of April and the chances of receiving additional money from the European Community appear bleak.

Since the government allowed the democracy conference to reopen last month, delegates have been working steadily to draft a charter that will regulate government procedures until elections are held. However, the conferees have yet to tackle the key issue of what form a transitional government leading to elections would take, and what Mobutu's role would be.

The president's ruling Mouvement Populaire de la Revolution (MPR) and the Union Sacre opposition coalition have been dealing with that problem in meetings on the sidelines of the conference.

The Union Sacre has proposed that Mobutu remain head of state, with his authority limited to such ceremonial tasks as signing international accords, after consulting the government. The opposition also offered to let Mobutu remain as commander-in-chief of the armed forces, but said it was "imperative" that, during the transition, Mobutu "stop interfering in government affairs" because his actions have "ruined the country."

The MPR, in a recent memo to the Union Sacre, protested that Mobutu is no "passive agent" of the country's politics and he should be more than a titular head of state during a transitional period. "The concept of a president who reigns but does not govern is not justified," the MPR said.

There are many Zaireans who oppose any compromise by the Union Sacre that would deny the conference the authority to investigate past government practices and expose Mobutu's wrongdoing. But many politicians believe that it will take such a concession to win an agreement that could end the current stalemate.

"The national conference is not a place to snatch power from Mobutu," said opposition leader Faustin Birindwa. "We want the national conference to be the place to organize the transfer of power." n

By Cindy Shiner


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


68 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 25, 1992 / June 7, 1992


Postings


LENGTH: 814 words


Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, a prominent Liberian political figure, has been named to head the United Nations Development Program's (UNDP) Africa bureau. Sirleaf, who is currently vice president and Washington representative of Equator Bank, is a former Liberian finance minister and former official of the World Bank and Citibank. In the mid-1980s, Sirleaf was jailed for opposition activities by the late President Samuel K. Doe, and she has been considered a possible presidential contender in the forthcoming Liberian elections.

Sirleaf serves on the boards of directors of several organizations, including the New York-based Synergos Institute and Africa News Service. At UNDP, where she will become the first woman to head one of the agency's bureaus, she succeeds Pierre-Claver Damiba, who returned home to Burkina Faso last September to take part in national politics. 

Walter Carrington is expected to be named staff director of the House subcommittee on Africa next month, congressional sources report. Currently the administrative assistant to subcommittee Chairman Mervyn Dymally (D-CA), Carrington served as President Jimmy Carter's ambassador to Senegal and before that as executive vice president of the African-American Institute. He has also served on the faculty of Howard University and is a member of the board of Africare, the Washington, D.C.-based development organization.

Carrington, who will succeed Adonis Hoffman, will be the third subcommittee staff director since Dymally assumed the chairmanship at the beginning of 1991. But his tenure may be short-lived, since Dymally is retiring from Congress at the end of this year. With so many members leaving the House this term, there is

uncertainty about who will assume subcommittee leadership next year. Rep. Donald Payne of New Jersey -- liry of state for African affairs, is slated to be named to head the Africa bureau of the U.S. Agency for International Development (AID). Rosenberg, who served as an aide to former Republican Senator Charles Percy, has been overseeing economic issues at the Africa bureau of the State Department as one of four deputies to Assistant Secretary Herman Cohen. who served as an aide to former Republican Senator Charles Percy, has been overseeing economic issues at the Africa bureau of the State Department as one of four deputies to Assistant Secretary Herman Cohen.

Cohen, who has served in a number of Africa posts, was recently promoted to the rank of career ambassador, putting him in line to head a large embassy abroad, most likely in Europe. He has told associates he plans to leave his current post at the end of the presidential term, even if an ambassadorial nomination is not forthcoming.

John Ordway has moved from the State Department to the White House, succeeding Walter Kansteiner as the director of African affairs on the National Security Council (NSC) staff. Kansteiner has become deputy press secretary at the NSC.

The White House has announced a number of new ambassadorial appointments for Africa. Princeton Lyman, director of the State Department's refugee programs, is going to South Africa. Dennis Barret, who has been directing the U.S. aid program in South Africa has been assigned to Madagascar. He will be replaced as AID director in South Africa by Cap Dean, the current director of AID's southern Africa office.

William Swing is moving from South Africa to Nigeria. Hume Alexander Horan, a former ambassador to Saudi Arabia, Sudan, Equatorial Guinea, and Cameroon, will take over the embassy in COte d'Ivoire. Roger McGuire, who was the U.S. representative in Namibia, has been assigned to Guinea-Bissau. Lauralee M. Peters will become ambassador to Sierra Leone. Joseph Charles Wilson IV is to become ambassador to S o Tome and Pr ncipe.

Peter de Vos is moving from Liberia to Tanzania, while Donald Petterson, a former ambassador to Tanzania as well as Somalia, is going to Sudan. Marc Allen Baas, who has been serving as charge d'affaires in Ethiopia, will become ambassador there, now that diplomatic relations with Addis Ababa have been restored to normal. Robert E. Gribbin III, the deputy chief of mission in Uganda, has been chosen for the Central African Republic.


LOAD-DATE: May 26, 1992


LANGUAGE: English
