69 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 25, 1992 / June 7, 1992


U.S.& Africa: Backing Democracy


SECTION: Briefing


LENGTH: 880 words


A new law shifts the foundation of United States policy in the Horn of Africa from pursuit of strategic interests to promotion of democracy and development, according to the law's supporters.

The Horn of Africa Recovery and Food Security Act, passed by Congress April 9 and signed by the president two weeks later, ties U.S. aid to progress toward democratic government.

Sharon Pauling, policy analyst at Bread for the World, a Washington, DC-based group that lobbied for the bill's passage, said the law provides the framework to transfer aid from programs designed to support U.S. strategic objectives during

the Cold War to programs that will meet the long-term needs of the Horn's people.

Rep. Doug Bereuter (R-NE), a member of the House Select Committee on Hunger International Task Force, who

co-sponsored the bill when it was introduced a year ago, said the key parts of the act are its "no democracy, no aid" policy and its flexibility. The act allows the administration to selectively lift restrictions Congress imposed on aid during the Cold War. 

"Our policy in the world now is not governed by the Cold War," says one state department official. "This is an acknowledgment of reality."

Specifically, the act:

* Prohibits U.S. development or military aid to the governments of Ethiopia, Somalia or Sudan unless they are certified as showing commitments to peace, human rights, democracy and the free distribution of emergency relief to those in need.

* Waives other restrictions on aid, including one that blocked assistance to Ethiopia.

* Urges that development aid be targeted to private voluntary organizations working at the grassroots level for a nation's poorest inhabitants.

* Provides no new funding for aid to people affected by war and famine in the Horn of Africa, but allows the unlimited use of unspent monies previously earmarked for military and strategic purposes during fiscal years 1992 and 1993. These monies can now be diverted to relief and development needs.

* Encourages the president to press for negotiated settlements of armed conflicts in the Horn; to propose a United Nations embargo on arms shipments to the region; to pledge support for peacekeeping activities; and to press the UN secretary-general to set a high priority for cease-fires, safe corridors for emergency relief and peace agreements.

Ethiopia will probably be the only country in the Horn to benefit immediately from the act.

Until recently, the United States had been blocked from giving anything but food aid to Ethiopia by the Brooke Amendment and Section 812 of the 1985 International Cooperation and Development Act. Section 812 prohibited development aid to the regime of ousted Ethiopian military ruler Mengistu Haile Mariam.

The Brooke Amendment restrict. aid to governments more than a year behind in paying their debts to the U.S. government.

Section 812 was recently repealed, and the Horn of Africa act waived the Brooke Amendment for Ethiopia at about the same time the country paid off enough debt to escape the restrictions.

Certification under the act is expected to come "any day now" from

President Bush for the governments of Ethiopia and Eritrea (annexed by Ethiopia in 1962 but now governed by an autonomous transitional admnistration), says Bill Dougd by Ethiopia in 1962 but now governed by an autonomous transitional admnistration), says Bill Douglass of the U.S. Agency for International Development. At that point, the U.S. can start releasing an estimated $ 80 million in development aid for 1992 and 1993.opment aid in the near future. Somalia, which lost U.S. aid in 1990 under the Brooke Amendment, is divided among competing armed factions and has no effective government. Sudan, which lost aid when the current government came to power in a 1989 coup, is split between the Islamic fundamentalist regime of President Omar Hassan Ahmad al-Bashir in the Arab-speaking north and rebels of the Sudan People's Liberation Army based in the Christian and animist black African south.


LOAD-DATE: May 26, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


70 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 25, 1992 / June 7, 1992


Return to the fray


LENGTH: 360 words


An 11-year ban on political parties in Ghana was lifted May 18, following an April 28 referendum in which a new multiparty constitution was approved . Parliamentary and presidential elections in November and December will complete the process of returning the country to democratic rule, and a newly elected government will be inaugurated January 7, 1993. 

An estimated 50% of Ghana's 8 million registered voters participated in the referendum, although the number is disputed. Officials counts showed 3,680,974 officially voting "yes" and 272,855 voting "no" to adoption of the new constitution. By all accounts the voting was fair and open, although there was concern that rural voters, in particular, had little knowledge of the provisions they approved.

Despite overwhelming support for the constitution, there is considerable hostility to provisions in the document which indemnify members of the government and military officers from prosecution for actions taken while in office since the coup of December 31, 1981. The opposition argues that the government wants to protect itself from public scrutiny, even though the military rulers handed out drastic punishment -- sometimes including execution -- to officials of previous regimes for corruption, abuse of power and mismanagement of public office.

The government's program for a return to constitutional rule has also been criticized. Major opposition parties have gone to court to lift limits on individual contributions to political campaigns and to overturn the ban on the use of old party names and slogans. The opposition accuses head of state Jerry Rawlings of trying to position himself to win the election, although he has not declared his intention to run.


LOAD-DATE: May 26, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


71 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 25, 1992 / June 7, 1992


Absence makes the heart grow?


LENGTH: 320 words


Not many world leaders would leave their countries for months at a time, but President Felix Houphouet-Boigny of Cote d'Ivoire boarded a Concorde for Paris on February 2, and has not returned. Now there is speculation he will leave for Cote d'Ivoire within the next few weeks. 

Tensions have been high throughout the country during his absence. Anti-government demonstrations in early February turned violent and led to the arrest of Laurent Gbagbo, leader of the Ivorian Popular Front, the county's largest opposition party. Gbagbo, who ran against Houphouet-Boigny in the 1990 elections -- the first contested vote in Cote d'Ivoire's 30-year history -- was sentenced to two years in prison after being convicted of destroying public property. Eight others, including the president of the Ivorian League of Human Rights, Rene Degny Segui, received two-year terms, while four more people received one-year sentences. Martial Ahipeaud, president of the national student organization, was sentenced to three years.

The protestors demanded the dismissal of armed forces chief Gen. Robert Guei, who was found responsible by a presidential Commission of Inquiry for a May 1991 raid on university dormitories in which soldiers beat and raped students. Just days before his departure for France, the president rejected the commission's recommendation that Guei be punished.

While away, Houphouet-Boigny has continued close oversight of the country's affairs. Prime Minister Allassane Ouattara has paid regular visits to the president, and most members of the Cabinet have been to see him as well, according to the Paris weekly Jeune Afrique.


LOAD-DATE: May 26, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


72 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 25, 1992 / June 7, 1992


Resisting reforms


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Domestic and international opposition to the rule of "President for Life" Kamuzu Banda is growing in Malawi.

The aging strongman is facing some of the largest demonstrations since independence in 1964, a suspension of all but humanitarian aid, and a series of strikes that have spread from cities to tea plantations. 

Banda, who has stifled all dissent during his 28-year tenure, is blaming the unrest on "outside influences."

In a country where a word against the ruling Malawi Congress Party can land the speaker in jail, thousands took to the streets in mid-May in the industrial center of Blantyre and the capital, Lilongwe. At least 22 people -- the official count -- and perhaps as many as 38 -- Amnesty International's figure -- died after the government used force to disperse the protestors in Blantyre. Members of a paramilitary youth group, the Malawi Young Pioneers, attacked striking textile workers and Malawi Polytechnic students, and police opened fire on demonstrators, according to Amnesty International.

The unrest came a week after hearings in the case of opposition and trade union leader Chakufwa Chihana., who was arrested at the airport when he returned from exile April 6 with a pro-democracy speech in his hand. An estimated 3,000 supporters gathered outside the courtroom. Michael Lescault , of the AFL-CIO's African-American Labor Institute, predicts that crowds will swell to much larger sizes at future hearings.

Donors voted early this month to put $ 74 million in new non-humanitarian aid on hold until there is "tangible and irreversible evidence of a basic transformation in the way Malawi approaches basic freedoms and human rights, " a World Bank statement says.


LOAD-DATE: May 26, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


73 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 25, 1992 / June 7, 1992


To the rescue


LENGTH: 254 words


Fifteen foreign oil firms have proposed spending between $ 3.7 and $4.2 billion to develop six Algerian oil fields in response to bid invitations from the government. The move is an attempt to attract outside cash and ease the country's debt burden. 

The government recently changed legislation to allow foreigners to invest in existing oil fields, despite critics claims that the new law will mean selling Algeria to outsiders. Foreigners are still restricted to owning no more than a 49% interest in Algerian oil fields, with the state-owned Sonatrach company holding the rest.

Algeria's economy is crippled by a $ 25 billion foreign debt that will require the government to make principal and interest payments of about $ 10 billion next year. Although energy exports are expected to bring the government about $ 11.5 billion this year, the country will spend almost $2.5 billion on food imports.

Sonatrach last month produced about 770,000 barrels of oil daily. Proposed improvements to the six fields would raise output 200,000 barrels per day by the end of the century. Over the 20 years between 1993 and 2013, this would amount to one billion more barrels of oil.


LOAD-DATE: May 26, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


74 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 25, 1992 / June 7, 1992


Strapped for cash


LENGTH: 267 words


An International Monetary Fund delegation is scheduled next month to visit the Central African Republic (CAR), which is running a $ 7.4 million deficit and hasnot paid civil servants in three months.

President Andre Kolingba turned for help this month to France, which has linked development aid to progress toward democracy in its former colonies. In the CAR, Paris supports the creation of a national union government in preparation for national elections.

But CAR opposition parties want a sovereign national conference on the nation's future, while Kolingba has agreed only to a "national debate." National conferences in other African countries have replaced heads of one-party states with transitional leaders mandated to oversee transitions to multiparty democracy.

Talks between government, trade union and opposition party representatives on holding a national political meeting collapsed in early May after two and a half months of negotiations. Opposition leader Joseph Bendounga, president of the Democratic Movement for the Renaissance and Evolution of Centrafica, was arrested on a charge of "insulting the head of state," after he wrote Kolingba a letter critical of his rejection of a national conference.


LOAD-DATE: May 26, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


75 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 25, 1992 / June 7, 1992


Don't take it for granted


LENGTH: 227 words


Western donors promised Uganda $ 830 million in aid after a meeting in Paris earlier this month, but warned continued human right violations could jeopardize future assistance.

"A number of donors expressed concern over reported violations of human rights," according to a statement from the World Bank, which chaired the consultative group meeting. "They welcomed the government's efforts to deal with this problem so far, but also underlined the importance of further progress."

Complaints about human rights violations led to the suspension of aid to Malawi by donors this month (see Malawi, page 3) and contributed to a similar decision on Kenya late last year.

The $ 830 million pledged for Uganda in 1992-93 includes $500 million for health care, education and transportation projects and $ 330 million to copewith balance of payments problems created by a sharp drop in export income due to low coffee prices. Coffee sales, which produce about 90% of Uganda's export income, raised just $ 120 million this year compared with $400 million in 1987.


LOAD-DATE: May 26, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


76 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 25, 1992 / June 7, 1992


Try, try again


LENGTH: 294 words


A new round of peace talks aimed at ending more than 12 years of devastating war in Mozambique is expected to start late this month or early in June.

The Italian government, brokering the talks with a Roman Catholic group, says negotiations will focus on military issues that must be resolved to allow a cease-fire between the government and rebels of the Mozambique National Resistance (Renamo), founded in the mid-70s by the army of white minority-ruled Rhodesia. The June sessions will be the 11th round of talks in two years.

The United States has decided to attend as a formal observer, following an April 25 meeting in Malawi between Assistant Secretary of State Herman J. Cohen and Renamo leader Afonso Dhlakama. Mozambique President Joaquim Chissano says the meeting has opened the way to a settlement. The Italian government may also invite Britain, France and Portugal to observe the talks.

There is speculation that the rebels may be more willing to negotiate because of pressure from the southern African drought, which has struck hardest in Renamo strongholds in Mozambique's southern and central provinces. Thousands of peasants are leaving those areas in search of food and water.

However, Chissano recently charged that Renamo has demanded $ 10 to $12 million to fund its future political activities before it will agree to a settlement of the conflict that has killed at least 100,000, driven hundreds of thousands more into exile, and destroyed over a third of Mozambique's health facilities and half its schools.


LOAD-DATE: May 26, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


77 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 25, 1992 / June 7, 1992


Fighting for democracy?


LENGTH: 347 words


Weeks of violence in southern and northern Nigeria have sparked new criticism of the country's military government, which is scheduled to hand over power to an elected civilian administration later this year. National and international groups have accused the government of human rights violations and are questioning its management of the transition to democracy. 

Between 200 and 300 people died during violence in mid-May in northern Kaduna state, before police and soldiers restored order, arresting nearly 250. Fighting between Christians and the area's Moslem majority began with land disputes in two towns and spread to Kaduna City, the state's capital. The two sides engaged in looting, arson and attacks on men, women and children.

The unrest followed similar violence in other parts of the country:

* Political tension during gubernatorial primaries in October and gubernatorial and state assembly elections in December inspired religious and ethnic violence that killed up to 1,000 during that period in the northern city of Kano and up to 5,000 in the central-eastern state of Taraba.

* At least 10 people were killed and vehicles and government offices burned during the first week of May in the Nigerian capital, Lagos, and other southern cities, after a shortage of gas at the government-subsidized price caused many bus and taxi drivers to raise fares up to 400 percent.

* After a two-day protest against high prices by university students in Lagos the following week, groups of young people barricaded streets, attacked passersby for money, set cars and buildings ablaze and looted businesses. At least 11 were killed and 120 arrested in the capital. The unrest also spread to other southern cities.


LOAD-DATE: May 26, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


78 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 25, 1992 / June 7, 1992


Fast Facts about AIDS


LENGTH: 320 words


* The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates that one in 40 adults in sub-Saharan Africa is infected with HIV.

* The U.S. Census Bureau reports that if condom use were increased by 25% in urban areas in Africa, HIV prevalence would drop in the next 25 years. About 200 people contract the virus every hour around the world, and more than half are African.

* AIDS is most commonly spread through sexual contact, blood transfusions, intravenous drug use and from an infected mother to her unborn child.

* WHO says 10 to 15 million uninfected children, mostly in sub-Saharan Africa, will lose their mothers to AIDS by the turn of the century. In Kigali, the capital of Rwanda, Africa's most densely populated country, up to 30% of child-bearing women are infected with HIV, according to a researcher with the U.S. Centers for Disease Control.

* HIV takes an average of 10 years from infection before symptoms of AIDS occur.

* People already infected with sexually transmitted diseases such as gonorrhea or syphilis are up to ten times more likely to be at risk for contracting AIDS.

* WHO estimates that up to 40 million people will have become HIV positive by the year 2000, compared to 9 to 11 million people presently infected.


LOAD-DATE: May 26, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


79 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 25, 1992 / June 7, 1992


Ugandan efforts loosen epidemic's grip


LENGTH: 734 words


Kambala, Uganda

Inter Press Service

Sexual behavior among Ugandans has been changing since the establishment here two years ago of the AIDS Information Center (AIC).

"The high demand for HIV (human immunodeficiency virus) testing and counseling in Uganda suggests that there is a preventive value of HIV testing and counseling," says an AIC report just released here.

The center offers free and anonymous testing for HIV -- which causes AIDS -- and counseling. The center is the first of its type in sub-Saharan Africa to offer such a service. 

According to the report, over 70% of AIC clients receive the good news that they are not infected with HIV, and they can maintain that status by adopting safer sexual practices.

"For those clients who are already infected, the ability to protect their partners is also a message which can empower people to change their sexual behavior," the report says.

Over 30,000 clients have received HIV testing at program sites here during the past two years, according to the report. AIC recorded positive rates of HIV at about 26% in November 1991.

Between June 1991 and May 1993, 280,000 Ugandans are expected to be tested and counseled. And during that period, AIC will open additional centers in the towns of Mbarara, Mbale and Masaka.

AIC was developed by a consortium of international donors, international and national non-governmental organizations (NGOs), including the Uganda government, the World Health Organization and the Uganda Red Cross Society.

The report says a recent review of AIC services by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control (CDC) found the quality of pre- and post-test counseling to be "excellent" and comparable to the best HIV testing and counseling centers in the United States.

AIDS was first diagnosed in Uganda about ten years ago in the southwestern district of Rakai. Since then, the disease has spread to all parts of the country.

Today, Uganda has the highest number of reported AIDS cases in Africa, with over 30,000 confirmed AIDS cases and about 1.5 million people out of a population of 16 million estimated to be HIV positive. Nearly all infections in adults are the result of heterosexual transmission.

Since 1988, the country's private and public sectors, in cooperation with international organizations, have been fighting the AIDS epidemic through dissemination of information and education. According to international AIDS experts, the work in Uganda includes some of the most innovative efforts developed to date.

Tactics include peer education in the workplace and in the informal economy, anonymous HIV testing plus counseling and support groups to bring about behavior change, and community outreach and assistance to persons with AIDS and their families.

A vaccine trial will begin in January, according to John Rwomushana, who coordinates research with the Uganda AIDS Commission. Volunteers are to be tested on a therapeutic or post-infection vaccine. He says the vaccine is reported to delay progress of the disease by reducing the virus load and its transmissibility.

The United States, Britain, France, Sweden, Switzerland and Zaire have also tried vaccines under the auspices of the World Health Organization. n


LOAD-DATE: May 26, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


80 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 25, 1992 / June 7, 1992


U.S. cutback cripples Zaire's AIDS program


LENGTH: 2107 words


Kinshasa, Zaire

by Cindy Shiner/Africa News Service

It's another hot Saturday afternoon in Kinshasa as Stephanie, Mireille and Rosy shuffle their tired teenage bodies into the Domino bar on the Boulevard 30 Juin for a beer.

Stephanie is wearing the same backless red flowered dress she danced in at the Spikizy (pronounced speak-easy) the night before, and Mireille has been whistling the tune to the song, ''Let's talk about sex, baby.''

"I'm better off than before,'' says Stephanie, 18. "There was no work, the family didn't have anything, and I was obliged to do it,'' she says of the decision she made the day her mother died to leave school and become a prostitute.

The three teenagers are among a growing number of young Zairean women who have decided to sell their bodies and risk fatal disease to survive in this economically crippled capital of 2.5 million, medical workers say. Unemployment is estimated at 70% and annual inflation has soared to 5,000%. 

Almost half of Kinshasa's prostitutes are infected with HIV, the virus that causes AIDS. Although that rate sounds high, it contrasts with other central and east African capitals such as Kigali, Rwanda, and Nairobi, Kenya, where up to 90% of prostitutes are infected with the deadly disease.

But unlike other countries in the region, which is in the heart of the continent's AIDS epidemic, the HIV prevalence in Kinshasa has stabilized, according to Mike St. Louis, a medical epidemiologist with the Atlanta-based U.S. Centers for Disease Control (CDC).

Determining how and why the occurrence of new cases has leveled off in Zaire could point health workers to strategies that might work in other countries. "It is a very big question, and a central question to understand AIDS in Africa,'' said St. Louis on a recent visit here.

But it is a question that may go unanswered. The CDC, a U.S. government funded agency, has withdrawn its financial support and its personnel from Project SIDA ("AIDS" in French), Zaire's AIDS program. The program is Africa's largest and most prestigious effort to combat the deadly virus, and medical workers say its closure could severely retard the continent's AIDS research.

The CDC says it is pulling out because the Zaire government cannot guarantee the security of CDC employees here. Medical workers were among 15,000 foreigners who were evacuated last September and October after unpaid soldiers led a looting spree throughout the country.

Tensions have continued to mount since last December, when President Mobutu Sese Seko refused to step down at the end of his fourth term in office. A growing democracy movement has demanded elections to choose a successor to the strongman ruler who seized power in a 1960 coup backed by the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency. On February 16, 1992, security forces fired on a church-sponsored pro-democracy demonstration, killing at least 40 people, according to church officials. (The government puts the number of dead at 17.)

One CDC official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, says that some U.S. State Department officials were "thrilled" after the pillaging last year, because the disorder provided an excuse to carry out earlier plans to scale back the U.S. diplomatic presence in Africa and bolster it in eastern Europe.

Project SIDA received about $ 2.5 million in funding over four years from the CDC, St. Louis says. Other assistance came from the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), Medicin Sans Frontiers, the government of Belgium, the European Community, the World Bank and Zaire's Health Ministry.

The project was used as a model for fighting AIDS in other countries around the world. "The government of Zaire, with all of its frailties in the areas of politics and economics, has been very progressive in the area of AIDS,'' says St. Louis, noting that the Health Ministry has been open about acknowledging AIDS as a national problem and has encouraged foreign aid.

With support from the CDC, Zairian doctors were at the forefront of AIDS research in Africa, and St. Louis says they have become international-level scientists, despite the economic and political troubles that plague their country.

"This is a very bad, bad thing. We planned a lot of things to do in Project SIDA. And these things are cut off and we can't do anything now,'' says Mukadi Ya Diul, a researcher who studies HIV-positive patients with tuberculosis.

Project SIDA conducted epidemiology research at eight sights throughout the capital, including tracking HIV infection in prostitutes, treating sexually transmitted diseases that facilitate the spread of the virus, and treating tuberculosis in AIDS patients. In Zaire, as in the United States, tuberculosis has become one of the leading opportunistic infections that kill people with acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

With USAID's assistance, Zaire also had an enormously successful education and condom distribution campaign. The brand most widely distributed, called Prudence, has become a word synonymous with safe-sex. About 100,000 condoms were sold in Zaire in 1985. In 1989, 9 million condoms were sold, says St. Louis.

Project SIDA's work with prostitutes was also innovative. The organization operated two clinics especially for prostitutes, provided money for transportation to and from the clinics, and provided free HIV tests and other health services.

Today, only one clinic with limited services remains, and its clientele has dropped dramatically since last September. The number of prostitutes seeking help dropped from a high of 443 in January 1991 to about 20 last month.

''The fact that prostitute intervention isn't going to go on at the same level will be the most visible impact'' of the departure of the CDC, according to Ann Marie Nelson, of the Armed Forces Institute of Pathology in Washington, D, who conducted pathology studies here.

Stephanie is one of the few prostitutes who recently visited the remaining clinic for an HIV antibody test. She said she used protection during dozens of sexual encounters, mainly with expatriate men who frequent bars such as the Spikizy, Domino and the Atmosphere at the Intercontinental Hotel.

But as a relationship with a Belgian man entered its third month and they began having unprotected sex, Stephanie got scared.

"I was sure I had AIDS. I told him I've made love five times without a condom and I'm sure I have AIDS, and he said, 'OK, we'll go get tested and if we have AIDS, we die,' and I said, 'OK, we die then.'''

They both tested negative. But Stephanie, whose cousin died of AIDS last month, said it is very tempting to have unprotected sex with the men she meets who offer her more than 10 million zaires ($ 100) to have intercourse without a condom.

Rosy said she has not had unprotected sex since becoming a prostitute three months ago. However, she is seven months pregnant, still working, and has not been tested for HIV. The Italian father of her baby was evacuated during the turmoil last October.

With its outside support plummeting, Project SIDA has fallen behind on tracking about 2,000 mothers and children infected with the AIDS virus, says Manzila Tarande, a deputy director of the project. Between five and ten percent of child-bearing women over the past five years in Kinshasa have tested positive for HIV antibodies.

Medical workers say they are not sure why the prevalence of infection in Zaire has stabilized, but it could be due to the country's education and condom distribution campaign and the fact that Zaire attracts few migrant workers. Infection rates are much higher in countries and areas of high mobility, such as along main truck traffic routes, and in big cities with multinational populations, researchers say.

Nevertheless, Zaire still has "an enormous burden of HIV disease,'' says the CDC's St. Louis, adding that almost half of adult deaths in Kinshasa are from AIDS. "The fact that (AIDS) is such a crisis in Zaire serves as only a backdrop for what is going to be happening in other countries in the next 10 years.''

The World Health Organization (WHO) predicts that by the year 2000 the cumulative number of adults and children infected with HIV will triple or quadruple, rising from the current 9 to 11 million cases to a possible 30 to 40 million. At that time, developing countries will account for nearly 90% of the world total of AIDS cases.

As prevention efforts in countries such as Zaire fall victim to international politics and domestic economics, hopes for a vaccine intensify. But that effort, too, is compromised by the crises. Doctors in Kinshasa wanted to begin conducting a major trial on an AIDS vaccine in Zaire using an African strain of the virus. But there will be few resources to conduct such research now that the CDC is gone.

''With the development of vaccine and clinical trials, we hoped to be the first in Africa to do this work,'' says Ya Diul.

Stephen Green, who is wrapping up a four-year clinical study on AIDS in rural southern Zaire, says that in order to conduct proper studies on AIDS in Africa, researchers must use a local strain of the virus. ''There's no use using a North American strain to detect an African AIDS infection,'' he says.

Zairian researchers say they will continue their work using the limited resources they have.

"We think that closing the project will have a negative impact on the knowledge of AIDS in Africa,'' says Nzilambi Nzila, a deputy director of Project SIDA, who recently returned from studying at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, MD. "We predict that the impact will be bad, but we'll see what we can do in the (transition) period.'' He says researchers will seek other funding from abroad. A national AIDS project supported by WHO will continue; an international physicians organization, Medecins Sans Frontieres, has expressed interest in working with Project SIDA and is looking for additional funding. The group's medical workers have already begun working with the prostitute clinic.

Meanwhile, 18-year-old Stephanie continues to survive by prostitution. She says that if there were a treatment for AIDS, she could buy it with her earnings and protect herself. "Now there is no means to do that, and I could die," she says. "I'm forced to risk my life for 10 million zaires.'' n


LOAD-DATE: May 26, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


81 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 25, 1992 / June 7, 1992


Dossier: Women's Rights Eroding in Sudan


LENGTH: 2747 words


Since General Omar Hassan Ahmad Al-Bashir seized power in Sudan three years ago, there have been growing complaints from women about human rights abuses by the Islamic fundamentalist regime he established, including harassment or worse by security officials.

International human rights groups, such as Amnesty International, have criticized both the legal erosion of women's rights and the growing problem of detention and torture of women who fail to support the National Islamic Front-backed government.

The continuing civil war between the government, based in the Arab-speaking, Muslim north, and rebels, based in the black African, Christian and animist south, raises tensions. Southerners, who reject the government's imposition of sharia and form the bulk of the rebel army, are frequent targets of government reprisals. As more and more southerners move into shantytowns in northern cities to escape the fighting in the south, conflicts over government edicts -- such as those on the rights of women -- intensify. 

On May 15, the U.S.-based Fund for Peace issued a report by staffers Leah Leatherbee and Hibaaq Osman, who investigated complaints about the treatment of women.

Below are excerpts from the report:

An unprecedented erosion of women's rights has occurred under the regime of General Omar Hassan al Bashir. The Bashir government's unwritten women's policy has included the humiliation, detention and in some cases even torture of female students and professionals, wives of political prisoners, and others.

Throughout Sudan's modern history, the status of women has been high relative to other African and Middle Eastern countries. Women have enjoyed access to education and civil service jobs, and beginning in the 1960s, women held important positions in national ministries and local government, as well as in prestigious fields such as law, medicine and education. Moreover, women participated in many aspects of economic life both at the national and local levels.

The Bashir government is energetically attempting to reverse the progressive tendencies of the past. Upon seizing power, in June 1989, one of the regime's first acts was to ban all political and non-political organizations likely to oppose the new military government. This included women's associations not affiliated with the ruling National Islamic Front (NIF).

Since the Bashir regime came into power an estimated 20,000 persons have been dismissed from their jobs because they have been associated with groups thought to be opposed to the NIF. Many of the 20,000 are women.

Crude official pronouncements regarding women suggest that some women may have been dismissed on the sole basis of gender. One such pronouncement was made by Bashir himself in January 1990 when he described the ideal Sudanese woman as one who "should take care of herself, her children, her home, her reputation and her husband."

Special mention should be made of women engaged in the informal economy of Sudan who work as street vendors selling food, on the margin of society and eking out a living in whatever way they can. Many of them are displaced southerners, easterners or westerners whom the government is eager to remove from the capital city. These women are frequently harassed, arrested and even flogged on the spot without due process of law.

Although rarely publicized, abuses against women engaged in the informal sector are routine in Khartoum, the capital, and Omdurman, the sister city across the Nile.
 
Dress Regulations

A government announcement made in November 1991 stated that Sudanese women should appear in public only in proper Islamic dress. On December 19, 1991, a presidential decree was issued in the Al Sudan Hadith by the governor of Khartoum requiring women to wear Islamic dress. General guidelines were put forward by an all-male committee in an eight-point plan which included requirements such as satr (keeping the entire body covered), and ensuring that the dress is loose and opaque so that no figure can be discerned through the material.

The new dress regulations are costing Sudanese women the freedom to make decisions as personal and as fundamental as what to wear and where to work. Moreover, the dress code is completely impractical, as it is modeled on the Iranian chador (Islamic dress with head cover, usually made of synthetic material in black), which is not suited to Sudan's sweltering climate.

Outrage about the government's policy is compounded by the pride most Sudanese women take in the traditional garment known as the thobe, a nine-meter-long dress which elegantly wraps the body. The thobe has long been a source of identity, modesty and practicality to the women of Sudan.

Some believe the regime is making a conscious attempt to confuse women about these issues as a means of further stripping them of control over their lives.

On January 24, the government denounced rumors that women were being punished for failing to comply with the new regulations. Acknowledging that time was needed to manufacture the new costumes at an affordable price, the government announced that the code would not be enforced until June. In a recent interview, NIF leader Hassan Turabi, claimed there was no law forcing women to wear the Iranian style of dress if they do not wish to do so. However, he did admit to a systematic policy of "moral education" designed to "encourage" women to wear Islamic dress. Meanwhile, Bashir recently announced that by May all women in public places, offices, streets and institutions should wear veils and opaque dress.

Appeals to the general public to cooperate with the police in these matters and report women who fail to comply, as well as official statements that such women can be flogged and forced to stay in their homes, indicate that the intention is to enforce the decree immediately.

Many women said they interpreted these pronouncements as an attempt to make all men become "dress police," and they expressed the fear that the apparent authorization of civilian street justice will be interpreted by zealots as a carte blanche to physically abuse "improperly" dressed women on the spot. Already, the Associated Press has reported the story of a woman who was stabbed to death for uncovering her hair as she washed before prayers at a public pump.

At this stage, it appears the government has not been able to secure widespread compliance with the new regulations. Those most vulnerable to enforcement attempts, however, are women who work or who are educated in public institutions where the regime's access and ability to coerce are most pronounced. We were told that women working for the Sudan Economic Institute are simply not permitted on the premises without accepted dress. A number of reports also indicate that some women have been sent home from their work place and ordered to "dress decently."

According to one source, the authorities are more insistent on the Islamic dress in Kordofan, and several women were beaten by the police for noncompliance. Another woman working for the United Nations Development Program in El Fasher was told by local authorities to comply with the new dress regulations. When she refused, the authorities forced her to leave her job.

Reports from Sudanese women living in Cairo indicate that there have been instances of Sudanese Embassies abroad refusing to renew the passports of women improperly attired.

Despite government rhetoric and the incidents of harassment mentioned above, the authorities have not been successful in achieving widespread compliance with the new regulations, as more and more Sudanese women view it as the last straw in a long line of humiliating and oppressive policies.

In December, a number of women at the University of Khartoum defied their Islamic dress code, and non-Muslim southern women are also defying the code. The Sudan Women's Union and another organizations established to preserve the national Sudanese dress have issued pamphlets protesting the regime's new restrictions on women, calling the restrictions a blatant attempt to deflect attention from the government's political and economic failures.
 
Marriage

In another intrusion by the state into the social fabric of society, the regime is encouraging mass marriages to "respect the nation's chastity" and to reduce the cost of traditionally expensive weddings.

Mass weddings have long been a tradition in NIF circles, but it appears that the Bashir regime is now attempting to institutionalize this practice. As an incentive, the government reportedly provides new couples with 3,000 Sudanese pounds to get married.

A number of people have already taken advantage of this money-making proposition and simply divorced soon after the wedding. The ironic effect of the government's "chastity" policy has been to increase the divorce rate.

Some Sudanese are upset by the regime's encouragement of mass marriages because they feel that the policy takes advantage of women in desperate economic straits who are also eager to get married. And, they feel the policy is a blatant political strategy for recruiting women into the NIF. Others argue that scarce government resources would be better spent on health services and other basic necessities.
 
Land Rights

Land ownership is one major area in which the discrimination against women in Sudan has stark economic consequences.

Land is usually granted by the government, and in most cases in which both husband and wife apply for land, only the husband's application is considered. If fact, it is rare for women to be granted land at all unless they are widows or have other special circumstances.
 
Restrictions on Travel and Movement(tx The Bashir government's attitude toward women is evident in itspromulgation of orders prohibiting women from leaving the country without theaccompaniment of a muharam - a male guardian or close relative. Anyone who wants to travel abroad, male or female, must submit anapplication to the Ministry of the Interior to obtain an exit visa. For a man,this is a security clearance procedure and many are denied exit visas foralleged involvement in dissident activity. A woman, purely on the basis of hergender must make an additional application to the "Women's Committee," anall-male body accountable to the Ministry of Interior. In very special cases where a muharam companion cannot be found (suchas in the case of a medical emergency or an extended period of study abroad),some women have been permitted to travel alone. In these cases, they eitherhave to have the written consent of a muharam, or the muharam is required tophysically appear before the Women's Committee to verify the accuracy of thewoman's travel account and to demonstrate that she has received permission fromthe muharam for her departure. This can be an impossible requirement to meet ifthe muharam lives far away. Women over 60 years old are apparently permittedto go on a religious pilgrimage without a muharam. Committee clearance, however, provides no ultimate guarantee ofpermission to leave the country. A number of cases have been reported in whichwomen were prevented from departing at the airport. The restriction of women's freedom of movement is not confined tointernational travel. A Sudanese newspaper reported that the governor ofEastern State issued a local decree stating that women must be off the streetsand in their homes between sunset and sunrise. Reports from inside Sudan also allege that attempts have been made byvarious local authorities to dissuade women from driving cars after 3:00 p.m. Women's freedom of movement is also restricted by a July 1991 familylaw that has been hailed by authorities as a victory for women. Under this law,a married women can visit her parents or close kin (i.e. persons whom shecannot marry) only on "reasonable grounds." It is the husband who determineswhich grounds are reasonable and which are not. According to the July law, even visits to female friends must besanctioned by the husband. A woman is not permitted to visit a male who is notclose kin under any circumstances. Under the Bashir regime, women have been stopped when strolling orriding in a car with a male relative or friend and asked to producedocumentation establishing their relationship. One person said that to avoidtrouble with the authorities, he never leaves home with his wife withoutcarrying his marriage certificate. Another man, who received a visit at hisoffice from a young female cousin, was sentenced to one year in jail.(shTorture

One of the most notable and tragic of the Bashir regimes "innovations" in human rights has been the introduction of the physical and psychological abuse of women.

Historically, even under the most brutal of previous dictatorships, strong cultural traditions demanding the protection of women have kept female dissidents from being subjected to the mistreatment visited upon their male counterparts. In a particularly disturbing departure from past practice, female NIF members have reportedly been trained to torture female detainees. Violations have included detention, torture and killings.

Among the examples is that of Bothaina Doka, a nurse at Khartoum Civil Hospital and a part-time employee of the Chevron Oil Company. Accused of being a supporter of the Sudanese People's Liberation movement, she was gagged with her bra, strung up by her hands and feet with her arms pulled behind her back, and beaten for over 12 hours.

Treatment of dissidents, real or suspected, includes women shot for refusing to comply with orders, sexually abused by security officers for failure to cover their hair, and imprisoned without charge or trial after peaceful demonstrations. When jailed, women have been physically abused, denied medical care and prevented access to family members, including nursing babies. n


LOAD-DATE: May 26, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


82 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 25, 1992 / June 7, 1992


Assassination Controversy Surrounds Angolan Rebel Leader


LENGTH: 2107 words


Washington, DC

Africa News Service

A year after a long-sought Angolan peace accord removed a contentious issue from the American foreign policy debate, Angola is again on the scene.

Jonas Savimbi, the Angolan rebel leader who was able to attract not only the Reagan administration but also many Democrats to his cause, is back in the spotlight. This time, however, it is Savimbi who is under fire.

In the forefront of the controversy are the executions late last year of two officials of Savimbi's National Union for the Total Independence of Angola (Unita). Pedro "Tito" Chingunji and Wilson dos Santos, along with their wives and children, were killed reportedly after long confinement in Jamba, the southwestern Angolan town that served as Unita headquarters throughout the war. Chingunji's fate has been a particular source of concern to many people in Washington, after he was recalled as Unita's U.S. representative in 1988, amid indications that he was under suspicion at home. 

Although Unita's leadership repeatedly denied that Chingunji was undergoing anything other than a change of assignment -- a story Savimbi now concedes was a deliberate misrepresentation -- Chingunji was charged and convicted of plotting against Savimbi. His stature in Washington, where he is credited with winning Congressional backing for U.S. covert aid to Unita in 1985, apparently kept him alive until late 1991, when he and the others were killed.

The story has come to light now because of the defection from Unita in March of two of Savimbi's most trusted associates, Col. Tony da Costa Fernandes, a Unita co-founder and secretary for foreign relations, and Col. Miguel N'zau Puna, the internal affairs secretary, who at one time was Unita secretary general and number two in the movement's hierarchy. The men say Savimbi was responsible for the recent deaths and for the elimination of many other potential challengers to his leadership. Unita, which conducted an internal investigation, says Puna instigated the killings to embarrass Savimbi and weaken his chances to win the presidency in the country's first free election, scheduled for September.

Although the versions of what happened differ, they are consistent with earlier suspicions that Chingunji got into trouble for undertaking contacts with the Angolan government that could have resulted in a settlement less to Savimbi's liking than the 1991 accord. Diplomats involved in the U.S.-mediated talks between Angola, Cuba and South Africa said privately at the time that Chingunji was present "around the edges" of those sessions, taking part in unofficial, parallel deliberations aimed at resolving the internal Angolan conflict (see AfricaNews, February 6, 1989).

The current controversy has reopened old divisions in Washington, where for nearly two decades Angola has been one of the hottest Cold War issues and Savimbi a favored anti-communist leader. Over the past seven years, Unita is believed to have received covert American assistance totaling $ 250 to $300 million for its war against the Soviet-supported Angolan government, which was backed by some 30,000 Cuban troops.

Thus far, the administration of President George Bush seems to be standing behind Savimbi, while emphasizing the importance of a smooth democratic process in Angola. But old-time Unita supporters on Capitol Hill are reexamining their stands. "Because this nation has been identified by its support for Dr. Savimbi, we have a right to expect certain specific actions will be taken," Senators David Boren (D-OK) and Frank Murkowski (R-AL), the chairman and vice chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, said in a letter to President Bush earlier this month. The senators said Unita, along with the Angolan government, must abide by the peace accord, release all prisoners, and allow free movement and access to its territory for Angolans and international organizations.

According to knowledgeable sources on Capitol Hill, Assistant Secretary of State Herman Cohen, in private briefings, has sought to downplay the internal Unita problems and refocus congressional concern on Angolan government actions. The sources say Cohen has provided assurances that Washington has evidence supporting Unita's assertions that the defectors are in the pay of the Angolan government. He also is said to support Savimbi's claim that the Angolan government hatched a plot to kill him in Luanda in March.

Following are excerpts from some of the most important pronouncements by the principal parties to the current controversy: (1) a statement in Washington by Fernandes and Puna, joined by Paulo Tjipilica, a long-time Unita central committee member and attorney who drafted the Unita constitution; and (2) Savimbi's response to Secretary of State James Baker's request for an explanation of the charges.

Former Unita officials Tony Fernandes, Miguel N'zau Puna and Paulo Tjipilica, speaking at the National Press Club, May 13 --

We decided to separate ourselves from Savimbi's leadership because of his permanent intolerance of other people's ideas, his continued abuse of human rights even in peace time. But foremost, when we learned about the execution of our former colleagues Tito and Wilson, their wives and kids, we pledged to each other that we would find a way to expose the murders, the executions and other gross abuses of basic human rights.

At the same time we decided to work with other like-minded colleagues to transform Unita into a modern civilian party. For this purpose, we announce today that we are organizing the democratic tendency within Unita to discuss the party's leadership that has to be elected following a broad political debate on Unita's own strategy and political agenda. We call on all Angolans to be vigilant and accept no more the lies that have become the strategic behavior of the leader of Unita. The pains we went through during the past 17 years could never be understood by those who have sincerely believed in Unita and its leader. At one time it seemed that Savimbi was the best thing that could have ever happened to Angola at a time when the country was overtaken by Cuba and what was then called the Socialist Republics of the Soviet Union.

We call on all people in Angola and abroad who want to see peace and democracy succeed in our country, to support our plea for an international investigation on what happened to Mr. Tito Chingunji and Mr. Wilson dos Santos, two Unita leaders who were opposed to Dr. Savimbi's dictatorial methods of leadership. The Angolan people, and indeed the international community want to know finally the whole truth about the human rights abuses within Savimbi-led Unita.

Letter from Unita leader Jonas Savimbi to Secretary of State James Baker, dated March 31, 1992 --

May I say in the first place that I fear violations of human rights are an inevitable, though of course, regrettable part of any war. The rights of hundreds of thousands, perhaps millions, of Angolans to security of person, freedom of movement, freedom of expression and even, in some cases, to life itself, have been violated for decades past, particularly since the invasion of Angola by Cuban forces, the imposition of an unelected government and the commencement of civil war. We do not relish the part our forces have played in restricting and violating these rights of the people of Angola, although we remain convinced that the struggle for self-determination, and democratic expression which entailed such violations was necessary and morally wholly justified.

From 1986 -- 87, we began to achieve real success in our efforts to ensure that our troops respected the rights of the people for whose liberation they were fighting. In retrospect, my erstwhile colleague, Miguel N'zau Puna, was a case where our efforts to persuade, rather than to discipline more harshly, were unsuccessful.

In 1987 and 1988, Tito Chingunji, then a promising young leader, held a number of discussions with senior MPLA officials. (The MPLA is Angola's ruling party.) Some of these discussions were authorized by the Unita leadership, but it soon became clear that the MPLA's goal was to exclude me from the leadership of Unita and then to integrate members of Unita into MPLA on the basis of the government's "clemency" policy. Tito was instructed to stop the contacts. It later transpired that he continued to meet in secret.

In time the story emerged. Tito (who named Wilson as a co-conspirator) had become convinced that a deal could be struck with the MPLA if I were removed. He and a number of others had developed a plan to destroy my reputation, alleging, inter alia, human rights violations and drug use, in an attempt to create a climate enabling Tito to take over the presidency. The alternative plan was to poison me in Jamba and rally the youth (and later others) to his banner. What made the situation particularly delicate was that Tito alleged that his plan enjoyed the active backing of the CIA.

Given the nature of our dependence on the USA for assistance and the risk that disclosure of all this would severely damage our relationship with the administration, we decided to pretend that Tito had simply been reassigned to a new post. We could not disclose what he had done without placing the relationship at risk.

I was determined that no harm should come to these two young men, not because I did not believe that Tito's intention to kill me should go unpunished, but because I was convinced they could be re-habilitated. I persuaded the other members of the leadership, moreover, that if serious harm were to befall them, the international repercussions would be very damaging.

We had, in fact, intended to have the two young men meet Congressman (Dave) McCurdy (the Oklahoma Democrat who chairs the House Intelligence Committee) and his delegation in Luanda early in January 1992. It may be that this prompted Puna to kill them so that it could not happen.

I am deeply frustrated at the fact that the tragic circumstances of the deaths of Tito, Wilson and their families are obscuring the assassination plot initiated by the government. The pattern of espionage, bribery, planned assassination and coordinated disinformation revealed by this plot is a real threat to the peace process.

I understand the need to deal openly and completely with the allegations of human rights abuses and trust that you agree that this letter is a good faith effort to do just that. We shall cooperate with you in dealing appropriately with this matter and putting it behind us. We are wholly committed to the process of peace and democracy on which we jointly embarked. n

LANGUAGE: English
