83 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 25, 1992 / June 7, 1992


AFRICAN NGOs HIGHLIGHT PEOPLE'S CONCERNS


LENGTH: 547 words


In the Africa-wide discussions held over the past year to formulate common perspectives and proposals for the Earth Summit, African non-governmental organizations (NGO) have been consulted much more extensively than just a year or two ago, says Peter Ngobese of Zimbabwe Environmental Research Organization (Zero), a Zimbabwean NGO.

Environmental sustainability should not just mean conservation of the physical environment, but also the sustainability of human resources, argue Zero and another NGO, Environment and Development Activities -- Zimbabwe. "There must be enough jobs, land, food and energy to meet people's basic needs while still sustaining the environment," they say in their report, The State of the Environment: Zimbabwe. 

A particular problem facing the Zimbabwean people is "the inequitable entitlements to natural resources" resulting from colonial policies that allocated land along racial lines. In the communal land areas, where a large portion of the rural population was confined, overutilization has contributed to severe soil erosion and deforestation. The rural poor therefore need "security of tenure and access to resources" if the cycle of poverty and environmental degradation is to be broken, say the two NGOs. They criticize the Zimbabwe government's structural adjustment program which, by reducing funding to environmental programs, "has institutionally marginalized environmental issues."

The Nigerian Environmental Study/Action Team (Nest) has similarly argued that some of that country's economic and development policies, associated with the rigors of structural adjustment and high debt-servicing obligations, have exacerbated pressures on the Nigerian environment. Besides incurring severe social costs, the economic austerity programs have "greatly encouraged mineral production and natural resources exploitation to secure much-needed foreign exchange," worsening the depletion of timber stocks, land degradation and other problems, argues Nest in its Unced report, The Path to Sustainable Development in Nigeria.

Environmental degradation can, in turn, bring serious economic losses, the Nigerian group says. Citing World Bank estimates, it reports that environmental losses cost Nigeria roughly $ 5 billion a year.

Most of these problems hit ordinary Nigerians the hardest, the report says. In addition, because of the enormous number of tasks carried out by women, environmental degradation has a "gender bias," imposing on women a heavier burden than on men. Nest argues forcefully that popular participation in forming environmental and development policies needs to be greatly strengthened.


LOAD-DATE: May 26, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


84 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 25, 1992 / June 7, 1992


African's Push Agenda for Earth Summit


LENGTH: 2600 words


by Ernest Harsch/Africa News Service

African countries are working to ensure that their concerns about desertification, poverty and other development problems facing the continent are given high priority at the "Earth Summit" in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, June 3-14.

In negotiations leading up to the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development (Unced), African representatives have been arguing forcefully that the continent's particular concerns should not be overlooked amid all the attention devoted to more global environmental problems such as climate change, ozone depletion and deforestation.

"For the majority of African countries daily confronted with the problems of thirst and hunger," says Burkina Faso's minister of environment and tourism, Mihyemba Ouali, "the struggle against environmental degradation is a struggle for survival. For us, the problem of environmental protection is a problem of development, a problem of the sustainable management of natural resources."

Similar themes were emphasized by many other African delegates who participated in the various rounds of formal and informal negotiations preceding the summit, which is shaping up to be the broadest and highest-level international conference yet held on environmental issues. 

Several key documents expected to be signed by heads of state going to Rio were tentatively approved in early April, at the close of a five-week round of preparatory negotiations at UN headquarters in New York. The "Rio Declaration on Environment and Development" outlines a general set of principles, while "Agenda 21" provides a detailed and comprehensive plan of action, extending into the twenty first century and spanning such broad areas as land degradation, poverty, forests, international trade, demographic pressures and toxic waste disposal. A draft convention on climate change has been negotiated, obliging industrialized countries to reduce their emissions of carbon dioxide and other "greenhouse" gases (although without any specific timetables, which were opposed by the U.S.). Talks have been taking place in Nairobi, Kenya, on a similar convention to protect the world's biological diversity.

While most donor countries have been reluctant to make specific financial commitments to back up their general pledges, they have nevertheless conceded that Africa and other developing regions will require "new and additional resources" if Agenda 21's ambitious programs are to be carried out. Some, such as Norway's minister of development cooperation, Grete Faremo, argue that "Africa deserves special attention in the process," given the severity of its environmental and development problems and its extremely limited financial capacity.

African governments believe their people have the "legitimate rights" to health, development and a healthy environment, declared Cote d'Ivoire's minister of environment, Ezan Akele, in presenting the "African Common Position on Environment and Development" to the preparatory meetings in New York.

While recognizing that Africa's commitment to sustainable development "calls for the use of our own resources in new and innovative ways," Africa nevertheless needs additional assistance from its development partners, E.O.A. Aina, director of Nigeria's Federal Environmental Protection Agency, told a March 29-30 meeting on the "African Common Position," sponsored by the UN Department of Economic and Social Development and the Washington-based Global Coalition for Africa. This assistance, Aina says, should include substantial debt relief as well as additional resources for the implementation of Agenda 21 programs.

Similar points were stressed by Guinea-Bissau's minister of rural development and agriculture, Mario Cabral, and Gabon's minister of tourism and environment, Pepin Mongockodji. Cabral warns the developed countries that no "oasis of prosperity" can last forever if it is "surrounded by increasing poverty."

Developing countries can either develop through the same environmentally damaging methods used by countries in the North, argues Senegal's minister of tourism and environmental protection, Jacques Baudin, or they can develop on a more sustainable basis, using new environmentally friendly technologies. These, however, cost more than most African countries can afford.

African delegates acknowledge Africa's responsibility to also help resolve global environmental problems and preserve humanity's "common heritage." Ouali warns, however, that under conditions of poverty and illiteracy, environmental protection often takes a back seat to more immediate concerns.

"How do you manage resources sustainably in a situation where there is massive poverty, where there is no development?" asks Peter Ngobese, environmental program director of the Zimbabwe Environmental Research Organization (Zero), a regional network of environmental experts actively involved in the African consultations.

The issue of poverty was also highlighted by Unced Secretary-General Maurice Strong, in a special message to an April meeting of African leaders in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, representing the member countries of the Permanent Inter-State Committee for Drought Control in the Sahel. "Poverty is at once a major source and a result of the deterioration of the environment," Strong stressed. "This reinforces the moral, humanitarian and social justification for granting priority to the fight to eradicate poverty."

The problems of drought and desertification -- the spread of deserts -- threatens livelihoods and economic development in many African countries and featured prominently at the Ouagadougou meeting.

According to recent estimates by the Nairobi-based UN Environment Program (Unep), nearly three-quarters of Africa's drylands -- which themselves comprise more than half the continent's total land area -- are now affected by moderate to very severe degrees of desertification.

Until the most recent round of preparatory meetings for the Unced summit, however, desertification received only limited attention, despite efforts by African delegations to press the issue. Some donor countries suggest that problems of land degradation could best be addressed through national plans.

This contrasts with the considerable international concern expressed over deforestation. Since tropical forests help absorb excess carbon dioxide (80% of which is emitted by industrialized countries), their preservation has been seen as a key line of defense against severe climatic change resulting from global warming.

However, African delegates point to the inconsistency of not considering desertification in a similar light. Mali's minister of agriculture and environment, Sy Maimouna Ba, argues that desertification deserves a high international priority, since its causes and consequences also are related to global warming. "Where do we draw a distinction between global and local environmental problems?" she asks.

With the aim of focusing African and international efforts on establishing "green belts" of trees north and south of the Sahara and around the Kalahari Desert, an international convention to combat desertification was proposed at a November 1991 meeting in Abidjan, Cote d'Ivoire, where African environment and development ministers drafted the "African Common Position."

At the recent preparatory meetings in New York, African position delegates again pressed their case against the creeping expansion of the deserts. This time, their position gained wide support, including support from the European Community. But further action on a possible convention on desertification is not expected until after the Rio summit.

Agenda 21 itself was amended at the initiative of the African group of negotiators in order to strengthen those portions dealing with desertification and drought.

The amendments put a greater stress on popular participation in environmental education, the role of women, the strengthening of national and regional capacities for gathering and analyzing environmental data, eradicating poverty and developing alternative livelihoods for people affected by desertification.

The African group estimates the cost of the latter undertaking alone at some $ 3 billion a year for all developing countries, while the projected financing required for programs related more directly to desertification, land degradation and reforestation has been put by Unced at an additional $ 6.5 billion a year, nearly half of which would need to come from external sources.

Such financing requests will face much competition in Rio. According to Maurice Strong the estimated total external concessional funding needed to implement all the programs encompassed by Agenda 21 would reach $ 125 billion a year, $ 70 billion a year more than current development aid levels.

"I realize that under today's conditions, this is not politically realistic," Strong acknowledges. But he says he hopes that the Earth Summit will bring an initial commitment of at least "several billion dollars" per year in additional financing for Agenda 21 and for the separate conventions on climate change and biodiversity.

F.L. Schlingemann, head of the Netherlands's Environment Program, told a Global Coalition for Africa meeting in March that if all donor countries raised their aid allocations to 0.7% of gross national product, as recommended by the UN, much of the additional resources needed for Agenda 21 would become available.

David Schiele of the U.S. Mission to the UN told the same meeting that the U.S. "will do what we can to help Africa," through increasing traditional aid programs or by more innovative methods involving the private sector.

The channels or mechanisms for the disbursement of any additional funding that might materialize was a matter of some debate during the Unced preparatory meeting. The developing countries' Group of 77 proposed a new "Green Fund" to complement Agenda 21, a call that was reiterated at an April meeting of the group in Malaysia. Others, particularly from the donor side, suggested that the Global Environment Facility (GEF), established in late 1990, could be a suitable instrument for enhanced environmental funding.

Administered by the World Bank and overseen jointly with the UN Development Program and Unep, the GEF currently has resources to commit about $ 1 billion in grants and technical assistance for projects related to ozone depletion, global warming, biodiversity and the pollution of international waters. Its first loan, early this year, went to Poland for forest preservation, another loan has been approved for a renewable energy project in Zimbabwe and several more loans are under consideration for Africa. However, many non-governmental organizations and developing countries have questioned the World Bank's predominance in GEF, however, given what they see as the bank's mixed record on environmental issues.

In response to such criticisms, GEF Chairman Mohamed el-Ashry announced at a May 1 news conference in Washington, D, that the facility would be restructured to broaden its membership and governing structure.

But, skepticism remains. Referring to the severe conditions imposed on African and other developing countries by the World Bank through its "structural adjustment" loans, William Pace, director of the Center for Development of International Law, warns that the new GEF may try to impose similar "political and structural conditions" on countries seeking to use the facility.

Maurice Strong suggests that additional environmental funding may be available through a variety of channels, alongside a modified GEF.

He recommends what he calls an "earth increment" in the current negotiations on replenishment of the World Bank's International Development Association, a proposal supported by the Nordic countries. Strong also proposes that new funding for the transfer to developing countries of environmentally sound technologies could in part be channeled through UNDP.

African countries have repeatedly signaled the importance of acquiring such new technologies. Their access is now hampered, however, by patents and other impediments, notes Abdelkader Gaid, director of environmental studies at Algeria's Secretariat of State for Scientific Research.

African countries have also urged respect for their "sovereignty" over the continent's own biological resources. At a conference in Algiers in February they established a new African Agency for Biotechnology, which will try to strengthen African countries' capabilities in this area.

In light of the high costs associated with global environmental protection, African and other developing countries are anxious to ensure that the burden is not laid on the poorest countries but on those, primarily in the industrialized North, that are most responsible for environmental degradation. The "African Common Position" affirms that "we expect our partners in global environmental management for sustainable development to adopt the 'polluter pays principle' in ensuring that our participation is fruitful." n


LOAD-DATE: May 26, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


85 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 25, 1992 / June 7, 1992


Election Preparations Begin Despite Difficulties


LENGTH: 1200 words


Luanda, Angola

by Vicki Finkel/Africa News Service

"What's the news today?" a British woman asks as she approaches a newspaper vendor on a war-battered street corner. "Politics, politics, politics," he replies, "nothing interesting at all."

"But my friend, Angola will have elections soon and you must be informed so you can participate," she tells him. "Why?" he asks. "We will all queue up and wait while the ministers and important people vote. Then we will be told that all the ballots are finished and there are none for us." 

After decades of colonial rule and post-independence warfare, many Angolans share the vendor's skepticism about their country's first multiparty elections. The reaction is not surprising, says Jorge Chikote, leader of the Angolan Democratic Forum, one of some 30 newly- formed political parties. "This country has always had dictatorship, people know nothing about multiparty democracy, and there is no education process going on."

There are many obstacles to the holding of elections, scheduled for September 29 and 30, in a country devastated by war with a population that is more than 80% illiterate. Chikote's Democratic Forum had argued that the problems were so massive that a five-year transition to democracy was required. But the shorter timetable is a central feature of the peace accord signed one year ago, ending a 16-year conflict between the government of President Eduardo Jose dos Santos, backed by the Soviet Union and Cuban troops, and Jonas Savimbi's National Union for the Total Independence of Angola (Unita), supported by South Africa and the United States.

Campaigning has begun, as demonstrated by the banners and posters throughout this capital, but it is unclear how far electioneering is penetrating into the countryside. "Most of the people cannot read or write and do not understand the elections," says Eusebio Faria from the state social welfare agency in the central province of Huambo. "Peace is the significant thing to them now," she says -- "the fact that they can return to their homes."

But as election day grows nearer, it seems likely that the chance to cast a vote may become more real for many Angolans. In fact, the widely felt desire for peace could provide an impetus for the balloting that would help offset the difficulties. "It will be a mess, but the election will have to take place," one senior United Nations official says.

Elections are the cornerstone of the peace accord, which designates an important role in the process for the United Nations. The UN's previous involvement in election monitoring in this region -- overseeing Namibia's pre-independence elections two years ago -- was considered a big success. But the UN budget for advice, preparation, implementation and monitoring in Angola is only one-quarter of what it was in Namibia, whose population is one-tenth of Angola's 10 million. The UN electoral mission "will be an operation limited in scale," UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali said in a recent report, similar to observer missions sent to Nicaragua and Haiti in recent years. He said that 400 international monitors are to be fielded by the UN during the polling. Another 350 may be provided by various non-governmental organizations.

"The national government is responsible for the elections," says Margaret Anstee, the UN special representative in Angola. "We are here to help provide technical assistance." A UN team is already in Angola, working with a newly formed National Electoral Commission charged with overseeing the entire election process.

With so much to do before election day, the government's delay in establishing the commission drew criticism not only from Unita but also from independent observers. But the new body seems to be trying to make up for lost time by plunging ahead this month with its first major undertaking, the registration of voters. This will put the peace plan to a test, since registrars will have to contend with blown-out bridges, ravaged road and communications systems, the danger of widespread land mines and a critical shortage of fuel and transport vehicles.

"This is a daunting task, and we have real concerns about the government's capacity under the time restraints, says Tom White, the chief UN administrative officer here. White estimates that half the registration process will have to be done with air transport and that about 100 helicopters will be required.

The effort to remove the thousands of deadly land mines littering the rural countryside has begun with South African and British assistance, but only limited headway has been made, and the task cannot be completed before the voting begins. In addition, some 400,000 Angolans must be repatriated from neighboring countries, a process that has not yet begun.

The election law stipulates that voter registration can only take place in areas under government authority. But this poses a potentially serious obstacle to the process, since Luanda's administration has not been extended to Unita strongholds in southern Angola. Similar problems are posed in Cabinda, an oil-rich enclave to the north, where the separatist Front for the Liberation of Cabinda continues to launch periodic attacks.

The peace accord mandates that a national army be established before the voting, but both sides continue to exchange charges of cease-fire violations and no progress has been made towards unification of the two formerly adversarial forces. Weapons are prolific, and the level of crime and banditry throughout the country has risen sharply.

Despite the difficulties, there is no talk of changing the timetable, which was one of the most contentious issues in the negotiations. International observers expect to complete the process even though they know that shortcomings will occur.

"This cannot be a perfect election," says the UN's Anstee. "It will have to be free and fair with the best results possible, but we cannot expect it to be what it would be in a more organized society with a long history of democracy and tranquillity." n


LOAD-DATE: May 26, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


86 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 25, 1992 / June 7, 1992


African countries lead misery index


LENGTH: 560 words


African countries are the poorest, most troubled, least developed and hungriest in the world, according to a group of recently released reports. Rankings from the World Bank, the U.S.-based Population Crisis Committee, the United Nations Development Program and the U.S. Agency for International Development list large numbers of African nations at or near the bottom in income levels, ability to feed themselves and quality of life:

* African countries account for more than 90% (23 of 26) of the most severely indebted nations in the world, according to the World Bank's World Development Report 1992. African countries account for more than 60% (33 of 51) of what the Bank calls "low-income" nations, the poorest in the world. 

* African countries account for more than 66% (20 of 27) of nations the Population Crisis Committee (PCC) places in the "extreme human suffering" category and more than 40% (24 of 56) of countries in the "high human suffering" category. The rankings, published this month in the committee's International Human Suffering Index, stem from measurements of health, income, inflation, secondary school enrollment, the number of telephones, and political and civil rights.

Mozambique heads the "extreme" category, meaning its population endures the greatest level of suffering in the world. The southeast African nation has the world's lowest per capita gross national product ($ 80 a year) and the lowest average daily calorie supply (76 percent of needed calories).

Somalia is listed just below Mozambique in the "extreme" category, and Sudan shares third place with two non-African countries, Afghanistan and Haiti, followed by Zaire.

Rapid population growth, economic decline and internal political conflicts are responsible for much of the suffering, according to PCC.

* African countries account for 66% (44 of 65) of the nations in the "low human development" category of the United Nations Development Program's Human Development Index, according to the Human Development Report 1992. The rankings are based on life expectancy, literacy and years of schooling, and gross domestic product. African countries occupy 18 of the top 20 places and nine of the top ten. Guinea is at the top of the list, and Sierra Leone is second. Afghanistan is listed third, Burkina Faso is fourth, followed by Niger, Mali, the Gambia, Djibouti, Guinea-Bissau and Somalia.

* African countries account for 75% (15 of 20) of the world's hungriest nations, according to the Agency for International Development's Food Security Index, issued in late 1991. Mozambique, followed by Somalia, Ethiopia, Sierra Leone and Chad were ranked worst according to the index, which is based on 1986-88 statistics for domestic food production, gross foreign exchange earnings, gross national product, daily calorie supply and child mortality.


LOAD-DATE: May 26, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


87 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 25, 1992 / June 7, 1992


ENVIRONMENTAL APPROACHES RECLAIM AFRICAN LAND


LENGTH: 1334 words


Africa News Service

In 1984, sand dunes were moving into Niger's Keita Valley, near the northwest border of Nigeria. The dry land was cut by crevasses dug by the runoff of vanished rains. The wind carried away soil. The few remaining trees were losing their leaves.

"The desert was rock," said Maurizio Malogioglio, senior program officer in the development department of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO). "The people in the villages would have left in 1984 to '85, except for the nomads who can get by on just a little grass." 

But some 156,000 people in 200 villages spread across 960 square miles (600 square kilometers) did not leave, thanks to their own hard work and an FAO program to reclaim the land. Led by women, the villagers abandoned the traditional practice of shifting cultivation, in which people moved from place to place every few seasons, clearing trees from new plots. With fertile land scarce, they began farming on permanent plots using new techniques: mixing millet with cowpeas, which fixes nitrogen in the soil; applying some artificial fertilizer; and "water harvesting," or building ditches to catch runoff and divert it into fields.

The benefits came with the first harvest -- and continued.

"It's become a green valley," Malogioglio said. "It's amazing. You see acres and acres of plants and crops."

But at the same time the Keita Valley was coming back to life, land in other parts of Africa was dying, losing its productivity.

The Global Assessment of Soil Degradation, released in March by the United Nations, says that 321 million hectares of the continent, 14 percent of vegetated land, suffered "moderate, severe or extreme degradation" between 1945 and 1990; 46% of the damage is water erosion in sub-Saharan Africa, and 38% is wind erosion north and south of the Sahara.

The assessment report, sponsored by the United Nations Environment Program as the first worldwide study of damage to the soil, ranked the two major causes in Africa as follows: 49% due to overgrazing, most serious in the Sahel and southern Africa, and 24% due to poor agricultural practices, such as not letting land recover long enough between periods of farming, failing to use adequate fertilizer on nutrient-poor soil, cultivating hillsides without erosion controls, and mismanaging irrigation systems so the ground becomes waterlogged or laced with salt. Deforestation accounted for another 14% of the damage and stripping land of wood for fuel for the other 13%, according to the study, published in World Resources 1992-93.

The destruction of fertile soil occurred while African farmers were falling behind in the race with population growth. Food production on the continent rose about 40% between 1970 and 1990, but per capita food production fell by about 20% during the same period, according to FAO figures cited in the World Resources Institute's annual report on the environment.

All but a small portion of the 791 million acres in Africa damaged between 1945 and 1990 can be reclaimed, according to the Global Assessment report, just as Keita Valley was. But doing so requires money and expertise beyond what the individual farmer can provide, and in the case of severe degradation, resources needed to reverse the damage exceed what developing nations -- already hard-pressed economically -- can muster, according to the World Resources report. Plots must be terraced and banks built along contours to stop erosion, ditches must be dug to drain fields, and land must be deep plowed and reseeded to restore its fertility after trampling by animals.

Restoring the damaged land is not enough. Future destruction must be prevented.

Africa's population, at 642 million in 1990, is expected to double by 2015 and reach almost 1.6 billion by 2025, according to UN figures.

As populations rise, there are not only more mouths to feed, there are also fewer acres available per person. Traditional shifting cultivation requires letting land lie fallow for years. Farmers face pressure to either return too soon to fertile land or to move onto vacant land that is less fertile and easily damaged.

How can Africa restore and protect its soil? The World Resources report, Worldwatch publications, and Africa in Crisis, a book by Lloyd Timberlake, editorial director of the environmental group Earthscan, give plenty of simple but effective answers.

Governments, the environmentalists say, must manage farmland on a regional and long-term basis and commit themselves to larger social changes, including:

* lowering the rate of population growth;

* giving farmers produce prices and marketing opportunities that create incentive and ability to invest in the land;

* ending preferences for export crop farming, which often leads to overcultivation and pushes farmers growing food onto marginal soil and herders onto evenmore easily damaged land;

* abandoning programs to settle herders, efforts that often lead to overgrazing;

* adopting the best of African farming techniques, which are adapted to the continent's poor soils and irregular rains, and combining these with methods developed by researchers.

The latter tactic often requires development organizations and aid donors to rethink their approach to agricultural assistance. Too often, Timberlake and other specialists say, the knowledge and skills gathered by the continent's farmers over centuries have been ignored by well-educated foreigners whose own ideas often prove unworkable under African conditions.

The only truly new development of the last couple of decades is agroforestry -- growing crops with trees that secure the land, produce leaves for fertilizer or animal feed and otherwise benefit nearby plants and the soil, says Alan Yates, a senior agriculturalist at the World Bank.

The FAO is promoting a return to "the bread and butter, no fancy techniques" in Africa, says Wim G. Sombroek, director of the Land and Water Conservation and Development Division. The integrated approaches to land management the FAO supports, like Keita Valley, combine agroforestry, planting crops that fix nitrogen in the soil, applying manure and some artificial fertilizer, improving water use and providing credit for small farmers. Eight countries so far have agreed to participate in the FAO's International Scheme for the Rehabilitation and Conservation of African Lands, launched in 1991.

"Soil conservation in Africa has been on the decline," Sombroek said. "Now it's catching on again."n


LOAD-DATE: May 26, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


88 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 8, 1992 / June 21, 1992


African Democracy Gets Little Notice in Washington 'Low Cost, No Controversy' are watchwords


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 3014 words


-- Washington, D.C

by Reed Kramer * Africa News Service

The U.S. government often has been in the forefront of humanitarian efforts to relieve suffering around the world. But State Department aides drawing up an advisory memorandum last month for Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger on the unfolding southern African drought were told to omit any reference to a need for increased U.S. assistance. Only a "reprogramming" of already approved aid to combat the expected human tragedy would be considered by the State Department's upper echelon, the aides were told.

And when the United Nations in April was deciding how to reinforce a fragile truce between warring parties in Somalia and get food and medicine to thousands of desperate residents of the Somali capital, the U.S. balked at a proposal to dispatch 500 armed troops to protect relief workers. Overriding the recommendations of officials involved in the crisis, the administration decided that a $ 7 million U.S. share for the operation might spark criticism from Congress, where the rising price tag for UN peacekeeping operations has provoked opposition. 

Critics of U.S. policy argue that the U.S. has a special responsibility to promote peace and democracy in Africa, because of a long history of doing the opposite. It is significant, the critics say, that of the six largest recipients of American aid to sub-Saharan Africa in the last 35 years -- Sudan, Zaire, Liberia, Kenya, Somalia and Ethiopia -- all are gripped by violent internal conflict.

Timothy Njoya, a Presbyterian pastor from Kenya who has been visiting the U.S. this month to seek support for his country's democracy movement, says the continent's most deadly conflicts are legacies of the Cold War, which built stockpiles of armaments that are now being used by rival groups against each other or by governments resisting democratic reforms. "The American arms that have been given to Africa are being used by authoritarian rulers to kill their critics," he says.

With Cold War rivalry no longer driving competition for influence, and with foreign affairs pushed off this year's political agenda, African issues rarely receive notice in Washington policy circles. Attention from the administration's top policymakers is generally limited to a lingering interest in issues that compelled attention in the Cold War era Q the transition from apartheid in South Africa, Angola's peace process and the fate of longtime U.S. ally Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire.

There also is little time for Africa among lawmakers on Capitol Hill, where

interest is generally limited to a few members in each house who write letters, sponsor resolutions or attend hearings, generally with the aim of pressing the administration into action on a humanitarian or human rights concern.

With the U.S. as the only remaining world superpower, the consequences of disinterest can be very high.

A "failure of leadership by the U.S." in the Somalia crisis, the human rights monitoring group Africa Watch has charged, contributed to massive ongoing suffering in that East African nation.

"Somalia is a place where a little action could have made a big difference," says Rakiya Omaar, Africa Watch's executive director.

"The U.S. today occupies a position of unprecedented leadership in the world," says Olara Otunnu, a former Ugandan foreign minister who now heads the New York-based International Peace Academy, a nongovernmental organization involved in conflict resolution around the globe. "A quiet word from Washington, a little bit of aid here or there -- this can be crucial in so many situations," he says. "As a result, the absence of U.S. action carries with it a heavy burden."

According to Assistant Secretary of State for Africa, Herman ('Hank') Cohen, the U.S. is meeting the challenge reasonably well. "It can be difficult," he concedes. "There's just not enough money to take care of every tragedy, but I think our record has been pretty good."

This month the U.S. pledged about $ 380 million for the southern African drought -- much of it re-allocated from funds and food that had been earmarked for projected winter shortages in the former Soviet Union that never occurred -- and led a campaign to win additional support from other major donors. In addition, stepped-up U.S. pressure on the Somali factions in recent weeks is said by many observers to have contributed to the success of the UN-mediated cease-fire.

But critics believe the U.S. could be doing far more -- and at little cost. "The Bush administration has failed to provide any leadership on African issues," says Michael Clough, who for the past five years has been senior fellow for Africa at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York. The end of the Cold War created an opening "to develop a new relationship with Africa," Clough writes in a recently published examination of U.S. Africa policy, Free At Last? -- but the opportunity has been squandered.

"Neither the president nor any of his senior foreign policy advisors has displayed any real interest in the continent," Clough argues.

He says that middle level officials charged with running Africa policy operate "with considerable latitude" but must follow three injunctions: "Don't spend much money. Don't take stands that might create domestic controversies. Don't let Africa complicate policy toward other, more important parts of the world."

As the administration's point man for Africa, the State Department's Cohen has been called upon to lead the response to the sea change which has taken place in Africa during President Bush's term in office. During the past two years, on a scale unmatched anywhere else in the world, most of Africa's 55 nations have moved rapidly toward political pluralism and toward adoption of free market economic policies that Washington has been advocating for years.

"We Americans who have been saying that Africans must democratize and must reform their economies must now give support to the changes," Cohen said in a recent interview. "The end of the Cold War allows us to do things we couldn't do before."

Under Cohen's direction and with congressional prodding, the administration has developed a policy of using aid flows to encourage democratic change. A substantial part of the annual $ 800 million U.S. aid package for Africa is being earmarked for countries making political and economic reforms.

"We don't want to be too rigid -- and above all, we don't want to require that African governments copy the U.S. system," Cohen says. But U.S. aid in the future will go to those governments that "embrace free speech, allow for greater participation by their citizenry," and demand accountability from government structures to minimize corruption and waste.

A quiet-spoken, 60-year-old diplomat who spent most of his career working on or serving in Africa, Cohen has won high marks for an earnest and disarmingly open approach to his job. In frequent appearances on Capitol Hill, he has received praise from both Democratic and Republican members, even when they have been critical of various aspects of administration policy.

Cohen has appeared on many platforms to discuss Africa throughout the U.S., and he has traveled extensively in Africa. The result, he says, is that African leaders "feel their concerns are taken seriously" by Washington.

"In the eyes of the Africans, we are not a declining power," he says. "They see us generally as impartial and they want us to be part of their solutions." Cohen cites U.S. mediation in Angola and Ethiopia as examples of successful interventions that helped end decade-long conflicts. "We made an effort in the Sudan, which didn't work, but we felt like we gave it the good college try," he says. The U.S. also has been playing a role in Mozambique peace talks and has been asked to take part in negotiations between the Rwandan government and the rebel movement known as the Rwandan Patriotic Front.

The fact that Africa is a low foreign policy priority has worked to Cohen's advantage, many Africa policy observers believe. "Unlike China, for which the president serves as his own desk officer, on Africa Hank Cohen has a relatively free hand," says Les Janka, a member of the National Security Council staff under Presidents Reagan, Ford and Nixon who is now executive vice president of Neill and Company, a Washington, DC public relations firm representing a number of African clients.

But Cohen rejects the notion that he is a free agent. "I don't consult the secretary of State on a daily basis, but I work under his broad guidelines," he says. "Support for democracy was his idea, and support for economic reform was something he was promoting as secretary of the Treasury."

Secretary of State James Baker III has directed Cohen to "follow South

Africa " and to "try to make sure all the work we have done in Angola leads to a free and fair election," Cohen says.

"Beyond that, I do make the day-to-day decisions and I think I've made the administration look good." good."

In late March, Baker suddenly reinvolved himself in Angola, which during the Reagan presidency and early Bush years was a pressing Cold War concern. Amid mounting allegations of serious human rights abuses by Jonas Savimbi, the Angolan rebel leader and recipient of large-scale U.S. covert aid during the past eight years, Baker dashed off a letter demanding a "full explanation" of charges that Savimbi was responsible for the deaths of several former top aides. After Savimbi's reply was received (see AfricaNews, May 25- June 7, 1992), Cohen was dispatched to Angola to talk over the matter with Savimbi firsthand.

Officials on the State Department's seventh floor, where Baker and his senior aides have their offices, say Cohen enjoys Baker's backing, even though meetings between the two are rare, as they are with all but the secretary's closest inner circle. "With the exception of Zaire, I can't think of any place recently where Baker and the White House have bothered to give direction to a policy issue on Africa," one well-placed official says.

The official was referring to discussions in March at Camp David, the presidential retreat, over the wording of a letter from President Bush to President Mobutu, calling upon the Zaire leader to reopen his country's national conference, a meeting of political, civic and religious leaders that had been debating Zaire's political future until it was suspended on January 19 by the government. In the letter, Bush appealed to Mobutu to exercise leadership and "assure a transition to democracy which can inspire the confidence of all parties," one official says.

The situation in Zaire attracted White House notice because of the history of close relations with Mobutu, a staunch Cold War ally whose country served as the base for U.S. covert activities in Angola and other parts of Africa, and because of longstanding personal ties between the Zaire leader and senior American officials, including Bush.

"We want to see a transitional government take full charge of the government and run everything," Cohen says. Mobutu should remain as "titular president," to provide "a sense of security" to the elements of the army "to make sure they don't go wild and engage in destructive acts like in Somalia." Bush's letter had the desired effect, Cohen says: Mobutu agreed to let the national conference resume in early April.

But many outside the administration believe the U.S. could play a more influential role in forcing Mobutu to relinquish power and avert economic disaster and widespread civil unrest. Calls for an end to all U.S. ties with Mobutu have been voiced by such leading members of Congress as Kansas Republican Nancy Kassebaum, the ranking minority member of the Senate Africa subcommittee, and Oklahoma Democrat David Boren, chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee. However, the president and other top officials have determined that, for the moment, the current posture will stand.

The costly political stalemate in Zaire is one of many indications that Africa "is still reaping the bitter harvest of the Cold War," says Martin Lowenkopf, a former State Department intelligence analyst. Four of the largest U.S. aid recipients in sub-Saharan Africa in the post-World War II period -- Sudan, Liberia, Somalia, and Ethiopia -- remain embroiled in devastating civil wars.

Writing of Liberia in a recent issue of CSIS Africa Notes, published by the Washington-based Center for Strategic and International Studies, Lowenkopf says that the late President Samuel K. Doe "would not have lasted as long, stirred up so much hatred and desperation, or developed the kind of security apparatus that compounded and prolonged the violence that eventually led to his downfall in 1990, had the United States not provided material support and political acceptance for 10 years."

Administration defenders say that recent events in Kenya demonstrate how aid can be a force for change. After resisting persistent domestic demands for democratization, President Daniel arap Moi caved in to concerted donor pressure and "the democratization process in Kenya is now irreversible," Cohen says. In discussions with Moi in Nairobi last month, Cohen raised the issue of Kenya's "history of rigged elections" and "how to make this one free and fair." Moi said he was willing to have election observers from the Commonwealth, made up of Britain and its former colonies, Cohen says.

In Free At Last? Clough recommends "principled nonintervention" as the major tenant of a new Africa policy, with all aid tied to human rights adherence, no funds going to political candidates or parties, and at least half of all assistance channeled through nongovernmental organizations. He also calls for increased interaction between American and African citizens and institutions like universities, which he argues could "make a significant difference in the way Americans relate to Africa."

One effort already underway to promote ties between Africa and a variety of U.S. groups, predominantly those involving African Americans, is the Constituency for Africa, spearheaded by the Washington-based development organization, Africare.

Cohen and other administration officials have emphasized growing opportunities for American business to get involved in Africa. "Only you, with your ability to create wealth, can help lead Africa out of poverty," Cohen told business leaders attending a trade and investment conference in Seattle last month. "There is money to be made, and when you succeed, Africa succeeds as well," he said.

There are many voices advocating what Otunnu of the International Peace Academy calls "a positive U.S. re-engagement in Africa in the area of peacemaking." The lead needs to be taken by Africans themselves, Otunnu says, "but the U.S. has a very important role to play."

Within the administration, some officials believe there is a pressing need for a re-examination of U.S. policy, particularly with regard to conflict resolution. "With all the changes that are taking place, we think this would be a good time for a policy review," one official says. "But politically, it may be awkward -- there's no real interest in tackling something like this on Africa right now." n

90 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 8, 1992 / June 21, 1992


Long live the king


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 294 words


The royal family in Ethiopia is planning a huge funeral for former Emperor Haile Selassie to be held July 23, the 100th anniversary of his birth. A separate event, a giant birthday party, is being readied by Rastafarians, who are named for the feudal ruler and believe he is the living God. 

Haile Selassie, which means "Mighty of the Trinity," held the name Ras Tafari as a young prince, before he was crowned emperor in 1930. Royalists believe he was the 225th in an unbroken line of kings that began with Menelik I, son of King Solomon and the Queen of Sheba.

In 1975, a year after a military coup deposed Selassie, the new government, led by Mengistu Haile Mariam, announced that the 83-year-old former emperor had died of natural causes while in detention. Royalists contend Mengistu and other military officers suffocated the emperor with an ether-soaked pillow.

A body tentatively identified as Selassie's was removed in February from a grave beneath a latrine in the old Imperial Palace. Members of the royal family have invited heads of state to attend a ceremony during which the body will be placed in a mausoleum in Addis Ababa's Trinity Cathedral.

The Rastafarians, plan to fete the "King of Kings, Conquering Lion of Judah" with a festival of Nyabingi drum music the rhythmic tradition that evolved into reggae.


LOAD-DATE: June 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


91 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 8, 1992 / June 21, 1992


Rhino's revenge


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 254 words


South Africa has sent a former army major to Connecticut to stand trial on charges of smuggling rhinoceros horns, autoas sent a former army major to Connecticut to stand trial on charges of smuggling rhinoceros horns, automatic weapons and hand grenades.rson extradited to the United States to face wildlife-related charges.

Meiring was arraigned in late May in the U.S. District Court in New Haven on charges of making false declarations for the purpose of illegally importing protected wildlife, automatic weapons and hand grenades. 

The extradition followed an eight-month undercover investigation by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. Meiring is said to have smuggled Soviet-made guns and rhinoceros horns from Angola through Namibia in South African military vehicles. The horns he is accused of bringing into the U.S. are believed to have come from endangered black rhinos. More than 65,000 of the animals lived in Africa in 1970. Fewer than 4,000 exist today.

All species of rhinoceros are listed on the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, which bans their import into the United States.

LANGUAGE: English

92 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 8, 1992 / June 21, 1992


Deep roots


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 174 words


Three fossil teeth found in Algeria have caused some scientists to push back by about 10 million years the date at which the branch in the primate line leading to humans was formed. 

The teeth belonged to a creature that was part of the line that evolved into humans, apes and Old World monkeys, according to a recent article in the British journal Nature. Previous fossils representing the same line were estimated to be about 38 million years old. But the teeth discovered at Hammda du Dra in the Sahara were embedded in 46- to 50-million-year-old rock formations.

The small creature from whom the teeth came has been dubbed Algeripithecus minutus by scientists.


LOAD-DATE: June 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


93 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 8, 1992 / June 21, 1992


No exit


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 294 words


Exiled King Moshoeshoe of Lesotho has put off returning home, pending a visit to London by the country King Moshoeshoe of Lesotho has put off returning home, pending a visit to London by the country's military ruler. The government has said the deposed leader can return as a chief and head of the royal family, but not as a monarch.d the monarchy of the executive powers it originally bestowed. He was deposed after he refused military orders to dismiss four government officials. The government named Moshoeshoe's son, King Letsie III, to take his father's throne.

Military ruler Elias Ramaema accuses the exiled king of plotting to overthrow him and sabotage preparations for elections scheduled for November 28. Moshoeshoe counters that he wants to see a constitutional multiparty democracy in Lesotho.

The exiled monarch agreed to postpone his trip so that Ramaema could travel to London to discuss the matter with a Commonwealth representative and possibly with Moshoeshoe himself.

Lesotho's military council issued a statement saying that there is "a tripartite effort involving the governments of Lesotho, Great Britain and the Commonwealth secretariat to ensure that the proposed return of the former king can take place in an atmosphere of peace and stability and that his return will in no way disrupt the elections due to be held this year."


LOAD-DATE: June 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


94 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 8, 1992 / June 21, 1992


Peace dividend feared


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 640 words


Soldiers concerned about losing their jobs, went on deadly sprees late last month and early this month, as government and rebel representatives prepared for talks in Paris aimed at ending a 20-month-old civil war. civil war.

The talks are focussing on achieving a cease-fire and developing procedures for future negotiations, according to a Rwanda Radio interview with Foreign Minister Boniface Ngulinzira.

For some government soldiers this is not welcome news. 

At least 27 people died when troops looted shops and homes in the northwestern towns of Gisneyi and Ruhengeri. Once order was restored, Defense Minister James Gasana and the heads of the army and police assured the soldiers they would not be demobilized. But soldiers later ransacked homes and businesses in two western towns and in the nation's second largest city, Butare, in the south.

About three-quarters of the army's 40,000 members are believed to have been recruited since the Rwanda Patriotic Front (RDF) invaded from Uganda in 1990.

As in neighboring Burundi, a majority of the population is from the Hutu ethnic group. But unlike Burundi, where the minority Tutsi control the government, Rwanda's Hutu group has been in power since a 1959 uprising against Tutsi dominance. Most rebels in Rwanda are members of the ousted Tutsi group

An Amnesty International report released June 4 says Hutu security forces executed more than 1,000 Tutsis without trial during the months following the rebel invasion, in retaliation for RDF killings of prisoners and civilians.

The RDF wants the government to allow Tutsi refugees to return to Rwanda from Burundi, Tanzania, Uganda and Zaire; asks that rebels be integrated into the country's army; and demands democratic reforms. Early this month in Brussels, the rebel group joined legal opposition parties in a statement accusing President Juvenal Habyarimana of opposing peace and democracy and calling for his removal from office.

Habyarimana's opponents accuse his regime of being behind a series of bombings that have killed or wounded dozens since March.

For its part, the government is offering to give all Rwandan citizens diplomatic protection and passports immediately, to distribute identity cards that do not name the holder's ethnic group, and to investigate human rights abuses, the Rwandan minister of works and social affairs said in a May 26 Radio Rwanda broadcast.

Fighting between the government and rebels fell off in advance of the talks, but was heavy during May. RDF members say they killed 1,000 government soldiers last month.

One of the latest casualties in the civil war was Mrithi, a 400-pound male mountain gorilla, well-known to tourists and animal researchers such as Dian Fossey. The 23-year-old silverback was found dead in his nest, apparently killed when either rebel or government fighters mistook a group of gorillas for the enemy. Mrithi was the first member of the endangered species killed in the conflict.


LOAD-DATE: June 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


95 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 8, 1992 / June 21, 1992


One thousand executed?


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 320 words


Amnesty International charges in a recently released report that government soldiers in Burundi summarily executed more than 1,000 people during counterinsurgency operations late last year.

A government spokesman responded to the May report by saying rebels, who have been mounting anti-government attacks, caused the deaths. However, a foreign ministry official says the government recognizes there were abuses and it has jailed some soldiers.

Amnesty International is asking for an inquiry.

The London-based human rights organization says it gathered eyewitness accounts of 11 Roman Catholic seminary workers murdered by soldiers, of prisoners left to starve or clubbed to death, and of civilians killed with bayonets or grenades thrown into their homes. Earlier, the government said about 500 died in November and December and denied that executions without trial took place.

Amnesty International says those summarily executed were Hutus suspected of supporting the rebels. Most rebels, who attacked parts of the northwest and the capital late in 1991, belong to the majority Hutu ethnic group. Most members of the army belong to the smaller but politically dominant Tutsi group.

Amnesty International also reports that security forces arrested hundreds of Hutus in addition to those killed. Some "disappeared" and some are still in custody without charge, the organization says.


LOAD-DATE: June 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


96 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 8, 1992 / June 21, 1992


No peace, no vote


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 146 words


 

Delegates at aan-African conference late last month in SENEGAL identified armed conflicts as among the greatest obstacles to the spread of democracy and worked toward establishing a committee to mediate disputes.s.

During the past 40 years in sub-Saharan Africa, armed conflicts have swallowed tens of billions of dollars and more than seven million lives, according to a report presented at the conference.

The region's countries spent more than five percent of their gross national products on the military during the 80s, according to the study. Between 1985 and 1989 alone, the weapons import bill topped $ 15 billion.


LOAD-DATE: June 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


97 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 8, 1992 / June 21, 1992


Democracy vote on hold


SECTION: DATELINE: AFRICA


LENGTH: 414 words


The transitional government of TOGO has postponed a referendum on a new constitution because of fighting in which at least 30 have died and 100 have been wounded.

The referendum -- the first in a series of scheduled national votes designed to lead to democratic rule -- was to have taken place May 31, but was called off two days earlier, after conflict began in the central town of Sotouboua. At least 20 people died, 40 were wounded and 1,500 fled. 

In Lome, the capital, a former government minister's house was ransacked and a grenade exploded at the home of another associate of President Gnassingbe Eyadema. The government has ordered anyone holding guns or ammunition without a permit to turn the weapons in.

Tensions are high between democracy movement supporters, concentrated in the more economically developed southern region, and people from Eyadema's home area in the north, who have been favored for government jobs and who make up most of the army.

An assassination attempt in early May that seriously wounded opposition leader Gilchrist Olympio and killed at least four others sparked a 72-hour general strike and demonstrations in Lome. Clashes in northern cities followed. At least one person died, streets were barricaded and buildings linked to Eyadema's political party were burned.

Eyadema's supporters and opposition members are jockeying for power as the country prepares for its first multiparty elections in 24 years. A national conference in August 1991 led to the formation of a transitional government to replace one made up solely of members of Eyadema's ruling party.

Olympio was expected to run for president against Eyadema. He is the son of former President Sylvanus Olympio, who was assassinated during the 1963 coup in which Eyadema came to power.

Transitional President Joseph Kokou Koffigoh has promised an international investigation into last month's attempt on Gilchrist Olympio's life.


LOAD-DATE: June 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June 8, 1992 / June 21, 1992


Human Rights Record Under Scrutiny


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 520 words


Three reports on the human rights situation in Nigeria have been released in recent weeks by two U.S.-based organizations.

*The Nigerian Police Force: A Culture of Impunity condemns the actions of the Nigerian police, the federal and state attorneys general's offices and the courts, which it says have failed to hold accountable police officers who violate human rights. The report says the problem of police brutality has been identified as a major human rights issue by Nigeria's human rights community. "Confident of their immunity from prosecution," the report says, the Nigerian Police "are increasingly responsible for committing serious abuses, including arbitrary arrests, the use of excessive force, and extra-judicial killings." The report was released on May 23 by the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, 330 Seventh Avenue, New York, NY 10001; phone (212) 629-6170, fax (212) 967-0916, telex 5106005783 LCHRNYC. 

*Nigeria: Attacking Those Who Defend Rights charges the Nigerian government with harassment of human rights lawyers. The reports says the government is in violation of the African Charter on Human and People's Rights, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the UN Basic Principles on the Role of Lawyers, and Nigeria's own constitution. This report, also produced by the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, was released April 24.

*Nigeria -- Contradicting Itself: An Undemocratic Transition Seeks to Bring Democracy Nearer, a special issue of the newsletter AfricaWatch, accuses the

current military regime in Nigeria of undermining the stability of future civilian regimes by continued human rights abuses and neglect of democratic principals. The 30-page report, a follow up to the groupincipals. The 30-page report, a follow up to the group's larger October 1991 study, charges that over the last six months, the government has maintained tight control over the

political process, continued to hold itself above the law, continued to viola 44-71-378-8029, telex 4026105927 GMA LU. n

as the universities, the press and the labor unions. The newsletter was released on April 21 by Africa Watch, 1522 K Street, N.W., Suite 910, Washington, DC 20005-1202, phone (202) 371-6596, fax (202) 371-0124; 485 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10017-6104, phone (212) 972-8400, fax (212) 972-0905, telex 910240-1007 FFFEXPSN NY; or 90 Borough High Street, London SE 11 LL, United Kingdom, phone 44-71-378-8008, fax 44-71-378-8029, telex 4026105927 GMA LU. n
