99 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 8, 1992 / June 21, 1992


Nigeria Stumbles as Woes Mount


SECTION: News Analysis


LENGTH: 1200 words


By Kingsley Moghalu A combination of social upheavals, seemingly irreversible economic decline, and human rights violations by Nigeria's military government have combined to make life a daily nightmare for millions of Nigerians in recent months.

Economic riots in the south and sectarian fighting between Muslims and Christians in the northern city of Kaduna last month reveal the inability of President Ibrahim Babangida's government to contain a severe fiscal crisis and rising religious tensions.

Babangida's six-year-old economic austerity program has failed to achieve its objective of pulling the economy out of a slump caused by depressed prices of crude oil, on which Nigeria depends for 95% of its export earnings. The recent protests have been sparked by increases in transport fares caused by gas shortages, which in turn were caused by the closure of the country's major refinery for maintenance. 

But beyond this immediate trigger, the riots reflect anger at the staggering inflation following the government's devaluation of Nigeria's currency, the naira, by 80% in March at the insistence of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank.

Discontent also is fueled by widespread corruption and a lack of public accountability by government. Tired of "tightening their belts" while the country's ruling military class wallows in luxury, Nigerians have lost patience with the once popular Babangida.

One disturbing recent action was Babangida's gift of cars to thousands of Nigerian military officers, a gesture clearly meant to placate the soldiers and forestall a possible coup attempt. Nigerians are asking how these purchases were funded.

A unpublished World Bank report reveals that about $ 2 billion of unexpected oil revenues in 1990 -- a consequence of the Gulf War -- are unaccounted for. In a thinly veiled reference to corruption, the report says that some $ 1.5 billion in revenues was allocated under ill-defined and poorly documented procedures outside the official accounting framework. These concerns have made the country's creditors unsympathetic to its pleas for substantial debt relief.

As a further sign of current difficulties, the government is having problems reaching agreement with the IMF on a new financial package that is key to the country's ability to meet its foreign obligations. In an unusual step, the Fund dispatched a senior official, Momadu Torre, head of the Africa department, to Lagos last month for top level discussions. Technical talks now underway center on resolution of such problems as the continuing budgetary deficit and oil price subsidies, which not only depress government revenues but also encourage smuggling.

The recent religious clashes in Kaduna, which claimed an estimated 500 lives, follows a long pattern of Muslim-Christian conflict. Tensions stem partly from a belief among Christians that Nigeria's leaders -- most of whom have hailed from the Muslim north -- have favored northern Islamic groups.

The religious divide has become increasingly violent since 1986, when Babangida approved the secret admission of Nigeria into membership of the Organization of the Islamic Conference (OIC) without prior discussion in the Armed Forces Ruling Council, the country's highest governing body. The constitution declares Nigeria a secular state and Christians have felt threatened by their country's joining the international Islamic organization.

Many Nigerians believe that taking Nigeria into the OIC was the biggest political mistake of the Babangida presidency. Roughly 90% of the population is evenly divided into Islam and Christianity, with the remaining 10% adhering to traditional religions. There is speculation that the government has discreetly withdrawn from active participation in the OIC following protests by Christians, but the country's membership status in the organization remains unclear. Even so, as in some other countries, Nigeria is discovering that religious fires are much easier to start than to put out.

Human rights violations by the government have increased sharply in response to public criticism. In addition to detaining and seizing the passports of human rights activists and lawyers, the government has leaned heavily on the press, forcing editors to tone down critical articles so their publications can remain on the newsstands. Recently, the news magazine African Concord was temporarily closed by the government for engaging in publications which Sam Oyouba, the information minister, said "offend national security and national interest."

The action against African Concord is seen as evidence of rising government intolerance for freedom of expression at a time when the military leaders are trying to steer the country to civilian rule.

Nigerians note with interest that American media pay little attention to the pivotal events in Nigeria, in contrast, for example, to extensive newspaper and television reporting on similar events in Thailand. It is hard for Nigerians to understand why Africa in general, and Nigeria in particular, which supplies large quantities of oil to the United States, is so ignored.

Nigeria's current crisis is seen as especially significant because it threatens the transition to democracy of Africa's most populous nation. Nigerians fear they are watching the concoction of a familiar recipe for a military takeover attempt, if not against the Babangida regime, then almost certainly against the civilian government scheduled to assume power in 1993.

In this uncertain situation, the human rights organization Africa Watch has cautioned Nigerians against expecting too much too soon from a new administration. "Despite the bleak situation awaiting the new government," Africa Watch says, "the only way that Nigerians can achieve their ultimate goal of democracy will be to be patient with the flawed government they will inherit and to work through democratic means to encourage a future in which stable, civilian governments succeed each other." n

Kingsley Moghalu is a Nigerian journalist and media attorney.


LOAD-DATE: June 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


100 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 8, 1992 / June 21, 1992


Big Apple Eyes Sanctions End


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 480 words


As South African political parties last month drew close to forming an interim government to guide the country toward free elections, New York City announced the imminent lifting of anti-apartheid sanctions imposed between 1985 and 1990.

But a second round of talks among South Africa's 19 political groups -- the Convention for a Democratic South Africa -- stalemated, putting New York's sanctions shift on hold.

New York Mayor David Dinkins had promised a "significant" reduction in the city's sanctions against South Africa, the toughest in the nation, if the talks established a multiparty executive council to prepare for elections in which blacks as well as whites could participate. He said he would make no changes until he received word from the African National Congress (ANC), the anti-apartheid organization that originally called for sanctions as a means of pressuring the government to end white rule. 

Dinkins' announcement came after he received a letter from ANC President Nelson Mandela stating that as soon as an interim government was installed the group would issue a call to end sanctions. In New York, the measures include:

* a prohibition on city contracts with companies or banks with business ties to South Africa;

* a policy of doing business with banks that have done the most to end the apartheid system; and

* a practice of avoiding investing the city's $ 43 billion pension funds in companies that do business in South

Africa.

Anti-apartheid sanctions by the federal government, states and municipalities cut the number of United States companies in South Africa to 110, from 360 in 1984, and reduced total American investment of $ 2.7 billion byabout two-thirds. The Bush administration ended most federal sanctions last year, but states and cities kept theirs to continue pressure for reform.

Also in May, the Congress of South African Trade Unions adopted a code of conduct for multinational companies that invest in South Africa once democracy is established. The code requires companies to create jobs, respect workers' rights, provide decent working conditions, protect the environment and use affirmative action programs to undo the legacy of apartheid. n


LOAD-DATE: June 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


101 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 8, 1992 / June 21, 1992


Donors Tune In to Southern Africa's Plight


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 347 words


Aftter months of uncertainty, international donors have begun to respond to pleas from southern

African nations for a concerted response to the region's worst drought in 100 years.

The pending disaster threatens to reverse a period of unparalleled change, including progress toward ending apartheid in South Africa; independence for Namibia; political and economic reforms in Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe; an end to decades of war in Angola; and hopes for peace in Mozambique. 

A United Nations-sponsored donor conference at the beginning of the month produced pledges of more than $ 525 million in aid from some 50 nations and 15 international organizations. Jan Eliasson, UN undersecretary general for humanitarian affairs, called the conference the most successful of it kind and expressed optimism that the additional $ 330 million in aid required would be forthcoming.

A similar aid appeal for the Horn of Africa in February so far has produced less than half the targeted $ 1.5 billion.

An estimated 18 million people face starvation in Angola, Botswana, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, Tanzania, Swaziland, Zambia and Zimbabwe. The U.S. has agreed to contribute about $ 382 million. Despite the large scale of the unfolding crisis, donors apparently feel the greater economic and political capacity in southern Africa provides hope that assistance supplied there will be more likely to reach those in need than assistance in the Horn, where war and poor conditions make relief work more uncertain. n


LOAD-DATE: June 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


102 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 8, 1992 / June 21, 1992


War and Peace Advance in Sudan


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1760 words


The biggest offensive by the Sudanese government in nine years of civil war has overrun about a dozen towns and driven rebels into the southeastern corner of the country.

But even with their backs against the borders of Kenya and Uganda, the guerrillas of John Garang's Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) are continuing their struggle against a succession of authoritarian governments based in Khartoum, the Sudanese capital.

As troops from the Islamic fundamentalist government advanced against the rebels last month, Khartoum hedged its bets by dispatching delegates to peace talks in Abuja, Nigeria.

While the two sides discussed the conflict in which thousands have died and more than a million have been forced from homes and farms, the shifting fighting has imperiled some 300,000 southerners who the United Nation's Operation Lifeline Sudan estimates are in desperate need of food and medicine. 

Relief organizations send most of their emergency aid to southern Sudan overland through northern Kenya and Uganda, the only feasible routes for delivering large amounts of supplies to much of the south. If the war forces relief organizations to operate solely out of Khartoum in the north, the flow of aid to the south will slow to a trickle, because supplies will have to be sent by barge down the White Nile, says Daniel Kelly, executive director of the Nairobi-based Association of Christian Resource Organizations Serving Sudan. The government has denied aid groups permission to fly to most rebel-held areas since the dry season offensive started in March.

The May 27 capture of Kapoeta, a center for relief operations on the road from Kenya, cut the main overland route into southern Sudan, blocking humanitarian organizations' access to most territory east of the Nile, Kelly says. But Operation Lifeline has so far been able to reach parts of southern Sudan west of the Nile and some territory east of the river, including Garang's headquarters of Torit, using overland routes from Uganda, says Detlef Palm, Nairobi-based program coordinator for Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund.

There are many reasons the government of Lt. Gen. Omar Ahmad Hassan al-Bashir has gained control over relief routes and the battlefield this dry season. Khartoum has benefited from:

* weapons Western diplomats say it bought with hundreds of millions of dollars received from Iran;

* the overthrow in May 1991 of SPLA backer Ethiopian military ruler Mengistu Haile Mariam; and

* a split in the rebel group last August that only began to heal early this month.

But the SPLA guerrillas have a single powerful element on their side -- the weather.

The rain that usually marks the end of the government's annual dry season offensive has begun falling already in southern Sudan. And, even if the dry season continues longer than usual, as appears likely, heavy rains almost certainly will make roads impassable by the end of June or early July, Palm says.

The rainy season, which continues through November, will leave government troops stranded on islands in the midst of the bush, controlled by the SPLA.

"As soon as the rains do come, the government troops will be in a vulnerable position," says a U.S. official in Washington, DC. "How are they going to supply these towns? Southern Sudan is huge. You could take all of Vietnam and drop it into southern Sudan and it would disappear. It's not like you can take 20,000 troops and go in there and subdue it."

Garang has vowed the rebels will fight on, even if the government takes every town the SPLA holds.

"What the government is doing is entering towns and saying it has captured them, which is true," says Bona Malwal, a London-based Sudanese journalist who endorses the cause of the SPLA. "But how much territory do these towns represent? I've never seen a guerrilla army defeated this way."

"The rebels haven't fought any big battles and lost," the U.S. official says. "There's been fighting (only) in the sense that the rebels have been harassing convoys and inflicting a lot of casualties."

"I don't think you can say there is a decisive victory by the government against the rebels," says Francis Deng, a former Sudanese foreign minister who is a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution in Washington, DC. "It's very easy to see these forces get back to the bush and continue fighting for years to come."

Even if the government succeeded on the battlefield, Sudan would not be rid of the deep religious, cultural and ethnic rift between north and south, fostered by the British in colonial days and widened in post-independence conflicts, Deng says. The north, which contains about four-fifths of Sudan's estimated 26 million people, is predominately Arab-speaking and Muslim. The government in recent years has imposed Sharia, or Islamic law, a move resisted by the black Africans in the south, who are predominately Christian and animist. Attempts to unify north and south by force will only fuel the anger that drives the rebels, Deng says.

Estimates of the troop strengths of the government and the SPLA vary. The U.S. official says each side has between 10,000 and 30,000 troops in the south. One press report estimates government forces at 80,000 and the rebels at 40,000.

Whatever their numbers, John Garang's faction of the SPLA, which contains 90% to 95% of the rebel troops, has been in retreat since the government began this year's offensive in March.

When Ethiopian rebels forced Mengistu Haile Mariam from power last year, the SPLA lost bases, a radio station and a source of military supplies. Since the split in the SPLA, government troops have enjoyed free passage through territory held by the breakaway "Nasir" faction, based in the Sudanese towns of Nasir, Akobo and Waat. The government has seized towns long held by Garang's forces, most recently Kapoeta, a crossroads of 45,000 in the heart of the rebel leader's territory that served as the headquarters for the relief arm of the SPLA, the Sudan Relief and Rehabilitation Association.

In addition to complicating relief efforts, the fall of Kapoeta sent thousands of refugees, including rebel fighters, over the border into Kenya and put further pressure on Garang's headquarters, a town about 90 miles (144 kilometers) to the west. Government forces cut a supply line, leaving Torit open to attack on two fronts.

An SPLA spokesman characterizes the rebel's losses of towns as "strategic withdrawals." But there are indications the setback is more serious.

The government-controlled Sudan News Agency reported that when the army took Kapoeta it captured 29 rebel fighters, including two lieutenants, chased three battalions into Kenya, where they were disarmed as refugees, and seized large amounts of weapons, food and medicine.

Elsewhere in the country, government officials report that hundreds of SPLA fighters, deprived of supplies, are surrendering.

This year's offensive represents the largest government advance into the south since 1983, when the SPLA began the latest in a series of north-south struggles that have divided Sudan since 1955. A 1972 accord granted the south limited autonomy and gave the country a decade of respite from civil war. But fighting began again after the government cut the south into three parts and seized areas containing oil, uranium and fertile land.

The negotiations in late May and early June marked the first time the government and the SPLA have met for peace talks in over two and a half years. The Nigeria talks were attended both by Garang's "Torit" SPLA and by the Nasir group, which split from the main rebel body over what it described as human rights violations, mismanagement and unrealistic objectives.

The government came to the peace talks with an offer of autonomy for the south within a federal system and exemption from Sharia for non-Moslem areas. The Torit SPLA came asking for a secular state and an end to Islamic law throughout Sudan, and -- if that was not possible -- either confederation or self-determination. The Nasir faction came demanding self-determination.

In the midst of talks, the two rebel groups announced they were unifying, at least at the bargaining table, to press for self-determination. When the government refused to discuss an independence referendum, the united SPLA agreed to drop the demand and discuss a Nigerian proposal for power-sharing.

Both sides agreed to meet again in Abuja at a later date. n --Karen Lange


LOAD-DATE: June 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


103 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 8, 1992 / June 21, 1992


Carter Turns Spotlight on Zambia's Economic Hopes


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1067 words


--Atlanta, Georgia by Richard Joseph

The Zambian trade unionist who defeated one of Africa's longest- serving rulers in historic free elections last year ran under the slogan: "The time has come!" Now that slogan must become the banner of an African/American partnership.

Last October, when it became apparent that Frederick Chiluba and his Movement for Multiparty Democracy was winning the countryuba and his Movement for Multiparty Democracy was winning the country's first free vote in 17 years, former President Jimmy Carter pledged to lend his support in helping the new government face the twin challenges of democratization and economic recovery. arter Center in Atlanta, examining growth and business opportunities in the southern African nation. President Chiluba has shown strong support for the process by sending five Cabinet ministers to the meeting, led by the minister of Commerce, Trade and Industry, Ronald Penza. Also taking part are economic advisors and representatives of Zambia's private sector enterprises. 

Carter is chairing the two days of discussions with international financial institutions, aid agencies, academic experts, private companies and banks. Though a less visible undertaking than the Center's monitoring of last fall's elections, our involvement in the Atlanta event has been equally demanding and will, we hope, produce positive benefits for Zambia.

What have we hoped to achieve by this meeting? First, we want to draw attention to the comprehensive socioeconomic changes that are occurring in many African countries alongside the more visible political changes. News reports are filled with accounts of the challenges of democratization and the transition to market economies in the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. Similar changes in Africa are not getting the same attention.

We also hope to combat cynicism within the American business community about Africa as a fertile terrain for private investment. Stories of the frustrated hopes of firms that have taken the gamble of investing in Africa could fill many volumes. Why, companies ask, should they believe that the experience of Zambia under Chiluba is likely to be any different?

The first reply to this question can be seen in the dispatch of the powerful government and private sector delegation to Atlanta to demonstrate the Zambian government's seriousness.

Few governments have been as faithful to commitments for quick and painful reversals of economic policies as has Chiluba's administration. Its privatization program, along with sharp reductions of consumer subsidies, the pruning of overstaffed agencies, deliberate probes of mismanagement and corruption, and the steady elimination of bureaucratic constraints to private investments are among the actions that have been taken with impressive urgency.

In Atlanta, we wanted to create a forum in which representatives from the Zambian public and private sectors could get frank and expert reactions to their new policies and hear sober reflections on the further challenges that lie ahead.

Among the most urgent of those tasks is managing the risks associated with the unrestrained capitalist strategy the new government has adopted. Clearing the way for private enterprise investments could also leave Zambia prey to exploitative practices. New economic activities could entail unacceptable social and environmental costs. These must be clearly identified. Finally, there is a risk that Zambian goals will be overwhelmed by the outward expansion of South Africa's much larger economy.

We also hope to help put Africa's economic recovery on the national agenda here in the United States, using the special moral authority of former President Carter.

In a recent poll in Poland, 39% of individuals questioned stated that they would prefer autocratic approaches to tackling the country's increasing economic difficulties. If Poland fails to experience resumed economic growth, the number of persons willing to abandon the new multiparty democracy will undoubtedly rise. Zambia and the other African countries which have opted for democracy and economic pluralism are hearing the ticking of the same clock.

But Zambia cannot confront any of these challenges successfully without changes in the global economy. Alongside the political and economic changes taking place in Africa, there must be a fresh examination of policies of the industrialized world that constrain development in poorer countries. These include high tariffs on imports from developing nations and heavy subsidies for agricultural and other products.

As citizens of richer nations, we also must assess the responsibilities of our own countries--and of the multilateral financial agencies such as the World Bank and International Monetary Fund--in helping clear away the massive debts that new democracies such as Zambia have inherited from former authoritarian regimes.

Now that Zambians are doing everything that can be asked of them to dismantle monopolistic political and economic systems, the spotlight must be shifted to us. n

Richard Joseph, an Emory University political science professor, directs the African governance program of the Carter Center in Atlanta.


LOAD-DATE: June 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


104 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 8, 1992 / June 21, 1992


Governments Pressed on Unasked Questions


SECTION: ViewPoint:


LENGTH: 1374 words


--Manila by David Korten

In the hundreds of forums, conferences and discussion groups around the world that preceded the Earth Summit, environmental activists have raised questions that go further than the formal debates in governmental circles. Much of the nonofficial debate has been carried in the pages of Network '92, the newsletter of the Geneva-based Center for a Common

Future and the IFC, a group coordinating nongovernmental activities in Rio. A

recent issue of Network published the following "guest editorial" by the president of the People-Centered Development

Forum in the Philippines, summarizing three major issues that have become promi-nent in discussions about radical new

environmental and economic strategies.

The governments of the world and thousands of citizens' organizations have assembled in Brazil for the UN Conference on Environment and Development (UNCED). There efforts will be made to formalize agreements intended to resolve major global environmental problems. Countless environmental issues have been identified, yet three fundamental questions, the answers to which are essential to any successful conference outcome, have been consistently sidestepped in official forums. 

Question 1:

Is sustained economic growth possible within a finite ecosystem?

The prevailing wisdom says that economic growth will provide us the additional wealth needed to invest in cleaning up the environment. This answer argues in favor of business as usual, with the added caveat that greater skill, wisdom and commitment should be applied in the quest for sustainable economic growth.

This argument does not take into consideration data which indicates that environmental destruction is a direct consequence of a world economy which has outgrown the capability of the Earth's ecology to sustain it. Economic growth and progress, as conventionally understood and measured, depend on increasing the flow of physical materials -- such as petroleum, minerals, biomass, and water -- through our economic system. We depend on nature to supply these materials and absorb the resulting wastes. But we have now reached a point at which further advances in human well-being must be achieved without further increasing the economic system's physical throughput. To survive and thrive, greater priority must be given to basic needs, wasteful consumption must be eliminated and physical resources must be used more efficiently. This means that more aggregated growth will only exacerbate the problem and hasten ecosystemic collapse.

If we do not bring our economic activity into balance with the limits of the ecosystem in an orderly way, nature will do it for us in a far more brutal way.

Those who challenge the conventional wisdom are dismissed as insensitive to the political realities and the needs of the poor. The real issue, however, is the reluctance of the wealthy to accept the

obvious implication that if further aggregate growth will not resolve the global crisis, then the only option that will assure the survival of human civilization is a massive reallocation of existing global wealth.

Unfortunately, self-deception is not an

option.

Question 2:

Is the removal of barriers to the free international flow of trade and capital consistent with the essential need for community and environmental stewardship?

Conventional wisdom says that economic growth, and thereby the well-being of people, is best served by the elimination of barriers to the free flow of trade and capital across national borders. We face two problems here, the first being the growing body of evidence indicating that increases in economic output do not necessarily result in improved human well-being.

The second is less evident but even more basic. The competitive market is a powerful force for human advancement and one of the most important institutional inventions of human society. However, as with any powerful force, including the state, it may turn destructive if unrestrained. In the East, we have seen the bonds of community and values of environmental stewardship -- both essential to a just and peaceful human society living in sustainable harmony with its natural environment -- sacrificed to the unrestrained power of the state. In the West, they are being sacrificed to the unrestrained forces of the market. Herein lies a simple lesson. The forces of both state and market must be balanced one against the other and held accountable to the people's interests through the mechanisms of civil society. Both balance and accountability are lost when goods and capital move freely across national borders and people thereby lose their ability to regulate their own national economies.

Question 3:

Is official international assistance part of the solution or part of the problem?

According to conventional wisdom, increases in international assistance are essential to environmental protection and the eradication of poverty in the South. While international assistance has continually increased over the past four decades, poverty and environmental destruction have consistently worsened. In the meantime, assisted economies have become strangled with debt -- the majority of it from official sources -- further deepening poverty and pressing assisted countries to mine environmental resources for foreign exchange.

Even if we discount the growing number of donor assisted projects actively exacerbating these unfavorable trends, we must conclude that official international assistance has failed, if its purpose has been to create equitable and sustainable development for assisted countries. There is therefore every reason to expect that more aid will only make the problem worse.

The official agencies responsible for the Earth Summit are not asking these basic questions. On the contrary, they repeatedly reaffirm the conventional wisdom with such ideological commitment that those who harbor doubts prefer to hold them in silence lest they be branded heretics.

It is unlikely that the delegates to UNCED will find the right answers to our global crisis without first asking the right questions. Concerned citizens have no alternative. We must commit ourselves to assuring that these and other fundamental questions -- no matter how heretical they may seem -- are asked and thoroughly examined within the context of the UNCED process and other official forums. n


LOAD-DATE: June 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


105 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 8, 1992 / June 21, 1992


The Concept of Sustainable Development


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1960 words


The call for sustainable development is not simply a call for environmental protection. Instead, sustainable development implies a new concept of economic growth -- one that provides fairness and opportunity for all the world's people, not just the privileged few, without further destroying the world's finite natural resources and carrying capacity.

Sustainable development is a process in which economic, fiscal, trade, energy, agricultural, industrial and all other policies are so designed as to bring about development that is economically, socially and ecologically sustainable. This means that current consumption cannot be financed for long by

incurring economic debts that others must repay. This also means that sufficient investment must be made

in the education and health of today's population so as not to create a social debt for future generations. Natural resources must be used in ways that do not create ecological debts by overexploiting the carrying and productive capacity of the earth. All postponed debts mortgage sustainability. 

Sustainable development is a comprehensive concept -- embracing all facets of human life. Implementation of models of sustainable development would require far-reaching changes in both national and global policies.

Sustainability demands a careful balance between the compulsions of today and the needs of tomorrow, between private initiative and public action, between individual greed and social compassion. Sustainable models will also require a major restructuring of existing budget priorities -- from military spending and inefficient public enterprises towards more human investment and environmentally safe technologies -- as well as mobilization of additional resources.

At the global level, sustainable models of development require no less than a new global ethic, a clear understanding that the world cannot be made safe for anyone without the willing cooperation of everyone.

Out of an unequal world of the poor and the rich, the concept of one world and one planet simply cannot emerge without some basic reforms. Nor can shared responsibility be created for the health of the global commons without some measure of shared global prosperity. Global sustain-ability without global justice will always remain an elusive goal.

It is within such a broad perspective that the following six basic policy messages are offered.

1. Environmental concerns are not a science fiction but a real growing danger.

The facts on environmental degradation are simply shocking. They are not the exaggerations of excited minds but a worldwide phenomena:

* Over the past 40 years, the world's population has more than doubled, to reach a size of 5.3 billion people. It is likely to double again over the next 40 years.

* About 10% of the planet's potentially fertile land has already been turned into desert or waste through human interference or human indifference, while a further 25% is endangered. Over 20 million hectares of tropical forests are being cut down each year.

* Most of the poor people live in the most ecologically vulnerable areas: 80% in Latin America, 60% in Asia and 50% in Africa.

* About 1.3 billion people have access to only polluted water; 2.3 billion lack access to sanitation facilities; and 1.5 billion lack sufficient fuelwood for cooking and heating purposes.

* The major industrialized nations produced some 9 billion tons of solid waste in 1990 including 300 million tons of hazardous waste; 70% of it is disposed of in landfills from where it can affect

human health and safety.

* American and European researchers have recently discovered that the depletion of the protective ozone layer is no longer just a problem in far-off Antarctica: it is about to occur over densely-populated zones in the Northern Hemisphere.

* Environmental losses are a reality. They affect the lives of billions of people -- in developed and developing countries alike.

2. A thoughtful response to these environmental concerns is neither a stoppage of economic growth nor a continuation of previous patterns of growth but designing of new models of sustainable development.

There is no choice between economic growth and environmental protection. Growth is not an option. It is an imperative. The issue is not how much economic growth but what kind of growth.

Continuation of the present state of poverty will be one of the greatest threats to the sustainability of the physical planet, not just to the sustainability of human life. Poor people and poor countries depend on the soil for food, the rivers for water, and the forests for fuel. Even though they need these resources desperately, the poor have little choice -- without assets or income -- but to overuse and to destroy their natural environment, simply to survive.

Continued growth in the industrial nations is necessary to generate both the new environmentally safe technologies and the extra margin of resources for transfer to poor nations. The current growth models of the industrial nations must change drastically. The current emphasis on quantitative growth should certainly be replaced by more concern with qualitative growth.

3. The new models of sustainable development must focus on people as their primary concern, incorporate new environmentally safe technologies into all investment planning and seek ways to reflect the scarcity value of environmental resources into future decision-making.

The new models of sustainable development must be based on at least four guiding principles.

First, these development models must place people at the very center of their concern. Environmental protection is vital. But is not an end in itself. Like economic growth, it is merely a means. The primary objective of our efforts must be to protect human life and human options.

Second, the new models of development must be based on the adoption of environmentally sound technologies. This is particularly important in the energy sector.

Third, we must provide a powerful incentive for reflecting the correct value of environment in all decision-making processes. Markets and private investors often regard environment as a free resource: the scarcity value of this resource is seldom reflected in investment decisions. The only effective way to underscore the value of environment is to put a price on it.

Fourth, sustainable development models must be participatory and community based. They must use local wisdom, experience and traditions for sustainable management of water, land and soils, forests, range and pasture lands, fisheries and wildlife. Unless local communities believe in and contribute to sustainability, national models of sustainable development will simply languish.

4. The concept of sustainability raises profound questions about the character and distribution of future global growth.

A question is often raised whether the present material wealth models of the rich nations can be replicated all over the world and whether the natural carrying capacity of the planet can bear such a burden. The answer is a resounding no. The North at present constitutes roughly one-fifth of the world's population, while it consumes 70% of the world's energy, 75% of its metals, 85% of its wood and 60% of its food. This clearly shows the impossibility of replicating and continuing present models of material consumption all over the world. The character of growth models must change.

What is more, the existing distribution of global consumption and global wealth must undergo a fundamental change. The North is not entitled forever to 85% of the global income. The limited carrying capacity of our physical planet raises profound questions about the material life styles of the rich, about simpler and less energy--intensive life styles all over the world, and about a major redistribution of future development opportunities.

5. There are critical differences between the environmental priorities of the developing and the developed nations.

Developed countries are preoccupied with global warming, depletion of ozone layers and disposal of chemical wastes. Developing countries are concerned with more basic issues of human survival: water and land. Thus, at the lower end of the income scale, poverty is as great an enemy of the environment as misspent affluence by rich societies.

6. Sustainable development models must avoid the false distinction between national and global environmental problems.

Such distinctions are often made. In fact, they are enshrined in the current oper-ations of the Global Environment Facility (a World Bank run environment "superfund") which is meant to deal only with the issues of global warming, destruction of biological diversity, pollution of international waters and depletion of the ozone layer.

Every global environmental problem results from a series of national actions. One cannot tackle global pollution without examining its national origins and dealing with its root causes.

Those who wish to tackle global pollution must tackle global poverty as well. The environment cannot be made safe at the global level if it is continuously threatened at the national level.

The Earth Summit offers a unique opportunity to strike a new global compact between rich and poor nations. If the human race finally discovers that its survival is linked together, then the Summit would have marked the beginnings of a new understanding, a new era of cooperation, a new journey of hope. n

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June 8, 1992 / June 21, 1992


Pondering Sustainable Development


SECTION: Dossier:


LENGTH: 160 words


In March, the Ministry of Development Cooperation of the Netherlands, the United Nations Development Program and the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development (better known as the Earth Summit and related activities) published a summary of the Hague Symposium, a meeting that convened some 40 international thinkers in

advance of the summit. Called Sustainable Development: From Concept to Action, the document will become part of a full report that is being prepared.

Following are excerpts from the summary's six-point policy message. The session also produced an action agenda to pursue the policy goals for presentation at the Earth Summit.
