107 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 8, 1992 / June 21, 1992


I Am Woman--New York


SECTION: Profile


LENGTH: 1347 words


by Tami Hultman * Africa News Service The first thing Wangari Maathai did when she regained consciousness in a Nairobi hospital after being clubbed by Kenyan police during a demonstration was to call a press conference.

Recalling the March 1 protest, where she joined the mothers of political prisoners in a march calling for their

release, the Kenyan biologist and environmental crusader says she felt a responsibility to the jailed men, who had spoken up for democracy at great personal cost.

It was not surprising that her participation made her a target of the authorities -- again. The founder of Kenya's 15-year-old Greenbelt Movement, she has become perhaps the most articulate symbol of the campaign for democratic reforms. She is able to mobilize action not only from international environmental groups, but also from human rights and political organizations around the world. Numerous government attempts to intimidate and silence her have backfired, making her more vocal and visible. 

When she appeared at a court hearing after the mothers' protest, limping from injuries suffered when she was taken into custody, the global network went into action.

Kenya's Ministry of Foreign Affairs issued a press release through its international embassies saying that most of the complaints it has received about suppression of the democracy movement "are centered around the arrest of Prof. Wangari Maathai." The statement denied that Maathai had been beaten by police, saying she was "suffering silently from rheumatism" -- an explanation that was greeted with hoots of laughter from environmentalists and journalists.

Still, the government is trying once more to still her voice. Maathai won a legal appeal to get a passport to attend the Earth Summit in Rio, but she is under court order to return by the end of the month to Nairobi, where she faces charges of "rumormongering" against the government.

Wangari Maathai is a perfect clincher for those who argue that women are Africa's future -- the key to democratization, sustainable development and environmental salvation.

Visiting New York en route to Brazil, she turns heads on the street. Dressed in a sweater and borrowed shawl against the unseasonable chill, with black Reeboks peeking from a tie-dyed cloth wrap skirt that has seen years of wear, she looks a bit like a rural refugee displaced to the streets of Manhattan.

She is also gorgeous, a quality irrelevant to her work but impossible to ignore. Her eyes sparkle, her ready laugh reveals straight white teeth, her capable hands gesture with animation.

Founding a group that has grown to over 50,000 women, who have planted millions of trees and saved thousands

of acres of topsoil, seems mere prologue for a person of such energy and optimism. She is already in the record books as the first Kenyan women to earn a doctorate, the first to be appointed a professor and the first to head a university department.

At the age of 52, she has earned ten international awards, is listed in three international "Who's Who" volumes, including Who's Who of World Intellectuals, has headed the National Council of Kenyan Woman and been appointed to several international scientific committees.

That she remains so vulnerable to attack is worrying to her friends, who have urged her to take personal security precautions. Asked if she isn't afraid to go home, she is uncharacteristically slow in answering. "Well, let me say this," she says finally. "I know that I am in danger, and I know that the government has tried to put me aside. At the moment, because of the political turmoil in my country, one cannot rule out the possibility of the worst, so I do feel that I need to take care of myself. I need to stay away from dangerous ground.

"But that doesn't mean that I will not go back home. I will go home because that is where I am needed most."

The mother of two teenagers and a son about to finish college, Maathai is a single parent, her marriage a casualty of her achievements and her notoriety. Her former husband was a member of parliament and a businessman, who finally tired of being regarded as unmanly by his colleagues for being unable to control his wife. Their divorce was a public affair, tried in newspapers -- her first but not last experience of a negative press.

Three years ago, Maathai scuttled President Daniel arap Moi's plans to build a 60-story office tower flanked by a large statue of himself in a Nairobi park, when she persuaded foreign funders that the project was environmentally unsound. Her victory was popular among downtown workers, who use the park as a lunch spot and refuge from urban sprawl. But her action earned her the bitter enmity of the ruling party, whose newspaper and a television station were to be headquartered in what was to have been Africa's tallest building.

Since then, Maathai has been under constant government assault. President Moi ruled that foreign assistance to women's development projects must be channeled through the state women's organization, effectively cutting off aid to the Greenbelt Movement, which also was evicted from its offices. She has been followed by menacing figures and threatened repeatedly.

Although Maathai recognizes that some of her problems have come from being a woman who dared stand up to men, she remains convinced that men and women must form a partnership for change. "I think that when we talk about the position of women in Africa and see how miserable it is," she says, "quite often we forget that these miserable women are married to miserable men. They are oppressed together, and it is only a small group of elite middle-class Africans who can say that they have made it."

"What I'd really like to see," she says, "is not just an improvement in the condition of women but the economic and political improvement of the African economy, so that all people can move forward."

Maathai's critics appear most enraged by her belief that rural women and men can be empowered by personal action and involvement. As a founding member of the Forum for the Restoration of Democracy in Kenya, Maathai is a lightning rod for the government's mounting anger at its opponents, a fact that appears not to deter her. "I don't want to pay a price with my life," she says, but she adds that fighting for democracy often entails a cost.

In an interview for the "MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour," Charlayne Hunter-Gault asked Maathai if the environmental movement has become a political movement.

"The environmental movement," she replied, "has become part and parcel of the pro-democracy movement." n


LOAD-DATE: June 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


108 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 8, 1992 / June 21, 1992


Gore on Africa


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 960 words


Senator Albert Gore, a Tennessee Democrat, has become the most verbal environmentalist in the U.S.government. His book, Earth in the Balance: Ecology and the Human Spirit (Houghton Mifflin, 1992), is a passionate plea for worldwide mobilization against what Gore sees as an imminent global disaster. As a member of the official U.S. delegation to the Earth Summit, Gore promised to raise, in the formal sessions, many of the issues that non-governmental organizations are discussing in adjacent meetings. Recently, AfricaNews spoke with the senator about Africa's place in the environmental equation. Here are excerpts from that conversation.

Africa News: How do you see Africa's political and economic changes in a global context? 

Gore: In the 1990s, the world as a whole seems to have made three important decisions: number one, democracy is going to be the preferred form of political organization on this planet; number two, modified free markets are going to be the preferred form of economic organization world-wide, and number three, people everywhere seem to feel themselves as part of a global civilization. Problems are now seen in a global context and tragedies, like the ecological catastrophies unfolding in many parts of Africa, can no longer be relegated to the back pages of our mind.

AN: Does that mean we should be paying more attention to events in Africa?

Gore: That ought to happen with those who are starving in Somalia or Ethiopia. It ought to happen to the victims of violence in areas of Africa that are undergoing such political turmoil. I believe it is only a matter of time before we see the effort to save the global environment as the central organizing principal (of our policies). If and as that occurs, then the problems besetting much of Africa will be higher on the list of priorities for wealthy nations like the U.S., and those of Western Europe and Japan.

AN: What do you see as the most pressing environmental issues in Africa?

Gore: Two items at the top of the agenda are climate change and biodiversity. The fires in the forests of Central Africa are almost as extensive as those in the Amazon in South America. The deforestation in parts of Africa is as extensive as anywhere in the world. Ethiopia had 40% tree cover at the end of World War II. Now it only has one percent tree cover. Problems like these should be addressed at the Earth Summit.

The stabilizing of population must be a top priority. Egypt has 52 million people today. Thirty years from now, according to the best projections, it will have 100 million people. Nigeria has 100 million people; it will have 300 million. Kenya has 27 million people today; within 25 years it will have 50 million people. Overall, the population of Africa is increasing so rapidly that the ability of the social and political order to accommodate these increases is strained to the breaking point. And good work by many men and women who are trying to rebuild their communities and societies is threatened by this instability that comes from rapid explosion in population and the pressure that exerts on the surrounding countryside.

AN: What sort of role is foreign aid playing -- and should it play -- in protecting the continent's environment?

Gore: Africa cannot hope to make it without help from the outside world. However, the amount of money that Africa pays in interest to the rest of the world is more than the total amount of foreign aid from every nation in the world which comes in to Africa. And in fact that gap (between money flowing out of Africa and resources coming in) is growing wider every year.

Robert McNamara said years ago that it is a little like a blood transfusion from the sick to the healthy. So ideas like debt-for-nature swaps (which reduce a nation's debt to foreign creditors in exchange for commitments to protect specific wilderness areas) must be pursued vigorously. At the Earth Summit, we have an opportunity to see the entire world reach agreement on the viability of an idea like that.

AN: Does public opinion support the strategies you advocate?

Gore: Well, we are not there yet, but we are nearing a threshold beyond which there will be a critical mass of public opinion in favor of saving the global environment. And we cannot save the global environment unless we save Africa and Latin America and Southeast Asia and Eastern Europe and other parts of the earth that are now under siege, where the environment is being devastated. When that is generally recognized and confronted, then political support for sensible measures taken in concert with Europe and Japan and the all rich nations of the Middle East, will become not only feasible but imperative. n


LOAD-DATE: June 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


109 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 8, 1992 / June 21, 1992


Crisis Rocks Oil Giant


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1294 words


Karl Maier * Africa News Service

Lagos, Nigeria

With discontent rising over plummeting living standards and severe fuel shortages, everyone from market women to foreign ambassadors sensed an explosion was coming here. Yet when it did, most Nigerians were shocked by its scope and ferocity.

A combination of anti-poverty riots in southern Nigeria and bloody clashes between Christians and Muslims in the north have rocked the military government, sparking a crisis unprecedented since an abortive military coup in April 1990. The regime of President Ibrahim Babangida has responded by shifting into a crisis management mode. 

After seven years in power, Babangida says he stands by plans to hand power to civilians a year and a half from now. But a question mark hangs over the leader's future. "We used to ask the question: 'Will Babangida really leave office at the appointed time?,'" said one human rights activist and government critic after the latest trouble. "Now we wonder if the government will last that long."

In a nationwide address to the nation on May 26, the president warned he would not be "bullied, through illegal action, to abandon the path of planned economic and political progress," and he promised "to crack down on all persons, associations and groups that seek to either derail the transition program or destabilize the nation."

Although expectations for the speech ran high, the only specific action Babangida announced was a two-year-old plan to create a national guard, trained for anti-riot duty.

The mid-May unrest in Lagos, a giant metropolis and Nigeria's commercial center, began when unemployed youths sidetracked a previously peaceful protest organized by the banned National Association of Nigerian Students. The young people smashed cars, looted shops and extorted money from passersby not wearing the green leaves that were a sign of solidarity with the anti-government demonstration.

Sporadic riots continued for several days, especially in the big Idumota market on the central island of Lagos, where local thugs known as "area boys'" sought to extort protection money from traders.

The unrest was worsened by rising disgust over fuel shortages that have nagged Africa's biggest oil producer for months, sometimes becoming so severe that several southern cities were paralyzed by huge lines of vehicles snaking through the streets waiting hours to make limited gasoline purchases.

The government's economic austerity measures, enacted in large part to satisfy foreign creditors, also have been a major source of dissatisfaction. A turning point in public opinion came with a devaluation in March of the national currency, from 10.5 to 18.6 naira to the U.S. dollar, which sent prices for basic necessities skyrocketing by 50% and more.

Since Babangida came to power in a 1985 coup d'etat, critics and supporters agree he has maintained the political initiative with a tightly controlled program to hand power back to civilians. A quiver full of military decrees, which the courts cannot challenge, has allowed him to shoot down problems as they arose.

On May 19, for example, the government banned all ethnic, religious and regional associations that have been organizing support for specific candidates in the national assembly and presidential elections later this year. Offenders were threatened with jail terms.

In an effort to weaken the ethnic, religious and regional divisiveness that has plagued Nigerian politics since independence from Britain in 1960, the military created the country's two sole legal political parties, the National Republican Convention and the Social Democratic Party, and wrote their party platforms. The regime has shifted the date for a return to civilian rule from its original date of October 1990 to January 1993. Politicians have been banned, then unbanned. Human rights activists have been detained and then set free, their passports confiscated and then returned.

For Babangida, the complexities of ruling a nation of nearly 90 million people and 250 ethnic groups are taking their toll. The government has drawn consistent fire from Muslim fundamentalists in the north for refusing to turn Nigeria into an Islamic state.

Although the religious clashes that claimed several hundred lives last month pose problems for the military leaders, the most vociferous critics of Babangida's transition program come from the small, intelligencia centered in Lagos.

The latest confrontation came with the arrest on May 19 of three leading members of the Campaign for Democracy -- Beko Ransome-Kuti, Femi Falanae and Baba Omojola -- and on May 29 of a fourth, Chief Gani Fawehinmi. "If the government thinks it can divert attention from the ongoing social protests enveloping the country by arresting patriots it is simply engaging in self-deceit," the Committee for the Defense of Human Rights said in a statement after the crackdown. "We therefore call on the Nigerian people to rise up with us to terminate the Babangida regime without further delay."

The government faces trouble on the external front as well. An agreement with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) on a new one-year standby credit agreement has stumbled over the government's massive budget deficit. The shortfall officially totaled $ 1.7 billion last year, but some Western donors believe it was closer to $ 2.5 billion. Last year's standby agreement was aborted after Nigeria missed meeting targets on curbing state spending and managing the exchange rate.

Without a new IMF stamp of approval, Nigeria has little hope of rescheduling its official debt to foreign creditors and reducing its debt service obligations this year, which now total $ 5 billion -- about half of total export earnings. IMF disapproval would also mean that negotiations on a three-year Extended Structural Adjustment Facility (ESAF), for which Nigeria is now eligible, would have to await the incoming civilian administration.

Nigeria's total foreign debt of $ 30 billion is the biggest in sub-Saharan Africa.

But with public outrage over fuel shortages so high, Babangida has ruled out the one possible action that could immediately erase the budget deficit: lifting the government subsidy on the price of fuel, which is among the lowest in the world. n


LOAD-DATE: June 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


110 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 8, 1992 / June 21, 1992


Africans Push More Ambitious Environment Goals


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1894 words


The slogan "Think globally, act locally," coined by environmental groups in the wealthy, industrialized countries of the northern hemisphere, is becoming a way of life for more and more people in the poor nations of the south. From mountain farmers protecting a nature reserve in Cameroon to Kenyan scientists developing environment-friendly pest controls, Africans are part of the trend.

No one person better personifies the environmental movement in developing countries than biologist Wangari Maathai of Kenya, who says that awareness of the need for urgent collective action is spreading. "People have personalized the message," she says, "because they have seen the need to take care of their immediate environment, and by participating they have been able to reap some of the benefits."

At the same time, the growing numbers of people trying to eke out a living on fragile tropical soils is putting unprecedented pressure on local resources. Trees are cut for fuel. Water is polluted by agricultural chemicals. Wildlife is killed by farmers shielding their crops. 

That reality has spawned a view evident in environmental discussions and press reports in the north, that people in poorer countries have less vested interest in protecting the environment than those in more developed nations. Newsweek magazine quotes a Western diplomat who characterized the view of many poor countries this way: "If there's a decision to be made between development and environment, they'll go for development."

Presenting the case for financial assistance to help poorer countries develop in ecologically sound ways, Newsweek says the world will reap the benefit. People in developing countries, the magazine

says, "might someday look at a tree the way people do in Marin County as the handiwork of God, rather than a big piece of firewood stuck in the ground."

Tell that to Wangari Maathai! The Greenbelt Movement she founded 15 years ago has mobilized 50,000 women who already have planted millions of trees and are still going strong.

As Maathai sees it, the debate over development versus the environment is a false one. The more pressing issue is one of power: who wields it and who benefits? As long as poor-country dictators are installed, supported or tolerated by powerful international interests, she argues, the global environment is at risk. Only democratic structures that empower ordinary people -- especially women -- can save the world.

"When we plant trees in Kenya," Maathai says, "we know that we will eventually have our hands on politics, on economics, on culture, on all aspects that either destroy or create a sustainable environment. And in countries like ours, where there is a lot of poverty, you eventually have to address that issue and ask: 'Why is there so much poverty?"

Maathai and other developing-country environmentalists acknowledge that rural peasants around &the world will chop trees or kill animals to survive the next day. On the other hand, the activists argue, poor people--when given the slightest margin to act in their own behalf--become the world's most vociferous conservationists.

To even the most zealous North American activist, issues like global warming are several removes from daily survival. Living closer to the edge, people in developing countries can reap immediate, tangible benefits from environmental protection and reclamation. A road not built through a coastal mangrove swamp spares the habitat upon which the day's fishing depends. A rain forest exempted from logging will provide culls for vital cooking fuel. A river saved from pollutants can be the difference between life and death for entire communities.

The spreading realization that rich and poor are united in their long-term dependence on a shared global heritage is the impetus behind the "Earth Summit" in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. The hundreds of world leaders and thousands of concerned citizens who have converged on the summit have begun, at least superficially, to speak a common language.

"Sustainable development," the concept that economic growth must be pursued in a way that preserves the ability of future generations to meet their own needs, is being championed in the halls of the World Bank, the mines of Zambia, the deserts of north Africa and the streets of Nairobi.

But how to achieve the goal remains a bitterly divisive question. One of the problems, says American economist Winifred Armstrong, is that governments remain committed to an obsolete model of economic growth. "As I see it," she says, "neither the North nor the South is sustainable under the present economic framework. Trying harder, using current economic premises, is clearly not working."

Armstrong, who derives her perspective from applied experience, including years of work for a major U.S. mining company with extensive international interests, recently returned from seven months of travel across Africa. She says both individuals and governments need to move beyond the restrictive framework of both capitalist and socialist economic models.

Like Armstrong, Wangari Maathai sees a multiplicity of factors constraining healthy economic growth, including the massive debts encouraged by international lenders and incurred by corrupt or inefficient authoritarian governments. Africa has the largest proportional debt burden by far, and repayment obligations consume the bulk of many countries' resources. The need to earn foreign currency to repay those debts has intensified the drive to abandon subsistence agriculture and clear forests in order to grow cash crops for export. "It is ordinary men, women and children who pay," Maathai says.

"Most people I talked to in Africa," says Winifred Armstrong, "believe they can live primarily on what their countries produce. But under the prevailing export model of growth, most African countries can't even survive."

Maathai believes that foreign aid, whether in the form of loans or grants, has played a direct role in stifling African development. "We have seen a lot of aid flowing into Africa," she told Charlayne Hunter-Gault of the "MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour." "But a lot of that aid was in the form of arms that were used to sustain dictators that we are now desperately trying to get rid of. And this was done with the full knowledge and support of the super powers."

African activists are insisting that shared power, not only within individual countries but also among the world's nations, is an essential ingredient of global progress.

"Certain actions by the industrialized countries indicate that developing countries will have problems being taken seriously in Rio," says Tendai Msengezi of the Southern African Research and Documentation Center (SARDC) based in Harare, Zimbabwe. "Developing countries fear that the industrialized countries are determined to dictate to them.

Economists and environmentalists from poor countries worry that -- despite the hoopla surrounding the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro -- developed nations will push ineffective half measures: insisting that poor countries remove tariffs on imports, while retaining their own barriers against competition from the developing world; insisting on debt repayment, while paying bottom dollar for the commodities that poor countries produce; demanding protection of wildlife in tourist-frequented game parks, but encouraging roads through rain forests housing endangered species; financing reforestation on the one hand and backing mining projects that denude vast tracks on the other.

Korinna Horta of the Washington, DC-based Environmental Defense Fund, maintains that "on the ground, it's business as usual." She cites a $ 10 milliongrant by the Global Environment Facility -- a sort of environmental superfund launched in 1990 and administered by the World Bank -- to a project in Congo, whose stated aim is to "bring forestry exploitation back to life." The United Nations Development Program and the World Rain Forest Movement are among the groups who have questioned whether renewed logging will benefit the area the grant is intended to protect.

The Bush administration's announcement that the United States will oppose the biodiversity treaty negotiated last month by 98 nations in Nairobi has further fueled doubts that northern governments are willing to do more than talk tough about the environment. The treaty, which was to have been a major achievement of the Rio meeting, along with an agreement on global warming, aims to protect threatened plants, animals and natural resources around the world.

In a SARDC report last month, Tendai Msengezi wrote that at the final preparatory meeting in New York prior to the Summit, northern governments balked at any conference follow-up "that is not dominated by the G7 countries (the United States, Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan)."

"Britain led an opposition group from the industrialized countries," Msengezi wrote, "which refused a proposal made by 40 developing countries for a sustainable development commission to monitor the performances of both the North and the South in implementing decisions that would have been arrived at in Brazil."

So the image of wealthy nations pressing for environmental safeguards and poor nations resisting strict standards, in the interests of their own development, may be turned topsy-turvy in the months after Rio. If the representatives of grassroots groups, green movements and non-governmental organizations forge a global network, as many hope, their voices may become the chorus that drowns out the established tune equating economic health with conventional growth models.

"Am I optimistic that we will do it? Not necessarily," says Winifred Armstrong. "Am I optimistic that we can do it? Yes." n


LOAD-DATE: June 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


111 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 22, 1992


The Cupboard Is Bare


LENGTH: 801 words


Zambia's president and its minister of commerce are appealing to Europe and the United States for investment, as the country's young democratically elected government faces a meager harvest, labor unrest and clashes between members of the ousted and the current ruling parties.

"If we falter for not having the right vision, democracy will perish," Minister of Commerce, Trade and Industry Ronald Penza told those attending an investment conference June 11 and 12 at the Carter Center in Atlanta (see AfricaNews, June 8, 1992, page 5).

Penza and other cabinet ministers said Zambia -- committed to major reforms since trade unionist Frederick Chiluba was elected president last October -- plans to reduce state ownership in the dominant copper mining industry, as well as in tourism and farming, paring the public sector to 20% of the economy from its present 80%. The country's labor leaders are urging a go-slow approach to privatization, which often involves a loss of jobs. 

Chiluba, who was general secretary of the Zambian Congress of Trade Unions when he defeated Kenneth Kaunda in Zambia's first multiparty elections since 1972, told a recent news conference in Geneva that assuming the reins of government had been sobering. "The thrill of victory," he said, "was soon replaced by an ominous realization that the country was not only run down and ravaged by mismanagement, but indeed also that the treasury was bare."

Chiluba also is facing other harsh realities:

* The southern African drought has reduced harvests of maize, Zambia's staple crop, to a third of its normal level.

* There has been conflict between members of Chiluba's Movement for Multiparty Democracy and Kaunda's United National Independence Party. The governing party has seized the offices of its predecessor on the grounds that they were built with public money.

* An economic austerity program that has raised staple food prices nearly 200% has been applauded by international lenders and donors but has received poor reviews from workers. Labor unions are demanding 600% pay increases to cope with cost of living increases. Their members have staged more than 30 strikes, walkouts and slowdowns at banks, schools and municipal offices.

Chiluba said in Geneva that the strikes reflect "some excitement and some abuse, now that we are all free." In time, he said, "the people will learn that democracy is their own creation and that they don't have to destroy their own baby."

Moves Toward Peace

The government of Chad says a peace accord has been reached with one rebel group based in the south of the country. The rebels agreed to end their fighting in return for an amnesty for an estimated 3,000 dissident troops and the release of all soldiers and civilians arrested after February disturbances in the capital, N'Djamena.

The February unrest included the murder of a prominent human rights leader, Joseph Behidi, a southerner, allegedly by government troops from the north. Led by Lt. Kette Nodji, southern troops fled N'Djamena after the killing and launched a low-level insurgency from the south.

President Idriss Deby, who pledged democratic rule when he seized power in late 1990, says his plans for elections are being jeopardized by continuing conflict and ethnic rivalries which have spilled over into several reported coup attempts. Larger insurgencies continue in the Lake Chad region north of the capital and in the center of the country, which is almost as large as Alaska.

Chad's army chief reported that 164 rebels and 19 government soldiers were killed in clashes near Lake Chad in early June. The chief's statement, read on state radio, said the rebels were loyal to former head-of-state Hissein Habre, who was ousted by Deby.

One opposition leader in N'Djamena, Gaileth Gattoul, secretary-general of the Revolutionary Democratic Council-Rejection Front, has issued a call for a national conference "to avoid a new civil war."


LOAD-DATE: June 22, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


112 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 22, 1992


It's Not the Humidity, It's the Heat


LENGTH: 534 words


The government of Algeria released about 3,000 detainees from sweltering camps in the Sahara Desert in early June, following demands to close the camps by opposition parties and human rights groups who say the oncoming summer heat is making conditions at the camps intolerable.

The detainees are suspected members of the Islamic Salvation Front (FIS), a fundamentalist group that appeared on its way to victory in Algeria's first free general elections since independence in 1962. Poised to declare Algeria an Islamic republic last December, the FIS was blocked by President Mohamed Boudiaf's army-backed High State Council, which canceled the general elections and outlawed the FIS and other Islamic fundamentalist political parties. 

About 4,000 remain in the Sahara detention camps. But the Algerian news agency reports more will be released and says those suspected of serious offenses will be moved north to escape the heat.

On June 9, Boudiaf announced the formation of a "National Rally" made up of citizens, associations and organizations, that will have a "mandate for radical political change." The FIS will be banned from participation.

Violence by suspected Islamic fundamentalists has continued during June, with the murder of at least two policemen, bringing the number of police and army personnel assassinated since the elections were canceled to about 60. In other incidents, five police officers were wounded in a daytime attack by gunmen in the Algiers area and bombs exploded at two police stations in the eastern city of Constantine.

They Shoot Elephants

Park managers in Zimbabwe say drought will force them to shoot 2,000 elephants and 1,500 buffalo in danger of starving.

Another 1,000 elephants will be herded from the Gonarezhou National Park, in southwest Zimbabwe on the Mozambique border. The animals will be moved to game ranches, which will assume ownership of half the herds as compensation for providing food and water. Crocodile, Roan antelope, sable zebra, waterbuck and nyala will also be moved from the national park, where virtually no rain fell this year.

Parts of Gonarezhou are barren, without grass or leaves. Only 80 of some 500 hippopotamuses remain alive. Bodies of dead hippos lie strewn in riverbeds.

Besides averting mass starvation of the animals, the forced cull will benefit hungry people who live near the park. Meat from the slain animals will go to villagers reduced by the drought to eating nuts and worms.


LOAD-DATE: June 22, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


113 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 22, 1992


Business As Usual


LENGTH: 320 words


Despite recent political changes in South Africa, police and members of the military have been involved in a systematic pattern of torture and assassinations aimed at the African National Congress (ANC) and its allies, according to a report released June 10 by Amnesty International.

"The reforms of the past two years have brought about some sweeping changes, but as far as the security forces are concerned, it's business as usual," the London-based organization says. 

The Amnesty report says that many mass killings in the townships were carried out by the Zulu-based Inkatha Freedom Party, an ANC rival, with support from police and security forces. The contention supports claims by ANC leader Nelson Mandela that the government is orchestrating and supporting Inkatha violence in order to further its own agenda of weakening his organization.

In a report issued in early June, the International Commission of Jurists agreed. The commission laid much of the blame for the continuing violence on Inkatha and says security forces colluded with them against the ANC.

A South African government-appointed judicial commission last month found that individual policemen had assisted attacks against the ANC, but said there was no evidence that the attacks were government orchestrated.

In statements released June 10, both Inkatha and the government rejected the findings of the Amnesty report. Government officials placed blame for the violence squarely on the Inkatha/ANC rivalry, while Inkatha criticized Amnesty's sources and research methods.


LOAD-DATE: June 22, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


114 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 22, 1992


S.O.S.


LENGTH: 374 words


The Horn of Africa's worst drought since 1984 and a massive influx of refugees have finally forced Kenya to launch its first appeal for international emergency aid.

Livestock are dying, food prices have skyrocketed and, according to Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi, one million people in the northeastern, eastern, coastal and Rift Valley provinces are facing famine, while the country copes with nearly a million refugees from neighboring Ethiopia, Somalia and Sudan. 

Moi has appealed for 175,100 tons of food to feed 680,000 of the worst-affected Kenyans and refugees over the next 12 months.

The European Community (EC) has provided 30,000 tons, including wheat, rice, oil and supplements for malnourished children. The EC aid is part of a $ 350 million assistance package for countries in East and southern Africa affected by drought and famine.

Moi's plea for food aid comes at a crucial time for Kenya. Six months ago, in response to an international aid cutoff and mounting domestic pressure for democratic reforms, Moi reluctantly agreed to legalize opposition parties. Critics say little has changed in the political landscape and charge that Moi has not accepted the spirit of multiparty politics. Democracy advocates cite periodic arrests of journalists and outspoken activists, bans on opposition rallies and the failure of Moi's government to establish an independent electoral commission.

But Sweden, which is among those Western donors who suspended most development aid to Kenya in December, announced June 7 that it would provide $ 35 million for water and road projects, veterinarian training and improvementsin administration of the country's banks.


LOAD-DATE: June 22, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


115 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 22, 1992


Pope Makes Ninth Africa Visit


SECTION: DATELINE: AFRICA


LENGTH: 387 words


Pleas for reconciliation marked masses and speeches during a six-city tour of Angola by Pope John Paul.

"We cannot help remembering the victims of this martyred part of Angola; many of them innocent, killed by the ideological confrontation and war," the Pope said on his arrival in Luanda. 

More than one million people were killed, injured or displaced in the conflict between Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos' ruling Marxist Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, backed by the Soviet Union and Cuba, and Jonas Savimbi's Union for the Total Independence of Angola (Unita), backed by the United States and South Africa. The war ended with a peace settlement 13 months ago.

Blaming the Soviet Union, China, East Germany and Cuba for exporting communism to Angola, the pope pledged that the church will play a major role to help move the nation to democracy.

Angola's first multiparty elections are scheduled for September 29-30.

The pontiff met with dos Santos and Savimbi, who will face off in the September vote, and urged the leaders to "overcome the temptation to prolong the armed conflict, the source of ruin and useless suffering." Both sides are reported to have stored caches of arms, should the move to multiparty elections fall through.

No violence took place during the visit, but three journalists affiliated with Unita were prevented from covering one of the pontiff's trips. Unita radio charged discrimination, but government radio said that the three were turned back because they were carrying guns in their vehicle.

An estimated 300,000 people lined roads leading to the site of the final mass of the tour on June 9. The Pope also visited the island nation of Sao Tome and Principe before returning to the Vatican June 10.


LOAD-DATE: June 22, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


116 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 22, 1992


Student Unrest Spreads Across African Campuses


LENGTH: 1494 words


By Steve Askin

On African university campuses from Harare to Lagos, economic hard times have sparked a wave of bitter conflicts between students and government.

At least half of Nigeria's universities are closed; the entire student body of Zimbabwe's most prestigious university was expelled in June; and Kenyan students have been protesting en masse against the government of President Daniel arap Moi.

In late April, 3,000 students clashed with police in the streets outside of Kenya's parliament while charging the government with instigating ethnic clashes in western Kenya. Students of Kenya Polytechnic waved anti-government placards and called for the resignation of Moi, Vice President and Minister for Finance George Saitoti, House Speaker Jonathan Ng'eno and Commissioner of Police Philip Kilonzo. The day before, students of the University of Nairobi held similar protests. 

On June 8, students from the University of Nairobi erected a roadblock on the street to Moi's official residence, threw stones at passing motorists and heavily damaged two university canteens. Reuters news agency reports students said bad meals at the canteens sparked the riots, which were also linked to the reluctance of university authorities to register a new student organization.

In Harare, the expulsion of more than 8,000 students at the University of Zimbabwe followed a month of student protests.

Student activists had sought increases in loans and grants -- money they said was essential to let them continue to attend school in a period of rapidly rising inflation. But they also raised broader challenges, denouncing alleged government corruption and calling for the resignation of several cabinet ministers.

The campus confrontation began May 8 with what has become an almost annual event at the University of Zimbabwe: an invasion of the campus by riot police, who unleashed a massive barrage of tear gas at the first sign of unrest. This year's conflict took an unusual twist, when the university's acting vice-chancellor, Gordon Chavanduka, convinced police to recognize the rights of students to demonstrate peacefully on or off campus.

Human rights advocates saw the agreement as a potentially significant breakthrough for academic freedom. However, the truce was smashed by students who rioted in downtown Harare in late May, breaking store windows and overturning cars after marching to the Ministry of Education building.

"They have a right to demonstrate, and we supported them in that right," Chavanduka said in a telephone interview. "But when it became violent at the end, that we could not tolerate."

Chavanduka emphasized that expelled students may apply for re-admission. However, re-entering students will be fined to cover the cost of property damage during the demonstrations. And, 15 members of the Student Representative Council are to be barred from receiving the loans and grants that almost all University of Zimbabwe students need to finance their education.

In Nigeria, government action against student activists is a part of a broader political crackdown that has been widely criticized by domestic and international human rights advocates. On June 15, the president of the National Association of Nigerian Students (NANS), Olusegun Mayegun, was one of five members of the Campaign for Democracy brought before an Abuja magistrate on charges of treason. Others arraigned included Beko-Ransome Kuti, president of the Committee for the Defense of Human Rights, and Femi Falana, chairman of the National Association of Democratic Lawyers.

The treason charges constitute "the most severe crackdown the government has made on the human rights community to date, and they've been pretty brutal," says Binaifer Nowrojee, head of the Africa Program of the New York-based Lawyers Committee for Human Rights. Nowrojee says the Abuja arraignment represents a direct violation of rulings from the Lagos High Court, which had directed the government to release Fulana and to bring the five defendants before the court in Lagos.

On June 12, two NANS leaders were arrested during a police raid of the University of Lagos campus.

The arrests follow the closure in May of about half the nation's two dozen university campuses. Student protests forced some closures, but Osaze Lanre Ehonwa, acting national secretary of the Civil Liberties Organization of Nigeria, charges that most closures were the result of "pre-emptive action" by the government. Ehonwa predicts that these "encroachments on academic freedom" will intensify in the weeks and months ahead.

The campus protests began May 9 at the University of Ibadan, when students barricaded the campus, saying they were protesting economic austerity programs that had led to rapid deterioration of campus facilities and educational programs. Conflict spread to the University of Lagos May 13, when students protested an acute shortage of gasoline that led to the doubling of public transit fares. The protests struck a responsive chord among non-students in Lagos' poor neighborhoods, triggering a wave of looting and attacks on motorists. Violence was also reported at Lagos State University, located in the center of one of Lagos' poorest neighborhoods.

These demonstrations followed six months of intensifying campus conflict during which the government "closed a number of universities, proscribed student unions on a number of campuses and expelled and suspended hundreds of students without fair hearings," according to a report issued in April by the human rights group Africa Watch. University of Lagos student leaders have been complaining since late last year about political spying and physical threats allegedly directed against campus leaders.

Africa Watch charges that the Nigerian government's "persistent attacks on the universities" created an environment in which "the costs of university education grew, conditions continued to deteriorate on campuses and the demand by students for a meaningful university education went unmet."

Julius Ihonvbere, former head of the Academic Staff Union at the University of Port Harcourt, says that "accelerating repression of faculty and students," combined with drastic budget cuts and runaway inflation, made campus conflict inevitable. "The conditions at the universities have deteriorated to such a level that it's difficult to talk about an academic system in Nigeria today. The very best academics are out of the country," says Ihonvbere, himself now in exile and teaching at the University of Texas at Austin. "The student unions have been suppressed."

In the United States, the Committee for Academic Freedom in Africa has appealed to American universities to provide assistance to Nigerian students displaced by violence and human rights violations.

"Many students who were arrested in recent crackdowns are trying to find ways to get out of Nigeria," says Committee Co-Coordinator Sylvia Federici, an assistant professor of political philosophy and international studies at Hofstra University, near New York City. "It is very important to make academics here see what's happening, find scholarships for students who need to leave Nigeria and provide material support for people who have been imprisoned."

Steve Askin writes on African campus issues for the Chronicle of Higher

Education.


LOAD-DATE: June 22, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


117 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 22, 1992


Draft Guidelines: Foreign Investment in a Democratic South Africa


LENGTH: 960 words


The objectives of ANC socioeconomic policy are to secure economic growth in a society which is politically and socioeconomically stable and democratic. It is our view that this is the most favorable environment for both foreign and domestic investors.

As a component of this environment a consistent, transparent and accessible policy framework for foreign investment will be essential. To achieve this requires a thorough review and revision of existing legislation. The ANC and its alliance partners are presently working in this area in conjunction with UN agencies to ensure that we embody the best of international practice. 

It is proposed that future policy will be located around certain central features that would move us away from complex incentive packages and policies which seek to exploit cheap labor.

These central features include: an open approach to the entry of foreign investment in its broad sense (direct foreign investment, portfolio investment and non-equity forms of partnership). This would be accompanied by safeguards for the economy that would be built into the overall policy framework and safeguards for foreign investors.

In the event of nationalization there would be fair compensation in accordance with acceptable principles of international law.

Foreign investors will be assured that, subject to regulations that are administered by the South African Reserve Bank, they will have access to foreign exchange for the purposes of remitting after-tax profits, repaying the interest and capital on approved foreign loans, purchasing inputs and repatriating the proceeds on the sale of assets.

Secondly, that the principle of national treatment for foreign investors would apply. Foreign investors would enjoy the same treatment as domestic investors, and foreign investors would be obliged in all respects to abide by the applicable law of South Africa.

The principle of national treatment for foreign investors would be qualified in ways that are generally specified here, and that would be spelled out clearly in a new policy framework. These are:

Foreign investors may be blocked from investing in certain strategic areas such as land, natural resources and certain other sectors, or they may be required to enter into joint venture arrangements.

Companies owned or controlled by nonresidents, or in which nonresidents have a significant shareholding, could have limits placed on their local borrowing facilities.

Exceptions from national treatment may also be provided in respect of special advantages and investment incentives granted to previously disadvantaged groups. Those will not be extended to foreign investors.

Where foreign investment can play a specific role in the achievement of policy objectives, specific contractual arrangements may be negotiated with foreign investors.

Within the broad policy framework of the ANC, the following issues would be of specific relevance to foreign investment:

* the extent to which the enterprise in which the proposed investment is to be made will utilize South African resources, so as to contribute to the economy, by increasing employment opportunities in South Africa; providing for the training of South Africans beyond minimum training obligations required by law; earning or saving foreign exchange; generating development in the less-developed areas of South Africa;

* the extent to which the investment will contribute to the transfer of technology and promote the spread of high-level technical skills amongst South African citizens;

* the extent to which the enterprise in which the proposed investment is to be made will contribute to the advancement of persons within South Africa who have been socially, economically or educationally disadvantaged by post-discriminatory laws and practices or will facilitate the implementation of policies and programs aimed at redressing social, economic or educational imbalances in South African society;

* the extent to which the enterprise in which the proposed investment is to be made will make provision for equal opportunities for women;

* the impact which the activities of the enterprise in which the proposed investment is to be made is likely to have on the environment, and the measures proposed to deal with any adverse environmental consequences.

* In the event of freer trade and investment relations within southern Africa, or beyond, foreign investors will have the option of investing in several different countries to get access to the same regional market. Participating countries should avoid unnecessary and costly competition. n


LOAD-DATE: June 22, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


118 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 22, 1992


Foreign Investment Debate Continues


LENGTH: 240 words


Prior to the ANC national conference in late May, representatives from the ANC, the Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu), and the South African Communist Party held a day-long workshop to debate one of the thorniest aspects of the economic policy equation -- the approach to foreign investment.

For the last several decades, anti-apartheid forces have focussed their energies on forcing multi-national corporations to withdraw from South Africa. 

But with the ANC committed to ending sanctions when an interim government is installed, the focus has shifted to potential new investment. Cosatu has drafted a "Code of Conduct for Multi-National Companies," calling for adherence to internationally established labor standards, equal-treatment policies, and safe, healthy work conditions.

A policy document adopted by the ANC national conference says the organization "will welcome foreign investment, in accordance with our objective for growth and development."

The workshop developed a more detailed draft, excerpted here.


LOAD-DATE: June 22, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


119 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 22, 1992


Tough Issues Trouble South African Negotiations


SECTION: Forum


LENGTH: 1027 words


A stalemate in multi-party negotiations over the future of South Africa has underlined the depth of differences dividing the administration of President F.W. de Klerk from its chief negotiating partner, Nelson Mandela's African National Congress (ANC). Opinions vary on whether the disagreements are substantial enough to slow process towards the abolishment of apartheid and the establishment of an interim arrangement, a crucial step towards democratic government.

The negotiations, involving 19 parties from across the political spectrum -- with only extreme right-wing whites and two leftist black groups not participating -- broke down in mid-May. Dismayed by the unexpected turn of events, the ANC on June 16 launched a two-week campaign of work stoppages and mass demonstrations to press its demands for a speedy end to white rule. 

One fundamental disagreement involves the government's insistence on what the ANC regards as a 'white veto' over the direction and extent of change. The government insists that decisions of a proposed interim legislature be subject to ratification by a vote of three-quarters of the members. The ANC argues that a two-thirds vote is sufficient. The legislature will be charged both with law-making responsibilities and with drafting a new constitution in the run-up to national free elections.

Another dispute involves the tenure of a transitional executive council. The government wants the body, made up of representatives from all 19 parties, to remain in existence indefinitely. The ANC wants to limit its tenure to the approximately three months required to elect the interim legislature.

The council will have the power to override actions of the de Klerk government and the present parliament, although both will remain in office during the initial transitional phase.

While political issues have been the international attention grabber, economic considerations loom large in the strategies of negotiators for every group. "We all, whites and black, think we're entitled to Swedish social security," John Kane-Berman, director of the South African Institute of Race Relations told the London Financial Times. "But with Polish GDP (Gross Domestic Product), it won't work that way," he said.

A chief legacy of white domination, one that no future government can ignore, is a huge racial gap in living standards that will endure long after legal separation is removed. Average income for black South Africans is about one-tenth of that of whites, according to World Bank estimates.

"South Africa simply does not have the resources to raise black living standards to white levels," the Financial Times says in a recently published survey of South Africa. "There is no explosion of economic growth on the horizon to meet the country's huge development needs," the survey states.

There also is no agreement on how best to stimulate growth in a manner that doesn't harm as many people as it helps. Derek Keys, the government's finance minister, told the Financial Times he is seeking "a national consensus" on a policy that defers expenditure in favor of investment.

But consensus will prove hard to achieve in a country divided not only racially but also between urban and rural, between employed and unemployed, and between stable wage earners and the marginally employed.

Many of these tensions are present within the ANC, the largest black-led political group. Historically, ANC economic pronouncements have emphasized redistribution of income and of land, only 13% of which has been given to blacks.

But the experiences of other African countries, the changes on the world stage, and the approaching prospect of assuming a major share of governmental authority have sparked a reassessment of policy by the ANC and its allied organizations.

In an extensive evaluation of the South African economy published earlier this year, the International Monetary Fund weighed in on the debate by declaring that redistribution alone "will not be adequate" to offset the severity of the country's poverty. A growth-oriented economic approach is required, the IMF study concludes, "to generate the resources necessary to satisfy the needs of the least privileged sectors of society on a sustained basis."

In a major policy statement -- "Guidelines for a Democratic South

Africa," adopted in late May by an ANC national conference -- the group endorses "initiating growth and development to improve the quality of life for all South Africans, but especially for the poor."

Leading the list of goals is the elimination of poverty and "extreme" inequality, along with "democratizing the economy and empowering the historically oppressed." Those priorities reflect both the ANC's mass political base and the continuing significance of the organization's close ties to the large labor federation, Cosatu, and the South Africa Communist Party.

The guidelines also endorse rural development as "an essential component of the ANC's program for redistribution and growth" and "an open approach" to foreign investment, "in accordance with our objectives for growth and development." n


LOAD-DATE: June 22, 1992


LANGUAGE: English

June 22, 1992


Where's Madagascar?


LENGTH: 214 words


The addition of vital information has truly made up for the changeover from newsletter format to newspaper format.

However, in the map of Africa on your cover, how come Madagascar is not included? As a member of the Madagascar Cultural Alliance, I think that this should be brought to your attention. The Malagasy and those of Malagasy ancestry would appreciate it!

Beverly A. Mendheim

Seattle, Washington

Response: The cover logo map of Africa is a visual device to convey a sense of place quickly, rather than a realistic depiction of the continent. None of the islands are shown, and the familiar Mercator projection misrepresents Africa's true size and shape. But we're asking our talented designer to take another look at possibilities.

Worn Around the Edges


LENGTH: 174 words


Congratulations on your new version. It is all you promised and more. I am especially pleased that you are giving good coverage to African women and attempting to make Islam in its many forms better known.

Have you heard from others that the paper arrived torn in several places, especially along the outer edge, lower right edge and top edge? I've complained about it at the local post office; I'm told it happened before it arrived here.

May your readers and influence continue to increase. Be sure of special prayer for you all.

Mary O'Callaghan, R.S.C.J.

St. Charles, Missouri

123 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 22, 1992


Reader Concerns: Junk Mail, Format, Ads


LENGTH: 774 words


I have been having a serious problem with junk mail because so many organizations now sell lists of their customers, subscribers or contributors to other organizations. I fervently hope that AfricaNews does not engage in this abusive practice, but if you do, please remove my name from any lists that you rent to any other organizations.

I love the new newspaper format, and I like the features at the back. And you finally did something about Tanzania -- small and on the back page, but you did it. If Tanzania does have multiparty elections next year, it would be nice to see a feature article on that and on economic reforms. 

Georgiana F. Coughlan

Gardena, California

I appreciate the expanded coverage of Africa's news that your new format allows. But I wonder if you realize that by changing to a newspaper format from the magazine-like format, you have rendered your publication much less useful to many of your readers. Neither the size of the new publication nor the paper on which it is printed will make it easy for us to keep it in our personal libraries for future reference.

The old AfricaNews was like a journal that one collects for years and refers back to on many occasions. I am still trying to figure out what I will do with the new newspaper. I am inclined to give up my subscription and just read it in the library.

Niara Sudarkasa

Lincoln University, Pennsylvania

The author is president of Lincoln University.

Your new format is great. But I was dismayed by the Coke ad (in the May 11, 1992 issue). The multinationals always say no strings attached but rarely mean it. Given their role in exploiting Africa, you need to be independent -- even if this requires smaller scale.

David Keppel

Essex, Connecticut

Response: The preceding letters raise issues related to strategic decisions at AfricaNews, and we'd like to address them briefly. In common with virtually all publishers, we periodically allow our list to be used by other publications, although we limit such use to a few times per year. And we ourselves acquire new subscribers by sending our promotional mailings to readers of other journals. Few publications could survive without list exchanges or rentals. However, we do honor requests from subscribers who object to their names being given to another organization.

Our new format is part of a larger multimedia plan to make Africa News Service both economically viable and increasingly influential during its third decade. (The news agency will be 20 years old next year.) The old format was a hybrid; newsstands, distributors, contributors and potential subscribers were confused about whether it was a newsletter or a newspaper or a magazine. In addition to avoiding ambiguity, the new look allows us to give you more news and information at lower cost -- an absolute necessity for survival. While we are pained when valued subscribers dislike the changes, we must make the newspaper an indispensable publication for more people, and we must do it at a cost that won't price it out of the range of most subscribers.

Similarly, the decision to accept advertising is part of the mix of revenue-generating strategies that we hope will allow AfricaNews to prosper and reach larger audiences. We always aim for our reporting to be unbiased and accurate. If we stumble in our obligation to reflect the urgent, complex issues facing Africans today, we expect to hear from you.


LOAD-DATE: June 22, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


124 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 22, 1992


Mobutu Needs Push From Bush


LENGTH: 560 words


Congratulations on your wide-ranging article "African Democracy Gets Little Notice in Washington." (AfricaNews, June 8, 1992) The Bush administration has steadfastly turned its back on the catastrophe which is overwhelming the people of Zaire. It is a disaster caused by President Bush's old friend, Mobutu Sese Seko, who was a useful "client" of the U.S.A. during the Cold War and during Mr. Bush's tenure as head of the CIA. 

At this writing, President Mobutu has thrown down the gauntlet before the National Conference in Zaire, which is on the verge of trying to establish a new transitional government and elect a new prime minister. The naming of the prime minister, the president has declared, is his prerogative to exercise alone. Will the situation turn violent? Probably.

Over the past few weeks Mobutu has been quiet, even projecting the image of serenity like a tail-twitching leopard before the lethal pounce. Realists in the opposition are convinced he was hatching his plans and preparing his moves. They know that tail-twitching in a big cat signals danger, not serenity. The few in Washington who even give Zaire a thought probably hoped -- as usual, unrealistically -- that Mobutu had seen the light and was preparing to "share in government."

Recently, when a senior American senator asked the White House about Mr. Bush's continued silent support for Mobutu, he was told that the American president sees no reason to turn his back on his African colleague and is unwilling to distance himself from that relationship. How pathetic! How superficial! Foreign affairs based on cozy, personal friendships have nothing to do with statesmanship.

Assistant Secretary of State for Africa Herman J. 'Hank' Cohen has apparently been told to keep his hands off Mobutu. Hank, whom I knew in Africa years ago when I took care of his family, is a master diplomat for the Bush White House. I am sure his calm demeanor and open ear are appreciated by many Africans. However, most are realistic enough to know that his hands are tied behind him by those higher up.

The United States, with problems in our inner cities and an enormous national debt, may or may not have a special role to play elsewhere. But within the constraints of our own economic realities, the U.S. must back representative governments. And our government does have the responsibility to openly disassociate itself from former "client dictators" who have become major obstructions to democratic forces.

William T. Close

Marbleton, Wyoming

Dr. Close is an American physician who served as President Mobutu's personal doctor from 1960 to 1976.


LOAD-DATE: June 22, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


125 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 22, 1992


Letters
