Africa News


June 22, 1992


Malawi's Travails Should Not Be Ignored


LENGTH: 694 words


by William E. Phipps The southeastern African nation of Malawi, comparable in population and size to the state of Pennsylvania, gets little international attention. Foreign journalists are generally barred from entering, and few people in the United States have much information on what takes place there.

Hastings Kamuza Banda, the country's pro-Western leader since independence in 1963, has taken the title "life president," and still rules with the firmest of hands. The Malawi Congress Party, essentially a cheering organization for the president, holds all the seats in parliament. Strikes are illegal, and free expression is not allowed. 

But tension in Malawi has been on the rise, especially since a pastoral letter from the country's eight Roman Catholic bishops in February criticized economic inequities and human rights abuses and called for democratic change. The government declared the letter "seditious," and the Montfort Press where it was printed was attacked and smashed by police.

Students at the University of Malawi staged protests to support the Bishop's stand, and the university was closed. The government sought to win faculty support by announcing a 50% wage hike, but that action sparked a strike by secretarial and maintenance personnel at Chancellor College, the liberal arts wing of the university, demanding comparable increases for themselves.

Civil servants also received pay increases to keep them from joining the growing pro-democracy cause. But strikes erupted in the textile industry, on tea plantations, and among lower-level government employees not affected by the pay hikes.

Most Malawians are desperately poor, although a tiny number of government officials live luxuriously on export earnings from tobacco, the main cash crop. Over 80% of the people are subsistence farmers. Those who are employed receive very low wages. Average per capita income is reported to be about $ 180 a year. Even primary education is not affordable or available to most children. Malawi is as hard-hit by AIDS as anyplace on earth. Over 25% of hospital patients and almost all prostitutes test HIV positive.

The economic and social problems are compounded by the hundreds of thousands of refugees from war-ravaged Mozambique next door and by the crippling drought spreading across southern Africa.

The growing pro-democracy protests have begun to attract international concern. Western donors suspended aid last month to encourage government reforms. But there are disturbing signs that the World Bank has agreed to help fill the funding gap. The bank reportedly has approved a controversial $ 55 million hydro-electric project and is said to be considering other loans as well.

Amnesty International has documented the torture and death of thousands of political prisoners by the Banda regime. The World Alliance of Reformed Churches, which includes the Presbyterian Church U.S.A. and the United Church of Christ, has appealed to Banda to accept far-reaching change. The Alliance's letter was co-signed by leaders of the Church of Central Africa (Presbyterian), one of Malawi's major denominations. It is time for the world to respond. n

William E. Phipps is professor of religion and philosophy at Davis and Elkins College in West Virginia, and spent several months teaching in Malawi early this year.


LOAD-DATE: June 22, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


127 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 22, 1992


Africa's Neglect Spans U.S. Political Spectrum


SECTION: VIEWPOINT


LENGTH: 1800 words


By Michael Johns "Who cares about Africa?"

Amidst the politically charged debate over a "new world order" and "America first," the unfortunate reality is: not too many.

Every day, Africa's human crises -- disease, famine, civil war -- quietly take the lives of thousands. Right now, drought in Ethiopia, Somalia, and Sudan threatens the lives of no less than 23 million people -- almost one-tenth the population of the U.S. In the coming months, many of these people will die, others will develop famine-related illnesses that ultimately will kill them, and even those who escape this current drought will undoubtedly be threatened by future ones. It is a bleak existence, where women and children suffer and die -- and almost no one notices. 

Lately, African crises are treated by America's national political leadership and the media as a low priority. The current drought in the Horn of Africa, for instance, has hardly broken from the back pages of any major American newspaper or received any significant television coverage. And with a few laudable exceptions, the foreign policy establishment seems to approach Africa's hardships without creativity, energy or urgency -- and often with a certain amount of cynicism.

To be sure, Africa's crisis is not America's. Washington holds no inherent obligation to solve problems created by others -- and there should be no mistaking that the blame for Africa's predicament rests almost exclusively with the economic and political policies of the continent's current leaders. Despite the end of the Cold War and talk of a "democratic revolution" in Africa, the continent continues -- with a few encouraging exceptions -- to be run by the politically unelected and the economically unenlightened. Economic statism, mismanagement, corruption, political autocracy -- these are the indigenous roots of the African catastrophe.

Still, one cannot help noticing the haunting silence with which Washington has met Africa's human crisis -- a crisis whose severity is unmatched anywhere in the world today. In 1984-1985, the world, led by America, rushed to the aid of millions of starving Ethiopians. Unfortunately, much of that aid was squandered and misused by a selfish Marxist regime, but many lives were saved because of Western generosity.

Today, however, that Western spirit seems to have dissipated. The once moving story of starving Africans, which prompted music videos, benefit concerts and regular network coverage, has been reduced to mere statistics buried in seldom-read reports of human rights groups and famine relief charities.

All of this is an indication of Africa's steady slide off the West's agenda.

Is there an element of racism in Africa's neglect? It's a fair question. Pat Buchanan has observed that, given the death of a dozen in Vilnius versus the slaughter of thousands in Burundi, American attention gravitates toward the crisis involving skin of a lighter pigmentation. Buchanan contends that this is understandable, and even appropriate, because America holds greater cultural and ethnic ties to Europe. Any objective analysis of world events would reveal that Buchanan's view is by no means a minority one. No matter how severe the human rights problems of Africa, those of Asia, Europe or Latin America consistently rise far faster on the priority list of American policy makers and the media.

So, one cannot blame Africa's neglect on Buchanan-like xenophobia; many of Buchanan's leading critics have never uttered the word "Burundi." This reflects something much deeper than racism.

Within the American policy and media elite, there exists a largely unspoken opinion that Africa is a dying horse that cannot be saved -- and that even if it can be saved, it is not worth the effort. Were it just a matter of Africa's geopolitical importance, this thinking would be more understandable (perhaps even warranted). But the message is that human rights concerns in Africa are less important than elsewhere.

This represents nothing less than the politicization of human rights, and it needs correcting. There is a need for a one-yard-stick approach to human rights.

The first place to start this correction is within the American conservative movement. During the Cold War, conservatives argued that the threat of Soviet geopolitical advancements needed to be halted and, wherever possible, rolled back. Conservatives used human rights arguments to justify an assertive foreign policy: It wasn't just that the Soviet Union had long-range nuclear missiles pointed at American cities; it also prohibited free immigration and imprisoned its dissidents. It wasn't just that the Sandinistas represented a threat to El Salvador; they also persecuted their Indian population and denied their people the right to vote. The support that was ultimately garnered for the Reagan Doctrine, and for anti-communism, was due at least in part to the fact that communism was perceived to be more than dangerous; it was also evil.

But with the Cold War won, evil does not seem to concern Americans as much anymore. As the Sudanese government starved 8 million people in the late 1980s, and as 23 million more Africans face the same fate in 1992, conservatives who justifiably railed against Cuban political prisoners and Soviet human rights violations have been hauntingly silent.

American liberals have been no better. Liberal Africa lobby groups, such as TransAfrica, have not spent much time or resources seeking solutions to Africa's human crises. Rather, they have been preoccupied primarily with partisan debates, especially American policy toward Angola and South Africa.

In at least one respect, this is an even greater crime than conservatives' neglect of Africa. For their part, conservatives may be concerned about the mass starvation in Africa; they simply lack a consensus on how to deal with it. Most conservatives are skeptical of massive food aid missions because they often result in driving down indigenous African food prices. The result of this is that the aid may minimize the toll of a current famine, but it usually facilitates famine's return the next harvest season, because farmers are driven out of business by competition with free Western-supplied food. As a result, conservatives (when they address Africa at all) tend to place more emphasis on the long-term solution of economic reform.

On the other hand, liberals by and large do not share this concern. They believe in food aid as the answer to famine -- and they are far less critical than conservatives of African leaders' economic policies. But African starvation is not now even among the top ten issues of concern to liberal America. Democratic candidate Bill Clinton has not made one high-profile mention of the 23 million starving people in the Horn of Africa (much less proposed an answer to the crisis), and liberal think tanks have not placed it very high on their priority list.

Why is Africa so neglected? One answer is that, among Africa watchers, South Africa is virtually an all-consuming area of concern. I continually encountered this as an Africa analyst for a major conservative think tank. For example, in the fall of 1988, I gave a speech for the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill's human rights awareness week. I spoke for an hour about the Horn of Africa and the politics of famine. But during the question-and-answer period, question after question came not about famine in the Horn of Africa, but rather about American policy in South Africa.

Another problem rests on the shoulders of African leaders themselves. With the exception of Angolan resistance leader Jonas Savimbi, newly elected Zambian president Frederick Chiluba and a few others, democratic African leaders, where they exist, have been by and large inept in pushing their cause in the West. Further, most African embassies are hopelessly inefficient. They almost consistently fail (perhaps for their own self-interest) to inform Americans about the challenges and disasters in their homelands.

But perhaps the greatest factor in Africa's neglect is the lack of creative thinking on Africa's problems. To the credit of the Bush administration, its Agency for International Development is at last looking anew at the role of foreign aid. (Vice President Dan Quayle put it bluntly during a speech last September in Abidjan: "The age of large-scale government-to-government aid is over. Africa must develop a vigorous private sector if it is to grow.") And organizations like the National Endowment for Democracy and its affiliates are engaged in promising work to strengthen democratic institutions in Africa. But this seems to be where the thinking stops.

In the absence of some tangible relevance to American security, economic or other interests, Africa's human crisis likely will continue its steady descent into oblivion. The only thing that can spare this is new thinking -- where the plight of our fellow person is not irrelevant. We need to think anew about those whose lives, because of their birthplace, consist of daily challenges of sickness, killing and starvation. n


LOAD-DATE: June 22, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 22, 1992


The Inaugural Address of Mali's Democratically Elected President, Alpha OumarKonare


LENGTH: 1934 words


Today, thanks to God, thanks to the sacrifices of our martyrs and thanks to the blessings of our ancestors, the sovereign people of Mali have entrusted me with the heavy but exalted mission of guiding the destiny of our country. I am ready to assume this awesome honor. At this moment when our people are turning to a page of hope in their glorious history, I would like to greet and thank the brotherly and friendly countries that have helped us, demonstrated their solidarity and made this day possible.

I would like especially to thank their excellencies, the heads of state, the prime ministers, ministers, special envoys and foreign personalities who have greatly honored us today by coming to demonstrate their brotherhood, esteem and solidarity. The Malian people will always remember it.

This day represents for us a stage in the long struggle, which our people have been waging for more than half a century now, for greater control of their own future, happiness, prosperity, in order to escape a gloomy wave of poverty, despair, exclusion and death. 

This day has been achieved after the bloody days in January and March 1991, after the great rallies and marches that preceded these bloody days, when the united democratic movement presented its demands on the streets of our towns. This day has been achieved following the underground struggle which many of us waged for 23 years. Today is the aftermath of our metamorphic pains. This day must bring back some memories, but it also brings a strong responsibility to make a change for the great majority.

As an elected president of a people who have suffered and who, for several decades now, have been expecting better, I want to be the man who will bring hope. I do not want to be a peddler of illusion. I want the people to believe that with me things can change, that actions will speak louder than words.

I am not a father of the nation. Let me pay tribute to the fathers of our nation who have contributed to our political awareness and who have led our country to independence. I am only a son, a son among others, who is today called upon to play the elder's role without being the eldest. I need the help of everyone -- fathers, mothers, brothers and sisters, sons and daughters -- because nothing can change all those social ties that must continue to function alongside new responsibilities.

I know that our people are capable of doing great things, provided that (the great things) are reconciled with the set of values that has characterized (us) historically, such as hard work, solidarity and a social creativity that has enabled us to produce active balances between individual perspectives and our collective destiny. These values also include dignity, a sense of past commitments and responsibility.

I want to be an instrument of reconciliation. To achieve this -- and I will commit myself resolutely to this -- democratic institutions need to be strengthened to guarantee the participation of everyone while laws are being written; a law-abiding state must ensure that the law is applied to everyone; and an active policy of social and national integration must be formulated.

One of our priorities will be to provide social peace and stability. It is essential that the state's authority be asserted, controlled and accepted by all. We shall ensure that the laws are known to all and that no one is above them. I will scrupulously see to the respect of the constitution, the separation of powers and the indispensable basic freedoms of the mass media.

The means to this reconciliation will be the revival of our economy through the liberation of and support of individual and collective economic initiatives. Justice and solidarity must back one another to share the wealth produced. The fight against corruption and waste and the decentralization of authority will form the living framework for the participation of the greater number of people in state affairs.

Finally, the effective accomplishment of African integration, the readiness shown by our people as early as 1960 to give up all or part of their sovereignty in favor of African unity, is irreversible.

These are the terms of the five-year contract I have signed with the Malian people, a contract of shared, rigorous efforts. I would like it to be a contract that defines the necessary collaboration, the desirable affinities and the reciprocal responsibilities that are necessary for the harmonious development of our country. For the time being, the nation's unity depends on the successful and strict implementation of the provisions of the National Pact signed on April 11. The pact cannot exalt the victory of one group over another.

It offers a chance to strengthen the democratic process. My compatriots of the northern region can count on my commitment to ensure that both peace and unity last forever. The means to this will be development, solidarity and justice.

National unity can also be achieved by the completion of the reconciliation of the Malian people with their army. A lot has been done in this direction, but a lot remains to be done. No democracy can be built with a worried army which has been made to feel guilty. I would hereby like to assure officers, NCOs, corporals and soldiers of our army of our complete solicitude (for them). Together we shall strengthen the republican virtues of our army.

Finally, reconciliation depends on an independent, credible and fair system of justice. Judgments will gain greater credibility. Justice also needs to be exercised in a climate of tranquillity.

During the next few days I will appoint a prime minister. Together we shall form a government made up of men and women from different political parties, all determined to bring changes for the improvement of people's living conditions. This arrangement seems necessary to create conditions for a genuine education in democracy.

The prime minister will negotiate specific contracts of substance and fairness with academics, labor unions and professional organizations -- all the social partners and all the people involved in our country's development.

Consultation will be the watchword of our policy. I have no doubt that all the democrats who fought for the advent of a new era that would herald an improvement in people's living conditions will understand that the most serious danger that could threaten the democratic process is to demand from the state what we know it does not have.

The government of the republic has no right to cheat our people with empty promises that will not be honored. It will, however, have to operate in accordance with the rules of discipline, good management, openness, solidarity and justice.

Everybody knows the catastrophic heritage of the former regime; everybody is aware of the courage with which the Transition Committee for the Salvation of the People (CTSP), led by Amadou Toumani Toure, and the government of Soumana Sacko set about restoring life, confidence and health to our country. May thanks be given to them always for this.

May thanks be given to Lt. Col. Amadou Toumani Toure, for whom our country's honor and the honor of his word as an officer served as a political creed and a guide for action during the 14 months in which many difficulties arose -- difficulties which his dynamic courage and patriotism managed to confront and overcome.

Mr. Chairman of the CTSP, the nation will always be grateful to you for making it understand that it has no need of a savior or a supreme guide. It will always be grateful to you for restoring confidence in the sons of Mali so that they could supervise the democratic process. In doing this, you adopted the tradition of change that is necessary for any democratic process. The lesson that you are teaching everyone will guide us. I wish you a very long life and a lot of satisfaction for you and your entire team. I am convinced that together we will always strengthen the basis for a democratic Mali. I am convinced that tomorrow you will be one of the best mediators of the country and one of the great messengers of the Malian nation.

Your Excellencies, ladies and gentlemen, yesterday I invited Malians both at home and abroad to be united more than ever before and to build a future of hope. I call upon the men and women of our country, the old and young -- yes the young -- always to defend the ideals of March 1991, which include making an effort, working and respecting others. I call on all the forces of change to show more unity, and to not confuse battles or enemies. I call on Almamy Sylla, Amadou Ali Niangado, Baba Akhib Haidara, Demba Diallo, Idrissa Traore, Moutaga Tall, Mamadou Batourou Diaby and Tieoule Konate (presidential candidates) -- all worthy representatives of our people -- and all the other political leaders to stand with us, so that together we can lift Mali up. Today is the time for practicing democracy. It is also a time for tolerance. Today, our country is shaken by different shades of opinion. This is normal for a sick person. But it is also a sign of life. Mali is a big boat and none of its occupants should want it to capsize. Mali can shake, but Mali will never capsize again.

Difficulties are assailing us today. More serious tests may appear tomorrow. I am convinced that we have the means to overcome them. It is a great honor for me and my entire team to be called upon to confront these trying moments. We will face them with our people, mobilized in a calm and determined manner. Nobody will build Mali except Malians.

My dear fellow citizens, today a brighter future is being launched for Mali and Africa, I hope. And I will work towards it. Long live the republic, long live democratic Mali in a united Africa. n

The address was broadcast in French by Radiodiffusion Television Malienne in Bamako and translated by the British Broadcasting Corporation's Summary of World Broadcasts.


LOAD-DATE: June 22, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


129 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 22, 1992


Mali's Democracy,Begun in Bloodshed,Completes Orderly Transition


SECTION: Dossier


LENGTH: 854 words


Thirty-two years after its independence, the West African nation of Mali has its first democratically elected president. Alpha Ouman Konare, a 46-year-old history professor, was sworn into office on June 8 and swiftly appointed a cabinet that includes members of three opposition parties.

Konare is one of the new generation of African leaders who have been brought to power by pro-democracy movements. He was elected in April after his Alliance for Democracy in Mali swept parliamentary elections a month earlier. His inaguration follows a 15-month transition period overseen by an interim government. 

As in many African nations where popular uprisings are winning political reforms, democracy in Mali has been bought with a price. Hundreds of pro-democracy demonstrators were killed by Malian security forces last year, and more than a thousand were injured, before a group of army officers ended 22 years of military dictatorship in the country by overthrowing strongman president Moussa Traore. The soldiers said they had been sickened by the carnage and were moved by the courage of the protestors to turn their guns on the man who ordered the killings.

Traore is now under arrest for murder and other crimes he is charged with committing while in office. But his trial, which began June 4, has been postponed due to concern for his safety and that of other accused former officals, as well as their lawyers. Crowds of youth outside the building where the trial was being held called for Traore's punishment and threw rocks through windows. Police responded with tear gas but no injuries were reported. Konare says the trial will resume and justice will be done "in a calm atmosphere."

Mali's transition to elections was managed by by Lt. Col. Amadou Toumani Toure, who led the overthrow of Traore, and by interim Prime Minister Soumana Sacko, a regional economist for the United Nations Development Program when he was tapped by the new ruling council to govern until free elections could be held.

Speaking at the inaguration, Toure cautioned that clemency and reconciliation will serve Malians better than retribution for the crimes of the past. "However, the country cannot forget those who died while fighting for freedom," he said, " and we will never stop paying tribute to their memory or seeing to it that their moral and physical courage live on -- by our safeguarding of the democratic ideals we now possess."

Malians should not try to avenge their martyrs, Toure said, "because the future will not be built on vengence -- but he added that "whoever caused their loss" should be fairly tried and punished.

During the inaugural ceremony, Konare praised Col. Toure for guiding Mali toward democracy and promoted him to brigadier general, making him Mali's only serving general.

Konare quickly followed the example of his predecessor by appointing a technocrat, Younossi Toure, as prime minister. An economist who briefly served as planning minister under the ousted Traore, Younossi Toure has been a national director for the Central Bank of West Africa, of which Mali is a member. Interviewed by Radio France International, Konare said he had tapped Younossi Toure to head the new government because he is "one of our most competent experts," as well as "a committed man" and "a democrat."

The new government will face numerous challenges, including reforming a bloated bureaucracy, where influence peddling and corruption were commonplace. Toure, in his speech, called for accountability and efficiency among public servants. "There can be no democracy without trust," he said. "We need to learn to be uncompromising with the nation's interests and with public property."

In a reaction to African politicians who have amassed vast wealth, Mali's new constitution calls for the head of state to declare family assets. Konare said he owns three plots of land, a house and a 13-year-old car, while his wife owns some land, some gold jewelry and a 1991 Peugeot.

A primary goal of the government will be extending and strengthening the peace pact forged with nomadic Touareg rebels in the north of the country. A truce signed in April reportedly was broken by skirmishes in early June.

The newly appointed cabinet includes a Touareg as well as two women. n


LOAD-DATE: June 22, 1992


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June 22, 1992


UN Pushes to End Western Sahara Deadlock


LENGTH: 547 words


The United Nations special envoy on Western Sahara is using shuttle diplomacy to try to end a 17-year war in the former Spanish colony. Sahabzada Yakub Khan spent mid-June talking to King Hassan II of Morocco, which claims the territory, and officials of the Polisario Front, which has declared Western Sahara an independent republic. The talks were held in Geneva, in Rabat, the capital of Morocco, and in the southwestern desert of Algeria, bordering Western Sahara. 

According to UN sources, the envoy's trips were intended to pave the way for talks in New York later in the month. Like the Middle East peace talks, however, the two sides in the Sahara dispute will meet formally only through negotiators.

Since September, the UN has maintained a peacekeeping force of between 350 and 375 military observers in Western Sahara. Drawn from 25 countries, including the United States, the group was intended as an advance party for a force of nearly 3,000 that was to have supervised a ballot on the territory's future in January. But the referendum has been postponed indefinitely because of a disagreement between Morocco and Polisario over who is eligible to vote.

In a report to the Security Council at the end of May, UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros Ghali strongly recommended that the Council extend the peacekeepers' mandate until the end of August. "It is my hope," he said, "that by then substantial progress would have been made to prepare the ground for the holding of a referendum leading to the peaceful settlement of the Western Sahara conflict."

Boutros Ghali said that despite the lack of progress up to now, the UN mission has played an important role in the area. "Although cease-fire violations have continued to occur and their frequency has even increased somewhat," he said, "the incidents reported have not been of a violent nature; nor has there been a single battle casualty on either side since the peacekeeping force was deployed last year."

Continuing a pattern the secretary-general noted in his last report to the Security Council three months ago, Morocco has been responsible for almost all the reported cease-fire violations -- in this case, 97 out of 102 since the beginning of March -- according to the report. The UN says most of the violations have involved such breaches as reinforcement of fortifications and construction of barriers and bunkers, although there often have been Moroccan overflights of Polisario positions.

Special Representative Yakub Khan says that, in his talks with the parties, he was assured of improved cooperation in the future. Both sides say they are committed to ending the deadlock and holding the referendum. n


LOAD-DATE: June 22, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


131 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 22, 1992


Troop Deaths in Liberia Spark Review by West Africans


LENGTH: 667 words


West African leaders are expected to meet soon to review peacekeeping operations in Liberia, where eight Senegalese soldiers have died in recent weeks.

Plans for holding an extraordinary summit to examine ways to ensure troop safety were announced by Senegalese President Abdou Diouf, current chairman of the Economic Community of West African States, which sent a combined force to end the fighting in Liberia in late 1990.

Six Senegalese died on May 28, in clashes with soldiers from the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL), the armed movement led by Charles Taylor. Two more died in a June 16 road accident which left 13 others injured. 

Following the deaths in May, Senegalese troops were withdrawn from Lofa County, the region in the northwest of the country where the clash occurred. The casualties were the first since the West African force, known as Ecomog, was deployed to Liberia's border with Sierra Leone two months ago to disarm and encamp rival factions, including the NPFL.

After arriving in Liberia 22 months ago, Ecomog succeeded in separating the warring groups and ending the worst of the bloody civil strife. But until the May deployment into NPFL territory, Ecomog operations had been limited to the capital, Monrovia, where an interim government led by President Amos Sawyer is in control.

Taylor finally accepted Ecomog expansion into the rest of the country, which his forces control, at a West African Summit in Geneva in April. The rebel leader has consistently criticized Ecomog, suggesting that the troops were sent to keep him from taking power and charging interference in Liberia's internal affairs.

A June 14 statement issued by the Ecomog commander, Maj. Gen. Ishaya Bakut of Nigeria, said the Senegalese would be replaced in the north by troops of another nationality but did not elaborate. Nigeria and Ghana have the largest contingents in the 7,000-strong peacekeeping force. The Senegalese contingent was added to Ecomog last year at Taylor's request, to dilute the influence of Nigeria, which has been the particular target of his criticism. Senegal says its troops will remain part of the peacekeeping effort.

The deployment of Ecomog along Liberia's border with Sierra Leone was intended to halt recent attacks on NPFL forces by another armed faction, the United Liberation Movement of Liberia for Democracy (Ulimo). "There seems little doubt that it is Ulimo's military successes against the NPFL, as much as the Geneva accord, that have led to improved cooperation between Ecomog and NPFL at the start of the deployment exercise," the London-based newsletter Africa Confidential said recently.

The six Senegalese deaths occurred after a shootout erupted in the northern town of Vahun. Although the soldiers were reported originally to have been "kidnapped" by NPFL forces, Senegal's Ministry for Armed Forces said June 8 that the soldiers had been "killed in a cowardly manner well after the clashes."

An Ecomog statement said that Maj. Gen. Bakut had been assured by Taylor that he was "committed to facilitating" the work of the Ecomog force. "I hope your words of commitment will be honored this time," the statement from Bakut said.


LOAD-DATE: June 22, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


132 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 22, 1992


U.S. Urged to Cut Aid to Uganda


SECTION: NEWS ROUNDUP


LENGTH: 827 words


A visit to Washington, DC, in late June by Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni provoked calls for an examination of Uganda's human rights and political record.

Rep. John Edward Porter (D-IL), writing on behalf of the Congressional Human Rights Caucus, which he co-chairs, called on the Bush administration to query Museveni on his plans for democratization and his treatment of political opponents. Although on a private visit, Museveni was scheduled to hold talks with Secretary of State James Baker III. Plans for a meeting with President George Bush fell through when the White House was unable to find time on Bush's agenda. 

"The Ugandan people have a right to democracy, political pluralism and internationally recognized standards of human rights," Porter said in a June 15 letter to Bush, asking that the administration "make it clear" that the U.S. will "carefully monitor" progress in these areas.

Referring to reports that Museveni has arrested dozens of political opponents and members of banned political parties, Porter raised a concern "that these arrests represent a coordinated effort by President Museveni to destroy political opposition and ensure his position as unopposed ruler of Uganda."

Prior to Museveni's arrival, a U.S.-based opposition group known as the Uganda Democratic Coalition issued a call for a cut-off in American aid to Uganda. Citing the examples of Kenya, Zaire and Malawi, which have suffered aid losses due to alleged human rights violations, the coalition condemned what it said is a "double standard" for Uganda.

According to the coalition, Museveni's regime has been responsible for killing, detaining and forcing into exile political opponents and murdering thousands of civilians since coming to power at the end of a military struggle in 1986. Museveni's victory followed several years of political instability after the overthrow of Ugandan dictator Idi Amin in 1979.

Recent criticism of government actions by both local and international human rights groups, including Amnesty International, resulted in an official inquiry into reports that government troops were responsible for atrocities against local residents in north and northeastern Uganda, where various anti-government rebel groups continue to operate. A May 21 report issued by the Justice Minister and Attorney-General Abubakar Mayanja confirmed that the government's National Resistance Army (NRA) has been responsible for excesses and said that disciplinary action against the officers involved will be taken.

The report, prepared by a government ombudsman, also criticized authorities for the arrest last year of a former prime minister, Daniel Omara Atubo, along with members of parliament; two senior officials of the Democratic Party, Zachary Olum and Ojok Mulozi; the National Liberation Party leader, Tiberio Okenyi; and 18 others on charges of treason and sedition.

In May, Ugandan courts acquitted Olum, Mulozi, Okenyi, Atubo and 13 others. Two cases were withdrawn for lack of evidence. Mayanja said treason charges will be dropped against hundreds of others because arrests were made unlawfully. During the May 29 trial of Olum, Mulozi and Okenyi, the judge said the scarcity of evidence presented by prosecutors seemed to indicate the defendants had been held for political reasons.

Meanwhile, Ugandan state radio announced June 9 that the government plans to severely trim the size of the army, reported to be anywhere from 80,000 to 100,000, despite a June 6 attack by rebels in the northeast township of Bukedea in which eight people were killed. The move follows pressure from the World Bank and Western donors to cut defense expenditures, now that insurgencies in the north and northeast are largely under control.

According to Agence France-Presse, some observers believe the changes in the Ugandan government's attitude, as evidenced by the ombudsman's report and the recent rash of acquittals, reflects the impact of pressure from Western donors. In mid-May, a donor group chaired by the director of the World Bank Eastern Africa Department pledged $ 830 million in aid for Uganda but warned that continued human rights violations could jeopardize future assistance.


LOAD-DATE: June 22, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


133 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 22, 1992


News Agency Collapse Threatens a Continent's Dream:African Leaders will Consider Rescue Proposal


LENGTH: 1720 words


Dakar, Senegal

by Kwame Karikari n Africa News Service

Telex machines are silent, telephones are cut and the water taps are dry at the offices of the Pan-African News Agency (Pana) in Senegal's seaside capital.

Thirteen years after it was founded, Pana has all but closed for lack of funds. The creeping collapse appeared to signal the end of a bold plan to foster news exchanges among African countries and to ease Africa's dependence on news that is written and produced by agencies outside the continent.

But a multinational committee, set up by African information ministers to study the Pana crisis, plans to submit a proposal for a restructured continent-wide news agency to the summit meeting of the Organization of African Unity (OAU) in early July.

Pana owes Senegalese telecommunications and utility companies over $ 1 million and has been unable to pay a $ 15,000 bill for transmissions to London that is owed to a telecommunications firm in neighboring Gambia. 

Ten employees have resigned and only nine of 16 on the editorial staff remain at the Dakar headquarters. Staff members who have stayed go to work but have nothing to do. All have gone unpaid for at least six months, and some have not received full salaries for nearly a year.

Pana was established by African governments in 1979 with the hope that it could promote regional integration and cooperation in Africa. Its stated purposes reflect the widespread dissatisfaction with the continent's reliance on reporting by powerful international institutions such as British, French and American wire services. The fledgling news agency was asked to "correct the distorted image of Africa, its countries, peoples and culture" and to provide information about the struggle of Africa's peoples "against all forms of exploitation and oppression."

Pana's existence gave hope to Africans who were dismayed at what they saw as scant or ill-informed coverage of the continent's complex realities by journalists from abroad. Africans who agreed on little else have long argued that the foreign press tends to see Africa as a primitive place, where almost every conflict can be explained by tribalism and every problem is an example of African incompetence.

Pana also was charged with assisting the development of national news agencies in individual countries and was expected to establish a data bank on Africa as well as a photo service to serve African media.

From the beginning, though, Pana has been an idea which didn't work in practice.

The immediate crisis was caused by the failure of African governments to pay some $ 18 million in arrears to Pana. From the time that the idea of a continent-wide agency was proposed at the founding summit of the OAU in 1963, it was expected that governments would foot the bills. But only about five countries have paid their assessments fully.

"Some countries have never even paid anything since the start," says Victor Olufemi Adefela, Pana's news director.

Pana was intended to be a clearinghouse that linked, as well as supplemented, the work of Africa's national news agencies. It gathered news and information; translated it into Arabic, French and English; and redistributed the results to subscribers and member agencies around the continent. There are five regional pool centers to facilitate the collection and dissemination process: Tripoli, Tunisia, for North Africa; Lusaka, Zambia, in Southern Africa; Khartoum, Sudan, for East Africa; Lagos, Nigeria, for West Africa; and Kinshasa, Zaire, for the central area. There are bureaus in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia and Harare, Zimbabwe, and correspondents are based in London, Paris and New York.

At its peak, Pana distributed about 80 news stories -- up to 25,000 words -- daily. The continent's major media have used large amounts of material from the agency, which has been one of the few sources for stories about African development issues, environmental concerns and the role of women.

News director Adefela argues that Pana has achieved "a good measure of success" in its aim of highlighting important African news that the international press corps doesn't cover. Before the African agency was established, he says, African countries learned nearly everything they knew about each other -- and all too often, about events in their own countries -- from foreign media. Much of the coverage was limited to disasters and emergencies.

But cooperation from Pana's constituency has been spotty and sporadic. "There are a number of countries which participate (only) from time to time," Adefela says. "Some have never participated. Countries like Comoros or Mauritius haven't sent anything for the last two years."

Adefela concedes that "our success has been minimal in efforts to project a more accurate coverage of Africa" to other parts of the world, because there was no method for distribution outside the continent.

And there was a structural problem inherent in the agency's constitution, according to Salim Lone, editor of the United Nations publication, Africa Recovery. "It is vital for Africa and indeed for every world region to have news organizations which can reflect their concerns and interests," Lone says. "Unfortunately, Pana was never able to make significant headway in this area, primarily because of limited freedom and autonomy." Because it was linked to government-owned news agencies, Lone says, Pana was not free to report fully and accurately.

That limitation became particularly apparent in the past two years, as democracy movements have challenged or toppled dozens of authoritarian regimes across the continent. Governments under attack have tried to ignore or trivialize opposition forces, and government-owned news agencies have done the same.

Still, many of the struggles for democracy have been reported by independent journalists -- unaffiliated with government agencies -- who are employed directly by Pana. And the fact that international media are largely ignoring these dramatic developments is yet another sign of the need for an African news agency, supporters of the idea say.

Rescue Attempt

At a late April meeting in the Nigerian capital Abuja, Africa's information ministers established a six-nation task force to explore the possibilities of reviving and restructuring Pana. "We are convinced that changes and new trends in the continent necessitate a rethinking of the operational, managerial and legal framework of Pana," the ministers said in a resolution.

Nigerian President Ibrahim Babangida told the meeting that the need for a pan-African agency has not abated. "The relationship of dependence is still very strong," he said. "Disparities in infrastructure and imbalances in the international flow of information persist."

The task force is chaired by Nigeria, with representatives from Cameroon, Senegal, Egypt, Zimbabwe and Uganda and has been working in cooperation with the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (Unesco). The group has prepared a broad outline for a three-unit organization: a foundation which will set policy and raise funds, a telecommunications entity to distribute news and a professional, independent journalistic arm. The enterprise would invite private investors, and governments would be limited to a 20% share in the venture. Private interests could control no more than half the shares.

Under the plan, if the OAU approves the idea in principle, the task force will prepare a final plan of operation by the end of the year.

Even with the best plans, however, resuscitating Pana will be a challenge.

"To operate on a commercial basis will be extremely hard," says Salim Lone, "because there isn't much international interest in Africa. And the African countries, who would be the main users of the information, are in such a financial crisis that they will be unable to afford the money required to make the agency a success."

Nevertheless, Lone thinks the effort is worthwhile. Democratic reforms in Africa have been accompanied by an upsurge of independent newspapers. In Cote d'Ivoire, for example, dozens of new journals have appeared in the last year. But the young publications need both information and training of the sort that an effectively functioning news agency could provide. n

With research from Monono Churchill in New York


LOAD-DATE: June 22, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


134 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 22, 1992


Mobutu Blocks Zaire Democracy Moves


LENGTH: 880 words


Kinshasa, Zaire

by Cindy Shiner n Africa News Service

President Mobutu Sese Seko has reiterated his refusal to ease his 27-year grip on power and yield authority to a national democracy conference representing the country's political, civic and religious organizations.

The president's intransigence has raised tensions in the capital and increased fears that widespread violence will recur.

In a statement read over national TV and radio on June 15, Mobutu said that only the president has the right to name a prime minister. He also said that the national conference is not empowered to make constitutional changes. 

More than two thousand delegates have been meeting on and off since last August with the goal of drafting a new constitution and choosing a transitional government leading to free elections.

The conference has declared itself sovereign from Mobutu and the unpopular administration of his appointee, Prime Minister Nguza Karl i Bond. In recent weeks, delegates have been moving towards selecting a new prime minister and revising the country's one-party constitution.

Mobutu's statement sparked protest in this capital, where hundreds took to the streets and some attacked cars thought to be carrying government officials.

"Mobutu's speech was very dangerous for the political future of Zaire," said Ngefa Apondoko, president of Zaire's Association for the Defense of Human Rights. "From the bread sellers to the intellectuals, everyone was angry. They wanted to loot the homes of the ruling party politicians and march to the people's palace," where the conference is being held, he said.

During nearly three decades in power, Mobutu has ruled with an iron fist and accumulated a personal fortune that makes him one of the world's richest people. The country itself, despite vast mineral resources, is bankrupt and largely unable to function.

Roman Catholic Archbishop Monsengwo Pasinya, the conference chairman, appealed for calm after the president's speech. He denied that the president can bar the conference from nominating a prime minister and said that the conference's legal framework authorizes delegates to choose a transitional government.

"The people have suffered greatly," said Monsengwo. "A new government needs to be implemented as soon as possible." With public frustration mounting, Monsengwo planned a trip to Europe and the U.S. to draw attention to the crisis and enlist support for keeping the democracy conference afloat.

Meanwhile, Zaire's economic situation continues to worsen. Inflation is out of control. The country's currency, the zaire, has dropped to a new low. To keep pace, the government treasury recently issued a 500,000 zaire note, the largest in circulation. But by mid-June, one U.S. dollar could buy 500,000 zaires on the illegal currency market.

Public servants earn an average wage of 4 million zaires per month, which is currently equivalent to about eight U.S. dollars. A large stack of manioc -- a staple food for most Zaireans -- costs about 6 million zaires.

In a country where unemployment is already an estimated 80%, about 1,500 more Zaireans stand to lose their jobs if the government does not reverse a recent seizure of petroleum assets of major foreign oil companies operating in Zaire. "If the situation goes on, next we will lay off all our people," says a major oil company executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

The government-owned oil company, Petro-Zaire, has said it requisitioned the foreign oil firms' stocks in early June to keep the price of petroleum down. Petro-Zaire has promised to reimburse companies for their losses. But the oil executive said it hasn't happened. "We haven't gotten anything," he said. "All the cash they got from the gas stations is going straight to Petro-Zaire, and we don't know what they are doing with the money."

He says Shell, Mobil and other foreign firms are losing about $ 30,000 a day because of the seizure. "This is pure theft," he says. "We don't have any revenue; how can we survive?"

"We are pretty sure now that (the government) doesn't have the money to pay for the stock of products," says Georges Fensie, a spokesman for Gulf Oil, which imports petroleum products to Zaire and stands to lose up to $ 10 million dollars because of the seizure. n


LOAD-DATE: June 22, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


135 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 22, 1992


After Rio, African Groups Have Contacts, Voice


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1374 words


Rio de Janeiro, Brazil

by Carole Collins and Colin Darch

Africa achieved limited gains at the recently concluded United Nations Conference on Environment and Development (Unced) in Rio. But the emergence of African non-governmental organizations (NGO) onto the international scene may mark a turning point in their influence on the world's ecology.

NGOs made their voices heard during the official Unced deliberations -- held at a plush high-security conference center 20 miles outside of town -- and at the parallel Global Forum organized by the world's environmental activists in a beach-front park near the city center.

At the Unced deliberations, discussion of well-honed drafts developed during months of preparatory meetings was more or less business-as-usual for African government delegations well versed in UN-style politics. At the more informal NGO-based Global Forum, relatively inexperienced African groups had some much-needed exercise in international diplomacy, negotiating and lobbying. 

Although 30 African heads of state were among the continent's delegations at the official Unced meeting, only 16 African countries had NGO representatives at the forum. And of 791 NGOs at Unced, only 230 were from the poor nations of the southern hemisphere. Still, at both the forum -- where they were lost among almost 8,000 participating groups from 187 countries -- and at Unced, African NGOs played what was perhaps their most assertive role ever at a world-level meeting.

At the forum, NGOs joined an open discussion process that produced 33 different agreements or "treaties" on a wide-range of environmental topics. In addition, the African NGOs issued a hard-hitting document, The Rio Declaration on Eradication of Poverty in Africa, which summarized their concerns for the future. The document attacks governments for having lost "the will to deal with the principal causes of environmental degradation," which the paper identifies as militarization, over-consumption, exploitative trade patterns and unfair and coercive financial systems.

Many official Unced delegations, confronted with the complicated issues of environmental policies and practices, called upon NGO activists for their specific and extensive expertise. NGO leaders such as Sam Moyo of the Zimbabwe Energy Resources Organization, Benjamin Makunzy Valerie of Angola's Programa Humanitario para Criancas Orfas (Humanitarian Program for Orphans) and others played active roles as technical advisors for their countries' official delegations. Valerie, for example, not only represented his own organization and assisted Angola's official delegation, but also represented a new national NGO forum.

Through their various contributions, African NGOs showed that their conspicuous lack of experience on the international negotiating and diplomatic scene was not to be confused with a shortage of expertise on the environmental issues facing their countries.

One of the central preoccupations of Africa's official Unced delegations was that the spread of deserts be recognized as a global problem rather than just an African concern. This notion was part of a common position, worked out under the auspices of the UN Economic Commission for Africa and the Organization of African Unity in November 1991. Over 45% of the world's deserts are located in Africa.

Despite some last-minute objections, Unced delegations agreed to set up an Inter-Governmental Negotiating Committee to hammer out an international convention on drought and desertification control, in a process similar to that which produced the recent conventions on climate change and biodiversity.

"Agreeing to develop a convention on desertification was a high African priority," says Raymond Kwerepe, a rangeland ecologist at Botswana's Ministry of Agriculture. But former Tanzanian President Julius Nyerere, attending as an informal advisor to Unced Secretary-General Maurice Strong, sees hard work still ahead. "Africans were specifically concerned with desertification, and that is now being taken seriously and accepted" he says. "We will have to sit down together and tackle the problem."

African heads of state joined others from the poor nations of the southern hemisphere in stressing the importance of poverty as a central factor fueling environmental degradation. African environmentalists say economic issues come to center stage wherever soil is eroded from the marginal land that poor farmers must try to cultivate, or when forests are cut for firewood or fresh water is polluted around population centers. "Beyond the screaming headlines of the 'loud' environmental emergencies such as global warming," says Tanzanian President Ali Hassan Mwinyi, "there are the silent environmental emergencies that affect the daily lives of millions in the world. The 'loud' emergencies have yet to affect many people. But the silent emergencies, the more immediate issues of human survival, are already wasting many lives."

Mwinyi says another obstacle to southern efforts to preserve the environment is "the compulsive pressure imposed on us to maximize export production and foreign exchange earnings to meet external debt service payments of more than twice our annual per capita income. He says international debt precludes "the opportunity for placing poor economies on a sustainable path."

For many of the newer African NGOs, Rio was more of a learning experience than one that produced concrete outcomes. Mamadou Saliou Diallo, of Guinea-Ecologie, says his contact with other NGOs taught him much about how to appeal credibly to potential funders. Angola's Valerie agrees, saying that for him one of the main shocks of the meeting was learning how poor his organization's funding proposals had been.

Several African NGOs noted continuing tensions and gaps of understanding between organizations in the industrialized northern hemisphere and the countries of the south. N'nenna Eluna, an NGO advisor to the Nigerian delegation, who represented the Women's Employment and Environmental Project, notes that while northern NGOs tend to work on "problems from a slightly abstract point of view," NGOs in poorer countries, whose members are "mainly indigenous people," tend to start "from the problem base" on such issues as "poverty, desertification and working against the extinction of species."

Prisca Molotsi of the Zambia Alliance of Women agrees. "We in Africa," she says, "tend to rely too much on donors from the West, rather than networking with NGOs from other parts of the world."

The idea that democracy is a necessary precondition for saving the planet rode a strong current at the Global Forum and at Unced. Democracy is needed not only within nations, but also between them, Niko Bessinger, Namibia's minister of wildlife, conservation and tourism, told fellow statesmen. Bessinger called for "the democratization of our country, the planet, where the weak and the small and the impoverished share fully in (the political) process." n


LOAD-DATE: June 22, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


July 6, 1992


South and North


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 188 words


Regional tensions in Rwanda are reported to have led to the beating of Education Minister Agathe Uwilingiyimana, who says she was attacked by 25 young thugs armed with grenades and machetes. The attackers beat her "expertly, so it left no trace" and stole money and clothes "to make it look like robbery," the minister says. 

Uwilingiyimana, who is from the south, says her attackers belong to President Juvenal Habyarimana's National Republic Movement for Democracy and Development, based in the north. The president says he is sure the May 7 attack was banditry and was not politically motivated.

But some southerners in the opposition-dominated transitional government see the attack as part of a campaign by Habyarimana to sabotage a promised transition to democracy and to keep the powers that have enabled him to favor northerners for almost a decade.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


137 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 6, 1992


United Front


LENGTH: 334 words


Two factions of the Sudanese People's Liberation Army (SPLA) are meeting in Nairobi, Kenya, to heal a 10-month split in this rebel movement based in southern Sudan.

Officials from the faction headed by John Garang, based in the town of Torit, and a breakaway group, based in the town of Nasir, announced in mid June that they would reunite on the battlefield, once they agree on a new structure for the rebel movement, who would lead the SPLA and how it would deal with human rights. The Nasir faction broke from the Torit faction last August over what its leaders described as human rights violations by Garang.

The two factions united at the bargaining table in early June during peace talks in Nigeria. Both pressed the government, dominated by Arabic-speaking Muslims, for self-determination for the south, which is populated mainly by Christian or animist Africans. The Torit faction had previously pushed for an end to Sharia, or Islamic law. The government has offered autonomy for the south within a federal system and exemption from Sharia for non-Muslim areas.

The split in the SPLA has contributed to recent battlefield gains by government troops, who have occupied 13 rebel-held towns in the biggest dry season offensive since the civil war began in 1983. Military ruler Omar Hassan Ahmad Al-Bashir has vowed government troops will soon take Torit, the last major town held by Garang's faction. Rebels seized the garrison center of Juba, the largest city in the south, for a couple of hours in early June, but government troops soon regained control.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


138 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 6, 1992


Presumed Innocent


LENGTH: 200 words


Two park rangers in Kenya who were accused of the 1988 murder of British tourist Julie Ward in a game reserve have been acquitted due to lack of evidence.

A trial judge in late June affirmed the decision of three court assessors that accusations against Jonah Tajeu Magiroi, 28, and Peter Metui Kipeen, 26, were based on circumstantial evidence. Judge Fidahussein Abdallah said a game warden, a revenue clerk and a police constable also suspected of the murder should have been investigated further.

Prosecutors had contended that Magiroi and Kipeen kidnapped Ward, 28, raped her at their Makari game post, killed her, chopped up her body and tried to burn the remains. Kenyan authorities initially said Ward was killed by wild animals, but pursued the case further after a detective hired by the woman's father uncovered evidence of murder.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


139 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 6, 1992


UN Rescue


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 480 words


A 50-member United Nations military observer team is expected to arrive this week in Mogadishu, the strife-torn capital of Somalia, to monitor a cease-fire between two rival warlords. But an exodus that has sent about 800,000 Somalis to neighboring countries, most recently in crowded, poorly supplied boats bound for Yemen, continues.

The refugees are fleeing shortages of food, continued lawlessness in the capital, drought and fighting. In the north, factions in the self-proclaimed Republic of Somaliland are struggling for power. In the south, the forces of Gen. Mohamed Aidid Farrah, one of the Mogadishu warlords, are battling supporters of former President Mohammed Siad Barre, who was overthrown by Aidid and others in January 1991 and driven over the Kenya border in April. 

Since Siad's overthrow, Somalia has splintered along ethnic lines into armed groups fighting for local control. The most intense battles have taken place in the capital, between Aidid and Ali Mahdi Mohamed, named the country's president by several factions. The 50 unarmed military observers are supposed to monitor a March cease-fire declared between Aidid and Mahdi. Aidid has not yet agreed to let the UN send a 500-soldier armed force to Mogadishu to guard relief supplies and convoys which are often attacked in this city where people are starving.

Estimates of the number dying of hunger in the capital range from 30 per day to 5,000 per day. Whatever the exact figure, the UN says about 4.5 million face starvation across Somalia.

An estimated 400,000 Somalis are refugees in Ethiopia, several hundred thousand are in Kenya, 90,000 are in Djibouti and 12,000 are in Yemen, according to the latest update from the U.S. Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance.

About 4,000 of the most recent Somali refugees are camped on beaches in Yemen, after crossing the Indian Ocean in two boats with inadequate food and water for the many days spent waiting at sea for permission to land. On the larger of the boats, more than 150 died of dehydration, heat stroke and cholera, were murdered by shipboard bandits, or perished trying to swim to land before authorities allowed them ashore.

More boatloads of refugees are reportedly bound for Yemen, Kenya and Tanzania.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


140 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 6, 1992


The Heat Is On


LENGTH: 200 words


Hundreds have been arrested and others have been killed or injured in Egypt following a late June crackdown on suspected Islamic militants. The move came after attacks on Coptic Christians and security forces. 

About 5,000 heavily armed police in river boats and armored personnel carriers descended on Egypt's southern Asyut province, sealing off roads, setting up checkpoints and storming the houses of suspected extremists. They searched most intensively in and around the village of Dayrut, a center of militant activity about 200 miles (325 kilometers) south of Cairo.

The crackdown followed three months of conflict in Asyut province, where more than 20 people, most of them Copts, died as a result of violence between Christians and Muslims. Each group makes up about half of the region's population of 1.5 million people. Both Christian and Muslim clerics have called for an end to the fighting.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


141 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 6, 1992


Olive Branches


LENGTH: 240 words


Djibouti's government has scheduled a constitutional referendum that would lead to multiparty elections. In a June 27 speech President Hassan Gouled Aptidon announced an amnesty for guerrillas fighting government troops and also announced the release of 14 members of the rebel Front for the Restoration of Unity and Democracy (FRUD). 

A moderate opposition leader, in Paris for a meeting to explore ways to set up a united political front, called the government's moves "positive." But he said opposition parties have not decided whether to participate in the September 4 referendum. Several opposition parties charge that the government, which is dominated by members of the Issa ethnic group, is planning to win the national elections it scheduled for November 20 by registering Ethiopian Issas as Djibouti voters.

FRUD's members mostly are from the Afar ethnic group and have been fighting a guerrilla war against the army since late last year. The president said restrictions on movement around the two towns in the center of the conflict have been lifted.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


142 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 6, 1992


Fragile Future


LENGTH: 320 words


France has dropped its call for a national conference in Chad, reportedly because the military government of Chadian President Idriss Deby is considered too weak to weather the debate.

The latest challenge to Deby's authority came in mid June with the discovery of a coup plot by Public Works Minister Abbas Kotti, who has fled to an as yet unidentified neighboring country. Kotti was the leader of a March protest by soldiers against proposed cuts in the army. During the protest, soldiers in tanks surrounded the presidential palace. After the plan to overthrow Deby was uncovered, clashes between rebels and the army in the Lake Chad region north of N'Djamena, the capital, killed 103 Kotti supporters and ten of Deby's soldiers, according to the government.

Deby has faced opposition from armed groups throughout Chad since he came to power in December 1990 by overthrowing former dictator Hissene Habre, whom he once served as defense minister.

Reportedly worried that Deby's regime would not survive a national conference that included attacks by Habre supporters and angry soldiers, France now favors the formation of a national unity government in order to establish democracy in Chad. Deby recently appointed as prime minister a former minister of planning and reconstruction under Habre, Joseph Yodoyman.

Deby had promised to convene a national conference in May to draft a new constitution and establish a multiparty system. That conference was not held, but five political parties have been registered.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


143 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 6, 1992


Cobalt Rush


LENGTH: 254 words


The Ugandan government and business partners plan to turn the East African nation into a substantial producer of cobalt, by using bacteria to extract the economically important metal from waste dumps at an old copper mine.

The government has recently signed a $ 54 million agreement with Barclays Metals of the United Kingdom and Bureau de Recherches Geologiques et Minieres (BRGM), a state-owned French mining group, to do a feasibility study and construct a cobalt extraction plant. 

Since copper production at the Kilembe mine in southwest Uganda stopped in 1972, trial methods to recover cobalt from the waste dumps have been rejected as either too expensive or too polluting. But BRGM has developed a new method that avoids those problems.

The project is supposed to contribute about five percent of the world's output of cobalt by 1995, producing at least 1,000 tons of the metal annually for 15 years. Zambia and Zaire now account for about 70% of production worldwide.

Cobalt is essential to the manufacture of several superalloys used in the aerospace industry and for various products used by the automobile industry.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


144 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 6, 1992


Shoo Fly


SECTION: DATELINE: AFRICA


LENGTH: 187 words


An infestation in Libya of a livestock-killing insect that scientists feared would spread throughout Africa has been declared officially over. 

The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization announced in June that a year has passed since the last New World screwworm, believed to have been brought to Libya on sheep imported from South America in 1988, was found in North Africa.

The female screwworm fly lays her eggs in open wounds on animals. Screwworm larvae then feed on the animals, sometimes killing them within a few days.

The infestation was ended by using radiation to sterilize hundreds of millions of male screwworm flies. The males were then released to mate with female flies who then produced sterile eggs.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


145 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 6, 1992


Progress for Ethiopian Transition but Polling Deemed 'Imperfect'


SECTION: DOSSIER


LENGTH: 1174 words


A 71-member delegation from the United States participated in the Joint International Observer Group for Ethiopia's elections, under the auspices of the New York-based African-American Institute (AAI). Four days after the voting took place, AAI issued the following statement, with contributions from nearly all members of the American contingent.

On June 21, 1992, Ethiopia held what was to be the first truly democratic elections in its history. The Transitional Government of Ethiopia (TGE) had great expectations that these district and regional elections would set the stage for national elections projected to take place in 1993. The primary political purpose of these elections was, according to the National Charter, to "empower" through the vote all of Ethiopia's nationalities within a new pluralistic political system. However, this first round of elections fell considerably short of this objective. 

Less than a week before the election, the Oromo People's Liberation Front (OLF), undeniably a significant political party in the South, as well as other parties including the All-Amhara People's Organization (AAPO), the Ethiopian Democratic Action Group (EDAG), the Islamic Front for the Liberation of Oromia (IFLO), and the Gideo People's Democratic Organization (GPDO), announced their withdrawal from the process. Together the partisans of these organizations represent a significant proportion of the Ethiopian electorate. Moreover, the provocative movement of Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Force (EPRDF) troops throughout the election process, combined with the OLF's decision to decamp approximately 15,000 fighters immediately after withdrawing from election, raised the prospects of a return to armed conflict in the Oromo region.

The bases of the OLF complaint were that the National Election Commission had not followed Proclamation 11, calling for the establishment and management of electoral committees; that OLF offices were arbitrarily closed in some areas; and that prospective candidates were detained without reason. In partial response to growing charges of procedural irregularities, the day before the election, the Council of Representatives ordered that in those locations where serious administrative problems were found to exist, the voting period would be extended by up to a week, while in those areas where there were enduring political obstacles, elections would be postponed indefinitely and these problems would be investigated and resolved.

In the rest of the country the elections did go on as planned. The results were mixed, with some parts of the North, including Addis Ababa and other major urban centers experiencing what appeared to be procedurally regular elections. Here some voters were enthusiastic about their opportunity to vote in these historic elections, and hopeful for a democratic future. In other places, such as the Afar and Somali regions, the charter city of Harar, and eastern and western Oromo areas, for various reasons elections were postponed indefinitely.

In very few places were there competitive, multiparty elections. The EPRDF and its affiliated parties (e.g. EPDM, OPDO, etc.) were usually the only parties on the ballot. Non-participation was explained both as a response to intimidation and detention of supporters and candidates, or alternately as an expression of a party's unwillingness to participate in the electoral process.

In rural and peri-urban areas of the north and central areas of Ethiopia, as well as in most parts of the South, there were serious problems in the election process. These problems were in part administrative and in part political. Among the administrative problems were the failure to constitute bona fide local and regional election committees in the manner specified by Proclamation 11; poor communications up and down the electoral commission hierarchy; the failure to deliver registration and voting materials on time; and, inadequate and/or delayed funding for election committees. Another serious problem had to do with the failure of election officials to adequately educate the population about the purpose of the ballot and the procedures for casting their votes.

Political problems were no less daunting. Where EPRDF controlled local administration (particularly in the South and East), it was not uncommon for electoral and local administrative officials to prevent candidates and voters from opposition parties from registering. In some cases those who refused to state their ethnicity or referred to themselves simply as Ethiopians were prevented from registering, notwithstanding a decision on the part of the ministry of justice that individuals could indeed refer to themselves as "Ethiopian" without violating any laws.

Prior to the elections, political intimidation and harassment were reported in most parts of the country. In addition, violence and fraud were reported in such areas as Dire Dawa, Harar, parts of Shoa, Dembi Dolo, Awasa, and elsewhere. In most cases, the allegations were made against local administrators and the EPRDF-based government. In others, they were made against opposition parties such as the OLF in Wollega.

The Transitional Government of Ethiopia, in accordance with the 1991 Charter, has begun to open up the political system. There is now more freedom of political expression than ever before.

Much needs to be done before the system is truly democratic. A strengthening of electoral institutions, along with the political and mutual restraint of all parties, are of the highest priority. A major shortcoming of the whole process appears to be that the government tried to do too much too soon.

This is not to say that some progress has not been made. Many Ethiopians spoken to by the AAI observers expressed fervent yearnings for peace and democracy. One can only hope that immediate steps are taken to avert further bloodshed and that these admittedly imperfect elections contribute toward peace and the advance of a democratic process. n


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


146 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 6, 1992


ELECTION JOURNAL: Voters Demonstrate Hopes for Change


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1880 words


 

Friday, June 19 -- The briefing we received yesterday included some hopeful signs: in some trouble spots, registration sites that had been closed by the Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front (EPRDF ) have been reopened; some political detainees were freed. Someone mentions, "everyone has guns." Security for the observers takes on a new meaning. We are made as "official" as possible -- we have Joint International Observers Group (JIOG) photo identification badges to wear on visits, we are encouraged to wear the official JIOG tee shirts we have been issued, our vehicles have the JIOG symbol prominently displayed, we have letters of introduction in three different languages. Interpreters travel with us, though many people speak English very well. 

The country is divided into 14 election districts, divided primarily along ethnic lines. This helps to ensure representation of all groups. We visit four urban kebeles, the Ethiopian equivalent of a precinct or ward, in Addis Ababa and one rural peasant association. The election committees are cooperative. They answer our questions thoroughly and make their records available to us. One even offered a guide to help us find the rural peasant association. We encounter two candidates campaigning. Tadele Bitul Kibrat, an engineer educated in the U.S. and Canada, is running for district office, but has much higher political aspirations. He is setting his sights on running the country one day. He carries a thick notebook detailing his lifelong struggle for democracy and justice. He proudly shows a photocopy of a letter he wrote opposing Haile Selassie's nomination for the Nobel Peace Prize. He is encouraged by the election process. However, there are no opposition candidates for his office, and he is assured of election.

When we visit the rural peasant association we notice the first hint of a problem. Looking through the registration book there are a group of pages where all the registrants signed on the same day from the same ethnic group, and they all had resided in the area for the same length of time. Are we witnessing mass fraud? Apparently not. We are presented with a very plausible explanation: the entries were made when members of the army who live in the area came en masse to register.

As we journey back toward town our guide proudly points out his kebele and invites us to visit. I'm pleased to see the election committee is composed of three women. The women tells us they are educating the public about the voting process and the candidates. They show us a room with posters listing all the candidates and some individual campaign flyers.
