On the wall beneath the Ethiopian candidates is a bumper sticker: it reads "Ross Perot for President."

Saturday, June 20 -- All of our time is spent in urban kebeles. We witness community meetings where the voting process is explained. Voters who cannot read or write can still participate. Each candidate has been assigned a symbol; voters indicate their choice by signing their name or by placing their thumbprint next to the appropriate symbol. I ask about the percentage of women who have registered; in many places over 50% of those registered are female. We meet several candidates for local and regional seats, and we see our first example of campaigning. A decorated pick-up truck equipped with a bullhorn is cruising the streets. Our interpreter informs us that the message is not for a specific candidate; the message is from the EPRDF calling for party unity.

The kebeles we have visited have each registered over 2,000 voters. All of the voting will be manual, and many people cannot read or write. Suddenly the enormity of situation hits us -- this will be a long, slow process. The election committees have not thought out how to get people in and out quickly. Will the voters have the tenacity to stick it out, waiting long hours in the sun? Are the election officials prepared to handle hundreds of people who may show up all at once? Is it fair for us to expect an essentially rural society to manage a complex election system? Should we evaluate it as we would in a more industrialized society?

Finally some ballots arrive, but it's after 4:00 p.m. The local election committee is quickly sorting the ballots. They must be delivered tonight -- quite a feat considering there are only two cars available.

Back at the hotel, the U.S. group meets to discuss issuing a joint statement. Some members are back from visits in the countryside. I hear talk of sabotage, intimidation, mistrust among parties, arrests, murders, reluctance on the part of voters. Are things that different in Addis than in other districts? Have I really misread what is happening at the sites I have visited? Obviously the process is not perfect but it appears to be working. After all, only a year ago peace was really new in a country that had been engaged in armed conflict for so long. Dare we even suggest that major progress is not being made? Certainly the democratic process has a long way to go, but the government has made an effort to extend the political process to all.

Sunday, June 21 -- I'm at kebele 14 when the polls open at 7:00 a.m. Already there is confusion, as all previous communications set the opening of the polls for 6:00 a.m. There are 84 people seated orderly in a small auditorium. We inspect the private voting booths, each with a listing of all the candidates and posters for the candidates and their platforms. It takes the committee almost 30 minutes to explain the process. It is now 7:50; there are almost 200 people in the auditorium. Outside there are two armed members of the Peace and Security Committee, a police force elected by members of the kebele. I did not find their low-key presence menacing. With much ceremony the first vote is cast by the local priest from the Coptic Church. When he emerges from the voting booth his right index finger is dabbed with indelible ink to prevent voting a second time. Here, it looks like the process is working.

I join a group who journey to Debre Zeit, a town 31 miles (50 kilometers) south of Addis. We stop at two kebeles on the way. There are long lines at both stops, and the voting seems to take forever. I am impressed that there are so many women waiting to vote. We make three stops in Debre Zeit, a town where the Oromo people are the dominant ethnic group. The Oromo Liberation Front has withdrawn from the elections, but it does not appear that many people are honoring the boycott.

At one polling place, a radio provides entertainment for those waiting to vote. There are not many sites where seats are being contested by opposition candidates or independents, but that does not appear to have deterred many voters. The turnout is steady and people seem committed to wait it out for their turn to vote. I speak to a local candidate who represents the EPRDF. I ask him why he is running. He says he is not sure. Is he a pawn of the party? Or does he not understand my question posed in English? We have a flat tire and a group of young men stop to help us. I ask if they are registered to vote, and they answer yes; but none have voted. A 19-year-old who is studying to be a mechanic gives me a long, rambling answer about why he did not vote. His English is good, but still it is difficult for me to understand his answer. He suggests there is not enough choice, and he does not feel the emphasis of ethnicity helps encourage the sense of unity Ethiopia needs.

I go back to my original polling spot at 6:30 p.m. There are more than a hundred people in line. The committee says the polls will remain open as long as there are voters in line. Another observer visits at 10:30 p.m., and the voting continues.

Monday, June 22 -- Controversy. Some polls closed on time the night before with the thought that the voting would continue on Monday morning. However, no provision has been made for this, and people are told to go home. We hear that in some kebeles hundreds are in line this morning. We hear of others where people were in line until very late Sunday night. There is serious confusion. There has been no official communication on how to proceed.

We go to kebele 22 to observe the counting of ballots. The room with the ballots is locked and sealed. Bold adhesive bands on the windows and doors are complete with the signatures and seals of the election committee. I have no doubt that these ballots are secure. We witness the opening of the room and the beginning of the counting process. There are almost too many witnesses to the process. Observers from the district committee, ten policemen, all of the candidates, four JIOG observers and the election committee all crowded into the room. Each ballot is shown to the group before it is officially counted. Over 1500 people voted here. The counting will take a long time.

The U.S. delegation gets together again to try to formulate a consensus statement of our impressions. More people are back from the outlying areas, and again there are differing views of the process and what actually took place. Because the elections were postponed in some parts of the country -- because of administrative and political irregularities -- it is difficult to put closure to what happened. Some observers note the low key mood of the voters and contrast the calm to the excitement in Zambia where voters chanted with enthusiasm the coming of the paper ballots.

I think back to home and my urban precinct in my model university town. We've had 200 years of election experience in the U.S. and many offices go unchallenged. The Ethiopians have had one year under a new system, and some condemn them because of the lack of opposition candidates in theirJelections. There are important questions to be answered. Were there clear violations? Was there consistent intimidation? Though rival army factions have decamped, is tension greater than before? The system certainly suffered from a lack of adequate civic education. The process was rushed and flawed, but compromises and changes went on, even on election eve. Progress? Yes. A long way to go? You bet. Will it work? I think the Ethiopian people will assure that it will.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


147 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 6, 1992


Elections Test Ethiopia's New Democracy


SECTION: FORUM


LENGTH: 387 words


After a century of imperial rule and two decades of military dictatorship, it should come as no surprise that the creation of democracy in Ethiopia is encountering obstacles. But recent events have taken a decidely disconcerting turn, beginning with a troubled election on June 21 and continuing with an escalation of ethnic divisions within the ruling transitional administration. 

The interim government, formed a year ago after the ouster of Mengistu Haile Mariam, who headed the military regime which seized power in 1974, has fought against divisiveness since its earliest days. Following last month's elections, the ruling coalition -- known as the Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front, whose combined guerrilla forces pushed Mengistu out of power-- suffered a serious setback. The Oromo Liberation Front (OLF), claiming to represent the country's largest ethnic group, pulled out of the government, charging fraud and mismanagement of the election process. Fighting between government troops and OLF forces reportedly erupted in the south, where the two groups clashed earlier this year.

President Meles Zenawi accused the OLF of attacking government positions, a charge denied by the front, which said its forces were the ones under attack.

In attendance during the voting for local council positions around the country was an international observer force of 200 coordinated by the United Nations and drawn from 27 countries, including the U.S., which sent a delegation of 71, assembled by the African-American Institute in New York. The following eyewitness account by delegation member and Africa News executive director Bertie Howard, provides a flavor of the process and the problems. The American delegation's assessment, in the form of a statement, is also reproduced below.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


148 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 6, 1992


Hopes and Questions Surround Sierra Leone Reform


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1187 words


 

The young military officers who took over the government of Sierra Leone in an April coup d'etat have fired up a demoralized populace by briskly moving to restore public services and to unearth public funds missing under the former regime. But many who have official or business dealings in Freetown, the capital, are skeptical about whether the National Provisional Ruling Council (NPRC), as the new government is called, is equal to its most critical challenge -- stopping the diamond smuggling and corruption that have cheated the nation of tax revenues and have helped consign Sierra Leone to the ranks of the world's least-developed countries.

Sierra Leone, where legal diamond exports have fallen from two million carats in 1970 to 132,000 in 1989, is not the only African nation to be bled of its mineral wealth. "All the diamonds have feet," said an official at the Bureau of Mines in Washington, "but in Sierra Leone the smuggling is so rampant." 

Indeed, it was hard to ignore the evidence that mine operators and diamond dealers were bribing officials of the government of former President Joseph Momoh to secure mining concessions and special detours around the tax authorities. Untended, the health, electric, water and telephone systems deteriorated. Ministers drove fancy cars over crumbling roads while unpaid civil servants left their desks to do odd jobs. When there was no money in the national treasury to cover imports, consumers paid higher prices for scarce staples and fuel.

As part of a series of reforms required to reinstate the country's borrowing from the International Monetary Fund (IMF), President Momoh had begun to renegotiate some of the country's major mineral contracts (rutile and bauxite, as well as diamonds). The contracts were negotiated under the close guidance of international financial institutions. Even so, "money needed to change hands in almost every deal," said a European consultant involved in some of the negotiations.

The NPRC, headed by Capt. Valentine Strasser, has repeatedly vowed to get a handle on diamond exports and has claimed that tax receipts were up 500% during NPRC's first five weeks in power.

To the delight of Sierra Leoneans, the NPRC also has jailed about 50 former officials of the Momoh government, frozen the bank accounts of the former president and his cronies and discovered eye-popping caches of wealth in some of their homes. A judicial probe of government corruption is under way, and officials and civil servants are now required to fill out financial disclosure forms.

But the real question is, can the NPRC itself resist succumbing to corruption? Optimistic observers say it all depends on how fast the government fulfills its promise to set the country back on the path toward multiparty democracy that President Momoh was halfheartedly pursuing when he was ousted. But a mining industry source saw an ominous sign in Strasser's decision to make his residence the opulent marble mansion built by Momoh's predecessor, Siaka Stevens, overlooking Freetown on Juba Hill.

Sooner or later, discussions of corruption turn to the Lebanese community, which dominates much of the diamond industry, and to the two Israeli companies that tried to muscle out the Lebanese during the Momoh regime. The Israelis, with their government's backing, wanted diamonds and a moderation in Sierra Leone's pro-Palestinian foreign policy, which was heavily influenced by the Lebanese. The Lebanese have engendered great resentment because of their relative wealth and the "special relationships" that some in the community, which dates back to the late nineteenth century, were able to maintain with Momoh and his predecessors.

Although several wealthy Lebanese Sierra Leoneans have been driven into exile, few believe rumors that the NPRC plans to expel the entire community. The Lebanese monopoly on Sierra Leone's retail trade is galling to the impoverished African population, but it is difficult to see who else might put up the cash to finance imports.

A Sierra Leonean official, however, guardedly suggested that the country could benefit from setting up a competition between the local Lebanese and Israeli investors. One of the NPRC's first foreign policy initiatives was to dispatch its foreign minister to Israel to renew diplomatic ties that were broken in 1973.

Ties with Israel will result in new weapons and training for Sierra Leone's army, Francis Gabbidon, Israel's lobbyist in Freetown, told Inter Press Service. Such aid might give the army the boost it needs to drive out Revolutionary United Front (RUF) guerrillas who have waged a destructive war in the south and east of the country since March 1991.

Sierra Leone's fight against the RUF is intertwined with its participation in the West African peace-keeping forces that have been trying to end the Liberian civil war. A peaceful resolution of the Liberian conflict may well bring an end to the fighting in Sierra Leone, where the RUF is seen as a proxy for Liberian rebel leader Charles Taylor. Anti-Taylor Liberian forces are fighting alongside the Sierra Leonean military.

Without such a settlement -- and without outside military aid beyond the limited support provided by Nigeria and Guinea -- there is little hope that Sierra Leone can defeat the RUF militarily. There is much riding on the outcome of the conflict. Not only is it raging over important mining areas, but the NPRC has said it will permit a return to civilian rule only when the RUF has been quelled.

The troops at the front now are complaining, according to the BBC, that they lack adequate food and pay, and that the veterans most needed at the front are palling around with NPRC officials. Ironically, it was to demand adequate supplies and support that Strasser and his associates traveled from the front to Freetown in April. They appeared to have been as surprised as anyone when their demonstration spiraled into a successful coup. n


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


149 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 6, 1992


Electoral Commission Promises Fairness


LENGTH: 374 words


Following are excerpts from a June 12 statement by Justice Z.R. Chesoni, chairman of an independent electoral commission appointed by Kenya's President Daniel arap Moi to oversee the nation's first multiparty elections since the 1960s. The portions excerpted refer to allegations of wrongdoing during the voter registration process which began June 8. 

The commission has taken seriously the errors that have been pointed out by various persons and organizations, and immediate steps have been taken to arrest the situation. In most areas, the corrective measures have included issuing of replacement cards for the faulty ones and even removal of inefficient officials.

The commission has set up a team which is visiting the districts and registration centers to check on the management of the registration process, and the commissioners are also visiting various centers for the same purpose.

The commission is open to receiving suggestions on how to improve and speed up the process, and we thank Kenyans who have already offered suggestions and advice.

Any applicant for registration who experiences a problem with obtaining an identification card should seek the assistance of the supervisor at the registration center where he or she wishes to be registered. As far as (is) practical, all qualified persons who apply shall be registered.

The only way any Kenyan can exercise his or her democratic right of electing a leader of one's choice is by obtaining a voter's card, which is the only weapon for removing undesirable leaders. Registration of voters is an exercise limited in time. Register before the time allowed expires. If you delay, it may be too late. It is better to have a voter's card and not use it than not to have one, so register now.


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


150 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 6, 1992


Kenyans Register to Vote as Opposition Raps Process


SECTION: INTERVIEW:


LENGTH: 2614 words


Sometime in the next nine months, the Kenyan government is expected to hold the nation's first multiparty elections since the late 1960s. President Daniel arap Moi has not yet announced a specific date for the elections, but according to the Kenyan constitution, elections must be held by next March.

At least five opposition parties have registered, and the two largest, the Forum for the Restoration of Democracy (FORD) and the Democratic Party (DP) have begun campaigning extensively in rural areas. Observers say there is a high level of popular discontent with Kanu, which has been the ruling party since 1963, and the elections, if carried through, may mark a watershed in Kenyan history.

Tensions have already risen, however, over what the opposition parties claim are attempts by Kanu to rig the electoral process in its favor. On June 8, the government began implementing the process of providing registration cards to the estimated 12 million eligible voters, under the supervision of an independent electoral commission appointed by President Moi. 

Despite some complaints that the electoral commission was not impartial, the opposition parties initially supported the registration process. But on June 10, both FORD and DP changed their position, issuing a joint statement calling on their supporters to boycott the registration process. The opposition charged that the registration had been tainted by massive irregularities and demanded that an entirely new commission be appointed to oversee the process. The registration process has continued, however, and as of June 28, the commission reported that about 3.3 million voters had registered.

If the controversy over the registration process is not resolved, the crisis could spoil the elections, worsen tensions and possibly intensify recent violent clashes in the Rift Valley and Western Province that are widely seen as being tied to political tensions between the government and the opposition. The conflicts have caused hundreds of deaths and forced thousands to flee their homes.

Raila Odinga, a leading FORD member, visited Washington late last month for talks with the State Department and the Congress. Odinga is the son of Oginga Odinga, former vice president under Kenyatta, a perennial dissident and one of the leading contenders to be the next president of Kenya. In the following interview with Will Acworth, Odinga talks about the boycott controversy and the campaign for multiparty democracy in Kenya.

AfricaNews: Herman Cohen, the U.S. assistant secretary of state for Africa, has called your boycott of the registration process ill-advised. How do you respond to this comment?

Raila Odinga: Cohen's statement was misinformed, it must have been based on a lack of information about the present exercise. The irregularities and the fraud are so massive that it does not permit any kind of rectification short of scrapping the electoral commission.

AN: Cohen has also emphasized the need for dialogue between the opposition and the government. How do you respond?

RO: As for the question of dialogue, we have been asking for dialogue all along. We have wanted to sit down with the government to discuss the program and the timing of change. Two days before President Moi left for the Rio conference, we sent a joint appeal to him asking for a meeting to discuss these issues, but he did not respond. So the ball is in the government's court.

AN: What was contained in this appeal?

RO: First, we must have a truly independent electoral commission. Second, the president must set a date and a timetable for the elections. Third is the question of the media, which Kanu is using as its own propaganda machinery. The Voice of Kenya is still the "Voice of Kanu." Fourth, the violence must be brought to an end. We can't register if people are being killed. Fifth is the problem of identity cards. There are 3.5 million Kenyans who still lack identity cards, which are required for (voter) registration. Sixth, the government must cease the harassment of our supporters and allow us to hold our rallies.

AN: What has been the reaction of the U.S. officials here in Washington to your charges of fraud in the registration process?

RO: They were shocked by the information I showed them. I tried to explain to them that we would not have called off this exercise if it had not been very evident that the whole thing was flawed.

I tried to indicate to them that the present exercise, if allowed to continue, would just amount to giving Moi a new lease on life. There is no way that we can proceed with this registration.

We had in fact asked the people to continue to register as we pressed for the resolution of the commission issue, but after two days it was evident that the registration was so fraudulent that it was therefore an exercise in futility. That's why we called it off. An independent electoral commission is an absolute condition of a free and fair electoral process.

AN: How do you propose that a new electoral commission be created?

RO: The current officials should be replaced with Kenyans in good standing who are not associated with the current government. We will propose some names of people (who) are approved by both the opposition and the government and then let the President choose from that list. Second, the commission must have its own funds and its own staff, so that the process is detached from the establishment. Not much time will be lost; if we move quickly, the registration process can begin in August.

The so-called independent commission exists just on paper. It sits in the parliament buildings, it is paid through the Office of the President, and the staff in the field are the provincial administration -- the district commissioners, the district officers, the chiefs and the sub-chiefs. And the Kanu stalwarts are being used as registration supervisors in the rural areas.

What we want to see is a completely new commission, which will have funding independent of the administration, so that the whole process is detached from the government. It can then proceed to hire its own staff and carry out the registration exercise independently.

In addition, all the opposition parties must be allowed to have their own representatives at each and every registration center to monitor the process.

AN: Are you saying that at this stage FORD cannot send representatives to the registration stations to monitor what is happening?

RO: Well, they are now saying that we can send people, but that is only after we made the boycott call. They should also allow international observers to participate and monitor the registration exercise. The government is allowing only the Commonwealth team, but we are highly suspicious. We accept that they should come, but the Ugandan experience has given them a certain stigma -- they certified that the 1980 elections were free and fair, but those elections now have been proved to have been massively rigged.

AN: According to reports in the Kenyan press, the British, the Germans and the EC have offered to provide funding for the electoral process. What about the U.S.?

RO: We have received confidential assurances that the U.S. is willing to provide some money for the elections. We advised the U.S. that they should provide materials, such as computers, printing of ballot papers, etc., and secondly that they should closely monitor the assistance to make sure that this money really reaches the people for whom it is intended.

AN: George Anyona, a former detainee with a long record as a fierce critic of the government, recently announced that he has decided to form his own political party. In spite of his opposition to the current government, he declared that the registration process should continue. How do you respond?

RO: Well, that's his own opinion. George has been a close comrade in arms. We have been in the struggle for quite some time together, but since he came out of detention, his entire conduct and utterances have left a lot to be desired. He has now more or less isolated himself, crying foul and criticizing for the sake of criticizing.

AN: There is a lot of disagreement and confusion within FORD, and you seem to have some difficulty coming up with a unified platform for the elections. Is FORD a full-fledged political party?

RO: We are a full-fledged political party... with a manifesto and policy statements. FORD is a vehicle for the restoration of democracy, for the resuscitation of the institutions (needed) to ensure democratic governance. Once the elections are over, we will have achieved our purpose, and at that point FORD may break up into different parties.

AN: FORD already seems to be breaking up. You have at least four different leaders competing to be the party's presidential candidate. Is it a sign of confusion that your leadership speaks with so many voices?

RO: We believe that disagreement is healthy. The fact that we have differing views within FORD should not be looked at as a split or a division. It is an exercise in democracy, because at the end of the day, it will be the people who will decide.

AN: How, exactly, will they decide?

RO: Grassroots elections (within the party) will be held on July 11 and 12, followed by sub-branch elections on July 18 and branch elections on July 19. Twelve delegates from each branch will attend the national delegates conference, which will be held on August 1, to ratify the constitution, decide on the process for choosing the presidential candidate and elect the office bearers for the party.

AN: Can you comment on the recent secret meeting between President Moi and Martin Shikuku, the secretary general of FORD, which caused so much controversy when it was leaked to the press?

RO: There would not have been much criticism of this visit if Shikuku had cared to consult with other members of FORD. But the fact that the visit was secretly done, and the fact that Shikuku himself did not announce it until the information leaked to the press, gave rise to the suspicion that there might be something sinister about this visit. The fact is he has not disclosed the content of the discussion, which lends weight to the conjecture that he may have been cutting some kind of deal with the president. The members of FORD were of course very incensed and angry, and a majority of the steering committee thought that he should be suspended. However, fortunately, goodwill prevailed, and he ended up just being stripped of some of his powers as secretary general. We realized that a suspension would just play into the hands of the enemy.

AN: One of the legacies of past political parties has been an emphasis on ethnic affiliation, where each politician claims to represent a certain bloc of voters. Is it correct to interpret the splits in FORD along these lines?

RO: It is very simplistic to look at the Kenyan situation in terms of tribal blocs. It is not true to say that (Masinde) Muliro leads the Luhya, or Odinga leads the Luo, or (Kenneth) Matiba leads the Kikuyu. It is a very fallacious view to say that because someone comes from a certain community, he therefore enjoys the support of the whole community.

We are just emerging from a dictatorship, where dissent was completely muzzled, where it was very difficult for a popular leadership to emerge across ethnic lines. The question of tribal affiliation itself is not, in my view, really a predominant factor in the Kenyan mind. The Kenyans will judge their leaders by who they are and what they stand for. Commitment to principles is going to be the main criterion the people will use to decide whom they will support for leadership.

AN: What about the fact that FORD has attracted so many former high- ranking members of Kanu? Is this a sign that FORD has become a vehicle for political opportunism?

RO: We began as a pressure group, as a coalition of people who agreed on the general goal of democracy. Then we were faced with an exodus of people (from Kanu) who wanted to cross over to us, and we decided for expedient and strategic reasons to keep an open door policy -- we thought that this would accelerate the process of Kanu's disintegration. But in the process, we gathered a lot of trash, the so-called political entrepreneurs, who have no convictions or understanding of our principles. We will let the people sort out the wheat from the chaff.

AN: If FORD comes to power, what will happen to the leading members of Kanu? One prominent FORD leader, Paul Muite, has said on a number of occasions that Moi himself should go on trial for his crimes. If FORD makes these kinds of threats, won't Moi try to cling to power as long as he can?

RO: We have been discussing that thing, and in Muite's last public address he said the same thing I have been saying, that we are going to provide (Moi) with some security. Moi has committed a lot of crimes. In order to prevent more bloodshed, we must give Moi a way out. The senseless killing in the Rift Valley can be avoided if Moi is given a way out. If he agrees to stop the bloodshed and presides over a smooth transition to a multiparty democracy, then he will also have made his contribution to the history of the country, and we can look kindly at his past transgressions. n


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


151 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 6, 1992


Quiet Defiance Marks Malawi Protests


SECTION: NEWS ROUNDUP


LENGTH: 1120 words


Blantyre, Malawi

After unprecedented urban unrest, businesses have reopened along Haile Selassie Road, a busy thoroughfare slicing through this east African industrial center. Opposition to the 28-year rule of "Life President" Kamuza Banda appears to have been swept away along with the shards of shattered windows.

But a closer look reveals a pattern of political defiance that is peculiarly Malawian. Unlike other countries across Africa, where mass street protests have forced dozens of authoritarian governments to reform or leave office, Malawi has remained largely quiet. In mid-May, demonstrations over wages paralyzed business districts like Haile Selassie Road -- and left an estimated 38 people dead. The disturbances were notable partly because they are so uncommon. 

Rather than taking to the streets to express their outrage at Banda's dictatorial powers, Malawians, in increasing numbers, are staying home. The trend is a reaction to the government's well-developed security system, with its network of informers, and to the dangers of opposition here, where suspicious automobile accidents and mysterious deaths have plagued dissidents.

Although staying home may seem a subtle form of protest, it is a highly visible one in a country whose political culture is built on well-orchestrated displays of support for the government. Recent ruling party rallies in empty stadiums and welcoming ceremonies for visiting dignitaries without the usual throngs of well wishers are signs of growing discontent.

"My brother is in jail because they had a picture of him demonstrating against police brutality," said a young woman in Zomba, where the university has been closed following student unrest. "They can't photograph me if I make my point by not showing up."

Another tool of dissent in Malawi is the facsimile machine. More difficult to intercept than telephone or telex transmissions, faxes have become the instrument of choice for communicating within the opposition and infiltrating government offices with anonymous messages of resistance. The effectiveness of this guerrilla information campaign was verified when the president in one recent speech condemned "anonymous letters defaming certain individuals."

While the stay-home approach by Malawians continues, hopes that Banda might finally have to loosen the reins on political dialogue and move the country toward peaceful change have been boosted by an aid cutoff approved by donors in May. But there is considerable uncertainty surrounding the status of some assistance programs.

The World Bank recently approved two additional loans for development projects in Malawi, and humanitarian assistance is specifically excluded from the donors' ban. Malawi is hosting nearly one million Mozambican refugees, the largest displaced population from a single county in any African nation.

"They're doing a great job with the refugees and they know it," a Western diplomat here said. "We all sympathize with the situation in Mozambique, and we all want to help them, but I wouldn't put it past this government to use them as pawns if it means more money."

Democracy Leader Readies for Showdown

Archbishop Monsengwo Pasinya, the chairman of Zaire's broad-based national democracy conference, has returned home from a visit with prom ises of the support he was seeking in Washington, Brussels and Paris.

During two days in the U.S. capital, where he met Secretary of State James A. Baker III, the cleric warned of an "apolcalypse" in Zaire if a solution is not found to the country's months-old political crisis. After the talks, the State Department issued a statement saying the administration supports "a process leading to democracy in Zaire, not any particular personality."

The Belgian and French governments also gave backing to the conference and pledged financial support.

Monsengwo was seeking backing in anticipation of a possible showdown later this month, when the conference -- a gathering of 2000 delegates representing Zaire's political, civic and religious organizations -- plans to name a new prime minister to govern until elections can be held.

In a recent statement and an interview on Zaire television, President Mobutu Sese Seko said he alone has the right to choose the prime minister. "I set the rules of the operation," Mobutu said.

Monsengwo predicts that it will be a difficult for the U.S. government to "untangle itself" from its long alliance with Mobutu. But he said that if the political reforms of the conference are blocked by "forces inside or outside Zaire," the situation would deteriorate quickly. He says people are becoming impatient with the political stalement.

In an interview, Monsengwo said American pressure could be pivotal if a confrontation develops between the Zaire president and the national conference. He credits a private letter in March from President Bush with persuading Mobutu to allow the democracy conference to reconvene.

The archbishop, who came to the U.S. at the invitation of the Africa Faith and Justice Network, a private Catholic organization, also was received at the White House by National Security Advisor Brent Scowcroft, was hosted at a State Department luncheon by Assistant Secretary of State for Africa Herman Cohen and met on Capitol Hill with Senate Foreign Relations Committee members Paul Simon (D-IL), Nancy Kassebaum (R-KA) and Richard Lugar (R-IN), and the chairman of the House Africa Subcommittee, Mervyn Dymally (D-CA). n


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


152 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 6, 1992


Fundamentalists Said to Favor Rights


LENGTH: 414 words


The images that many Americans hold about Islamic fundamentalism in Algeria are false, says Anwar Haddam, a member of the Islamic Salvation Front (FIS) who gained a seat in last year's parliamentary elections, which were aborted when the military-led ruling council took power in January.

The front is committed to allowing opposition parties, to tolerating other religions, and to guaranteeing the rights of women, he says. "The FIS puts the freedom to express opinions, form political parties, and hold elections as fundamental," he says. 

Haddam, who fled Algeria to avoid arrest, has been visiting the United States to press his party's case.

The FIS won the largest bloc of votes in round one of the parliamentary elections and was expected to win the second round as well, before the army suspended voting. Algerians are bitter about what has happened to them over the past six months, Haddam says. "People have the right to choose their own leaders."

Haddam criticizes the U.S. government for failing to condemn the January takeover and the subsequent crackdown on the FIS leadership. The seven top officials of the front are in detention, facing capital charges of insurrection.

"The U.S. denounced coups in other countries, the Soviet Union and Peru, for example," Haddam says. "Why, if the U.S. supports democracy in those places, do they not in the case of Algeria?" He also questions why the United States opposes the FIS but fails to criticize Saudi Arabia which "violates Islamic law and human rights and oppresses women."

He says he fears that "a new iron curtain " is being erected between the west and the Muslim world. "We don't want this," he says.

Asked about the assassination of Algerian head of state Mohamed Boudiaf, Haddam says the FIS "is not directly involved in violence" but does not condemn those "who will try to free our people." n


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


153 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 6, 1992


Boudiaf Assassination Clouds Algeria's Future


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

Mohamed Boudiaf had only a short tenure as Algerian head of state before he was gunned down on June 29, but the suspicions that arose immediately about his possible assassins indicate that he had an important impact during his six months in office.

The first assumption by most observers was that Boudiaf was killed by Islamic fundamentalists, who appeared poised to take power before Boudiaf agreed in January to head a five-man government created by the military following a bloodless coup d'etat. But some observers also pointed suspicion at elements within the long-serving military and civilian leadership who were discomfited by Boudiaf's recent moves to investigate and crack down on high-level corruption.

One of nine leaders of Algeria's revolt against French colonial rule in the late 1950s, Boudiaf had been in exile in Morocco for 28 years when he came home on January 16 to head the High State Council, which the military said would govern until 1993. Four days earlier, the military had forced President Chadli Bendjedid to resign to prevent him from going through with a second round of elections which almost certainly would have been won by the Islamic Salvation Front (FIS). The vote also would have produced Algeria's first multiparty parliament. 

Many regarded the 72-year-old Boudiaf as a figurehead for the military, valued because his long absence had left him untainted by the charges of corruption and human rights abuses that plague his former National Liberation Front (FLN) colleagues after their three decades of single-party rule. Boudiaf had fallen out with the FLN soon after Algeria won its independence from France in 1962 after an eight-year struggle. He accused the party of abandoning its commitment to democracy and was briefly jailed under a death sentence for his dissent.

The military's takeover was welcomed by some Algerians -- and by a number of Western governments, including the Bush administration -- who feared that the FIS would have established a radical Islamic state and, as some of the party's leaders had suggested, would have prevented the subsequent election of a secular government. But some of the democratic parties which had lost the first round of elections to the FIS in December protested the abortion of the electoral process, saying the FIS's popularity would only be dissipated when it was shown incapable of mending Algeria's frayed economy. After the ouster of Bendjedid, the FLN -- which won only 16 parliamentary seats -- joined the democratic opposition.

The FIS vowed to overturn the coup. "This regime is going to fall," FIS leader Abdelkader Hachani told his followers as the High Council took power. In June, the organization announced that its young members were going "underground" to wage armed struggle -- and to evade the security forces' manhunts.

The six months that Boudiaf led the government (also referred to as the collective presidency) were marked by constant FIS demonstrations and increasingly deadly armed exchanges between FIS militants and the military. On February 9, Boudiaf declared a state of emergency.

The government hunted down FIS leaders and rounded up thousands of the organization's members, sending them to detention camps in the Sahara. Only as the broiling desert heat of summer approached did the government yield to the demands of human rights organizations and begin releasing the detainees. In mid June a human rights leader appointed by Boudiaf said 4,000 detainees still remained in the camps; 3,000 had been released.

As the political crisis persisted, there were indications that Boudiaf was playing an increasingly dominant role in the council and that a "nonparty" movement was coalescing around him. Boudiaf then floated the idea of a "patriotic rally" to draw up new ideas for governing Algeria.

In April, the council appointed a 60-person "think tank" to draft a new constitution. And in early June, Boudiaf ignored the call of secular democratic parties to form a national unity government. Instead, he appealed to Algerians to join his 'rally', where he said political parties could conduct a dialogue as a prelude to a return to democracy. He refused to specify when the council would permit elections.

An economic reform program, begun by President Chadli Bendjedid in 1988 -- in the wake of riots that shook the nation -- and continued by the state council government, has not yet powered the economy out of its indebtedness and stagnancy. Creating jobs for the hundreds of thousands of young Algerians who cannot find work is regarded as essential by those who favor confronting the FIS at the ballot box. Sixty-five percent of the population is under 30, and a great majority of the jobless young turned to the FIS to bring dignity and meaning to their lives.

In May, Boudiaf gave his backing to a formal inquiry into alleged corruption by the FLN government. A former FLN prime minister has charged that $ 26 billion was siphoned from official funds between 1962 and 1989, and other high FLN figures, including President Bendjedid, a native of the region where Boudiaf was killed, have been accused of enriching themselves while in power. n


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


154 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 6, 1992


De Klerk's Image Takes a Tumble Abroad


LENGTH: 774 words


Washington, D.C.

by Reed Kramer

When dozens of people were massacred in Boipatong township near Johannesburg last month, the swift re-emergence of confrontation politics in South Africa was a shock to many people outside the country who had come to accept the certainty of apartheid's collapse.

But distrust between the white government and the opposition, led by the African National Congress (ANC), had been deepening, despite the progress made in formal negotiation sessions prior to a mid-May stalemate.

At the heart of the dispute is the continuation of the violence that has claimed so many black lives. A report released this month by the Human Rights Commission, a private South African group that has been highly critical of the government, identifies 49 massacres averaging 25 deaths each that have occurred since June 1990. That tally is in addition to more than 6,000 deaths in smaller-scale violent incidents. A detailed, 100-page study by Amnesty International accuses police and security forces of "complicity" in the killings. 

The recent dramatic changes in South Africa, beginning with the release of Nelson Mandela and the lifting of restrictions on the ANC and other anti-apartheid groups just over two years ago, have failed to improve the lives of the overwhelmingly poor black majority. That fact, plus the anguish caused by large-scale killing, means that the ANC is having an increasingly difficult time holding onto support from its political base in the black population.

In a memorandum to President F.W. de Klerk following the ANC's decision to suspend negotiations after the Boipatong massacre, ANC President Nelson Mandela blamed the crisis on the "direct and indirect involvement" of government forces in the violence.

The ANC claims to have evidence of a two-pronged government strategy to undermine the opposition during the transition from white rule. One prong, code named "Operation Springbok," is a complex plan to diminish political backing for the ANC, according to an article in the current issue of the official ANC journal, Mayibuye, which cites "sources within government circles."

The article says what places the plan beyond the bounds of acceptable political maneuvering is the second prong of the strategy, dubbed "Operation Thunderstorm," a carefully crafted scheme to spawn violence in black areas. "The unbanning of the ANC and the release of its leaders would then appear, in the eyes of blacks in particular, as the cause of their terrible suffering," the article says. It charges that the operations are directed by the Department of Military Intelligence, an arm of the defense force. The civilian-run National Intelligence Service is "informed" about the activities but is not operationally involved, Mayibuye says.

The world stature de Klerk attained when he freed Mandela and opened talks with the ANC has enabled the government to erode one of the ANC's chief sources of leverage -- the outside pressure that left South Africa isolated. Most sanctions have been lifted, de Klerk has been received around the world, and South African sports teams appear headed for the Olympics.

Now the government is on the defensive. The ANC is pressing demands for international investigators to monitor security force actions and is calling for an end to all covert military and police activities as preconditions for resumption of the negotiations.

De Klerk responded by leaving the door open on international observers -- something the government has opposed strenuously in the past -- and by dispatching Foreign Minister Roelof Botha to Nigeria for talks with President Ibrahim Babangida and the visiting United Nations secretary general, Boutros Boutros Ghali. n


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


155 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 6, 1992


Hope, Fear Mingle in Fractured South Africa


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 760 words


Johannesburg

by Tami Hultman

In the wake of the most publicized killings here in three decades and the government's forceful response to demands that it curb political violence, South Africans are expressing a mixture of fear that the situation is beyond redemption and hope that the crisis will jolt politicians to a speedy agreement on democratic reforms.

Two months ago, negotiators from 19 groups, including the government and the African National Congress (ANC), appeared on the verge of approving plans for a multiracial interim government to lead the country toward free elections. But deadlock at the table and atrocities in the streets have blocked an accord and fueled anger in black communities. 

"I think we are in for a period of unprecedented mass action, which we hope will fall short of uncontrolled violence," says Devan Pillay, editor of Work In Progress, an independent political journal.

Two factors are behind the current crisis. One has been the government's insistence on what the ANC and its allies see as a minority veto on future constitutional changes -- a device government opponents say would make a mockery of universal suffrage. The other is the steadily escalating violence in black communities. Although the massacre of more than 50 people in the nearby settlement of Boipatong received international attention, an average of ten South Africans are killed in political conflict every day.

While all sides are implicated in the violence, the weight of international opinion appears to be swinging behind charges that elements within the government are primary instigators and frequent participants in the conflicts between ANC supporters and followers of the Inkatha Freedom Party led by Mangosuthu Buthelezi. Recent reports blaming police and security forces have been issued by Amnesty International, the International Commission of Jurists, the Lawyers Committee for Civil Rights Under Law, and the U.S. State Department.

Among government opponents here, conviction is growing that the de Klerk government believed it could divide its enemies, and thus continue to dominate both the transitional administration and a future coalition government. If true, that belief has proven dangerously naive.

"The outside world sees de Klerk and his people as clever sophisticates," says one observer of the political scene. "I went to school with some of these guys in the cabinet, and I can tell you that they just don't know what is going on. They thought they could do an end run around the ANC and stay in power."

Veteran journalist Allister Sparks, in a July 1 column in the Johannesburg Star, argued that the government's plan to destabilize the ANC makes no sense: "What de Klerk and his colleagues have never understood, what they are too conditioned by their own past to grasp, is that the ANC is essentially a moderate organization, yet at the same time, one that is widely acceptable in the black community because of its record as the primary resistance movement and its long list of heroes and martyrs. That placed the ANC in the unique position of being able to carry a black community embittered by half a century of apartheid into a negotiated settlement."

Instead of sensibly harnessing that capability, Sparks wrote, de Klerk "has destabilized all of South Africa."

As Pillay sees it, unless the next few weeks produce significant evidence of the government's willingness to move toward real democracy, South Africa is likely to face an explosion of protest. n


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


156 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 6, 1992


Congo Takes Faltering First Steps Toward Democracy


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 507 words


Brazzaville, Congo

by Cindy Shiner

A year after a national democracy conference in Congo eased control of the country from President Denis Sassou-Nguesso and set the stage for an end to 30 years of one-party rule, voters have discovered that multiparty government is not without difficulties.

Legislative elections late last month were plagued by charges of wrongdoing, raising the likelihood that long-awaited presidential elections will be postponed.

"The election went very badly," says Blaise Loukelo, a 31-year-old voter. "There was too much cheating. In our precinct, if you wanted a ballot, they would tell you there weren't any." 

Pierre Fafard of Canada, one of a small number of foreign observers here for the June 24 vote, calls the legislative elections deplorable. Presidential voting, originally set for June but currently scheduled for July 19 and August 2, "could be delayed for months," he says.

Congo, with a population of 2.3 million, has about 1.3 million registered voters. Some 1,800 candidates are vying for 125 seats on the National Assembly, but final selection of assembly members is awaiting a second, run-off round which also has been delayed. Interior Minister Alphonse Nzoungou says that because of alleged irregularities, such as a lack of ballots and other voting materials, about 25 of the 800 polling stations here in the capital would have to repeat first-round voting. Some results in other places, such as Pointe Noire, the country's second largest city, were also annulled.

Roman Catholic Archbishop Ernest Kombo, the head of Congo's transitional legislature, said there was no explanation for the missing ballots that were reported at some polling stations. He promises an investigation and urged Congolese to remain peaceful "so that we have the time to work calmly."

The government of Prime Minister Andre Milongo publicly acknowledged fraud in May's municipal elections, and six mayors and nine regional prefects subsequently were fired. The country's transitional legislature called on Milongo's government to resign. Instead, the prime minister reshuffled his government and pared it from 18 to ten members.

Fafard says it was premature to have the elections. "They lacked organization and planning." n


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


157 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 6, 1992


Drought Challenges Spirit in War-Torn Mozambique


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1467 words


 

Chibabava, Mozambique

by Ruth Aneah Ayisi

Squatting in front of their wattle and daub huts, women mechanically sort out "good" and "bad" strands of grass. Then they put the good strands into pots of water boiling on log fires.

The women and their children, many with swollen stomachs and spindly legs, seem to have no real interest in what is to be their only meal for the day. The community's few remaining men are old and despondent.

"I have had no food to eat for two weeks," says Chilente Simango, a grandfather of seven, who is now living in a government-controlled accommodation center in Chibabava, in the central province of Sofala. "We're having to eat like wild animals in the bush." 

The drought that has burned crops in many countries throughout southern Africa has struck a stinging blow to Mozambique, where a war between the government and the rebels of the Mozambique National Resistance (Renamo) has driven tens of thousands of peasants off their land. Even before the drought, half of the country's 16 million people were dependent on foreign food aid for their survival.

For an old man like Simango, the drought may have destroyed hope of survival. His long life has seen too many tragedies. His frail body matches his frail spirits as he speaks of his loneliness: "The war has separated me from my family. I do not know where any of them are or who is alive or dead. The rebels did not take me, because I am too old."

Despite the sense of hopelessness in this community, a nurse is busily treating the severely malnourished children. "We still have milk, oil and sugar for them," she says. "I think they will recover if more food aid is sent soon."

Donor agencies have responded positively to past emergency appeals from the government, but the task of delivering the food to the needy is another hurdle to overcome. Food aid sometimes arrives late or is stolen by hungry soldiers. The government says it is cracking down on such abuses.

The war is also causing many needy communities to become increasingly difficult and costly to reach. Chibabava, for example, is only accessible by air. Rugged brush land controlled by Renamo surrounds the lonely district.

In the southern province of Gaza, a recently burned-out convoy which was carrying maize for a hungry community is a silent symbol of the cruel reality of war. Government soldiers say the convoy hit one of the many land mines hidden in the sandy road. Reaching the burned trucks involved walking single file behind young troops who tested the way ahead. The villagers, however, never have this protection, as evidenced by the high number of people with missing limbs.

Mozambique is a country with the potential to feed all its people, but according to many estimates, it is the poorest nation in the world. The conflict has cost the lives of a million people and has forced another million to flee to neighboring countries.

The drought has already caused thousands to die of hunger and thirst, and estimates predict that at least one million people will become dependent on food aid. In the interior of the southern province of Inhambane, women must walk for a whole day just to get to the few gallons of water they need for their families. Then they must sleep overnight and walk for another day to bring the water home.

The drought also has caused an increase in salt levels in existing sources of fresh water. Greg Keast, a water and sanitation project officer for the United Nations Children's Fund, visited districts in Inhambane where some families are forced to drink salty water. "I drank some of it myself," says Keast. "It's almost like drinking sea water. It's too salty for any kind of irrigation. There's no plant that can take that sort of water. In fact, it's too salty in most cases for cooking. It can only be used for drinking. And drinking salty water means not quenching your thirst."

In Chimundzi, another village in Inhambane, 13 children died of starvation or hunger-related diseases, according to a report in June by Mozambique's national news agency AIM. The village chairman, Andre Mazive, told AIM that unless urgent measures are taken, many more of Chimundzi's 3,500 residents will die. Like the Chibabava residents, some of the children who died were forced to eat things they would not usually dream of consuming. "They had to eat something to deceive their stomachs," says Mazive.

What has become obvious is the ability of Mozambicans to battle on to the end -- even if it means eating grass. Health workers in many isolated districts work tirelessly to save the lives of children. And they carry their work out at a risk. Viewed as collaborators with the ruling Mozambique Liberation Front, some health workers have been massacred and others kidnapped by the rebels.

Peasant farmers have also learned to live with the threat of attacks and adapt their lives. Elisa Nhangane, an elderly widow living in Marrecuene, a rural district in the southern province of Maputo, is determined to push ahead. In previous years, Nhangane enjoyed bumper harvests, but this year the drought has destroyed most of her crops. The sweet potatoes and cassava survived but were stolen.

Unlike Chibabava, Nhangane's community is not cut off. Only 28 miles (45 kilometers) from Mozambique's capital, Maputo, residents there can still carve out a living -- even against tremendous odds. "I'm still managing to keep alive after all these years," says Nhangane. "But this year the security situation is the worst. I hear people saying that someone was killed there or another kidnapped. I became frightened, so now I sleep in the bush at night."

The war has intensified in many areas of this vast and sparsely populated country, despite the fact that President Joaquim Chissano's government is planning for peace -- the only real solution for Mozambique. But an end to the conflict will begin another emergency situation -- that of rebuilding the nation and providing food assistance to peasant farmers returning to their lands.

The challenges of lasting peace are great. A new nonpartisan army will have to be formed, and many disillusioned soldiers demobilized. They will need jobs or some kind of compensation. Renamo's army, many of whom are just children under the age of 16 and accustomed to violence as a way of life, will be particularly difficult to integrate into society.

Already, the social fabric of society has been ripped apart, as families like Simango's have splintered. The urban crime rate in recent years has soared as arms circulate out of control.

Hopes for peace have been dashed repeatedly in the past two years, since direct negotiations began in Rome between the Mozambican government and Renamo rebels. Much of the blame has been put at the feet of Renamo, an organization with a reputation among many for mutilations and grisly massacres. And analysts say that Renamo's leader, Alfonso Dhlakama, is having difficulty in transforming his movement from a military one to a political one.

The hope for peace is what gives most people like Nhangane the will to battle on. "I have been following the peace talks on the radio," she says. "I feel confident that peace will come here. I know some day the drought and the war will end." n


LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1992


LANGUAGE: English

159 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 20, 1992


Farewell to Arms


LENGTH: 414 words


A truce has been agreed in Rwanda between the rebel Rwandan Patriotic Front (RPF) and government troops, following successful peace talks in Arusha, Tanzania.

A full cease-fire will take effect July 31 and will be monitored by military observers from Nigeria, Senegal and Zimbabwe under the supervision of a rebel/government commission, according to a communique issued at the conclusion of four days of talks earlier this month.

Besides agreeing to stop fighting, the two sides also decided that the Rwandan army will absorb RPF fighters, and they jointly called for the withdrawal of foreign troops from the country. The rebels have charged the government received help in the civil war from 300 soldiers France sent to Rwanda ostensibly to protect its citizens there. The government has charged the rebels received help from Uganda, from which the RPF invaded in October 1990 with a force mostly drawn from deserters from that country's army. 

A March 29 cease-fire was broken within days, but diplomats at the talks said the government has several compelling reasons to make the current agreement work: the cost of an army that has quadrupled in size since the rebels invaded; the dislocation of 250,000 people and the disruption of food transport routes in the north due to fighting; and pressure from Uganda, the Organization of African Unity, former colonial ruler Belgium, France and the United States, all of which sent observers to the talks.

The government and rebels are scheduled to meet August 10 to develop a comprehensive peace plan by October 10. That plan would include a role for the RPF in the government and an agreement on the demand of the Tutsi-dominated RPF that about 500,000 members of that ethnic group be allowed to return home from exile in Burundi, Tanzania, Uganda and Zaire.

Tutsis, who make up about 15 percent of Rwanda's population, ruled the country until an uprising by the majority Hutus in the late 50s. Many Tutsis left Rwanda after about 100,000 were massacred in the early 1960s.


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


160 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 20, 1992


Judgment or Mercy?


LENGTH: 360 words


Algeria stands braced for violence after two leaders of the militant Islamic Salvation Front (FIS) were each sentenced to 12 years in prison on July 15, following a trial called the most important since the country's independence.

But there are expectations that government concessions may avert further bloodshed in the wake of the June 29 assassination of President Mohammed Boudiaf and FIS attacks that have killed more than 100 police and soldiers since the party was banned in March. 

An FIS statement circulated before the sentencing of Front President Abassi Madani and Deputy Ali Belhadj warned the court that it would be held responsible for its judgment.

But the government made several conciliatory moves. Madani and Belhadj had originally faced death if convicted of being behind June 1991 riots in which at least 55 people died. Though the courts have sentenced 26 Islamic militants to death since May, the prosecutor sought in the Madani and Belhadj case only life sentences, and the terms the two received were much lighter.

Five other FIS members, convicted of undermining the economy during a strike that preceded the riot, received relatively short sentences of four to six years.

But the court did not budge in its decision to bar foreign journalists, human rights observers and lawyers from attending the trial, held before a military tribunal. The defendants and their attorneys boycotted the trial because of the ban.

The FIS had warned in circulars that if the seven were tried at all their supporters would take up arms.


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


161 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 20, 1992


Walking Papers


LENGTH: 294 words


For the second time in two months, Comoros President Said Mohamed Djohar has dismissed the government of the three-island nation.

The first dimissal came in May, after allegations that government members, including presidential son-in-law, Mohamed Said Abdallah -- minister of the economy, finance, trade, planning and the budget -- were involved in a financial scandal. 

Following the reinstatement of Abdallah and other ministers, this month Djohar again dismissed them, accusing Prime Minister Mohamed Taki Abdoulkarim of appointing a former mercenary, Patrick Klein, as special advisor on foreign relations.

Klein was one of a group of French mercenaries who brought former President Ahmed Abdallah to power in a 1978 coup and then orchestrated his assassination in 1989. After Abdallah's death, Djohar, then president of the Supreme Court, took over as acting head of state.

Djohar was elected president in 1990, in the first elections since the Indian Ocean islands gained independence from France in 1975. Taki, Djohar's main opponent, charged that the vote was rigged. Since his election, Djohar has clung to power through a bloodless coup attempt and defections among his own supporters. He appointed Taki prime minister in January, when he formed a government of national unity in preparation for new elections.


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


162 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 20, 1992


Missing?


LENGTH: 534 words


Pro-democracy activist Chakufwa Chihana's release earlier this month in Malawi led some to believe "President for Life" Kamuzu Banda was bending to Western pressure to improve his human rights record.

But three days after Chihana was finally charged with sedition and freed on $ 2,400 bail, he was back in police custody after reporting, as required, to a police station in the capital city of Lilongwe. Chihana was told security officers had orders to take him to Zomba, a city 190 miles (300 km) south. 

According to a July 15 Reuters news agency report, he has not been seen since, and a police officer in Zomba said there has been no sign of Chihana. Reuters also reports that large crowds gathered outside the magistrate's court in Zomba, where Chihana was charged on July 13, but the report does not say if Chihana was actually seen. "We don't know where he is," a Malawi attorney told Reuters.

"There has been much distortion of the facts concerning Chakufwa Chihana's case by the dissidents outside the country," Banda said in an Independence Day speech broadcast on Malawi Radio July 5, six days before the activist's release and re-arrest. "His case is not one of detention without trial at all. He will be appropriately tried and charged in an open court soon. I have given instructions that all subsequent detainees should be charged and tried in an open court."

Many had interpreted Banda's words as a response to a donors suspension in mid May of $ 74 million in new non-humanitarian aid, pending a change in the way Malawi approached basic freedoms and human rights.

Chihana, chairman of the recently formed Interim Committee for a Democratic Alliance, was the first political detainee to be released on bail under Banda, who has ruled Malawi since independence in 1964. On the same day, the government released ten other political prisoners, including a former Cabinet minister and secretary-general of the ruling Malawi Congress Party held for ten years without trial.

Chihana faces five years in prison if he is convicted of importing seditious publications and preparing an act with seditious intent, his lawyer says. The activist was originally arrested April 6 as he stepped off the plane at the Lilongwe airport. Police took him away as he tried to deliver a speech calling for a mutliparty system.

Chihana's detention has drawn Malawians into the streets. When police failed to produce him for a hearing in mid May, thousands chanted his name outside a Lilongwe courtroom.


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


163 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 20, 1992


Making Peace


LENGTH: 280 words


Western and United Nations diplomats have been visiting southern Ethiopia to mediate a conflict between the Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front (EPRDF) and the Oromo Liberation Front (OLF), which pulled out of the country's interim government in June.

The southern-based OLF withdrew its ministers from the EPRDF-led government and boycotted June 21 regional elections. 

Some 15,000 OLF fighters have left camps they entered under a peace agreement in the spring, and OLF attacks on traffic along roads in the south have intensified. Four people, including a police chief, were killed when the OLF ambushed a bus in the southwest town of Bale earlier this month.

The diplomats are trying to persuade OLF Secretary-General Galaso Dilbo, who says his organization has started a guerrilla war, to go to Addis Ababa, the Ethiopian capital, for negotiations with the government.

Headed by President Meles Zenawi, the governing coalition was formed after the EPRDF overthrew President Mengistu Haile Mariam in May 1991. The OLF, which represents Ethiopia's largest ethnic group, was given positions in the government. But the OLF says it wants greater representation for the Oromos, who make up about a third of the country's population. It also accuses the EPRDF of harassing, detaining and assassinating its members.


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


164 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 20, 1992


Back to the Bush


LENGTH: 307 words


The Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) has retreated into the bush following the fall of its headquarters to troops of military ruler Omar Hassan Ahmad Al-Bashir.

Sudanese radio announced July 14 that government forces had captured the SPLA stronghold, the southern town of Torit, and called on Popular Defense Forces (PDF) reservists and recruits to assemble for transport to the war zone. 

"Torit has now joined the liberated areas of the homeland with the national banners flying high," Al-Bashir said during the broadcast.

The rebels say they do not need to hold towns in order to continue fighting, and an SPLA spokesman describes the loss of Torit, the last major town held by the main faction of the rebels, as a "tactical withdrawal."

John Garang, the leader of the SPLA's main faction, has reportedly moved his headquarters to Kajo-Kaji, across the Nile from Torit.

The southern-based SPLA wants self-determination for the region, inhabited mainly by Christians and animists. The government, based in the mostly Muslim Arabic-speaking north, has offered the south autonomy within a federal system and exemption from Sharia, or Islamic law, for non-Muslim areas. This stops short of the SPLA demand for a referendum on whether the region will remain part of Sudan.

Peace talks in early June in Abuja, the capital of Nigeria, produced nothing but an agreement by the two sides to meet again.


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


165 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 20, 1992


Difficult Transition


SECTION: DATELINE AFRICA


LENGTH: 454 words


President Gnassingbe Eyadema of Togo has been meeting since June with opposition leaders in response to a wave of violence against government opponents that has forced postponement of multiparty elections.

But the violence continues, and some are placing blame on Eyadema's main backer, the army.

On July 10, a grenade explosion in the capital of Lome destroyed a platform for a memorial service to honor one of four men killed during a May 5 attack which wounded opposition leader Gilchrist Olympio. No one was injured, since the explosion took place before people assembled. 

Witnesses say they saw soldiers in a black Mercedes without license plates near the former parliament building where the platform was erected.

President Eyadema went on state television to condemn the grenade attack and other acts of violence. He said unexploded grenades left at the scene were of a type made in Russia and not used by the Togolese army.

A report released this month by the Paris-based International Federation of Human Rights says the army is implicated in the May 5 assassination attempt.

The attackers used army weapons and vehicles and were led by an officer of a paratroop regiment based nearby, the report says. Eyadema's son, army Capt. Ernest Eyadema, was in the area just before the ambush, according to the report. The younger Eyadema denies that the military carried out the attack.

The president, who has ruled the country for 21 years, was stripped of much of his authority a year ago, when a national conference appointed reformer Joseph Kokou Koffigoh as prime minister to lead a transition to democracy. But Eyadema continues to wield power, largely because of his influence over the army, which in December shelled Koffigoh's residence and seized the prime minister, releasing him only after he appointed three Eyadema supporters to his cabinet.

Koffigoh said this month that he will not run for president because he wants to shift attention away from himself and toward the country's political transition. Presidential elections, once scheduled for August, are now tentatively scheduled for late this year or early 1993.


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


166 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 20, 1992


Mandela: 'We Cannot Accept an Undemocratic Constitution' Highlights from Nelson Mandela's July 4 response.


LENGTH: 1000 words


I have received the response of Mr. F.W. De Klerk to a memorandum which I addressed to him on the 26th June, 1992. I enclosed the statement of the emergency meeting of the National Executive Committee of the ANC adopted on the 23rd June, 1992.

In my memorandum and the statement of the ANC we pointed out that South Africa is on the brink of disaster for which we hold the NP (National Party) government entirely responsible. Specific and concrete demands were made to Mr. F.W. de Klerk as a means of finding a way out of the impasse. These demands related to two crucial aspects:

Firstly, the deadlock in the negotiating process because of the refusal by the NP government to move together with all of us in the process of truly democratizing South Africa. Our fundamental position in this regard is that we cannot accept an undemocratic constitution aimed at addressing the fears of a minority party about its own future at the cost of democracy. 

This is at the root of the negotiations deadlock. It is for this reason that we focussed attention on the Constituent Assembly. We are clear in our demands that the NP government abandon positions directed at subverting the sovereignty of the Constituent Assembly, which include subjecting it to a veto by a second house and ensuring that a minority in the Constituent Assembly shall be able to frustrate an overwhelming majority.

Secondly, with regards to the violence in our country, our demands centered on three aspects:

* Ensuring that the direct and indirect involvement of the NP government, it's surrogates, the security forces and police are brought to an end forthwith.

* Ensuring that the de Klerk government immediately implement agreements reached with the ANC more than a year ago on curbing violence.

* The establishment of an international commission of inquiry into the Boipatong massacre and all acts of violence as well as the international monitoring of violence.

In communicating with Mr. F.W. de klerk, we made it crystal clear that "(his) response and practical steps ... to these demands will play a crucial role in determining the direction and speed with which bona fide negotiations can take place."

He has chosen to ignore the gravity of these demands. He seeks to channel them into endless negotiations and discussions. In particular, the content of his reply seeks to elevate government to a legitimate and credible force standing above the crisis. This is part of the deliberate attempts to perpetuate the notion of "black on black" violence rather than draw attention to the central role of the de Klerk government and its security forces.

He tries to enhance this position by calling for a meeting between Dr. Buthelezi and myself at which Mr. F.W. de Klerk and his government will participate "in view of it's (i.e. the de Klerk government's) responsibility for the maintenance of law and order." He persists in shielding his regime behind the back of the government-supported IFP (Inkatha Freedom Party). Government covert and open support for the IFP has been confirmed in numerous instances. These include the Second Interim Report of the Goldstone Commission, the International Commission of Jurists fact finding mission and the Amnesty International report.

De Klerk's memorandum, and his state of the nation address on 2 July, 1992, are characterized by a threatening mode and a propensity toward repression. He assumes the legitimacy of the existing order and his government. He appears also to believe that the military power that his government commands can be a means of resolving the conflict. This was demonstrated when Mr. de Klerk attempted to visit Boipatong, where the people in the township demonstrated their anger and revulsion. Shaken by this overwhelming rejection, at a press conference held immediately thereafter, he threatened to return the country to the old style repression of the P.W. Botha regime by raising the possibility of the re-imposition of the state of emergency.

We have sought to ensure that the de Klerk regime responds to our demands positively and undertakes practical steps.
