We have done so with the clear knowledge that the longer it takes to find a way out of the current impasse the more difficult it will be to reach agreement and the more difficult it will be to ensure peace and stability in the future. If he shared this commitment, there is nothing in our demands that he could have not addressed practically and immediately. His response has failed to address the crucial issues. It is riddled with factual inaccuracies, distortions and blatant party political propaganda. It confirms the fundamental feature of our society that he and his government want to be both player and referee. By responding in the manner he has done, Mr. F.W. de Klerk has chosen to drive South Africa into a collision course. I accordingly see no reason to mislead the public and the international community about the gravity of the crisis facing our country. No good purpose will be served in my meeting him at this stage.-30-


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


167 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 20, 1992


De Klerk: 'Insurrectionist Thinking' Threatens Peace Excerpts from President de Klerk's July 2 memorandum to Nelson Mandela.


LENGTH: 1667 words


I acknowledge receipt of your memorandum dated 26 June 1992. However, an exchange of memoranda is no substitute for face-to-face talks. I was therefore disappointed that you did not accept my invitation to immediate discussions. Every day that is lost will make the resumption of the process more difficult and may lead to the loss of further lives.

Annexures A-F contain observations relevant to issues raised in your memorandum and elaborations on issues dealt with in this letter. There are however a number of fundamental issues which need to be addressed urgently at a meeting between us.

Violence

Contrary to the ANC's accusations, the government has not, and will not plan, conduct , orchestrate or sponsor violence in any form whatsoever against any political organization or community. The lie that the government is sponsoring and promoting violence remains a lie no matter how often it is repeated. Where elements in state structures err in this regard, the government will not hesitate to take appropriate measures. There are prosecutions and convictions on record to prove this. 

The second interim report of the Goldstone Commission showed that the causes of violence are numerous and complicated. The fact remains that most political violence occurs between supporters of the ANC (African National Congress) and the IFP (Inkatha Freedom Party). This question must therefore be urgently addressed by leaders of the ANC and the IFP, and by the government, in view of its responsibility for the maintenance of order. I therefore propose that you, Dr. Buthelezi and I meet as soon as possible for this purpose. The agenda for this meeting could be to consider:

* an active full-time monitoring mechanism on the adequacy, efficacy and performance of all the instruments and processes already in place to combat violence and intimidation; and

* the advisability of a joint monitoring body through which the three parties could act to defuse and solve problems that could give rise to violence. The role of the international community in an observer capacity could be considered, especially in relation to this item.

The ANC's Mass Mobilization

The South African government acknowledges the right of peaceful demonstration and protest as important civil liberties. However, the ANC alliance's campaign of mass mobilization, owing to its nature and aims, poses serious threats to the stability and safety of the whole of South African society, particularly in the current volatile climate.

Furthermore, the use of this kind of mass mobilization to make and impose demands in the negotiation process is just as unacceptable as the use of violence for this purpose. Our information indicates that the SACP (South African Communist Party) and Cosatu (Congress of South African Trade Unions) have played a dominant role in redirecting the ANC from negotiations to the politics of demands and confrontation which are inherent in mass mobilization.

Insurrectionist thinking is currently flourishing within the ANC and is being propagated by a cabal with close links to the SACP and Cosatu. These elements undermine the attempts of many ANC realists to negotiate in good faith and also induce within the ANC the spirit of radicalism and militancy of the insurrectionist school, which was evident at the SACP's eighth congress in 1991.

The ANC/SACP have been trying to create the impression that they and the South African government are the only adversaries. This is patently misleading and wrong since there are numerous players on the South African political scene, each with its own identity but opposed to ANC/SACP policies and methods. The ANC's rhetoric has been radicalized and is now virtually indistinguishable from that of the SACP, and so are the ultimatum and polarization politics now being conducted. In recent days this rhetoric has degenerated into incitement to violence and hatred at (the) grass-roots level.

The current mobilization action can unleash forces which the instigators will not be able to control. This will, in turn, make extended government action unavoidable. The program of mass mobilization, in the prevailing circumstances, will inevitably:

* lead to further violence;

* delay the search for democratic solutions;

* damage the economy, on which all South Africans depend; and

* seriously disrupt social services to the detriment of those in need of medical care, protection, support and education.

The ANC'S Aborting of the Negotiation Process

You say that you have withdrawn from the negotiating process because of the government's involvement in violence and its lack of commitment to genuine democracy in the negotiating process. Your allegations about government involvement in violence have already been dealt with.

With regard to your allegations concerning the government's commitment to genuine democracy, I should like to refer you to the substantial agreements already reached in the working groups of Codesa (Congress for a Democratic South Africa). The fundamental difference between the approach of the ANC and that of the government regarding the purpose of negotiations lies, on the one hand, in our commitment to constitutionality and a transitional government as soon as possible; and on the other hand, in the ANC's insistence on an unstructured and immediate transfer of power before a proper transitional constitution is negotiated.

Even after Codesa 2, our approach to transitional arrangements was again explained to ANC representatives. Our proposals are in line with universally accepted democratic principles. A summary of our approach can be found in Annexure "F," and in Annexure "B" allegations that the government is clinging to power are conclusively refuted.

Once again, the remaining differences between the ANC, the government and the other political parties on key constitutional questions make multiparty negotiations more -- and not less -- imperative.

ANC "Demands"

In our view what you are presenting as demands are issues that are being tailored by the ANC to support its program of mass mobilization and to justify the abortion of the negotiation process. All these issues could have been suitably discussed at the negotiation table, and it is imperative that such discussions do take place to remove any misconceptions and misunderstanding. It should be recorded that some of these have already been dealt with by governmental measures. Annexure "E" contains observations in this respect.

However we would like to comment in particular on the hostels and dangerous weapons.

The problems relating to the hostels have been the focus of much concern and attention, but as you are aware, it is an extremely complex situation and although extensive deliberations and consultations have already taken place, much work remains to be done. This is therefore an issue that we would like to be given particular attention at our proposed meeting.

As regards dangerous weapons, weaponry and explosives, measures have been taken and adopted regarding the carrying and possession thereof. These measures will be strictly enforced. Further regulations about the possession and carrying of dangerous weapons are currently under consideration.

The carrying and possession of dangerous weapons should receive attention when we meet, but particular attention must be given to the implementation of measures relating to the illegal possession of firearms and explosives and the introduction of such weapons into the country. The AK47 has become the symbol of political and criminal violence, and firearms are the weapons mainly used to kill political opponents and to perpetrate criminal violence. Ways and means must be found to ensure that this problem is resolved, and we must discuss this issue when the leaders of the government, the ANC and the IFP meet. Until now this question has been dealt with bilaterally, but it has become such an integral part of the problem of violence that it can no longer remain solely on a bilateral agenda.

I reiterate the government's commitment to peaceful negotiations as the only way to bring us to a new democratic constitution as soon as possible. I repeat my proposal that we should met urgently for fundamental discussions, especially on the above mentioned four issues.-30-


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


168 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 20, 1992


South Africans Move Toward the Brink


SECTION: DOSSIER:


LENGTH: 454 words


After trading accusations in a mid-June United Nations Security Council debate, the South African government and Nelson Mandela's African National Congress (ANC) have resumed their face-off at home, leaving negotiations over the country's future hanging in the balance.

Mandela won agreement for a UN role monitoring the increasingly deadly violence, and he has received other concessions from President F.W. de Klerk, including a pledge to disband three controversial security units that have been accused of instigating anti-ANC attacks. De Klerk also repeated an earlier promise to increase security at migrant workers' hostels in black townships, which have been a major locus of confrontation between pro-ANC township residents and hostel dwellers loyal to Mangosothu Buthelezi's Inkatha Freedom Party. 

The ANC rejected de Klerk's offers as meaningless. Mandela says the controversial troops, for example, will simply be incorporated into other sections of the police or army.

The suspension in negotiations which followed last month's massacre of more than 40 people in the Boipatong township prompted a new exchange of public statements between de Klerk and Mandela. De Klerk's July 2 memorandum contained a gesture apparently designed to persuade the ANC to resume talking, although it was contained near the end of 31 pages of a lengthy and bitter attack on the ANC's approach, in the last of six appendices.

The president offered to reduce from 75% to 70% the majority needed to approve constitutional change. When negotiations bogged down in mid May over this provision, the ANC offered 70% as a last-ditch compromise between what it regarded as the government's excessively high demand, giving whites a veto over future change, and the two-thirds that many constitutions around the world require. But after the ANC offer was rejected, a special ANC congress reaffirmed 66% as the formal negotiating stance, and Mandela lost his maneuvering room on this issue.

As the confrontation continues, some observers fear that other opportunities for agreement are being forfeited. But both sides remain committed to negotiations in principal.


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


169 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 20, 1992


People & Places


SECTION: BRIEFING:


LENGTH: 614 words


Not Ready for Prime Time? You'll notice that Africa is generally missing when world affairs and trends are discussed publicly. For example, Jeane Kirkpatrick's syndicated column in the July 13 Washington Post. She wrote: "Democracies have multiplied so rapidly in Latin America, Central and Eastern Europe and into Asia that it is tempting to see this as an inevitable historical development." And when was the last time you heard a presidential candidate -- or president -- asked about Africa? Or heard any of the talk show pundits muse about an African issue? But Africa's democracy movement finally made prime time this month with Jesse Jackson's address to the Democratic National Convention. Jackson mentioned the democratic tide sweeping Africa as a sign of hope that must be sustained. 

Is change in the air (waves)? National Public Radio has scheduled a series of reports on Africa's problems and possibilities in an era of democracy. Scheduled to air the week of July 27, the series will include reports by Africa News Service. The project is the brainchild of Foreign Editor Codi Simon and "All Things Considered" Executive Producer Ellen Weiss. During that same week, NBC crews from "Today" will be fanning across the continent to do preliminary work for six days of live broadcasts from Africa that will air in November. Show co-host Bryant Gumbel will anchor the series from Harare, Zimbabwe. Stay tuned.

New Kids on the Block. The New York Times and the Washington Post have appointed new correspondents to South Africa at a time of unprecedented political ferment there. Bill Kellor of the Times and Paul Taylor of the Post are regarded as rising stars at their respective papers. They replace Christopher Wrenn who is going to the Times Moscow bureau, and David Ottaway, who served four tours in Africa and will be posted to Vienna.

Assignments Changed. Bernadette Paola has been promoted to the post of staff director at the House Subcommittee on Africa by Rep. Mervyn Dymally (D-CA), the chairman. Dymally's plan to name Walter Carrington was thwarted by a hiring freeze. Adonis Hoffman, the former director, remains a consultant to the subcommittee.

African American Institute President Vivian Lowery Derryck has announced the selection of Steve McDonald as executive vice president, the number two position at the New York-based organization. McDonald has been administrator of the Aspen Institute's Southern African Policy Forum. McDonald previously headed the United States-South Africa Leader Exchange Program and served as a U.S. foreign service officer in Uganda and South Africa.

Prize Winners. This year's recipients of African Prize for Leadership for the Sustainable End to Hunger are Graca Machel, president of the National Organization of Children of Mozambique, and Ebrahim Samba, a Gambian doctor directing a region-wide effort to eradicate river blindness. Machel, a former minister of education, is also the widow of Mozambique's first president, Samora Machel. Samba heads the Onchocerciasis Control Program. The winners share a $ 100,000 award.-30-


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


170 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 20, 1992


Is It Really Possible to Rank Countries by Their Magnitude of Suffering?


SECTION: LETTERS


LENGTH: 654 words


 

In the May 25, 1992 issue of AfricaNews, you published some results of the International Human Suffering Index , a study by the Population Crisis Committee. While the study is interesting and perhaps even important, one must be very careful when interpreting its results.

Since countries differ a great deal in their features, most cross-sectional studies that involve many countries are misleading. They are done mainly because they lend themselves to expediency and are marketable -- and because we live in an era of fascination with data, scores and rankings. (The fascination with ranking peaks every Olympic year!) 

While the study at hand may indeed suggest something -- levels of economic development , for example -- it is inaccurate to cast it under the label International Human Suffering Index.

First, what constitutes suffering? It is inappropriate to use the same criteria for all countries. In some societies, suffering would be measured in terms of, among other indicators, the divorce rate, suicide rate, drug use, abortion rate, the number of people you know in the immediate community (i.e., a loneliness factor -- the fewer the people, the higher the suffering index), the number of children per family (the lower the number, the higher the suffering index!), etc.

A second problem, related to the first, is how one arrives at the measures for various criteria. Life expectancy, for example, presumably is used to measure the fullness of life. Yet someone in Africa or Asia may be considered to have lived a full life by the members of his or her society if he or she lived long enough to see grandchildren and great grandchildren. This may be accomplished in 60 years or even less in these societies. Of course, it may be that the factors that cause someone to live for only 60 years instead of 76 do give rise to suffering; I do not denigrate the importance of working to improve life expectancy. My point is that it is misleading to use such statistics as a measure of human suffering.

Third, even if we agree on the criteria and they were applicable to all countries, it would be wrong to give them equal weight in different countries. For example, an inflation rate of 10% in a country whose economy is fully monetarized (i.e., where almost all goods and services enter commercial channels), is not the same as inflation at the same rate in a country where a substantial part of output does not enter commercial channels. Likewise, two countries with the same per capita GNP may have very different income distribution patterns. Another example: communications technology in one society may be a necessity, while it may be merely a luxury or even useless in another (where its absence certainly does not give rise to the "suffering" another society may experience in its absence).

Fourth, even if the study were for a single country, it would be wrong to give each criterion the same weight. In a measure of suffering, how can communications technology -- in any country -- be given the same weight as the availability of food? Richard E. Mshomba Assistant Professor of Economics La Salle University


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


171 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 20, 1992


World Response to Suffering in Somalia, Sarajevo Differ


LENGTH: 1134 words


Hazel M. McFerson

As an American who has lived, worked and traveled throughout Africa, particularly in the Horn, I am dismayed by the double standard evident in the contrasting responses of the world community to the tragedies of Somalia and Sarajevo.

News that the United States has dispatched six warships to the Adriatic Sea in response to the conflict in Yugoslavia underscores the differences. There is a disturbing lack of urgency in the world's response to the Somalia crisis. While the West musters military force to deliver humanitarian assistance to the 400,000 residents of Sarajevo, millions of Somalis are ignored. 

Serbian nationalists opposed to Bosnia's secession from Yugoslavia have bombarded Bosnia and Herzegovina with heavy artillery for 12 weeks. But in Somalia, competing forces in Mogadishu have subjected civilians to severe heavy artillery and aerial shelling for over seven months. This follows years of famine and a long civil war against the country's former dictator, Mohamed Siad Barre, who was ousted in January 1991.

An estimated 50,000 Somalis have been killed or gravely injured since last December. Hundreds of children are dying every week. Reports say that 4.5 million Somalis are at risk from hunger and disease.

Somalis are fleeing their country every day, and many arrive at refugee camps in Kenya with wounds that have gone untended. Recently, a mercy boat arrived at one camp carrying 280 starving Somalis, mostly women and children. One woman had severe burns caused by a bomb. Another woman was bleeding from a miscarriage caused by soldiers in Somalia who beat, kicked and robbed her. Somalis in the poorly administered refugee camps are dying of respiratory infections, malnutrition and diarrhea. An inadequate water supply is also a major problem in the semi-desert areas where the camps are located. Other Somalis, sick and near death, are descending in boats upon neighboring Yemen, which does not have the resources to care for them.

The international community has been slow to respond to Somalia's humanitarian needs, even though Somali factions signed their eleventh cease-fire agreement on March 3. As early as last December, UN relief organizations were mired in controversy about war and humanitarianism in Somalia.

UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali expressed interest in UN mediation of the conflict, but became preoccupied with equally pressing issues elsewhere. The Organization of African Unity condemned the fighting, although it took Secretary-General Salim Salim more than a month to offer to mediate. UN Undersecretary-General James O.C. Jonah made a hasty visit to Mogadishu from the safety of Nairobi, where the majority of relief organizations also waited for the conflict to cool down. The UN evacuated its foreign staff from Mogadishu in January, and until very recently, prevented staff from going back because the city is considered to be too dangerous. Food and medicines did not reach Somalia for close to six months. The delegate general for Africa of the International Committee of the Red Cross asked: "How come Unicef/Somalia has 13 people in Nairobi and no one inside Somalia?" The deputy director of the UN Development Program for Somalia, Mario Borsotti, replied that "in a situation of war, we don't operate."

The United States, a major ally of Somalia during the Cold War, has also declined to press for humanitarian intervention. AfricaNews, the New York Times and the Washington Post reported that the Bush administration derailed a UN Security Council's effort to send a 500-member peacekeeping force to Somalia to protect UN, Red Cross and other workers trying to deliver food and supplies to the suffering Somalis. John R. Bolton, U.S. assistant secretary of State, responded to the reports by saying that "the problem is that the key Somali parties have not agreed to the specifics of the guard force."

But recent headlines illustrate a different urgency in the West's attitudes toward humanitarianism and war in Sarajevo. Consider, for example, the ultimatum delivered by the UN Security Council reported recently in a banner headline in the New York Times: "Serbs Told to End Siege of Sarajevo or Risk UN Force." The combatants were warned that if they did not comply, the Security Council would "determine what ... means would be required" to deliver humanitarian relief. The Bush administration repeatedly has expressed indignation over the suffering in Sarajevo and has indicated a possible willingness to commit air and naval combat forces to escort relief convoys.

Before the blockade of Sarajevo was lifted, President Bush had initiated urgent and intensive consultations with allies about forming an international military coalition to break the blockade. Included within this coalition were nations which have been slow responding to humanitarian needs in Somalia: the United Kingdom, France, Germany, Italy and the Netherlands. French President Francois Mitterand felt so compelled to act that he undertook a personal mission to Sarajevo, even though UN military commanders warned that the mission was extremely dangerous.

One cannot help but wonder if the differing responses to war and humanitarianism in Somalia and Sarajevo are rooted in differences of pigmentation. Whether intended or not, the message is that European lives are more important than African lives, and responses to war and humanitarianism seem guided by this reality.-30-

Hazel M. McFerson is associate professor of conflict analysis and resolution and public affairs at George Mason University, Fairfax, VA. She was a social science analyst for the US Agency for International Development in Mogadishu, Somalia, from 1985-87.


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


172 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 20, 1992


Pressure On Rebels Could Stop Mozambique Killings


LENGTH: 1707 words


Janice McLaughlin

While the worst drought of the century threatens the lives of more than 3 million of Mozambique's 15 million people, peace talks aimed at ending 12 years of brutal civil war drag on without agreement, blocking deliveries of food and medical supplies.

The problem lies with the rebel movement known as the Mozambique National Resistance (Renamo), which continues to create excuses for delaying the discussions and refuses to sign a cease-fire accord. Established as a destabilization tool by the Rhodesian white regime in the 1970s, Renamo is known for widespread atrocities, seemingly pointless attacks on civilians, and the forced recruitment of child soldiers.

Sparked by war and drought, famine is spreading to large sections of the country. Experts say that unless food aid is able to reach the worst drought-stricken areas within the next few months, the scale of human suffering and death will exceed that of the Ethiopian famine of 1984, which stirred worldwide reaction. 

Yet Renamo continues to rebuff calls for a nationwide truce or for "corridors of peace" to allow food to reach those in need. When peace talks, which began in Rome two years ago, entered their eleventh round last month, Renamo startled negotiators by demanding renegotiation of issues previously agreed upon by both sides.

By contrast, Mozambican President Joaquim Chissano has made nearly every concession demanded by Renamo. During a visit to the United States earlier this month, he told me he was even willing to meet face-to-face with the Renamo leader, Afonso Dhlakama, if this would bring peace.

Chissano looks like a man who is suffering with his people. He speaks in poignant terms of the impact the drought is having and the effects of war, which Mozambicans have experienced almost non-stop since the early 1960s when the Mozambique Liberation Movement (Frelimo) launched its campaign to win independence from colonial Portugal.

Chissano says he fears that Dhlakama is only playing for time, as he tries to turn his ruthless military organization into a political party that can compete in the multiparty elections that are scheduled to be held one year after a cease-fire is signed. "He wants to use me to build himself up," Chissano says, referring to a possible meeting. But the president says he is willing to take this risk.

Chissano also expresses disappointment about the stance of the mediators in the Rome talks -- the Italian Roman Catholic lay community of Saint Egidio. Founded by 10 students in 1968, the order has grown to 15,000 members worldwide and has gained a reputation within Roman Catholic circles as a more liberal version of the larger and better known Opus Dei.

Members of the community first went to Mozambique just after independence in the mid-1970s at a time of considerable tension between the church and the government, which seized church-run schools and other properties in retaliation for the church's history of ties to the Portuguese colonial authorities.

When church leaders in Mozambique offered to attempt the mediation effort a few years ago, the government accepted, believing the intervention might succeed since the church could not be seen by Renamo as having a pro-government bias.

But as talks continue without producing a settlement, dissatisfaction with the mediators has grown. In the view of some observers, the mediators have failed to press Renamo, which has repeatedly stalled the proceedings by not appearing for scheduled sessions and by introducing last-minute agenda changes.

Renamo also violated the partial cease-fire, signed in December 1990, and has rebuffed all attempts to speed the pace of the talks.

Suspicions of an ecclesiastical bias against the government have been reinforced by the actions of Archbishop Jaime Goncalves of Beira, Mozambique's second largest city, who has shared the mediation role with Saint Egidio. In one unpopular move last year, Goncalves mandated the exclusive use of the Ndau language in all churches in his diocese, which spans the provinces of Manica and Sofala where approximately two-thirds of the people speak Sena. Since the Renamo leadership and many of its followers are Ndau-speaking, this was taken as evidence of the archbishop's leanings, and public demonstrations denouncing his action took place in Beira.

To strengthen Renamo in negotiations and elections, Dhlakama is seeking to boost his international stature and ties. After long seeking an audience with the Pope, the Renamo leader was invited to the Vatican last November. But, because of Renamo's history of brutality against civilians, he was received only by Monsignor Claudio Cellim, undersecretary for foreign affairs, and not by the pontiff. Among Renamo's latest victims are a Catholic priest, two nuns and 23 lay catechists killed at a Catholic training center near Inhambane, which lies between Maputo and Beira.

The Pontiff, who had visited Mozam-bique in 1988 and seen some of the war victims himself, apparently differed with the church mediators over this issue of meeting the Renamo leader. At the same time, various elements from within the church, including the Archbishop of Nampula, the Africa Working Group at Maryknoll and the Catholic Institute for International Relations in London, have begun to lobby the mediators to put equal pressure on Renamo and Frelimo to end the war.

To encourage Renamo's cooperation, Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe and Botwana's President Quett Masire met Dhlakama on July 4 in Gaborone, the Botswana capital, where the rebel leader reportedly agreed to enter cease-fire talks in exchange for a personal meeting with Chissano.

But there are widespread fears that Renamo will continue to delay, sticking to a demand for constitutional talks to precede the signing of a truce. This may reflect the influence of Renamo supporters in Portugal, who want the constitutional amended so that they can reclaim property confiscated at independence or be compensated for it.

The South African government gave backing to the demand for constitutional reform, outlining this position in the three-page memorandum presented to Chissano when he stopped off in Cape Town on his return from the Earth Summit in Rio.

Renamo is receiving advice in the negotiations from Thomas Haussen, a South African lawyer from Witswatersrand University, from Bruce Fein of the Heritage Foundation in Washington, D.C., and from David Hoile, founder of the Mozambique Institute in London. Among other known Renamo supporters are several American fundamentalist religious groups, such as the Shekinah Ministries in Jacksonville, Florida, the Jimmy Swaggart Ministries, Christ for the Nations, and television evangelist Pat Robertson.

In Rome meanwhile, after a month of stalling, Renamo finally agreed to begin discussions on military issues at the beginning of July.

The mediators, perhaps in an attempt to boost their credibility, arranged a meeting in Rome on July 10 between the leaders of some 15 Catholic communities with personnel working in Mozambique and the Renamo and Frelimo delegations in Rome. The two delegations were presented with several thousand petitions from church personnel, urging them to end the war for the sake of the suffering people.

Later the same day, the mediators convened a session with United Nations relief agencies to work on an agreement to allow food into areas affected by the drought, regardless of whether these areas are in Renamo or the government-controlled territory.

Despite misgivings about the lack of progress in Rome, many Catholics and others continue to pursue peace efforts. In an Easter appeal, the Archbishop of Maputo called on Renamo soldiers to lay down their arms. "You who are killing us, who burn and loot our houses, who kidnap the innocent and who oblige us to flee every night, you who create terror in our neighborhoods, this is not the way you will win the justice you say you are seeking," he said.

Chissano expresses sorrow that the United States and other Western governments appear unwilling to play a larger role in forcing an end to the fighting. "They claim they don't have any leverage over Renamo," he says. But he obviously believes much more could be done.-30-

Janice McLaughlin is a Maryknoll Sister who has spent the last 22 years in Africa. She worked with Zimbabwean refugees in Mozambique from 1978 to 1980 and served most recently as communications officer for the Zimbabwe Mozambique Friendship Association in Harare.


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


173 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 20, 1992


Democracy Requires More than Elections


LENGTH: 1827 words


Maina Kiai

A disturbing trend is gradually emerging in Kenya as the country begins to edge away from its past history of tyranny and dictatorship.

Opposition parties have decided to put all their energies and focus on contesting elections, with a view to replacing an incumbent regime that has lost credibility both nationally and internationally. As soon as they are in power, critics assert, they will implement the reforms necessary to rid Kenya of its repressive and corrupt legacy and restore democracy.

The strategy assumes that the primary obstacle to democracy, good governance and respect of human rights is the government and the people running it. It follows, therefore, that the struggle for democracy is close to completion once the government and the individuals running it are replaced in free and fair elections. 

This is a serious and an unacceptable misdirection of focus. It is not that the individuals running the government in Kenya were born with a "special" repressive and corrupt streak that members of the opposition parties do not possess. The injustice and greed that have characterized the regime of President Daniel arap Moi are a product of state structures deliberately created to be repressive and corrupt. Anyone in his shoes, clothed with the same vast economic and coercive powers of state, would almost certainly do the same. Without changing the constitutional and institutional orders to reflect a commitment to democratic norms, changing the government is meaningless.

But even at a purely practical and pragmatic level, the strategy of focusing all attention and energies on elections is flawed.

First, there is no guarantee that the opposition parties will actually win. Cote d'Ivoire in 1990, and Burkina Faso more recently, demonstrated the foolhardiness of counting out the existing regime as a force -- whatever its human rights or corruption record. If this fate befalls Kenya, woe to those who challenged and ridiculed the people in power.

Repressive regimes always control all aspects of life in their countries, including media, and do not hesitate to use them. With illiteracy running to about half the population in Kenya, control of radio waves can make a significant difference in any electoral contest. Nor should one discount the impact that the prolonged use of intimidation and patronage tactics could have on an electorate that is poor and dependent on government largess.

Second, opposition parties cannot be certain that they will win enough seats to implement their stated legislative agenda of restoring democracy. The leading opposition party, Forum for the Restoration of Democracy (FORD), will not only face stiff challenge from the ruling party, the Kenya African National Union, but also from the Democratic Party (DP) that is generally composed of wealthy conservatives who were part of the government until December 1991, when opposition parties were legalized. While DP claims to support democratic reform, the fact that its leadership never articulated concern for democracy until it was safe to do so casts doubt on its commitment. Nevertheless, the party has gotten some support because it appears better organized and funded than FORD, because it tilts toward an upper middle class that has more influence than its size and because it appeals, to some extent, to certain ethnic groups that have been alienated by the Moi regime.

Third, even if the opposition were to win a landslide victory, there is no guarantee that the new rulers will restructure Kenya's legal and institutional framework.

Given the enormous powers at the disposal of the president and his or her government, it would take a Herculean effort to convince any president to voluntarily reduce those powers. Thus, the temptation would be to release political prisoners while leaving the laws that persecuted them intact; to verbally affirm and permit free expression and free press while maintaining the legal right to control them in the future; to prosecute individuals closely associated with repression and corruption; and to institute investigations and commissions of inquiry into some of the more abominable acts of the previous government.

Fourth, it is by no means clear that the free and fair elections will take place. Indeed, some observers, pointing to Mobutu Sese Seko's extended tenure as president of Zaire after his constitutional term expired in December, are skeptical that Moi will permit elections that he could lose.

Recent events in Kenya are disturbing. Registration of voters, which began on June 8, was immediately followed by an opposition call -- later withdrawn -- for a boycott, due to a perceived bias in favor of the ruling party. Independent organizations such as churches concurred. They noted that the Electoral Commission is tied closely to the present regime. It is funded by the government; its members were appointed by the president; and it has inherited the structures of provincial administrations that were formerly responsible for conducting elections. In effect, it is nothing more than an arm of the present government.

Most frightening is the violence and terror that has been unleashed on the people of western Kenya and the Rift Valley. The violence there is believed by many to be tied to political tensions between the government and the opposition. The conflicts have caused hundreds of deaths and have forced thousands to flee their homes.The Moi regime has done little to check the killing, preferring instead to issue statements deploring the trouble.

Many independent observers believe this attitude exists because the government (or high ranking officials in the government) is behind the violence. According to one eyewitness, the terror is being perpetrated by well-organized groups of warriors with significant government support. The warriors have camps from which they plot their attacks on unsuspecting villagers. The eyewitness, who was abducted in order to provide free labor for the warriors, saw the murders of hostages. Before he made his escape, he witnessed an inspection tour by a close Moi associate -- a government official in charge of the area. Food, medicines and weapons are air-dropped from government helicopters.

A report by the National Christian Council of Kenya following on-site investigations asserted that Vice President George Saitoti was hosting warriors on his land and that former energy minister, Nicholas Biwott, who remains close to Moi, was financing the groups.

There are two possible objectives for this violence. Either Moi is trying to make the country unstable and volatile as an excuse for imposing martial law and suspending the constitution and civil rights. Or, the individuals in the regime are signaling that they have the capacity to wreak havoc if they are replaced.

The Kenyan opposition seems to see the stunning electoral defeat of Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia as a model for Moi's loss of power. But this is misleading, for there are notable differences between Zambia and Kenya. While Kenneth Kaunda was no democrat, he was not nearly as repressive as Moi. Zambians, for the most part, had some political space within which dissent was tolerated. The judiciary was often independent and frequently refused to sanction the persecution of some of Kaunda's harshest critics. The labor movement was cohesive and independent and operated as a significant check on the state. It is instructive that current Zambian President Frederick Chiluba was the long-time leader of that nation's labor movement. The fact that Zambia is the most urbanized country in Africa made it easier to organize the opposition and disseminate information.

In Zambia, the opposition coalesced into a single unit to contest the elections. Given the wrangling within the Kenyan opposition movement, different parties are unlikely to form a coalition for the election. In fact, some observers expect FORD to break up before the elections that are scheduled to be held next March.

What is most disheartening is the opposition's total focus on the vote. Basic democratic rights should never be dependent on the outcome of elections.

It is of utmost importance, therefore, that the necessary foundation for Kenya's future democracy be laid before the election takes place.They include constitutional amendments to reduce presidential power, to limit presidential terms, to provide for effective impeachment procedures and to adopt an absolute and enforceable Bill of Rights. These reforms would abolish the laws that permit indefinite detention without trial, that make criticism of the government and president a criminal offense, that restrict the freedom of association and that control the press and media. Kenya also must have an impartial and independent judiciary and police force.

Democracy consists of rules and norms that govern behavior and conduct of power between elections. It is a culture that needs deep roots to survive. The United States, with its long democratic tradition, must promote these ideals over the easier option of elections without democratic foundations. Without a similarly firm foundation in Kenya, the struggle for democracy and human rights is bound to be long and arduous, no matter which party wins the elections.-30-

Maina Kiai is executive director of the Kenya Human Rights Commission.


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


174 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 20, 1992


Kenya on Road to 'Flourishing' Democracy


SECTION: VIEWPOINT


LENGTH: 2227 words


George Saitoti

Irreversible Steps

When the time comes to review the history of Kenya, I believe that our achievements, particularly in this recent and testing period, will be judged in a positive light. In the short space of seven months, guided by the statesmanship of President (Daniel arap) Moi, we have taken fundamental and irreversible steps to lead Kenya to multi-party democracy. Each stage of this sometimes daunting exercise has been in accordance with the provisions of our Constitution. ...

Registration of Voters

We have now reached the stage where, with the registration of voters, the countdown to multiparty elections has truly begun. Nearly 6 million Kenyans have already registered -- an encouraging figure. The registration process began on 8 June and the Electoral Commission has used its powers to extend the 30-day registration period by a further ten days.

Setting up the registration process has been a huge task. To speed up the process and cut down congestion and unnecessary queuing, 5,631 registration centers were established throughout the country, each with four or five registration clerks and a supervisor. Considerable resources have gone into this operation in terms of materials, personnel and transport. More than 6,000 vehicles have had to be hired in various parts of the country. Particular efforts have been made to persuade young people to register once they have obtained their identity cards at the age of 18. 

Also in place are the mechanisms of checking and cross-checking before the voters' roll is finally certified. The temporary roll of voters -- before certification -- can be inspected by any person to see if his or her name is on the register and also to object to the registration of any person who should not be on the register. There are legal limits, too, for the length of this exercise. ...

Electoral Commission

Section 41 (1) of the Constitution stipulates the creation of an Electoral Commission. The independence of the Electoral Commission has been greatly strengthened through the amendment to section 41 (7) of the Constitution to provide for security of tenure of the members of the commission. Subsection 9 provides that, in the exercise of its functions under the Constitution, the commission is not to be subject to the direction or control of any other person or authority. The term of office of the current commission expires in September 1996.

Building a Responsible Opposition

Since the repeal of section 2A of the Constitution, and the subsequent mushrooming of political parties, the government has striven to establish the necessary administrative machinery to ensure a smooth transition to elections under a multiparty system. The government has been able to set up this machinery despite strident and often negative calls by the opposition to hasten the process.

We have been disappointed by the performance of the opposition, which at each step has attempted to frustrate the constitutional process. In the era of multiparty democracy, we need a responsible opposition. Earlier this year the Forum for the Restoration of Democracy (FORD) campaigned for a nationwide strike which, if it had succeeded, would have caused great damage to our economy and to the livelihood of our people. It failed to gain support.

As the international community is fully aware, the process itself requires time and meticulous planning -- it cannot be rushed. Recent developments have vindicated the government's approach. ...

Holding of Elections

We are often advised to announce a firm date for elections -- to eliminate, we are told, a key element of uncertainty. Let me make it clear that our Constitution is quite specific on this issue. Section 59 (4) states that Parliament, unless sooner dissolved, shall continue for five years from the date when the National Assembly first meets after dissolution and shall then stand dissolved. We have, since independence, held elections within the constitutional framework -- in 1969, 1974, 1979, 1983 and 1988. Strictly speaking, the five years start from the date of the first session of Parliament. Thus the current parliamentary term ends in March next year. However, it remains the prerogative of the president to call an election earlier -- similar to the (prerogative of the) prime minister in the UK.

Reform and Key Legislation

... Major reforms were made following the recommendations of the Kanu (Kenya African National Union) Review Committee, which I chaired in 1990 and which solicited the views of our people throughout the country on a wide range of issues. Queue voting and the 70% rule were abolished, as was expulsion from the party as a disciplinary measure. Security of tenure for judges, the attorney general and the auditor general was also restored, and the Constitution of Kenya (amendment) Act 1990 strengthened their position by providing for tribunals to be appointed in any case where the question of removing or investigating a judge arose. ...

Ethnic Loyalties

... Kenya remains one of the least urbanized countries in the world, and particularly in the rural areas, strong tribal and ethnic loyalties remain -- even among those who have lived together peacefully since independence. These rivalries came to the surface earlier this year, and the result was a loss of life and property we greatly regret. Nor, must it be said, were the forces of law and order -- partly due to limited resources -- able to cope fully with the situation. However, peace has been restored, and security forces have been deployed in sensitive areas. ...

I must state categorically that there is absolutely no truth in the allegations that the government fomented these clashes. Apart from being morally unacceptable, it would have been politically counter-productive. After all it is the government that inevitably gets the blame when law and order break down. Instead, it was the opposition which took advantage of the strains in the social system -- and tried to benefit accordingly.

Creating the Right Environment

... We accept that freedom of expression, association and assembly are the bedrock in which democracy is founded. Since the first major FORD rally in January, opposition parties have held rallies and meetings all over the country -- and all news agencies and broadcasting services report these meetings extensively. Freedom of the press, for example, is a totally established fact in Kenya -- and periodicals, often vitriolic in their criticism of the government, are published regularly. However, the sad fact has been their irresponsible and often wildly distorted reporting at times -- particularly during the period of the unfortunate ethnic clashes. I should like to urge the various sections of the press to be responsible, objective and fair at all times.

Kenya's respect and commitment to human rights is unequivocal. As a party to the various international instruments on human rights, Kenya has put into place legal and constitutional framework to effect the protection of human rights. ...

As a result of this on-going review process, several of the so-called political prisoners have been released. There are no political detainees in Kenya just as there are no refugees living abroad.

Greater Transparency

We are committed to a fully transparent political and economic system in Kenya. Parliament, the press, which reports parliamentary procedures fully, and watchdog bodies, such as the Public Accounts Committee, are all part of a transparent and accountable system. However, we are now strengthening this transparency. We have introduced anti-corruption legislation and have set up an anti-corruption unit. Certain senior public servants have already been moved from their jobs and prosecuted. In the Finance Bill, currently before Parliament, measures to ensure greater transparency are outlined. We aim to cut through bureaucracy, rationalize licenses for new business operations and regulate tendering procedures while cutting out single sourcing.

Refugees

If the return to multiparty democracy was not a powerful enough challenge on its own, we have had to contend with poor rains, severe drought in the northeast and an enormous influx of refugees. The refugee crisis is an appalling additional burden for us to bear, and we have no idea when the influx will stop. The impact on the economic and social life of our own people in the border area is horrendous. The strain on resources -- our infrastructure -- on the local environment is intolerable. Many refugees are armed and come into the country in armed bands.

While we are grateful for international support in terms of food and medical assistance, this problem requires serious international attention. We are, after all, hosting one of the largest concentrations of refugees in the world -- around 750,000 at the present time. There must be a long-term program to deal with this situation, and this must include a concentrated international effort to put Somalia back on its feet. ...

Drought

In addition to the refuge problem, we are afflicted by serious drought with over a million Kenyans now at risk. We have over the years been self-sufficient in food production -- and, in fact, have not had to import basic foodstuffs since 1984. Other countries in Africa are similarly suffering, but our own situation has not received the same international attention. As a result, we have (unlike other countries) been forced to buy food commercially. This does not seem to be an even-handed approach to a serious regional problem.

Withholding of Funds

A further heavy blow has been the withholding of critical financial resources in the form of fast-disbursing loans and grants since the meeting of the Consultative Group for Kenya in Paris last November. These resources were intended to finance the structural adjustment program negotiated with, and approved by, the donor community. The abrupt withholding of this quick-disbursing aid -- in excess of $ 350 million -- which was scheduled for expenditure programs and macroeconomic forecasts, has caused a general decline in economic activity. ...

Economic Reform Through Efficiency

The government continues its commitment to the promotion of economic efficiency through reform as stipulated in Sessional Paper No. 1 of 1986. The implementation of the reforms has been accelerated by means of a number of economic measures since the donor meeting in November 1991. The thrust of all these measures has been to obtain greater efficiency in resource use and the re-establishment of fiscal discipline. The deficit has come down from 6.3% of gross domestic product in 1990-91, to 3.5% in 1991-92, and I have tabled the 1992-93 budget to reflect a two percent deficit. ... n

George Saitoti, Kenya's vice president and minister for finance, delivered the address excerpted here to the House of Commons in London on July 9.


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


175 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 20, 1992


Kenyans Disagree Over Political Reform Process


LENGTH: 294 words


As Kenya moves towards multiparty elections, scheduled to take place sometime early next year, debate over the country's political future grows sharper. Opposition groups, legalized last December for the first time since 1969, continue to complain about the pace and the particulars of the government's election preparations. But the administration of President Daniel arap Moi contends that the preparations for the vote are moving ahead.

Kenyan Vice President George Saitoti toured Europe this month to campaign for a resumption of international assistance to Kenya. Aid was suspended by major donors late last year to pressure Moi to end one-party rule and reform what donors regard as corrupt and wasteful economic practices. Pro-democracy forces within Kenya have supported the aid cut to strengthen their demands for political and economic change.

Saitoti argues that the government and the ruling Kenya African National Union (Kanu) has met or is in the process of meeting all the prerequisites for renewed outside assistance, and he predicted that aid might be restored after a visit to Kenya in September by a team from the International Monetary Fund (IMF). This week, we present the views of the government -- in the form of Saitoti's major address in Europe -- and of Maina Kiai, executive director of the newly formed Kenya Human Rights Commission, which has offices in both Nairobi and Washington, D.C.


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


176 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 20, 1992


U.S. Business Takes New Look at Mozambique


LENGTH: 494 words


Will Acworth * for Africa News Service

President Joaquim Alberto Chissano of Mozambique has returned home from a two-week U.S. trip earlier this month with some welcome news. Several promising ventures by American mining companies appear to be moving ahead, offering the prospect of a much-needed boost for the country's post-war reconstruction after peace is finally achieved. The economy is one of the world's least developed, as a result of 12 years of civil war and five centuries of Portuguese colonial rule. 

Chissano visited Washington and New York to promote his country's long-term economic potential. He met Secretary of State James Baker III in Washington and held discussion with business leaders in both American cities.

In the wake of the talks, the Washington, DC-based Edlow Resources Ltd. is preparing to close a $ 400 million deal to develop titanium deposits in Mozambique. The company is reluctant to discuss the deal publicly before the details are concluded, but sources close to the firm say that Edlow, which has been active in Mozambique since the early 1980s, has located two deposits in Mozambique which have world class potential.

A much larger deal may be in the making with Kaiser Aluminum. During his trip, Chissano met with John Seidl, chief executive officer of the huge multinational, to discuss the construction of an aluminum smelter in Mozambique to take advantage of the energy potential of the giant Cahora Bassa dam. Kaiser, which has operated a smelter in Ghana since the 1960s, is interested in opening another smelter in Africa, a project that could cost $ 1 billion over a five-year period.

A key participant in the discussions between Kaiser and Mozambique is Philip Ringdahl, who handled Africa at the National Security Council for two years during the Reagan administration. Ringdahl says Mozambique, along with Cameroon and Namibia, is on Kaiser's short list of potential sites, in spite of the security situation caused by the continuation of war. Seidl may visit Mozambique as early as next month, he says.

Washington attorney Robert K. Kelly, who is negotiating with the Mozambican government on behalf of several other U.S. firms, says investor interest in Mozambique is on the rise. Kelly is in practice with John P. Sears, a former Reagan campaign manager who until recently served as a principal Washington lobbyist for the South African government. n


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


177 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 20, 1992


Ivorian President Weighs Clemency for Opponents


LENGTH: 667 words


Abidjan, Cote d'Ivoire Richard Nyberg * for Africa News Service

For more than three decades, Felix Houphouet-Boigny has piloted Cote d'Ivoire through cocoa-based economic prosperity and subsequent financial collapse. Now people are asking if the aging leader, recently returned from a nearly five-month absence, can rescue the nation from the worst political crisis in its history.

Two years ago Houphouet-Boigny, Africa's most senior leader, became one of the first of the continent's autocrats to bend to burgeoning popular demands for political pluralism. He legalized opposition political parties, allowed an opposition press, and held the country's first multiparty elections for Parliament and the presidency. But Laurent Gbagbo, who stood unsuccessfully against Houphouet-Boigny in the presidential balloting, along with other opposition leaders faces a jail term stemming from a series of incidents in February that reflect the level of tension caused by the severe economic crunch. 

The incidents began February 18, when Gbagbo's Ivorian Popular Front (FPI) and other dissident groups protested Houphouet-Boigny's refusal to punish Gen. Robert Guei, the army chief of staff, for ordering a night raid on dormitories of Abidjan University in May 1991. A government-sanctioned commission found Guei responsible for the crackdown, during which several students were raped and beaten.

The February demonstration attracted hundreds of rowdy youths who, brandishing clubs and stones, left the march route and attacked the courthouse where a student leader, Martial Ahipeaud, was being tried. About 300 arrests were made and 75 people were sentenced from one to three years for helping organize the march. Ahipeaud was subsequently sentenced to three years in jail on charges of fomenting student unrest and resurrecting a banned student union. Gbagbo and nine others received two-year sentences for their roles in the February march.

On June 23, after three postponements, Judge Yapo Yanon appeared before the court, saying that he could not read his verdict as planned. The audience was told to return in a week. But the verdict didn't come. State prosecutor Tia Kone, acting on instruction from the Ivorian Justice Minister, on June 26 urged the Supreme Court to take Judge Yanon off the case on "grounds of legitimate suspicion."

"Recent press reports have presented Judge Yapo Yanon as a 'democrat' fighting for the same cause as the accused," Kone told the court. With that motion, the case has been indefinitely set aside.

Critics charge that Houphouet-Boigny forced the action against the judge in order to appear magnanimous by granting clemency to Gbagbo and his co-defendants; government critics want a clear-cut acquittal by the court. Diplomats here see the chance to grant clemency as an opportunity for Houphouet-Boigny to boost his popularity at a time of severe economic difficulty.

Opposition groups are not letting up. Last month, the FPI called for Prime Minister Alasane Ouattara and his cabinet to step down to make way for a transitional government. Meanwhile, everyone is waiting for Houphouet-Boigny to act.-30-


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


178 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 20, 1992


Nigerian Vote Leaves Transition Questions Unanswered


LENGTH: 827 words


Africa News Service

A third round of elections in Nigeria has failed to quell uncertainties surrounding the country's progress towards democracy after nearly nine years of military rule.

The July 4 voting for a two-chamber national legislature was largely peaceful, with few allegations of fraud or mismanagement. A moderately liberal party won slight majorities in both bodies.

But human rights groups and government opponents continue to question the military's procedures for establishing an elected civilian government in Africa's most populous nation, where soldiers have ruled for more than two of the country's three decades of independence. 

The election was a contest between the only two legal parties, the slightly left-of-center Social Democratic Party (SDP) and the more conservative National Republican Convention (NRC), both created in 1988 by the government of President Ibrahim Babangida.

In November and December, voters supported the two parties in nearly equal numbers, with the NRC gaining a slight majority in state gubernatorial races and the SDP gaining an edge in state assemblies and local councils.

In this month's national balloting, the SDP took 47 Senate seats to the NRC's 37, and 310 House seats to the NRC's 267, narrowly emerging a winner in the last vote before the presidential election, scheduled for December 5.

Despite the attempt of the Armed Forces Ruling Council to create national constituencies for the two parties, which it named, organized and financed, many of the votes apparently were cast along regional and ethnic lines.

The SDP has won landslide victories in the mainly Christian, Yoruba-speaking southwest, including the capital, Lagos, and carried the multi-ethnic "middle belt" states. And the NRC has swept the mainly Moslem north, where the Hausa and Fulani populations are dominant. The NRC won twice as many seats as the SDP in the predominately Christian, Igbo-speaking east and southeast, and SDP candidates fared well in some parts of the north, Kaduna, Kano, and the region bordering Lake Chad. However, the largely north/south, Moslem/Christian split evident in the results confirmed the findings of a survey published in the Nigerian weekly magazine Newswatch. Some 70% of 100 Nigerians in the "top executive bracket" said religion and ethnicity would play a part in their choice of a candidate for president, Newswatch reported.

Although the July 4 vote was the first legislative election in Nigeria in 12 years, less than a third of eligible voters cast ballots. Human rights groups and government opponents blame the low turnout on lack of enthusiasm for an election heavily controlled by the military.

Besides creating the only legal parties, the government, through the National Electoral Commission (NEC), disqualified 28 candidates (a week before the election). Officials say that people were disqualified for being too young, owing taxes, having criminal records or being morally unfit, but the authorities refuse to give specific reasons, citing the privacy rights of those removed from the slate.

The NEC decreed that citizens must vote by forming lines behind a picture or some other symbol of their candidate, arguing that public counting would prevent the fraud that was commonplace in past secret ballot elections. But critics believe the queuing system allows people with power to sway voters, whether the influence is by employers over workers or husbands over wives.

The recently formed Campaign for Democracy (CD) has called on the government to abandon its transition program in favor of a national conference, representing a diversity of Nigerian religious and civic organizations, to establish "genuine" multiparty democracy.

"We want the right to form political parties and vote for the policies and leaders we like," says Beko Ransome-Kuti, chairman of the CD and one of five pro-democracy activists released early this month on bail after being held as long as 42 days on treason charges. "We don't want to be told what to do by generals."


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


179 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 20, 1992


UN in Angola Said to Need Support


SECTION: NEWS ROUNDUP


LENGTH: 654 words


William Acworth * for Africa News Service As Angola heads for its first multiparty elections, scheduled for September 29- 30, an American business group is lobbying to increase U.S. public and private support for the United Nations team that is monitoring the process. "Angola's devastated infrastructure is presenting tremendous logistical challenges for the UN Verification Mission (Unavem), whose responsibility it is to ensure free and fair elections," the United States-Angola Chamber of Commerce said in letters distributed to business leaders this month.

Voter registration that was to have concluded by late July is "progressing, but slowly," a recent UN report concludes. According to Angola's National Electoral Commission, less than half of the nation's eligible voters have been registered. Logistical difficulties have slowed the process, which has been extended into August with the consent of both major political groups, the ruling Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA) led by President Jose Eduardo dos Santos and Jonas Savimbi's National Union for the Total Independence of Angola (Unita). 

At the same time, a rise in banditry has raised concerns about the social costs of the transition to democracy. Tens of thousands of soldiers from both sides have slipped away from demobilization camps and are roaming the countryside with their weapons in an increasingly desperate search for food and shelter. In recent weeks, crime in the capital city of Luanda has claimed the lives of several foreigners, including the wife of an employee of a French oil company and several Portuguese businessmen.

Two former top Unita officials, Miguel N'zau Puna and Tony da Costa Fernandes, who left the movement in a disagreement with Savimbi earlier this year, say Unita is keeping as many as 20,000 soldiers out of the disarmament camps, holding them in reserve in case of an electoral defeat. The soldiers are said to be some of the best trained and most experienced of the Unita forces.

The allegation has resulted in an unusual dialogue between the Bush administration, which backed Unita during the civil war, and the Angolan government, which has asked the United States to share intelligence, including satellite data, about Unita troop movements.

The request came in an unannounced meeting at a Washington, DC hotel in late May between Assistant Secretary of State for Africa Herman Cohen and two senior Angolan officials.

According to sources close to the talks, Cohen told the officials -- General Jose Maria, the Angolan president's national security advisor, and Jose Leitao, secretary of the MPLA Council of Ministers -- that the U.S. is equally concerned about MPLA forces that still have not been demobilized. Cohen is said to have offered to provide the satellite information, but only if the MPLA is able to pinpoint more precisely where the soldiers may be located, a request the Angolan government apparently is unable to meet. Unita has vehemently denied the charges that it is withholding its crack units.

Last month, Cohen visited Luanda, where, according to U.S. officials, he advised both dos Santos and Savimbi to tone down their attacks on each other and to concentrate on implementing the election timetable as outlined in the U.S.-mediated peace plan.


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.
