Africa News


July 20, 1992


Trek Promotes Bicycles for Africa


LENGTH: 347 words


As the Africatrek cyclists ride across Africa to make Americans more aware of the continent, they will have another objective as well. Buettner and his team hope to interest Africans in making greater use of bicycles. 

Except for Burkina Faso in West Africa and a few other countries, bicycling is not as popular in Africa as it is in many parts of the world. Sometimes bicycles are even banned from highways by governments, says David Mozer, author of Bicycling in Africa: The Places in Between.

In conjunction with Africatrek, Rotary International has pledged to send 1,000 used, cleaned and repaired bicycles to Kenya and Tanzania. Don Kuplic, chairman of the Rotary Bike Project in Burnsville, Minnesota, says the organization is raising $ 25,000 to transport the vehicles to Africa. Bicycles will be given to health workers, teachers and others chosen by local Rotary clubs, Kuplic says.

In his book, Mozer extols the bicycle as a means to "move underdeveloped, largely impoverished Africa into a healthier, more productive, more prosperous and sustainable society." The bicycle is inexpensive, can be used anywhere, does not pollute and would cut the travel times now required to walk or to carry wood, water and other heavy loads, Mozer writes.

But this potential is so widely overlooked that the word "bicycle" does not even appear in a World Bank urban transport policy statement released in the late 1980s, Mozer says. "Despite the fact that the cost of energy has put most African countries deeply in debt, and despite the fact that pollution and congestion are strangling the major urban centers on the continent, it is business as usual for the policy makers," he writes.-30-


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


181 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 20, 1992


Cyclists Set to Ride Across Africa


LENGTH: 1120 words


Karen Lange * Africa News Service

Veteran U.S. cyclist Daniel Buettner is preparing for a record-setting trip that he hopes will focus international attention on the African continent.

In 1987, Buettner's 16,000-mile, Guinness World Record-setting ride from Prudhoe Bay, Alaska, to Tierra del Fuego, Chile, was covered by the Associated Press and several outdoor magazines. Three years later, Buettner led a 13,000-mile trek through parts of the Soviet Union previously closed to North Americans. Reports by NBC's "Today" show, David Letterman, National Public Radio and large daily newspapers drew the notice of an estimated 300 million Americans to the U.S.S.R., Buettner says. 

Later this year, Buettner hopes to make the record book again, as part of a multiracial, international group that will depart from Bizerte, Tunisia -- the continent's northernmost point -- and travel to Africa's southern tip. Guinness lists no one as having traversed Africa from north to south.

"When we did the Soviet trek, (the area) was a place the world had been turning its eyes to," he says. "I just feel that Africa will be a continent people in the West will start turning their eyes to in the mid-1990s."

With Daniel Buettner will be his 27-year-old brother Steven, James (Chip) Thomas Jr., a 35-year-old physician who has worked in Liberia, and an African rider to be chosen from among candidates in Cameroon, Ghana, Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda. The Buettners are white. Thomas is African American.

Publicity for the ride is already underway. "Africatrek, " as the planned eight-month journey is called, has its own quarterly newsletter. The third issue has just been published. And Buettner says CNN, ESPN and the Washington Post have indicated an interest in covering the venture.

The project also has an educational component. The Center for Global Environmental Studies at Hamline University in St. Paul, Minnesota, is developing materials for teaching students about the geography, culture, history and environment of the continent through Africatrek. Computerized progress reports and a toll-free telephone hotline will help pupils in classrooms around the United States track the cyclists on their journey.

Michael Clough, outgoing senior fellow on Africa at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York City, says Africatrek is a start at changing the continent's negative image, fostered by media coverage that focuses almost exclusively on cruel and corrupt governments, wars, disease, droughts and famine.

"I see this as part of a much broader approach to the need to acquaint people with Africa as an interesting part of the world and to begin to reach people who are not Africanists," he says. "It has the potential to be a very important event."

Buettner says he himself had a negative image of the continent from reading screaming headlines and hearing about the continent's problems. "The State Department sent me a packet of information on Africa that read like descending strata in Dante's Inferno," he says. "If you talk to people who have never been (to Africa) before, they always know someone who's been shot."

But the cyclist says that conversations with Peace Corps volunteers and other experienced travelers have given him a broader view of the continent. He says he is looking forward to seeing some of Africa's natural beauty, cultural richness and economic potential.

Volumes have been written about the difficulties and dangers of traveling in Africa. "We inherit a burden because much of the information and news coverage on Africa focuses on crises," says David Mozer in Bicycling in Africa: The Places in Between. "The result is an exaggerated awareness of the tragedies, without a knowledge of the opportunities."

Buettner knows that he and his colleagues must prepare for any of several significant hazards -- dehydration, disease, banditry, political unrest and potentially fatal altitude sickness on the slopes of Mount Kilimanjaro, Africa's highest peak.

To meet the challenge of riding the 1,680-mile Trans-Saharan Highway from El Golea in Algeria to Niger's Agadez, the Africatrek cyclists will carry 20-liter bags of water to help them quench their thirst between water sources, some 150 miles or more apart. They also will tote an "earth location device" to help them navigate in the desert. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is supplying the device in exchange for data on climate and vegetation that the riders will collect.

"Much of the pavement is broken and unusable," Buettner says. "The Sahara is no game." Two Canadians and a Japanese bicyclist died in the desert two years ago when they lost their way.

But the greatest threat to the biker's safety, he believes, will be the same hazard that confronts cyclists in the United States -- traffic.

As Africatrek makes its way south out of the Sahara, the bikers will see glimpses of the continent's vast diversity. The group is scheduled to pass through both Abidjan -- Cote d'Ivoire's coastal metropolis of skyscrapers and sidewalk cafes -- and the legendary Timbuktu, a dusty town in rural Mali that once was the crossroads of trading routes on which ancient empires were built. "At the beginning of this millennium Timbuktu was one of the most important cities anywhere," Buettner says. "I still get people all the time who ask whether it really exists."

From West Africa, the team will travel eastward, through tropical forests along the equator, to Mount Kilimanjaro, Tanzania, the tallest free-standing mountain in the world. They will end the journey in South Africa at Cape Agulhas, where the Atlantic and Indian Oceans meet.-30-


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


182 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 20, 1992


Suffering Rises as Civil Strife Persists: New Initiatives to End Wars in Somalia and Mozambique


LENGTH: 1214 words


by Reed Kramer * Africa News Service Two lingering African conflicts are claiming human lives in staggering numbers, largely outside the public eye. The wars in Somalia and Mozambique seem to sidestep every attempt at resolution.

Yet the United Nations and the world community at large have mustered little energy to bring the suffering to an end. "It is clear that the only crisis that matters to the powers-that-be in the Security Council is the crisis in Eastern Europe," says Ambassador Legwaila Joseph Legwaila of Botswana, who after 12 years in his post is the longest serving African envoy at the UN. "People are dying by the thousands in Africa, but no one here is convening urgent consultations. Our crises don't spark that kind of response," he says. 

But several recent developments, including an unannounced trip to Somalia by a prominent Republican U.S. senator and a quiet intervention in Mozambican negotiations by two African presidents, may be pointers to an increased international focus on solving the two escalating conflicts before the death toll reaches record levels.

The United Nations estimates that 100 children are dying every day in Mogadishu, Somalia's war-wracked capital, and that 4.5 million people -- of a total population of about 7.7 million -- face starvation throughout the country. An estimated 30,000 Somalis have been killed in fighting that began with the ouster of former dictator Siad Barre at the end of 1990 and continues with inter-clan rivalry that leaves the nation in the grip of political paralysis and economic disaster.

In Mozambique, another catastrophe-in-the-making -- as a result of a deadly combination of brutal war and spreading drought -- starvation-caused fatalities are already being reported. The mortality rate will climb rapidly unless the ongoing peace process succeeds.

"Massacres, mutilations, the forcible relocation of population and the forced recruitment of soldiers -- many of them children -- have been characteristic of a war that has claimed thousands of lives," says the human rights group Africa Watch in a new 200-page report on Mozambique, Conspicuous Destruction.

The situations in Somalia and Mozambique are probably the most serious, due to the continuation of fighting there. But the impact of the drought throughout southern and eastern Africa, parts of which have only recently seen conflicts ended, has put some 50 million people under the threat of severe famine, according to a recent warning from the Washington, D.C.-based relief and lobby group Bread for the World.

"While the international community rallies to safeguard lives amid civil strife in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, a crisis of epic proportions in being neglected a continent away," says Bread for the World's Sharon Pauling.

In an attempt to focus attention on the suffering, the Senate Africa subcommittee's ranking Republican, Nancy Kassebaum of Kansas, took advantage of the Senate adjournment for the Democratic Convention in mid July to schedule a visit to Mogadishu, which has seen almost no high-ranking official visitors since large-scale fighting last year.

Kassebaum, who also scheduled stopovers in Khartoum, neighboring Sudan's capital, and Nairobi, was cosponsor with Senator Paul Simon (D-IL), the subcommittee chairman, of a resolution adopted by the upper chamber in May calling on the United Nations to "remain committed to the diplomatic and peacemaking tasks" in Somalia to facilitate emergency relief assistance to the country "as a matter of highest priority."

A UN-sponsored cease-fire has halted the worst fighting in the capital, but relief work remains a risky endeavor, since food is a principal focus of competition between the two well-armed factions, and no neutral source of law and order exists. UN attempts to deploy 50 military observers have met with numerous obstacles, and the relief effort was dealt a setback when a Russian plane that had been chartered to deliver emergency supplies made an unauthorized flight from Nairobi carrying a cargo of cash to one of the sides.

Though both parties have come under international pressure to end their dispute, neither self-declared interim president, Ali Mahdi, nor Gen. Mohamed Farah Aideed has shown any willingness to compromise on claims to the leadership. Despite this standoff -- and the prospect that clan-based rivalry could spread fighting to other parts of the country, a new report from the Congressional Research Service in Washington strikes one positive note. "Although the Somali conflict may seem unresolvable, most observers find the character of the Somali culture to be forgiving and compromising," says the author, Theodros S. Dagne, an international relations analyst.

The recent effort to breath life into the Mozambique peace process was spearheaded by President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe and Quett Masire of Botswana, who held a day of discussions with the Mozambican rebel leader, Afonso Dhlakama, to persuade him to agree to a cease-fire and speed movement toward a comprehensive peace accord with the government of President Joaquim Chissano. In the meeting, which was also attended by the U.S. ambassador to Botswana, David Passage, Dhlakama agreed to end his attempts to delay the peace talks underway in Rome. In exchange, he asked for a meeting with Chissano.

But the significance of the outcome is uncertain, since Dhlakama has backed down from previous pledges, including a commitment in an April meeting with U.S. Assistant Secretary of State Herman Cohen to move cease-fire discussions to the top of the agenda in Rome.

The Africa Watch report, funded by the J. Roderick MacArthur Foundation, examines the war and the government's political reform program and accuses both the army and the rebels of "indiscriminate killings of civilians," although the report concludes that "the largest massacres have been carried out by Renamo.

Military abuses and human rights violations in combination have resulted in "reducing much of Mozambique's population to a state of chronic famine," Africa Watch says.-30-


LOAD-DATE: July 20, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


183 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


AUGUST 17, 1992


Zaire Ruler Tussles with Democracy Forces


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 600 words


Zaire's President Mobutu Sese Seko has complained privately to foreign ambassadors that if the country's national conference does not change its tack, he will overstep its authority and head straight to elections.

Mobutu, at his request, met with the ambassadors of the United States, France and Belgium, Zaire's former colonial ruler, in mid August. He told them the conference's proposals for a transition period prior to elections were unacceptable, according to sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. Mobutu is said to favor a one-year transition rather than the 18-month to two-year period proposed by the opposition. 

The president was infuriated earlier this month when the conference, a gathering of representatives from Zaire's civic, church and political groups, decided to revert to the country's old name, the Congo. Mobutu discarded that name in 1971 in favor of his personal choice, Zaire.

The government threatened to set up its own constitutional commission and blacked out transmission of the forum -- which was being broadcast live on state-run television. But broadcasts resumed and the conference decided to include its proposed name change in a constitutional referendum.

Since promising in November 1990 to hand over power to a democratically elected government, Mobutu has played his opponents off one another to maintain control of Zaire behind the scenes. His current presidential term expired last December.

The sources say Mobutu feels humiliated by the conference and its president, Roman Catholic Archbishop Monsengwo Pasinya, who received an unusually high-level welcome during a visit to Washington last month seeking support for the democracy process.

Herman Cohen, U.S. assistant secretary of state for African Affairs, at the end of July delivered a letter from President George Bush urging Mobutu to allow the conference to proceed peacefully.

American officials say the letter was stronger than one Bush sent to Mobutu last March, urging reopening of the conference, which the government had suspended.

This month, conference executives have been interviewing candidates for a prime minister to replace Mobutu's appointee, Nguza Karl-i-Bond.

The sources say Mobutu told the ambassadors he would not accept a prime minister who is from Zaire's Kasai region because it would inflame ethnic tensions in mineral-rich Shaba province -- rival to the Kasai area -- and promote its secession. Opposition leader Etienne Tshisekedi is from Kasai.

The Shaba provincial capital, Lumumbashi, already has experienced student protests and crackdowns by security forces in recent months.

Last year Mobutu appointed Tshisekedi as prime minister but fired him when he defied orders. *


LOAD-DATE: August 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


184 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


AUGUST 17, 1992


Desert Soldier Boosts Sahara Team


SECTION: NEWSMAKER INTERVIEW


LENGTH: 1907 words


This time last year, Col. Albert Zapanta, U.S. Army Reserve, was a man on the spot. A United Nations peacekeeping mission was due in Western Sahara, on Africa's north Atlantic coast, to supervise a September 6 cease-fire. Zapanta was head of the contingent of some 30 Americans assigned to the international force, known as Minurso.

The mission's first task was to monitor the cease-fire between the army of Morocco, which claims the former Spanish colony, and guerrillas of the Polisario Front, who have been fighting for the territory's independence. The UN team also planned to organize a referendum that would allow Saharans to choose between independence or union with Morocco.

But the Moroccan government was stalling. Finally, after a flurry of high-level meetings, UN Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar gave the go-ahead at 9 p.m. on August 29. An advance team of peacekeepers would arrive in Western Sahara by the cease-fire date -- if they could get there. 

Zapanta went into action. Throughout the Labor Day weekend, he notified mission personnel to get ready, plotted logistics, and lobbied Pentagon officials. The U.S. Air Force agreed to fly the group of nearly 50 people -- American and Canadian military personnel and UN civilians -- from Andrews Air Force base directly to the Western Saharan capital, El Aaiun.

"We arrived at 1 o'clock in the afternoon on September 5," Zapanta says. "Obviously, we took the Moroccans somewhat by surprise."

For most of the next six months, Minurso -- which has grown to about 350 people -- sparred with Moroccan officials in an attempt to get deliveries of essential supplies. "We had no equipment," says Zapanta, " and no means of providing food or water other than whatever we could buy." Shelters were "tents we were able to round up and set up in some locations."

While Minurso supplies were blocked at the Moroccan port of Agadir, peacekeeping troops were deployed to remote desert posts. "For four months we never saw the equipment such as our ablution units," says Zapanta. "The comforts to make life habitable were locked in the port of Agadir and the Moroccan authorities were the ones holding it up."

In the beginning, the mission members didn't even have their radios. "There were many, many times that we were not in communication with our team sites, which meant that if somebody got really sick or got hurt, we couldn't evacuate them."

After the radios arrived, the situation improved -- a little. Diarrhea was a constant threat and at least four soldiers got amebic dysentery from the lack of clean water. "Because of the heat, they dehydrated so bad that we almost lost a couple of people," Zapanta says. "Thanks to the superb Swiss medical team, which had a plane, our people were evacuated and stabilized and after about a week or so were able to get back on their feet." Still, Zapanta says, "we were very, very lucky that things did not happen that we couldn't respond to."

Extremes of temperature in the desert was a constant problem. "Toward the beginning of December it became very cold. It was 39 degrees, almost freezing, and our people did not have the capability to keep themselves warm."

About that time, a few supplies filtered through, including vehicles, but the satellite-linked ground positioning systems were kept in port. Zapanta says that being unable to know exactly where you are in the Western Saharan desert is more than an inconvenience. "We would drive for eight or nine hours and never see a live soul, so our people were out there and their lifeline was less-than-adequate equipment." Particularly worrisome were the land mines. "After 17 years of war," Zapanta says, "there were minefields and neither side knew where they were. The shifting sands covered them up."

He says both Morocco and Polisario had casualties from mines. "Here are people who know the area and they are still getting blown up, so you can get a pretty good feeling how we felt. Eventually we got sandbags -- we didn't even get that until January -- so we could put them on the floorboards and at least have some protection."

After about the second month, Zapanta says, the morale of his forces began to plummet. The colonel became concerned, too, about his teams' objectivity. "You started to see a marked animosity towards the Moroccans by the military in the field," he says. "They knew the equipment was blocked in Agadir. They felt that they were being abused and the Moroccans were at fault."

"On the other hand," he says, "where the Polisario didn't have much to give, they did try to give whatever they had."

And where Polisario was cooperative, Morocco was obstructionist. Morocco refused UN observers access to several areas. "There were two instances, in particular," Zapanta says, "where American officers were forcibly stopped at gunpoint and weapons were loaded and cocked." Moroccans threatened to shoot the Americans if they tried to carry out their orders. Moroccans also refused to provide the UN team with their troop positions and strength, as required by the peace agreement.

"The first day we met with Polisario," Zapanta says, "they gave us their order of battle and their troop dispositions." In addition, when Morocco failed to cooperate, Polisario shared its intelligence information with the UN teams. "So we were

able to use what the Polisario gave us to find out where the Moroccans were," Zapanta says. "I thought that was rather interesting."

Zapanta worried that the different attitudes of Morocco and Polisario to the peacekeepers would compromise the impartiality of the mission. Feelings were especially friendly towards Polisario when guerrillas helped Minurso members find shelter and shared food and water with them. "You started to run the risk, in my estimation, where the American soldiers -- and I had to worry particularly about them as well as about the rest of the force -- were starting to skew their attitude in favor of the Polisario. The Polisario were helpful and fairly open and shared what little they had, where the Moroccans were trying to control whatever they could."

Zapanta recommended to his military superiors that the American members of the UN team be rotated out after six months and that a new group be sent to replace them.

Meanwhile, he swung into action again. At Thanksgiving he returned to the U.S. to ask UN authorities for greater support for the mission and to press Moroccan officials at the UN for more cooperation.

The personnel under his command credit him with forcing Moroccan compliance, at least to the extent of allowing supplies out of port faster.

George Pickart, a staff member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, says Zapanta was largely responsible for making it possible for Minurso to function effectively. Although there has been no referendum and the political stalemate persists, the cease-fire has held for a year.

Pickart visited Western Sahara on behalf of the committee chairman, Senator Claiborne Pell (D-RI). The staff report Pickart wrote, which documented Zapanta's descriptions of conditions, drew attention to Minurso's problems and paved the way for Senate hearings on the mission, scheduled for next month. Zapanta will testify.

It is, he acknowledges, a strange role for him to play. He's a military man, not a policy maker, and he has been comfortable with that role. But when he saw political factors interfering with the health and safety of the people under his command in Western Sahara, he felt responsible for solving the problems. He says he'll share with the Senate panel his conclusions about the Saharan deadlock.

"It became very clear to me," he says, "that the United States represents the key country or key element in the whole force and mission. Morocco looks to the U.S. as its strongest and longest-standing ally and friend. Polisario looks to us as the strongest nation and -- when we flew in -- they felt we were the country that made the breakthrough and really began the peace process. So the United States is the country that can make things happen because of its credibility with both sides."

Zapanta concedes that the role of aggressive peacemaker in Western Sahara requires Washington to shed its ambiguity on the democratic process in the region. "I do think you get caught in a dichotomy," he says. "From a strategic, bilateral relationship, the U.S. wants to see a stable Morocco." That has meant, he says, that U.S. officials have backed the idea that "the existing power structure stay intact." King Hassan II of Morocco, one of the world's last absolute monarchs, has staked his throne on holding onto the phosphate-rich Western Sahara.

On the other hand, says Zapanta, "as part of the UN, we want to see self-determination for the Western Sahara, so we backed the peace plan and the referendum." The two views, he says "are not exactly in concert with one another, and so the U.S. finds itself in a rather tough position."

In the long term, Zapanta believes, the U.S. will be best served if "we as a country do back the peace plan. And so I think we want to see the referendum go forward." Zapanta believes that the monarchy is so determined to hold onto Western Sahara that some negotiated compromise will be necessary before a vote is possible.

That won't be easy. Morocco and Polisario remain far apart on criteria for voter registration. Polisario accuses Morocco of flooding the territory with Moroccans to pack the ballot boxes in the king's favor. Morocco denies it.

On August 11, Morocco announced that it will hold its own elections, including balloting in Western Sahara, during the first week of September. Diplomats regard the move as a ploy to preempt the UN-supervised vote. *

Africa News


AUGUST 17, 1992


Freed Ivorian Opposition Leader Wants Dialogue With Government


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 507 words


Abidjan, Cote d'Ivoire by Richard Nyberg for Africa News Service

The leader of the opposition Ivorian Popular Front (FPI), released after serving over five months in prison, is calling on the government to share power with its rivals.

Cote d'Ivoire legalized opposition political parties in 1990. FPI leader Laurent Gbagbo ran against President Felix Houphouet-Boigny in presidential elections that year but lost badly. 

"We have proposed nothing," Gbagbo said upon his release. "We are open to all forms of discussion. We want to make serious propositions."

He blamed Cote d'Ivoire's disastrous economic situation on the ruling Democratic Party (PDCI). France earlier this month granted its former colony a $ 200 million loan to help repay arrears on loans from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

Gbagbo and 74 others were jailed February 18 after a protest march they organized in Abidjan ended in rioting. President Felix Houphouet-Boigny introduced an amnesty law July 24, which was adopted by legislators five days later. A jubilant crowd of about 9,000 supporters welcomed his release at a rally August 9 held in a sports stadium.

The FPI leader, defeated in his bid for the presidency in 1990, said his party and other opposition groups are prepared to sit down and talk to the government, which is dominated by the PDCI. The ruling party holds 165 of the National Assembly's 175 seats.

So far, no plans have been made for discussions between the two sides. But PDCI Secretary-General Laurent Dona-Fologo told the government daily, Fraternite Matin, that his party is ready to talk. "We are in favor of opening dialogue," he said.

Diplomats here say it is too early to speculate on the strength the fragmented opposition might bring to negotiations. The FPI is exploring a merger with the smaller Ivorian Workers' Party (PIT), led by Francis Wodie.

"We have formed two delegations which are in the process of discussing the possibility," Gbagbo said.

Others freed under the new amnesty include student leader Martial Ahipeaud and human rights leader Rene Degne Segui. They say they will continue to fight for their causes, despite the risk of being returned to prison under an "anti-vandalism" law enacted along with the amnesty. *

Africa News


AUGUST 17, 1992


Ivorians Fear Violent Crackdown on Crime Wave


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1254 words


ABIDJAN, Cote d'Ivoire Cindy Shiner for Africa News Service Comlan Dossou lay bleeding on the floor of the Punch Coco Number One dance club when he reached into his back pocket in a desperate attempt to save his life.

His parents, Gregoire and Monkoule Dossou, were at home a few blocks away and heard the gunshots. On a street corner six hours later, neighbors would tell them what happened. Newspapers the next morning would show them. 

As his friends tell it, Comlan was trying to give police his student identity card when they shot him again, this time fatally. The 14-year-old was among 10 people gunned down at the club that Sunday night by units of Abidjan's newly formed Anti-Crime Brigade, which more and more Ivorians are criticizing as a group of thugs who shoot first and ask questions later.

"They've got to stop crime," said Aime Mian Kadio, a reporter with the opposition La Voie newspaper, who is investigating the shootings. "But killing is not the answer."

Ivorians and expatriates agree that stronger measures to fight crime in Abidjan were needed. Diplomats have complained to the government of President Felix Houphouet-Boigny repeatedly about poor security. The residences of the ambassadors from Cameroon, Gabon, Central African Republic and Nigeria have all been robbed. Two years ago, bandits raiding an Abidjan restaurant gunned down the Italian ambassador to Cote d'Ivoire.

Now many restaurants are deserted in the evening, due to fear of both the bandits and of the eager police who chase them. In the poor areas of the city, where crime hits hardest, many residents are afraid to leave their homes after dark.

In response to the public outcry, the government last year allocated $ 125,000 to support national efforts aimed at curbing crime. Ivorians applaudedthe measures initially, but now appear to fear security forces almost as much as the bandits. Police have killed more than 50 people since beginning an intensive crime sweep in this city of 2 million four months ago. Almost daily, government newspapers such as Ivoir Soir and Fraternite Matin splash gruesome pictures of the latest victims across their pages. Comlan's body appeared on the June 29 front page of Ivoir Soir under a red banner headline: "Cops Strike Ten Times." Next to the photo of Comlan was a photo of the body of a 15-year-old girl, also killed in the shooting. The back page displayed more victims, as well as a gun, knife and grenade seized at the club. Police did not say which of the suspects possessed the weapons.

Ivorian police had staked out the Punch Coco Number One in the Vridi Canal industrial zone of Abidjan for two weeks before making their hit. Ivoir Soir said police had received a tip that a gang of bandits was preparing to rob the home of a rich merchant nearby. Police said the gang members had gone to the bar to drink or take drugs prior to the attack.

Witnesses say seven police from the Anti-Crime Brigade, dressed in civilian clothes, infiltrated the bar that Sunday night. According to authorities, the gang leader threw a grenade at the police. Although it failed to explode, panic caused pandemonium in the crowded, dimly lit night club. By the time calm was restored, 10 people were dead and several others wounded.

La Voie reporter Kadio says it is difficult to know which of the victims, if any, really were bandits. But he said criminals' bodies usually go unclaimed. At least six of the dead at the Punch Coco club, including Comlan, were identified by family or friends.

Police have declared the hit a victory. But the parents of Comlan and the 15-year-old girl angrily deny that their children were bandits.

"For us, it was a job well done. Because of the police, the population has security," said a Security Ministry official who asked that his name not be used. "A young person who is armed and on drugs is just as dangerous as an adult who is armed." The official defended the tough police response to crime. "It's not necessary to kill," he said, "but if they are better armed than the police, you can't let the bandits kill the police."

The war in neighboring Liberia has made arms easier to obtain in Cote d'Ivoire, authorities say. And the country's deepening economic crisis is pushing more people, many of them impoverished immigrants, to use the weapons. West Africa magazine says 60% of Cote d'Ivoire's criminals are not Ivorians.

As the economic center of West Africa, Cote d'Ivoire attracts immigrants from the nearby countries of Ghana, Mali, Guinea, Liberia, Togo, Benin and Burkina Faso -- home to Comlan's family before they moved south. Cote d'Ivoire's population doubled to 12.6 million between 1975 and 1990, including about 2.5 million migrant workers.

The country's faltering economy cannot support the burgeoning population. Unemployment has risen sharply. Foreign debt is estimated at $ 15 to$ 17 billion and the state commodities marketing board owes almost $500 million to exporters of cocoa and coffee, the country's leading revenue producers.

The International Monetary Fund last month praised Cote d'Ivoire's economic recovery efforts and pledged further support for the reforms.

But residents of neighborhoods like Vridi Canal see little change. The urban shanty towns seethe with banditry, open sewers and resentment of police harshness. There is a widespread suspicion among Abidjan residents that police are being paid up to $ 400 for each suspected criminal they kill. "The police have become bandits. They're one and the same," said Jacques Arron, a friend of Comlan Dossou, who witnessed the shootings.

Comlan's father says the night of the shootings was "real terror." He and his wife turned off the lights and crouched on the floor of their tiny home when they heard the gunfire. "The police can't just kill people like that, like you kill a chicken," he says. His wife sat nearby, virtually catatonic for an hour, raising her eyes only to acknowledge a parting visitor.

Dossou said he has filed a complaint to police about the death of his son and has visited the authorities repeatedly to request information about the shooting. "Everything now depends on what the government does," he says.

"He was the future of my home," he says of Comlan, the oldest son of nine children. "He was my light, completely. For the rest of my life I will never see that light again in my house." *


LOAD-DATE: August 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


AUGUST 17, 1992


Famine Hits Zimbabwe Breadbasket


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Bulawayo, Zimbabwe, from Richard Nyberg for Africa News Service Signs of the famine stalking southern Africa are starkly visible in this southwest corner of Zimbabwe. Drought has withered the region's primary corn-producing fields, threatening commercial livestock and water supplies.

In Bulawayo, water is tightly rationed. The main reservoir reportedly holds only five percent of its capacity, and city taps run just two hours a day. Public anxiety is growing at the prospect of layoffs for thousands of workers -- such as those on irrigation projects -- whose work depends on adequate water supplies. 

The price of cornmeal, the area's staple food, has shot up in response to the shortages. "Malnutrition now has become one of the highest causes of hospitalization in the country," says Health Minister Timothy Stamps. "People, particularly children, are literally dying due to lack of food."

Waves of drought refugees squatting near the railway station in Gweru, 150 miles to the northeast have overloaded municipal sanitation services, increasing the risk of cholera.

As feed costs rise, ranchers are unloading cattle at bargain prices to thin their herds. Western development officials in the capital, Harare, predict that as many as 2 million of the nearly 4.5 million cattle owned by communal peasant herders may die before the next rains are due in November.

Over 200 cattle a month are dying already in Bikita, according to district counselor Noah Makunde. Makunde has asked the government to subsidize loans for farmers to purchase tractors, to offset the anticipated shortage of animals to till the soil for the next planting season.

The crisis has been a shock to a country accustomed to exporting grain. Critics of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund say the two agencies encouraged Zimbabwe to sell its reserve stocks of grain last year to earn money to meet debt payments. Over one million tons of surplus corn was sold -- enough to meet this year's shortfall for eight months. And there are widespread public complaints that the government of President Robert Mugabe could have staved off tragedy by prompt action when the threat of shortages became apparent as early as last October. Many here believe that although drought created a problem, poor policy planning led to the current disaster.

Whatever the cause, Zimbabwe is now totally dependent on commercial food imports. Nearly two million tons of corn, wheat, sorghum, rice and sugar are needed before the earliest possible harvest next June. *


LOAD-DATE: August 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


188 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


AUGUST 17, 1992


Drought Dampens Africa's Economic Prospects


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1800 words


 

Hopes of accelerating economic growth in Africa this year are being dashed by a widespread drought in nearly 20 countries.

Already, tens of thousands are dead and the livelihoods of millions more are being destroyed as the drought threatens to undermine already difficult economic reform efforts.

Analysts say growth in the continent in 1992 will now probably fall below the predicted 3.5 percent range earlier forecast and could drop to less than 2.5 percent. The final outcome will depend on whether rains fall later this year and on the faltering pace of economic recovery in industrial countries, where slower than expected growth is further adding to fears for growth in Africa.

Economists agree that growth must be sustained at four to six percent if living standards are to rise even minimally during the 1990s. 

With the economic impact of the drought likely to extend through 1993, World Bank and International Monetary Fund (IMF) officials warn that economic reform programs risk being derailed unless additional funding is made available to offset the wider economic consequences on affected countries. "Steps will need to be taken to safeguard the implementation of IMF-supported programs," IMF Managing Director Michel Camdessus told the April meeting of the Fund's Interim Committee.

With reforms already hurting living standards, countries are facing mounting political instability as they try to adhere to often unpopular adjustment programs. Many programs are already being modified. "Any new government is in danger of being swept away; any old (government) is likely to feel forced to Ttighten up' in the face of the very real threats to social and political order, as well as to itself," says Professor Reginald Green, an adviser to the Southern African Development Coordination Conference (SADCC).

In a May 26 appeal on behalf of SADCC, Botswana's President Sir Ketumile Masire warned that the drought was not only putting lives at risk, "but will also wreak havoc on the economic stability" in several countries.

In a series of appeals over the last three months, the UN has called for some $ 2 billion in emergency assistance for over 40 million people facing famine in 16 southern and eastern African countries. Drought has also caused large crop losses in Morocco, the UN Food and Agriculture Organization has warned, while natural and political factors are causing severe food shortages in Liberia, Madagascar, Rwanda, Sierra Leone, Togo and Zaire.

The scale of humanitarian needs will further strain already tight aid budgets. Most of the aid requested is in the form of food shipments, with some funding directed to meeting health and transport bills, but international agencies argue that action is also needed to minimize the longer-term economic impact of the drought. The IMF has already supplemented Mozambique's enhanced structural adjustment facility (ESAF) by $ 21 million and granted new credits for Lesotho to help compensate for the impact of drought. Additional funds could follow for other affected countries, such as Malawi and Zimbabwe.

Similarly, the World Bank in June approved $ 310 million in loans for four southern African countries -- Malawi, Mozambique, Zambia and Zimbabwe. Further funding for the four could come from redirecting or accelerating disbursements from existing bank credits and from additional bilateral sources.

If rains fall later this year, this strategy should cope with the situation in southern Africa, bank officials say, pointing to the underlying strength of most economies. But the situation is very different in the Horn, where there has been a slower donor response to emergency appeals and economies are weaker. A combination of civil war, political problems and disagreements over economic policies is both thwarting relief efforts in many areas and keeping the IMF and World Bank from marshaling longer-term economic assistance.

Only Sudan -- where agricultural production is sharply up -- is expected to show growth this year. For Kenya, economic growth in 1991 was already a disappointing 2.2 percent, George Saitoti, vice president and finance minister, announced in his June budget. It could drop closer to one percent this year, according to Nairobi sources, as the government battles economic and political problems. Drought is compounding this situation, adding to food import costs. Low water levels have already led to power shortages, shutting down factories and further raising the import bill as water-generated energy is replaced by oil.

While the Horn gives the greatest cause for immediate concern, it is the impact of drought on southern Africa which has altered most dramatically the economic picture for Africa this year. Relatively fast growing economies like Botswana, Lesotho and Swaziland are badly affected. Malawi, Zambia and Zimbabwe, which were expecting growth in the range of two to four percent, have also been hit hard. According to government and World Bank estimates, Malawi's gross domestic product (GDP) could fall by some four percent this year, Zambia's by more than six percent and Zimbabwe's by as much as nine percent.

Agricultural output has fallen by up to 60%, and the IMF puts the cost of food imports alone for the region at between $ 800 million and $1.2 billion. Green puts the cost higher, at $ 1.775 billion, with an additional $500 million in transport and distribution costs. Zimbabwe has announced a $ 946 million Emergency Drought Relief and Recovery Program. For Malawi, Mozambique and Zambia alone, the bank estimates drought-related financing requirements in 1992-1993 at $ 800 million.

On top of food losses -- and the consequent surge in import requirements -- reduced crops for cotton, sugar and palm nuts will hit export earnings as well. In Zimbabwe, industrial output will be badly affected by a shortage of cotton for the important textile sector, threatening jobs as well as earnings. The government is moving to make foreign exchange available to firms to enable them to import cotton. This will further worsen the country's balance of payments -- the current deficit could climb close to $ 1 billion thisyear from last year's level of under $ 700 million.

Rapidly rising prices are accelerating inflation rates, while jobs and livelihoods disappear as factories close and farms fail. Countries like Zimbabwe are beginning to experience increased migration to the towns as thousands flee the devastation in rural areas, only to threaten to overwhelm already inadequate housing, health and sanitation facilities.

In many countries funding is geared to making sure that smallholder farmers have both the resources and the incentive to resume production quickly. Referring to Zimbabwe, where smallholders now account for 60% of marketed maize, one official commented: "we must insure this success story isn't put at risk." This strategy also includes greater emphasis on the provision of water. Zambia has already asked donors to fund a thorough review of the country's water resources with a view to developing more small-scale sources.

Bank officials say their latest fast-disbursing credits are to ensure that meeting the costs of the drought does not drain funds from ongoing adjustment efforts. But implementing tough adjustment measures is proving increasingly difficult and politically dangerous as the consequences of the drought further hit already precarious standards of living. Planned targets for reducing balance of payments and budget deficits -- including those for state-run industries -- are being raised to reflect the need for increased spending. With inflation accelerating, plans to remove price controls are being delayed and reductions in subsidies slowed. In Zambia, for example, the last subsidy on maize -- on roller meal -- is to remain for the time being.

In Zimbabwe there has been strong criticism of the running down of the country's large maize stockpiles in recent years. Bank officials agree some strategic stocks are necessary, but argue that carrying stocks sufficient to deal with drought does not make economic sense. "A country needs financial reserves, not large grain reserves," one comments.

The bank expects most economies in southern Africa to show significant recovery in 1993, though the lingering effects of drought will mean that, at best, it will be 1994 before economies make up all the ground lost in the recent months.

Funding is coming through for most southern African countries, though Malawi still faces some shortfall, in part because of donor concern over human rights issues. This is also true for Kenya, while disagreement over economic policies and civil unrest will prevent anything but the most basic emergency assistance going into countries such as Ethiopia, Liberia, Somalia and Zaire. Sudan has recently undertaken a series of economic reforms, including large devaluations of the Sudanese pound, but a combination of disagreement with the IMF on the size of the budget deficit and with bilateral donors over human rights issues is preventing their receipt of most economic aid.

Low and even negative economic growth, therefore, is likely to plague a significant number of African countries, while even for the more resilient economies of southern Africa, the impact of drought effectively means two lost years in the battle for sustained growth. *

Roy Laishley is managing editor of Africa Recovery, from which this article is reprinted.


LOAD-DATE: August 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


189 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


AUGUST 17, 1992


American Families Adopt African Children


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1920 words


by Karen Lange * Africa News Service

Across five thousand miles, two continents and racial and cultural divides, Cheryl Shotts of Indiana, saw a young African nomad on television and wanted to be his mother.

"Diane Sawyer was doing a story on famine in a country called Mali, which I had never heard of," Shotts says of that day in 1985 when she saw Mohammed's face on "60 Minutes." "She interviewed a boy for 18 seconds, and I don't know why, but I immediately felt he was my son and I had to find him."

Shotts was newly married then, with three grown children from a previous marriage. She and her husband, Charlie, were determined to adopt Mohammed. 

They called the State Department, the United Nations, the Malian Embassy, the Peace Corps and the International Committee of the Red Cross, but made no progress. Charlie Shotts took a six-month unpaid leave of absence and the couple used up $ 5,000 in savings and borrowed another $7,000 to continue the search.

When they finally found him, Mohammed was a 13-year-old street kid, living off his wits and the kindness of strangers. He had a gift for making friends who helped him survive, including a dozen members of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers who were stationed in Mali. The arrival of the Shottses in his life also gave him a family.

Mohammed flew with Charlie Shotts from the Mali town of Gao, near Timbuktu to Indianapolis, Indiana -- and Americans for African Adoptions was born.

The agency that the Shottses established to help other people do what they had done grew out of the Sahel drought of a decade ago. The famine that ravaged northwest Africa disrupted traditional patterns of life and left thousands of children to fend for themselves.

Although still small, the Shottses' agency has expanded and has contributed significantly to the trickle of children leaving Africa for new homes with American parents.

Adoptions from abroad account for an estimated one-third of all adoptions in the United States. But in fiscal 1991, adoptions from Africa accounted for only 41 of 9,008 international adoptions, according to the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service.

Since 1985, Americans for African Adoptions has placed 59 children from Ethiopia and Mali with American families. That number will rise to 69 in October, when Cheryl Shotts returns to Ethiopia for two 10-month-old babies, the agency's youngest adoptees yet, and eight other children.

With only a home office and without salaried staff, the agency is struggling to place about 350 children. They come from as far apart as Liberia, on the west coast, where two years of war has orphaned many youngsters, and Uganda, in east Africa. Shotts says she hopes to overcome reluctance from prospective parents due to fears of HIV, the virus that causes AIDS.

In addition to seeking families for the youngsters, the agency is looking for sponsors for children awaiting adoption. Cheryl Shotts says it costs from $ 25 to $35 monthly to support children in their own countries until adoptions can be arranged.

So far all the couples adopting through Americans for African Adoptions have been white. That fact has led to criticism from some who believe that black children should be placed only with black families.

The National Association of Black Social Workers (NABSW) issued a statement in 1972 against transracial adoption that caused most agencies to abandon the practice, according to Elizabeth Bartholet, a Harvard Law School professor and the author of, "Where Do Black Children Belong?: The Politics of Race Matching in Adoption," published in a recent volume of the University of Pennsylvania Law Review.

"Black children belong -- physically, psychologically and culturally -- in black families, in order that they receive the total sense of themselves and develop a sound projection of their future," the social workers' statement says. "Black children in white homes are cut off from the healthy development of themselves as black people."

Twenty years later, the NABSW maintains its position. A May 1992 Association report says African American children raised in white families will not learn to feel positive about their race or receive the skills necessary for coping with racism.

The Child Welfare League also believes adoptions should be arranged within the same race and same culture, although it thinks there are times when international or transracial adoptions are necessary, says spokesperson Joyce Johnson.

Cheryl Shotts says she sees the placements as "transcultural" rather than transracial and believes black families would also have a difficult time bridging the cultural gap. "These are not African American children; they're African children," she says.

Shotts has received a letter from a black social worker accusing her of committing genocide, and she was asked to leave a minority caucus she tried to attend during a Washington, DC, adoption conference in 1990.

Bartholet, an advocate of lowering barriers against transracial adoption in the United States, writes that a review of studies on the practice shows that black children placed in white homes adjust well, seem fully integrated into their adoptive families and develop strong senses of racial identity and self-esteem.

Shotts says of the 59 children that Americans for African Adoptions has brought to this country, only two have experienced serious adjustment problems.

She says the failure of her agency to recruit black families to adopt African children is not for lack of trying. She says she has done dozens of interviews with radio and television stations, including those reaching predominantly African American audiences.

Although she will keep trying to broaden her outreach to potential parents, Shotts argues that the children placed by Americans for African Adoptions cannot wait until the agency finds African American adoptive families. "We're talking about kids who are going to starve to death," she says.

Taye Gemeda, an Ethiopian social worker who helps the program locate children who need homes, says an adoptive parent's race is not an issue for him.

"The children have nothing to eat, they have nothing to wear," he says. "Americans for African Adoptions is saving lives."

"We figured there weren't any other kids who needed us more," says Temple Moorehead, a South Carolina elementary school teacher who, with her husband, Kevin, adopted a 3-year-old Ethiopian girl and a 7-year-old Ethiopian boy through the Shottses' agency. "We don't know (whether) they would have survived if they'd stayed (in Addis Ababa)," Moorehead says. "This is the best thing we ever did."

Charlie and Cheryl Shotts encourage adoptive parents to keep their children's African names, learn about the countries their children are from, and expose the children to Africans and African activities, Shotts says.

The Mooreheads have hung Ethiopian baskets on the walls of their children's rooms and bought books on the country. They stayed up late with their son, Ismael, to watch Ethiopians compete in the Olympics. Now, Temple Moorehead says, the family plans to move to Virginia, nearer to Washington, DC, where they can have more contact with Ethiopians and Ethiopian food and culture.

"I was scared," Ismael Moorehead says of how he felt when he first arrived in the United States. He says he stopped being afraid when he learned English. After 16 months in the United States, Ismael speaks fluent English, is learning to read and shows great promise in math, his mother says.

Ismael says he misses Ethiopia "a little bit" and will return there on visits.

The agency's long-term goal is that the adopted children return to Africa to help the continent, Shotts says. One boy adopted from Mali, who required 46 surgeries to repair damage to his face, wants to go back to the country of his birth as a plastic surgeon, she says.

Cheryl Shotts admits that caring for any child is a challenge and that adopting impoverished children who have experienced massive trauma is particularly intimidating. But she is passionately insistent that the effort pays off for everyone involved.

The Shottses' son, Mohammed, had some vague ideas of what to expect of life in the United States from his contacts with Americans. But years spent in the streets and in refugee camps, without parents or schooling, left him unprepared for life among American teenagers. "He could speak six languages," says Cheryl Shotts, "but he didn't know how to hold a pencil. He didn't know red from blue or how to tell time."

It took five moves from school to school before Mohammed found one -- a private, Jesuit institution -- where he felt comfortable and able to thrive. Now he is doing well academically and says he wants to study political science or international relations. He says his aim is to become secretary of state some day. *

Americans for African Adoptions

8910 Timberwood Drive

Indianapolis, IN 46234

phone (312) 271-4567

A six-issue subscription to the African Connection, the agency's newsletter, costs $ 20.


LOAD-DATE: August 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


190 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


AUGUST 17, 1992


National Guard May Join Angolan Election Effort


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 400 words


Washington, D.C.

by Reed Kramer * Africa News Service

The Bush administration is boosting U.S. support for the United Nations monitoring effort in the upcoming Angolan elections. In a letter to UN Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali on August 3, President Bush offered the use of three C-130 airplanes "to assist with demobilization of soldiers and to support the electoral process." 

The president called a successful outcome in Angola a "personal foreign policy priority." The U.S. government, which supported the anti-government Unita movement in Angola with covert military aid, brokered the 1991 peace accord that led to plans for the vote, scheduled for September 29 and 30.

The Pentagon has dubbed the deployment of the planes "Operation Provide Transition." A directive issued by the U.S. Air Force Command in Europe earlier this month calls for "continuous airlift operations" in Angola until the end of September.

Bush said the U.S. already has contributed $ 3 million in humanitarian assistance and about $ 30 million for the transition and electoral process.

The Defense Department also is considering the dispatch of National Guard units to help transport approximately 1,000 international observers who are expected to monitor the process. After completing a cost analysis this month, administration officials will probe the budgets of various agencies in search of the required funds.

During a visit to Washington in July, the UN special representative in Angola, Margaret Anstee, pinpointed Angola's inadequate transportation system as one of the major challenges for the successful implementation of her mandate. The National Guard operation would use helicopters and small fixed-wing aircraft to move monitors from site to site. *


LOAD-DATE: August 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


191 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


AUGUST 17, 1992


Expert Pushes Butter, Not Guns, To Stop Somali Fighting


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 640 words


Several times in recent days she's been interviewed on National Public Radio. The BBC cites her on major international newscasts. The Washington Post quotes her repeatedly.

The message is always the same: fighting in devastated Somalia is largely over the limited supplies of food. The quickest way to ease the conflict and save lives is massive food aid. 

Rakiya Omar, the executive director of the human rights group Africa Watch, jokes that she's becoming a bit tiresome. "At this stage I feel I'm getting to a point where I should just say, THold on, here's my cassette.'"

Then she becomes serious. "No, that's really not true," she says, in a telephone interview from her London office, "because I feel so much outrage that it's not difficult to get very passionate." Omar, who is Somali-born, says a sharp increase in food shipments is the only possibility of feeding Somalia's starving millions without a major military intervention.

Aid groups say that a cease-fire between rival factions in Mogadishu, the capital, has held for five months. But marauding gangs continue to fight over any possible source of food. All movements of relief supplies are now heavily guarded.

Omar says that because food is such a scarce commodity, controlling supplies has become a way to amass power and gain strategic advantage over rivals. She is frustrated that so many diplomatic pronouncements on the Somali crisis focus on security considerations rather than on the need for more food.

"There is no way to move on to addressing the many ills plaguing Somalia unless you take food out of the equation," she says.

"That's why we're saying that we must flood the area with so much food that there'll be no incentive for gangs to divert it or unscrupulous merchants to horde it."

Aid groups in Somalia agree. "Only massive food aid will lessen the attacks on humanitarian aid convoys," said Rony Brauman, president of Medecins Sans Frontieres (Doctors Without Borders), during a recent visit to Washington, D.C. The Washington-based anti-hunger group Bread for the World also is calling for "stepped up action to flood Somalia with food and other urgently needed supplies."

Omar says such supplies include seeds and tools. "Unless people have the means to plant," she says, "we'll be having this same conversation this time next year."

Aid groups say the lack of widespread media scrutiny during months of mounting crisis allowed the world to ignore Somalia. That has changed.

Journalists are competing to cover the story and policy makers have swung into action. In an August 7 letter to UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, signed by 20 members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Congressman Dan Burton (R-IN) asked the UN to send an armed force to see that food aid is distributed to hungry Somalis. "No reasonable action alternative should be ruled out," the letter said.

On August 12, the United Nations announced that it will be sending 500 armed escorts to Somalia to protect relief workers and supplies. *


LOAD-DATE: August 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


192 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 28, 1992


Transition Back on Track


LENGTH: 361 words


In a bid to quell political violence in Togo that has claimed 80 lives since May, pro-democracy forces have forged a compromise agreement with representatives of General Gnassingbe Eyadema, Togo's longtime military ruler.

The county has been in a political limbo for months, since a national democracy conference appointed Joseph Kokou Koffigoh as interim prime minister. The conference stripped most powers from President Eyadema, who has resisted reforms and has maintained control of security forces.

The new agreement returns much of Eyadema's authority but it sets firm dates for democratic elections, which are to follow a September 27 constitutional referendum. Local elections are scheduled for October 11; national representatives are to be chosen on October 13 and 14; and presidential voting is set for December 6 and 20.

To win Eyadema's cooperation, democracy advocates agreed to drop from the new constitution a provision that would have required the president to resign his military post before standing for national office. Eyadema, who has ruled Togo since seizing power in a 1967 coup, says he will be a presidential candidate. The pact also establishes an interim "national unity government," which some fear will give Eyadema loyalists the power to influence election results.

Days after the agreement was reached, security forces detained journalists from the opposition newspaper Forum Hebdo, which had attacked the compromises.

The accord has not yet achieved its aim of ending political violence. The home of opposition leader Ouattara Nguessan was bombed, and the Reuters news agency reported in late September that at least four people have been injured in grenade attacks.


LOAD-DATE: September 28, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


193 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 28, 1992


Lose Some, Win Some


LENGTH: 227 words


In what officials have termed "unfortunate" timing, Namibia took delivery of a new presidential jet just as it was appealing for international aid to deal with a worsening drought. News of the purchase from France of the $ 30-million Falcon 900B for transporting President Sam Nujoma and other government leaders provoked an outcry in local newspapers. The affair also embarrassed the government with donors. Some governments, including Norway, Sweden and Germany, suspended or considered cutting drought relief assistance.

On the plus side of the government's ledger is an apparent breakthrough in sensitive talks with South Africa on the future of a disputed port city. After more than two years of negotiations, South Africa has agreed to joint administration of Walvis Bay, the largest port on Namibia's Atlantic coast. Namibia claims the port, but South Africa -- asserting historical rights to the area -- has retained control since Namibia became independent in early 1990. Namibia hopes a move toward joint administration could lead to a formal hand-over after a period of transition.


LOAD-DATE: September 28, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


194 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 28, 1992


Better Late


LENGTH: 214 words


The international effort to save millions from starvation in Somalia is encountering obstacles that have been made worse by the slow initial response to the crisis. Heavy seasonal rains have slowed relief supplies, flooding potential runways for airplanes and making roads impassable in some of the most destitute parts of the country. Relief workers who sounded the alarm last year had hoped to pre-position food stockpiles before the rain arrived.

Banditry, which has escalated markedly over the past few months as the country plunges deeper into anarchy, also is plaguing relief efforts. The long-delayed arrival in Mogadishu of 500 Pakistani armed guards dispatched by the United Nations is expected to help, but no one believes their presence alone will deter all attacks on food supplies.

Nevertheless, the increased flow of aid and personnel is having an impact, and officials still hope to see a reduction in the death rate as more assistance reaches those in need.


LOAD-DATE: September 28, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


195 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 28, 1992


Abuses


LENGTH: 254 words


Amnesty International has charged Uganda's National Resistance Army with committing atrocities against civilians and making arbitrary arrests. In a mid-September report, Amnesty criticizes rebel groups in northern and eastern Uganda for mutilitating civilians. The report includes victims' accounts.

Ugandan Justice Minister Abu Mayanja says steps have been taken to improve Uganda's human rights record since the National Resistance Movement came to power in 1986. Government officials have responded to charges of human rights injustice by conducting their own investigations and executing army soldiers found guilty of abuses. Amnesty has urged the Ugandan government to halt what it sees as further human rights violations by using execution as a means of deterrence and punishment. The group's officials have asked President Yoweri Museveni's government to address the problem by establishing a formal system of control over its armed forces.

Uganda remains under the shadow of General Idi Amin's legacy of disregard for human rights. Amin, who ruled Uganda for eight years after seizing power in a 1971 coup, is thought to be responsible for over 500,000 deaths.


LOAD-DATE: September 28, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


196 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 28, 1992


Democracy Begins


LENGTH: 347 words


Late last month, Pascal Lissouba became the first democratically elected president of the Congo, replacing Gen. Denis Sassou-Nguesso.

The defeated Sassou-Nguesso said the Congolese "should rally around Lissouba to meet the economic challenges facing us." Last year, witnesses at Congo's national conference on democracy accused the former leader of ordering political assassinations and enriching himself at the public's expense during his 13-year rule. His opponents say the former leader's endorsement of the new president is a ploy to escape prosecution for his crimes.

Within a week of taking office, the new prime minister, Stephane Bongho-Nouarra, named his 28-member coalition government. The Labour Party, which had been the country's ruling and only legal party before the transition began, was originally offered only the education portfolio. However, the new president's party, the Pan-African Union for Social Democracy, holds only 40 of the 125 seats in the nation's new parliament and needed the Labour Party's support to form a new government. When the Labour Party threatened to refuse to take part in the national unity government it received two more ministries.

Following the elections, a group of opposition political parties formed the Union for Democratic Renewal (URD), dedicated to "constructive opposition," according to Bernard Kolelas of the Congolese Movement for Democracy and Integral Development, a member of URD. Kolelas was a candidate for president and had challenged Lissouba's victory with a complaint to Congo's Supreme Court of election irregularities. Kolelas accepted the court's decision to uphold the election, and said that URD "will not constitute an obstacle to Pascal Lissouba and his government."


LOAD-DATE: September 28, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


197 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 28, 1992


Peace Impasse


LENGTH: 347 words


Peace talks in Rwanda have reached a deadlock over the issue of power sharing within a proposed transitional government.

The government has proposed the establishment of a council of ministers headed by a president to serve as the interim executive body until national elections can be held. Representatives of the Rwandan Patriotic Front (RPF) oppose the government's plan and are arguing for the formation of a seven-person presidential council representing all major political parties.

Government officials and RPF representatives earlier agreed to dissolve the parliament and establish a transitional legislature with representation from the RPF. The peace accord that is in the works would allow the immediate formation of an interim legislature and begin the process of organizing elections.

Previous rounds of peace talks led to a cease-fire that went into effect in August and the signing of a protocol of understanding on the rule of law. Tanzanian Minister of Foreign Affairs Ahmed Hassan Diria is mediating the current discussions.

Ongoing peace talks have been held since July 1992, in an attempt to end a 23-month civil war following the RPF invasion of the small central African country in October of 1990. The RPF draws its members largely from the minority Tutsi ethnic group. Tutsi bitterness against the 19-year rule of President Juvenal Habyarimana has risen in recent years, as the government resisted efforts by Tutsi refugees in neighboring Uganda to return home. Thousands of Tutsi have been living in Uganda since the 1960s, when attacks by the majority Hutu group forced them to flee.


LOAD-DATE: September 28, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


198 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 28, 1992


Chihana Chairs


LENGTH: 360 words


Malawi dissident Chakufwa Chihana, awaiting trial on sedition charges, has been named chairman of an internal pressure group for political change. A spokesman for the group, Alliance for Democracy (Aford), said last week that the formation of Aford represents "a major political development in Malawi and brings to an end speculation and anxiety over the lack of a visible pro-democracy movement inside the country." 

Chihana's arrest on sedition charges followed interviews he gave to the international press in July criticizing the government.

Chihana's trial was postponed until October 12, following defense arguments of insufficient time to prepare their case.

A September report by Amnesty International blasts the dictatorial government of President Kamuzu Banda and calls for the release of hundreds of political detainees. An Amnesty spokesperson says the group has received reports of prisoners kept in leg irons and subjected to severe beatings and electric shock, as well as a "frightening pattern of deaths in custody."

Addressing thousands at a public rally in Lilongwe, the capital, last week, Banda announced a program to distribute free corn to hungry Malawians affected by the region's drought. He also called on the international community to help Malawi combat water shortages by supporting a project to drill deep wells throughout the county. Party leaders at the rally pledged support to Banda and said that the people of Malawi would not tolerate "confusionists" to disturb the country's peace and calm.

Banda has released about 60 political detainees this year, but opposition leaders call the move a political ploy to appease aid donors who are critical of Malawi's human rights record.


LOAD-DATE: September 28, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


199 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 28, 1992


Showdown at Shaba


SECTION: DATELINE: AFRICA


LENGTH: 374 words


President Mobutu Sese Seko and opposition leader Etienne Tshisekedi are continuing on their collision course in Zaire, but this time the face-off could come at the polls.

Tshisekedi was named the country's prime minister in August by the Sovereign National Conference, which has been shaping a new democratic structure to replace Mobutu's 27-year authoritarian regime. 

Remaining disagreements between the two sides include a timetable for holding elections. Mobutu wants a vote in six months time; Tshisekedi believes a longer period is required to prepare for a free and fair vote. Both seem convinced they can triumph at the polls.

Nguza Karl-i-Bond, who served as Mobutu's prime minister prior to Tshisekedi's taking office, says he is backing the president and expects him to win. During a visit to Brussels in early September, Nguza told the Belgian News Agency that he expects to return to the prime minister's post as head of a coalition administration After the election.

Since Tshisekedi's selection, Nguza has charged the National Conference with ignoring the wishes of the people of mineral-rich Shaba, his home region. Shaba, formerly known as Katanga, attempted secession in the early 1960s, soon after Zaire's independence from Belgium. The province was the scene of serious unrest in the late 1970s.

In Brussels, Nguza promised to maintain "ferocious and implacable opposition" to Tshisekedi's government. He said continued "exclusion" of the people of Shaba could lead to "a new Yugoslavia or another Liberia."

Democracy advocates in Shaba dispute Nguza's view. They supported Tshisekedi's selection as prime minister and accuse Nguza of trying to stir up secessionist sentiments in Shaba.


LOAD-DATE: September 28, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


200 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 28, 1992


A Hut Is Not a Home


LENGTH: 160 words


You have been leaders in challenging media stereotypes of Africa. Please don't use the word hut. Can't you program your computers to replace every hut with house?

Also, I've kept all my issues of AfricaNews since I first discovered you in 1978. They fit neatly on shelves for quick reference and research. Congrats on the new format, but the new issues are hard to save. Perhaps you could suggest ways for us to store them.

Jo Sullivan

Outreach Director

African Studies Center, Boston University

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


201 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 28, 1992


Wanderers


LENGTH: 147 words


On my return from a trip to Senegal, our airline overbooked the flight and many in our group were forced to stay for an extra week. I think it is appalling that there is such a deficiency in direct-route travel to and from Senegal and other African nations. We have enough black people here and abroad to invest in an airline to have a direct communication line to the continent. We should not have to go around the world to go to Africa.

As a people we wandered out of Egypt, and we are still wandering.

Audrey Walker

St. Albans, NY
