LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


202 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 28, 1992


Stick to Africa


SECTION: LETTERS


LENGTH: 347 words


It seems to me that AfricaNews has become more American-oriented. In the past few issues there have been three instances where I thought, "Wow, this isn't really about Africa, it's about the United States. It serves (white) Americans' image of ourselves."

The first instance was the story about the bicycle trip across Africa (July 20-August 2). This might have been an interesting one-paragraph item, but it scarcely deserved the length it received.

In the issue of August 17-30, the article on Americans' adoptions of Africans reinforced my growing sense that it was white Americans who count. There was a discussion of some of the qualms that African Americans have about transracial adoption, but the article lacked depth of thought as it pursued the story of philanthropic white Americans.

Finally, what is this picture caption?! "Albert Zapanta is national director of Veterans for Bush-Quayle" (August 17-30). The article to which it was attached concerned UN peacekeeping activities in the Western Sahara and relied heavily on interviews with Zapanta. But his role in U.S. politics was irrelevant to the article. What did you mean by putting his partisan activities in such an eye-catching place?

I subscribe to AfricaNews in order to read news of Africa without the chauvinistic bias that pervades other sources such as Newsweek and the New York Times. Please remind yourselves that your journal concerns Africa, not the United States.

Ann P. McNeal

Pelham, MA


LOAD-DATE: September 28, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


203 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 28, 1992


Mozambique Journal: Children at War and Play


SECTION: FORUM


LENGTH: 1560 words


If a new peace agreement holds, one of the world's longest lasting and most destructive wars may be coming to an end. Mozambican President Joaquim Chissano and rebel leader Afonso Dhlakama are scheduled to sign a cease-fire in Rome on October 1, following two years of difficult negotiations.

Mozambicans have endured war almost without interruption since 1964, when the Frelimo independence movement launched a guerrilla campaign to end five centuries of Portuguese presence. The end of Portuguese rule in 1975 brought a brief respite, but the fighting resumed quickly, this time between government forces and Dhlakama's Mozambican Resistance Movement, known as Renamo. The 17-year conflict has resisted repeated efforts at resolution and has been marked by a high level of atrocities.

Renamo was established by the intelligence service of white-ruled Rhodesia, but was handed over to South Africa's security establishment when Rhodesia became independent Zimbabwe in 1980. Renamo's apparent purpose was to undermine Mozambique's support for majority rule in southern Africa. 

Throughout the conflict, Renamo has employed the "systematic use of mutilation and killings and indiscriminate violence," according to a recent study by the human rights group Africa Watch. The study is also highly critical of Mozambican government troops for "significant killings and attacks on civilian targets."

The long period of fighting has taken a grim toll on the country's 16 million people and its rudimentary infrastructure. Now the suffering is being exacerbated by a worsening drought that is engulfing all of eastern and southern Africa. According to Africa Watch, the war has been a "major contributor" to the current famine that threatens the lives of three million people.

One particularly tragic aspect of the Mozambican conflict has been the victimization of children. Tens of thousands have been wounded, many severely, and at least 200,000 have been orphaned.

For many years, human rights groups have tried to mobilize an international response to Renamo's practice of using child soldiers, some as young as ten years old. Thousands of children have been kidnapped by the rebels in the course of the war.

Ruth Minter writes occasional letters about life in war-torn Mozambique.

Today, I came home and found a half-dozen young children deeply engrossed in creating elaborate villages of clay figures -- houses with many well-furnished rooms, with people, animals, cars, a television, a mortar and pestle, beds, chairs, tables, and outside, a soccer field. Very elaborate creative group play -- with zero materials purchased.

Other days the middle-sized or older boys have been absorbed by the construction of elaborate wire cars and trucks with wheels made from the two ends of a coke can tucked together like a lid on a box. The majority of these wire vehicles are equipped with long-shafted steering wheels that the boys use to guide the car as they walk along. Marvelously creative -- using mostly trash found here and there.

There are local varieties of hide-and-seek, dodgeball, jump rope games, marbles, hopscotch. Kites and balls of all sizes are homemade. What is obvious is that poverty is no bar to creativity and the instinct to play and to learn. Many of these children eat only once or twice a day, most are perennially barefoot, many wear what in the United States would be considered rags. There is no money in their homes to buy toys from a store, but the toys they create themselves are astounding.

This is the joyful side of watching children here in Mozambique's capital city. But there are much more painful realities for children here.

Recently I was privileged to translate for a group of visiting Americans when they talked with six boys who have spent time living with Renamo. Three of the children had trained with weapons and had participated in killing and looting. One had herded Renamo's cattle. Two younger boys were used for reconnaissance.

The youngest had shown Renamo the way to his own family's house, where the raiders stole all the belongings and food and forced the boy's mother and other relatives to serve as temporary porters to transport the goods When the child was recaptured by government troops a couple of months later, the troops called the parents in and said they could take the child home. They refused, saying they feared if he were with them, Renamo would come again. So this eight-year-old remains in limbo until social services -- or somebody -- decides what to do with him.

The oldest boy, 15-year-old Zamito -- had been with Renamo for eight years. He was trained in the use of four heavy weapons including AK47 and tank-mounted guns, plus the detonation of chemical bombs, and the use of hand-held weapons such as knives and machetes. He described in detail the layout of the last camp he was in -- on the border with South Africa -- and the presence of South African white soldiers brought in to give the training whenever a new group was there to receive it. He himself was the bodyguard and personal servant of a Renamo commander and always accompanied him on missions.

When the boys were asked if they feared anything while with Renamo, Zamito said, "no, we used a vaccine." When pressed, he explained that the boys' thighs were cut with a razor blade and white powder was rubbed into the cut line "so that we would not be afraid when we had to kill a person, and so we would not tire on long marches." Both Zamito and a 13-year-old boy said they had "wives" while with Renamo. Zamito said his wife was 14 years old, near his own age at the time. He said young women captured by Renamo are given to the soldiers and commanders. The commander he worked for had five women, according to Zamito.

These boys, captured at a young age by Renamo, traumatized or brutalized as they may be, are luckier than their older brothers. Yesterday while calling on a parish-ioner, I learned his wife's absence from church last Sunday was due to the funeral of her nephew, aged 16, kidnapped from Matola, a Maputo suburb, last week, then killed and left by the road. Sixteen is too old to be reliably malleable and apparently Renamo doesn't offer captives many chances to be cooperative.

War, drought, rising food prices because of structural adjustment policies, higher costs for health care and education for the same reason, and desperation to survive all take their toll on children here. A nine-year-old from a family I am close to arrived at my door early one recent morning with a note which said, "Please do you have a bit of corn. We have not eaten for three days." An older brother in his twenties had finally found a job, but after only one week at work had not yet brought home any pay. This same family, which lives in one room under the eaves of a rooftop, has so little money that for three months they have been unable to pay their rent -- about 75 cents a month.

We have listened with desperate hope for word from Rome that the two-year-old peace talks have produced fruit. Meanwhile Renamo attacks continue. Roads remain too vulnerable for relief deliveries. Drought has dried even the beds of major rivers like the Zambezi. Death is a constant reality.

But here in the capital city, although there is poverty and hunger, there is a bit of a cushion from the agony of the countryside -- and the resilience and creativity of the children still joyfully flood our consciousness. Even as we know there is much to do to get beyond the current physical difficulties, both on the ground here and in international circles, it is good to have the children to keep us from being too serious! n

Ruth Minter, a United Church of Christ minister from the United States, teaches at the Rictala Seminary in Maputo, Mozambique. Her work is supported by the United Church Board of World Ministries, Christian Church (Disciples of Christ), and the Presbyterian Church, USA.


LOAD-DATE: September 28, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


204 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 28, 1992


South Africa on the Brink


SECTION: DOSSIER


LENGTH: 2174 words


The South African National Congress (ANC) and the South African government have been scrambling to patch together an agreement that will allow the country to move towards power sharing among competing parties. Both sides appeared to be eager to reach a compromise before a mid-October session of Parliament. The task was complicated by high feelings in the wake of the massacre of at least 28 people in an ANC demonstration on September 7.

In a major interview with the Johannesburg Star on September 15, ANC leader Nelson Mandela adopted a conciliatory tone, asking the government to address his group's concerns about political prisoners, violence in single men's hostels, and the widespread use of a dangerous weapons. Three days later, in a speech to a regional meeting of the ruling National Party, President F.W. de Klerk took a tough approach while behind the scenes, government negotiators held out some promise of concessions. Here are excerpts from the two statements.

Mandela:

My message to the government is: Make good on the undertakings you have given to us and Mr. Cyrus Vance. We are not challenging here, not demanding. It is our deep concerns we have put forward. 

What has happened now is that the negotiations process has lost credibility. You must realize it was a heated debate within the ANC when we decided to suspend armed struggle and to negotiate. But we convinced one another then. Now my people are beginning to say to me: "What was the value? Let's abandon negotiations, they will never be able to take us to our goal."

If Mr. de Klerk can just say to me: "You have expressed your three concerns. I give you my undertaking that I will address them." Just give me an undertaking that (political prisoners) will be released in the next two months. Give me a date on which hostels will be fenced and secure them. Give me an undertaking that within a month or two we will be able to ban dangerous weapons.

I will be able to go back to my people and say: "Look, he has met us. Let us meet him."

When you negotiate you must be prepared to compromise. But that compromise must not compromise your own position. It must be seen as an effort to move forward, to pull South Africa out of this quagmire. Therefore, if the government does something visible to show that they are now prepared to negotiate in good faith, there will be no necessity for mass action. An interim government is going to represent us all, and the ANC is not going to have mass action against itself! We will be in government, the ANC will be fully represented like all other political parties. There will be no question of sanctions. There will be no question of isolating South Africa. South Africa will go back to the United Nations -- we will be saying this. All that will remain will be the arms and oil embargoes, to be lifted as soon as a democratic constitution is accepted. But even on that there can be compromise.

The point is that if an interim government is introduced, these conflicts fall away.

We haven't got much time. The next elections are in 1994. The economy is falling to pieces, and that we cannot afford. I have been talking to businessmen. We have to come up with strategies that give the country and investors hope that we are working together to ensure that our economy is not destroyed.

I have a special interest in this. Of the 7 million unemployed, the overwhelming majority are blacks. We are sitting on a time-bomb. The youths in the townships have had over the decades a visible enemy, the government. Now that enemy is no longer visible, because of the transformation that is taking place. Their enemy now is you and me, people who drive a car and have a house. It's order, anything that relates to order, and that is a very grave situation.

I believe business must take positions. We have said to the government we are prepared for the adoption of the constitution by a two-thirds majority, and we even went up to 70%. The government wanted 75%, and we could not agree. I say to business, take a position. If you think we are wrong, say so. If you think the government is wrong, tell them.

We are well aware of the concerns of whites in this country, which are genuine, if mistaken. We are prepared for checks and balances, but that must be done in a constituent assembly. I would like to remove the concerns of business. There is the potential for cooperation. One has to be very, very careful not to use rhetoric that is going to frighten people, but rather to enable people to have confidence that we have a workable strategy -- however difficult the situation is.

I think business has responded very responsibly during the period of mass action. I have thanked them for that, and I have told my own supporters my view. I said we have had cooperation, and therefore we must avoid any attitudes of hostility or actions which will further damage the economy.

One of the mistakes that has been made by both the ANC and the National Party is that we have embarked on an electioneering campaign while we are negotiating. One party is talking to the other while at the same time trying to undermine that party. Now that destroys that whole atmosphere of negotiations.

But I have explained that we must have free political activity. We can't sit down and fold our arms.

I face a situation in which it becomes increasingly difficult to resist the demands of my people to arm and defend themselves. You know, when I went to Boipatong (site of a June massacre), I was met with placards "Mandela, give us guns". And these were not coming from the youth, but elderly people, members of the branch.

Then I went to the rally, and I went round as I normally do to greet people. And the song they were singing was "Mandela, you behave like a lamb while you are being killed". I had to make a speech there to say I had noted what they were saying.

Now if we don't do something visible to show that we are fighting against oppression, those who are demanding the resumption of the armed struggle are going to prevail. Mass action is actually a peaceful form of channelling the anger of the people -- for us to say we don't need armed struggle, we can make progress through mass action.

You must understand that mass action is being used today throughout the democratic world and by people who have the vote. We haven't got the vote. What else can we do?

De Klerk:

Power sharing includes proportional representation, strongly entrenched devolution of power to strong, autonomous regional governments and local authorities, the distribution of functions, and participation by major important parties in government.

This, power-sharing -- in contrast to the ANC's power-grabbing model -- is what is needed in our complex country.

Implicit in this trend is the need to give individuals and communities more and more scope and freedom to do their own thing within the framework of just laws. The powers of the state should be circumscribed and limited. The state may not smother or suppress the freedom of individuals and communities.

To be able to progress and prosper, a country -- particularly a developing one with a rapidly growing population such as South Africa -- needs stability, as well as new investments and the ability to produce and trade unhindered worldwide.

General declarations of good intentions and vague and fine promises are not enough to restore investor confidence in our country. For that we need tangible and visible proof of stability -- an end to violence, an end to irresponsible incitement and provocation, an end to uncalled-for demonstrations and disruption, an end to continued flirtations with failed Marxist ideas and obsolete economic systems.

The lack of peace and stability is the single negative factor in the country at present. The continuing violence and disruptive mass actions are eating away like a cancer at the security and welfare of all South Africans. They have brought our economy practically to a standstill. They are bedeviling the negotiating process. They are hanging over us like a dark cloud. For this the National Party and the government cannot be blamed. We reject the torrent of ANC propaganda to that effect.

I do not wish to use this platform simply to launch political attacks on opponents. For that, conditions are too serious. It has become time, however, to deal with the distorted perceptions of the causes of violence and with the suspicions being cast on the government and the National Party.

Scientific analysis of the violence plaguing our country clearly shows where the blame really lies. It is not the nationalists who frequently invite violence through demonstrations and mass actions -- it is the ANC/SACP/Cosatu alliance that is doing so. It is not the nationalists who assault, intimidate and murder political opponents -- it is the supporters of the other parties who are doing that.

Violence will not end as long as there are important political leaders who condone it or encourage it, either directly or indirectly. Violence will not end as long as vengeance and retribution remain part of the vocabulary of certain political parties. Violence will continue as long as political intolerance persists.

Today, the National Party is saying to every political party and organization that is guilty of these things. Turn your backs on these things. You are playing with fire.

Today the National Party is reiterating once again: We shall not let ourselves be intimidated. We know what we want and stand by it. The aims to which we are aspiring are fair and just and offer hope and progress to all South Africans. Our plan is to be able to bring peace to all and will do so. Our proposals guarantee just, democratic participation by everybody.

I wish to conclude on a positive note -- not merely because it is politically expedient, but because there is cause for optimism.

The National Party will continue to plan and work calmly and purposefully to be the stable anchor in a sea of political unrest; to take the lead by means of solution-oriented initiatives. As long as you, the leaders of the party in every community keep our party strong and expand it, we shall ensure that our country and all its people will be shareholders in long-term prosperity and peace. Then, however, we have to stand firm, keep our courage and not go off course.

That course is aimed at:

South Africa First; and

Justice, as God wills it. n


LOAD-DATE: September 28, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


205 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 28, 1992


South Africa


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Meanwhile, within Africa, there are high hopes for the strengthening of economic integration through various regional organizations. Southern Africa in particular is seen as having a bright future, once South Africa makes the transition to a non-racial democracy.

In a move that seemed to indicate a welcome spirit of conciliation, delegations from both the African National Congress (ANC) and the South African government attended the annual meeting. Led by Derek Keys, minister of finance for the government, and Trevor Manuel of the ANC's economic planning department, the two delegations held extensive consultations with staff from the bank and the fund and with leading financial officials from around the world. South Africa has no current program with the bank or the fund, but officials from both institutions meet regularly with representatives of the major political forces inside South Africa to map out economic policies for the future. 

Many African delegates hope a political accord can be reached soon, because they see South Africa as a powerful engine of economic growth for much of the continent. In the words of the African Development Bank's Babacar Ndiaye, "the African tree has deep roots in southern Africa," and he urged African leaders to promote economic cooperation and to realize their comparative advantage as a region.

When the two South African delegations appeared together at a private breakfast on the first day of the meeting, however, sharp divisions emerged between Manuel and Keys over the issues of state intervention in the economy and political violence in the country. Keys's comments about opening the economy, encouraging the private sector and ending the "economic civil war" pleased European bankers and other potential investors in the audience, but Manuel's remarks made it clear that the two sides still have a long way to go before agreeing on how to manage the economy. Manuel emphasized the need for state action to redress the economic inequities of apartheid, and criticized the apartheid regime for not doing enough to end the violence, leading some to wonder how soon this engine of growth will leave the station. n


LOAD-DATE: September 28, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


206 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 28, 1992


Economic Regionalization


LENGTH: 320 words


 

For African countries, as with most countries in the developing world, the growing trend towards regionalization in the global trading system is a two-edged sword.

On the one hand, there is the hope that unified markets in the industrialized world will improve export opportunities for poorer countries. On the other hand, many industrialized countries continue to maintain stiff barriers to imports from developing countries in order to protect politically important industries and farmers. Some African delegates are concerned that the emergence of regional economic blocs in Europe, North America and the Pacific Rim could raise new barriers to their products.

"While we welcome the emerging phenomenon of regional associations, we must not allow a situation to arise in which this phenomenon results in discriminatory trade blocs," said Mohammed Berrada of Morocco.

In this context, African delegates joined other delegates from the developing world in calling for "the speedy and successful completion" of the Uruguay round of negotiations of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (Gatt). Although critics of Gatt talks say the agreement will undermine environmental standards and workers' rights, many African governments hope the accord will improve their market access and promote their export potential. They also see it as an essential complement to their own efforts to lower trade barriers. The G-24 communique expresses concern "that the efforts of many developing countries to liberalize their economies have not met with an adequate response on the part of industrial economies."


LOAD-DATE: September 28, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


207 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 28, 1992


Debt a Concern


LENGTH: 667 words


 

African delegates to the annual meeting say that they will continue to press demands for greater debt relief. In contrast to Latin America, where the debt crisis is easing, African countries remain heavily burdened by high levels of debt, most of which is owed to international financial institutions and official donors in the developed world. The delegates say that payments on the debt consume a large proportion of their countries' export earnings and create a serious obstacle to economic development. Africans argue that in certain cases, such as Poland and Egypt, donor countries have been willing to make a much more generous debt reduction than for most countries in sub-Saharan Africa. 

"We all know that a heavy debt overhang diverts investable resources to debt servicing, and reduces the incentive to invest," said Babacar Ndiaye, president of the African Development Bank. "Mexico's tremendous advances in recent years and the vibrant entrepreneurial activity that has fueled these advances are, in no small measure, due to the significant easing of the external debt burden of that economy."

Since most of Africa's debt is owed to official creditors, the principal means for debt reduction is through the Paris Club, a group of major Western governments that handles debt negotiations. A few countries, such as Zambia, have been able to take advantage of the relatively generous "enhanced Toronto terms" for debt repayment established in December 1991, but those terms are limited to the poorest and most severely indebted countries, and some Western officials concede that this will not end the debt crisis in sub-Saharan Africa, particularly for middle income countries.

A few African countries have managed to cope with their debts. Finance Minister Bernard Chidzero of Zimbabwe, which has a diversified economy of agriculture and industry, says his country is one of the fortunate few. "We are paying all our debt; it is not a burden on us," Chidzero says. But he says that poorer countries, whose economies tend to be based on one or two commodities, are in serious trouble. "The poorest countries in Africa," he says, "will require an imaginative program of debt rescheduling, cancellation, and interest-rate reduction."

Adding to Africa's debt difficulties, Russia has initiated moves to collect on the former Soviet Union's loans to developing countries. Pyotr Aven, Russia's minister for foreign economic relations, told reporters at a press conference here that the total debt owed to the former Soviet Union by its allies and customers in the developing world is an estimated $ 142 billion, twice the amount of the Soviet debt still owed to the developed world. Aven said that the amount owed by such African countries as Angola, Mozambique and Zambia is "in the range of billions."

Those figures are sharply disputed by delegates whose countries borrowed from the Soviets. Africans and others say that the Russians have inflated the value of the debt by ignoring the precipitous decline in the value of the ruble. Indian financial officials, for example, say that their debt to Russia is less than $ 3 billion, much less than the Russian estimate of $10 billion.

Whatever the results of the debate over numbers, Russia's attempts to collect on its loans have added a troublesome new dimension to Africa's debt crisis.


LOAD-DATE: September 28, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


208 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 28, 1992


African Delegates Resist Marginalization At World Bank, IMF Meeting


LENGTH: 720 words


Washington, DC by William Acworth for Africa News Service

As financial leaders from around the world arrived here in September for the annual meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF), African delegates expressed concern that their countries will be pushed aside in the race for economic growth.

The new republics of the former Soviet Union, which have become full members of the bank and the fund, represent tremendous new competition for the limited resources available for development. Russia, Ukraine, and 12 other former Soviet republics expect to receive billions of dollars in aid from industrialized nations over the next few years, as they undergo the process of market-oriented economic reform. 

Africans at the annual meeting say that they are ready to welcome the new members, but they are concerned that the world's attention and resources will be diverted from the problems of Africa.

"This year's meeting is the first truly global meeting," says George Saitoti, Kenya's vice president and minister of finance. "For the first time in history, there is no demarcation between East and West. What that means is that the focus is now being put on the incoming states. If Africa is not careful, it is going to be marginalized."

IMF projections show that Africa will continue to lag behind other regions of the developing world, due to the effects of drought, low commodity prices, and sluggish world demand for its products. Despite more than ten years of painful structural adjustment designed to reform African economies, World Bank President Lewis Preston concedes that Africa will be "the only region of the world where poverty is projected to increase by the turn of the century."

Yet the prospects for increased aid to support the poorer countries of sub-Saharan Africa are growing increasingly dim. IMF officials say that the overall level of development aid by the bank and the fund will rise over the next few years, as a result of the new programs in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union. But the officials say that it is "highly unlikely" that aid levels for Africa will rise in real terms.

Even more ominous, in Africa's view, is the decreasing support by the donor countries for concessional aid -- money loaned at low interest rates with long repayment schedules. World Bank and IMF officials say that they will not neglect Africa, but they face difficulties in maintaining concessional aid at current levels, given the increasing reluctance by major donors to increase funding for the two institutions. The IMF's concessional lending facility, known as ESAF, is due to expire in November 1993, and increased funding for the fund as a whole continues to be held up by the United States. Washington also is among the many donors that have not yet approved funding for IDA-10, the next three-year replenishment of the World Bank's concessional lending fund.

In a communique before the annual meeting, the G-24 group of developing countries, led by chairman Abubakar Alhaji of Nigeria, called attention to the special needs of sub-Saharan Africa. "Additional resource flows to the low-income and lower middle-income sub-Saharan countries need to be much larger in volume and must continue to be on highly concessional terms," said the G-24, "given the widespread poverty, low levels of saving and investment, excruciating debt service burden, and recently, the severe drought and famine problems with which these countries have had to grapple." The G-24 group added that increased concessional aid will be essential for the poorer countries in Africa to maintain progress on economic reforms.


LOAD-DATE: September 28, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


209 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 28, 1992


Liberian Vote Under Fire


LENGTH: 1387 words


MONROVIA, Liberia by Cindy Shiner * Africa News Service

Former U.S. President Jimmy Carter has called for a new diplomatic initiative to salvage a West African peace plan for Liberia. An outbreak of fighting that ended a 20-month-long truce has threatened implementation of the plan, which calls for internationally supervised elections.

After a visit here in early September, Carter asked United Nations Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali to send a small observer mission, unarmed and numbering no more than 20 people, to help get the peace process back on track. The observers, led by a respected international figure, could reassure contending parties during the critical pre-election period, Carter said. 

The latest fighting was started by the United Liberation Movement of Liberia for Democracy (Ulimo) which in August inflicted substantial casualties on the country's largest armed group, the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL), led by Charles Taylor. Ulimo is made up of elements from the old Liberian national army of former President Samuel K. Doe, whose overthrow Taylor sought when he launched the war nearly three years ago.

Fighting was halted in late 1990 by the intervention of a West African peacekeeping force, known as Ecomog. Since then, Liberia has been a divided nation, with an interim government administering the capital Monrovia, under Ecomog protection, and Taylor controlling most of the countryside.

Ulimo appeared on the scene about six months after Ecomog enforced the truce, staging raids on NPFL positions from bases inside neighboring Sierra Leone. A primary Ulimo aim appeared to be revenge for the casualties Taylor's forces inflicted on Doe's troops during the initial conflict.

Until recently, Ulimo had little impact on the situation. "People did not take us seriously," says Joseph Taybior, the group's secretary-general and one of its founders. "But we are proving that we are a very determined organization and we are capable of liberating our country."

Ulimo's offensive, begun in August, has driven the NPFL out of long-held positions in the southwest of the country. The objective, Ulimo says, is to force Taylor to comply with the peace plan and disarm his soldiers.

Taylor has accused Ecomog of arming Ulimo and says the interim government is giving the insurgency quiet support.

The Ulimo action is the first serious challenge Taylor has faced since Ecomog forced his troops out of suburbs around the capital and imposed the cease-fire in 1990. The West African intervention blocked NPFL's advance towards Doe's headquarters, allowing a splinter rebel faction, led by former Taylor aide Prince Johnson, to get there first. Johnson's men captured Doe, then tortured and killed him.

Taylor nurses a deep distrust for Ecomog, saying it is a Nigerian-inspired effort to keep him from becoming president of Liberia. As West African leaders have groped for negotiated solutions, Taylor has resisted, agreeing to proposed peace measures only when pressured strongly by those he regards as friends, such as the government of neighboring Cote d'Ivoire.

An accord signed over a year ago, in the Ivorian capital Yamoussoukro, binds all the Liberian parties to accept West African-supervised elections, tentatively scheduled for November 30. The latest fighting, and signs of heightened tensions between Taylor and Ecomog, appears to have set back that timetable.

In early September, the NPFL detained over 500 West African peacekeepers, seizing their weapons and vehicles. When Carter arrived in the country, he demanded their release as a condition for meeting Taylor. A contingent of about 300 was freed, but the remaining 200 were held for another ten days before being returned to Monrovia.

Taylor denies that he was using the soldiers as a shield against attack. "We are not terrorists and we do not hold hostages," he said in a radio broadcast. He said the soldiers' weapons were seized because he feared that the Ecomog soldiers would hand over the sophisticated arms to Ulimo.

Under the peace accord, Ecomog was to deploy its forces throughout Liberia, and all armed factions, including the NPFL, promised to disarm and place their combatants in camps.

"We are not here to conquer ground," says Major General Ishaya Bakut of Nigeria, who is field commander of the peacekeeping force. "We're here to conquer the minds of the people, to disarm and encamp."

But the Ecomog deployment has faced repeated delays and Ecomog forces have been denied free movement in Taylor-controlled territory. In May, the NPFL killed six Senegalese soldiers sent by Ecomog to the north when they refused to surrender their heavy artillery.

"It's very embarrassing for us as Liberians," says Lamini Waritay, information minister for the interim government, headed by President Amos Sawyer. "This is an excellent opportunity for the sub-region to tackle the problems of the sub-region. But Mr. Taylor and the NPFL have taken it upon themselves to embark on a systematic program of discrediting Ecomog," he says.

"We are taken as a warring faction and not as a peacekeeper," says Lt. Col. Ajyei Mensah, a Ghanaian staff officer at Ecomog headquarters. "Any time Ecomog personnel are moving to Charles Taylor's area, the peacekeepers are escorted by the NPFL."

The NPFL has organized demonstrations against the West African presence. And, according to informed observers, merchants in several areas have been prohibited from selling food to the soldiers, and residents are urged not to house them.

"As a peacekeeper, you have to exercise restraint to avoid any shootout," said Col. Alex Ackumbo, commanding officer of Nigeria's Eighth Battalion. "That is what we are doing."

Liberia's civil war made refugees of over half the country's 2.6 million people. Although many Liberians who fled the country have been returning, the latest fighting has created as many as 100,000 new refugees, relief workers say, including people from Sierra Leone as well as from Liberia. Poor roads in the border areas make it difficult to get food to those who have fled their homes.

Those who are hungry enough and strong enough journey to Monrovia, where the population has more than doubled to one million since 1990. Another 30,000 refugees and homeless people have flooded the capital in the weeks since the Ulimo offensive began.

Mohammed Eskayhadi, refugee chairman at the Congo Town refugee camp outside Monrovia says he and hundreds of others walked more than a week to reach the capital. "We are suffering a lot from the NPFL soldiers," Eskayhadi says. "The commandos take all our belongings. We only arrived here with one shirt, one trousers." n


LOAD-DATE: September 28, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


210 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 28, 1992


Impasse Clouds Saharan Peace Plan


LENGTH: 1240 words


United Nations by Karen Gellen * Africa News Service One year after a United Nations-negotiated cease-fire in Western Sahara, the peace process appears to be unraveling, prompting concerns that fighting will resume. The world body's plan to supervise a referendum in the former Spanish colony is far behind schedule, with no sign of an agreement on voting procedures between the Saharan independence movement, known as the Polisario Front, and Morocco, which claims the territory.

Meetings held here in mid-September between the UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali and the two rival parties to the peace pact have reflected the increased tensions. "We're back to square one," says Bachir Mustafa Sayed, chief negotiator for Polisario. The Saharan official says the United Nations "did not fully commit itself to its own plan" and is allowing Morocco to scuttle the accord. Those charges were punctuated September 22 with a warning from the movement's top leader, Mohamed Abdelaziz, that Morocco's stand "conjures up the specter of a return of the war." Moroccan Foreign Minister Abdellatif Filali denies the charge, saying that Polisario is to blame for the stalemate. 

The immediate dispute is over Rabat's intention to include the Western Sahara in nationwide Moroccan local elections scheduled for this fall. The Saharan group says the vote is meant to pre-empt the referendum on the territory's future that is central to the UN plan. In a letter sent to world leaders, Abdelaziz argued that the Moroccan vote "can have no other objective than the pure and simple burial of the peace plan." He appealed for international pressure to ensure Morocco's cooperation in the peace process.

A day earlier, Morocco's Filali, told the General Assembly that Morocco has cooperated with the UN team in Western Sahara. He expressed hope that "realism will prevail over obstructionist tactics" employed by the other side.

To support his point on Moroccan compliance, Filali cited a report on the UN's Western Sahara operation issued by the secretary-general in mid-August. Although the United Nations blames Morocco for most of the cease-fire violations recorded by monitors stationed in the territory, the report appears to support voter eligibility criteria introduced by Morocco.

Under the peace plan negotiated last year by Boutros-Ghali's predecessor, Javier Perez de Cuellar, Saharans are to be given a choice between independence and integration into Morocco. The conflict over how the voter roll will be determined has been the main obstacle to the holding of the referendum, originally scheduled for last January.

Morocco has been trucking large numbers of its citizens into the former Spanish colony, which it has occupied since 1975, in preparation for the UN-supervised polling. The 120,000 new residents are legitimate voters, says Rabat, because they come from Saharan families that have migrated into Morocco over the years.

Polisario says the original UN plan, agreed to by both parties, specifies that only the families and descendants of the 74,000 or so Saharans counted in a 1974 Spanish colonial census will be eligible to vote. But the front's UN negotiator concedes that Perez de Cuellar, during the final days of his tenure, had "opened the door" to Morocco's importation of voters.

In an annex to the agreement, says Bachir Sayed, the former secretary-general expanded the criteria for eligibility to include anyone who can claim Saharan lineage. That approach, Sayed argues, removes Saharan nationality from "time and space," and enables Morocco to cull voters from the entire Mahgreb region. Sayed says that in his September talks with Boutros-Ghali, the secretary-general told him the UN has "no teeth" with which to enforce Moroccan compliance with other aspects of the peace plan.

In the past, Polisario has been supported by the Organization of African Unity, and Western Sahara was admitted to the continent-wide organization in 1984, over Morocco's objections. But the Saharan issue appears low on the agenda African countries have brought to the current UN session. The stalled peace operation in Western Sahara received only a bare mention, for example, from the foreign ministers of Angola and Zimbabwe -- countries that have been strong Polisario allies -- when they addressed the General Assembly on its opening day. And Morocco currently sits on the 15-member Security Council, a position that gives Rabat added clout in the UN's political horse trading.

As a counterpoint to the UN talks, Morocco has welcomed with fanfare a group of high-level defectors from Polisario. Eight former officials of the front appeared September 15 at a Rabat press conference, where they declared the independence movement dead. The session was chaired by Brahim Hakim, who served as the Saharan foreign minister for a decade before being replaced in that post in 1985.

The group said Polisario has run out of weapons, allies and popular support. According to one of the movement's founders, Salek Fadili, former Polisario backers including Algeria and Cuba, are no longer able to provide aid. "Cuba is in distress, shipwrecked, and Polisario is foundering along." He said Cuba has given Polisario no aid since 1991, except for educating Saharan students. One participant in the press conference, Fadel Maa el-Ainine, had been Polisario's military attache in Cuba.

The eight defectors echoed long-standing Moroccan claims that tens of thousands of Saharan refugees living in camps just across the Algerian border were being held against their will by Polisario. Mohamed Takillah, who said he had been security chief for the camps, told reporters that the refugees "want to see trucks coming to take them home, to the kingdom of Morocco."

Asked at the UN to comment on the defectors' claims, Bashir Sayed denied Polisario had been receiving weapons from Cuba and disputed a claim by Fadili that the guerrillas were nearly out of fuel, tires, batteries and spare parts. He said Polisario retains its ability to fight again if a collapse of the UN plan makes armed struggle necessary. But the front understands that it "cannot defeat Morocco militarily," Sayed said. For us, he said, "the political solution is an imperative." n


LOAD-DATE: September 28, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


211 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 28, 1992


Efforts Intensify to End Sudan Agony


LENGTH: 1374 words


Washington, DC Reed Kramer * Africa News Service

Now that months of mounting suffering in Somalia has pierced the world's consciousness, concern for another crisis in the region is increasing among international relief officials and observers.

War in Sudan, between the Islamic fundamentalist-led government and rebels fighting for autonomy for the largely Christian and animist south, is raising the likelihood of mass starvation.

"I'm deeply worried about the fate of the people of southern Sudan," U.S. Assistant Secretary of State for Africa Herman J. Cohen said at a Senate hearing on September 23. Cohen said he is "very pessimistic" about the prospects for a solution to the civil war. 

Sudan, Africa's largest country with a land mass about the size of the United States east of the Mississippi River, has a population exceeding 25 million -- the fifth largest on the continent.

Since the current conflict erupted in 1983, several hundred thousand people have died from the almost continuous famine that has accompanied the fighting. With the war intensifying, some 3.7 million people are in need of urgent aid, United Nations officials believe.

Some of the worst affected are the 300,000 inhabitants of Juba, the south's largest town, which is controlled by government troops but surrounded by an aggressive rebel army. In recent months, relief flights to Juba have been suspended due to the fighting. But the most immediate threat Juba residents are facing, according to eyewitness accounts, is from increasingly edgy government forces.

"The local people are suffering greatly at the hands of the army and the security police," says Sister Nancy Lyons, a Maryknoll nun who was working in Juba until she and other foreigners were expelled in August. "Many, many men from the town have been arrested, many have been tortured and executed," she says.

On September 22, the State Department announced that a Sudanese employee of the U.S. Agency for International Development was executed in Juba after being convicted of treason by a military tribunal. Another Sudanese national who worked for the U.S. government and two more who worked for other international organizations may have suffered the same fate, U.S. officials said.

Interviewed during a visit to Washington, Lyons and Marilyn Norris, another Maryknoll sister, said they thought they were forced to leave because the government wants no witnesses to the "horror" that is taking place. Amnesty International says government forces recently executed at least 300 unarmed civilians and prisoners in Juba and arrested hundreds more.

The current crackdown in Juba began after several major assaults on the town by the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) in July. Until that time, government forces defending Juba included many southerners, who are easily distinguishable from lighter-skinned northerners. The Maryknoll sisters say that after the attacks, southerners were removed -- with many arrested and apparently executed -- because of suspicions they were SPLA sympathizers or supporters. Most residents of Juba are supportive of the SPLA, the sisters say.

Local people told the Maryknolls that many of the replacements for the southerners are Iranian. U.S. officials believe Iran has been supplying the Sudanese government with arms and training but say there is no confirmation that Iranian troups have joined the fighting in the south.

Sudan's problems, like Somalia's, stem partly from superpower rivalries during the Cold War. The countries of what is called the Horn of Africa, which also includes Ethiopia and Djibouti, were considered strategic by both the United States and the Soviet Union. Competition for influence led to shifting alliances, to support for dictators who dismantled local administrations and social structures, and to massive arms buildups that are fueling the power struggles in Somalia and Sudan.

Sudan, the top recipient of U.S. aid in sub-Saharan Africa during the post-World War II era, was led during much of the period by Gaafar Muhammad Numeiri, an authoritarian military ruler who seized power in 1969. Numeiri survived more than a dozen efforts to oust him before losing control to rival soldiers in 1985.

Initially, Numeiri reached an accommodation with the rebellious south, granting a measure of autonomy. But in the early 1980s, in an attempt to shore up his shaky political base, he adopted an increasingly strict version of Islam. He finally imposed Sharia, or Islamic law, on the entire nation, sparking resumption of war with the south.

Although peace talks began earlier this year, under the sponsorship of Nigeria and the Organization of African Unity, the current Sudanese regime, led by General Omar al-Bashir, has pressed the effort to Islamicize the country and stepped up measures to defeat the SPLA militarily. The government offensive has weakened the SPLA, which has also suffered an internal split.

The government's "holy war" has been expanded to non-southerners, including the Nuba peoples in the country's mountainous central region. Many of the one million Nuba are Muslim, but the SPLA has recruited among them and has operated from bases in the southern Nuba mountains, adjacent to the SPLA stronghold in southern Sudan. In response, the government has waged what the human rights group Africa Watch has termed a "campaign of horrifying dimensions" against the Nuba.

The worsening situation in Sudan remains largely unreported, in part because of the government's successful efforts to fend off bad publicity. Access to Sudan by journalists and other outsiders in severely limited.

Prompted by rising concern among aid workers and the U.S. government, Jan Eliasson, the United Nations undersecretary for humanitarian affairs, traveled to Sudan in early September. In the capital, Khartoum, he sought government consent to resume relief flights to the south. After arranging a brief cease-fire with the SPLA, Eliasson also stopped in Juba to assess aid requirements. Following the trip, which included talks in Nairobi, Kenya, with both factions of the SPLA, Eliasson announced agreement on restarting the airlift of food to Juba and 20 other southern sites.

Meanwhile, there are indications that long-delayed peace talks may resume. Nigerian mediators have visited Khartoum to discuss holding a second round of peace talks between the government and the rebels in October.

Tiny Rowland, head of Lonrho, a British conglomerate with extensive interests throughout Africa, held talks in September with SPLA leader John Garang and with al-Bashir. Rowland, who has also been a central player in the Mozambique peace talks, told the Financial Times of London that a cease-fire agreement in Sudan will be reached "very soon." n


LOAD-DATE: September 28, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


212 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1992


No Shows


LENGTH: 351 words


For the first time in its 17-year history, the president of France did not participate in the annual Franco-African summit. President Francois Mitterand, who recently underwent prostate cancer surgery, was advised by his doctors not to travel to Gabon, site of this year's meeting. 

Gabon's President Omar Bongo was reported to be unhappy that Mitterand failed to attend. A low turnout of heads of state was attributed to the French leader's absence. Only 14 heads of state attended the summit, the lowest number since 1980.

French Prime Minister Pierre Beregovoy took part in the conference in place of Mitterand. He announced a debt conversion plan for Cameroon, Congo, Gabon, and Cote d'Ivoire worth $ 824 million. The four are considered middle-income countries and have not qualified previously for concessions on their debts. Under the proposed plan, new investment by the four countries in infrastructure development will be deducted from their debt to France. French officials say the program is an attempt to alleviate the economic burdens of the former French territories.

Prior to the summit, almost 200 opposition supporters staged a sit-in outside the General De Gaulle military base in Libreville, the Gabonese capital, to protest the summit. The demonstrators, organized by the Coordination of the Democratic Opposition, said that Bongo's failure to lead the country toward democracy in his 25 years of office made him unfit to host the summit. Protesters demanded that Bongo's "imperialist rule" come to an end. Bongo gave in to demands for multiparty elections in 1990, but the opposition agreed to let him complete his current term, which ends in 1994.


LOAD-DATE: October 15, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


213 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1992


Foiled Coup


LENGTH: 347 words


Junior army officers staged an unsuccessful effort to depose the president of the Comoros last month. Troops loyal to President Said Mohamed Djohar managed to regain control within a few hours of the initial attack on September 26, removing rebels from the radio station in Moroni, capital of the Indian Ocean archipelago, which has a history of political instability. 

According to government officials, two of the alleged coup organizers are sons of former President Ahmed Abdallah Abderrahmane, who was shot dead in November 1989, during an argument with Bob Denard, a French mercenary. Denard came to the islands in 1978, with a troop of 30 "dogs of war" to reinstate Abdallah, who had been deposed in a coup three years earlier. Denard served as commander of Abdallah's presidential guard until the shooting, when the mercenary seized personal control of the islands. He surrendered after dozens of French paratroopers landed in Comoros to oust him from authority.

The third suspected leader of last month's attempt to overthrow Djohar is a former member of Abdallah's presidential guard known as "Captain Combo," who is linked to Denard, now exiled in South Africa.

Djohar, former president of the Supreme Court, was named acting head of state following the death of Abdallah and was elected president in an uncontested race in 1990. In August of the same year, Djohar escaped one coup attempt, and in 1991 he foiled an attempt by opposition leaders to have the Supreme Court impeach him on the grounds of his alleged senility. The latest uprising follows protests by Comorian dissidents, who claim that their current government is corrupt and that Djohar is a dictator. The officers who tried to seize control have made no official statements about the coup attempt.


LOAD-DATE: October 15, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


214 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1992


Whose Money?


LENGTH: 280 words


It is on-again, off-again for the face-off between Zaire's new prime minister, Etienne Tshisekedi, and the entrenched president, Mobutu Sese Seko. After sending troops to surround the central bank in the capital, Kinshasa -- a move to thwart Tshisekedi's attempt to replace the bank chief, a Mobutu loyalist -- Mobutu issued a call for "national reconciliation" earlier this month. 

The president dispatched the soldiers after Tshisekedi charged the bank's governor with responsibility for the disappearance of $ 5 million from the national treasury during the last week of September. Foreign donors have said they will not resume any aid flows to Zaire until they are assured that Mobutu's access to the national funds has been blocked. The 62-year-old leader is believed to have diverted many millions -- perhaps even billions -- of dollars for his personal use and to reward loyalists.

Tshisekedi, who was named prime minister by a national pro-democracy conference in August, is trying to end Zaire's economic downslide and put the country on a recovery footing. National elections to chose a new government are planned, but no date has been set. Mobutu wants the voting to take place within the next six to twelve months, while Tshisekedi and the national conference say at least 18 months are required to prepare for fully free balloting.


LOAD-DATE: October 15, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


215 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1992


Kaunda Quits


LENGTH: 374 words


Kenneth Kaunda, who served for 27 years as president of Zambia until his defeat in last October's election, resigned this month as head of the United National Independence Party (UNIP). The party, meeting in a special congress, chose Kebby Musokotwane to replace the former president. Musokotwane, who was the party's secretary-general, was Kaunda's choice as his successor.

Musokotwane garnered 4,590 votes compared to his closest competitor, Godwin Yoran Mumba, who only received 106 votes. Prior to the congress, the race between Musokotwane and Mumba had led to violent disputes between groups vying for power within the party.

Kaunda long has been urged by friends at home and abroad to leave party politics and take on the role of "senior statesman." The leader of UNIP since it was established in 1959 during the struggle for Zambian independence, Kaunda was recently named "founding father of the nation." His rule ended in October, when he lost a presidential election to Frederick Chiluba, leader of the Movement for Multiparty Democracy.

In a farewell address at the party congress, Kaunda criticized President Chiluba's privatization program, charging that the new leader is allowing foreigners to make important policy decisions. Kaunda also criticized the country's adoption of multiparty democracy, which he accepted last year under domestic and international pressure. The former president said that rising prices of fertilizer and seeds under the Chiluba government fail to take into account the needs of workers and peasants.

In his acceptance speech, Musokotwane told the members of congress that under the new UNIP leadership, the party would fight to regain control of the Southern African country. Musokotwane stated that he is now rededicating himself to the goals of the party and to serving the people of Zambia.


LOAD-DATE: October 15, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


216 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1992


Reebok Awards


LENGTH: 294 words


Floribert Chebeya Bahizire of Zaire was recently named one of the four recipients of the 1992 Reebok Human Rights Award. The five-year-old award recognizes the achievements of individuals under the age of 30 who advance the cause of human rights. 

Under the strong army rule of President Mobutu Sese Seko, stories of human rights violations have become commonplace. Reports of physical punishment, arbitrary detentions, harassment, death threats and kidnappings are frequent.

In 1983 when he was 18 years old, Chebeya organized a group of students to protest human rights abuses. Calling themselves Voice for the Voiceless (VCV), the students published and distributed a bulletin detailing human rights violations, working under dangerous circumstances with no budget. VCV functioned as an illegal underground organization until April 1990, when Mobutu, pressured by growing democracy movements, began to allow multiparty democracy movements to function legally. Chebeya continues to serve as the president of VCV though he receives regular threats on his life.

On behalf of the Reebok Foundation, Paul Fireman, CEO of Reebok International Limited, will present Chebeya with an award of $ 25,000 to donate to the human rights organization of his choice. This year's awards will be presented in a ceremony in Boston on October 9.


LOAD-DATE: October 15, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


217 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1992


No New Wage Cuts


LENGTH: 320 words


The government of Cote d'Ivoire has again rejected a call by the International Monetary Fund for sharp reductions in salary outlays for civil servants. "Cote d'Ivoire cannot accept a major reduction in civil service spending," Prime Minister Alassane Ouattara said during an unprecedented four-hour, live, question-and-answer session on national television October 1. 

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) suspended a $ 120-million stand-by credit agreement with the West African nation in June, saying the government had failed to meet budgetary targets. The IMF wants Ivorian authorities to cut the government payroll, increase tax revenue, and eliminate price supports for coffee and cocoa, the country's principle exports.

But the government has been unwilling to take these unpopular steps, despite pressure from the fund and from foreign aid donors. Civil servants and farmers form the core of support for the ruling party, headed by long-serving President Felix Houphouet-Boigny.

Political tensions rose to record heights earlier this year with the jailing of leading opposition figures, including Laurent Gbagbo, head of the largest opposition party. But since Houphouet-Boigny returned to the country last July after a five-month absence and ordered the release of Gbagbo and 74 others, the atmosphere has quieted.

Gbagbo is continuing his attacks on the government, accusing Ouattara of mismanagement and calling for an emphasis on industrialization as an alternative to dependence on cash crop sales.


LOAD-DATE: October 15, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


218 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1992


Campaign Heats Up


SECTION: DATELINE: AFRICA


LENGTH: 480 words


The government of Cameroon has closed the national voters' register amidst protests from opposition party members who were barred from registering. Some opposition supporters missed the annual April 1 deadline for registration because of a boycott against parliamentary elections in March. When President Paul Biya decided to move national elections originally scheduled for next April to October, many party members discovered that they would be unable to vote in Cameroon's first multiparty elections in almost 30 years. Despite continuing protests, Biya has refused to reopen the voting register. 

Eight candidates are standing for the upcoming presidential ballot including incumbent Biya and his major rival, John Fru Ndi, head of the Social Democratic Front (SDF). According to a recently released survey, Ndi is leading Biya by 20 points.

Since the campaigns officially began on September 26, there have been three reported attacks on opposition leaders. Progressive Movement leader Jean-Jacques Ekindi survived an assassination attempt on October 4, when Biya supporters threw a Molatov cocktail into his car. Members of the National Democratic Union also reported a similar attack in Ngaoundal, 300 miles north of the capital. Last week, opposition sources reported that eight members of the SDF were hospitalized with cuts and head wounds after a clash with Biya supporters.

The rising tensions were also evident in a recent allegation made by Gregoire Owana, deputy general secretary of the ruling Cameroon People's Democratic Movement. Owona told Radio Cameroon that if Ndi's SDF wins the October 11 vote, the victors would execute top officials of the ruling party.

As violence in the central African country has mounted, national security chief and Biya campaign adviser John Fochive ordered all Cameroon embassies to stop issuing visas to international observers. Some opposition supporters, who accuse Fochive of suppressing a pro-democracy student movement last year, fear that his control of the police could lead to massive vote-rigging.

SDF supporters also are concerned that France might back a military coup to prevent Ndi from winning the election, in order to maintain their influence in the country. Ndi has described France's interest in Cameroon as "the genuine fear of one whose umbilical cord may be cut."


LOAD-DATE: October 15, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.

220 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1992


Luanda, October 1993Statement of the International Foundation for Electoral Systems (IFES)International Observer Delegation on the Elections in Angola, September 29-30,1992


LENGTH: 814 words


Among the 600 outside observers for the presidential and parliamentary elections in Angola was a 39-member delegation organized by the International Foundation for Electoral Systems, a non-partisan non-profit organization based in Washington, DC. Funding for the project was provided by the United States Agency for International Development (AID). The delegation was made up of U.S. citizens, plus nationals of Brazil, Costa Rica, the Netherlands, Nigeria and Surinam. Here are excerpts from the delegation's statement.

The delegation is impressed that over ninety percent of the estimated eligible electorate of Angola registered to vote, and that a very large percent of these registrants apparently voted. Although different members of the delegation observed a range of problematic conditions and recurrent difficulties, along with isolated lapses of adherence to regulations, the delegates agree that with respect to the primary concerns of the IFES mission the Angolan elections of September 29-30 were admirably conducted. Furthermore, delegation members were struck by the enthusiasm, resolve, and persistence of the Angolan voters, who often had to stand in very long lines for up to twelve hours or more in order to vote. 

Among the more serious difficulties encountered were many instances of late opening of polling places, and related instances of unruliness at the entrance to voting sites. While perhaps the largest segment of voters used without difficulty the complicated balloting materials that were officially mandated, a substantial number of voters seemed confused by them. The relatively large number of null and blank ballot papers recorded appear to be indicative of this situation .

Ballot counting at voting sites and provincial tabulating centers were observed to have proceeded as stipulated by the electoral code. Unanticipated delay and complications sometimes arose in connection with the collection and transport of results to provincial capitals. Transmission of vote totals and tally of results at the national tabulating site in Luanda took place slowly, and this gave rise to widespread public concern and anxiety. The delegation's statement, however, cannot fully take into account this last phase of the process.

The IFES delegation believes that the achievements of these elections are remarkable in light of the relatively short period of time that passed between the commencement of official election preparations and the actual event. The delegation is also conscious that this success was achieved in the extremely tense circumstances arising from the recent Angolan civil war, notably the fierce competitive relationship between the two major Angolan political parties, many of whose more active adherents have been armed and organized combatants. In these settings particularly, the generally peaceful and effective administration of the Angolan elections represents a milestone in the history of Angola.

In conclusion, the IFES delegation wishes to stress the strict limitations of our statement, which does not bear upon the conduct of the electoral campaign proceeding the election, nor on the reception by various segments of the Angolan people of the outcome. The delegation also has not considered issues underlying the entire electoral process such as the possible impact of the uncompleted military demobilization on the emergent parties or, more importantly, on the general attitude of the Angolan people and the degree of their willingness to participate. Nor does this statement address other factors such as access to the media in Angola, external assistance, and related controversies.

Bearing in mind the limits of our terms of reference, and also the limits of our opportunities to observe, from what the delegation observed the consensus of the IFES international delegation of election observers was that the Angolan elections of September 29-30, 1992 constituted a proper and effective application of the mechanism of elective choice of political representatives, and the delegation congratulates the entire country. This statement does not presume to speak for the Angolan people. n


LOAD-DATE: October 15, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


221 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1992


Massive Effort Nets Huge Voter Turnout


LENGTH: 3587 words


There's no mistaking that an election is going on in Angola. Baseball caps, key chains, posters, umbrellas, flags and banners of all sizes, motorized billboards that rotate to reveal different messages and tee shirts in a variety of styles urge people to support a party or vote for one of 13 candidates running for president. It's almost like being on Main Street, USA preparing for the November elections. All the trappings of a Madison Avenue PR firm are here -- from miniature blimps flying in the sky to campaign videos. Buildings, homes, statues and buses are plastered with bumper stickers and posters. There is a sense that this election is special, despite the rumblings that the potential for violence is high. The people are ready for this election and the excitement clearly shows.

Seventeen parties have fielded candidates for the parliament and/or president. The deluge of paper is mind-boggling. Several times a day vehicles, drive through neighborhoods showering streets and yards with hundreds of brochures and flyers extolling the virtues of a candidates or party. The streets of Luanda are littered with refuse from the campaigns. 

Even though the percentage of the population owning television sets is small, video productions have been an important part of preparing citizens for the election. To encourage the get out and vote effort, the National Electoral Council recorded an official song and video. Strongly reminiscent of the "We are the World" campaign during the Ethiopian famine of 1985, the video features Angolans in a studio wearing Vote Angola tee shirts, solos by various singers including a Stevie Wonder look-alike complete with dark sunglasses and Stevie's characteristic movement, and an ending that features hands waving in the air. Mixed in with the studio scenes are shots of Angolans getting voter registration cards, street scenes, and shots of people flashing the "V" for vote signal. The video and accompanying song are played frequently on the radio and during television.

The Angolan electoral law gives all parties and candidates access to twenty minutes of public radio daily and ten minutes of public television time daily. The videos for various political parties exhibited a wide range of creative thinking and production capability. The video for Daniel Chipenda, the candidate of the National Democratic Party of Angola (PNDA), opens with an electoral rap. Other videos feature panoramic views of a pastoral Angola, arty shots of the countryside, and candid photos of people. In sharp contrasts to parties with the financial capability to produce a dramatic video were simple presentations that featured a candidate in a studio reading a prepared statement.

On the Saturday preceding the election, the two main parties stage big events in the capital. Unita holds a historic rally in May 1st Square -- the first time a major political gathering by the opposition was permitted in Luanda. Thousands gather, most wearing Unita tee shirts, many women wearing cloth in a traditional African print featuring a likeness of Jonas Savimbi, the party leader and a presidential candidate. In a minor incident the crowd shows its disdain for the ruling party and the police. When a jeep filled with police tries to penetrate the outer edge of the rally, the crowd quickly blocks access to the square chanting for the police to go away. Prudently the vehicle backs away.

The MPLA event is more like a festival. Tents line the perimeter of the grounds, where people grill chicken, mill around stands dispensing sodas and beer, and take advantage of giveaways of election paraphernalia. A band plays popular tunes interspersed with songs praising the virtues of the party.

On Sunday, September 27 four teams from the International Foundation for Electoral Systems delegation leave for the airport at 6 a.m. to travel to outlying provinces. Four additional teams head for other provinces by car. We fly on an Army C-130 plane with our cargo of sleeping bags, a supply of bottled water, first aid kits and food. I am assigned to Huila, where 509,000 people have registered to vote.

We are dropped off literally in the middle of a runway at the Lubango airport, where the expected United Nations contact person is nowhere in sight. The C-130 rushes to take off, to avoid confrontations with former Angolan soldiers trying to get back to their home provinces. The demobilized men hang around airports in hopes of hitching a ride, but the U.S. army wants no part of that plan.

Suddenly ordered off the runway by an Angolan soldier, our group takes refuge under the shade of a small tree. There are nine of us, four from the United States and five observers from the European Community (EC) and Canada. A row of MIG fighter jets in varying states of disrepair are neatly parked on the side of the runway. We can see other discarded war equipment, parts of rusting troop carriers,

disabled trucks and jeeps and assorted tanks and weapons nearby. The Canadian remarks that we are looking at perhaps half a billion dollars worth of war equipment. He muses about what that money could have bought if spent on health, education and development projects. Another team member says, "The war was real here," and the thought sobers all the warm feelings generated by the good times at the rallies and by the cute posters papering Luanda.

The hotel in Lubango, the provincial capital of Huila, begins to fill with international observers. There is an additional U.S. delegation brought by Unita. There are Somali and Ethiopian observers representing the Organization of African Unity, as well as several Europeans. Some observers seem more serious and better prepared than others. My group secretly coins a phrase, "electoral tourists," to describe the folks who seem to be along just for the ride.

We visit the provincial governor's office, a safeguard in case there is trouble. We want him to know who and where we are. We visit the provincial election headquarters and make a few pre-election stops to polling sites. Everyone is busy preparing for the vote, scrubbing floors, rearranging furniture, setting up tables to get ready. At the UN headquarters -- which is the home-base for United Nations Angola Unification Mission (Unavem), United Nations development Program (UNDP), United Nations Children's Fund (Unicef) and several other UN programs -- there is hustle and bustle. All available aircraft, jeeps and vans are in use, delivering remaining voting kits and scheduling travel for observers across the province. A helicopter crash the day before does not dampen the determination to pursue the process.

An expectant air surrounds the opening of the polling sites on September 29.

My team observes the opening of a site in the middle of town at the cultural, or cultural center. By 6:45 a.m., all is ready. The site has two tables, each with 1200 ballots -- 1000 for the expected number of voters plus 200 extra. The ballots are color coded, pink to cast a vote for president and blue for members of parliament. In the parliamentary poll voters cast one vote for the party of their choice, and 233 representatives are allocated according to the percentage of the vote each party receives. At each polling site there is a president, secretary and three scrutineers who make up the election's official staff. Each party and each presidential candidate also has the right to appoint official observers to monitor the polling sites.

There are twelve additional people in this cultura as observers, representing five parties. With considerable ceremony, the two presidents -- one for each voting table -- open the pink and the blue metal ballot boxes, present them for inspection to verify that they are empty, and proceed to lock them under the careful scrutiny of all present. This process, along with the accompanying speeches, takes some time. Afterward, the officials get to vote.

Outside, 500 or 600 people are in line and the crowd is restless. In an attempt to facilitate the process, numbers are passed out, but this serves to further frustrate the crowd, as some people who have been in standing line more than an hour realize there are already over 500 people ahead of them and it's only 7 o'clock in the morning!

I am puzzled because there seem to be so few women in line. A quick count revealed about 30 women out of the 500 or so people in front of the cultura. I ask one of the female "scrutineers" why there are so few women. She points out to me that most women and men have formed separate lines, according to an Angolan custom that separates the sexes in public places. The line for women was a single line formed neatly around the side and back of the building. I walk to a side street and indeed there is a large crowd of women patiently waiting.

The voting proceeds slowly. Even in this well-organized site, some efficiency is lost because of the problem of illiteracy. Approximately 58% of Angola's people cannot read or write. Anticipating the problem, the electoral law permits marking the ballots with an "X" or placing a thumb print next to the desired candidate or party. The pink ballot for president lists the names of the candidates and has pictures next to the names. The blue ballot for parliament has the name of the party, the party flag in full color, and the party symbol. Still it is apparent that many people are having great difficulty in figuring out the ballot. Because there is so much information on each ballot, the printing, photos and symbols are small, causing special difficulty for people with vision problems. The law failed to provide for assistance at the polling sites, and the party observers struggled to find out ways to help people figure out the ballots.
