Many people were literally paralyzed by the process of voting, too nervous to mark the ballot until they could calm down. Others clearly relished the experience, proudly casting their vote. All seem to be dressed in their finest garb -- everything from party dresses to men in fur caps and heavy wool jackets, despite the warmth of the day.

I am disturbed by the large number of people with handicaps who come to vote. After several hours of observing, I estimate that a third of the voters are missing one or more limbs, have body disfigurations, are on crutches or in wheelchairs, or walk with a limp. The human toll of war fuels a growing sense of the futility of battle. Another member of the IFES delegation tells me that her polling site lets all the disabled people vote first and it takes hours. The ravages of war ... .

At noon, less than 400 people have completed voting and committee members decide to set up a second voting "booth" to speed up the process. They quickly find a long table and set up a barrier in the middle for privacy; thus, they enable privacy for six people instead of four at a time to vote. I am continually impressed by the commitment and the dedication that both the election committee and the party observers exhibit. At the end, they speak of themselves as a team -- and throughout the three days of voting and counting they worked that way. There was none of the partisan bickering and mistrust that was predicted.

In the afternoon, we travel out into the province. About 18 miles (30 kilometers) away, at Chibia, 43 tables have been set up for the 43,458 people registered there. En route we stop at several rural voting sites. Everywhere there are hundreds of people in line, many of whom have waited for hours in the sun. The spirit of the crowds is high and all are determined to vote. At one site, elderly men get stones for makeshift seats and squat on them while they wait. At another, the women seat themselves on the ground in a separate group from the men standing in line.

In Chibia, voters at one site wait under a stand of shade trees across the street from a community center where voting taking place. The process in many sites is excruciatingly slow, because the act of voting is carried out so ceremoniously. It is after 4:00 in the afternoon and some rural sites have voted less than 300 people. There is no electricity at many of these sites, so voting will probably end at sunset. I wonder if people who have waited so long will return the second day to try again.

At 6 p.m., we return to Lubango and revisit several polling stations. The lines are shorter now, but a significant number of people still wait. At a site in a school building, the electoral committee in one room decides to close the polls 45 minutes early because there is no light. The committee has been provided with two lanterns but no oil. In the next room, voting continues because the lanterns there have fuel. The crowd is unhappy with the decision to end the voting for the day, and there is angry shouting and some pushing and shoving, but order is maintained. The committee goes through the long process of officially closing the polls for the day. I remember that I have a flashlight, and the work continues. Each step is witnessed by the party and candidate observers and they sign various documents to attest the accuracy and veracity of the reports before ballot boxes are locked. Committee members prepare to spend the night in the school building with the boxes to ensure ballot security.

Back at the culture center, there is electricity and the voting goes on until 7 p.m. About 50 people who are still in line when the polls close are told to return the next day. Approximately 800 people have voted at each of the two tables. The ballot boxes are locked with great ceremony and the international observers are asked to witness the sealing of the boxes by signing a form.

On Wednesday morning, the polls reopen at 7 a.m. The IFES delegation officially witnesses the reopening of the ballot boxes. The process moves quicker today, and we decide to visit another province at the suggestion of a UN official.

The trip to Namibe province, where 85,000 people are registered to vote, takes over three hours rather than the two hours we had been told to expect. The narrow, mountainous road winds precariously through high cliffs that look like the Grand Canyon. The provincial capital, Namibe, is a picturesque waterfront town with pastel colored houses and delightfully landscaped squares. At the provincial election council we are told that most of the voting has been completed, though it is still early afternoon. We do not observe any people waiting in lines and committees are waiting for 7 p.m. to officially close the polls and begin the counting.

In Lubango once again, the closing of the polls on the second day goes smoothly. There are a few people drifting in to vote up until 7 p.m. Counting was to have begun immediately, but a government order arrives, postponing the tally until the next day. The order cites problems with inadequate lighting or lack of lighting in many sites and the possibility of power outages in the night that could threaten ballot security. The electoral council president is not satisfied with the directive and waits until he receives confirmation of the ruling from the Provincial Election Center -- 90 minutes later. Some sites go ahead with the counting, while others stop for the night once the call comes in. Meals for the poll workers have been provided by a local restaurant. Although election police are guarding the ballots, one president wolfs down his food and hastily returns across the street to keep an eye on the ballot boxes, "because that is very important."

Counting begins promptly at 7 a.m. on October 1 at the cultura in Lubango. One group counts the ballots for president, while a second group tallies the assembly votes. The party and presidential observers are prepared to verify and record the votes for themselves. The process is slow, with every ballot viewed by each member of the voting committee and each observer. (Later, one U.S. observer describes an election ballet, where the president physically carried each ballot for the folks to see, often almost pirouetting.)

Three hours later, only one box for the president has been counted. The table counting the assembly votes are only two-thirds of the way through their first box. The number of null votes -- incorrectly marked or otherwise invalid -- and blank votes -- ballots folded and inserted in the ballot boxes -- is statistically significant. It is well into the evening before that counting is completed, all ballots are accounted for, and the official report is done. We return to Luanda to await the national vote count.

The National Electoral Council planned for an orderly count as fast as possible. Provincial councils were given dedicated fax lines to transmit results; for those sites where that was not possible, shortwave radio reports were anticipated. The Unavem operation would supplement those efforts with air and ground transport of reports where necessary. Even with all these provisions in place, at the end of the first day of counting only about 12% of the national vote was accounted for. A week after the polls closed, still only 81% of the ballots have been noted officially, giving rise to charges from opposition parties of vote fraud.

Official statements from the various observer groups indicate no mass fraud, intimidation or serious voting irregularities, although the slowness of the count was frustrating. Where technology failed, the human spirit thrived and the counting went on with a spirit of determination to complete the process and of compromise to accommodate opposing concerns.

The country's need for peace and stability is stressed above all else by Angolans I met. Many expressed the view that they were not wedded to one presidential candidate, that the most important thing to support was the end to violence and the meaningless slaughter of people. It is impossible to ignore the consequences of war here, both human and material. Everywhere there are broken down army vehicles, rusted out shells of planes, and abandoned radar equipment. Army barracks no longer in use dot the countryside and children romp in makeshift play equipment fashioned from parts of tanks. A large segment of the population wears army uniforms, perhaps the only clothes they own. Forgetting the 16 years of civil war will not be easy; there are too many daily reminders. Armed personnel are everywhere, gunshots are common occurrences at night, and it is only with cautious optimism that people say life in Angola is improving.

Angola was once self-sufficient in food. It has vast oil, diamond and mineral resources. Its roads and rail lines, though heavily damaged, can provide decent transportion throughout much of the country. The elements for progress and stability are in place. After hundreds of years of struggle for freedom and independence, I strongly feel the Angolan people are determined to survive and prosper. n


LOAD-DATE: October 15, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


222 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1992


Angolans Revel in First Free Vote Rebel Leader's Actions Cast Shadow OverFuture


SECTION: ELECTION JOURNAL:


LENGTH: 640 words


Angolans finally got their turn at the ballot box last month, and they turned out in huge numbers. Four centuries of particularly brutal colonization and 16 years of devastating civil war have left the country in shambles and its people eager for a respite.

With transport, electricity and communication facilities in short supply, organizing elections in this mostly rural country -- about the size of Texas and California combined -- was a complex task. Despite numerous minor hitches, voting went surprisingly smoothly as candidates from 17 parties vied for the country's top post and seats in the 200-member parliament. But the future for the country is clouded by uncertainty about the plans of Jonas Savimbi, leader of the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, known as Unita. 

The rebel leader voiced a protest as soon as preliminary vote counts showed him losing the presidential race to Jose Eduardo dos Santos, the current Angolan president. Savimbi stirred further fears one week after the voting when he suddenly left the Angolan capital, Luanda, for the provincial capital of Huambo. With his lieutenants suggesting that Unita was prepared to turn Angolan into another Somalia, Savimbi seemed to be hunkering down for a possible return to war. Observers say he apparently was unprepared for defeat.

The United States, which has provided over $ 300 million in covert funding for Unita since 1985, called on Savimbi to accept the results.

Savimbi may have overestimated his backing, largely on an assumption that Angolans are angry about economic mismanagement and corruption in the dos Santos government and the ruling MPLA party. With large oil revenues and huge agricultural capability, Angola is potentially one of the strongest countries in Africa. Its economic woes are seen as only partially the result of the destruction and dislocation caused by war.

Prior to the balloting, there were other worrisome developments. Both the government and the rebel movement were accused of major violations of the 1991 peace accord, which set the stage for the vote. Unita's refusal to allow free movement in territory under its control and its failure to demobilize the bulk of its army were seen by many outside observers as particularly threatening.

Unita's control extends over about one-fifth of the country's territory -- in the center around Huambo -- and in that region Savimbi received about four-fifths of the votes. Much of Savimbi's following comes from the Ovimbundu, Angola's largest ethnic group. So any attempted secession by Savimbi could split the country along ethnic lines.

Dos Santos defeated Savimbi in almost all other areas. Voters throughout the country endured long walks and long lines to cast their votes under the gaze of a United Nations monitoring group and about 600 international observers.

Bertie Howard, executive director of Africa News Service, was part of an observer delegation organized by the Washington, DC, based International Foundation for Electoral Systems (IFES). Her trip journal is a personal look at the election process.


LOAD-DATE: October 15, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


223 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1992


Fraud Charges Prompt Suspension of Nigerian Election


LENGTH: 787 words


Nigeria's transition from military rule to a democratically elected civilian government hit a snag this month, as allegations of electoral fraud prompted the government to suspend elections. President Ibrahim Babangida's Armed Forces Ruling Council (AFRC) officially put further rounds of voting on hold in response to charges of widespread vote-rigging and misconduct by election officials during initial primaries. The AFRC also ordered the National Electoral Commission (NEC) to conduct a full investigation of the charges and to issue a report of their findings within one week.

Problems began during the first round of voting on August 1, when critics claimed that the election results were falsified. Presidential candidates from both the left-of-center Social Democratic Party (SDP) and the right-of-center National Republican Convention (NRC) charged party officials with instructing presiding officers to award predetermined numbers of votes to favored primary candidates. Following a meeting between the chairman of the NEC and party leaders, both sides agreed to repudiate all results, citing "widespread malpractice." Vice President Augustus Aikhomu issued a warning that the government would disqualify candidates if the primaries failed again. 

Government officials, promising that the process would be monitored closely, set a new date for the first round of three primaries. The September 12 vote was reported as peaceful with few protests. Five men survived the balloting: Olu Falae and Shehu Musa Yar' Adua from the SDP and Adamu Chiroma, Umaru Shinkafi, and Bamanga Tukur from the NRC, with Falae and Shinkafi leading their respective parties.

A second primary on September 19 was marked by heavy protests. Eight SDP candidates charged their party chairman, Baba Kingibe, with conspiring to advance Yar' Adua as the party's presidential candidate. The other candidates asked for the removal of Kingibe, the dissolution of the SDP national executive council, and the appointment of an administrator for the third and final primary. Despite candidates' threats to boycott the next round, the government refused to intervene.

Ten of the 12 SDP candidates withdrew from the election in protest. Yar' Adua and Abel Ubeka, one of the least known candidates, elected to stay in the race, and Yar' Adua swept the September 26 primary, emerging as the party's presidential candidate. On the NRC side, Adamu and Ciroma were scheduled for a run-off in October, since neither candidate managed to receive one-third of the vote from at least 20 out of 30 states, but those results also were disputed.

The allegations of fraud gained credibility when NRC party officials admitted to rigging poll results. Officials from the eastern state of Adamawa claimed that they were forced by death threats to add 10,000 votes to Ciroma's tally, which gave him a slight lead over Bamanga Tukur, the candidate who was eliminated. Protesters called on the government to stop the political process and order the NEC to investigate.

Observers of Nigeria's democracy movement have expressed concern about the suspension of the transition to civilian rule. But Nigerian officials say the delay will not affect plans to hand over power to civilian leadership in January 1993. Vice President Aikhomu says the government aims to ensure that the person elected president is cleared of any allegations of corruption or fraud. Officials also say that any candidates found guilty of misconduct will be banned from political activity for 10 years, in accordance with a military decree issued by the government before the primaries began.

Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation, has been under military rule for 22 of its 32 years of independence from British rule. Following the removal of President Shehu Shagari in 1983, President Babangida assumed control of the country after staging a barracks coup in 1985. Babangida established the two parties, using the American political system as a model, as part of his plan to return the country to civilian rule. National presidential elections are still scheduled for December 5. n


LOAD-DATE: October 15, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


224 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1992


Peace Declared in Mozambique


LENGTH: 680 words


For the first time since independence in 1975, Mozambique faces the prospect of peace. On Oct. 4 the country held its collective breath as President Joaquim Chissano and Afonso Dhlakama, leader of the rebel Renamo movement, signed an agreement to end the war that has taken more than a half-million lives. Although the two men embraced and called each other "dear brother," implementation of the agreement -- which provides for a cease-fire and multiparty elections -- is likely to be rocky. 

The pact, signed in Rome, came after two years of tense negotiations mediated by Italy, the Vatican, the United States, France, Britain and Russia. Agreement was spurred by a killing drought stalking the economically devastated southern African state.

If the cease-fire holds, it should enable a large-scale international relief effort to reach the 3.2 million Mozambicans who the United Nations estimates face imminent starvation. For much of the war, the country's main roads were made impassable by rebel attacks on civilians.

Ten thousand soldiers from neighboring Zimbabwe have been operating inside Mozambique, guarding the vital Beira railway corridor that has been one of the country's fragile lifelines. The peace accord mandates a withdrawal of the Zimbabwean troops and the formation of a new 30,000-member national army that will be half government forces and half former Renamo rebels.

Originally formed by Rhodesian intelligence to thwart Mozambican support for the Zimbabwe independence movement, Renamo later was taken under South Africa's wing. The movement destroyed most of the country's infrastructure, including virtually all schools and health facilities in rural areas. The rebel force, also known as the Mozambican National Resistance, has been repeatedly condemned

by international human rights organizations for its brutal tactics, characterized by large-scale massacres and horrific maiming of civilians.

At the Rome signing ceremony, Renamo's Dhlakama vowed to abide by the outcome of a UN-supervised vote scheduled for October 1993 in Mozambique. "Power is not important," he asserted. "If we lose the election we will go into the opposition. We will respect the agreement."

President Chissano stressed the urgent need for peace in the "devastated country ... with hundreds of thousands of lives at risk" from the drought. The Italian government, which played a principal mediating role in the frequently broken-off talks, announced after the signing that it would soon host an international conference to coordinate aid for Mozambique.

The prospects for national reconciliation and economic relief for the population of l5 million remain daunting, however, given the scale of bloodshed and the country's dire poverty. This year the World Bank reported that Mozambique has the lowest per capita gross national product of any nation. Nevertheless, both parties to the historic accord expressed optimism about rebuilding the country.

The prominent behind-the-scenes role played in the talks by British business figure Roland "Tiny" Rowlands is widely viewed as a sign that international investment will flow to Mozambique if peace takes hold. Chissano, Dhlakama and Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe, who participated in the Rome ceremony, praised Rowlands -- who has extensive interests throughout Southern Africa -- for his efforts.


LOAD-DATE: October 15, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


225 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1992


Warring Factions Edge Peacekeepers into Liberian Conflict


SECTION: NEWS ROUNDUP


LENGTH: 694 words


Abidjan, Ivory Coast$ % Cindy Shiner * Africa News Service$ % As a West African peacekeeping force tries to avoid being drawn into fighting between armed Liberian factions, regional leaders are attempting to breathe new life into the stalled Liberia peace process.

Three West African soldiers were killed in a battle on October 3 between Charles Taylor's National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) and a rival rebel group on the outskirts of the capital Monrovia. Several rebel soldiers also were killed. 

West African commanders say Taylor's forces and rebels from the United Liberation Movement of Democracy for Liberia (Ulimo) are trying to involve them directly in the Liberian conflict. They say Taylor, who claims the West Africans are backing Ulimo, wants to discredit the peacekeeping force. Ulimo seeks West African help in defeating Taylor's forces, these sources say.

Meanwhile, Benin's President Nicephore Soglo, who heads the Economic Community of West African States that created the peacekeeping force, called Ecomog, has proposed a meeting of Liberia's warring factions. However, the idea has not been endorsed by the region's other heads of state, who have met repeatedly over the past two years to hammer out peace accords among feuding Liberians. According to official sources, these leaders say they want the factions to adhere to agreements previously negotiated.

Taylor, who controls most of Liberia's economy and countryside, ignored a regional mandate to disarm by August 31 or face sanctions. But he has said he will not give up his weapons until Ulimo stops attacking his troops.

Liberia's interim government, which controls the capital, Monrovia, under the protection of the African peacekeepers, says West African leaders have shown little inclination to enforce their own edicts against Taylor. Lamini Waritay, interim minister for information, says officials in Monrovia hope for "a more vigorous implementation of the (peace) accords.'' Maj. Gen. Ishaya Bakut, Ecomog commander, is ending his tour of duty and returning to Nigeria. The interim government hopes his successor will be more forceful with Taylor.

''We have tried to disavow the use of force," Waritay said in a telephone interview, but if Ecomog decides to take action against the NPFL, "I don't think many people will be opposed."

Many of Ecomog's 7,000 soldiers deployed in the Monrovia area have stopped wearing their white peacekeeping helmets, replacing them with combat helmets. Searches of vehicles at roadblocks throughout the capital have been increased.

Ulimo, composed of the remnants of the army of former dictator Samuel K. Doe, who was killed in 1990, launched an offensive against the NPFL in August, saying that only force would make Taylor disarm and demobilize. Since then, each side has accused the other of killing innocent civilians.

No formal confirmation of the alleged attacks is available. Earlier this month, the interim government reported eyewitness accounts that Taylor's forces had killed over 300 people in an attack on Ulimo. But Ulimo's secretary-general, Joseph Taybior, said only 15 to 20 people died.

Ecomog imposed a cease-fire in Liberia in November 1990, ending almost two years of fighting among the NPFL, a splinter rebel group led by Prince Johnson, and the Liberian army.


LOAD-DATE: October 15, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


226 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1992


Kenya Lobbies U.S. For Aid As Election Nears


LENGTH: 1640 words


WASHINGTON, DC$ % Will Acworth for Africa News Service$ %

Top Kenyan officials have been lobbying the U.S. government and the World Bank to release millions of dollars of aid that was frozen last fall over concerns about corruption and human rights abuses in the East African nation.

George Saitoti, Kenya's vice president and minister of finance, and Wilson Ndolo Ayah, foreign affairs minister, argued Kenya's case in separate visits to Washington during September. Their message was that Kenya has met the conditions for a resumption of aid and desperately needs the assistance.

Despite those efforts, however, it appears that the United States and the World Bank will continue to withhold aid until the Kenyan government follows through on its promise to hold multiparty elections that the international community recognizes as free and fair. Kenyan officials suggest that elections could occur as early as late November, although other sources say January is more likely. 

The Kenya elections are widely considered an important milestone in Africa's transition to political pluralism. One of the most stable and prosperous countries on the continent, the former British colony has been a de facto one-party state since the late 1960s, when President Jomo Kenyatta banned an opposition party led by former vice president Oginga Odinga. In the two decades since that crackdown, security forces have jailed, tortured, harassed and even murdered political dissidents. But until the late 1980s, relations with the West remained relatively positive.

Since 1990, a growing pro-democracy movement has forced reforms in Kenya. Protests against the ruling Kenya African National Union (Kanu) grew so strong that the government of President Daniel arap Moi repealed the ban on opposition parties.

Seven political parties have announced plans to compete in upcoming elections since the repeal of the ban. The two largest -- the Forum for the Restoration of Democracy and the Democratic Party -- have attracted massive crowds to campaign rallies in recent months. Despite intense internal divisions, the opposition parties are expected to win a substantial number of parliamentary seats.

Kenyan activists say that winning concessions from the government would have been more difficult without pressure from outside, and opposition leaders have succeeded in persuading the United States and other donors to maintain pressure on the Moi regime until the transition to democracy is complete.

Last November in Paris, Kenya's principal foreign donors announced a joint decision to withhold about $ 300 million to $400 million in aid until the government made a number of economic and political reforms. High on the list of donor concerns was the issue of "good governance," which officially was defined as "transparency and accountability in decision-making" but was interpreted widely as a concern about excessive corruption and political repression.

Since the Paris meeting, the Kenyan government has accelerated the move to political pluralism. As a result, some donors -- including France and the United Kingdom -- are moving to resume normal relations with Nairobi.

The United States and the World Bank have held firm on the aid freeze, however, leading the Kenyan government to intensify its efforts to improve relations with Washington. Saitoti, one of Moi's most trusted aides, discussed Kenya's economic and political reforms with top officials from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank during the groups' annual meeting last month. He also met with administration officials, including Herman Cohen, the assistant secretary of State for Africa.

In an interview with AfricaNews, Saitoti said he was told that the U.S. government is "satisfied" and "happy" with Kenya's political reforms, and he suggested that the two countries were on their way to a "warmer and cordial relationship." After returning to Kenya, the vice president told reporters at a Nairobi press conference that the donors would end the aid freeze by mid-November.

That interpretation is flatly denied by World Bank and U.S. officials, who agree that they are pleased by the reforms so far but insist that no change in policy on the aid freeze is imminent. Annoyed World Bank officials called Saitoti's comments "exaggerated" and "premature," adding that such comments are typical of finance ministers who have just returned from annual meetings and are trying to impress constituents at home. U.S. officials were more circumspect, saying only that a resumption of aid will depend on "concrete actions" such as free and fair elections.

Foreign Minister Ayah, who arrived in Washington at the end of September, took a slightly different tack. En route to New York to address the UN General Assembly on October 6, the soft-spoken foreign minister drew attention to the burdens placed on Kenya by regional drought, global recession and, most importantly, the crisis in neighboring Somalia.

Ayah told reporters that Kenya is hosting 450,000 Somali refugees -- not the 275,000 that the U.S. State Department estimates have crossed the border. Ayah said some of the refugees are heavily armed and that the influx has put an enormous strain on Kenya's meager resources.

In addition to providing food and shelter, Kenya has been the principal logistical base within the region for the United Nations relief effort in Somalia and, despite some initial difficulties, has generally supported the UN effort.

Ayah also raised the specter of militant Islam, an issue that until recently was not a major concern in Kenya-U.S. relations. The Kenyan official claimed that Islamic fundamentalists in Iran and Sudan are funding the Islamic Party of Kenya (IPK), a newly formed political party based in the coastal city of Mombasa that has been denied permission to compete in the upcoming elections.

The IPK appeared to pose little threat to the government until a violent crackdown on the party in May 1992, when police stormed a mosque and arrested several Imams. The move appears to have boosted popular support for the IPK among the predominantly Muslim people of the coast. Kenyan officials say they are pleased that the State Department has been tracking the ties between the IPK and its alleged Khartoum and Teheran patrons.

In addition to meeting Acting Secretary Lawrence Eagleburger and other State Department officials, Ayah went to Capitol Hill, where he saw several senators and representatives.

Congressional sources say the Washington meetings went well, but that the election remains the key issue. If the election is free and fair, legislators say, relations can go back to normal. But getting both sides to agree on what constitutes "free and fair" is posing some problems. Kenya has invited observers from the Commonwealth and the European Community but says that groups in the United States that have monitored elections in other parts of Africa are too biased to be trusted with the job in Kenya.

The National Democratic Institute (NDI) has been highly critical of the Kenyan government's handling of the election process. The institute -- an arm of the federally funded National Endowment for Democracy -- is active in facilitating elections and political pluralism.

In an opinion piece for the Christian Science Monitor on September 2, NDI President Brian Atwood accused Moi of maneuvering to "steal" the election by imposing procedures that favor the government. NDI's concerns are shared by over 100 members of Congress, who signed a mid-August letter to Moi drafted by Rep. Joseph Kennedy (D-MA) expressing doubts about the Kenyan government's commitment to free elections.

Ayah's visit apparently helped soothe concerns on both sides. Kenyan officials -- who said earlier that no Americans would be asked to observe the balloting -- now say that they are ready to invite "non-partisan" U.S. observers. Washington insiders say that the International Foundation for Electoral Systems, a Washington-based group with experience observing elections in several African countries, including this month's elections in Angola, has the inside track for the job. The Carter Center in Atlanta and the Congressional Black Caucus may also participate. n


LOAD-DATE: October 15, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


227 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1992


Famine, Drought Challenge Somalia's Nomads


LENGTH: 1067 words


In the Desert, Somalia$ % Jennifer Griffin for Africa News Service$ % Omar Ado Ali, elder for the once 2,000-strong nomadic Hawiye clan, wipes his brow as he squints to look out over the group's last ten camels.

Armed bands of soldiers who roam war-torn and starving Somalia have looted thousands of camels during the last two years of civil war that destroyed the country and induced a largely man-made famine.

"Before, people used to come to us and beg and we used to help them. Now we don't have money to buy basic necessities," says Omar. "We are very sad." Omar himself used to own 200 camels and 300 cows. 

Since Omar's group left the northern town of Belet Huen and began its two-year journey in search of security, 1,500 of its members have died from illness and starvation.

Between the two rivers that separate Somalia's fertile strip from an arid desert, bands of nomadic people once wandered from watering hole to watering hole settling for six months at a time before moving on.

Now the nomads stay nowhere for longer than one night, unless they abandon their way of life and settle near one of Somalia's cities. Their days have become an endless trek to protect their last few animals from theft.

Despite a March cease-fire between the country's two main warlords, the fighting continues, and vicious feuding continues to inhibit food distribution by aid agencies.

The nomads, who once made up half of Somalia's population, have been hit particularly hard by the anarchy that allows anyone with a gun to steal food or camels.

Survivors from Omar's withered clan were forced to settle outside the southern port capital, Mogadishu where they built dome-shaped, thorn tree twig hovels near a Red Cross feeding center to prevent their last ten camels from being stolen.

"Some elders stand guard and Allah protects them," says Omar.

Despite the temporary security of their new home, every day another few people from the settled nomadic group die from starvation.

Omar points to an empty hut covered in burlap surrounded by a low fence of thorn tree scrub bushes.

"Seven persons lived there, but six of them died. The other one -- too weak -- was taken to hospital," says the 52-year-old Omar whose veins strained through the weathered skin on his forehead.

A mound of overturned orange sand marked by a strip of old cloth tied to a single stick showed where a baby was buried the night before.

The influx of rural people to the cities also may cause other kinds of pain to the proud nomads. Somalis of the towns often look down on the desert wanderers. "We say (a nomad) is like those camels he is looking after. He doesn't bathe and his clothes smell," says Ali Ibrahim Mursat, who has lived in Mogadishu for 13 years.

Sixty-two miles (100 kilometers) down a desert road from Omar's village, another clan marches its 90 camels toward Mogadishu. One camel might bring 250 U.S. dollars -- the currency of choice in today's Somalia.

But as security problems increase and food remains scarce, some nomads say they will take whatever money they are offered for their camels. One clan's elder, 60-year-old Aden Farah Mohamud, whose good camels were looted by soldiers, says he would accept as little as $ 40 or $50 for one of the group's remaining camels.

With money, the nomads can buy food for their families from the thriving markets in towns like Mogadishu.

Having no need for money in the past, Aden's clan wandered the land, supporting themselves and eating mostly camel meat.

Now most of the group's 90 camels, whose ribs have begun to show, are too weak to carry the clan's belongings.

"What is left can be carried by the people," says Aden as he holds only the yellow plastic detergent bottle that he uses for water.

The clan's weaker members walk several miles behind the elder and three other men who discipline the camels with sticks.

The group eats once a day, normally at 4 p.m. But when the dried camel meat carried by the weaker family members runs out, the group sometimes doesn't eat for two or three days, Aden said.

Since they can't stay in one place, the nomads no longer build the rounded twig houses that once protected them. "We just sleep on the ground," says Aden, his cheeks hollowed from exhaustion and lack of food.

As the former desert walkers move toward Mogadishu in search of food and safety, they lament their forced journey.

"We don't know Mogadishu," says Aden, who has visited a city only once in his life. "The crowds of people bring a headache to me."

Experts on Somali culture say that the war has threatened more than the nomads' living conditions. For centuries, Somalia has been known as a nation of poets, and nomads were masters of the art.

During the rainy season, normal for this time of year, the desert once hummed with the sounds of herders singing to their camels.

"Before the war we used to sing," says Aden. "Now we are too sad." n


LOAD-DATE: October 15, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


228 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1992


Egypt Seeks Balance in Ties to U.S. and Libya


LENGTH: 1414 words


Jane Hunter for Africa News Service$ % Egypt is trying to head off an attempt by the Bush administration to stiffen United Nations sanctions aimed at forcing Libya to extradite two men accused of the 1988 bombing of a Pan American jet.

In late September, as Egypt stepped up efforts to negotiate a face-saving solution to the Pan Am case, Egyptian Prime Minister Atef Sidki and 12 of his cabinet ministers were in Libya, putting the finishing touches on a package of major economic agreements. This was the fourth meeting of a joint ministerial committee that Cairo and Tripoli set up in 1990 to oversee an ambitious program of economic integration.

Economic activity between the two nations has grown rapidly since 1989, when Egypt and Libya put 12 years of hostility behind them and re-established diplomatic ties. For Egypt, relations with its oil-rich but sparsely populated neighbor took on new urgency after Iraq invaded Kuwait and hundreds of thousands of Egyptian workers came home from the Persian Gulf to a jobless and landless future. 

For many of those displaced workers, Libya offers new possibilities. Already, one million Egyptians -- teachers and professionals as well as laborers -- are reported to be living and working in Libya. The money they send home eases the pressure on Egypt's troubled economy.

By this spring, 6,000 to 8,000 people were crossing the Libyan-Egyptian land border each day, according to Egyptian officials. In July, Egyptian exports to Libya were running at $ 25 million a month, according to theCairo newspaper Al-Ahram.

Egypt has politely rebuffed Libyan leader Col. Muammar Quaddafi's proposal for political integration, saying through editorials in the semi-official press that such a union may evolve over time. Last February, however, Egyptian Foreign Minister Sidki was quoted by Middle Eastern reporters as saying that Egypt's periodic talks with Libya are aimed at the maximum economic integration possible. Such pragmatic collaboration promises infusions of Libyan cash, which Egypt badly needs to reduce its high foreign debt and finance job creation.

A joint venture launched earlier this year, in which Libya will sell petroleum products to Egyptian consumers, will allow Egypt to export its own oil to earn hard currency. Domestic consumption presently absorbs about half Egypt's output.

Libya's Tamoil, which operates 2,000 service stations in Italy, will provide 80% of the investment for the new company. Egypt's General Petroleum Corporation will hold 10%, with the remaining 10% sold to the public. The company plans to operate a string of service stations along the Egyptian coastal road that runs from the Libyan border to Alexandria. And Libya is to finance a pipeline from its refinery at Tobruk to Alexandria, which will carry petroleum products to be sold within Egypt.

Other agreements under discussion include Libyan plans to finance a 400-mile railroad line connecting the two countries along their Mediterranean coasts and the interconnection of the two nations' electrical power grids, with plans to eventually hook up the entire Maghreb (the Arabic speaking states of North Africa).

In April, just before the UN Security Council imposed sanctions on Libya, discussions about the establishment of an Egyptian-Libyan bus company got under way. The venture would, in time, transport Muslim pilgrims from across the Maghreb to Saudi Arabia for the annual Hajj, or pilgrimage to Mecca.

Egypt and Libya also have been negotiating agreements on agriculture, fishing and ship repair. Libya has announced plans to build modern, irrigated settlements for Egyptian farmers in the southern part of its territory.

In late 1990 and early 1991, several delegations of Libyan military officers visited Cairo, giving rise to speculation that Libya would make investments in the Egyptian arms industry.

The government of Egypt is caught between the country's new ties with Libya and its special relationship with the United States. Egypt is the world's second largest recipient of U.S. aid, after Israel, and a key supporter of U.S. policies in the Middle East.

Egyptian President Hosni Mubarek has made repeated efforts to resolve the crisis created by the bombing of Pan Am flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in December 1988. The crash killed 270 people. Mubarek has visited Libya several times to urge Quaddafi to turn over the two men indicted by the U.S. government a year ago.

Mubarek has made equally strenuous efforts to persuade the United States and Great Britain, which has also brought charges against the two Libyans, to compromise on their demand that the men be tried in the United States or the United Kingdom. If Washington and London would agree to a trial in a neutral, third country, Mubarek says, Libya could surrender the men without appearing to surrender its national dignity.

Libya, in apparent eagerness to avoid the isolation and economic damage of sanctions, has moved to comply with the demands of UN Resolution 748 that calls for Libya to distance itself from "terrorist" groups. The Quaddafi government has dismantled guerrilla training camps and given Britain information on past links with the Irish Republican Army. Although President Mubarek has been unable to get Washington and London to soften their position on the extradition issue, Egypt recently got the support of the Arab League. At a mid-September meeting, the group's foreign ministers praised Libya's flexibility and called on Western nations to accept Tripoli's recent appeal for direct negotiations.

The league also urged the UN Security Council to lift the sanctions against Libya. Like other Arab states, Egypt has been complying with the sanctions, while making some moves to mitigate their impact. Egyptair, for example, temporarily hired some workers from the grounded Libyan Arab Airlines.

Egyptian officials are acutely aware that their prospects for economic cooperation with Libya hang on the thin thread of resolving the Lockerbie dispute. The current sanctions, imposed by the Security Council in April, are limited to a ban on air traffic, a prohibition of sales of arms, aircraft and spare parts, and a reduction in the size of Libyan diplomatic missions.

But moves to curb trade with Libya may come soon, according to a source on the House Subcommittee on Europe and the Middle East, who asked not to be named.

A Bush administration drive to get the United Nations to implement trade sanctions against Libya is "coming to the crunch," the source says. And UN Undersecretary-General Vladimir Petrovsky warned at an August 21 press conference in Tunisia that the time for Libya to comply with the extradition demand is running out. The official predicted further action "within days or weeks" unless Libya responds.

If that action includes a ban on trade or travel, Egypt risks losing what its government sees as a crucial safety valve for its building economic pressures. n


LOAD-DATE: October 15, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


229 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1992


War Could Resume in Disputed Saharan Desert


LENGTH: 1040 words


TIfariti, Western Sahara$ % Chris Simpson for Africa News Service$ %

The Polisario Front independence movement in Western Sahara says it is ready to resume hostilities if Morocco reneges on its promise to go along with a United Nations-supervised referendum to determine the territory's future.

More than one year after the signing of a cease-fire agreement, Polisario is frustrated at the long delays in implementing the UN peace plan and at what it sees as the world body's indifference in the face of persistent provocation from Morocco. Polisario leader Salem Ould Salek spoke for many Saharans when he remarked in Algiers on October 4 that Rabat has led the peace plan into an impasse and that Polisario is ready to fight its way out of it.

Although Polisario has not given up on the UN, it is evident that its patience is wearing thin. The peace plan called for a vote last January, allowing Saharans to choose between independence and union with Morocco, which forcefully annexed the former Spanish colony in 1976. The ballot has been postponed indefinitely, due to disagreements over voter eligibility. Each side says the other is intransigent on the issue. 

Visitors to the recent Festival of Saharan Youth at the Saharan camps near Tindouf, just inside the Algerian border, encountered widespread disappointment and frustration among the tens of thousands of refugees who fled the Moroccan invasion. Amidst the festivities, the traditional singing and dancing, the military parades and the children's displays, there is real anger at what is seen as the UN's hypocrisy.

"Iraq invaded Kuwait and there was an all-out war over it. Morocco annexed the Western Sahara and nothing happened," complained one embittered Saharan. The refugees know that Western Sahara is now a back-burner issue, not urgent enough for international civil servants to lose sleep over.

Although the Organization of African Unity has backed Polisario's call for Saharan self-determination, no powerful UN member has made an issue of the stalled peace process. Saharan refugees believe that Morocco's King Hassan II has effectively outmaneuvered the United Nations by moving in tens of thousands of Moroccans and asserting their right to vote as descendants of Saharan families.

The king also has forged ahead with a constitutional referendum, which includes Western Sahara as a Moroccan province.

The refugee camps are located in Algeria, which has steadily supported the Polisario cause. But no one knows how Algeria, pressed by its own constitutional crisis, would respond to a resumption of the war. And there is no real evidence that Polisario is poised to return to guerrilla warfare.

Polisario's top officials reiterate their commitment to the peace plan and their willingness to play by the UN rules. They say the cease-fire has been scrupulously observed, that every effort has been made to accommodate the UN peacekeeping force and that Polisario officials are ready to assist in the referendum process, provided an acceptable agreement on voter eligibility can be found.

But they warn that Saharan patience has its limits. If pushed, Polisario will fight, say the Saharan commanders and their troops.

So far, the monitoring of the cease-fire has been the only successful part of Minurso -- UN Mission for the Organization of a Referendum in Western Sahara. UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali's latest report on the mission, released last August, praises the 300 Minurso military personnel who have been deployed in both Polisario- and Moroccan-controlled territory.

Whatever Polisario's reservations about Minurso in general, relations between the independence movement and the UN troops on the ground appear excellent. Minurso officers were honored guests at the recent youth festival. In conversation, the peacekeepers give every impression of enjoying their time with the Saharans, although they express concern at the lack of information about the peace process from diplomats.

The mood also is cheerful at Minurso bases in Polisario-controlled territory, 300 miles west of the Algerian border, where Russians, Chinese, Americans and other international observers patrol the surrounding area, checking on Polisario units and keeping the UN flag flying. The peacekeeping troops compliment Polisario's fighting forces for being friendly, cooperative and professional.

But for the Saharan combatants, camped out in the shells of buildings that were bombed by Morocco only days before the cease-fire in August 1991, conditions are considerably harsher than those enjoyed by Minurso, and the mood is markedly more serious. Here among the debris, the shells and the odd broken-down Moroccan tank, memories of the war are very fresh and very bitter. The enemy has not changed, nor has Polisario's objective of Saharan self-determination.

Despite the prevalent war-weariness, the atmosphere here suggests that Polisario's warning that fighting could begin again is more than mere posturing. n

Chris Simpson is a British journalist who has just returned from a trip to Western Sahara and Saharan refugee camps in Algeria.


LOAD-DATE: October 15, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


230 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1992


Group Charges U.S. Allowed Flow of Shotguns to South Africa Lawsuit Seeks Release of Documents


LENGTH: 1840 words


Karen Gellen * Africa News Service A New York-based anti-apartheid group is taking the U.S. government to court, charging that Washington looked the other way as tons of American-made shotguns poured into South Africa.

The Africa Fund launched a law suit last month to force the federal government to release 1,100 documents detailing arms exports to Southern Africa. According to the Africa Fund, the illegal arms flow paralleled a sharp escalation in township fighting, leading to suspicions that the weapons helped fuel the violence that has killed more than 8,000 people since 1989.

The fund acted after the Commerce Department refused to comply with a request for the documents that the fund filed in June 1991 under the Freedom of Information Act.

Government officials say that disclosure would be contrary to the "national interest" and would "jeopardize an ongoing criminal investigation." 

The anti-apartheid group charges that the Commerce Department repeatedly issued export licenses to companies violating U.S. sanctions laws and the United Nations arms embargo against South Africa. The Africa Fund says Washington has refused to investigate the documented diversion to South Africa of shotguns ostensibly destined for sporting goods shops in neighboring Southern African countries.

In a September 14 Federal District Court hearing on the civil suit, the Africa Fund publicly presented detailed evidence of such diversions. The group, working in cooperation with the Philadelphia-based American Friends Service Committee (AFSC), quietly provided the Commerce Department with much of the same material nearly two years ago. The documents show that in 1989-91, U.S. companies shipped large quantities of shotguns to the South African port of Cape Town and to Namibia's Walvis Bay, then under Pretoria's control.

Commerce Department memos obtained by the Africa Fund confirm government knowledge that many of the export licenses authorizing the shipments were "fraudulent." But the evidence marshaled both by the anti-apartheid group and by government investigators has been consigned to "a black hole in space," according to Africa Fund attorney Franklin Siegal.

The investigation is on "the bureaucratic slow track," says Siegal, who is affiliated with the New York-based Center for Constitutional Rights. He says the apparent foot dragging stems from U.S. foreign policy priorities, charging that some embargoes are enforced vigorously, and some not at all."

Siegal argues that the wheels have turned far more rapidly in other cases. "Try to send a can of evaporated milk to Baghdad," he says, "and they stop you at the airport, and the embassy in Amman, Jordan, knows your name. The U.S. is not taking the South African arms embargo seriously."

Assistant U.S. Attorney Peter Sobol, who is defending the Commerce Department in the Africa Fund suit, counters that "the documents we're investigating are cumbersome." Sobol says "it takes weeks and months to verify and corroborate." Another U.S. attorney in the case, Chinta Gaston, says the government is "vigorously pursuing" the probe.

The Africa Fund is calling for a halt to all arms shipments through South African ports, given the documented opportunity for diversion. The group also views high-volume shotgun sales to small neighboring states as highly suspect.

A report last month in the Johannesburg-based Weekly Mail cites documents confirming that over 50 tons of U.S-made munitions were exported to Southern Africa in the past four years. The documents show that "hundreds of semi-automatic pistols, revolvers, rifles, magazines and hundreds of thousands of rounds of ammunition left the United States but never arrived at their stated destination of Harare, Zimbabwe," the paper reports. "The weapons," writes correspondent Peter Stober, "were to have been shipped via Cape Town."

In one memo released by the Africa Fund, then Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger informs the Commerce Department that a shotgun dealer in Botswana, named as the buyer in one U.S. export license, "apparently does not exist."

Another memo from Eagleburger, who is currently acting secretary of State, describes a deal where the named customer in Zimbabwe, Tatos Brothers, denies placing two weapons orders for which U.S. export licenses were granted. "What became of these shipments," asks Eagleburger, "if they did not go to Zimbabwe?"

According to the Africa Fund, the government should have anticipated the illegal opportunities presented by such loopholes and closed them from the outset. "You don't send embargoed goods through an embargoed country," says the fund's research associate, Richard Knight. "You wouldn't ship weapons to Amman through Baghdad or send hunting rifles through Bosnia right now."

The organization charges that at least 20 tons of U.S.-made shotguns and ammunition reached South Africa from mid-1990 to mid-1991 alone. The fund says it is an irony that eight tons of arms left New York harbor for South Africa in June l990, during Nelson Mandela's first U.S. visit.

Testifying September 23 before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Africa Fund Executive Director Jennifer Davis charged that the Bush administration has declined "to take effective public action" against the violence plaguing South Africa. She decried in particular the administration's "obstruction and delay rather than energetic investigation" of the illegal shotgun exports documented by the Africa Fund and the AFSC.

Davis termed the current situation in South Africa a "replay" of the protracted process leading to Namibia's independence. There was a l2-year delay, she recalled, between the first negotiated agreement on ending South African rule and the day the independence flag went up in 1990. It is now documented, noted Davis, that during the long years of talks, Pretoria utilized "hit squads, death squads and dirty tricks" to stave off independence.

Drawing on her June visit to South Africa, Davis provided the Senate committee with graphic examples of conditions in northern Natal province, where local activists told her they were living like hunted prey. After recounting the mass killings and destruction of homes in the area, one labor organizer said, "We are like gazelles. We have no home; we must lie down in the field at night."

The Africa Fund alleges Washington is at best "asleep at the switch" for not stemming the arms flow to South Africa. The group cites a sizable arms cache discovered in May at the home of a Natal police officer. The cache included a shotgun manufactured by the Connecticut-based company, O.F. Mossberg & Sons. Maston-Wright, the North Haven, CT, company that handles Mossberg exports, categorically denies "any U.S. laws were broken" in the deal.

Documents obtained by the fund show that the Mossberg weapon had been licensed for export to a buyer in Zimbabwe. Commerce Department approval was given, even though the order was faxed directly from South Africa, with no accompanying documentation about the supposed customer in the neighboring country. The documents obtained by the Africa Fund detail scores of such shady deals involving phantom buyers outside South Africa or shipments made directly into Cape Town with no additional destination listed.

The fund first provided the government with documentation of the sanctions-busting in November 1990. The recently obtained internal memos written by Eagleburger and others indicate that elements of the scam were clear to top officials. Those facts led Davis to tell the Foreign Relations Committee in mid-September that "the claims that a good faith investigation is underway appear to be flimsy."

Some sources cite contending interests among the various government agencies involved -- Commerce, Customs and State -- as a factor in the seeming disarray.

A cable sent to Washington from the U.S. Embassy in Botswana, a copy of which was obtained by the Africa Fund, referred to the bogged-down investigation and noted that Botswana was balking at allowing more U.S. probes. The memo attributed the country's stand to irritation at "Clouseau impersonators tramping about, each conducting his or her own little investigation, repetitively interrogating the same bemused officials and Botswana citizens."

Africa Fund attorney Siegal charges that the disorganization and interagency rivalry are "deliberately structured" to stall the investigation. A serious government probe, he observes, is tightly coordinated by the attorney general and the FBI.

U.S. Attorney Gaston rejects that view, asserting that crossed wires among various government agencies is often "unavoidable" and has "no bearing" on the diligence of the probe. In the long-running John Gotti case, for example, says Gaston, a series of "Clouseau impersonators" on the prosecution side enabled the now-jailed Mafia boss to evade conviction repeatedly.

The Africa Fund, however, views those supposed obstacles as a pretext. "It's not as exotic as the government is making it appear in court," says Siegal. "When they really want to investigate, they make sure people don't step on each other's toes.

"We've been stonewalled from the first," he says. "Something fishy is going on." n


LOAD-DATE: October 15, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


231 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1992


Bush Team Readies Africa Policy Directive: Clinton promises to boost support for democracy


LENGTH: 1360 words


Reed Kramer * Africa News Service Washington, DC. Administration officials are drafting a presidential directive redefining post-Cold War policy toward Africa.

The document, which President George Bush could sign in the next few weeks, is intended to help avoid future Somalias and fine-tune Washington's response to the rapid changes taking places across the African continent, senior officials say. The directive is the outcome of an extensive interagency study, known as National Security Review (NSR) 30, which was completed last month. 

Although Africa has received little attention during the current presidential campaign, in which foreign policy has been a side issue to the economy, Governor Bill Clinton this month criticized Bush for an "ambivalence about supporting democracy." The governor earlier decried the administration's "months of neglect" of famine in Somalia.

Bush has defended his record, pointing in a recent statement "to significant achievements in Africa over the last four years in conflict resolution, support for burgeoning democracies and human rights, and assisting in humanitarian crises."

Preparation of the policy review has involved more than a dozen federal agencies, according to administration sources. Although the study was begun before Somalia attracted top-level attention, unease over the slow response to the Somali crisis has spurred the decision-making process, officials say. "Some people thought we should wait -- this close to election time -- but after what happened in Somalia, we decided we had to move this thing forward," one senior administration aide said.

The review has looked at ways to promote political stability and economic growth, how to expand American markets and to preserve Africa's fragile ecology, and at what can be done to settle the continent's on-going wars. "We've always looked at Africa through the prism of East/West competition," the official said. "Now that that has melted away, we can focus on what's important for Africa and what best serves our interests in Africa."

"Our major focus is humanitarian, now that all the Cold War baggage is gone," another official said.

In his most recent foreign policy speech, Clinton said the president "has been slow to place America's support behind the fledgling democratic movements" in Africa. Speaking in Milwaukee on October 1, the Democratic nominee said the United States must "encourage and nurture the stirrings for democratic reform that are surfacing all across Africa." He said the administration had pursued a "failed" policy towards South Africa and "had to be prodded" to impose sanctions and to pressure Pretoria to change.

Bush administration officials say they don't see major differences on Africa policy issues between the two candidates. They expect the current reassessment and the resulting directive to guide American relations with Africa no matter who gets elected.

Unlike previous policy reviews, where contentious questions often led to heated disagreements between departments or agencies, the latest study has evoked almost no dissension. "It's remarkable how agreed everyone is," says one official involved in coordinating the input from the various parts of the federal bureaucracy. "We have been able to concentrate on setting priorities and choosing emphases."

Participants in NSR 30 include officials from the departments of State, Defense, Treasury and Commerce, and from the Central Intelligence Agency, the Defense Intelligence Agency, the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the Office of Management and Budget, the Environmental Protection Agency, the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, the Export Import Bank, and the Peace Corps.

According to several officials, the language outlining the premises of the draft presidential directive is much like the statement the administration submitted to Africa Report, published by the New York-based African-American Institute. "Our basic interests are the promotion of peaceful change and conflict resolution, democracy and improved governance, free market economic policies, sustainable development, and effective African action on transnational issues such as AIDS, the environment, population growth and terrorism," Bush says in the statement, which appears in the current issue of the magazine.

NSR 30 emphasizes the need for greater U.S. support for conflict resolution, officials say. "We recognize that it is difficult to advance any of our other objectives when fighting is underway," says one of the document's authors. "We have strengthened conflict management capabilities at both the national and regional levels in Africa," Bush told Africa Report. "Our goal is to encourage Africans to play a greater role in solving Africa's problems and conflicts and to involve more fully the rest of the world community, especially the United Nations."

In one unannounced move in that direction, the president signed a formal "determination" last month authorizing U.S. funding for a planned peacekeeping operation by the Organization of African Unity (OAU), the continent-wide grouping of 51-member-nations. The action was sparked by an agreement now in the works, for an OAU-initiated multilateral force to monitor a cease-fire between government troops and an armed rebel movement in Rwanda, in preparation for national elections.

Although the projected U.S. contribution is only $ 500,000, the presidential determination positions the administration to make additional outlays for OAU-directed peacekeeping when additional opportunities arise.

Clinton, in a statement also published by Africa Report, says U.S. support for democracy in Africa and around the world should not be pursued "selectively or half-heartedly." The democratic nominee advocates "a new strategy of American engagement" to support "the spread of consolidation" of democracy in Africa.

"The Bush administration has been tepid when it should have been decisive in ending aid to dictators, such as Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire, in reacting to the crisis caused by escalating violence in South Africa, in responding to the humanitarian tragedy in Somalia," he says. "I believe we can do better."

Michael Clough, a Clinton advisor on Africa, says the United States could have done much more to support positive trends in Africa, even with limited resources. Clough, who is director of the World Policy Institute in New York, sees the current policy reappraisal as a classic case of too little too late. "If we had been serious about creating a stable democratic Africa," he says, "we wouldn't have some of the crises we now have. Somalia did not have to happen." n


LOAD-DATE: October 15, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


232 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1992


Ghana Prepares for National Vote


LENGTH: 1760 words


Kwame Karikari * Africa News Service

In cities and towns across the country, Ghanaians are agog with electioneering, as the West African nation moves toward its first national ballot in more than a decade.

Cars and vans displaying party symbols and colors blare slogans and songs from rooftop-mounted loudspeakers. Crowds fill empty lots, sidewalks and village squares for weekend rallies. Posters, handbills and leaflets vie for space on street lamp posts, tree trunks, bus stops, storefronts and billboards.

Wherever two or three people congregate there is lively political discussion, and interest grows as election day nears. The country's next president will be selected in voting on November 3. Members of parliament will be chosen on December 7. 

This will be the fourth time since independence in 1957 that Ghana could try to establish multiparty constitutional government. It will be the second time that Flt. Lt. Jerry Rawlings, head of the country's ruling military council, supervises such a changeover.

This time Rawlings is himself a player. He retired from the Ghana Air Force in mid-September to qualify as a candidate for the presidency. If he wins, he will become the first military ruler in Africa to secure a new term in office through a fair and contested election.

Although campaign excitement is apparent, an underlying layer of disquiet is evident. Politicians and the press preach peace, and prayers in churches and mosques call for a harmonious outcome to the process.

But mutual mistrust characterizes supporters and opponents of the government. Tensions have been increased by the agitation and strikes called by civil servants and other public employees that have been taking place alongside the electoral campaign.

By September 30, the deadline for filing for the presidency, five candidates and nine parties had registered. By early October, according to the Interim National Electoral Commission, five parties had registered 1,000 candidates for the 200 parliamentary seats. But the number of contestants could drop as a result of mergers or alliances before election day.

The major parties that emerged after the ban on political activity was lifted in May all claim the mantle of half-century-old parties -- one populist, one conservative -- whose rivalry dates from the independence struggle in the 1940s.

But the dominance of these two traditions has been challenged by the emergence of the National Democratic Congress (NDC), led by Rawlings.

Four parties trace their ancestry to the old Convention People's Party, founded in 1949 by the country's first president, Kwame Nkrumah. They are: the People's Heritage

Party (PHP), led by Emmanuel Erskine, a general who formerly headed United Nations peacekeeping forces in Lebanon; former President Hilla Limann's People's National Convention (PNC); the National Independence Party (NIP), headed by wealthy poultry farmer and fundamentalist Christian Kwabena Darko; and the National Convention Party (NCP), chaired by K. N. Arkaah, a Harvard-trained economist and former international civil servant.

Among several elements of the opposition, the old rivalry is yielding to a shared determination to see Rawlings lose. At the end of last month, Limann's PNP announced agreement with the New Patriotic Party (NPP) to support each others' candidates in the event of a presidential run-off. The exception to the anti-Rawlings movement is the National Convention Party, which has entered an electoral alliance with Rawlings' NDC and named NCP leader Arkaah as Rawlings' running mate. A key figure in the NCP is Capt. Kojo Tsikata, the number two official in the ruling military council who is blamed by many for the regime's human rights abuses.

The opposition grouping that seems to have the most popular support is the New Patriotic Party (NPP), with origins in the old conservative nationalist United Party and a solid following from middle class urban voters.

Other Ghanaians seem to be gravitating towards the NPP and its standard-bearer, the well-known historian Albert Adu Boahen, as the only strong competition to oust Rawlings and the NDC. One of the Nkrumahist formations, the PHP, has already said it might ally with the NPP to try to insure a Rawlings defeat.

The NDC is running on Rawlings' record of economic recovery. The country's structural adjustment program is hailed by Western donors and international financial institutions and has attracted millions of dollars in foreign aid.

The government can point to the rehabilitation of the country's communications infrastructure, heavy investments in mines and extractive industries, reorganization of the banking sector, and the invigoration of service industries.

But the economic reforms have dealt a hard blow to local manufacturing and to food production. And despite its ambitious programs, a reputation for honesty and competence among officials, and an economic growth rate that is among the highest in Africa, Ghana has had little success in attracting overseas capital.

Rawlings also faces criticism because of the high level of unemployment and the reduction of government subsidies for health, education, and agriculture. Urban workers have lost earning power, and they blame their plight on Rawlings' economic austerity program.

However, opposition parties have offered almost no substantive alternative plans, promising instead to make changes on the fringes of the economic reforms. The NPP's Boahen says he supports the recovery program in principle but differs with Rawlings on implementation.

"Private investors have refused to participate in the economy because they are afraid of persecutions," Boahen said. "It should have been possible for us to register an 11% to 12% growth rate, not the 5.6% the government has so far achieved."

The opposition's strongest plank is probably its criticism of the government's human rights record, which is widely viewed as the worst of any administration since independence.

Preparations for voting are moving ahead. International observer missions, including teams from the Carter Center in Atlanta and the British Commonwealth, are lined up to monitor the process. But the national electoral commission has warned that incidents of political violence could pose a threat to the transition program.

Recently, the commission accused the government of being "petrified into inaction" and said it would not be able to "perform the work for which we were created" if the violence is not stopped.

The commission's accounting of the violent acts implicates supporters of Rawlings' NDC for attacking NPP loyalists in many parts of the country.

The commission has announced the registration of over eight million voters, after the elimination of 1.5 million names believed to represent duplication. The figure is still seen as suspiciously high by some observers, since such a large segment of the country's less than 16 million population is under 15 years of age.

To ensure unfettered campaigning, the opposition had demanded the repeal of the Preventive Detention Custody Law and the Habeas Corpus Amendment Law, adopted in 1982 and 1984 and used by the military government to detain critics without charge or trial. On October 2, both laws were rescinded.

After more than a decade at the top, Rawlings is clearly the focus of the debate. The opposition says the new parliamentary system is doomed to instability if Rawlings remains on the political scene. The last time he turned over power to an elected administration, he returned 27 months later to stage another takeover, ousting President Limann from office in 1981.

For his part, Rawlings has expressed doubts that the opposition would accept an NDC victory peacefully. He says he expects the results to be challenged if he emerges as winner.

Campaigning by government opponents has been overshadowed by the NDC effort. Rawlings has the support of paramilitary organs created by the regime, the national women's organization that is headed by his wife, and district and administrative agencies established in recent years as part of the transition to elected civilian rule.

Opposition parties say they lack the resources to effectively challenge the NDC, which they suspect is using state facilities and funds. Nor can opponents match Rawlings' populist stagecraft, which attracts rural people and considerable sections of the urban youth. Nevertheless, the opposition alliance itself commands large followings, and the outcome of the voting remains unpredictable. n


LOAD-DATE: October 15, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


233 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 26, 1992


Deja Vu


LENGTH: 308 words


After nearly two years of unsettled calm, Liberia has been thrust back into active warfare. Fighting broke out on October 15, just outside Monrovia, the capital, between the West African peacekeeping force, known as Ecomog, and the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL), led by Charles Taylor. 

Brutal civil strife began at the end of 1989 and continued until Ecomog separated three warring Liberian factions in late 1990. The conflict left an estimated 60,000 persons dead -- 20,000 from the fighting and another 40,000 who starved. The war also destroyed most of the country's infrastructure and uprooted half the population.

Taylor has accused Ecomog, which includes soldiers from seven West African nations, of trying to keep him from taking power. West African leaders have been attempting to broker a peace arrangement that was to have led to elections before the end of this year.

In the latest fighting, Ecomog has bombarded Taylor's forces and NPFL commandos have conducted nighttime raids into Monrovia where some reportedly have knifed Ecomog soldiers to death.

The fighting has disrupted the city's electricity, water and communications services, and has sent tens of thousands of people scurrying from areas around the capital into the city center. The situation is an eerie repetition of events during the summer of 1990, when refugees thronged into Monrovia to escape fighting in the countryside. Monrovia residents are fighting off panic that the conflict will again sweep through the city as it did then.


LOAD-DATE: November 2, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


234 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 26, 1992


Elections on Hold


LENGTH: 240 words


Algerian government officials have announced there will be no parliamentary elections in the near future. In a speech on October 20, Prime Minister Belaid Abdesselam told Algerians that he needs at least three years to spark economic recovery and stabilize the country's political climate before elections can be held. 

Officials cite the rise of Islamic fundamentalism as the basis for political instability in Algeria. The government banned the Islamic Salvation Front (FIS) opposition group last March after it appeared headed for an electoral victory. President Ali Kafi claims that the FIS's goal is to destabilize the current government through the use of violence. FIS supporters have been blamed for killing about 140 members of the state security forces since the government imposed a state of emergency in February.

In mid-October, Kafi signed a measure that will allow sentences ranging from five years to life imprisonment without appeal for people convicted of terrorism, in an attempt to curb mounting violence. The government's get-tough campaign has been dubbed "iron cleansing."


LOAD-DATE: November 2, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


235 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 26, 1992


Campaign Trail


LENGTH: 534 words


Only days before Ghana's November 3 presidential election, politicians opposed to incumbent military leader Flt. Lt. Jerry Rawlings have gone to court seeking to disqualify him as a candidate.

John Bilson, a prominent politician and physician, wants the courts to bar Rawlings from the contest on the grounds that he is not a Ghanaian citizen.

Rawlings' paternal parentage is unknown -- a point constantly raised by his opponents to ridicule him. 

Bilson also wants the court to stop the Interim National Electoral Commission (IEC) from holding the elections until Rawlings is struck from the contest.

Almost nobody expects the courts to grant Bilson and his supporters their plea. The purpose of the case may be more to throw political pebbles that embarrass the head of state rather than a serious attempt to get Rawlings out of the race by legal means.

The judge, an object of public sympathy, adjourned the case from October 19 to 21, pleading the need for more time to study the presentations. In the streets of Accra, security forces had difficulty restraining angry Rawlings followers who gathered when the court sat.

Though reports continue of isolated cases of political violence, there has been no major disruption of the electoral program. But several religious and civil groups organized a march for October 31 to call for peaceful elections.
