Meanwhile, workers have mounted demonstrations in the industrial city of Tema, near Accra, in the central provisional capital of Cape Coast, and elsewhere. Organized labor is apprehensive that government promises for wage raises and other improvements will not be kept after the elections are over.

The election campaign is lively. The Ghana Broadcasting Corporation is televising interviews with the five presidential candidates and the University of Ghana Alumni Association organized a symposium in Accra for all the presidential hopefuls.

As the debates go on, the ruling Provisional National Defense Council has increased soldiers' pay and has been giving contracts to rehabilitate roads, build public projects and renovate collapsed structures in several rural communities. The opposition says the actions are a play to win votes.

The opposition also demands the repeal of repressive laws still on the books. The secretary of the Interior can order "administrative detention" arbitrarily, and the PNDC has the power to execute people for political offenses -- a deterrent, critics say, to the conduct of a free election.


LOAD-DATE: November 2, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


236 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 26, 1992


Transition Postponed


LENGTH: 427 words


Following a six-hour meeting of the Armed Forces Ruling Council, Nigerian President Ibrahim Babangida canceled the results of the October presidential primaries based on reports of massive fraud and malpractice. In a speech at Abuja, the nation's capital, Babangida also announced the dissolution of both the Social Democratic Party (SDP) and the National Republican Convention (NRC) party leadership and gave control of the parties to provisional caretaker committees. He asked the National Electoral Commission (NEC) to propose a new election process within two weeks and to organize party conventions, that will restructure party leadership and produce an official list of presidential candidates. 

Many Nigerians are concerned that Babangida's latest actions will postpone indefinitely the country's transition to civilian rule. A spokesman for the Lagos-based Civil Liberties Organization accused the president of setting the stage for electoral fraud and then using the botched primaries as an excuse to prolong his stay in power.

Election results were canceled once before during this presidential race. Following the primary held on August 6, NRC and SDP officials voided the results, citing "widespread malpractice." Vice President Augustus Aikhomu warned party officials and candidates that the government would intervene if the primaries failed again. After two reportedly successful rounds of primaries, the third round resulted in a resurgence of cries of vote rigging. Ten of 12 SDP presidential candidates withdrew from the race in protest of government inaction on their charges against party chairman Baba Kingabe. Candidates alleged that Kingabe had conspired with party officials to name retired general, Shehu Musa Yar' Adua, as the party's presidential candidate. Eleven NRC candidates also protested the election results. On October 6, Babangida's government intervened and put the primaries on hold pending the results of a NEC investigation of charges of electoral fraud.

Babangida, who has been Nigeria's head of state since 1985, has pledged to return control of the country to civilian rule in January of 1993.


LOAD-DATE: November 2, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


237 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 26, 1992


Banda Bows


LENGTH: 414 words


In a slight bow to domestic and international pressure, President Kamuzu Hastings Banda has announced a referendum on whether to end one-party rule in Malawi. But opposition leaders say they still are not convinced that Banda will ease political restrictions in the country and allow a truly free vote. 

Banda, believed to be over 90 years of age, has governed the small southern African nation since independence in 1964. Two years after taking office he banned opposition parties.

On October 20, Orton Ching'oli Chirwa, a close colleague of Banda's during the independence campaign and the country's first attorney-general, died in jail after a lengthy imprisonment. Chirwa, exiled after a fallout with Banda, was kidnapped with his wife by Malawian security agents along the Malawi-Zambia border in 1981, was convicted and condemned to death for treason. His sentence was commuted to life imprisonment after an international clemency campaign by human rights groups.

In May, international aid donors suspended aid to Malawi and called for improvement in the treatment of dissidents. Amnesty International says the Malawi government routinely detains and tortures opponents.

The government denies the accusations, and Banda, a self-declared "president for life," contends that his decision to allow the referendum will prove conclusively that the people of Malawi prefer his single-party leadership.

Several former top members of Banda's Malawi Congress Party have formed a coalition to press for multiparty democracy. The group, known as the United Democratic Front, welcomed Banda's decision to hold the referendum but said that all those involved in campaigning for or against the change should be given equal access to state-run media. The front also is calling for international monitors for the referendum process to ensure that voting is conducted fairly.


LOAD-DATE: November 2, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


238 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 26, 1992


Two Steps Forward, One Back


LENGTH: 347 words


Disagreement over the composition of an interim parliament have stalled talks between the government of Rwanda and leaders of the rebel Rwandan Patriotic Front (RPF). In their proposals for an interim government, Rwandan officials have invited RPF leaders to join the present parliament but say all other opposition groups should be elected. RPF officials insist that the government dissolve the parliament and form a new legislative body representing all national parties.

Earlier, in mid-October, Tanzanian Foreign Minister Ahmed Hassan Diria, who is chairing the talks, announced that both groups had made compromises and were close to signing a peace accord that would end two years of civil war in the central African country. Both groups agreed that some powers of the presidency would be transferred to an appointed all-party cabinet. The prime minister would nominate cabinet ministers, who would be endorsed by parliament. The president would chair cabinet meetings, but would have no veto power over cabinet decisions.

Among the areas of disagreement between the RPF and government officials is how to share judicial power with members of opposition groups. And the two sides remain split over the length of the transition period. The government wants the interim administration in place for six months before elections are held; the RPF has proposed a four-year transitional government.

The negotiations are aimed at ending conflict between the government and the RPF, which invaded the country from neighboring Uganda in August 1990. Signing of a peace accord was scheduled for October 1, but the RPF demand for more far-reaching political reforms has delayed the agreement.


LOAD-DATE: November 2, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


239 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 26, 1992


Try Again


SECTION: DATELINE: AFRICA


LENGTH: 334 words


Amnesty International has appealed to Tunisian authorities to retry or release 265 Muslim fundamentalists convicted of plotting to overthrow the government last August. Amnesty representatives have presented Tunisian officials with evidence of torture and the deaths of several prisoners while in custody. 

Leaders of the London-based human rights organization are calling for a full government investigation of the allegations. The group says observers report that the courts heard insufficient evidence to substantiate the charges against the defendants. Amnesty observers also reported that the prisoners did not have lawyers during their months in detainment, and that some of the defendants, who told the courts that they had been the victims of torture, had to be supported by police officers to walk. Tunisian Foreign Minister Habib ben Yahia denied Amnesty's charges and said that the government is investigating the circumstances of one prisoner's death.

President Zine El-Abidine Ben Ali's government has cracked down on Tunisia's Islamic fundamentalist movement since he came to power in a bloodless coup in 1987. He claims that the arrests were necessary to protect the country, located between Algeria and Libya, from a coup attempt and potential civil war. In July, 279 Muslim fundamentalists were accused of being members of the banned An-Nahda movement and were tried before a military tribunal in Tunis. Fifty-five defendants were tried in absentia, including An-Nahda President Rached Ghannouchi. Several of those who were convicted were sentenced to life imprisonment.


LOAD-DATE: November 2, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


240 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 26, 1992


Think Positive


LENGTH: 360 words


Doom and gloom. Doom and gloom is mostly what you report on Africa. I find it hard to believe that virtually nothing good ever happens across almost 12 million square miles of land occupied by millions of people. I find it hard to believe that the motherland of civilization no longer has anything good to say or offer the world.

I would expect a negatively skewed portrayal of Africa on the pages of the New York Times or the Washington Post. After all, that's their job in the Western habit of downplaying the significance or mere existence of Africa. But AfricaNews is supposed to be different. Isn't it? Yet there is hardly ever a positive headline on the front page of AfricaNews.

My criticism is not that reporting of negative or tragic occurrences on the continent should not be done, but rather that the reporting should be more balanced with positive events. For example: What progress is being made in housing development? What are the African scientists working on? What is new in African art and music? What of human perseverance stories of how the children and women deal with the problems of life in African countries?

Walter Collier, Oak Bluffs, MA

Reporting on the many positive changes taking place in Africa is a priority for us, as is trying to keep our readers abreast of important political and economic developments. With our limited staff and financial resources, the scramble to stay current means that coverage of crises affecting millions of Africans may take precedence over the optimistic stories you suggest. But you can find some of these in our recent issues, and more are on the way. -- Ed.


LOAD-DATE: November 2, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


241 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 26, 1992


Not !


SECTION: LETTERS


LENGTH: 267 words


I am writing to ask you to print a correction to my recent note that was published as a letter to the editor. I wrote that note as an unaffiliated subscriber with only my home address on the letter. I was offended that someone at AfricaNews took the liberty to give me an affiliation that I did not claim. I have not been at Boston University since December 1989. Dr. Barbara Brown is the Outreach Director of the African Studies Center at Boston University and has been in that position since 1990. Your mistake led readers to conclude that I had made that claim (of current affiliation with Boston University) and caused embarrassment to me, to Dr. Brown and to Boston University. In addition, you should also consider that even when one has an affiliation, a letter writer may be writing as a private citizen and may not want even a current affiliation included.

Jo Sullivan, Lynn, MA

We regret the error and apologize for any misunderstanding this may have caused. It is our policy to contact all letter writers to confirm that they wrote to us and to obtain their permission before publication. That was not done in this case, and we are sorry. -- Ed.

LANGUAGE: English

242 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 26, 1992


Report on the Commission of Inquiry Into Complaints by Former African NationalCongress Prisoners and Detainees


LENGTH: 3400 words


Terms of Reference

In letters to each of the members of the Commission, the President of the ANC indicated his attitude to the task of the Commission. The letter stated, among other things, the following:

"Complaints have been made to the ANC by a number of persons who were previously held as prisoners by it in camps outside of South Africa concerning the conditions in which they were held, the manner in which they were treated and the manner in which their property was dealt with after their detention.

These complaints are serious and call for a full and thorough investigation by the ANC to establish whether or not they are correct, and if they are, what action it should take in consequence thereof." 

Physical Conditions of Detention

Evidence was presented about the conditions of detention at various prison camps. These prison camps included those specially set up by the ANC, as well as ordinary prisons run by the governments of the countries in which they were situated. It is clear from the evidence, however, that the gravest abuses were perpetrated in Quatro camp in Angola. This camp was apparently also known as "Camp 32" and the "Morris Seabelo Rehabilitation Center." It was originally conceived of as a rehabilitation center. The terms of reference empowered the commission to visit the places of detention subject to making the necessary arrangements with the governments of the countries concerned. In the case of Quatro, we were informed by witnesses that the camp had been demolished. An inspection, therefore, would have revealed little.

The complaints about the physical conditions of detention related mainly to the type of cells in which detainees were held, the lack of proper medical facilities and poor nutrition. What follows is a general overview of the evidence.

The Cells

The evidence revealed that at Quatro camp, provision was made for both communal cells as well as isolation cells. The communal cells were, from time to time, overcrowded and inadequately ventilated. We were told that on occasions, the temperature inside the cell was higher than outside it. Certain detainees were held in solitary confinement, often for extended periods.

Hygiene and Medical Care

One of the persistent and most severe complaints which emerged from the evidence concerned the lack of adequate health treatment. The necessity for medical care cannot be separated from the conditions under which detainees were held. We were told that the tropical climate in Angola resulted in high temperatures. Problems associated with the heat and the conditions of detention included the development of skin complaints, diarrhea and malaria. We were advised that there was no running water in the entire camp

These difficulties affected all and not only the detainees. However, the evidence revealed that the camp guards and commanders made it virtually impossible for detainees to maintain themselves and their clothing in a healthy condition. We were informed that blankets were allowed to be washed only once every six months and that the detainees were then allowed to bathe in the water which remained after the blankets had been washed.

Toilet facilities for detainees were primitive. Detainees were required to attend to their bodily functions by means of plastic containers, which were cut in half and which were emptied once a day.

It appeared that no suitable qualified medical officer was available at all times to deal with the day-to-day medical problems of detainees. A doctor did visit the camp, but only on rare occasions. We were informed that his attitude was generally unsympathetic since he was advised in advance that the detainees were responsible for the deaths of members of the ANC.

The absence of suitably qualified medical personnel was particularly serious in view of the injuries suffered by inmates at the hands of their captors. Many detainees were severely assaulted and injured. Not only was the health care inadequate, but we were informed that some of the medical orderlies actually participated in the assaults.

Food

The consensus of the witnesses was that the food at Quatro camp was worse than anywhere else. The diet consisted primarily of beans and rice. Certain detainees received one glass of water every 24 hours. In 1987, the then president of the ANC, Mr. Oliver Tambo, visited Quatro camp. Although he was apparently disturbed by what he saw, his visit had little impact upon the food situation. Indeed, for some six months thereafter, the diet of detainees consisted mainly of diluted tomato puree and rice. Food deprivation was frequently used as a form of punishment.

The lack of adequate nutrition was, in our view, unconscionable and pernicious. We were informed that the camp had an adequate supply of tropical fruit which grew freely in the vicinity, but which was out of bounds to detainees. The camp commanders, in contrast to the detainees, had a plentiful supply of food, which included tinned products supplied to the camp. Any food left over after the commanders had their fill was fed to the pigs.

Maltreatment

A striking feature of the evidence presented to the commission was its consistency. The experience of the former detainees was depressingly similar, varying only in degree of severity. The witnesses who testified included persons still loyal to the ANC and those who are hostile to the ANC. It included persons convicted of crimes and others never charged. The periods of detention and the alleged reasons therefore varied markedly. Yet, the same practices and names cropped up over and over again. We rule out the possibility of collusion or fabrication.

It is not proposed in this report to detail the treatment of each detainee individually. The individual statement of the detainees together with the typed record of the inquiry will be made available separately to the president of the ANC. A general overview of the abuses will be given. The most persistent abuses were perpetrated in Quatro, which was not inappropriately described by one witness as a concentration camp. There were abuses, sometimes of the most chilling kind, perpetrated elsewhere. These will be dealt with separately.

Quatro

Quatro was essentially a camp for suspected enemy agents and dissidents. The attitude of the camp guards, commanders and medical assistants seemed to be universally hostile to the inmates. The inmates, whether convicted of any offenses or not, were denigrated, humiliated and abused, often with staggering brutality. The violence inflicted on the prisoners usually had nothing whatsoever to do with any disciplinary transgression. It was violence for the sake of violence. One witness articulated what emerged as the common experience of the detainees. He said that after a while, he no longer knew how to behave. Any excuse was seized upon by the guards to inflict punishment. We set out below the main forms of abuse. We emphasize that not every detainee was subjected to the practices described hereunder.

Discipline and Denigration

All detainees were given names which sometimes bore derogatory or humiliating connotations. Names of some of the group of 32 included "donkey," "goat," "monkey," "pig" and "fool." The general disciplinary regime was harsh and arbitrary. Talking during work was forbidden. Requests of almost any sort were frowned upon and often met with assault. Detainees were forbidden to reveal their real names to each other.

Hard Labor

Various forms of hard labor were required from some of the detainees. In the main, hard labor consisted of felling trees, chopping wood, breaking stones, digging trenches and hauling a water cart. It was the latter form of hard labor that elicited the greatest bitterness. The camp had no running water. Accordingly, water had to be collected in a tank from a spout near the camp.

Assault and Punishment

A variety of assaults and punishments were regularly meted out to detainees. One form of abuse, known as "pompa" was described by one witness as a "tradition" at Quatro. The victim was required to puff out his cheeks while being repeatedly slapped in the face. The effect was to create unbearable pressure on the eardrums and excruciating pain. Nearly every witness who appeared before the commission was a victim of this abuse. Some complained of burst eardrums and bleeding from the ears. The evidence revealed that this form of abuse was routine.

Another practice frequently carried out was known as "gas mask." A pawpaw shell, from which the pulp had been removed, was pushed into the face of the detainee until he could no longer breathe. This practice was widespread.

Other Places of Detention

Quatro was evacuated in December 1988, in terms of the New York Accord which stipulated that the ANC had to leave Angola with its soldiers, prisoners and equipment by March 31, 1989. Close to 90 detainees were taken from Quatro to Nonkala, a warehouse in Luanda. This was to be a temporary prison. The evidence established that the evacuation from Quatro was particularly unpleasant. We were told prisoners were piled into trucks and some were handcuffed to other prisoners. Newcomers were apparently handcuffed to those who had spent time in Quatro. This was done as a precaution to prevent the newcomers from escaping since they were in better physical condition and more likely to attempt to escape than other prisoners. One of the detainees who testified before us told us hat he fainted on the way to Nonkala, as a result of the heat in the truck.

From Nonkala, some prisoners were taken to Uganda and others to Kakawa in Tanzania. Conditions in the Ugandan prison, while better than Quatro, still left much to be desired. The evidence established acts of gratuitous and random violence perpetrated on the detainees by the camp guards, but not with the same frequency that occurred at Quatro. One of the noteworthy features of the period of detention in Uganda was attempts by certain ANC officials to improve conditions. Several witnesses specifically singled out the efforts of Tenjiwe Mthintso, the ANC's chief representative in Uganda. She apparently displayed a genuine capacity to listen to complaints and as a result of her efforts conditions improved. We were informed that for the first time, detainees were able to relate their complaints without the guards being present.

Forced Confessions

We heard several harrowing accounts of the use of torture to extract confessions. In the main, attempts to extract confessions preceded internment at Quatro. The means used to extract confessions were, according to the witnesses, brutal in the extreme.

Most of the witnesses who appeared before the Commission from whom confessions were allegedly extracted by torture stated that they had made the confessions simply to escape the pain. They denied that their confessions were true.

Loss of Property

Most of the witnesses who appeared before the Commission complained that personal possessions had been confiscated from them and that they have either not been compensated at all or have been inadequately compensated. In the main, complaints of loss of property related to clothing and jewelry. Upon their return to South Africa, some former detainees received vouchers to enable them to purchase clothing from a particular shop. It is not proposed in this report to detail the items lost by each witness who testified before the Commission. A schedule will be made available to the President of the ANC and appropriate recommendations will be made hereafter.

The Treatment of the Mutineers

Although we considered the focus of this inquiry to be the group of 32, some evidence was led by those who were detained as a result of their alleged participation in the 1984 mutiny. There are a number of published accounts on the mutiny including a chapter in the recently published book by Stephen Ellis and Tsepo Sechaba entitled Comrades Against Apartheid. The authors record that included in the demands of the mutineers was the suspension of the ANC security apparatus and an investigation of Quatro. The mutiny was the subject of an official inquiry by the ANC led by James Stuart. We were eventually furnished with a copy of the Stuart Commission report. The contents of that report were never made public and, it seems, not formally tabled before the ANC National Executive Committee. According to Ellis and Sechaba, although the findings of the Commission were never released, it was widely known that the investigators attributed blame for the mutiny on the excesses of the security department, poor political education, poor recreational facilities and quality of food and the yearning to go home and fight. These are indeed the findings of the Stuart Commission.

There was evidence that both soldiers and mutineers died in the exchange of fire. We were told that some of the mutineers were thereafter executed. The circumstances in which this occurred are far from clear. However, there is a sense of unease that these executions may have been carried out summarily. It appears that after the initial executions, strenuous efforts were made to stop the executions.

Recommendations

In making the recommendations that follow, we have been guided by three principles: redress, accountability and prevention. In accordance with these principles, we make the following recommendations:

(1) Those witnesses who were detained without trial should have the allegations against them unequivocally and unconditionally withdrawn.

(2) All witnesses who suffered maltreatment while being detained in ANC camps should receive monetary compensation for their ordeal.

(3) Some of the witnesses who appeared before us were, in our view, in need of medical and psychological assistance. Such should be offered and provided by the ANC.

(4) Some of the witnesses expressed the desire to continue with their education which had been interrupted by long periods of detention. We recommend that the ANC provide assistance in this regard.

(5) Detainees who lost property should be compensated for such loss.

(6) We suggest that consideration be given to the creation of an independent structure which is perceived to be impartial (in place of continuing a formal Commission of Inquiry) and which is capable of documenting cases of abuse and giving effect to the type of recommendations made in this report.

(7) We suggest that the impartial and independent structure referred to in paragraph (6) above, or some other appropriate body be charged with the responsibility of investigating all allegations of disappearances and murder.

(8) We strongly recommend that urgent and immediate attention be given to identifying and dealing with those responsible for the maltreatment of detainees.

(9) We strongly recommend that the Thami Zulu Commission report be released to the public and once the NEC has received the Stuart Commission report it too should be considered for public release.

(10) Finally, the terms of reference of this Commission contain an undertaking that this report will be released to the public. We strongly recommend that this be done as soon as possible. *


LOAD-DATE: November 2, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


243 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 26, 1992


South Africa's ANC Says It Has Been Guilty of Rights Abuses


SECTION: DOSSIER


LENGTH: 427 words


In the wake of an internal investigation detailing human rights violations by some of its exiled leaders, the African National Congress (ANC) has promised "as a matter of urgency" to find and punish those responsible for the "serious abuses and irregularities" that occurred.

A three-member panel of lawyers -- two of them members of the ANC -- issued the report in late October, following a seven-month inquiry. "We were left with an overall impression that for the better part of the 1980s, there existed a situation of extraordinary abuse of power and lack of accountability," the panel members said. 

"Nobody was beyond the reach of the security apparatus," the lawyers reported, citing the experiences of Pallo Jordan, a senior ANC official now heading the Information Department, who spent six weeks in detention in 1983.

The report identifies Quatro, an ANC detention camp in Angola, as a place where systematic abuses took place. ANC members suspected of collaboration with the South African government were held in Quatro and other detention facilities, where they were interrogated and sometimes tortured, the report said.

The practices covered by the report took place during a time when the exiled organization was fighting for its existence. In a policy that spread suspicion and paranoia throughout the ANC, the South African government infiltrated the group with hundreds of agents and used the information they gleaned to block ANC attacks, to plan assassination attempts against top ANC leaders, and to launch military raids against the movement's offices and supporters in neighboring countries.

At a press conference where the report was issued, ANC President Nelson Mandela said the abuses "must be understood in the context in which they occurred." But he strongly condemned the actions themselves as "inexcusable" and said the ANC leadership had agreed already to the panel's principal recommendation -- an independent investigation into the abuses.

Here are excerpts from the panel's report.


LOAD-DATE: November 2, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


244 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 26, 1992


Angolan Election in Dispute


SECTION: NEWS ANALYSIS


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

Luanda, Angola

Sunni Khalid for Africa News Service

Angolan opposition leader Jonas Savimbi is a tough fighter. He founded the rebel movement Unita and battled Portuguese rule for nine years in the fertile, empty expanses of central and southern Angola with little external support. After Angola's independence, he waged guerrilla war for 16 years against a government that was backed by 40,000 Cuban troops and large-scale Soviet military aid. He lobbied for and won the enthusiastic endorsement of the American government and substantial covert assistance from the CIA and from South Africa. In the end, he outfoxed his war-weary adversaries and an overextended international community and got the national elections he said he wanted. 

When campaigning in Angola's first-ever contested national vote began, the elections were Savimbi's to lose. The electorate seemed anxious for an alternative to 16 years of botched socialism under a corrupt government, which had quickly jettisoned its ideology when its former sponsor, the Soviet Union, fell apart.

Both Unita and the ruling Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA) were confident they could win at the ballot box the political hegemony that had eluded them on the battlefield. But many foreign observers were convinced that Savimbi would easily defeat the incumbent president, Jose Eduardo dos Santos, a former petroleum engineer trained in the Soviet Union, who has led the country since the death of its internationally known first president, Agostinho Neto, in 1979.

However, Savimbi turned out to be more of a zealous pit bull on the campaign trail than the charismatic figure his supporters had been expecting. He often harangued his audiences, using appeals to racial and ethnic differences rather than the calls for national unity he had so often voiced on his overseas forays. The result was to send potential backers running reluctantly to dos Santos and the ruling MPLA.

In stark contrast, dos Santos assumed a kinder, gentler approach. Using the same Rio-based public relations firm that engineered the victory of Fernando Collor de Mello in Brazil last year, dos Santos presented himself as a quiet, humble family man. He stressed national reconciliation and the promise of lasting peace for a war-weary people.

Savimbi also may have been hurt by controversy over Unita's human rights record, sparked by the defections earlier this year of former Unita foreign minister, Antonio da Costa Fernandes, and top military commander Miguel N'zau Puna. Charging that Savimbi ordered the murders of some of Unita's most promising leaders, including a popular former Unita representative to Washington, Pedro "Tito" Chingunji, and his family, the defectors put Savimbi on the defensive both at home and abroad.

Whatever the reason, Savimbi never was able to capture the initiative in the campaign. What Unita thought would be a cakewalk to the presidency became a fight for political survival.

By August, dos Santos was able to stump across Angola's central highlands, the country's agricultural heartland and Savimbi's political and military stronghold. A better campaigner than anyone had suspected, dos Santos drew large crowds at rallies on what most had regarded as Unita's home turf. When election day came, dos Santos had hit his stride and Savimbi appeared exhausted.

The MPLA took Hula, Moxico, Cunene and Namibe provinces and ran a respectable second in Benguela. It was a stunning rebuke delivered by a largely illiterate but determined electorate. After all, these were the areas where Unita had operated militarily, where it thought it had almost unanimous popular support.

The results were humiliating to an astonished Savimbi, who had convinced his supporters and himself that victory was assured. Before the polling, Savimbi predicted he would take all of the country's 18 provinces and 70% of the popular vote. Unita officials had projected sweeps of the crowded shantytowns that surround Angola's cities. But official results show Unita winning only four provinces and finishing second in 13 others. The margins of defeat were also surprisingly large.

Savimbi is still playing to win. Since the outcome became clear, he has maneuvered frantically to regain lost ground. Operating from the central highland city of Huambo, Savimbi has received visiting would-be intermediaries, including South African Foreign Minister Roelof (Pik) Botha and U.S. Assistant Secretary of State Herman Cohen. He has issued threats, and he has agreed to meetings with dos Santos and then failed to attend.

The United Nations has announced results showing dos Santos with a margin of victory just short of the 50% required to avoid a run-off, but agreement on holding a second round of voting has remained illusive. In the views of many observers, Angola is headed for a return to war.

If that happens, it will likely be a fight to the finish this time -- a winner-take-all proposition that would make the results of the country's first-ever democratic elections a mere footnote to continued decades of armed conflict. It is not what the Angolan people want, that is very clear. But it may happen. *


LOAD-DATE: November 2, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


245 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 26, 1992


Ivorian Leader Marks Birthday


LENGTH: 720 words


Yamoussoukro, Cote d'Ivoire

Cindy Shiner * Africa News Service

If there is any doubt whether Ivorian President Felix Houphouet-Boigny still has fans after holding power longer than any other African head of state, just ask Bakary Kone.

Kone traveled three hours from Abidjan to Yamoussoukro on October 18 to wish Houphouet-Boigny a happy birthday and personally deliver a gift he said took him nine months to make and cost him $ 1,000.

"I want to tell him I am content with him and I am devoted to him," said the 28-year-old artist. 

Against the backdrop of the massive Roman Catholic basilica that Houphouet-Boigny built to rival St. Peter's in Rome, Kone and a colleague pushed the gift -- a wooden statue of a seated Houphouet-Boigny with two small elephants at his feet -- in a wheelbarrow. They were on their way to the presidential residence in Yamoussoukro because authorities would not allow them to present the gift at the basilica, where the president was attending mass.

The service was a special mass held to mark Houphouet-Boigny's 87th birthday, although he is believed to be older. He is also thought to be the world's oldest president, as well as Africa's longest-serving head of state, having been in power since 1960.

Born the son of a chief in Yamoussoukro, Houphouet-Boigny was a prosperous farmer and rural doctor for almost 20 years. In 1946, as he organized opposition to French colonial rule, he added "Houphouet," meaning "battering ram," to his name.

He has compared himself to a crocodile because he says he sleeps with his eyes open, but there is nothing vicious about his demeanor. A small man with gnome-like features, he had an aide lift him slightly off the marble floor in front of the basilica so he could wave to fans over the roof of his limousine. Followers chanted "Houphouet! Houphouet!" as he drove away.

Long-standing rulers in other African countries are not always received with such warmth. When Zaire's President Mobutu Sese Seko showed up unannounced for the funeral of the leader of the country's Kibanguist church in Kinshasa, critics lined the road yelling "hibou! hibou!" It is the French word for "owl," but it also has the derogatory meaning "night-prowler."

Houphouet-Boigny is not without his critics. In 1990, the president was forced by opposition demands to end one-party rule. He was easily reelected in a vote his main rival charged was rigged, but most observers said the aging head of state was the clear winner.

Since the elections, however, discontent has mounted. The opposition newspaper Ivoire Soir carried a headline Sunday reading, "Happy Birthday, Papa Houphouet-Boigny! But your country is going down the drain!" The phrase, "going down the drain" is a polite translation of the French slang that actually was printed.

Opposition leaders blame the president for the collapse of the country's economy, once considered the miracle of sub-Saharan Africa. Prices for Cote d'Ivoire's chief exports, cocoa and coffee, have plummeted in the past decade. In the last two years, as inflation has risen and subsidies for services such as education have been slashed, there have been periodic street demonstrations demanding that the president resign.

Houphouet-Boigny also has been heavily criticized for building the basilica, which cost about $ 200 million, while the country went into an economic tailspin. The president says the project cost only half that much and was built with his own money. *


LOAD-DATE: November 2, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


246 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 26, 1992


First Cameroon Elections Marred By Fraud Charges


LENGTH: 1054 words


ABIDJAN, Cote d'Ivoire

Cindy Shiner * Africa News Service

Allegations of fraud in Cameroon's first democratic presidential election have thrust the central African country into renewed political turmoil, while its president of ten years appears poised for a new term.

Opposition leaders have accused the government of President Paul Biya of rigging the October 11 elections, and U.S. observers said there were "serious problems" with the conduct of the vote.

The Supreme Court rejected petitions by the opposition to annul the elections and the government has recalled its envoy to the United States, accusing Washington of meddling in Cameroon's internal affairs. Although they were not invited by the Cameroon government, 19 observers from the National Democratic Institute for International Affairs monitored the elections. 

On October 21, the leading opposition candidate John Fru Ndi said an unofficial count of returns by his own Social Democratic Party showed that he had won more votes than the president. "Let the Biya regime know that we are ready to fight to the last man to ensure that our victory is not stolen," he warned in what he called a "victory speech."

The government court put Biya ahead of Fru Ndi by about 200,000 votes, out of 2.8 million votes cast. Neither candidate claimed to receive over 50% of the ballot, but election rules say the top vote getter can win with less than a majority. All results remained unofficial pending confirmation by the Supreme Court on October 25.

In response, angry opposition party officials withdrew from the vote commission to protest the government court.

"The results they are going to announce have already been decided," said Dorothee Kom, spokeswoman for Fru Ndi. "It is only a masquerade.'' She accused the government of loading the commission in its favor, giving 11 of the 13 seats to representatives from Biya's southern home region.

The state-run media contend the voting was fair and quoted U.S. observers as saying they were satisfied.

But the leader of the observer mission, James Tierney, denied the report. Among irregularities the group cited were Biya's hasty calling of the election, the government's refusal to reopen voter registration, last-minute changes to electoral laws to favor Biya and questionable validity of some voting cards.

Observers also said the government monopolized the official media for its campaign. They cite the example that Biya used 142 minutes of air time on the eve of the election, although all five opposition candidates had only 12 minutes combined. Biya also broadcast a campaign speech in French and English -- Cameroon's official languages -- the Sunday morning of the election when campaigning officially ended at midnight Saturday.

After the elections, Biya was embarrassed by the resignation of one of his ten provincial governors. George Achu Mofor, the brother of Biya's prime minister, quit as governor of the eastern province, charging that members of the ruling party, the Cameroon People's Democratic Movement, pressured him to falsify results. He also criticized the government's human rights record.

Cameroon is among dozens of African nations whose governments have yielded to cries for democracy over the past three years by legalizing opposition parties, holding national conferences or scheduling elections. The ethnically and ecologically diverse country is a microcosm of the continent, and its neighbors look to Cameroon for clues as to what they themselves could face as they prepare for the first free votes in their own countries.

Cameroon has colonial ties to Germany, France and Britain and is home to at least 200 separate ethnic groups, each with its own language. But within that diversity are divisions that prevented the opposition from uniting behind one candidate and consolidating its power against Biya. Five opposition candidates competed against him in the race for the presidency, and others dropped out at earlier stages.

Some opposition leaders called for a boycott of March's legislative elections, but not all of Biya's opponents followed suit.

Biya's two leading contenders were Fru Ndi, a 51-year-old bookstore owner, and Bello Bouba Maigari, 46, who once served as prime minister under Biya. Fru Ndi comes from English-speaking western Cameroon, and Maigari is popular in his native, and largely Muslim, north.

Biya was forced to legalize opposition parties last year after strikes and unrest left dozens dead. However, he refused to allow installation of a transitional government to oversee the election process.

The president was not always so controversial. Cameroonians cheered him when he succeeded authoritarian President Ahmadou Ahidjo in 1982 and promised to bring democracy. But his popularity began to decline after he cracked down on dissent following a 1984 coup attempt.

Further damaging his image were the country's economic woes. Economic growth had averaged eight percent into the 1980s, but world market prices for Cameroon's oil, cocoa, coffee, cotton and timber tumbled, and by 1988 the gross domestic product was falling as well. More than one-quarter of Cameroon's workforce was unemployed last year. *


LOAD-DATE: November 2, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


247 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 26, 1992


Island Nation Prizes Adventurous Spirit:Cape Verde Embraces Democracy


LENGTH: 1760 words


Karen Gellen

Cape Verde's energetic new prime minister says his island nation is on the move economically, fueled by the heady air of democracy. Carlos Veiga, 41, describes with palpable pride Cape Verde's bloodless transition to multiparty rule and the popular energy and international financial support he says the process has unleashed.

Elected last December with an overwhelming majority of the vote, Veiga's government has moved quickly to promulgate a new constitution and dismantle the apparatus that gave the previous ruling party a hammerlock on the country's economic, political and cultural life.

Veiga, a former attorney general under the African Party for the Independence of Cape Verde, known as the PAICV, which had ruled since independence, is president of the Movement for Democracy. Founded in 1989, the opposition party won 56 seats in the 79-member National Assembly in the December vote and captured the presidency in February 1992 elections. 

During an October conversation, while visiting Cape Verdean communities in several U.S. cities, Veiga talked about the heritage of single-party rule and the sweeping changes under way in his West African country, which is about the size of Rhode Island.

AfricaNews: How have elections changed Cape Verde?

Veiga: The change has been fundamental: today we have complete freedom of the press and of political association. There are actually more newspapers in opposition than in support of our government. The political police and people's tribunals are gone, and the new constitution guarantees free elections, multiple trade unions and the full range of democratic guarantees. You can feel in the air a real environment of freedom and liberty.

AN: Is that change reflected in the economy?

Veiga: Definitely. We're making very deep reforms to enable a shift to a market economy -- from privatizing the public sector to liberalizing foreign trade. We have instituted bank reform. Currently there is only one state bank, but we are open to new national and foreign banks. There is now the legal framework that will allow private interests to take root in a strong way, especially in the key areas of tourism, fisheries and international services, such as transport and telecommunications.

AN: What conditions gave rise to the Movement for Democracy, and why was there such a strong consensus for political reform?

Veiga: Single-party rule had caused economic strangulation and social corrosion. The weight of the state on the society undermined positive values like hard work, initiative and creativity.

The system used social engineering to manacle the individual, so they could only express themselves with the imposed ideological line. I have personal experience with this: I became a member of parliament under the previous regime, joining the single electoral list because many people had asked me to run. During my term I found it increasingly difficult to express my views. I became completely isolated.

You can't compare this to a place like Romania in terms of repression, but there was no right to political association other than in the so-called mass organizations of the party. That control was enforced by people's militias scattered throughout the country and by people's tribunals and neighborhood commissions that were extensions of the political police. The system made people passive. It robbed the society of its dynamism.

AN: How did an idealistic liberation movement, founded by an African hero like Amilcar Cabral, end up creating what you describe as an instrument of oppression?

Veiga: We have to acknowledge that the PAICV worked hard and that corruption never reached the levels we see in other countries. But independence leaders such as Cabral and Angola's Agostino Neto became politically conscious in the environment of the clandestine opposition to the Portuguese dictatorship. That movement was dominated by the Communist Party, which had experience in the underground and viewed its enemy as Western imperialism. Thus the Eastern bloc model prevailed when the liberation movements came to power.

In Cape Verde the anti-democratic seeds were planted even before independence. We were supposed to have multi-party elections for an assembly that would write a constitution within three months of independence. But the liberation movement exercised strong pressure to prevent other parties from forming, and it ran alone. It then took five years, instead of three months, to pass a constitution. During that time, the ruling party organized itself and the society so it could exert total control.

AN: How will your government ensure that the new free-market system does not bring the negative aspects we've seen in some other formerly socialist countries?

Veiga: We do not defend pure and absolute liberalism. We believe the state should have a role in protecting workers, women, young people and the elderly. Those goals are clearly defined in our economic strategy. We believe that private enterprise will result in social progress. All conditions are in place for success, and we expect rapid change during this first term of our legislature.

AN: Some African countries making similar democratic changes say they are being left in the lurch by the developed countries. Are you optimistic about receiving international aid and investment to back up your programs?

Veiga: Our country is so small that what is considered inadequate or marginal for other countries is enough to achieve the results we want. We haven't had difficulties getting support for our projects. Our main problem is the internal capacity to absorb this external aid. But we are creating that capacity, which will eventually enable us to have an economy that is minimally self-sufficient.

The World Bank, a very demanding organization, analyzed our program and agreed with it. The bank is supporting us in programs we consider financially significant and fundamental to our development. And the countries we have economic relations with have expressed the same optimism. At a round-table meeting in Geneva this month, we presented our economic plan to our main bilateral and multilateral partners -- these include Sweden, the United States, Germany, Portugal, Austria, Switzerland, the Netherlands, the World Bank, the African Development Bank and many others.

In Geneva, we obtained a consensus, an agreement that they will support us. A second session will take place in November in Praia, our capital, so that these contributions will be organized and integrated into our economy.

AN: Currently, more Cape Verdeans live abroad than at home -- 600,000, throughout the world, including 300,000 in the United States compared to the 400,000 in Cape Verde itself. Do those communities maintain links with their homeland?

Veiga: My visit here is specifically to meet with the Cape Verdeans in the New England states, here in New York, in Washington, DC, and in California. These communities keep strong cultural and political ties to Cape Verde. In fact, the first nucleus of opposition to the one-party system came from Cape Verdeans abroad, who were exposed to alternative ideas.

Cape Verdeans abroad make a strong financial contribution to our economy: the remittances they send to their relatives at home make up 45% in foreign currency of our imports. The communities outside also play a direct political role. My party pressed to have representatives from those communities in our parliament, and the new constitution provides for a doubling of their seats in the future. They will also have the right to vote in our next presidential election. The Movement for Democracy has received strong moral support from Cape Verdeans here, but we don't accept any financial contributions from outside. The PAICV did accept money from abroad, and it gave the party a very bad image.

AN: Does your new economic plan contain measures aimed at stemming such large-scale emigration?

Veiga: The emigration has both positive and negative aspects. It is negative because so much of our youth has to leave the country to find jobs. And Cape Verdeans have been forced out over the centuries by drought and famine that decimated the islands.

But there has always been a positive side as well: a spirit of adventure that is very deep in our culture. Living on small islands surrounded by a vast sea can sometimes feel like a prison, and there is an intense desire to learn about the world outside.

We hope by the next generation Cape Verdeans won't have to leave home for economic reasons. But our spirit of adventure will remain. And even when Cape Verde becomes a developed country, many of our people will still go out and explore the world. *


LOAD-DATE: November 2, 1992


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


OCTOBER 26, 1992


Letter from Ghana


LENGTH: 1120 words


Tamale, Ghana

Riley Edwards-Raudonat

Greetings to all of you from the traditional Presbyterian stronghold of Agona Nsaba, site of the 63rd Synod of the Presbyterian Church of Ghana (PCG), to which I am a delegate.

The 63rd Synod is being held in the very large Presbyterian Church of Nsaba, a structure capable of seating the 600-odd delegates without difficulty. There are a handful of female pastors and 200 lay people -- perhaps 560 men and 40 women. There are a handful of female pastors, one of whom gave the devotional this morning. But the overriding impression is that the PCG is governed by men -- black men. Mine is the only white face in the crowd. 

Even if the bulk of the synod is devoted to church affairs, there have been moments in which other concerns came to light. One such moment was the appearance of Albert Adu Boahen, presidential candidate of the Patriotic Party. Yes, this is election year in Ghana, signaling the end of some 11 years of military rule.

Boahen, appearing before the synod "as a member of the Presbyterian Church and not as a presidential candidate," called on the officers of the country to exercise "humility and accountability." The moderator of the synod, the highest officer of the PCG, expressed hopes of a peaceful transfer to the "Fourth Republic" -- the fourth elected government of post-colonial Ghana -- warning that should the specter of military coup again raise its ugly head, the people of Ghana should resort to civil disobedience -- a remark greeted with hefty applause by the synod.

Though we find ourselves in a good place in Ghana these days, we also see that for many Ghanaians, it's a hard place. This year is a year of climatic disturbance. The rainy season, of vital importance to the nation's agriculture, has more or less not taken place.

The Tamale area is particularly dry, worse than most other areas. When visiting villages these days, I sense a spirit of quiet desperation. Where is the rain? Rain callers, for the price of a sheep, are willing to do their best to rectify the situation. They are quite busy this year, to no avail. I also am perceived as someone who might know how to call rain. Thus the offerings at our worship services are running higher than usual, and the prayer request is always the same: "Pastor, pray for rain. You pray for us." And I do, but it doesn't rain.

Many younger people have been sent south by their parents to look for work. Driving south to the synod, I happened to meet some of them in Kintampo, about 125 miles (200 kilometers) south of Tamale.

"Did you get work?" No work. They said they were hoping to hear of rain in Tamale; then they would go back. How I would have liked to have obliged them with the good news: "It's raining." But that would have been nothing but a cruel joke. I fear we are headed for a crisis.

Why is it that Africa must lurch from one crisis to the next? If there should be no harvest in Germany this year, food would be bought on the world market, the shelves in the supermarket would be full, and most people would never know the difference. Here, children will lie awake at night with empty stomachs, too weak to cry, staring at their parents with wide hungry eyes, their parents at wits' end to know what to do. There is no justice. None whatsoever. None.

It was my good fortune to be invited to a conference in the United States this summer, giving me opportunity to visit at home for the first time since 1989. But the United States seemed strange after so many years away. The roadside, so lively in Ghana, and once certainly also in the United States, was entirely given over to concrete and cars. Where were the sidewalk vendors with their "fast food" -- I mean the fresh bananas, the oranges already sliced and peeled, the hot corn on the cob, the hard-boiled eggs, the freshly pounded fufu, the roasted groundnuts wrapped in old newspaper? That's the fast food in Ghana.

Fast food in the United States? Well, yes, hamburgers and fried chicken and what have you, sold not at the roadside but in neatly appointed stores with easy, drive-in access. But whether you eat it there or take it with you, you get it wrapped and rewrapped and even boxed up and put into a bag, so that the event at hand, consumption of food, must always be preceded by much unbagging, unboxing, unwrapping, unpacking.

Once down to the food, you may decide it needs a bit of seasoning. No problem. Handy packages of ketchup, mustard, salt and pepper are everywhere. Unpack and season to taste. And then all the packaging must be thrown away -- waste, useless, good for nothing, fuel for the incinerator. Why, when it could be so much more simple -- and is nearly everywhere in the world but in the United States?

And where were the people? Always inside. Inside their houses, inside their cars, inside their offices, inside, inside. Looking down the street, I saw nothing but cars, buildings, concrete. No people. I found myself homesick for the crowded street life in Ghana: people on every corner, people walking, people on bicycles, people carrying water, people carrying their goods to market and home again; people also in cars, but always cars chock full of people, none of this one-person-one-car solitude.

Yes, I've been away a long time. Although there's no place like home, I'm not sure I'll ever fit in again. *

Riley Edwards-Raudonat works for the Presbyterian Church of Ghana. He and his family live in Tamale.


LOAD-DATE: November 2, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.
