Africa News


OCTOBER 26, 1992


Ghana's Largest Newspaper Wins Censorship Battle


LENGTH: 854 words


Accra, Ghana

David Zaring for Africa News Service

A conflict between the state-owned People's Daily Graphic and its government-appointed board of directors has turned into a significant victory for Ghana's recently deregulated press.

The Graphic, Ghana's largest daily, with a circulation of 100,000, was ordered by its directors on September 25 to transfer 11 journalists to and from new administrative posts and regional desks. The journalists concerned, including two feature editors, a news editor and a popular columnist, are noted for what the Morning Sun, an independent Ghanaian weekly, called "their outspokenness and criticism of some of the policies of the Provisional National Defense Council" (PNDC), the country's unelected ruling body.

The Graphic staff vigorously protested the order, first by wearing red armbands in support of the 11 transferees and then by petitions and editorials condemning the directors. The editors charged that the transfers were designed to provoke "open confrontation with the editorial board to cripple its initiative and resourcefulness." 

"Looking at the caliber of the staff the board of directors is transferring out, the editorial board is left with no other choice than to conclude that this is a deliberate attempt to disintegrate the editorial department," the editors protested in a letter to the Graphic directors.

These complaints were supported in a resolution passed by the Ghana Journalists Association and by what Frankie Asare-Donkoh, one of the affected journalists, describes as "the spontaneous support (for the Graphic staff) shown by the public nationwide."

"The telephone calls, letters, personal calls, and articles condemning the board's action were just innumerable," says Kwaku Bakla, another transferee.

On October 6, the board of directors called for a truce and a series of meetings with Graphic editors, and the next day the board rescinded the transfer directive. Asare-Donkoh calls the reversal an "overwhelming victory for objective journalism."

Kwesi Yankah, editor-in-chief of Uhuru, a weekly Ghanaian news magazine, agrees. "When suddenly this happened at the Graphic, one clearly saw it as an attempt to draw us back to the old days of Ghanaian journalism where the press was directly controlled by the government," he says. "I think that the reaction of the Graphic and the public is very good news for the press. It augurs well for the future."

But the victory of the Graphic reporters had a price. The paper was forced to adopt a series of political reporting guidelines, sponsored by the board, that limits media coverage to those parties registered by the government and those holding police permits for meetings. Sam Clegg, editor-in-chief of the Graphic, says adoption of the guidelines was a necessary compromise to avoid further confrontation with the board of directors over the transferal issue.

Ghana's press has coped with censorship since 1963, when the country's first newspaper licensing law curbed criticism of then head-of-state Kwame Nkrumah. The PNDC, during its 11-year rule of the country, has banned one newspaper, the Chronicle Standard, has detained some journalists without trial and has forced other reporters into exile. In 1989, the PNDC capped its efforts to control the Ghanaian press with a new newspaper licensing law, granting Secretary of Information Kofi Totobi Quakyi the power to "revoke or suspend such licenses as he deems fit."

The law was revoked last year in preparation for national elections and a transition to civilian rule. Over 30 newspapers, most of them four-page broadsheets, have begun publishing since the restrictions were lifted.

In the current climate of democratization, the Graphic has sought to distance itself from its traditional editorial stance of uniform support for the policies of its government owners, claiming that a newly objective approach would win the paper more readers.

"People had come to associate journalists with a fanatic and fundamentalist support of the government," it editorialized. "We have managed to extricate ourselves from those entanglements." *


LOAD-DATE: November 2, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


250 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 26, 1992


Okavango Fence Stirs Botswana Storm


LENGTH: 1454 words


Gaborone, Botswana

Peter Warren

Plans to complete a buffalo fence around Africa's last great wilderness, the Okavango Delta in Botswana, have caused a storm of protest from environmentalists and local people who cannot agree on its site.

At issue is the Okavango Delta itself -- 5,800 square miles (15,000 square kilometers) of unique wetland and the world's largest inland waterway. The area supports a greater diversity of animals than virtually anywhere else on earth due to the concentration of habitats ranging from Kalahari sands, lagoons and forest and scrub, flood plain, and reed bed.

The fence -- five strands of wire and one line of steel cable capable of withstanding a lateral impact of 25 tons (enough to stop a charging buffalo but not an elephant) -- loops around the delta to the south and aims to close in the top before swinging on a meandering course up to Botswana's northern border.

Its ostensible purpose is to prevent contact between the buffalo of the delta, which carry foot-and-mouth disease, and Botswana's 3 million cattle. But its opponents see many other reasons for its construction. 

The installation of the first stage of the 140-mile (226-kilometer) northern buffalo fence has become a bitterly divisive issue among environmentalists, big game hunters, locals and the Botswanan government, oddly provoking accord in some cases between usually opposing groups all wanting to dismantle the four-foot-high fence.

The depth of the passion is due to cattle. Botswana is cattle country and "buffalo fence" is a misnomer for cattle fence. In an area of semi-arid grazing susceptible to seven-year drought cycles, the vast water resources pouring into the Okavango Delta have long been a source of dispute between cattle and wildlife -- a dispute temporarily settled in the wildlife's favor by the invasion of the area by the tsetse fly after 1825.

But with the country's cattle population at the limit of the land's capability to support it, the pressure on the delta as a wildlife and water resource is immense. For Botswana, cattle is big business. "They are money in the bank as far as Botswanans are concerned," says Seeido Liphuko, the country's secretary of natural resources.

Some 684,000 of Botswana's 1.5 million people are involved with beef and a further 456,000 want to be. The result of such belief in cattle in Africa's most stable democracy is that "cow power" is an enormous political factor. It is also one that could be considerably amplified in the event of a drought, according to Rick Lomba, the fiercest and most vocal critic of Botswana's conservation policy and its plans for the delta.

Pressure on the government to open up the Okavango is growing because the delta, whose headwaters are in Angola, where rains have been good, is at its highest level in 20 years. This has resulted in an almost mile-wide natural barrier to the cattle at a time when the rest of southern Africa is suffering a disastrous drought that is decimating Botswana's southern areas.

A U.S. citizen, filmmaker and conservationist living in South Africa, Lomba is a one-man crusade who lobbies the U.S. Congress and the European Community with his claims that Botswana intends to turn the delta into a giant ranch to the advantage of the cattle and to the detriment of the wildlife.

Lomba and his supporters, who maintain that the fence is ineffective because of the difficulty of maintaining it in a swamp and the problems of joining a section that runs through perennial marsh, want it removed while an independent environmental impact assessment examines its effects on wildlife.

The reception of Lomba's views in Washington and the European Community headquarters in Brussels has been sufficiently sympathetic to prompt the Botswana government to finance a fact-finding team to study placement of the fence as well as Lomba's claims that it prevents migration of wildlife and the traditional use of parts of the delta by hunter-gatherers.

The real bone of contention lies in the Selinda Valley. Inhabitants of the rapidly growing villages of Beetsha and Seronga, which lie 25 miles (40 kilometers) outside the fenced delta, claim they are being denied access to traditional grazing areas. Safari organizers and conservationists claim that an area of great importance to the ecology of the delta is being threatened. Conspiracy theorists see a plot to provide cattle with access to 695 square miles (1,800 square kilometers) of land to the east of the Okavango River, giving commercial owners plentiful grazing along the banks and access to water.

As a result, the fence has been given as many proposed routes as the Channel Tunnel rail link between Dover and London, with conservationists arguing for a more northerly line, cattle farmers arguing for its siting further south, and Lord Wilmot of the local safari lobby demanding that it include the whole Selinda Valley to protect the river from over-grazing.

Cattle can only travel a maximum of about 7.5 miles (12 kilometers) from a water source and their wide mouths consume vegetation that otherwise could support a great diversity of wildlife.

Environmentalists recognize that with a projected explosion in human population, demands on land will increase. What they don't accept is the government's interpretation of where these various interests can be separated. According to the people of Seronga, they were consulted on the placing of the fence and then their views were ignored by the government. "Visit the fence and you'll see destruction of giraffe and animals of the earth of all sorts," says one man, echoing the claims that the fence is interfering with wildlife migration routes -- a charge that the Wildlife Department denies.

Though Seronga's villagers claim to understand the compromise and the need to conserve wildlife, they also hint at the political questions that lurk behind the issue of the fence. "Because of our democratic tradition, we think it should be a decision of the majority that decides where this fence goes," says the local councilor. His colleague, the village chief, is similarly political in his response. "All developments must look at the figures with regard to the population of people, wildlife and cattle. There should be a balance between us, but the balance should bear in mind our children and their need for space, for food and housing."

At Beesha, views on the fence are more forthright. An area which had reverted to hunting and gathering after the expansion of the tsetse fly, its people now participate in the cattle invasion which has pushed numbers from 3,000 to 15,000 in less than a year.

"We have been oppressed by the government in the siting of this fence. Most of the food that we gather is beyond the fence, so it is preventing us getting to it," says one resident. Among the chief criticisms of the Tshomarelo Okavango Conservation Trust is that fences create boundaries for people as well as animals. This point is conceded by Wildlife Director Nigel Hunter, although he maintains that rights laid out in the government's Land Use and Development Plan for the Okavango will solve the problem.

But another resident, who admits that he is a recent big cattle owner, stated the future pressures on the fence more clearly. "I'm worried that the grazing land will decrease. We are not against wildlife, but what we are saying is give cattle a fair chance in the grazing area. If you make the decision to remove cattle from this area," he says, "then you kill (my people)." *


LOAD-DATE: November 2, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


251 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 26, 1992


Somali War Draws Scribes, Hustlers


LENGTH: 960 words


Mogadishu, Somalia

Bruce Wallace

Banking the seven-passenger plane into a steep descent to the seaside airstrip in Mogadishu, Somalia, our Libyan-born pilot, Tom, remarked that he was "flying just a single Moga today."

Translation: he was making just one return flight to Mogadishu from Nairobi, Kenya, with a cargo of medical supplies, relief workers and journalists entering the Somali nightmare. There are some days when the demand to get into Somalia is so great that Tom makes two trips -- "a double Moga." Two trips with stopovers in the southern Somali city of Kismayu are "a double Moga with cheese," in the daredevil pilot's language. 

As the world becomes more aware of the tragedy unfolding in Somalia, scores of aid workers and others are trying to get into the country at the same time that thousands of Somalis are fleeing war and famine for refugee camps in Kenya.

One of the remarkable relief workers is Matthew Bryden, 24, a British-born political science graduate of McGill University in Montreal. He has worked in Somalia for three years and now coordinates logistics for the French humanitarian aid group Doctors Without Borders in Mogadishu. Bryden was working in northern Somalia earlier this year with a team of Dutch doctors who decided to pull out of the country rather than hire local armed guards for security. But Bryden instead moved to Mogadishu and joined a French team that was committed to staying. "Walking away from this country is just not an option," he said. Bryden admits to mixed feelings about Somalis. "Westerners find it difficult to like Somalis because they do not put on any pretense of being grateful that we are here," he said. "But I really admire the toughness of these people."

The attraction of working in a country where inhumanity is on bald display daily is also hard for outsiders to grasp. Traveling anywhere requires hiring local armed security staff, or "technicals" as they are called. The best squads use four-wheel drive Land Rovers and have their men, Kalashnikov and M-16 rifles at the ready, positioned in the seats and on the roof.

A team of technicals costs about $ 180 a day, not including gas, to provide protection in the countryside. But the price of all services, including technicals, began to climb when the United States began airlifting aid.

CBS News's medical reporter, Robert Arnot, arrived with his roller blades in the hope of getting in some exercise -- a stark impossibility on Mogadishu's battered and murderous streets. Other new arrivals were better prepared. A photographer for the Swedish Red Cross showed up at the Kenyan border town of Liboi with a black studio backdrop to take pictures for a fund-raising campaign for Somali relief. For about three dozen filthy, hungry Somali refugees crossing the border checkpoint, their first experience in Kenya was to be led in front of a photographer's backdrop in the middle of a desert and told how to pose for a portrait.

Among other regular visitors to Somalia now are a half dozen Kenyans who fly tiny Cessna planes crammed with bags of the leafy, and legal, drug called khat into the famine-stricken country. Even before the sun is up, Nairobi's Wilson Airport is swarming with Kenyans and local Somalis involved in the drug trade, which produces a profit of about $ 12,000 on each flight. Somalis are huge consumers of khat, but they do not grow the plant. The khat flights are the first planes off the ground each morning, often so grossly overloaded that they require double the normal amount of runway to get airborne. By mid-afternoon, Somalis who can afford it are chewing the plant, which heightens the user's energy levels and dulls the sensation of hunger.

The strangeness of the war-ravaged country is only heightened by the presence of the drugs. Street scenes seem to have emerged from a special effects laboratory for post-apocalyptic science fiction. In the southern town of Baidoa, Land Rovers roar through the streets, their well-armed and well-fed teenage passengers in "I'm The Boss" T-shirts pushing skeletal adults out of the way. Among themselves, the teenagers wield their guns like fists, jabbing each other with the muzzles in the manner of a friendly punch. "I really like my work," says Omar Abdi Farrah, who hires himself out as a translator to Westerners. "But I don't know how long I can go on worrying about the security," he says. "If you play with a bee long enough, it will sting you."

But in the end, it is the hungry and the weak that you remember most about Somalia, because there are so many of them. In Baidoa, a city that is now nothing more than a cemetery for the dead and nearly dead, it is impossible to look anywhere without seeing people suffering. *


LOAD-DATE: November 2, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


252 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 26, 1992


South Africa Drought Hits Rural Poor Hardest:Aid Workers Say Government Ignored Black Farmers


LENGTH: 1160 words


     Johannesburg, South Africa
      Jennifer Griffin for Africa News Service

Two hundred seventy-five miles from this bustling financial center, in the black rural reserve of Gazankulu, Ellesa Mkuma sat on an empty 25-liter water container in the scorching midday sun, stroking her young daughter while they waited their turn at the water tap. They had been waiting since 5 a.m.

Dozens of other women with babies and children lined up behind Ellesa as water trickled hesitantly through the outdoor tap. Near dry river beds, dead vegetable gardens lay on the parched earth -- testimony to the worst drought to hit southern Africa in a hundred years.

Reverie Greenburg of World Vision, the California-based Christian aid group, says such scenes are haunting development workers, who wonder why the most developed country in the region cannot provide more relief to the suffering people in its rural areas. 

There have been no reports of starvation deaths in South Africa, but malnutrition is on the rise and some 2 million people need food aid. Critics say the government's bureaucratic inefficiency and a lack of interest in the problem have caused it to be slow in helping impoverished rural blacks who have no political clout.

"How long can these people survive on just radishes and cabbage?" asks the Rev. E. Daniel Sebe, who is conducting a drought survey for World Vision in the northeastern Transvaal province.

Black farm workers evicted from white-owned farms have formed squatter settlements on open patches of land throughout the countryside. No factory jobs exist. The mines are not hiring and rural villagers cannot sell their livestock because prices have fallen so low.

Dependent on what they can grow, rural South Africans must contend with failed crops and reduced surface water. South Africa's corn harvest was down by 60% this year, forcing the former exporter to import almost 4.5 millions tons from the United States and other countries.

Those who can afford food often lack the water needed to cook it.

"Even though they can buy mealie meal (corn meal), they say they may not eat for two or three days because there isn't water," says Star Motswege, a field worker for the Transvaal Rural Action Committee (Trac).

The first signs of potential drought came in September 1991, says Mpho

Mashinini, the deputy director of Operation Hunger, a private South African aid group. Yet the government only began addressing the problem in February 1992, when it voted to allocate $ 155 million to drought relief that has benefited mostly white farmers, he says.

"It's quite difficult to understand why that money wasn't used earlier. The government took too long to respond," says Trac's Motswege.

Officials deny those charges.

"One can't say the government in September should have known there would be a drought," says Mike Walters, executive secretary of the government's Drought Action Coordinating Center. Walters says the first conclusive indications of a crisis was the failure of the main seasonal rains in January and February.

Critics counter that when the government did act, it channeled aid to white farmers rather than to the more vulnerable blacks.

"Most Afrikaaner farmers were helped first," says Mashinini. "They were told to help their workers. But most of those black workers are now living in squatter camps because the farmers fired them instead."

The government concedes that of the 26,000 farmers being given drought assistance, most are white. But Walters says that rural black farmers have received $ 46 million in government aid.

"Aid to farmers is irrespective of race. Black farmers in South Africa are entitled to the same money," says Walters. "But there aren't too many of them."

Aid agencies say that most of the drought relief money earmarked for black farm workers never reaches those for whom it is intended.

"In some areas you find that the white farmers are the chairmen of the committees for allocating drought relief money. That itself means that a lot of people may be overlooked," says Motswego. "Most whites in the countryside aren't very sympathetic to blacks."

The hardest hit parts of south Africa are the rural reserves that were established under apartheid policy to divide black South Africans by ethnic group. More than 5 million people were forcibly moved from areas set aside for whites into the reserves, which were dubbed "homelands." After years of being starved for resources, the areas suffer from impassable roads and nonfunctioning wells.

Overseas engineers, brought in to help drill new water holes, have withdrawn from the government's Water Task Force, according to Len Abrams, director of the Consultative Forum on Drought. Abrams says the engineers believe the scope of the crisis can be blamed more on "long-term problems of neglect" rather than "emergency conditions brought about by drought."

Walters defends the government's drought-relief efforts, saying that drilling rigs have a hard time reaching the communities that need water because of the deterioration of homeland roads and the ruggedness of the terrain, particularly in the worst-affected areas in the northeast of the country. The government has drilled 35 well holes in Venda since the beginning of August and has nine rigs operating in the northern Transvaal, Walters says.

"Our suppliers assure us there is enough food," says Operation Hunger's Mashinini. "South Africa, unlike other countries, could reduce the effects of the drought if there were coordination between the government and the aid agencies. If hunger wasn't being used as a political weapon, we could cope." *


LOAD-DATE: November 2, 1992


LANGUAGE: English

253 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 26, 1992


Cape Verde Envoy Casts A Long Shadow:Boutros-Ghali's Controversial Plan for Angola Deflected


LENGTH: 2800 words


Karen Gellen * Africa News Service When a hitch in the Angolan election process placed yet another crisis at the doorstep of the United Nations in early October, Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali went before a closed session of the Security Council with a novel idea.

Faced with threats of renewed fighting by opposition leader Jonas Savimbi and the prospect of a costly extension of the UN's 600-person observer mission in Angola, Boutros-Ghali urged the Council to press the Angolan government to appoint Savimbi vice president. Such a move, the UN chief argued, might avert further conflict and forestall the need for a run-off election between Savimbi and the incumbent President Jose Eduardo dos Santos, who led the official vote tally but lacked the majority needed to win.

The response that scuttled the proposal came from one of the world's smallest nations.

Ambassador Jose Luis Jesus of Cape Verde, which holds one of the rotating seats on the 15-member Council, denounced the idea as a circumvention of the democratic process. Abandoning his usual cautious approach, he made what UN sources say was an impassioned, impeccably argued speech that "blew the plan away." 

Rallied by the ambassador's plea, the Council unanimously expressed its confidence in the peace process and named Jesus (pronounced Zhay-zoos) to lead a four-person mediation team to Angola. When the delegation returned to UN headquarters in late October, U.S. Ambassador Edward Perkins, a member of the mission, praised Jesus for exemplary diplomacy, saying he had played a critical role as the team's spokesman and leader. While in Angola, the group worked to persuade both sides to negotiate conditions for a run-off vote.

In UN hallways, meanwhile, where word of the secretary-general's controversial stand quickly circulated, several diplomats from developing countries expressed pride -- and some surprise -- at the decisive role one of their number had assumed.

For Ambassador Jesus, however, "the role one can play in the United Nations is not predicated on the number of trees in your country's backyard. My country's size has never dictated our capacity to deal with the issues."

The diplomat's homeland is a series of 10 tiny islands plus five islets dotting the Atlantic Ocean, 310 miles off Africa's western coast. Home to less than 350,000 people, and smaller than the state of Delaware, the former Portuguese colony has stretches of barren land that evoke the image of a moonscape. In February 1991, a Cape Verde opposition party defeated the party that had ruled since independence in 1975.

Tall and graceful, the 41-year-old Jesus cuts a striking figure in UN corridors. Although he is preoccupied by the economic disparities between the wealthy northern hemisphere and the poor nations of the south, he is outspoken on what he sees as his own continent's mistakes and false priorities. He insists on holding African leaders accountable for what he terms a "shameful" record of governance since decolonization.

He says he puts his highest hopes in a new generation of leaders, who are emerging as African countries adopt multiparty political systems. This generation, he says approvingly, is the first not saddled by historical links to the liberation movements that brought many countries to independence.

Those movements, the ambassador says, established a tradition of single-party rule "that has been a disgrace all over the world, but especially in Africa." He acknowledges that Africa's problems are multifaceted. But single-party systems, he says, "have been an important factor in the decline and misery of Africa."

Jesus believes that one-party rule, "privileges not the most competent people, but those who belong to the party or have connections with people in high party positions." he says that the spread of democracy "will go a long way toward restoring Africa's credibility and prestige."

Asked about the hardship and repression that occur in developing countries that have a tradition of multiparty elections, Jesus argues that pluralism is a "necessary, but not sufficient" condition for progress.

He cites, as an example, the international scandal in early September over the transport of toxic waste from Europe to war-torn Somalia. Cape Verde, Jesus says, "would never accept such dumping, which can only take place in countries with dictatorships. No democratic regime, where the people have control over the political system, would accept being the garbage can of another country."

Jesus rejects the view that poor countries must choose between rapid development and a clean environment. Nor does he think that Africa must remain underdeveloped to compensate for the environmental destruction already caused by industrialization in northern countries.

"It is totally unacceptable," he says, "for those who have developed at the cost of everyone else, to deny others the possibility of development.

At the Rio conference on the environment in June, delegates were looking for a balance, he says. Poor countries acknowledge that the process of industrialization changes the atmosphere. But they give rich countries a clear message: 'You who have developed by damaging everyone's good environment will have to come up with the financial means to ensure that in developing our countries we don't further destroy the atmosphere.'

Jesus says poor countries must refuse to become a kind of "lung" for the world. "In Rio," he says, "we told the developed countries that if they want us to curb our emissions, they have to come up with the money to help us buy the new technology, to transfer that technology to us. "If the developed world does not provide those funds, it will suffer the consequences because the poorer countries will use classical, environmentally unsafe means to develop. We cannot escape the popular pressure for development."

But the ambassador is pessimistic that wealthy nations will respond in time to prevent further environmental deterioration. "The North," he says, "won't be motivated to take such measures unless they see more concrete damage. The day they see rashes and cancers on their skin, they will take action to clean up the environment."

He observes ruefully that moral arguments have failed to spur action. "Money is only given out when there is a vested interest," he says, "and that sense of urgency is not yet here. We will see a lot more destruction before anything changes."

While presiding over the Security Council in the monthly rotation of the chair last July, Ambassador Jesus confronted the potentially explosive issues of Somalia and Bosnia. He agrees with critics that the world community's response to the crisis erupting in Europe was far greater than to the one unfolding in Africa.

"The UN operation in Somalia was thwarted for nearly five months by the opposition of one faction in the conflict," Jesus says, He says he strongly opposed Boutros-Ghali's decision to delay deployment of the armed guards until all the Somali factions gave their consent. "I would have deployed the UN force despite this opposition, " he says, "because I could not accept that millions would die if we did not act quickly." He says he would have provided "necessary massive force" to protect relief personnel. The wait spelled death on a massive scale, he says.

The Council first addressed the Somali crisis in January, when it agreed to send a technical team to assess how to restore and prevent mass starvation. Four months later, on April 24, the 15 members agreed "in principle" to the dispatch of 500 armed guards to protect a large-scale food-distribution effort. But deployment of the guards was delayed, and the situation continued to deteriorate.

As Council president, Jesus sponsored a provision in a resolution that required the UN to do everything necessary to make sure the food was delivered, even if all factions failed to cooperate. Amid rising public concern at the appalling news from Somalia, the UN approved the stronger stance.

However, the armed troops did not arrive in Somalia until late September, and an additional 3,000 guards recently authorized by the council are not yet on the ground. The long delay in providing security for the humanitarian effort has drawn scathing criticism from some African diplomats at the UN.

"The UN should have intervened, and I do not understand why they didn't," says Mohammed Sahnoun, the secretary-general's special envoy for Somalia. "It was a very long delay and a tragic delay," he says.

Botswana's ambassador, Joseph Legwaila, is more blunt. The UN did not act until outside pressure became "unbearable," he says, and then only with "very reluctant, hesitant interest" in the plight of the Somalis. Concerned African diplomats were forced into "cajoling, praying, kneeling and groveling" for Western aid, he says.

Legwaila says that while 20,000 UN and European Community troops have been deployed in the Balkans to guarantee humanitarian aid, Africans had to wage a "war" in the Security Council to obtain 500 guards for Somalia. "Color," the ambassador argues," dulled some people's consciences."

As Council president, Ambassador Jesus was at the center of that diplomatic battle. Some closed-door council sessions reportedly became shouting matches as the African members -- Zimbabwe and Morocco, in addition to Cape Verde -- fought what they viewed as a double standard.

Jesus says that even without UN action, individual nations could have sent planes "to drop food and supplies as the European countries did in Bosnia, without any Security Council mandate."

Africans at the UN remains dissatisfied with the world body's commitment in Somalia, says Jesus. There is still no massive infusion of humanitarian aid, nor adequate coordination of UN efforts, he says.

The political minefields confronting small, developing countries at the UN were also evident last March, when the United States and Britain asked the world body to impose sanctions on Libya. At issue was Tripoli's refusal to extradite two Libyan nationals accused by the U.S. and Britain of a direct role in the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland.

Cape Verde abstained on the sanctions vote, despite intense U.S. pressure to approve the resolution. The final tally was 10 in favor, with five abstentions.

According to Jesus, the Security Council was not an appropriate venue for the extradition issue, and Cape Verde could not, in any case, press for Libyan compliance when its own constitution forbids such extradition.

Another consideration, says Jesus, was African unity: in a controversial issue involving an African state, Cape Verde did not want to separate itself from the other African council members, both of which abstained.

Some African UN sources who decline to be identified view Cape Verde's vote "courageous," given the strong U.S. interest in unanimity against Libya. One diplomat says that Washington briefly suspended food aid to Cape Verde shortly after the vote. The aid now has been restored.

Jesus acknowledges that pressure is always a factor for developing countries, particularly those least able to "bear the economic consequences" of their votes. There are no direct threats, he observes, "but you get the message." Nonetheless, he adds, countries such as his sometimes opt to take the heat when, as in the Libyan case, principle or regional loyalty are involved.

One other issue to which Jesus has devoted considerable attention is the negotiation of a "Law of the Sea ." The UN 's effort to reach agreement on the use and exploitation of the world's oceans has dragged on for more than a decade. The talks, like those on the environment, pit rich nations against poor ones, with poor countries arguing that oceans and their resources should be protected as a "common heritage" of all people.

Critics of the United Nations often cite the world body's failure, after years of discussion and a large expenditure of funds, to forge an agreement on the issue. The continuing dispute centers on UN efforts to regulate seabed mining. The U.S., other Western countries and Russia have refused to sign any treaty that restricts their access to ocean minerals.

Jesus accepts some of that criticism. The effort to "internationalize" the mineral wealth under the oceans was doomed from the start, he says. The idea was "a theoretical construct that was simply not viable." But he points out that the bulk of the treaty has been endorsed by the entire UN membership. The ambassador defends the notion that the international statecraft that often seems arcane to observers is nevertheless important to nations like his own.

The people of my country "are directly affected " by UN actions on issues like war, peace and international security, he says. "We can't have normal trade and develop our resources in an insecure world filled with conflict."

And he argues that adding Cape Verde's voice to the discussion makes the country more visible. "When we discharge our functions in a very responsible way," he says, "it creates a better image for our small African country. In the end that will create a better space for our own interests, such as trade and foreign investment, to be considered. Our diplomacy demonstrates that we will have an appropriate response to the security of investments and to international cooperation and friendship. This has a direct impact on our people's lives."

Jesus also believes in regional cooperation and in alliances based on mutual interests. Some diplomats have called for disbanding the Non-Aligned Movement -- founded in 1955 by countries who sought independence from East/West spheres of influence. Jesus says the group should stay together, but that it needs a new agenda for a world without superpowers.

"The most important role such an alliance can play," says the ambassador, "is to help democratize its own member countries and foster respect for human rights. It will take time to convince the movement to shift its priorities," he acknowledges, "but unless the developing countries take the lead in ensuring democracy, free speech and human rights, they will not have any credibility." *


LOAD-DATE: November 2, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


254 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 9, 1992


Can Peace Last?


LENGTH: 1081 words


Ngungwe, Mozambique

This account of a trip into Mozambican rebel territory appeared in the New Nation, a Johannesburg newspaper.

Only a year after its independence in June 1975, Mozambique was once again at war -- this time against dissident right-wing elements, former army personnel and a ragtag bunch of mercenaries recruited by the white rulers in what was then Rhodesia. The group, which grew into the Renamo rebel movement, was used to sow destruction across Mozambique.

When Rhodesia became independent Zimbabwe in 1980, Mozambicans expected that peace and stability would be restored. This was not to be. The attacks continued from inside Mozambique. 

The 1980s was a savage decade for the country. Millions died or were injured as the war intensified and became increasingly brutal. Renamo, backed by the South African Defense Force (SADF) and shadowy Western right-wing groups, launched a reign of terror against the Mozambican population -- burning crops, looting, raping, wiping out whole families, and press-ganging orphans as young as five into Renamo's army.

The signing of a peace accord should be cause for jubilation for millions of Mozambicans who are scattered all over the country and the subcontinent, some without their children, their parents or their limbs. But whether peace can take root and flower in a country with the severe problems caused by the drought and the war is a question Mozambicans are pondering.

About four hours after the cease-fire agreement was signed in Rome, New Nation visited Renamo general Vieira Chimuadza at his headquarters in Ngungwe near the Kruger National Park -- the largest Renamo base in southern Mozambique and the nerve center of military operations against government forces in the provinces of Inhambane, Gaza and Maputo.

Chimuadza -- who claims to be a founding member of Renamo and third in the organization's hierarchy -- was surrounded by his lieutenants and several women and children, all talking about the signing of the peace pact. "The accord has been signed," was the first thing he said as we shook hands.

Chimuadza, 39, was born in Sofala province and joined Renamo in 1977, after fleeing from a Frelimo reeducation camp where he claims he was held after being caught listening to a Renamo radio station. He says he was then a standard six (eighth grade) student at the Missao Benedito Secondary School in Beira, Mozambique's central and second largest city.

"It troubled me, because I didn't kill anybody. I didn't steal anything. I thought it was better to join Renamo at once," he said, adding that he was in the company of several fellow detainees.

He was trained by the then Rhodesian army, and he says he began his operations in Manica province, which borders Zimbabwe. "We would attack (government) installations and go back to Rhodesia," he said.

Shortly before Zimbabwe became independent, he said, the headquarters of the rebel movement was transferred to Gorongosa, in Manica province, and the South African security establishment took control of the group.

Chimuadza received additional training at an SADF base in Phalaborwa, South Africa. He was also trained in parachute jumping in Namibia, before that country's independence, he said.

The Renamo leader claimed that after leading successful battles, he was trusted by Renamo head Afonso Dhlakama to open a southern front.

From his base in Manica, he fought his way through to Inhambane and Gaza provinces until he was able to open the Ngungwe base, northwest of Maputo, the capital, and about four miles (six kilo-meters) from the border with South Africa. Having opened the new base, his task was to fight government forces in Maputo province, as well as sabotage the southern railway link between Mozambique and Zimbabwe, the Limpopo line. He claimed that he performed his task with success and "cleaned the area" of government troops.

As the war has now officially ended, the general is awaiting instructions on the demobilization of his soldiers and what to do with thousands of captives -- he referred to them as "refugees" -- that remain under his control.

He says he is convinced that some of the members of his army will be given jobs in a future administration. "That is what our leaders told us -- that (the government and Renamo) will demobilize some people and give them jobs and the remainder will jointly form the new army."

Chimuadza is confident that peace will endure.

"If our leaders have hugged each other as a sign of peace, we will follow their example."

He claimed that the government's decision to sign the accord signaled that it had been defeated. "They have agreed to all that we wanted -- this is what we wanted," he insists. He dismissed suggestions that the severe drought had contributed to bringing the two parties to the negotiating table.

But he acknowledged that without the help of various agencies, including right-wing Western sympathizers and South African church and other groups, Renamo would have had problems continuing the fighting.

He did not deny that the South Africans, including the army, had given material support, but he refused to comment on the direct military help that was given.

"No. I can't comment on that. That is better known by my leaders. It is something only they can answer," he said. *


LOAD-DATE: November 12, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


255 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 9, 1992


Mozambique's Peace Accord


LENGTH: 520 words


The peace agreement signed by Mozambican President Joaquim Chissano and Renamo chief Afonso Dhlakama provides that Zimbabwean and Malawian troops stationed in Mozambique must be withdrawn immediately. Both government troops and Renamo soldiers will be regrouped into assembly points. Supervision of the cease-fire is the responsibility of a joint commission of the government and Renamo, with a small number of United Nations forces present in a monitoring role. 

The new national army is to be made up of 30,000 troops, half of them contributed by the government and half by Renamo, with training aided by personnel from Britain, France and Portugal. Mozambicans are concerned that recent episodes showing a lack of discipline within the government army, and Renamo's long history of brutality and terror, will be significant obstacles to establishing a military force capable of maintaining security.

The peace accord provides that existing Mozambican laws and institutions will have authority over the entire country in the period before general elections. But the government has conceded that administrators in Renamo-controlled areas would be selected from among residents of those areas, who may be members of Renamo. The police and the Mozambican intelligence service will be overseen by two commissions, each including six representatives from the government and six from Renamo, and nine other citizens appointed by President Chissano after consultation with all political forces in the country.

Both the peace process and the elections -- the latter expected to cost some $ 80 million -- will depend on good faith from both parties as well asinternational assistance.

By last month, only 25 UN monitors and support personnel had arrived in Mozambique. Although there has been no decision yet on the total number of peacekeepers that will be authorized, there has been no proposal that begins to approach the commitment of personnel and budget allocated for Cambodia. With about half the number of people as Mozambique and less than a quarter of its area, Cambodia has a UN peacekeeping force of 22,000.

The U.S. State Department has expressed its view that the UN presence in Mozambique should be roughly the same as that in Angola -- less than 1,000 people, including both civilian and military personnel.

But the attempt to keep the Mozambique mission small is a gamble. Relief agencies are warning that without urgent action to see that the cease-fire holds and to get food delivered, much of rural Mozambique could become as desperate as Somalia. *


LOAD-DATE: November 12, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


256 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 9, 1992


Food Aid Keeps Millions Alive


LENGTH: 800 words


Jennifer Griffin for Africa News Service

Maqueze, Mozambique

Women and children in tattered rags emerge from the surrounding bush to watch as a Red Cross plane loads sacks of food from this Mozambique air base. Red Cross trucks shuttle back and forth across the sandy airstrip, filling the plane that will fly 62 miles (100 kilometers) north into an area held by the rebel movement Renamo.

In an old farm warehouse next to barracks for government troops, Red Cross aid worker Christopher Wieser has organized another food distribution, this one for people from nearby villages. "We have to feed both sides," says Wieser, whose organization is the only group delivering food to Renamo territory. 

Hundreds of barefoot, dusty people stand in the shimmering heat in a line that snakes around the warehouse. A man with a stick makes sure the crowd stays orderly. Waiting children play a cat-and-mouse game with him, laughing as he chases them away. A small boy in the line wears blue rubber boots. Although there's been no rain, the soles protect his feet from the hot sandy soil.

Women with babies strapped to their backs collect parcels that appear too heavy for them to manage on the long walks back to their homes. A few men wearing leather shoes stand alongside their wives and daughters, but even in those groups, women carry most of the loads. A blind woman with a walking cane hoists a bulging bag of corn meal onto her head without any assistance and heads back towards her village of Aito Changane, about a 5-mile (8-kilometer) walk away.

"Most men are in the army, in South Africa or dead," says Wieser.

The 16-year war waged by the rebel movement has killed over a million people and wrecked the country's infrastructure. Farmers were forced off their land by looting and attacks from both Renamo and government troops. Migrant work in neighboring South Africa is one of the few ways to earn income.

For many of Mozambique's people, a second year of drought has made an already desperate situation worse. Emergency food aid to the country has doubled this year. By the end of December, humanitarian groups expect to have distributed 400,000 tons of food to 3.1 million people, according to John Yale, director in Mozambique for World Vision, the California-based aid agency.

"As we speak, stocks are very low," says Joe Kessler of CARE, the U.S. agency that has coordinated the Mozambican government's relief effort. "But in the next five weeks, 160,000 tons are coming in."

The lack of an independent ability to sustain themselves has created almost total dependence on foreign aid. As though embarrassed by their plight, hungry people stream past aid workers, accepting their food parcels with barely a nod of acknowledgment.

"These people are ready to continue what they were doing before -- farming," says Felice Dindo, head of the International Red Cross operation in Mozambique. "But this drought is pushing everyone to the cities." Shantytowns built of sugar cane have sprung up in every urban area where food may be available.

Dindo and other aid workers say that without the devastation from the war, most Mozambicans could have survived the drought. Being forced out of their villages means not being able to take advantage of any rains that come this year. "It's useless to give people seeds when they have no fields," Dindo says.

Sometimes the Red Cross center at Maqueze runs out of food before everyone receives a ration, but there are no signs of panic among those waiting their turn. People here, within reach of help, are among the fortunate ones in this war-ravaged land. "They know there is food coming," says Wieser, who pays his employees food for their work. "We'll probably run out today, but they know there will be more tomorrow." *


LOAD-DATE: November 12, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


257 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 9, 1992


UN Monitors Have Tall Task


LENGTH: 1094 words


Jennifer Griffin for Africa News Service Maputo, Mozambique

Civilians are traveling again on Mozambique's main north-south highway, bringing coconuts and other goods to the capital. Leaders of the Renamo guerrilla movement, whose attacks once made the road impassable, now hold court in Maputo's beachfront bungalows, where they conduct poolside conversations with diplomats and journalists.

Tourists are returning to the renovated Polana, the posh hotel of the colonial era, whose broad green lawns and imposing facade have been restored to their former grandeur.

But the thin veneer of normalcy that has returned to the city is patchy, at best, in outlying areas. Since an October 4 cease-fire, signed in Rome by the leaders of Renamo and the Mozambique government, Renamo forces in the north of the country have seized at least five towns. Two of them, including Angoche, a coastal city of 200,000 people, have been retaken by government troops. 

Each side accuses the other of starting the hostilities. Renamo says government soldiers were moving into territory Renamo held when the cease-fire was signed. "We didn't violate the accord," says Laurencio Manque, a Renamo representative in Maputo. "We were just defending ourselves."

The government says Renamo is guilty of "systematic violations" of the accord as it tries to improve its position on the ground.

Hopes for a binding peace pact rest largely on United Nations special envoy Aldo Ajello, a 56-year-old Italian diplomat whose mission is responsible for organizing cease-fire committees, establishing assembly points for troops, and seeing that elections are held by next October.

It's a tall order, as Ajello recognizes. He arrived here on cease-fire day with a contingent of 20 military observers, for a country about the size of Texas and Pennsylvania combined. The peace pact specified that government and Renamo troops would assemble at 49 points "under the supervision and coordination of the United Nations" within six days of the signing. But there are not enough UN monitors to have even one observer at each site. Questioned about the cease-fire breakdown, Ajello replies with a wry smile that "the fighting is going very well."

Meanwhile, all the substantive issues of cease-fire implementation remain unresolved while the two sides bicker over housing arrangements for the Renamo negotiators who are due in Maputo. Anselmo Victor, the group's chief representative here, says the hotel rooms and the furnished, air-conditioned villas offered by the government are not good enough for Renamo leaders. He also says telephone services are inadequate.

"It's not about housing," counters Mozambican Minister of Transport Armando Guebuze, who has been the government's top negotiator with the rebels. "The central problem," he says, "is whether or not Renamo has decided to take any steps towards peace."

The charges and countercharges are reminiscent of 16 years of war since Renamo's founding by the white government of what was then Rhodesia, in retaliation for Mozambique's support of majority rule there. When Rhodesia became the independent nation of Zimbabwe, responsibility for Renamo shifted to South Africa.

Renamo now claims to be a self-reliant Mozambican group that is fighting for democracy. Internationally, as well as in Mozambique, that claim is viewed somewhat skeptically. The group's tactics of terror, intimidation and kidnapping have earned it a reputation for brutality on a massive scale. But the poorly trained and often unpaid soldiers of the government have committed atrocities of their own, according to human rights groups. Mozambique's 15.7 million people, mostly rural peasants, have been caught in the middle.

Their plight assumes a special urgency now, as a killing drought spreads across southern Africa. Although the region appears to have enough emergency food for at least the next few weeks, little can be delivered unless the cease-fire holds. An estimated 3 million people are totally dependent on food aid and may starve if the fighting continues.

Several incidents since the cease-fire have called into question Renamo's ability to impose discipline over the ragtag bands of fighters who government officials dub "bandits."

Late last month, a group of foreign journalists tried to accompany a Red Cross food airlift to the Renamo-held village of Ndindiza in Gaza province, about 125 miles (200 kilometers) north of Maputo. Although the trip had the blessing of Renamo's Victor, the reporters spent three days sitting in sandstorms at a rural Gaza airstrip, waiting for approval from local Renamo commanders before giving up and returning to the capital.

But amid the cease-fire violations, there have been some hopeful reports, especially from southern regions where the drought has hit hardest. In the town of Salamanga, for example, troops of both sides reportedly have been celebrating together, dancing and sharing beer and cigarettes. In the Gaza province town of Chipadja, Renamo soldiers emerged from the bush to request food from government soldiers, who gave them part of their own stores.

Mozambique state radio reported that in the north, in Zambezia province, a Renamo unit stopped an army-escorted relief convoy to ask for food. When they were given a few bags of corn, the radio said, they demonstrated their thanks by filling in craters in the road ahead. *


LOAD-DATE: November 12, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


258 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 9, 1992


Mozambique Accord Brings Hope of Peace


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Until the current crisis in Somalia, Mozambique has headed all recent misery indexes. During five centuries of Portuguese colonialism and the nearly two decades of war that followed, Mozambicans have been among the world's poorest people. 

Visitors to the fertile tropical nation on the Indian Ocean are struck by the contrast between the country's potential and its grim reality. Through the years, the country has attracted hundreds of young volunteer workers from Western countries who were drawn by the idealistic rhetoric of its Marxist government and the apparently unquenchable spirit of its people. But recent visitors comment on the air of desperation and discouragement that permeates everything.

In 1989, the ruling party abandoned its Marxist label and proposed constitutional reforms in advance of multiparty elections. The government appealed to the Renamo rebel movement, whose attacks had destroyed most of the country's few hospitals, roads, schools and churches, to give up its arms and join the democratic process. On October 4, after more than two years of peace talks in Rome, Italy, the two sides signed a peace accord.

After a brief lull, fighting resumed. The three articles here examine some of the challenges facing Mozambicans, as they try to give peace a chance. *


LOAD-DATE: November 12, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


259 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 9, 1992


United Nations Opens Mission to Aid South African Transition


LENGTH: 1000 words


Arthur Goldstuck * Weekly Mail Johannesburg, South Africa "Glass palace" was John Vorster's scathing term for it. And as little as a year ago, the idea of involving the United Nations in solving South Africa's problems was unthinkable.

Yet by the time the UN Observer Mission in South Africa (Unomsa) set up office in Johannesburg last month, it blended almost immediately into the South African political scenery.

"I think South Africans have adjusted exceptionally fast to the idea of transition toward a democratic society,' says Angela King, chief of the mission, in an interview at her office in Johannesburg's Carton Hotel. "The reaction to our arrival has been warm and welcoming." 

Jamaican-born King, who is 54, moved into the Unomsa hot seat -- her first UN post as a "field worker" -- from a position as director of staff administration and training in the UN office for human resources management. Before that, she was director of recruitment and placement.

Why was a personnel manager chosen for a peacemaking job? "You'll have to ask (UN secretary-general) Boutros Boutros-Ghali," she says, but adds that effective use of people's skills is as crucial in human resources management as it is in a UN mission.

She bristles at the suggestion that the mission is a "second division team," foisted upon South Africa because more seasoned observers were busy in other trouble spots. In part the perception arose because of the mission's small size -- 50 people compared with 800 in Yugoslavia.

"We have a clear mandate from the Security Council, she says. "The numbers of the forces and the nature of their deployment were left very much to the discretion of the secretary-general.

"The original team in Yugoslavia was (only) 30 strong. UN people also went to Namibia in phases. They started with probably 150 and then, as they established themselves on the ground, it went wider. By the time of the election it was 800."

King stresses that the size of United Nations missions are linked to requirements on the ground. In Namibia for instance, the UN was involved in everything from setting up electoral districts to training workshops on how to run an election. In Cambodia, by contrast, the UN was asked to move into virtually every government department and get the country running again.

The UN and the Security Council looked very carefully at the African National Congress' demand for 400 monitors, King said. The world body decided that because of the sophistication of the peace infrastructure in South Africa, observers, not monitors, were appropriate.

"In South Africa you have well developed structures. We will liaise with these structures and report back to the secretary-general on whether the UN mandate needs to be broadened.

"The decision was that the mission should be enlarged in a phased way. The Security Council did give the secretary-general the authority to deploy any amount of people, and a total of 400 has not been ruled out."

The delay in the arrival of the full UN team has fueled criticism that the demand for a UN presence in regional disputes around the world means it cannot give South Africa the attention it needs.

King heads a group that initially numbered 28 and was expected to reach 50 by the end of October. A third of the Unomsa team was to arrive from Angola at the conclusion of that country's first democratic elections. However, the dispute over the Angolan election results delayed their arrival here.

King is aware of suspicion of Unomsa in some anti-government circles, based on a perception that it works hand-in-glove with the authorities. There also has been criticism of the UN for allowing government security forces to provide mission members with transportation in certain cases.

"We've been at pains to be in touch with all parties involved in the National Peace Accord," she explains. "We have had offers of assistance not only from the government but from the major parties concerned -- for transportation, arranging meetings, and so on.

Unomsa's public assertion of its neutrality ranges from a liberal use of UN flags and stickers on its cars to a refusal to appear on platforms that are not part of the peace accord structures. The Security Council resolution that created Unomsa specifically requires the mission to "strengthen and reinforce the indigenous mechanisms set up under the National Peace Accord, so as to enhance their capacity in the building of peace," says King.

South Africa's network of peace structures, she says, offers tremendous hope for the future, because "so much work went into thinking out the structures," she says.

"We're here to try and help, by our presence, to defuse tensions which may prevent the transition to democracy. The structures are there and the means are there for it to happen." *

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.
