Africa News


NOVEMBER 9, 1992


Bishops Appeal for Action to End Sudan Deaths


LENGTH: 1494 words


Karen Gellen * Africa News Service United Nations

War and famine in Sudan will turn Africa's largest country into "another Somalia" unless the international community intervenes. That warning was brought to the United Nations by two prominent Sudanese bishops who say they are seeking to pierce a wall of silence surrounding a widening disaster.

Paride Taban and Macram Max, representing the Sudanese Roman Catholic Bishops Conference, are calling for strong international pressure to end their country's bloody civil war. In a meeting with UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, the clerics stressed the urgent need for a full-scale relief effort to avert widespread starvation.

Their alarm is being echoed by relief workers in Sudan. Jean-Luc Siblot, an official of the UN World Food Program, says the situation for the 5 million people in the south of the country, where the latest round of fighting has persisted for the past nine years, has "never been worse." Up to a million people now face death from hunger, he told Cable News Network late last month. Amid the mounting death toll, Siblot says, there is "chaos everywhere." 

Food has become a key weapon in the war between the government in Khartoum, the capital, and the rebel Sudanese Peoples' Liberation Army (SPLA), which controls large stretches of territory in the South. Relief flights to those in desperate need can only take place when clearance is obtained from both warring sides -- and each frequently has balked. Because of the war, private aid agencies are unable to maintain personnel in the embattled region.

Last month, three UN workers and a journalist died under still unexplained circumstances in rebel-held territory in the South. And the government is believed to have executed two Sudanese employees of the U.S. government and another employee of the European Community in Juba, the largest southern town.

The bishops charge that the Sudanese government's effort to impose Islamic fundamentalism on the country by force is leading to a form of "genocide." Max calls the government's practices a "shameful and degrading example of apartheid." Although the clerics charge the government's principal target is the mainly black population of the South, which largely practices Christianity or traditional African religions, the bishops stress that moderate Arab Muslims in the North "are also being persecuted."

According to Bishop Taban, who is president of the Sudan Council of Churches, the world is largely unaware of the disaster in his country. Much of the population in the South is "locked up as if in a zoo," he says. "But it's worse -- at least in game parks in places like Kenya, people drive by the animals in cars -- our people are never seen by any other human beings."

The most severely affected people, Taban says, are those trapped in areas under neither government nor rebel control. Their condition is appalling, he says. "Millions are isolated, reduced to wearing leaves from the trees. Many haven't tasted salt in 10 years -- they have been returned to the Stone Age. Thousands are dying of disease and hunger, and no help is allowed to reach them."

Vast numbers are homeless, living in camps as internal refugees, Taban says. In one small area just over the Kenyan border, the Sudan Council of Churches is caring for l6,000 Sudanese orphans between the ages of six and l5. And near the town of Torit, the bishops' parish, there is a camp housing 250,000 uprooted people.

The bishops say the government has systematically expelled foreign church workers who were aiding the population and is closing local Sudanese church parishes. "They are tightening the noose every day," says Bishop Max. "They have even expelled the sisters of Mother Theresa of Calcutta. In one case they ran a bulldozer right through a church."

The expulsions not only have thwarted relief efforts, but they also have removed foreign witnesses to the suffering and repression, the clerics say. At the same time, the government is recruiting other foreigners to fight in the South. Fundamentalist university students from Pakistan and Iran, says Taban, have joined what the Sudanese government terms a jihad, or holy war, in southern Sudan. He says: "There are Muslims in Juba now who have long beards and are ethnically unlike any Moslems we've ever seen in Sudan. They are fighting and playing a security role in special areas such as the university in Juba."

When the Sudan Council of Churches lodged a protest with the Pakistani government about the role of its citizens, Taban says, Karachi denied giving aid or official sanction to the fighters, whom it terms "volunteers" or "mercenaries." Taban says Khartoum is also receiving financial aid from the Iranian government and is using the money to buy weapons from China.

The bishops hope their visit to the United States will help build pressure on Khartoum to cooperate in helping stem the immediate suffering and, ultimately, to negotiate with the SPLA for an end to the war. They point with satisfaction to the resolution adopted a few weeks ago by the U.S. Senate that condemns the Sudanese government's "consistent pattern of gross violations of internationally recognized human rights."

The resolution demands that Sudan allow "unrestricted" and "unconditional access" to international relief organizations and guarantee the safety of aid workers. The statement condemns what it terms a "cruel campaign" to relocate some 750,000 internally displaced southerners and westerners from the outskirts of Khartoum to "inhospitable camps far from the city" and criticizes the government for forcibly displacing tens of thousands of Nuba-speaking people from their ancestral homes, destroying villages, and "killing hundreds of civilians."

"Now we finally have something in our hands," Taban says. "We're carrying that statement around like a newborn baby."

The bishop also welcomed last month's official pronouncement by the Vatican on human rights in Sudan. Pope John Paul II spoke publicly on the issue for the first time during a meeting with a delegation of Sudanese bishops. But the bishops want the church to take the further step of breaking off relations with Khartoum. While in Rome, Taban says, the bishops questioned continued Vatican contacts with a government "that is slaughtering its own people, because that kind of diplomacy means fearing a government more than fearing God."

The bishops say they hope their session with the UN secretary-general may boost their efforts to get a hearing in Khartoum. "We're very grateful to have had our photo taken with Boutros-Ghali," Taban says. "Now someone in the Sudanese government may give us an answer instead of simply throwing our letters in the trash."

At the United Nations, the bishops discussed efforts to open relief routes in the South with Jan Eliasson, the undersecretary- general for humanitarian affairs, who recently visited Sudan. Eliasson won the agreement of both the government and the SPLA for flights to 21 new areas, but large stretches of the region are still out of reach of aid deliveries.

In addition, Bishop Taban warns, a further destabilizing factor now pushing Sudan toward a tragedy of the dimensions of Somalia is the splintering taking place within the SPLA. In rebel-held areas, he says, the SPLA historically has provided a modicum of order. But the movement now is split into three contending factions, and this could be a prelude to the kind of deadly "warlord-ism" seen in Somalia, the bishop fears. *


LOAD-DATE: November 12, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


261 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 9, 1992


UN Strains to Settle Lingering Cold War Conflicts


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 880 words


Peacekeeping is not a new function for the 179-member United Nations. It was a central purpose when the organization was founded after World War II. But the demand for UN mediation of conflicts in Africa and elsewhere has reached an unprecedented level.

The resignation late last month of the UN's chief official in Somalia, Mohammed Sahnoun, is an indicator of the strains on the peacekeeping process. Currently, the organization has a direct involvement in five problem areas on the African continent and is likely to take a role in at least two others (see map on page 7). "We are stretching to get the troops and logistical support and to find the financial resources to insure that we carry out these operations effectively," says Kofi Annan, UN assistant secretary-general for peacekeeping operations. 

Twelve peacekeeping efforts have been undertaken by the United Nations in the past three years, as many as in the three preceding decades of the organization's existence. The easing of East/West tensions and the end of the Cold War has opened doors for UN peacekeepers that had been closed by big power rivalries. In Africa, where many of the Cold War's battles were fought, the cries for outside mediation are particularly loud.

This is a "propitious moment," a time when "carefully concerted intervention and carefully concerted assistance can produce results, says Olara Otunnu, president of the New York-based International Peace Academy. The "Cold War scaffolding" that kept unpopular regimes in place and fueled destructive wars has disappeared, Otunnu says, replaced by "conflict fatigue" throughout Africa.

Otunnu argues that the United Nations must be bold enough to seize the opportunity to promote lasting peace. "It has a Secretariat which has been honed to play this role," he says. "It has a Security Council that includes the major powers and provides the political back-up for the secretary-general. The United Nations is the only organization that can do this job adequately.

The crisis in Somalia has created special difficulties for the UN system. After a slow start, a relief effort has been gaining support and momentum and a new 100-day emergency plan has just been adopted. But many UN officials and ambassadors fear that Sahnoun's departure will set back the process at a crucial juncture. Interviewed in New York just prior to his resignation, Sahnoun emphasized the importance of "increased international pressure" on the warring factions and of a "fully coordinated approach" to ensure that all UN and private relief agencies "present a common front."

On a number of occasions, Sahnoun's outspokenness about the United Nations' failure to move decisively created tension within the organization. In an interview with the Washington Post's Africa correspondent, Keith Richburg, Sahnoun specifically criticized UN Undersecretary James Jonah, saying: "Jonah was the African in charge. He should have drawn the world's attention to Somalia."

Jonah has other critics within the UN system, and there are reports that he will lose his job in a budget-cutting restructuring that Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali is expected to announce soon. But the public criticism provoked a reprimand from Boutros-Ghali to Sahnoun, who resigned and was immediately replaced by Iraqi diplomat Ismat Kittani.

Despite the difficulties, Annan believes the United Nations is making progress in Somalia. "By the beginning of December, we hope to have 750 Canadian troops, 550 Belgian troops, 750 Egyptians and, eventually, 750 Nigerian troops, plus logistical units from as far away as Australia, New Zealand and India," he says. Including the 500 Pakistani soldiers already on the ground in Mogadishu, the Somali capital, the combined forces of about 4,200 should be able to secure the ports and airports and protect the deliveries of relief supplies to all parts of the country, he says. At the same time, the United Nations is seeking to promote a political settlement among all the Somali parties.

The Somali crisis has stimulated a reassessment of conflict resolution generally, says the Peace Academy's Otunnu. "For the first time, the issue is being looked at through a humanitarian prism and the issue of national sovereignty is no longer seen as automatically overriding," he says. In situations of "extreme suffering," the world community now seems more willing to intervene to help those in need. *


LOAD-DATE: November 12, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


262 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 9, 1992


VIEWPOINT--by Margaret Calhoun


LENGTH: 867 words


Angola's first election, which pitted areformist Soviet satellite regime, the MPLA, against Unita, a formerly U.S.-backed rebel insurgency, has been praised as free and fair.

The strong voter turnout proved the Angolan people's desire for peace and democracy. While it is accurate that the casting of ballots -- a process witnessed on a limited basis by international observers -- was relatively free and fair, it must also be said that the largely unobserved tabulation of these ballots may have been fraudulent.

On October 2, ten of 13 political parties fielding presidential candidates, including Unita, issued a joint declaration alleging fraud, which they warned could be a "catalyst for destabilization of the whole democratic process." 

The complaints stem from a fundamental problem in Angola's electoral structure. The MPLA-staffed National Electoral Commission (NEC) is in charge of processing and disseminating all electoral data and, in an evident conflict of interest, handling fraud complaints. The NEC was to have been supervised by the United Nations, but the UN admitted it had a severe shortage of resources to manage the election observation properly, including a lack of helicopters, aircraft and ground personnel.

The system had, nevertheless, a built-in verification mechanism: party poll watchers were permitted to verify the results, which were compiled and transmitted from polling stations to the 18 provincial capitals and then to the national capital, Luanda. Unfortunately, both the UN fraud investigators and opposition political parties have had difficulty accessing NEC computers. Further, NEC results reportedly were determined in some instances by tallies signed by poll workers and party monitors.

Other disturbing elements of the election include reports of stolen ballots, faceless voter registration cards, the sudden creation of some 100 "mobile" polling stations without the knowledge of party delegates, the circulation of surplus ballots, reports of Namibians crossing the border to vote, and a curiously large percentage of nulos, or nullified ballots.

These irregularities can and should be reconciled and resolved, but it is impossible to quantify the impact on voters of the MPLA's feared "anti-riot" police -- armed with Soviet AK-47 assault rifles and highly visible in Huila Province, where I was a monitor, and frequently near polling stations within the restricted boundary. We saw several examples of riot police engaged in both subtle and overt intimidation.

At one remote polling station outside of Lubango, which we reached after passing through a police roadblock, two armed policemen stood on the open road only 50 yards from the voting booth. At another site in Chibia, two polling stations were positioned one block from the local police station. In Luanda, the standard anti-riot police posture is a vertically held AK-47, forefinger on the trigger.

It is now clear that the MPLA does not want adequate international monitoring of a second round of voting. Instead, with the killing of top Unita leaders, the MPLA has reverted to its well-known Stalinist tacticts.

A summit between dos Santos and Savimbi has been delayed repeatedly, primarily because Savimbi's security could not be safegauarded in the capital. The murders of Unita officials proves that those concerns were justified. The United States must hold the MPLA responsible for the safety of Savimbi and the remaining Unita leadership.

The United States is Angola's largest trading partner, and the U.S. government spent approximately $ 250 million backing Unita with the purpose of forcing the MPLA Marxists to hold free elections. If a broad range of the Angolan political spectrum believes fraud was rife in the system, it is unlikely there will be the necessary political consensus to bring about the objective of U.S. policy toward Angola -- a peaceful democratic state. The only choice for the Angolans -- if the fraud investigation is a whitewash and no structural improvements are made prior to the second round of voting -- could well be a return to lengthy armed conflict. *

Margaret Calhoun is the senior Africa analyst at the International Freedom Foundation in Washington, D She was an accredited observer of the elections in Angola under the Angolan National Electoral Commission.


LOAD-DATE: November 12, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


263 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 9, 1992


VIEWPOINT--by William Minter


LENGTH: 1320 words


Just one month after enthusiastic Angolans voted peacefully in their first multiparty election ever, the war-battered country is again on the brink of all-out war.

Even if the rebel group Unita is persuaded to halt its current offensive, there may be months of uncertainty before a runoff takes place between President Eduardo dos Santos, who won 49.57% of the September 29 vote, and Unita leader Jonas Savimbi, who came in second with 40.07%.

Although Savimbi was persuaded temporarily to accept the official election results, which also gave the ruling Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA) a 129 to 70 margin over Unita in the legislature, he continued to claim the election was marked by massive fraud. He has signaled his willingness to use violence to ensure his preeminence, despite a lack of support from his former patrons in the United States and South Africa. 

Five days after the Angolan election, a peace agreement in Mozambique formally ended over 12 years of insurgency by the externally supported rebel group known as Renamo. But there, too, fighting resumed when Renamo launched attacks on government-held towns.

Millions of people have died in these two wars that were fueled from outside by South Africa's defense of apartheid and by the Cold War campaign against Maputo and Luanda. For the peace agreements to hold, the international community must take an active role in supporting the processes of peace and elections, as well as economic reconstruction.

The United States, which provided direct military support to Unita and tolerated South African backing of Renamo's terror campaign, bears special responsibility. It must support adequate levels of international involvement and help to restrain combatants who received outside backing from taking up arms again.

The Angolan and Mozambican situations are not identical. The threat in Angola comes from a megalomaniacal political leader with real political support among a minority of Angolans, who has demonstrated unwillingness to share power with his opponents or even with his colleagues. In Mozambique, the danger comes from a movement with an unparalleled history of brutality and from the coincidence of the worst drought in the 20th century.

But beyond the differences there is a striking similarity. In both cases, violent forces have been fostered from the outside. The United States must support effective sanctions barring any outside material support to parties violating the peace accords and should offer adequate military resources to those defending the integrity of the democratic process.

Renewed war in Angola would be a tragic sequel to what was, against great odds, an exemplary election process. Coming just 16 months after the May 1991 cease-fire, the Angolan voting faced enormous practical difficulties. Many roads are still mined; the country's population is almost 60% illiterate; and there has been large-scale movement of rural people since the last census in 1970. The country still has two separate armies, despite the peace accord proviso that the troops would be demobilized and a new national army created before the elections.

International support for the polling was minimal. An estimated 800 international observers were present, compared with 6,000 for the 1989 elections in Namibia, a country with less than one-fifth Angola's population. International ob-servers nonetheless were highly impressed with the orderly, cooperative and transparent organization of the election process. The National Electoral Council, which includes representatives of all parties, made an extraordinary effort to demonstrate openness and impartiality.

After careful study of all the specific complaints received, United Nations observers concluded that the elections were "generally free and fair." The U.S. State Department concurred. Nongovernmental observers also agreed.

Even Unita supporters among U.S. officials stationed in Luanda seem to feel that Savimbi has only himself to blame for the loss. His belligerent campaign, in which he often appeared in uniform armed with a pistol, was at odds with Angolan war-weariness, while dos Santos effectively projected a peacemaker image.

Angolan voters had many conflicting pressures: disillusionment with government economic failures, fear of war, traditional ethnic loyalties and fear in many rural areas of possible reprisals by one side or the other. But the balance tilted against Unita.

If there were unfair aspects of the election, they were structural and not readily apparent to short-term visitors. Minor parties correctly complained that they did not have a fair chance, despite equal television time allocated to all parties regardless of size. But in comparative terms they undoubtedly had a fairer chance than non-billionaire minor condidates in the United States.

The Luanda government did use the advantages of incumbency. But the most serious breach in fairness -- possible intimidation of rural voters -- probably aided Unita. Areas under Unita control were the most restricted and least open to campaigning by rival parties.

The international community, including the United States, has unanimously urged Savimbi to accept the election results. Angolans, including Unita supporters, are almost universally war-weary. But Savimbi and his closely knit group of top officers remain both unpredictable and militarily potent.

The Angolan government and most outside observers agree that there must be some form of participation in government, beyond its share of legislative representation, for Unita's constituency. But no compromise proposal can inspire confidence that it will be adhered to by both sides, as long as Unita is controlled by a leader hostile to democratic values.

In Mozambique, the history of Renamo's failure to adhere to agreements suggests that future violations are highly likely. Over the years of negotiations, the international community, including the United States, provided support for the Mozambican government and refused overt assistance to Renamo. At the same time, however, outsiders failed to bring significant pressure to bear on Renamo and its backers. There is legitimate concern in Mozambique that fighting will continue unless there is a major international effort to oversee compliance with the peace accord. *

William Minter is a scholar-in-residence at American University's School of International Service and associate director for education at the Washington Office on Africa. He participated in the International Foundation for the Electoral System's observer mission to Angola.


LOAD-DATE: November 12, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


264 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 9, 1992


Save the Peace in Angola and Mozambique


SECTION: VIEWPOINT


LENGTH: 320 words


Peace accords ending two of Africa's longest-lasting wars are being put to the test in the former Portuguese colonies of Angola and Mozambique.

An agreement signed last month in Rome by the government of Mozambique and the Mozambique Resistance Movement, known as Renamo, was breeched almost immediately by Renamo attacks on four district capitals in the north. The continuing fighting increases the threat of starvation for more than three million Mozambicans already experiencing famine from severe drought.

In Angola, disagreement over the results of late-September elections erupted in violence at the end of October, raising further fears that the country could be plunged back into civil war. A cease-fire was signed last year by the U.S.- and South African-backed National Union for the Total Independence of Angola (Unita) and the Soviet-backed ruling party, the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA).

MPLA led the September balloting, but Unita and other opposition groups have charged that the process was unfair. The clashes came amid reports that Unita had launched military offensives in several parts of the country. In Luanda, the capital, top civilian and military leaders of Unita, including Vice President Jeremias Chitunda, were killed in the fighting, with Unita accusing the MPLA of execution-style murders of its followers.

Diplomats from several nations have been working to bring the warring parties back to the negotiating table. On this page, two Americans who observed Angola's election present differing views about the causes of the conflict. *


LOAD-DATE: November 12, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


265 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 9, 1992


Dossier: Opposition Contests Results of Cameroon's First Multiparty Election


SECTION: FORUM


LENGTH: 2147 words


Observers Conclude Balloting Failed to Meet Standards of Fairness

Last month's election in the West African nation of Cameroon was a breakthrough.

For the first time since independence in 1960, Cameroonians were offered a choice of candidates on their presidential ballots. But when the official results showed President Paul Biya as the winner, with 39.9% of the votes, the opposition cried foul.

Now the country is locked in a stand-off. On November 3, Biya was sworn in for a third term. However, opposition leader John Fru Ndi is claiming to be the victor and his supporters have been protesting the government's actions. 

Prior to agreeing to hold the elections, Biya resisted calls for political reform, insisting until recently on the maintenance of the one-party system. However, continued domestic demands and pressure from international aid donors forced change, and the October 11 contest pitted Biya against eight opponents.

Large-scale demonstrations, like those that forced Biya's hand last year, have again become commonplace in the northwestern region, where Fru Ndi's backing is the strongest. The government has reacted by sending police to break up marches and by placing Fru Ndi and other opposition leaders under house arrest.

Foreign observers have concluded that the election failed to meet international standards of fairness. A multinational observer mission organized by the National Democratic Institute (NDI) in Washington, DC, has issued a preliminary report outlining the reasons for the negative assessment. The report follows:

On election day, the NDI observer delegation visited polling sites in nine of Cameroon's ten provinces. On October 15, four days after the election, the delegation issued a preliminary statement, which highlighted problems in the electoral process. However, the delegation withheld a final assessment of the process, pending release of the final results and an evaluation of the election-related complaints filed by various political parties.

Due to the close nature of the contest, the slow counting of the ballots, and the serious allegations of fraud and manipulation presented by opposition parties, delegation co-leader and former Maine Attorney General Jim Tierney remained in Cameroon for 11 days after the election. Mr. Tierney met with representatives of the political parties and the election commission and other knowledgeable Cameroonians. Mr. Tierney also sought to investigate specific complaints presented by representatives of several political parties. On October 23, the Supreme Court announced the official results, in which incumbent President Paul Biya was declared the winner of the election.

NDI notes several positive features of the election. In particular, these include a strong sense of civic duty on the part of the Cameroonian people on election day and the dedication of the many election officials and political party representatives who, under difficult circumstances, sought to conduct an open and fair election.

Nevertheless, NDI concludes that widespread irregularities during the pre-election period, on election day and in the tabulation of results seriously call into question, for any fair observer, the validity of the outcome. It would not be an exaggeration to suggest that this election system was designed to fail. While several parties were responsible for election irregularities, the overwhelming weight of responsibility for this failed process lies with the government and President Biya.

The evidence supporting this conclusion includes, but is not limited to, the following:

* The election was scheduled hastily by President Biya before the adoption of an election law. Once enacted, the law provided for a 30-day period prior to the polling, which was impossible given the date already set for the election.

* The election system provided civil administration officials responsible to President Biya ... with excessive discretion in matters of voter registration and ballot tabulation, which many officials abused to further the political interests of the incumbent president.

Tabulation of votes was conducted under the authority of the minister of Territorial Administration, whose partisan support for President Biya was unmistakable. In violation of the electoral law, the Ministry of Territorial Administration had originally decided to prohibit political party representatives from obtaining tally sheets of election results at the polling sites. While this decision was ultimately reversed, the electoral law did not provide an opportunity for party representatives to monitor the transfer of tally sheets to the departmental election commissions.

NDI has received direct testimony to the effect that prior to the elections, high-level government officials were told that their performance would be rated on the number of votes President Biya garnered in their respective areas. They were reportedly given a goal of 60% and told that this figure should be achieved by whatever means was necessary.

* The National Vote Counting Commission, which was appointed only days before the election, failed to inspire public confidence in the integrity of the tabulation process. The commission did not represent a geographic, ethnic, regional or political balance.

* Voter registration was needlessly restricted, as the registration process was not reopened following the announcement of the election date. This decision, in effect, disenfranchised the many Cameroonians who had boycotted the March 11 legislative elections.

* Little control was exercised over the distribution of voter registration cards, thus creating an opportunity for multiple voting and underage voting. Handfuls of cards were repeatedly offered to the observers as proof of a lively market in voter card trafficking.

In Maroua, a recently arrived subdistrict officer signed what were, by some accounts, 6,000 voter registration cards which were back-dated to appear to have been issued during the legally permitted registration period earlier in the year. Observers witnessed the distribution of these cards by opposition parties as well as supporters of President Biya.

In addition, voter registries were generally not published before election day, precluding the possibility that parties or voters could review the lists to ensure their accuracy. The NDI delegation observed or received complaints regarding numerous examples of voters whose names had been on the electoral list but who were not allowed to vote. In a number of provinces, would-be voters who had not been allowed to cast ballots showed observers voter cards that had been stamped at the time of the March legislative elections to demonstrate that they had been permitted to vote at that time.

* The election campaign was marred by the extremely partisan use of the government-controlled television and radio in favor of the incumbent president. The observer delegation's preliminary statement makes reference to this biased news coverage. The statement cited the television news broadcast on October 7, in which the government received 142 minutes of coverage, while only 12 minutes were allotted to the opposition.

* On election day, rules regarding voter eligibility were not uniformly applied. Through-out the country, the names of eligible voters were improperly crossed off the register.

* Polling sites were arbitrarily moved in some areas prior to election day in an apparent effort to sow confusion and reduce voter turnout in specific regions. Observers documented this problem in Yaounde, Maroua, Douala, Garoua, and Ebolowa.

* Political party poll watchers were prevented from entering polling sites and, in one case, were barred from entering the entire territory of Rey-Bouba in the district of Mayo Rey, which was controlled by a traditional leader who supported President Biya. The observer delegation noted other highly partisan acts by polling site officials in Yaounde and Maroua.

* "Ghost" precincts, i.e., precincts that did not exist on the official list distributed by the election commission prior to the election, reported overwhelming vote totals in favor of President Biya, contrasting dramatically with the results from other polling sites in the area. In Foumbat in the Noun Division in the West province, for example, ten polling places which did not exist on the official list of polling places were cited in a compilation of results forwarded by the subdistrict officer to the departmental commission. The results from these polling places provided overwhelming, and similar, vote totals in favor of President Biya, while the remainder of the area voted largely in favor of another candidate.

* Statistically anomalous results were reported from several polling sites. One example involved a polling site from the Mvila Division in the Ebolowa area, which reported a 100% turnout of 5,856 eligible voters, all of whom cast their ballots for President Biya. Similar, although slightly less extreme, examples were recorded in neighboring polling places.

* Undue delays in the release of the official results provided the opportunity for wholesale manipulation, while the failure to publish site-by-site results precludes the possibility of a credible, independent review of the overall election results.

NDI has an obligation to evaluate the election process in Cameroon using the same objective standards that it has employed in observing more than 40 elections throughout the world. In the case of Cameroon, the seriousness of the irregularities has been underscored by the chief justice of the Supreme Court, when he announced the official results, and by the minister of Justice in an interview with a Cameroonian newspaper.

In conclusion, NDI urges all Cameroonian political parties to pursue a peaceful resolution to the problems confronting the country. The divisions that have emerged as a result of the presidential election should not be allowed to reverse the progress that has occurred in Cameroon during the past two years.

NDI recognizes that the people of Cameroon are the ultimate judges of their electoral process. This interim report is a reflection of a growing consensus in Cameroon. NDI hopes that the views expressed herein will contribute to a better understanding, both inside Cameroon and around the world, of what occurred during this electoral process.

NDI urges all sides to come together in peaceful dialogue and to reach agreement on a course of action that will resolve the current impasse. A violent reaction by any of the parties or the government will tend to influence negatively the views of the international community toward the perpetrators. It is time for reflection, dialogue and negotiation among all Cameroonians. *


LOAD-DATE: November 12, 1992

NOVEMBER 9, 1992


King and Chief Minister Set for South Africa Face-Off


LENGTH: 654 words


 

King Goodwill Zwelithini, leader of the traditional royal family of the Zulu nation, appears headed for a confrontation with the ethnic Zulu administration established by the South African government.

Mangosuthu Buthelezi, chief minister of kwaZulu, has monopolized the headlines in recent years as a rival to African National Congress (ANC) leader Nelson Mandela. But King Zwelithini, whose role is largely ceremonial, commands strong loyalty in rural Natal province, which is also Buthelezi's power base. Although Zwelithini has appeared in the role of "head of state" at functions where Buthelezi presides, he has avoided political attachments. 

Now the king is backing traditional chiefs who are resisting Buthelezi's attempts to install his own handpicked leaders in northern Natal. The area, known as Babanango, is historically under the direct rule of the crown and in recent years has been administered by the king's cousin. When the cousin died in September, Buthelezi stepped up a four-year effort to appoint his own chiefs to administer Babanango.

Fourteen local leaders have filed suit against Buthelezi in the Durban Supreme Court, asking that the chief minister be stopped from imposing administrators without popular consent. Although King Zwelithini is not a formal party to the court case, he has let it be known that he favors the Babanango petition.

In recent months, as the conflict between supporters of the ANC and loyalists of Chief Buthelezi's Inkatha Freedom Party has grown more violent, the king has been under increasing pressure to take a public stand.

Last month the president of Contralesa -- the Congress of Traditional Leaders of South Africa -- told students in Natal that Zwelithini should start attending ANC rallies, as well as those of Inkatha. Zwelithini is king "of all the Zulus, including those who are members of the ANC," Patekile Holomisa said in a speech at the University of Zululand. Holomisa said the king could use the respect he enjoys to encourage a climate of political tolerance among Natal's warring parties.

Buthelezi has been dubbed the "leader of the Zulus" in news accounts and the ANC/Inkatha rivalry has been reported as an ethnic conflict. But a number of South Africans, including journalists, are challenging those labels. Writing in Britain's Observer newspaper, Allister Sparks says Buthelezi's claims to represent public opinion in Natal have never been proven. "Opinion polls are frustratingly inadequate," Sparks says, "and pollsters do not venture into strife-torn parts of Natal and kwaZulu."

ANC activists say that the 90% support in Natal cities for the group's strikes and "mass actions" suggests that Buthelezi's mantle of leadership was conferred more by the press than by the people. And they argue that the ferocity of the fighting in Natal, where almost all the victims are Zulu, is irrefutable evidence that the rivalry is political rather than ethnic.

Buthelezi, who has a reputation for supreme self confidence, recently implied that his own influence in Natal may be more limited than he has sometimes indicated. He told a reporter last month that the conflict is too bitter for anyone to curb, including himself or Nelson Mandela.

Enter the king? *


LOAD-DATE: November 12, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.

NOVEMBER 9, 1992


Ghanaians Give Rawlings Large Mandate at the Polls


SECTION: NEWS ROUNDUP


LENGTH: 414 words


Kwame Karikari * Africa News Service Accra, Ghana

When Ghanaians went to the polls on November 3 -- the same day as the presidential election in the United States -- they chose continuity over change. Flt. Lt. Jerry Rawlings, who took power in a military coup on December 31, 1981, had a margin of victory that was much wider than his opponents had expected.

Teams of international observers from the Carter Center in Atlanta, the Organization of African Unity and from Commonwealth countries, who monitored the process, rated it largely free and fair, although widespread irregularities were noted. Opposition parties are protesting the outcome and threatening to boycott the parliamentary elections scheduled for December 8.

Preliminary totals show that just under half of the country's 8.4 million registered voters took part in the nation's first election in 13 years. Rawlings received over 2.3 million votes (58.6% of the total) compared to nearly 1.2 million (30%) for his closest rival, Albert Abu Boahen of the New Patriotic Party. The former air force flight lieutenant ran well in several areas thought to be opposition terrain. While the Volta region, Rawlings' ethnic base, voted overwhelmingly for him, some of his rivals lost in their home areas. However, Rawlings is reported to have lost to Boahen in several military barracks. Rawlings resigned his military commission to participate in the election.

Rawlings' popularity stems both from his charismatic personality and from his government's success at achieving six straight years of robust economic growth.

Except for a few short-lived marches of jubilation by Rawlings' supporters on election night, Accra remained curiously quiet after the voting. A curfew was imposed in the northern city of Kumasi following post-election rioting, but party leader there called for calm pending the release of the final election report from the National Electoral Commission. *


LOAD-DATE: November 12, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


NOVEMBER 9, 1992


NBC's 'Today' Goes to Africa 12 Hours of Programming is a Network First


LENGTH: 1640 words


New York Tami Hultman & Reed Kramer * Africa News Service

Three years ago, five production teams from NBC's "Today" show were about to fan out across Africa as the advance troops for an ambitious campaign to cover the continent.

The bold plan to originate live from a different region every day called for a chartered Swissair jet to whisk host Bryant Gumbel across thousands of miles between each show. It was a grueling schedule -- and a costly one. And that was its undoing.

Extensive coverage of Chinese student protests in Tienanmen Square had sapped the show's news budget, and the executives of General Electric, which had recently bought NBC, were reluctant for the network to commit itself to a sizable expenditure for Africa coverage. "Their attitude," said a person who worked for "Today" at the time, "was: 'Who cares about Africa anyhow?'" 

As it turned out, Bryant Gumbel did. Although the idea was shelved, he kept it alive, going back to executives again and again. On Friday, November 13, viewers can see the result when the show goes on the air from Harare, Zimbabwe. During the week of November 16, the program's backdrops, in addition to Harare, will be the Hwange National Park and Victoria Falls.

In his New York office, nursing sharp back pains that he hopes will ease before the long flight to Africa, Gumbel is reluctant to expand on the problems of getting the project approved by NBC executives. "I'll allow this," he says. "They could always find a number of reasons why they should not take the risk, and on our part we kept coming to them with a budget that was difficult for them to swallow, because the cost of doing business in Africa is considerable.

"I would prefer to focus on the fact that we kept going back and redoing the budget and rethinking our game plan in order to find some way of representing the continent fairly and economically," he says.

Hosting the shows from one country rather than five was one of the economies. But half a dozen segment producers with camera crews have traveled widely in recent months, taping reports that will be used in the programs. Gumbel is pleased with the breadth and diversity of the pieces that will air. He says there were many stories he wanted to do and couldn't because of cost or logistical problems or safety factors. "But I don't want to belabor them," he says, "because the fact is the continent offered us so many possibilities that, while I may lose three dozen, five dozen stories, there are a hundred dozen that are still valid and do-able, so I don't feel terrible about it."

There turned out to be so many stories that the production team couldn't bear to exclude that the original five-day schedule was expanded to six.

Lynne Edwards, who works from NBC's London bureau, says the shows have been a welcome opportunity to do substantive journalism on Africa for a major television audience. "To be able to produce a report on women and desertification in West Africa for a program like 'Today' is fantastic," she says. But Edwards says that the serious reporting won't spell disappointment for viewers who are looking for exotic locations and fascinating topics. River journeys and a trip to the fabled Malian city of Timbuktu are among the show's destinations.

Filming among the cliffside villages of Mali's ancient Dogon people, whose sophisticated cosmology still confounds astronomers, Edwards says she felt the thrill of being in a place that few Western camera crews have penetrated.

Gumbel believes many viewers will be astonished as their images of Africa are eroded, and he sees that as one of the legacies of the series. It was Gumbel who argued, against some resistance, to use Harare, Zimbabwe's capital, as the setting for at least one of the shows. "It doesn't necessitate somebody being so crude as to say, 'We're here in Africa and, yes, that's a city, and it's as modern as wherever..." he says. "I think it's enough to have that as a backdrop for two hours. That's going to shock some people. I'm not interested in beating them over the head with it, but I think it's worthwhile to surprise them."

If there was a reason why the Africa shows are being done now, beyond the interest of some of the show's producers and Gumbel's own persistence, it is an accident of timing. Last summer's Olympics, for which NBC had the broadcast contract, occupied the morning hours, preempting what Gumbel calls "the assembly line of 'Today'."

"The problem with the 'Today' program," he says, "is when I say goodbye on a Monday, I'm 22 hours removed from the next show. And the line keeps running. That doesn't afford us the opportunity to go over and shoot the footage we would need. Having the Olympics this year allowed us to shut the assembly line down for two and a half weeks and created a very rare window of opportunity."

Gumbel acknowledges that the 12 hours of programming will not be all things to all people. "People who are experts on Africa are going to be able to walk away and say, 'Well, that didn't do anything; that was superficial.' And they'll probably be right." But his pride in the project is obvious, and he argues that for most of those who watch, the shows will mean a major advancement in awareness. "When you are working from ground zero," he says, "even two seems like a large number."

The scope of the programs is so broad -- ranging from art to missionaries to safaris to antiquities to archeological treasures -- that there may, in the end, be something for everyone. And the show's staff has made a genuine effort to probe the complex issues that govern contemporary African reality, such as AIDS, debt, the democracy movement and the role of women.

Asked what surprised him most when he finally got to Africa, Gumbel begs off answering. "You've got to understand," he says, "that I've been living with this project for years, and I have been trying to brief myself as much as possible."

For Gumbel, NBC's earlier decision not to go ahead with the project was a personal blow. But he didn't have long to think about it, because the "Today" show seemed to be falling apart around him. Reports of dissension among the staff and the departure of former co-host Jane Pauley sent ratings plummeting, and there was open talk in some quarters that Gumbel himself would be replaced.

Now, "Today" leads the morning ratings and the show's elated producers credit Gumbel with aiding the climb back to the top. Doing her share of the coverage, is current co-host Katie Couric, who will make her first trip to Africa to do this month's shows.

Unlike Gumbel, Couric cheerfully admits to being a total novice on African affairs; like most Americans, she still has a hard time sorting one African country from another. But the bubbling enthusiasm that helped attract viewers back to "Today" is near the surface when she talks about the Africa project.

One person who has worked on the series speculates that Couric's excitement when she gets to Africa may not do as much as the spectacular footage and dazzling graphics to infuse the audience with a sense of Africa's richness.

Gumbel says doing the shows has offered the perfect opportunity to inform while entertaining. "The pictures are breathtakingly beautiful," he says, and audiences will find the shows fun to watch. That's important, he says, because ratings are important. "Ultimately, it does not do us any good to do the most journalistically correct and worthwhile shows -- and have nobody watch them."

He says personal commitment to the project has been more complicated than his natural interest as an African American. "It's a question of fairness," he says. "I've originated programs from South America, from Europe, from Asia, from Australia, from New Zealand. The only one that hadn't been done is Africa. At some point you have to ask yourself, 'Why?'" *

Alice Sharpe contributed to this report.


LOAD-DATE: November 12, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


NOVEMBER 9, 1992


A Guide to the Complex and Growing Web of Armed Groups in Liberia


LENGTH: 520 words


The Economic Community of West African States Monitoring Group (Ecomog) -- A West African peacekeeping force sent to Monrovia in August 1990 by the Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas) to impose a cease-fire in the civil war. With soldiers from seven Ecowas member nations (Nigeria, Sierra Leone, Guinea, Ghana, Senegal, Mali and Gambia), the force has maintained order in the capital but has not been successful in plans to extend operations throughout the country, due to opposition from Charles Taylor. There were about 7,000 soldiers in Ecomog until recently when Nigerian reinforcements began arriving, pushing the total to an estimated 12,000 or more. 

National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) -- The group that launched the civil war with a small-scale invasion from Cote d'Ivoire on Christmas Eve 1989, with the aim of ousting President Samuel K. Doe. Headed by Charles Taylor, the NPFL controls most of the Liberian countryside and has established a provisional government, headquartered in Gbarnga, 120 miles (194 kilometers) northeast of Monrovia. At the height of the war in 1990, NPFL was estimated to have about 10,000 people under arms.

Independent National Patriotic Front of Liberia (INPFL) -- A breakaway faction led by Prince Johnson, a former top Taylor lieutenant who took part in the original NPFL invasion. This group beat the NPFL to Monrovia in September 1990 and killed President Doe. Last month, after Taylor's forces overran Johnson's base at Caldwell, just outside the capital, Johnson surrendered to Ecomog in Monrovia. Many of his soldiers are believed to have rejoined the NPFL.

Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL) -- The country's national army, encamped and inactive since Ecomog's arrival and Doe's death in late 1990. AFL soldiers, who were Taylor's main opponents during the 1990 war, recently set up their own roadblocks and checkpoints in the capital. The AFL has also joined in some of the fighting on the front lines outside Monrovia, alongside Ecomog and a rebel group known as Ulimo.

United Liberation Movement of Liberia for Democracy (Ulimo) -- A rebel group that emerged last year, made up of former members of Liberia's Armed Forces (AFL). Ulimo fighters launched an offensive against Taylor last August, saying force was the only way to make him disarm.

Black Berets -- The newest addition to Liberia's armed factions. This group of about 400 armed men appeared in the capital in the past few months after undergoing training in Guinea. Their role is unclear. However, the interim government calls them an anti-terrorist force that assists with VIP protection in Monrovia. They are named for the caps they wear. *


LOAD-DATE: November 12, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.


270 of 270 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 9, 1992


Liberians Cope With Worsening Conflict


LENGTH: 1787 words


Cindy Shiner * Africa News Service Monrovia, Liberia

A breeze carries the putrid smell of rotting flesh across the dirt road where the yellow carcass of a torched armored car lies idle. As gunfire breaks through the sound of buzzing flies and bird songs, the barefoot 72-year-old Rev. Samuel Jaia approaches with his family.

"Hello," he says cheerfully, putting down his little black briefcase and suitcase to speak with a reporter. He lets out a sigh, wipes the sweat from his forehead and smiles as if he is only having a hard day, instead of running for his life.

But it is clear that he and his wife, daughter and grandson left their home in a hurry, just as more than 160,000 others around Monrovia have done since fighting broke out last month. Wearing only tattered white underwear and a T-shirt, five-year-old James tightly grips a little green lantern, flip flops and a yellow plastic water bottle, his eyes wide with fear. 

"A lot of -- how do you call them? -- rockets fall around my place. Too much," says the pastor. "So, I say, well, let me try and go to my family to Logantown" closer to the city. The firefights have knocked out telephone communications, and he hadn't heard that most of Logantown is deserted because of the fighting.

An estimated 3,000 people -- mainly civilians -- have been killed in the siege of Monrovia alone since Charles Taylor's National Patriotic Front attacked the capital on October 15.

For two years, a West African peacekeeping force has protected Monrovia and the surrounding area, and the city's pre-war population of 600,000 has more than doubled. The ferocity of the current fighting has terrified Liberians who thought the West African coalition would keep the city safe.

Ruth Tshabalala, the World Health Organization's representative in Monrovia, says her team of 40 relief workers cannot even reach remote areas of the suburbs to pick up and bury the bodies because the task is too dangerous. She fears the decomposing corpses will lead to outbreaks of cholera.

Hospitals and relief centers in central Monrovia are jammed with families like the Jaia's. Some of the overcrowded facilities have problems with sanitation and are running short on medication and water. The United Nations has been distributing water by tank trucks, and a lingering rainy season has helped avert "a disaster," says UN Children's Fund representative Carl Tinstman. Relief workers are urging residents to collect rainwater when they can.

Other refugees have been stranded in rural areas since fleeing their homes last August when the United Liberation Movement of Liberia for Democracy (Ulimo) launched an offensive from neighboring Sierra Leone against Taylor's forces.

About 100,000 refugees, mainly from Sierra Leone, are in northwestern Liberia, cut off from assistance. Fighting and poor roads block relief workers from access to the area, and people are subsisting on the wild yams and fruit they can gather.

Johan Heffinck, of Medecins Sans Frontieres says there is a malnutrition rate of 43% among at least one group of 15,000 of the refugees -- a rate as bad as in Somalia.

Even in the capital, where West African patrols once inspired a sense of security, armed factions and thieves move freely. An interim government, sanctioned by the peacekeepers, appears powerless. At one shelter in the Monrovia suburb of Sinkor -- where shells launched by Taylor's forces and short-falling rockets from the West Africans land almost daily -- dozens of refugees swarm around a taxi carrying a foreigner, thinking money or food has arrived.

After the taxi pulls onto the street, three men follow the car and block its path. "Why don't you get out of the car and take a walk with me down the street? I would like to discuss some things with you," says one, inspecting the inside of the car and staring at a purse on the floor. Such confrontations are a routine hazard.

Some refugees themselves have resorted to stealing, but it's a risky way to get by. Liberians deal with thieves harshly: crowds chase them down and beat them, sometimes until they die.

The most brutal thieves are the country's various rebels -- with noms de guerre such as Ulimo Ninja and Captain Blood -- who storm into homes and businesses, shooting anyone in their way.

"Ulimo fighters did this to me! They almost killed me!" shouts Nazem Fawaz, a young Lebanese businessman, to relief workers and reporters on a crowded street. He pulled open his shirt, exposing a stitched, diagonal shoulder-to-belly gash. "I was watching the news and I hear a knock at my door. I ask, 'Who is that?' They say, 'Officers.' I say, 'What officers?' and they say, 'Open the door or we'll spray the door.'"

He says a rebel slashed him with a bayonet when he said he had no U.S. dollars. The soldiers stole most of his belongings and destroyed his home and business, he says. As he recounts his tale, two Ulimo rebels stand a short distance away, watching and listening intently.

Perhaps the most tragic victims in Liberia's war are its children, like five-year-old James, whose childhood memories will be of gunfire and terror. Late last month, the fighting trapped 300 orphans in Chocolate City, on the outskirts of the capital. Taylor's National Patriotic Front rebels stole their food and forced some of the children to fight alongside them, say orphans who managed to escape through the swamps to the Freeport area in Monrovia, where peacekeeping troops are based.

"They are catching some of the boys to go with them, to (carry) arms, but still we escaped," says an emaciated 14-year-old named Junior Juluto.

Most of the boys who were kidnapped have gotten away, according to relief workers, but the girls and babies are still trapped and have been without food for over two weeks. Fighting has obstructed United Nations efforts to evacuate the children.

Many of the orphans lost their parents in 1990, when civil war claimed an estimated 60,000 lives, including some 40,000 who starved. "I don't have nobody here," says Junior, at the American Cooperative School in Monrovia where he is housed with 22 others who fled Chocolate City. "I depend on the almighty God that I escape from there. I just pray to God to strengthen me. I just ask the Lord to bless me. That's all."

Many of the children who lost their parents and were separated from other family members are probably too young to identify themselves, says Myrtle Gibson, director of Liberian Children's Concern. "I don't think most of those children will ever see their families again."

Although foreigners once felt relatively safe in Liberia, no one is spared the current conflict, as the deaths last month of five American nuns demonstrated. "Missionaries have always, always been respected in Liberia," said Sister Barbara Brillant, an American nun from the Franciscan Missionaries of Mary, in an interview just before the killings. "Old people have been respected in Liberia. This is the first time there has been that loss of values."

The nuns were members of the Adorers of the Blood of Christ order, based in Ruma, Illinois.

Sister Brillant, who has spent 15 years in Liberia, conducted missionary and relief work behind Taylor's lines in 1990. When American jets flew over Taylor's territory, to evacuate Americans that year, rebels held a gun to her head because she was an American, and they thought the United States was going to attack.

She says she was able to talk her way out of being shot, using the street speech common among Liberians: "I say, my man, you wanna shot me, you shoot me. But you see my face in the plane? I'm not in the plane," she told her captors. "Today, it's a different situation," she says. It's harder to talk your way out of a mess.

During the fighting in 1990, soldiers from the national army of then-President Samuel K. Doe were believed responsible for the summary execution of hundreds of Liberians in the capital.

Now, for many Liberians, the nightmare of those days has returned. On a recent day along a back road near Monrovia's James Spriggs Payne Airport -- where many of the daily executions in 1990 took place -- one Liberian youth was seen trying his best to talk his way out of trouble with two soldiers. As one of the soldiers stopped a taxi carrying a foreign journalist and demanded to check the trunk for possible weapons, the other soldier kept his gun pointed at the youth.

Dressed only in his trousers, the boy fell to his hands and knees, begging and crying for the soldier to have mercy on him. The taxi was allowed to drive away, but the teenager had nowhere to run. *


LOAD-DATE: November 12, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1992 AllAfrica, Inc.
